In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Publisher's Introduction. Praise be to Allah alone, and peace and blessings be upon him after whom there is no Prophet, and upon his family and companions. To proceed: This is the book "Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab" by the virtuous Imam, the Muhaddith, Sheikh Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani - may Allah have mercy on him and dwell him in His vast Gardens. It comes out to its readers and lovers to see the light after decades passed while it was locked in the Sheikh's library, may Allah have mercy on him. The drafting of this book was completed in the year (1366 AH) - as we found it on the book's cover in the author's handwriting. This act by the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, is nothing but a practical lesson for those pseudo-scholars whom we have seen selling books to publishers that have not even been written yet; rather, they are merely an idea. Once they receive the known payment, they start gathering from here and there, collecting and inflating, until the cover becomes a volume and the volume becomes volumes, then after that, they appear with the appearance of verifiers and commentators and... so on of glittering, shiny words. And there is no power nor strength except by Allah. What appears to us is that our Sheikh, the Imam, did not finish this book, and that he reached where he reached in it before the year (1370 AH); as indicated by his opinion on the Palestinian refugees dwelling in mosques during the days of the Nakba (1948 AD), so refer to (p. 820) of this book. Thus; we do not need to introduce the merits and characteristics of this book; as they are clear to every reader - Allah willing -; except that we find ourselves compelled to mention some of those merits, so we say: The most important of them:
book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 1 - You find our Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, jealous for Tawhid with great jealousy since his upbringing, so you see him dedicating more than twenty pages here (pp. 357-380) to forbidding prayer in graveyards and mosques built upon graves. 2 - Despite the status that our Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, occupied, especially in the science of Hadith, we find him pious and scrupulous in the issue of authentication and weakening; so you see him - for example - seeking Istikharah (guidance) from Allah the Almighty in authenticating or weakening some Hadiths; as in (p. 543). 3 - You find our Sheikh - as in all his works - folding up the banner of fanaticism, fearless and unhesitating, spreading the banner of following the Imam of Imams, peace and blessings be upon him, until he became known for this and famous for it. 4 - You find our Sheikh honoring the Righteous Predecessors (Al-Salaf Al-Salih) since his upbringing, so he does not proceed with an opinion in which he has no Imam, as appears clearly here in (pp. 214, 628). 5 - You also find the opinion of our Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, in some few issues in this book different from the opinion he died upon, which we found in his later printed books; as in the issue of the impermissibility of approaching a menstruating woman who has become pure until she bathes (p. 54), so see his retraction in "Adab al-Zafaf" (pp. 125-129 - Islamic Office print), and as in the issue of the limit of a man's awrah (p. 246), so compare it with "Tamam al-Minnah" (p. 159). Likewise, you see him retracting the authentication or weakening of some Hadiths; as in the Hadith: "Whoever preserves the prayer..." coming in (p. 52), so compare it with "Da'if al-Targhib" (No. 312) and others. And that is a virtue that only one who fears Allah the Almighty in what he writes approaches, and does not care about people's talk; for the change of Ijtihad - for the known reasons

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: in this chapter - is the practice of the people of knowledge since Ijtihad arose among people. We must not miss pointing out that this book, in its beginnings, consisted of bullet points for issues recorded by the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him; as a reminder for himself of what he would address in his jurisprudential lessons for the youth in Syria in the past; therefore, we find him mentioning the edge of the issue, then the edges of the evidences or what points to them. Then it appeared to the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, to elaborate and author a book reviewing the issues with mention of their evidences from the Quran and the authentic Sunnah; therefore, we find him, may Allah have mercy on him, in the early parts of the book - and within the limit of some ten pages - mentioning the sources of extraction as symbols without mentioning the volume and page. Then after that, he began mentioning some chains of narration and discussing them, reducing the symbols and replacing them with names while mentioning the volume and page for those sources; except very rarely. And to facilitate for the reader, we mention here the meanings of those symbols used, and here they are: Symbol = Meaning ... Symbol = Meaning Kh = Al-Bukhari ... Ya'la = Abu Ya'la M = Muslim ... Tab = Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" Ham = Ahmad ... Tas = Al-Tabarani in "Al-Awsat" D = Abu Dawood ... Mas = Al-Hakim in "Al-Mustadrak" N = Al-Nasa'i ... Haq = Al-Bayhaqi in "Al-Kubra" T = Al-Tirmidhi ... Hab = Ibn Hibban in his "Sahih" Maj = Ibn Majah ... Khaz = Ibn Khuzaimah Mi = Al-Darimi ... Qat = Al-Daraqutni Taya = Al-Tayalisi ... Taha = Al-Tahawi

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Thus; let the noble reader know that our Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, used to return to this book of his from time to time, adding and deleting, refining and verifying - although the modifications were few; due to the crowding of the Sheikh's works -, and death overtook him before its completion. So we were keen to bring it out in the best attire, and we checked the printed version against the Sheikh's original, and we made it into two volumes; the first volume ends with (p. 514), and the second volume begins with (p. 515) and ends with (p. 851). We created various scientific indexes for it; to facilitate reference and to complete the benefit. Among them were an index of Hadiths and Athar (narrations) mentioned in the book, an index of men discussed regarding criticism and praise (Jarh wa Ta'dil), an index of strange words, and an index of topics and benefits. So we ask Allah the Almighty to benefit all Muslims with it, and to place it in the balance of our Sheikh's good deeds, and to write for us the reward of cooperation in righteousness and piety. And may Allah bless our Prophet Muhammad, his family, and his companions and grant them peace. 5 / Jumada al-Ula / 1422 AH The Publisher

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 1 - Book of Purification (Taharah) (1) 1 - Waters: (And We send down from the sky pure water. That We may bring to life thereby a dead land and give it as drink to those We created of numerous livestock and men) [Al-Furqan: 48-49]. Purity of Sea Water. Purity of water used in it. From Jabir: The Messenger of Allah came to visit me while I was sick and unconscious, so he performed ablution and poured his ablution water over me, and I regained consciousness (Darimi: 1/187) (Agreed upon). And in the Hadith of the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not expectorate spittle except that it fell into the palm of a man, who would rub his face and skin with it. And when he performed ablution, they would almost fight over his ablution water (Kh Ham). And similar meaning from a group. Hadith of Hudhayfah: (Indeed, the Muslim does not become impure) (Kh M). And in it: That he used to bathe with the leftover water of Maimunah. (M). Ibn Abbas: One of the wives of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, bathed in a large bowl, so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, wanted to perform ablution from it. She said: O Messenger of Allah, I was Junub (ritually impure). He said: (Indeed, water does not become Junub). Authentic. Chosen by Ibn Taymiyyah (3) in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) and in (Majmu' al-Rasa'il) (2/217) (Ham D N T: Sahih - Maj Mas Qat Khaz). And the prohibition of it is for dislike (Tanzih). (Let none of you bathe in stagnant water while he is Junub) (M), and that is due to repulsiveness. And like it and uglier than it is urinating
foot_note: 1. (1) The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, wrote at the top of this page: (Bullet points about the issues that will be discussed in our upcoming lessons, Allah willing)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: in it: (Let none of you urinate in stagnant water that does not flow, then bathe in it). (Kh): (Then bathe from it). (1) (M and others): (Then perform ablution from it) (T). And it is pure water that is not made impure by anything as long as it does not change due to impurity. And this was chosen by Ibn Taymiyyah (3) and in (Majmu' al-Rasa'il) (2/217). 2 - Leftover water of animals: If a dog licks, spill it. The cat: It is not impure. 3 - Purifying Impurities: Feces. Urine of a human. Dung of horses, mules, and donkeys. Blood and Madhy (pre-seminal fluid). Purification is mostly by water. For purifying blood and what resembles it, Asma bint Abi Bakr said: A woman came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: One of us gets menstrual blood on her garment, what should she do? He said: (Scrape it, then rub it with water, then wash/sprinkle it, then pray in it) (Agreed upon). And the impure earth is purified by pouring abundant water over it as in the Hadith of the Bedouin, and by the sun and wind if no trace of impurity remains, and this is the choice of the Sheikh (11). And the vessel which a dog has licked is purified by washing it with water seven times and rubbing it once with dust. And what is affected by Madhy and the urine of a nursing boy is purified by sprinkling and spraying, and the first is the choice of the Sheikh (15) excluding the urine of the girl. And the sandal is purified by wiping it on the ground. And the hide
foot_note: 1. (1) It was said: His prohibition, peace and blessings be upon him, of urinating in stagnant water does not indicate that it becomes impure merely by urination, as there is nothing in the wording to indicate that; rather, his prohibition might be because urination is a means to making it impure, for if this one urinates and that one urinates, it changes due to urine, so his prohibition was blocking the means. Sheikh al-Islam (Al-Fatawa).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: by tanning, even if it is a pig's hide. And impurity is purified by transformation (Istihalah), and this was chosen by Sheikh al-Islam (14) and Ibn al-Qayyim in (Al-Ighathah). See the invalidity of the distinction between small and large amounts of impurity in (Tafsir al-Qurtubi) (8/263) and in (Tafsir Ibn) (1) (1/416). Purity of the dead animal's hair and wool in (Ahkam al-Quran) by Al-Jassas (1/140-141) and Fatawa al-Subki (1/139). 4 - Utensils: It is prohibited to use gold utensils due to his saying: These two are forbidden... etc. As for silver, play with it [as you wish]. It is prohibited to eat or drink from them. It is permissible to use a vessel that has a silver chain for need (Hajah) based on text, or gold by analogy - in place of the crack. And the jurists meant by 'need' here that one needs that specific form as one needs mending and the clasp, whether it is of silver, copper, iron, or other than that, and they did not mean that one needs it specifically to be silver. (Fatawa Sheikh al-Islam) (2/353). It is recommended to cover utensils: (Cover the vessel - and he added in a narration: and mention the name of Allah over it, even if you place a stick across it - and tie the waterskin, for indeed in the year there is a night in which an epidemic descends) (Muslim, and the addition is agreed upon, and (Mushkil al-Athar) (2/20-21)).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And it is permissible to use the utensils of disbelievers, for it is authentic that he, peace and blessings be upon him, performed ablution from the waterskin of a polytheist woman (Agreed upon). Jabir said: We used to raid with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and we would acquire the utensils and waterskins of the polytheists and enjoy using them, and he would not criticize that against them. (D (2/148) Ham (3/379) with a good chain). However, if eating pork is predominant among them and they do so openly, then it is not permissible to use them unless no others can be found; then it becomes obligatory to wash them. Abu Tha'labah Al-Khushani said: I said: O Prophet of Allah, indeed our land is a land of People of the Book, and they eat pork and drink wine, so what should I do with their utensils and pots? He said: (If you do not find others, then wash them and cook in them and drink) (Ham 4/194) Mas (1/143), and it is authentic according to their conditions. It has another path in (D: 2/148) with a soft chain. 5 - Relieving Oneself (Takhalli). What to say upon entering and exiting. When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, entered the toilet, he would say: (O Allah, I seek refuge in You from male and female devils [Al-Khubth wal-Khaba'ith]) (The Group). The command for it is established in (D Maj Taya Ham Mas), so one should be attentive to it. And when he exited, he said: (Gufranaka / Your Forgiveness) (The Five except Al-Nasa'i), and it is the most authentic Hadith. (Ilal) (1/43). And he would not relieve himself while traveling until he disappeared so he could not be seen (Maj D). And perhaps he would go as far as two miles (Ya'la Tab). And he would screen himself for the need with elevated ground (Sadaf - any elevated structure, sand dune, or mountain) at times, and with a cluster of palm trees at times (Ha'ish: Palm trees wrapped together,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: as if due to their density they enclose one another. Nihayah). Narrated by Muslim, Ham, and Maj. He, peace and blessings be upon him, used to urinate while sitting and sometimes standing (The Group), and the intent is safety from splashback; whichever achieves that is obligatory. If someone greeted him while he was urinating, he would not reply until he finished. From Al-Muhajir bin Qunfudh, that he came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was urinating and greeted him, but he did not reply to him until he performed ablution, then he apologized to him saying: 'I disliked mentioning Allah the Almighty except in a state of purity (or purification).' (D N Maj Hab M) and proof of permissibility is that he used to remember Allah at all times (D T Maj Ham). 6 - Prohibitions: He forbade facing or turning one's back to the Qiblah while relieving oneself (M Ham) without differentiation [between open space and buildings], and this is the choice of Ibn Taymiyyah (5). And [he forbade] cleaning oneself with the right hand, and [using] dung and bones (The Five except Al-Tirmidhi), and relieving oneself in people's path or in their shade (M D Ham). And in Al-Mawarid (D Maj Mas Haq from Mu'adh and Ham from Ibn Abbas). And [he forbade] urinating in a hole (D N Mas Haq Ham) and in stagnant water as previously mentioned, and in flowing water based on text (Tas), and in his bathing place (N Maj T Ham Mas) or washing place (D N Mas). And [he forbade] cleaning oneself with less than three stones, and cleaning oneself with a bone (M D T) and he said: It is the food of the Jinn. Likewise, he said regarding dung (M Ham Kh). And [he forbade] getting urine on clothes etc., and said: (Most of the punishment of the grave is from it). He used to clean himself with water at times (Agreed upon) and with stones at times (Kh). And regarding it was the revelation of His saying: (In it are men who love

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: to purify themselves) [Al-Tawbah / 108]. See number (35) of (Sahih Abi Dawood). 7 - Ablution (Wudu). Its obligation: (O you who have believed, when you rise to [perform] prayer, wash your faces and your forearms to the elbows and wipe over your heads and wash your feet to the ankles) [Al-Ma'idah / 6]. (Allah does not accept a prayer without purification) (The Group except Kh). He used to perform ablution for every prayer (Kh 4) and he said: (Were it not that I would burden my nation, I would have ordered them to use the Siwak with every prayer and with every ablution). Narrated by Ahmad with an authentic chain as in (Al-Muntaqa), and Ahmad narrated it (2/258-259) via Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah from Abu Hurairah. This is a Hasan chain. See (Targhib) (99). Obligation of Intention. Its description: Siwak. The Basmalah: (Perform ablution in the name of Allah) (1). Washing the hands three times, which is Sunnah. Rinsing the mouth (Madmadah), sniffing water into the nose (Istinshaq), and blowing it out (Istinthar), which are obligatory. He used to combine rinsing the mouth and sniffing water, taking half a handful for his mouth and half for his nose. He would sniff water with his right hand and blow it out with his left. He commanded exaggeration in sniffing water (unless you are fasting). Washing the face is obligatory, and it is recommended to run fingers through the beard. Washing the arms including the elbows. And he commanded running fingers [between fingers/toes]. Wiping the entire head is obligatory, and its form is to wipe his hands
foot_note: 1. (1) As for the addition: (Wal-Hamdu Lillah / And praise be to Allah) as came in the book (Al-Salah) by Ansar al-Sunnah and (Al-Din Al-Khalis) (1/228), it is not authentic, even if Al-Haythami declared it Hasan and those who were deceived by him were deceived. See (1171) of (Al-Mu'jam Al-Saghir).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: over the front of his head, then move them to his nape, then return them to the place where he started. It is recommended to wipe three times. It suffices to wipe part of it if he continues over the turban, and it suffices to wipe over the turban. Wiping the ears is recommended with the water of the head. Washing the feet is obligatory up to the shins, and woe to the heels from the Fire, and one should run the pinky of the right hand between the toes during ablution and in everything. And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (When you dress and when you perform ablution, begin with your right side) (D 1/187) with an authentic chain. He used to perform ablution once [for each limb], twice, or thrice. He said: (Whoever increases upon this has done wrong, transgressed, and oppressed). It is recommended to say after finishing: (I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, having no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger. O Allah, make me among the repentant and make me among the purified) (See Majallat Al-Manar 16/670 for he has an error here). Or (Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise, I bear witness that there is no god but You, I ask Your forgiveness and I repent to You). Permissibility of Assistance in Ablution. Ablution for one who wants to sleep: (If you come to your bed, perform your ablution for prayer, then lie on your right side, then say...). Ablution for the Junub if he wants to return [to intercourse]: (If one of you comes to his wife then wants to return, let him perform ablution) (M 4, Ham). And if he wants to eat (M Ham), and sometimes he restricts himself to washing hands (N Ham: Sahih).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And this is emphasized for him if he wants to sleep while Junub. And ablution upon every Hadath (minor impurity) due to the Hadith of Buraydah bin Al-Husaib, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, woke up one day and called Bilal, saying: (O Bilal, by what did you precede me to Paradise? I entered Paradise and heard your footsteps in front of me). Bilal said: O Messenger of Allah, I have never given the Adhan except that I prayed two Rak'ahs, and I never had a Hadath except that I performed ablution upon it. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Because of this). Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his (Sahih) and (T Mas Ham: Sahih based on M). See (Al-Targhib) (1-99). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (And none preserves ablution except a believer) (Mas Ham Tab: Sahih). And see (Al-Fatawa) (2/424-425). Ablution before Ghusl (Ritual Bath). Ablution for the one who carries a dead person due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Whoever washes a dead person, let him bathe, and whoever carries him, let him perform ablution). Narrated by Al-Tayalisi (305) and Ahmad (2/454) via Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah from Abu Hurairah. This is a Hasan chain according to some opinions, and Mawla Al-Taw'amah, who is discussed, is not alone in narrating it. For Ahmad narrated it (2/272) from Ibn Jarir (1): Suhail bin Abi Salih told me, from his father, from Abu Hurairah with it. This is an authentic chain according to Muslim's condition. Sufyan opposed him and said: From Suhail bin Abi Salih from his father from Ishaq Mawla Za'idah from Abu Hurairah with it. Narrated by Abu Dawood (2-63), inserting between Abu Salih and Abu
foot_note: 1. (1) And Abdul Aziz bin Al-Mukhtar followed him from Suhail. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and he said: A Hasan Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Hurairah, Ishaq Mawla Za'idah, and he is trustworthy from Muslim's narrators as in (Al-Taqrib). So the chain is in any case meeting his condition, whether Abu Salih heard it from Abu Hurairah directly or through the medium of this Ishaq. And it has a third path: Ibn Abi Dhi'b also narrated it from Al-Qasim bin Abbas from Amr bin Umair from Abu Hurairah with it. Narrated by Abu Dawood (2-62) and from him Ibn Hazm (2/23), and its narrators are narrators of the Sahih except this Amr bin Umair, for he is unknown as in (Al-Taqrib). And it has a fourth path narrated by Ibn Hazm (1/250, 2/23) Hammad bin Salamah from Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah bin Abd al-Rahman bin Awf from Abu Hurairah with it. This is a Hasan chain. In summary, the Hadith is authentic without doubt, even if it has been discussed. 8 - Wiping over the Khuffs (Leather Socks). This is established from him, peace and blessings be upon him, by way of Tawatur, and it is authentic that he wiped after the revelation of the verse of Al-Ma'idah: (O you who have believed, when you rise to [perform] prayer) [Al-Ma'idah / 6]. It is interpreted by the Sunnah according to the recitation of Khafd (genitive case), so the intent is wiping over the Khuffs, and Ibn Taymiyyah inclined to this in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) (8). It is permissible to wipe over them even if they are torn as long as the name applies to them and walking in them is possible, due to the generality of the Lawgiver. Sheikh al-Islam detailed this in (Al-Fatawa) (1/257-263).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He used to wipe while traveling and while resident. He set the time for the resident as one day and night, and for the traveler as three days and their nights, if he purified himself and then put on his Khuffs, as in the Hadith of Abu Bakrah in Al-Daraqutni (71) with a Hasan chain. The period of wiping starts from the time he wipes until the same time the next day, which is the opinion of Ahmad as in (Masa'il Abi Dawood) (10). The period of wiping is not timed for the traveler for whom engaging in removing and wearing is difficult, such as the courier dispatched in the interest of Muslims, and the story of Uqbah bin Amir is interpreted upon this. Sheikh al-Islam said this in his (Ikhtiyarat) (9). The story referred to is what Al-Daraqutni narrated (72) via Ali bin Rabah from Uqbah who said: I went from Sham to Medina on Friday, entered Medina on Friday, and entered upon Umar bin Al-Khattab - added in a narration: wearing two Khuffs from those thick Khuffs - so he said: When did you put your Khuffs on your feet? I said: On Friday. He said: Did you take them off? I said: No. He said: You hit the Sunnah. Al-Daraqutni said: It has an authentic chain. Sheikh al-Islam said in (Al-Fatawa) (1/259): And it is an authentic Hadith. It is as they said. See the detail in (Al-Fatawa) also (2/188-189). I say: The Hadith was narrated in (Al-Mukhtara) (1/93) with this wording. And in a narration: (You hit) without (the Sunnah), he said: It is the preserved one. He used to wipe the top of the Khuffs, and absolute wiping suffices for it. It is preferable for everyone according to his foot. So the wearer of the Khuff may wipe over it

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and not remove them, following his example, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions. And for the one whose feet are uncovered is washing. One should not seek to wear them just to wipe over them. He, peace and blessings be upon him, used to wash his feet if they were uncovered and wipe if he was wearing Khuffs. Sheikh al-Islam in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) (8). Then he said: (9): The ablution of the one wiping over the Khuff and the turban is not broken by removing them nor by the expiration of the period, and this was said by Ibn Hazm (2/80-84 and 97). Nor is he obliged to wipe his head or wash his feet, and it is the school of Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, Ibn Abi Layla, and Dawud as in (Al-Muhalla) (2/94), like removing the hair that was wiped over, according to the correct view of Ahmad's school and the opinion of the majority. Al-Tahawi narrated (1/58) from Shu'bah from Salamah bin Kuhail from Zabyan that he saw Ali perform ablution and wipe over his sandals then enter the mosque, take off his sandals, then pray. This is a very authentic chain. 9 - Wiping over the Jawrabayn (Socks/Stockings). It is established from him, peace and blessings be upon him, that he wiped over the socks, and it is an authentic Hadith; whoever faults it has no proof. Abu Dawood said after narrating it: This was also narrated from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he wiped over the socks, but it is neither connected nor strong. Al-Tahawi narrated it (1/58). Abu Dawood said: Ali bin Abi Talib, Abu Mas'ud, Al-Bara' bin Azib, Anas bin Malik, Abu Umamah, Sahl bin Sa'd, and Amr bin Hurayth wiped over the socks. And that was narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab and Ibn Abbas. Socks are like Khuffs in wiping as Said bin Al-Musayyib and others said, as in

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Al-Muhalla) (2/86), so they have their ruling. It is not a condition that they be leather-soled nor that they stay up by themselves; therefore, Ahmad stated that it is permissible to wipe over socks even if they do not stay up by themselves; rather, if they are held up by sandals, it is permissible to wipe over them, as Sheikh al-Islam transmitted in (Al-Fatawa) (1/262). Based on this, it is permissible to wipe over thin socks if they are fastened with an elastic band as is used today. Ibn Hazm stated explicitly (2/81) the permissibility of that even if it is of silk for a woman specifically. It is also established that he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to wipe over sandals (Na'layn). Abu Dawood narrated it from the Hadith of Al-Mughirah, then Ahmad narrated it (4/9 and 10) from the Hadith of Aws bin Abi Aws, and likewise Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), both via Hammad bin Salamah and Sharik, both from Ya'la bin Ata from Aws bin Abi Aws who said: I saw my father one day perform ablution and wipe over the sandals. I said: Do you wipe over them? He said: Thus I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, do. This is an authentic chain. Abu Dawood narrated it via Hushaym from Ya'la bin Ata from his father: Aws bin Abi Aws Al-Thaqafi told me that he saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, come to the reservoir of a people, perform ablution, and wipe over his sandals and feet. This contradicts the first in chain and text:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: As for the first, he made it from the Musnad of Aws and inserted Ata Abu Ya'la between him and Ya'la bin Ata. As for the text, he added in it: 'and his feet.' Ahmad narrated it (4/8) via this way without his saying: 'and wiped over his sandals and feet.' The first narration is more authentic to me due to the agreement of two trustworthy narrators on it: Hammad and Sharik, while their opponent - Hushaym - engages in much Tadlis (concealing defects in the chain) as in Al-Taqrib, and he used 'An' (from) in it. Ahmad (1/148) and Al-Darimi (1/181) narrated it from the Hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said - and the context belongs to the first -: Abu Nu'aym told us: Yunus told us from Abu Ishaq from Abd Khayr who said: I saw Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, perform ablution and wipe over the sandals, then he said: Were it not that I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, do as you saw me do, I would have thought that the bottom of the feet was more deserving of wiping than their top. This is an authentic chain. Al-A'mash followed him from Abu Ishaq with the wording: I used to think that the bottom of the feet was more deserving of wiping than their top until I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, wiping their top. Narrated by Ahmad (1/114, 124). It seems some narrators abbreviated the mention of the sandals from it, so it is interpreted as wiping over the sandals based on the evidence of the first narration. Likewise, Al-Suddi narrated it from Abd Khayr similarly, and in it: And he wiped over his sandals then said: Thus is the ablution of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, for the pure one as long as he does not have Hadith (impurity).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Ahmad (1/120) from Sufyan from him. However, Ahmad also narrated it (1/116) via Sharik from Al-Suddi with it with the wording: And he wiped over the top of his feet then said: This is the ablution of one who has not had Hadith. Then he said: Were it not that I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, wipe over the top of his feet, I would have thought that their bottoms were more deserving. It is said regarding this what we said about the narration from Abu Ishaq, especially since Sharik has poor memory, so the narration of Sufyan from Al-Suddi is more authentic. Moreover, Ibn Abd Khayr followed him from his father with the wording: So he washed the tops of his feet and said: Were it not that I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, washing the tops of his feet, I would have thought that their bottoms were more deserving of washing. Narrated by Ahmad also (1/124) via Ishaq bin Ismail: Sufyan told us from Abu Al-Sawda' from Ibn Abd Khayr. Then he said: Ishaq told us: Sufyan told us once again saying: I saw Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, perform ablution and wipe over their tops. This is an authentic chain. Abu Al-Sawda's name is Amr bin Imran and Ibn Abd Khayr's name is Al-Musayyib; both are trustworthy. So all these narrations are interpreted by the first narration, otherwise, by their appearance, they would be an argument for the Shi'a. As for the other narration in Ahmad also (1/139, 144, 159) via Abdul Malik bin Maisarah from Al-Nazzal bin Sabrah that he witnessed Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, pray Zuhr then sit in the courtyard for people's needs. When Asr arrived, a vessel was brought, so he took a handful of water and wiped his hands, arms, face, head, and feet... the Hadith. It is interpreted as

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: washing, based on the evidence that 'wiping' was used in this narration for all limbs, and that is not permissible by the agreement of Muslims. It says in (Al-Nihayah): Wiping can be wiping with the hand or washing. The chain of this narration is authentic on the condition of Al-Bukhari. This, and the Hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding wiping over the sandals was also narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah and Ahmad bin Ubaid Al-Saffar as in (Nayl Al-Awtar) (1/158). In the chapter, there is [a report] from Ibn Abbas in Ibn Hibban and Al-Bayhaqi as in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) by Sheikh al-Islam (8), and from Anas in Al-Bayhaqi. I say: Al-Dawlabi narrated it in (Al-Kuna) (2/96) from Humyan bin Thumamah Al-Zamani who said: Rashid Abu Muhammad Al-Hammani told me, saying: I saw Anas bin Malik perform ablution and wipe over his sandals and pray. This Humyan, I did not find anyone who mentioned him, while the rest of its narrators are trustworthy. Wiping over them is established from Ibn Mas'ud and from Amr bin Hurayth. Al-Tabarani narrated both in (Al-Kabir); the chain of the first has narrators who are deemed trustworthy, and the other has trustworthy narrators as in (Al-Majma'). Al-Awza'i held the permissibility of wiping over them, as did Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla) (2/103). So the statement of Sheikh al-Islam in (Al-Fatawa) (1/266) that (It is not permissible to wipe over them by the agreement of Muslims) is refuted by what we mentioned. It is strange that he interpreted wiping here as sprinkling (Rash), while mentioning in another place: (The

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: foot has three states: Being uncovered warrants washing, which is the highest rank. Being covered warrants wiping. And an intermediate state, which is in the sandal; it is neither permissible to wipe nor is it exposed to necessitate washing, so it was given an intermediate state which is sprinkling. Where the term 'wiping' is applied to it in this state, the intent is sprinkling. Sprinkling over sandals and wiping over them has been reported in (Al-Musnad) from the Hadith of Aws bin Abi Aws. And Ibn Hibban and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas). Thus in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) (8). Yet there is no mention of sprinkling in any of these Hadiths, neither in the Musnad nor elsewhere from the Hadith of Aws bin Abi Aws nor from the Hadith of others. Unless it is in another Hadith from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: O Ibn Abbas, shall I not perform for you the ablution of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him? I said: Yes - may my father and mother be your ransom. He said: So a vessel was placed for him, he washed his hands, then rinsed his mouth, sniffed water, and blew it out. Then he took water with his hands and splashed his face with them, inserting his thumbs into the front of his ears. He said: Then he repeated that three times. Then he took a handful of water with his right hand and poured it on his forehead, letting it run down his face. Then he washed his right hand to the elbow three times, then his other hand likewise. Then he wiped his head and ears from their backs. Then he took water with his palms and splashed it on his feet while they were in the sandal, then he turned it (the foot/sandal) with it, then on the other foot likewise. He said: So I said: And in the sandals? He said: And in the sandals. I said: And in the sandals? He said: And in the sandals. I said: And in the sandals? He said: And in the sandals. Narrated by Imam Ahmad (1/82-83) from Muhammad bin Ishaq: Muhammad

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: bin Talha bin Yazid bin Rakanah told me, from Ubaidullah Al-Khawlani from Ibn Abbas who said: Ali entered my house and called for ablution water. We brought a bowl holding a Mudd or near it, until it was placed before him, and he had urinated. He said: O Ibn Abbas... etc. This is a good chain. This Hadith is almost a text for what Sheikh al-Islam, may Allah have mercy on him, adopted regarding sprinkling the foot while it is in the sandal. However, it does not necessitate invalidating the other Sunnah which is wiping over the sandals like the Khuffs and socks, by interpreting wiping over them as sprinkling as the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, said, due to the absence of a definitive diverting context from the literal to the metaphorical. And Allah knows best. Then I found a text by Sheikh al-Islam in which he adopted wiping over sandals on the condition of difficulty in removing them. He said in (Al-Fatawa) (2/85): Wiping over the feet has been transmitted from him, peace and blessings be upon him, in the place of need, such as having on his feet sandals that are difficult to remove. And he restricted it in (Al-Ikhtiyarat): Except with a hand or foot. 10 - Nullifiers of Ablution. 1, 2 - Urine, Feces: (Allah does not accept the prayer of one of you if he has Hadith (impurity) until he performs ablution) (Agreed upon). (No ablution except from a sound or smell) (T: Sahih, Maj Haq Ham (2/410)). 3 - Madhy: Ablution is required for it (Agreed upon).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 4 - Sleep: He used to command us when we were traveling not to remove our Khuffs for three days and their nights except for Janabah (major impurity), but not for feces, urine, and sleep. (T: Sahih N Ham). It is the school of Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Al-Muzani, Abu Ubaid Al-Qasim bin Sallam, Ibn Rahwayh, and Ibn Al-Mundhir, and Ibn Hazm went to this (1/222-231). 5 - Eating camel meat. Ahmad, Ishaq, Ibn Al-Mundhir, and Ibn Khuzaimah said this. Al-Bayhaqi and Ibn Hazm (1/241) chose it. Al-Shafi'i said: If the Hadith is authentic, I say it. Al-Nawawi said in Muslim: This school is stronger in evidence even if the majority is against it. Sheikh al-Islam supported it in (Al-Fatawa) (1/57-59) and inclined to it in (Majmu' al-Rasa'il) (2/432). Al-Shawkani said it (1/175-177). 6 - Touching the organ with desire. 11 - The purified person doubts impurity. (If one of you finds something in his belly and it is unclear to him whether something came out or not, let him not leave the mosque until he hears a sound or finds a smell) (M T). 12 - What Ablution is recommended for. Ablution for every prayer. Ablution from what fire has touched. Sheikh al-Islam in (Majmu' al-Rasa'il) (2/231-232). Ablution for remembering Allah Almighty and for the Quran even more so, from Al-Muhallab.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ablution from vomiting: (Majmu' al-Rasa'il) (2-234). Ablution after every Hadath. See (Al-Targhib) (1/99 No. 4). 13 - Obligatory Causes for Ghusl. 1 - Exit of Mani (semen) with desire: (If you ejected the water, then bathe from Janabah, and if you did not eject, then do not bathe) (Ham: 1/107) from Jawab Al-Taimi from Yazid bin Sharik - meaning Al-Taimi - from Ali with it elevated (Marfu'). This is a Hasan chain, its narrators are trustworthy except this Jawab, who is truthful but accused of Irja' as in (Al-Taqrib). In a wording for him from another path (1/109) and D (1/32): (So if you gushed the water, then bathe) and its chain is good. 2 - Its exit in a wet dream, and women in this are like men (1): From Umm Salamah that Umm Sulaim said: O Messenger of Allah, indeed Allah is not shy of the truth. Is there Ghusl upon the woman
foot_note: 1. (1) In it are two Hadiths: The first: From Khawlah bint Hakim that she asked the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, about the woman who sees in her sleep what the man sees. He said: (She has no Ghusl until she ejaculates just as the man has no Ghusl until he ejaculates). Narrated by Ahmad (6/409) and Ibn Majah (1/209), and in it is Ali bin Zaid bin Jad'an and in him is weakness, but the following Hadith strengthens it which is: From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, similarly. Narrated by the Five except Al-Nasa'i and in it is weakness also.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: if she has a wet dream? He said: (Yes, if she sees the water). Umm Salamah said: Does a woman have wet dreams? He said: (May your hands be dusted, in what does her child resemble her?). Agreed upon). In it is a refutation of those who said that a woman's water does not come out. 3 - Touching the circumcised parts. Circumcision: If he sits between her four parts and the circumcised part touches the circumcised part, then Ghusl becomes obligatory. (Ham M T: Sahih) even if he does not ejaculate (M Ham). The ruling in the beginning of Islam was: (Water is from water) (M), then it was abrogated. This is supported by His saying, the Almighty: (And if you are Junub, then purify yourselves) [Al-Ma'idah 6]. For the speech of the Arabs implies that Janabah applies in reality to intercourse even if there is no ejaculation, as Al-Shafi'i said. 4 - Menstruation (Hayd). (If the menses comes, leave the prayer, and if it goes, then bathe and pray) (Kh M). 5 - Post-Partum Bleeding (Nifas). Consensus has occurred among scholars that Nifas is like Hayd in all that is permissible, prohibited, disliked, and recommended. 14 - Obligatory Ghusls. 1 - Ghusl for the Disbeliever who embraces Islam. From Qais bin Asim, he said: I came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, wanting to embrace Islam, so he ordered me to bathe with water and Sidr (lotus jujube). (D N T Ham: 5/61). 2 - Friday Ghusl upon every adult (Muhtalim). 3 - Washing a deceased Muslim.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 15 - Recommended Ghusls. 1 - Ghusl from washing a dead person. Regarding it is what preceded (Whoever washes a dead person, let him bathe, and whoever carries him, let him perform ablution). 2 - Ghusl from burying a Polytheist. From Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him: When my father died, I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: Indeed your uncle has died. He said: (Go and bury him). I said: He died a polytheist. He said: (Go and bury him and do not speak anything until you come to me). So I did, then I came to him, and he ordered me to bathe. Narrated by Al-Tayalisi (19): Shu'bah told us from Abu Ishaq, he said: I heard Najiyah bin Ka'b say: I witnessed Ali say... so he mentioned it. Likewise, Ahmad (1/97) and Al-Nasa'i (1/41) narrated it from Shu'bah with it with some abbreviation. Sufyan Al-Thawri followed him from Abu Ishaq. Narrated by Abu Dawood (2/70) and Al-Nasa'i also (1/282-283). This is an authentic chain (1). And Sufyan added: So I bathed and he prayed for me. It has another path narrated by Abdullah bin Ahmad in (Zawa'id Al-Musnad) (1/103-129) from Al-Hasan bin Yazid Al-Asamm who said: I heard Al-Suddi Ismail mention it from
foot_note: 1. (1) Narrators of the Two Sheikhs except Najiyah bin Ka'b, and he is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). Ibn Hazm's statement (2/27): (He is very unknown) is something for which I found no precedent.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Abu Abd al-Rahman Al-Sulami from Ali with it, and in it: So I bathed then came to him. He said: So he prayed for me with supplications; I would not be pleased to have red camels and black ones in exchange for them. He said: And Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, used to bathe if he washed a dead person. This is a Hasan chain. (3) Ghusl for Ihram, even for the woman in Nifas. It was said: It is obligatory for her. Al-Hasan and the literalists (Ahl al-Zahir), including Ibn Hazm (7/82 and 2/26), said this. (4) For entering Mecca. Ibn Umar said: It is from the Sunnah to bathe if one wants to assume Ihram and if one wants to enter Mecca. (Qat Mas: Sahih). See (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad). (5) After Intercourse: From Abu Rafi' that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, went around to his wives one day, bathing at this one's and at that one's. He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, will you not make it one Ghusl? He said: This is purer, better, and cleaner). Narrated by D (1/34), Maj (1/206), and Ham (6/8-9) from Hammad bin Salamah from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Rafi' from his aunt Salma from him. This is a Hasan chain. (6) After Fainting, as in the Hadith of Aisha regarding the illness of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. (7) Ghusl of the Mustahada (woman with irregular bleeding) for every prayer. Or for Zuhr and Asr together with one Ghusl, and likewise for Maghrib and Isha, as the first is delayed to the time of the other. And one Ghusl for Fajr prayer. Refer to our comment on (Al-Mu'jam) (2/178-179) and (Al-Majma') also (1/280-281) and (Al-Musnad) (6/128-129).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 16 - Description of Ghusl. When he bathed from Janabah, he would start by washing his hands twice or thrice, then pour with his right hand over his left and wash his private parts, then perform ablution as his ablution for prayer, then take water and insert his fingers into the roots of the hair until he saw that he had saturated it, then he would pour three handfuls on his head, then pour over the rest of his body, then wash his feet. Agreed upon. He used to start with the right side of his head then the left. Agreed upon. He did not perform ablution after Ghusl. It suffices a woman to pour three handfuls on her head then pour water over herself to become pure (M H). 17 - Amount of Water in Ghusl and Ablution. He, peace and blessings be upon him, used to bathe with a Sa' and perform ablution with a Mudd (Ham Maj M T: Sahih) and Al-Tahawi (1/322-324) and Qat (35). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (A Mudd suffices for ablution and a Sa' for Janabah) Ham: (3/370) and Mas: (1/161) and he said: (Authentic on their condition) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. The most apparent view is that the Sa' is five and a third Iraqi Ratls, whether it is a Sa' of food or water, and it is

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the view of the majority of scholars contrary to Abu Hanifa. Thus in (Ikhtiyarat Sheikh al-Islam). Al-Tahawi narrated (1/324) from Ali bin Salih and Bishr bin Al-Walid together from Abu Yusuf who said: I arrived in Medina and one whom I trust brought out a Sa' to me saying: This is the Sa' of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. So I measured it and found it to be five Ratls and a third. Al-Tahawi said: I heard Ibn Abi Imran say: It is said that the one who brought this out to Abu Yusuf is Malik bin Anas. The Sa' is four Mudds, and the Mudd is the fill of the palms of a moderate man if he fills them and extends his hands with them. It is named Mudd thereby. I have tested that and found it correct. It is said in (Al-Qamus). It equals (700) grams in the estimation of Sheikh Bahjat Al-Bitar, may Allah the Almighty preserve him. He sometimes performed ablution with less than that, performing ablution once in a vessel containing water amount to two-thirds of a Mudd (D: 15) Sahih. What is obtained from the sum of Hadiths and texts is that (The sufficient amount for Ghusl is what achieves wetting the body in the considered manner, whether it is a Sa' or less or more, as long as it does not reach in decrease to an amount where its user is not called a bather, or to an amount in increase where its doer enters the limit of extravagance. And likewise Ablution, the sufficient amount of it is what achieves washing the limbs of ablution, whether it is a Mudd or less or more, as long as it does not reach in increase to the limit of extravagance or in decrease to a limit where the obligatory is not achieved). Thus in (Al-Nayl) (1/219-220). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Indeed there will be in this nation a people who transgress in purification and supplication) (D: 15). See (Naqd Al-Taj).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 18 - Etiquette of Bathing and Entering the Bath (Hammam). He, peace and blessings be upon him, if he bathed, would screen himself with a garment. In (Al-Sahih) is that his daughter Fatimah (1) screened the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in the Year of the Conquest with a garment while he was bathing, then he prayed eight Rak'ahs. In it also is that Maimunah screened him so he bathed. He saw a man bathing in the open space (Baraz), so he ascended the pulpit, praised Allah and extolled Him, and said: (Indeed Allah Almighty is Forbearing, Modest, Concealing; He loves modesty and concealment. So if one of you bathes, let him screen himself) (N: 70) via Zuhair: Abdul Malik told us from Ata from Ya'la. This is a good chain. Narrated by (Ham: 4/224) and (N) in a summarized narration with the wording: (Indeed Allah Almighty is Modest, Concealing, so if one of you wants to bathe, let him hide with something). Narrated by Abu Dawood (2/170) with both wordings and said: The first is more complete. And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (The Children of Israel used to bathe naked, looking at one another, and Moses, peace be upon him, used to bathe alone. They said: By Allah, nothing prevents Moses from bathing with us except that he has a scrotal hernia (Adarah). He said: So he went once to bathe and placed his garment on a stone, but the stone fled with his garment. He said: Moses ran after it saying: My garment, stone! My garment, stone! Until the Children of Israel looked at the private parts of Moses, peace be upon him, and said: By Allah, there is no harm with Moses. He said: So he took his garment and started beating the stone) (Agreed upon). And he, peace be upon him, said: (While Job, peace be upon him, was bathing naked, locusts of
foot_note: 1. (1) In original: (Umm Hani), and the correct is what we established. (The Publisher)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: gold fell upon him. Job started gathering them in his garment. His Lord, Blessed and Exalted, called him: O Job, did I not enrich you from what you see? He said: Yes, by Your Might, but I have no richness from Your blessing). (Ham Kh N). See (Naqd Al-Taj) number (60). He, peace and blessings be upon him, encouraged covering even in privacy, saying: (Guard your nakedness except from your wife or what your right hand possesses). He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, if people are together? He said: (If you are able that no one sees it, then let no one see it). He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, if one is alone? He said: (Allah is more deserving that one be shy of Him than people) (D: 2/171, T: 2/130, Maj: 1/553, Al-Bayhaqi 2/225) and Al-Hakim (4/179-180). T said: Hasan Hadith, and it is as he said. Al-Hakim authenticated it (4/180) as in (Al-Fath) (1/306) and Kh suspended it. He, peace and blessings be upon him, allowed men to enter the bath (Hammam) on condition of screening, and forbade women from it absolutely. He, peace be upon him, said: (Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not enter the bath except with a lower garment (Mi'zar), and whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not make his wife enter the bath) (N T and declared it Hasan, and Mas: Sahih). In a wording: (Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day among your women, let them not enter the bath) (Mas Hab: Sahih). See (Al-Targhib) (1/88-90). The exception of the sick woman and the woman in Nifas (post-partum) is not authentic, so there is no harm in their entering for necessity if the awrah is covered, as in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) (3/61).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (There is no woman who removes her clothes in other than the house of one of her mothers except that she is tearing every screen between her and the Most Merciful Almighty) (Ham Hab). In another narration: (In other than her husband's house) (D T Maj Mi Mas Taya Ham). 19 - Tayammum (Dry Ablution). Whoever does not find water performs Tayammum, whether traveler or other than traveler. Allah Almighty said: (O you who have believed, do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated until you know what you are saying or in a state of janabah, except those passing through [a place of prayer], until you have washed [your whole body]. And if you are ill or on a journey or one of you comes from the place of relieving himself or you have contacted women and find no water, then seek clean earth and wipe over your faces and hands) [Al-Nisa / 43]. They were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, on a journey, and he prayed with the people. Suddenly there was a man keeping apart. He said: (What prevented you from praying?) He said: I became Junub and there is no water. He said: (Use the earth, for it suffices you) (Agreed upon). He, peace and blessings be upon him, performed Tayammum in Medina to return a greeting. One performs Tayammum with whatever is on the face of the earth, whether dirt or otherwise, as he, peace be upon him, performed Tayammum on the wall. And due to the generality of his saying: (And the earth was made for me and my nation a mosque and a purifier). This is the school of Abu Hanifa, Malik, and others, and chosen by Ibn Hazm (2/158-161). He prays with it whatever he wishes of obligatory and voluntary prayers as long as he does not find water: (Indeed,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: clean earth is a purifier for the Muslim even if he does not find water for ten years. But if he finds water, let him make it touch his skin, for that is better) (D T: Sahih Ham from Abu Dharr). It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah with an authentic chain as Ibn Al-Qattan said. I say: Its narrators are narrators of Al-Bukhari with the wording: (Let him fear Allah and make it touch his skin). See Al-Zayla'i (1/148-150). It is the saying of Ibn Al-Musayyib, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Al-Zuhri, Abu Ja'far Al-Baqir, and Yazid bin Harun. (Al-Muhalla) (2/128). If he finds water, he does not repeat what he prayed, and it is the school of the Four. Abu Sa'id said: Two men went out on a journey and prayer time arrived, and they had no water. They performed Tayammum with clean earth and prayed. Then they found water within the time. One of them repeated the ablution and prayer, and the other did not repeat. Then they came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and mentioned that to him. He said to the one who did not repeat: (You hit the Sunnah and your prayer sufficed you). And he said to the one who performed ablution and repeated: (You have the reward twice) (D N) and others. See (Naqd Al-Taj). Nothing invalidates it except what invalidates ablution among the nullifiers, and finding water due to the Hadith of Abu Dharr and Abu Hurairah mentioned previously, and due to his saying - in the Hadith of the one who kept away from prayer while Junub which passed recently -: And the end of that was that he, peace and blessings be upon him, gave the one who had Janabah a vessel of water and said: (Go and pour it over yourself). The Junub performs Tayammum for a wound with the presence of water: Al-Walid bin Ubaidullah bin Abi Rabah reported that Ata told him from Ibn Abbas that a man became Junub in winter and asked, so he was ordered to bathe

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: so he bathed and died. That was mentioned to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said: (What is wrong with them? They killed him, may Allah kill them - three times - Allah has made the earth or Tayammum a purifier). Narrated by Al-Hakim (1/165), Ibn Khuzaimah, and Ibn Hibban. The first said it is authentic. Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, which is strange from him, for he mentioned in his (Mizan) that Al-Daraqutni weakened this Al-Walid. However, he has been followed in it, for Abu Dawood (1/56), Ibn Majah (202), Al-Darimi (192), and Al-Hakim also (1/178) narrated it via Al-Awza'i that it reached him from Ata bin Abi Rabah similarly, and in it that the man had a wound, and at its end: Is not the cure for ignorance asking? And in a narration of Al-Hakim from Bishr bin Bakr: Al-Awza'i told me: Ata told us with it. This, if established, would be authentic, but its defect is that Al-Awza'i did not hear it from Ata; he only heard it from Ismail bin Muslim from Ata. I say: This Ismail is weak, but the narration of Al-Walid strengthens him as previously mentioned. Likewise, Al-Zubair bin Khurayq followed him but opposed him in the chain saying: From Ata from Jabir with it, more complete than it. Abu Dawood (56) and Al-Daraqutni (69), and he said: Only Al-Zubair bin Khurayq narrated it from Ata from Jabir, and he is not strong. Ibn Al-Sakan authenticated it as in (Al-Nayl) (224). In summary, the Hadith is strong and established with these corroborations.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And one performs Tayammum for fear of cold: From Amr bin Al-Aas, who said: I had a wet dream on a cold night in the expedition of Dhat Al-Salasil, so I feared that if I bathed I would die, so I performed Tayammum then prayed the Morning Prayer with my companions. They mentioned that to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so he said: (O Amr, did you pray with your companions while you were Junub?) I informed him of what prevented me from bathing and said: I heard Allah saying: (And do not kill yourselves. Indeed, Allah is to you ever Merciful) [Al-Nisa / 29]. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, laughed and did not say anything. Narrated by Abu Dawood and others in broken and connected forms, both are correct, and Al-Hafiz strengthened it in (Al-Fath). We discussed it in detail in (Naqd Al-Taj) number (45). If the water is insufficient for ablution and Ghusl, he uses it to wash his initial limbs then performs Tayammum for the rest, due to his saying: (If I command you with a command, do of it what you are able) (Agreed upon). This is the school of Ibn Hazm (2/137). 20 - Description of Tayammum. From Ammar, he said: I became Junub and did not find water, so I rolled in the dust and prayed. I mentioned that to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said: (It would have sufficed you to do like this) and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, struck the earth with his palms, blew into them, then wiped his face and palms with them. (Agreed upon). It is one strike for the face and palms. Ahmad, Ishaq, and others said this. As for encompassing them [arms] with wiping, there is no evidence for it. (Al-Muhalla) (2/156-158).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 21 - Menstruation (Hayd). It is the black, thick, foul-smelling blood specifically. Whenever it appears from the woman, she becomes menstruating (Ha'id). From Fatimah bint Abi Hubaish that she had irregular bleeding (Istihadah), so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to her: (If it is menstrual blood, then it is black blood that is known; so if it is that, refrain from prayer. But if it is the other, then perform ablution and pray, for it is only a vein). (D: 45 and 50, N: 66, Qat: 76, Mas: 174) and Ibn Hazm (2/164) from Ibn Abi Adi: Muhammad bin Amr told us: Ibn Shihab told us from Urwah bin Al-Zubair from her. This is a Hasan chain. Ibn Al-Arabi declared it Hasan in (Al-Aridah). Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of Muslim) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is not as they said. Then Al-Hakim narrated it (1/174) via Suhail bin Abi Salih from Al-Zuhri from Urwah bin Al-Zubair from Asma bint Umais who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, Fatimah bint Abi Hubaish has had irregular bleeding since such and such time and has not prayed. She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Glory be to Allah, this is from Satan. Let her sit in a tub, and if she sees yellowness on top of the water, let her bathe for Zuhr and Asr with one bath, and bathe for Maghrib and Isha with one bath, and bathe for Fajr, and perform ablution in between that). And he said: (Authentic on the condition of Muslim) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is as they said. Narrated by D (48), Qat (79), Taha (60-61).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: So this Hadith indicates that yellowness is not menstrual blood due to his saying: (Menstrual blood is black and known). This is the school of Ibn Hazm and the majority of literalists as he said in (Al-Muhalla) (2/168). As for redness and yellowness after purity (Tuhr), it is not counted as anything. This is the opinion of Abu Hanifa, Sufyan Al-Thawri, Al-Awza'i, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and others. From Aisha, wife of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that Umm Habibah bint Jahsh, the sister-in-law of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and wife of Abd al-Rahman bin Awf, had irregular bleeding for seven years, so she asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, for a ruling on that. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Indeed this is not the menses, but this is a vein; so bathe and pray). Aisha said: She used to bathe in a tub in the room of her sister Zainab bint Jahsh until the redness of the blood would overcome the water. (M: 181, D 44, N: 655, Maj: 215-216, Mi: 196-198, 199 and 200) and Ham (6-83 and 187). Narrated by: M (181-182) N (65) D (43). And from Aisha that some of his wives performed I'tikaf with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while she was Mustahada seeing blood, so perhaps she would place the basin under her for the blood. He claimed that Aisha saw safflower water and said: This was something such and such [woman] used to find. (Kh: 26, Mi: 217, and in a wording

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: for Kh: 327 and 4/226): A woman from his wives who was Mustahada performed I'tikaf with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and she would see redness and yellowness, so perhaps we placed the basin under her while she prayed. And from Ayyub from Muhammad from Umm Atiyyah who said: We used to not count turbidity and yellowness as anything. (Kh: 338, D: 50, N: 66, Mi: 214, Maj: 222, Mas: 174). Then D, Mi: 215, Maj: 222 and Mas narrated it via Hammad bin Salamah from Qatadah from Umm Al-Hudhail from her with the addition: 'After purity as anything'. Mas said: (Authentic on their condition) and Umm Al-Hudhail is Hafsah bint Sirin, and Al-Dhahabi said likewise. However, it is on the condition of Muslim because of Hammad bin Salamah, and the first is on their condition, and his rectification upon Al-Bukhari is meaningless. Al-Darimi narrated from Ibn Sirin who said: They did not see any harm in turbidity and yellowness. 1 - So if menstrual blood is black and known, then anyone who sees it and distinguishes it is menstruating (Ha'id), otherwise she is Mustahada. 2 - Except the one who cannot distinguish her blood due to its abundance and continuity, she must refer to her habit and her known days of menses. 3 - And if she does not know the days of menses and does not distinguish the blood, she must refer to the predominant habit of women in that.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The first is evidenced by the Hadith of Fatimah bint Abi Hubaish previously mentioned. The second is evidenced by the Hadith of Umm Habibah in Ahmad which passed recently, and it is from the Hadith of Aisha. Umm Salamah also narrated it in Ahmad (6 - 322 - 323 and 320 and 393), Abu Dawood (42), N (65), Mi (199), Maj (215), Qat (76) from Sulaiman bin Yasar from her. It is defective due to disconnection between him and her, for D and others narrated from him that a man informed him from her. But it has another path in (Al-Musnad) (6/304): Suraij told us: Abdullah - meaning Ibn Umar - told us from Salim Abu Al-Nadr from Abu Salamah bin Abd al-Rahman from her. This is a Hasan chain with what preceded it. The third is evidenced by the Hadith of Hamnah bint Jahsh who said: I had severe and heavy irregular bleeding, so I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, asking for a ruling and informing him. I found him in the house of my sister Zainab bint Jahsh. She said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have heavy and severe irregular bleeding, so what do you see regarding it? It has prevented me from prayer and fasting. He said: (I describe cotton for you, for it removes the blood. She said: It is more than that. He said: (Then use a cloth). She said: It is more than that. He said: (Then bridle it [make a diaper like a bridle]). She said: I am gushing profusely. He said: I will order you with two commands; whichever of them you do, it will suffice you for the other, but if you are strong enough for both, you know best). He said to her:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (This is only a kick from the kicks of Satan, so count yourself as menstruating for six days or seven in the knowledge of Allah, then bathe until when you see that you have become pure and clean, pray for twenty-four nights or twenty-three nights and days, and fast, for that suffices you. And do likewise every month as women menstruate and as they become pure for the timing of their menstruation and purity. And if you are strong enough to delay Zuhr and hasten Asr, then bathe and pray Zuhr and Asr together, then delay Maghrib and hasten Isha, then bathe and combine the two prayers, then do so. And bathe with Fajr and pray, then do so. And pray and fast if you are able to do that). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (And this is the more impressive of the two commands to me). Narrated by the authors of the Sunan except Al-Nasa'i and others. It is extracted in the commentary on (Al-Mu'jam) (p. 179 / vol. 2) and it is a Hasan Hadith. The three states we mentioned were held by Ahmad and Ishaq. In Al-Tirmidhi (1/227): And Ahmad and Ishaq said regarding the Mustahada: If she knows her menses by the coming and going of blood, and its coming is that it is black and its going is that it changes to yellowness, then the ruling is for her based on the Hadith of Fatimah bint Abi Hubaish. And if the Mustahada has known days before she became Mustahada, then she leaves prayer during the days of her periods, then bathes and performs ablution for every prayer and prays. And if the blood continues with her and she does not have known days and does not know menstruation by the coming and going of blood, then the ruling is for her based on the Hadith of Hamnah bint Jahsh. Likewise Abu Ubaid said)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Mustahada must perform ablution for every prayer. From Hisham bin Urwah from his father from Aisha: That Fatimah bint Abi Hubaish came to the Prophet and said: I menstruate for a month or two months. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (That is not menses, rather it is a vein. So if the menses comes, leave prayer, and if it goes, bathe for your purity then perform ablution at every prayer) Taha (61) from Abu Hanifa from him. And Kh (1/264-265) and T (1/217-219) Qat (76) from Abu Mu'awiyah from him. T said: Hasan Sahih. And Hab as in (Nasb Al-Rayah) (203) from Abu Hamzah from him. And M (180) D (44) N (64) Maj (214) Mi (198) Taha (62) Qat (76) Ham (4/84) narrated it via paths from Hisham with it without his saying: (Then perform ablution at every prayer), which is the narration of (Kh T). Therefore some discussed this addition claiming it is interpolated, but Al-Hafiz refuted that in (Al-Fath). It came from another path from Urwah bin Al-Zubair in Maj (215), Taha (61), Qat (78), Ham (6/42, 204, 262) from Al-A'mash from Habib bin Abi Thabit from Urwah. Ibn Majah added: Ibn Al-Zubair with it similarly with the wording: (And perform ablution for every prayer if blood drips on the mat). Its narrators are narrators of the Two Sheikhs but it was faulted for disconnection between Habib and Urwah. It has another path from Fatimah from

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Uthman bin Sa'd Al-Katib from Abdullah bin Abi Mulaikah who said: Fatimah bint Abi Hubaish told me saying: I came to Aisha... The Hadith. In it is that he, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Aisha: (Order Fatimah bint Abi Hubaish to refrain every month for the number of days of her periods, then bathe, use a pad, bind it, clean herself, then purify herself at every prayer and pray)... The Hadith. Narrated by Ham (6/464), Qat (80), Mas (175) and he said: (Authentic Hadith). Uthman bin Sa'd Al-Katib is Basran, trustworthy, abundant in Hadith, his Hadith is collected. I say: Others besides Al-Hakim weakened him. In (Al-Taqrib): He is weak. In the chapter there are other Hadiths refer to (Nasb Al-Rayah). Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, Abu Thawr, and others held that the Mustahada performs ablution for every prayer. Abu Hanifa and his two companions said: She performs ablution for the time of every prayer. This is a metaphor of omission that needs evidence. Therefore, Al-Shawkani refuted it (240) following Al-Hafiz. It is forbidden to have intercourse with a menstruating woman in the vagina, but permissible to enjoy her in other than that. From Anas bin Malik: The Jews, if a woman menstruated among them, would not eat with her nor associate with her in houses. The companions of the Prophet asked the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so Allah Almighty revealed: (And they ask you about menstruation. Say, "It is harm, so keep away from wives during menstruation"... to the end of the verse). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Do everything except Nikah (intercourse)). And in a wording: (Except intercourse). Narrated by the Group except Al-Bukhari.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Whoever goes to a menstruating woman or a woman in her anus or a soothsayer and believes him in what he says, has disbelieved in what was revealed to Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him). Narrated by the people of (Al-Sunan) with an authentic chain as we clarified in (Naqd Al-Taj) number (64). Prohibition of intercourse with a menstruating woman is agreed upon. Ahmad bin Hanbal, Muhammad bin Al-Hasan, Ishaq, and others held based on the Hadith that approaching the woman in other than the mentioned is permissible, but it is disliked for one who fears falling into the prohibited to block the means. Whoever approaches her must give charity of a Dinar or half a Dinar by choice: From Ibn Abbas from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the one who approaches his wife while she is menstruating, he gives charity of a Dinar or half a Dinar. Narrated by the authors of Sunan with an authentic chain. The scholar Ahmad Muhammad Shakir elaborated on verifying its chains and authenticating some of them in the commentary on Al-Tirmidhi (1/246-254). She does not pray nor fast: He, peace and blessings be upon him, said to women: (Is not the testimony of a woman like half the testimony of a man?) They said: Yes. He said: (That is from the deficiency of her intellect. Is it not that if she menstruates she does not pray nor fast?). They said: Yes. He said: (That is from the deficiency of her religion). Narrated by Al-Bukhari. She makes up fasting but not prayer: From Mu'adhah, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: I asked

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Aisha saying: Why does the menstruating woman make up fasting but not prayer? She said: That used to happen to us with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and we were ordered to make up fasting but not ordered to make up prayer. Narrated by the Group. She does not circumambulate the House (Tawaf). He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (The menstruating woman performs all rituals except Tawaf of the House). Narrated by Ahmad (6/137) from Aisha and (1/364) from Ibn Abbas, and one of them strengthens the other, especially since its meaning is in the (Two Sahihs) from her. They attend the Eid prayer place (Musalla), saying Takbir with the people and avoiding the prayer. From Umm Atiyyah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered us to bring them out on Fitr and Adha; the mature girls, the menstruating women, and those in seclusion. As for the menstruating women, they avoid the prayer and witness the good and the supplication of the Muslims. I said: O Messenger of Allah, one of us does not have a Jilbab (outer garment). He said: (Let her sister dress her from her Jilbab). In a narration: We were ordered to go out for the two Eids, including the secluded and the virgin. She said: The menstruating women go out and stay behind the people, saying Takbir with the people. M (3/20-21) and see Kh in Eid and others. It is permissible for her to enter the Mosque: From Aisha who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to me: (Hand me the mat from the mosque) N so I said: I am menstruating? He said: (Hand it, for the menses is not in your hand). (M 168) D (41) N (1/52-53 and 68) and T

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (1/241) and authenticated it, and Mi (248) Maj (218) and Ham (6/45, 101, 106, 110, 111, 114, 173, 179, 208, 214, 229, 245) from paths from her. In the chapter from Abu Hurairah in M N Ham (2/428, 6/214), Umm Salamah in N Ham (6/331 and 334), Ibn Umar in Ham (2/70 and 86), Anas in Al-Bazzar, and Abu Bakrah in Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir). Majma' (1/283). Ibn Hazm allowed that for her (2/184-187) and narrated it from Al-Muzani, Dawud, and others. It is permissible to eat with her: From Aisha who said: I used to drink while I was menstruating, then I would hand it to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and he would place his mouth on the place of my mouth. Narrated by the Group except Al-Bukhari and Al-Tirmidhi. It is in (Al-Musnad 6/62, 64, 127, 192, 210, 214) and in Al-Darimi (1/246). Abdullah bin Sa'd said: I asked the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, about eating with a menstruating woman? He said: Eat with her. T (1/240) Mi (248) and Ham (4/342 and 5/293) from Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi: Mu'awiyah bin Salih told us from Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith from Haram bin Mu'awiyah from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: Hasan Hadith. It is as he said. Then Al-Darimi narrated it (1/249) via Al-Haitham bin Humaid: Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith told us with it with the wording: So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Indeed some of my family are menstruating and we are dining together, Allah willing).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It is not permissible to have intercourse with her until she becomes pure [stops bleeding] and bathes, so bathing is necessary due to His saying: (And do not approach them until they become pure (and purity is by the cessation of menses), and when they have purified themselves (i.e., bathed), then come to them from where Allah has ordered you) [Al-Baqarah / 222]. This is the school of the Majority. See Al-Darimi (249-251) and (Nayl Al-Maram) by Siddiq Hasan Khan. As for the Mustahada, nothing regarding her specifically has been reported in the Sunnah from him, peace and blessings be upon him, as far as we know. Scholars have differed regarding intercourse with her, and the Majority allows it, which is the truth because the default in things is permissibility and because prohibiting it causes harm to the husband if the irregular bleeding is continuous as happened to Umm Habibah bint Jahsh as preceded. How excellent is what Al-Darimi narrated (207) with an authentic chain from Salim Al-Aftas who said: Said bin Jubair was asked: Can one have intercourse with the Mustahada? He said: Prayer is greater than intercourse. And similar was narrated from Bakr bin Abdullah Al-Muzani with an authentic chain also. The minimum Hayd is a moment (def'ah); if the woman sees black blood from her vagina, she refrains from prayer and fasting... if she sees a trace of red blood... then she has become pure. (Al-Muhalla) (2/191). 22 - Post-Partum Bleeding (Nifas). Its maximum is forty days. Umm Salamah said: The woman in Nifas used to sit for forty days during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and we used to coat our faces with Wars (a yellow plant used for dye) for freckles/spots (dark redness on the face). D (50) T (254) Mi (229) Maj (223) Qat (82) Mas (175) Ham (4/300, 303, 304, 309) from

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: paths from Ali bin Abd Al-A'la from Abu Sahl Al-Basri from Mussah from her. Then D Mas narrated it from Yunus bin Rafi' from Kathir bin Ziyad Abu Sahl who said: Mussah Al-Azdiyyah told me saying: I performed Hajj and entered upon Umm Salamah and said: O Mother of the Believers, indeed Samurah bin Jundub orders women to make up the prayers of menstruation. She said: They do not make up. The woman among the wives of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, would sit in Nifas for forty nights, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, would not order her to make up the prayer of Nifas. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Strange Hadith). But Al-Hakim said: (Authentic). And Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, which is rejected by his statement in the biography of this Mussah Al-Azdiyyah in (Al-Mizan) - and he cited this Hadith for her -: (Al-Daraqutni said: She is not used as proof). I say: Only this Hadith is known by her. Al-Hafiz said about her in (Al-Taqrib): (She is Maqbulah / Accepted [if corroborated]), but the Hadith has many witnesses that do not let it fall below the rank of Hasan li-ghayrihi (Hasan due to others): Among them is what Abu Bilal Al-Ash'ari narrated: Abu Shihab told us from Hisham bin Hassan from Al-Hasan from Uthman bin Abi Al-Aas who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: (Forty days were set for women in Nifas during their Nifas).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Qat (81) and Mas (176) and he said: If it is safe from Abu Bilal, it is Mursal Sahih for Al-Hasan did not hear from Uthman. Qat said: This Abu Bilal Al-Ash'ari is weak. Among them is similarly from Aisha in Al-Daraqutni via the mentioned Abu Bilal: Hibban told us from Ata from Abdullah bin Abi Mulaikah from her. He said: Abu Bilal is weak and Ata is Ibn Ajlan, abandoned in Hadith. Among them is from Jabir who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, set forty days for women in Nifas. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and in it is Ash'ath bin Sawar; Ibn Ma'in declared him trustworthy but citing him is disputed as in (Al-Majma') (281) and in (Al-Taqrib): He is weak. In the chapter there are other Hadiths which will be mentioned soon. I found a strong Mauquf (stopped) witness for it narrated by Al-Darimi (1/229 and 230) via Abu Awanah from Abu Bishr from Yusuf bin Mahak from Ibn Abbas who said: The woman in Nifas waits for forty days or thereabouts. This is an authentic chain on the condition of the Six. Likewise, Al-Bayhaqi narrated it (1/341). If she sees purity before that, she bathes and prays. In it are Hadiths strengthening each other:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (1) From Anas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, set forty days for the woman in Nifas unless she sees purity before that.
