Maj (224) Qat (81) from Abd al-Rahman bin Muhammad Al-Muharibi from Salam bin Sulaim from Humaid from him. Qat said: No one narrated it from Humaid except this Salam, who is Salam Al-Tawil, and he is weak in Hadith. As for the statement of the author of (Al-Zawa'id) that its chain is authentic and its narrators are trustworthy, this is an error originating from not tracking who extracted the Hadith. Refer for that to the commentary on (Al-Muhalla) (2/206). Ibn Hazm extracted it (2) From Abdullah bin Amr, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (The woman in Nifas waits for forty nights; if she sees purity before that, she is pure. If she exceeds forty, she is like the Mustahada; she bathes and prays, and if the blood overcomes her, she performs ablution for every prayer) Qat (81) Mas (176) via Amr bin Al-Husain: Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Ulaithah told us from Abdah bin Abi Lubabah from Abdullah bin Babah from him. Qat said: Amr bin Al-Husain and Ibn Ulaithah are weak and abandoned. (3) From Mu'adh bin Jabal elevated (Marfu'): (If seven pass for the woman in Nifas then she sees purity, let her bathe and pray) Qat (82) from Abd al-Salam bin Muhammad Al-Himsi, nicknamed Sulaim: Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid told us: Ali bin Ali reported to us from Al-Aswad from Ubadah bin Nasi from Abd al-Rahman bin Ghanam from him with it. Sulaim said: So I met Ali bin Ali from Al-Aswad from Ubadah bin

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Nasi from Abd al-Rahman bin Ghanam from him similarly. Al-Aswad is Ibn Tha'labah, a Levantine. I say: Al-Hakim narrated it (1/176) from this way but he said: Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid told us: Al-Aswad bin Tha'labah informed me with it. I do not know if the narration is like this with him or if the mention of Ali bin Ali fell from our copy. Then he does not have the second chain. Then he said: (Muslim cited Baqiyyah bin Al-Walid as witness, and as for Al-Aswad bin Tha'labah, he is a known Levantine). He said so and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, although he says in his biography in (Al-Mizan): (Not known), said by Ibn Al-Madini. And in (Al-Taqrib): (Unknown). Al-Shawkani said (1/247): (The evidences indicating that the maximum of Nifas is forty days support each other by the Sunnah to the level of validity and consideration, so resorting to it is obligatory. What is obligatory on the woman in Nifas is stopping for forty days unless she sees purity before that as the previous Hadiths indicated). Al-Tirmidhi said (258): (And the people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, the Followers, and those after them have agreed

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: that the woman in Nifas leaves prayer for forty days unless she sees purity before that, then she bathes and prays. If she sees blood after forty, then most people of knowledge said: She does not leave prayer after forty, and it is the opinion of most jurists, and Sufyan Al-Thawri, Ibn Al-Mubarak, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq say it). I say: What he mentioned about Al-Shafi'i is one opinion of his, otherwise the famous opinion mentioned in the books of his companions is that the maximum of Nifas is sixty days. Al-Tirmidhi narrated it from Ata bin Abi Rabah and Al-Sha'bi. They differed regarding the minimum of Nifas on opinions; the closest to correctness is that there is no limit for its minimum due to his saying previously: If she sees purity before that. It is the opinion of Al-Shafi'i and Muhammad, and it is the choice of Sheikh al-Islam (16) from (Al-Ikhtiyarat) and Ibn Hazm (2/203). Know that Nifas is like Hayd in all that is permissible, prohibited, disliked, and recommended, and Al-Shawkani transmitted consensus on that (248) from (Al-Bahr). They have agreed that the menstruating woman does not pray, so likewise the woman in Nifas.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: 2 - The Book of Prayer 1 - It is one of the five pillars: (Islam is built on five)... The Hadith (Agreed upon). And in it is the Hadith: I will not add to them nor decrease [from them]. 2 - It was mandated first as fifty, then made five: Anas bin Malik: The prayers were mandated upon the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, on the night he was taken on the Night Journey as fifty, then they were decreased until they were made five. T (1/417) and he authenticated it, and Ham (3/161): Abdur-Razzaq told us: Ma'mar told us from Al-Zuhri, he said: Anas bin Malik informed me of it. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim], and it is with them as part of the long Hadith of Isra with a similar wording. 3 - It is permissible for the rulers to accept the Islam of a disbeliever even if he does not agree to establish all five prayers: Nasr bin Asim Al-Laithi from a man among them: That he came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and embraced Islam on the condition that he would only pray two prayers, so he accepted that from him. Ham (5/24-25 and 363) by way of Shu'bah from Qatadah from him. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of Muslim. And regarding it are [other] Hadiths. 4 - It was mandated first as two Rak'ahs, two Rak'ahs, except Maghrib, then it was increased in residency except for Subh (Fajr), and it was left as it is in travel. Aisha said: Prayer was mandated as two Rak'ahs, two Rak'ahs in Mecca, then when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, arrived in Medina, he increased two Rak'ahs with every two Rak'ahs except Maghrib, for it is the Witr of the day, and the Fajr prayer due to the length of...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...their recitation/reading. She said: And when he traveled, he prayed the first prayer. Ham (6/241 and 265) from Dawud bin Abi Hind from Al-Sha'bi from her. And this is with a Sahih chain according to the condition of Muslim. And he has (6/272) another path from her with similar wording, and its chain is Hasan. Its origin is in Al-Bukhari and Muslim briefly without mentioning Subh and Maghrib. This does not contradict the Hadith of Ibn Abbas who said: Allah mandated prayer on the tongue of your Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in residency as four, in travel as two, and in fear as one. Muslim (2/143) and others, for this is a report about what the matter settled upon. 5 - And the one who abandons it, Kufr (disbelief) is feared for him due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Between a man and Kufr is that prayer) M. Hibatullah Al-Tabari added: (So if he abandons it, he has committed Shirk). Al-Mundhiri said: (Its chain is Sahih). And the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (The covenant that is between us and them is prayer, so whoever abandons it has disbelieved) (Ham, N, T: Sahih, Ms: Sahih) and refer to (Naqd Al-Taj). Therefore, the companions of Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did not view the abandonment of any deed as Kufr other than prayer. (T) from Abdullah bin Shaqiq Al-Uqayli the Tabi'i with it. Al-Hakim connected it mentioning Abu Huraira in it. And it is Sahih in chain. Therefore, he will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection with the major polytheists. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Whoever preserves it, it will be a light, a proof, and a salvation for him on the Day of Resurrection, and whoever does not preserve it, he will not have light, nor proof, nor salvation...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and on the Day of Resurrection, he will be with Qarun, Pharaoh, Haman, and Ubayy bin Khalaf) (Mi, Ham, Tab, Hib in his (Sahih) and its chain is Hasan. However, his Kufr is not of the type that Allah cannot forgive and admit him to Paradise; rather that is possible. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Five prayers Allah has written upon the servants. Whoever comes with them and did not waste anything from them out of disdain for their right, he has a covenant with Allah that He will admit him to Paradise. And whoever does not come with them, he has no covenant with Allah; if He wills He punishes him, and if He wills He admits him to Paradise). (Malik, D, N, Mi, Maj, Ham with a Sahih chain). And know that many Hadiths have come attributing Kufr to one who commits a sin from the major sins, rather in some of them [it says] it is Kufr and that he is a Kafir (disbeliever). So he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Abusing a Muslim is Fusuq (wickedness) and fighting him is Kufr). And he said: (There is no man who claims other than his father while knowing it except that he has disbelieved). And (Two things in people are Kufr for them: Defaming lineage and wailing over the dead). And (Do not return after me as disbelievers, striking the necks of one another). And (Any slave who runs away from his masters has disbelieved until he returns to them). And (Whoever says to his brother 'O Kafir', then one of them has incurred it; if it is as he said, otherwise it returns to him). All these Hadiths are in the (Sahih). So if we know that Kufr is degrees and that some of it does not make its doer abide eternally in the Fire, then there is no resort then to interpretation. Whoever the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, named a Kafir, we name him a Kafir, and we do not exceed this amount. Refer for this to Al-Shawkani (1/254-260).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: 6 - And the one who abandons it is killed: (I have been ordered to fight the people until they testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, and they establish prayer and give Zakat. If they do that...) The Hadith (Agreed upon). (There will be rulers over you, so you will recognize [some deeds] and reject [others]. Whoever rejects is absolved, and whoever hates is safe, but whoever is pleased and follows). They said: Should we not fight them? He said: (No, as long as they pray) (M). (Does he not pray?) He said: Yes. And there is no prayer for him. He, peace be upon him, said: (Those are the ones Allah forbade me from killing). Malik (1/185) Mursal with a Sahih chain, and Al-Shafi'i and Ahmad connected it in their (Musnads). It has a witness from the Hadith of Anas in Al-Tabarani, Abu Ya'la, and Al-Bazzar in (Al-Majma') (1/296) and another from Abu Huraira (D 2/305). 7 - Prayer is not obligatory upon a child until he reaches puberty: (The pen has been lifted from three: from the sleeper until he wakes up, from the child until he has a wet dream [puberty], and from the insane until he reasons) (D, N, T, Mi, Maj, Ms, Ham 6/100 - 101 and 101). It is Sahih by the sum of its paths and witnesses. Refer to (Nasb al-Rayah) (4/161-165), (Al-Talkhis) (2/95-96), and (Miftah Kunuz al-Sunnah) (p. 152). 8 - However, the guardian must order him to pray when he reaches seven years and beat him [lightly] if he reaches the tenth: (Order your children to pray at seven years, and beat them for it at ten years...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and separate them in beds). It is a Hasan or Sahih Hadith via its two paths. See (Naqd Al-Taj) (No. 80). The Shafi'is held this view: Majmu' (2/11), and Al-Shawkani went to it (1/260). 9 - There is no Making Up (Qada) upon the insane, whether the time of insanity was short or long - and it is the school of the Shafi'is, and narrated from Malik and Ahmad as in (Al-Majmu') (2/6-7). It is the school of Ibn Hazm (2/233-234) and chosen by Sheikh Al-Islam (19). 10 - Likewise, the one who fainted, there is no Qada upon him, and it is the school of those mentioned, and Ibn Hazm narrated it from Ibn Umar, Tawus, Al-Zuhri, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Ibn Sirin, and Asim bin Bahdalah. 11 - Likewise, the disbeliever if he embraces Islam, there is no Qada upon him, due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (Islam wipes out what was before it). Ham (4: 198-199 and 204 and 205) from paths from Amr bin Al-Aas. 12 - As for the sleeper, he makes up the prayers he missed during his sleep state: (If one of you sleeps through prayer or neglects it, let him pray it when he remembers it, for Allah the Mighty and Majestic says: (Establish prayer for My remembrance) (M). 1 - Dhuhr (1) The first time of Dhuhr prayer is when the sun passes the zenith, and its last time is when the time of...
foot_note: 1. (1) It is preferable to start with Fajr. Refer to (Ikhtiyarat Sheikh Al-Islam) (18).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Asr enters. This is a piece of a Hadith by Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Indeed, prayer has a beginning and an end. The beginning of the time for Dhuhr prayer is when the sun passes the zenith, and its last time is when the time of Asr enters. And the beginning of the time for Asr prayer is when its time enters, and its last time is when the sun yellows. And the beginning of the time for Maghrib is when the sun sets, and its last time is when the horizon disappears. And the beginning of the time for the last Isha is when the horizon disappears, and its last time is when the night is half over. And the beginning of the time for Fajr is when the dawn rises, and its last time is when the sun rises). It was narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (1/283-284), Al-Tahawi (1/89 and 93), Al-Daraqutni (97), Al-Bayhaqi (1/375-376), Ahmad (2/232), and Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla) (3/168), all of them via Muhammad bin Fudayl from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from him. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the two Sheikhs. Ibn Hazm authenticated it. Al-Bukhari and others found fault with it stating the correct view is that it is Mursal, but Ibn Hazm and others refuted that, and he was correct, especially since it has a witness from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked about the time of prayers, so he said: (The time for Fajr prayer is as long as the first horn of the sun has not risen. And the time for Dhuhr prayer is when the sun passes the belly of the sky as long as Asr has not arrived. And the time for Asr prayer is as long as the sun has not yellowed and its first horn has not fallen. And the time for Maghrib prayer is when the sun sets as long as the twilight has not fallen. And the time for Isha prayer is until half the night). Narrated by Muslim (2/105) and the wording is his, Abu Dawood (1/64), N (90-91), Al-Tahawi...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...(90 and 93), and Ahmad (2/210 and 213 and 223) from Qatadah from Abu Ayyub from him. And Ibn Hazm narrated it (3/166) and Al-Tayalisi (297). It is recommended to delay it during heat: From Anas bin Malik, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, if it was hot, he would cool down [delay] the prayer, and if it was cold, he would hasten. N (87): Ubaydullah bin Sa'id informed us, he said: Abu Sa'id, the freed slave of Banu Hashim told us, he said: Khalid bin Dinar Abu Khaldah told us, he said: I heard Anas bin Malik with it. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of Al-Bukhari. And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (If the heat intensifies, then cool down for the prayer, for the intensity of heat is from the exhalation of Hell) (The Group). It is the view of Ibn Al-Mubarak, Ahmad, and Ishaq. This applies equally to one aiming for a mosque far from him or close to him due to the Hadith of Abu Dharr regarding cooling down during travel while they were together. See Al-Tirmidhi (296). 2 - Asr: The first time of Asr prayer is when the shadow of everything becomes like it [in length]: From Jabir that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came to him Gabriel and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed Dhuhr when the sun passed the zenith. Then he came to him for Asr and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed Asr when the shadow of everything became like it, or he said: its shadow became like it. Then he came to him for Maghrib and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed when the sun set (wajabat). Then he came to him for Isha and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed when the twilight disappeared. Then he came to him for Fajr and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed when the dawn gleamed, or he said: when the dawn brightened. Then he came to him the next day for Dhuhr and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed Dhuhr when the shadow of...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...everything became like it. Then he came to him for Asr and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed Asr when the shadow of everything became twice like it. Then he came to him for Maghrib (Maghrib) at one time which did not shift. Then he came to him for Isha (Isha) when half the night had gone, or he said: a third of the night. So he prayed Isha. Then he came to him for Fajr when it became very light (Asfara jiddan) and said: Stand and pray it. So he prayed Fajr. Then he said: What is between these two is a time. Narrated by Ahmad (3/330-331) and the wording is his, Al-Nasa'i (91-92), Al-Tirmidhi (1/281), Al-Hakim (195-196), and Al-Daraqutni (95), all of them from the path of Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak: Husayn bin Ali bin Husayn informed us: Wahb bin Kaysan informed me from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). Al-Hakim said: (Sahih famous) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. It has another path from Jabir narrated by Ahmad also (3/351), Al-Nasa'i (88), and Al-Tahawi (88) from the path of Abdullah bin Al-Harith: Thawr bin Yazid told me from Sulayman bin Musa from Ata bin Abi Rabah from him. This is a good (Jayyid) chain. Burd bin Sinan and Abdul Karim bin Abi Al-Mukhariq followed him, both from Ata. Al-Daraqutni and Al-Hakim narrated it. This view is the school of the majority, and a narration from Abu Hanifa in Al-Tahawi (95).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And its last time is when the sun yellows and its first horn falls, as in the Hadiths of Abu Huraira and Ibn Amr previously mentioned. And what indicates that is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Whoever catches a Rak'ah of Asr before the sun sets has caught Asr) (Agreed upon). This is the school of the majority as in (Al-Nayl) (2/267). Among those who said this are Abu Hanifa, Abu Yusuf, and Muhammad bin Al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on them, as in Al-Tahawi (90). As for Al-Shawkani's saying: 'And Abu Hanifa said: Its end is the yellowing,' perhaps it is a narration from Abu Hanifa. However, it is not permissible to delay it until yellowing before sunset except for an excuse. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (That is the prayer of the hypocrite; he sits watching the sun until when it is between the two horns of Satan, he stands and pecks it four times, not remembering Allah except a little) (Narrated by the Group except Al-Bukhari and Ibn Majah). Al-Tirmidhi (300) reported the view of disliking its delay from Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq. It is the view of Ibn Hazm (3/164). It is the Middle Prayer (Al-Salat Al-Wusta). He, peace be upon him, said on the Day of Ahzab (Trench): (May Allah fill their graves and houses with fire as they distracted us from the Middle Prayer until the sun set) (Agreed upon). And for Muslim, Ahmad, and Abu Dawood: (Distracted us from the Middle Prayer, the Asr prayer). And in its meaning are many authentic Hadiths. It is the view of most scholars from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and others, stated by Al-Tirmidhi (1/342).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: 3 - Maghrib: The first time of Maghrib is when the sun sets, and its last time is when the twilight (Shafaq) disappears. This is a piece from the Hadith of Abu Huraira and the Hadith of Ibn Amr also, and they have preceded in the beginning of the chapter. The first ruling is agreed upon, and the other is disputed. Some scholars held that Maghrib has only one time, and they referred to the Hadith of Gabriel, peace be upon him, previously mentioned, in which he prayed Maghrib on both days when the sun set (wajabat) at one time. This is the view of Ibn Al-Mubarak and Al-Shafi'i. However, the authentic Hadiths imply the extension of Maghrib time until the disappearance of the twilight. This is a view of Al-Shafi'i in the Old and New [schools]. A group of Shafi'is authenticated it, and Al-Nawawi chose it and supported it; so refer to his words in (Al-Majmu') (3/29-33). The Hadith of Gabriel only indicates the time of virtue and choice, just as it also indicated that specifically regarding Asr prayer. The Shafaq (twilight) is the redness, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (And the time of Maghrib is as long as the Thawr of the Shafaq has not fallen). Narrated by Muslim (2/104) in a narration from the Hadith of Ibn Amr previously mentioned. It is with Abu Dawood with the wording: Fawr of the Shafaq. It means Thawr, i.e., its rising/eruption. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu') (3/36): (This is a description of the red, not the white). Ibn Khuzaymah narrated it in his (Sahih) explicitly stating that, he said: Ammar bin Khalid told us: Muhammad bin Yazid - he is

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Al-Wasiti - told us, from Shu'bah from Qatadah from Abu Ayyub from Abdullah bin Amr raised [to the Prophet]: (The time of Maghrib prayer is until the redness of the twilight goes...) The Hadith. This is a good (Jayyid) chain, except that Ibn Khuzaymah said after citing it: If this wording is authentic; Muhammad bin Yazid was alone in it, while the companions of Shu'bah only said in it: 'Nur' (light) of the Shafaq instead of 'Humrah' (redness) of the Shafaq. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Talkhis) (3/28): (I say: Muhammad bin Yazid is truthful). And he said in (Al-Taqrib): (Trustworthy, firm, worshipper). The majority of jurists and linguists held that Shafaq is redness, and it is the view of the two Companions [Abu Yusuf and Muhammad]. Al-Bayhaqi narrated it with a Sahih chain from Ibn Umar as in (Tahdhib Al-Asma') (2/165). Al-Daraqutni (100) narrated it raised [to the Prophet] and found fault with it. Then he narrated it from Ubadah bin Al-Samit and Shaddad bin Aws together, and from Abu Huraira as Mawquf (stopped at the companion). Abu Hanifa, Al-Muzani, and a group of jurists and linguists said: The intended is the white [twilight] which is after the red. It says in (Sharh Muslim): (The first is the preponderant view). And Ibn Hazm went to it (3/192-194). It is recommended to hasten to Maghrib prayer and accelerate it before the stars appear/intertwine, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (My Ummah will not cease to be in good - or upon the Fitrah - as long as they do not delay Maghrib until the stars intertwine). It is a Sahih Hadith by its paths, and I have mentioned many of them in the commentary on

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Al-Tabarani number (365). Al-Hakim and Al-Dhahabi authenticated it. This does not contradict praying the two Rak'ahs before Maghrib due to their establishment from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, by word and approval. He, peace be upon him, said: (Between every two Adhans is a prayer, between every two Adhans is a prayer), then he said in the third: (For whoever wills). (The Group) and Ibn Nasr (26). In a narration: (Pray before Maghrib two Rak'ahs) then he said: (Pray before Maghrib two Rak'ahs) then he said at the third: (For whoever wills) out of dislike that people might take it as a Sunnah. (Ham, Kh, D, N, Qut). Anas said: The Mu'adhin used to call Adhan, and people from the companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, would stand rushing to the pillars until the Prophet came out while they were like that praying two Rak'ahs before Maghrib; there was nothing between the Adhan and Iqamah. And in a narration: Except a little. (Ham, Kh, Ibn Nasr). And in a narration: It was said to him: Did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, pray them? He said: He used to see us praying them and did not order us nor forbid us. (M, D, Qut: 100). It has a witness from the Hadith of Uqbah in (Kh, Ham, Qut, Ibn Nasr). As for what Abu Dawood alone narrated (202) from the path of Shu'bah from Abu Shu'ayb from Tawus who said: Ibn Umar was asked about the two Rak'ahs before Maghrib, so he said: I did not see anyone during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, praying them. Even though he is negating - and it is known that the affirming takes precedence over the negating - it does not equal in authenticity what preceded, for this Abu Shu'ayb, his name is Shu'ayb and is not very well known. Abu Zur'ah said regarding him:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (There is no harm in him). And likewise in (Al-Taqrib). He remained silent on the Hadith in (Al-Talkhis) (4/8) and in (Al-Dirayah) (119). As for Al-Nawawi, he said in (Al-Majmu') (4/8): (Its chain is Hasan). And Allah knows best. Then, after writing what preceded, I returned to (Al-Muhalla) by Ibn Hazm, and found him saying (2/254) - and he mentioned this Hadith of Ibn Umar -: (It is not authentic because it is from Abu Shu'ayb or Shu'ayb, and we do not know who he is). That's it. However, if dinner (Al-Asha) is placed and his self yearns for it, he should start with it even if that leads to delaying the prayer. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (If dinner is served, start with it before Maghrib prayer, and do not rush your dinner) (Agreed upon). This applies to every prayer. He, peace be upon him, said: (If prayer is established and dinner is present, start with dinner). And he said: (There is no prayer in the presence of food) (M). Food would be placed for Ibn Umar and prayer would be established, so he would not come to it until he finished, while he could hear the recitation of the Imam. This is emphasized for the fasting person due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (People will not cease to be in good as long as they hasten the Iftar) (Agreed upon). It is not permissible to name it [Maghrib] Isha due to his saying, peace be upon him: (Do not let the Bedouins overcome you regarding the name of your prayer Maghrib). He said: (And the Bedouins say: It is Isha). Narrated by Al-Bukhari in (Prayer: Chapter on he who disliked that Maghrib be called: Isha). And Ahmad (5/55). In (Al-Muntaqa) he attributed it to Muslim also, saying: (Agreed upon), which is a delusion/error, for it is not in Muslim. The author of (Al-Mashariq) restricted its attribution to Al-Bukhari, and likewise Al-Nawawi in (Al-Majmu') (3/29). Al-Sindi said: It seems the meaning in it and similar ones is the prohibition of frequently using the language of the Bedouins such that the language of Bedouins prevails over the Sharia name, so the usage of the Sharia name becomes rare among people and the usage of the Bedouin name becomes frequent. So it does not contradict using the name Isha rarely. For this reason, a similar prohibition came regarding using the name Al-Atamah for Isha, then the usage of the name Al-Atamah for Isha came in the Sharia rarely. And Allah knows best. 4 - Isha: Its first time is when the twilight disappears, which is the red one - as preceded. Among the arguments of those who said this is what Ibn Sayyid Al-Nas said in Sharh Al-Tirmidhi: (And everyone who has knowledge of risings and settings knows that the white [twilight] does not disappear except at the first third of the night with certainty. And this is

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: what he, peace and blessings be upon him, defined the exit of most of the time by. So it is authentic with certainty that its time enters before the first third of the night with certainty. Thus it is established from the text that it enters before the disappearance of the twilight which is the white one. So it became clear by that with certainty that the time enters by the twilight which is the redness). Al-Shawkani quoted it (2/9). Ibn Hazm preceded to this meaning in (Al-Muhalla) (2/193). Ibn Sayyid Al-Nas seemed to have taken it from him. This is the school of the majority. And its last time is when the night is half over, as in the Hadith of Abu Huraira and Ibn Amr previously mentioned. It is the school of Ibn Hazm (2/164). He narrated it from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, with the wording: (And pray the Isha prayer from Isha to half the night, meaning when you sleep (tabit)). (It is written in the original without dots. Like this in (Al-Muhalla). I say: The correct reading is: 'You wish' (Shi'ta). Ibn Hazm mentioned it from the path of Al-Hajjaj bin Minhal: Yazid bin Harun told us: Muhammad bin Sirin told us from Al-Muhajir that Umar bin Al-Khattab wrote to Abu Musa with it. Al-Tahawi narrated it (1/94) from the path of Abu Umar Al-Hawdi - his name is Hafs bin Umar - he said: Yazid bin Harun told us with it with the wording: Meaning when you wish. This is a Sahih chain, its men are the men of the two Sheikhs. This Al-Muhajir is Abu Al-Hasan as Ibn Hazm explicitly stated (190). This narration has another path narrated by Malik (1/25) from the path of Hisham bin Urwah from his father that Umar bin Al-Khattab wrote to Abu Musa with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (And pray Isha between you and a third of the night; and if you wish, then to half of the night, and do not be of the heedless). This is a very Sahih chain. As for what Al-Tahawi narrated from the path of Sufyan Al-Thawri from Habib bin Abi Thabit from Nafi bin Jubayr who said: Umar wrote to Abu Musa: (And pray Isha any [time of] night you wish and do not neglect it), it contradicts what preceded. The defect of this narration is the interruption between Habib and Nafi, for Habib, although trustworthy, was frequent in sending Mursal narrations and Tadlis (obfuscating chain) as in (Al-Taqrib). And you see that he used 'an' (from) and did not explicitly state hearing it, so his narration is not used as evidence, especially since it contradicted what trustworthy narrators narrated. This view [of extended time] was narrated from Malik as a saying in (Bidayat Al-Mujtahid) (75). It is the view of Abu Sa'id Al-Istakhri who said: (If a third of the night or its half goes, the prayer is missed and becomes Qada). Mentioned in (Al-Muhadhdhab). It is the apparent meaning of Imam Al-Shafi'i's saying in the chapter of Facing the Qibla: (If a third of the night passes, I do not see it except as missed). Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab) (3/40): (Some of our companions agreed with Al-Istakhri due to the apparent meaning of this text, and the majority interpreted it). I say: Among Al-Shafi'i's proofs for his view of the third is the Hadith of Aisha who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, delayed Isha one night until it was dark (Atamah). So Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, called out to him: The women slept...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: and the boys. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out and said: (No one is waiting for it other than you). And he was not praying on that day except in Medina. Then he said: (Pray it in the time between the disappearance of twilight to a third of the night). Narrated by Al-Nasa'i from the path of Ibn Humayr, he said: Ibn Abi Ailah told us from Al-Zuhri from Urwah from her. This is a good (Jayyid) chain, its men are trustworthy except Ibn Humayr, his name is Muhammad; some spoke about him although he is from the men of Al-Bukhari. He [Bukhari] narrated it in his (Sahih) from the path of Salih bin Kaysan: Ibn Shihab informed me with it similarly, except that he said instead of 'Then he said: Pray it... etc': He said: And they used to pray Isha in the time between the disappearance of twilight to the first third of the night. However, the limitation of Isha prayer time to half (the night) has been established in the two previous Hadiths, and it is an addition that must be accepted as is obvious. Other Hadiths have come regarding that, including the Hadith of Anas who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, delayed Isha prayer to half the night, then he prayed, then he said: (The people have prayed and slept. Beware, you are indeed in prayer as long as you waited for it). Kh, Ham (3/200), and Al-Tahawi (94), both from Humayd Al-Tawil from him. Al-Nasa'i narrated it (93) from this aspect with the wording: (To near half (shatr) the night). It is a narration of Ahmad (3/189). And it has other paths, including from Thabit from him with the wording: (To half the night) or (Almost...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: half the night goes). Narrated by Muslim (2/116) and Ahmad (267), and he does not have: (To half the night), but rather he said: (Until half the night almost went). Among them is from Qurrah bin Khalid from Qatadah from Anas with the wording: (Until it was near half the night). Narrated by Muslim also and Al-Tayalisi (267). He said: (Until half the night passed). This wording is odd (Shadh), contradictory to other narrations. And among them is from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet]: (Were it not that I would burden my Ummah, I would have ordered them to delay Isha to a third of the night or its half). Narrated by T and he authenticated it, Maj (234), Ham (250-433) from Ubaydullah bin Umar from Sa'id Al-Maqburi from him. Its men are the men of the two Sheikhs. Al-Hakim narrated it (1/146) from another path from Sa'id with the wording: (To half the night) without doubt. Ahmad narrated it from another path from Abu Huraira with the wording: (To a third of the night) without doubt. Therefore, he narrated it from another aspect from Sa'id from Ata, the freed slave of Safiyyah, from Abu Huraira. There is confusion in this wording. See the commentary on Al-Tirmidhi.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And among them is the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, he said: We prayed the prayer of Al-Atamah (Isha) with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and he did not come out until about half (shatr) the night passed. He said: (Take your seats). So we took our seats. He said: (Indeed, the people have prayed and taken to their beds, and indeed you will not cease to be in prayer as long as you wait for the prayer. And were it not for the weakness of the weak and the illness of the sick, I would have delayed this prayer to half the night). Narrated by D (69) and the wording is his, N (92), Maj (234-235), and Ham (3/5) from the path of Dawud bin Abi Hind from Abu Nadrah from him. This is a Sahih chain as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Talkhis) (3/29). I say: And it is on the condition of Muslim. We did not find for those who held - and they are the majority - that the time of Isha extends to Fajr prayer except two Hadiths, and they are not explicit text in that: The first: From Abu Qatadah raised [to the Prophet]: (There is no negligence in sleep; negligence is only upon the one who does not pray the prayer until the time of the other prayer comes). Some of the early literalists (Ahl al-Zahir) used it as evidence for what we mentioned. And Al-Shawkani the investigator from the later scholars (1/10). Ibn Hazm refuted that strongly, saying (3/178): This does not indicate what they said at all. They agree with us without dispute from any of the Imams that the time of Fajr prayer does not extend to the time of Dhuhr prayer. So it is correct that this report does not indicate the connection of the time of every prayer to the time of the one after it. Rather, it only contains the sin of one who delays a prayer to the time of another only, whether the end of its time connects to the beginning of the second for it or does not connect. And there is not in it...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...that he is not negligent also if he delays it until its time exits even if the time of another does not enter, nor that he is [not] negligent; rather, it is silent in this report. But its explanation is in other reports which contain text on the exit of the time of every prayer. Necessity dictates that whoever transgresses with any deed its time which Allah defined for that deed, he has transgressed the limits of Allah. And Allah the Exalted said: (And whoever transgresses the limits of Allah - it is those who are the wrongdoers). And the second Hadith is from Aisha, she said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, delayed Isha one night until the general part of the night went and until the people of the mosque slept. Then he came out and prayed and said: (Indeed, it is its time were it not that I would burden my Ummah). Muslim (2/116), N (93), Mi (1/276), and Al-Tahawi (94) from the path of Ibn Jurayj, he said: Al-Mughirah bin Hakim informed me from Umm Kulthum bint Abi Bakr that she informed him from her. So the apparent meaning of the Hadith is that he prayed it after the first half of the night passed. However, the Hadith is interpreted. Al-Nawawi said: (The intended meaning by 'general part of the night' is much of it, and the intended is not the majority of it. This interpretation is necessary due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: 'Indeed, it is its time'. And it is not permissible that the meaning of this statement is what is after half the night because no one from the scholars said that delaying it to after half the night is better). I say: What indicates this interpretation is that the Hadith came in Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, and Al-Musnad (6/43, 215, and 272) from paths from Al-Zuhri from...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Urwah from Aisha, and it does not contain her saying: (until the general part of the night went). Rather, it contains: (Until Umar bin Al-Khattab called out to him: The women and boys have slept). And that usually happens before half the night. This is strengthened by the fact that Ibn Abbas narrated this Hadith more completely than it, saying: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, delayed Isha one night until [part] of the night went. So Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, stood and called out: Prayer, O Messenger of Allah, the women and children have slept. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out while water was dripping from his head, and he was saying: (Indeed, it is the time, were it not that I would burden my Ummah). Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (92) and Al-Darimi (276) from the path of Sufyan from Amr from Ata from him, and from Ibn Jarir from Ata from him. These are two Sahih chains on the condition of the two Sheikhs. Muslim (117) and Ahmad (1/366) narrated it from Ibn Jurayj with it, and it contains the explicit statement of Ibn Jurayj hearing from Ata. So this narration indicates that the Hadith of Aisha by the narration of Umm Kulthum from her, and her Hadith by the narration of Urwah from her, are but one Hadith which some narrators abbreviated. It indicates clearly that his saying in it: (Indeed, it is the time) intends by it the time when the women and children slept, and that is before half the night usually as we said. So the Hadith returns to [the meaning] that the intended by 'general part of the night' is much of it, not the majority of it, as Al-Nawawi said, and this is from the precision of his understanding, may Allah have mercy on him. Even if one must take the apparent meaning of Umm Kulthum's Hadith from her, this only indicates that he prayed it at the beginning of the second half. For that reason, Ibn Hazm said (3/184):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (If half the night goes, the general part of the night has gone). And upon this he built his saying in the beginning of the chapter (3/164): (Then the time of Atamah (Isha) continues until the expiration of the first half of the night and the beginning of the second half. So whoever says Takbir for it in the beginning of the second half of the night has caught the prayer of Atamah without dislike nor necessity. If he exceeds that, the time for entering the prayer of Atamah has exited). As for it indicating the extension of the time to Fajr prayer as Al-Tahawi claimed, there is not the slightest evidence in it for that. It is a view of Al-Shafi'i as Al-Shawkani mentioned (2/10). And the night ends with the rising of the true dawn, which is the school of the Shafi'is and all scholars. Refer to (Al-Majmu') (3/10). He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to prefer delaying Isha. (Narrated by the Group). Ahmad added (4/424 and 425): To a third of the night. Its chain is Sahih on their condition. And he encourages that, saying: (Delay this prayer (Atimu), for you have been favored by it over all other nations, and no nation before you prayed it). Abu Dawood (69) and Ham (5/237) from the path of Hariz bin Uthman: Rashid bin Sa'd told us from Asim bin Humayd Al-Sakuni - and he was from the companions of Mu'adh bin Jabal - that he heard Mu'adh bin Jabal say: We waited for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, for the Isha prayer, and he delayed until we thought he would not come out, and one of us said: He has prayed and will not come out. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... so he mentioned it. Abu Dawood added:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: So we remained like that until the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out. They said to him as they had said. So he said to them... The Hadith. This is a good (Jayyid) chain. Regarding this waiting, the saying of the Exalted was revealed: (They are not [all] the same; among the People of the Scripture... And Allah is Knowing of the righteous) [Al Imran / 113-115]. Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, delayed the Isha prayer then came out to the mosque, and behold, people were waiting for the prayer. He said: (Beware, there is no one from the people of these religions remembering Allah at this hour other than you). He said: And these verses were revealed: (They are not [all] the same; among the People of the Scripture...) until he reached: (And whatever good they do - never will it be denied them. And Allah is Knowing of the righteous). Narrated by Ahmad (1/394) from Shayban from Asim from Zirr from him. This is a Hasan chain. He used to not make it determined upon them due to the hardship in it as preceded. Despite that, he, peace be upon him, used to consider the conditions of those gathered, few or many. He would sometimes delay it and sometimes hasten. If he saw them gathered, he hastened, and if he saw them slow, he delayed. (Kh, M, Ham: 3/369) and Taya (124) from Abu Barza.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And Aisha said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, never slept before Isha nor conversed (Samar) after it. Maj (238), Taya (201), Ham (6/264) from the path of Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Ya'la Al-Ta'ifi from Abdul Rahman bin Al-Qasim from his father from her. This is a Hasan chain, and its men are the men of Muslim. The author of (Al-Zawa'id) said: It is Sahih. It has another path in Ibn Nasr, he said: Mahmud bin Adam told us: Yahya bin Sulaym told us: Hisham bin Urwah told us, he said: I heard my father say: I returned after the last Isha and heard the speech of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, my maternal aunt, while we were in a room with a roof between us and her. She said: O Urwah or O Urayyah! What is this Samar (night conversation)? I never saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, sleeping before this prayer nor speaking after it; either sleeping and safe, or praying and gaining [reward]. This is also an improved (Muhassan) chain, and its men are the men of Al-Bukhari. Ibn Masud said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, scolded (Jadaba) (1) us for Samar after Isha, meaning: he rebuked us.
foot_note: 1. (1) It is with Jim (J) according to all who extracted it, and it came explained in Ibn Majah with what you see. Ahmad said: Khalid - he is one of the narrators from Ata - said: The meaning of 'Jadaba ilayna' (scolded us) is he criticized and blamed it. I say: And this is how he explained it in (Al-Nihayah). Al-Tahawi (2/390) narrated it from the path of Wuhaib and Hammad bin Salamah from Ata with the wording: 'Hadaba ilayna' (urged us) with the unpointed Ha (H). It is not a typo, for Al-Tahawi made it evidence for the permissibility of Samar in what is an act of closeness, so he said: And he urged (Hadaba) them to what is an act of closeness. So I do not know if that was misspelled by Al-Tahawi or by someone above him? And Allah knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Narrated by Ibn Majah (238) and Ahmad (1/388-389, 410) from three paths from Ata bin Al-Sa'ib from Shaqiq bin Salamah from him. Its men are the men of Al-Bukhari, but Ata had become confused. Al-Tirmidhi said: Most scholars disliked sleeping before Isha prayer and talking after it, and some of them permitted that. Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak said: Most Hadiths are for dislike. What appears from the sum of Hadiths reported in this chapter is the dislike of Samar and staying up late except in what is beneficial to the speaker or beneficial to the Muslims. Regarding that are Hadiths: (1) From Umar bin Al-Khattab, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to converse (yasmuur) with Abu Bakr regarding the command from the commands of Muslims, and I was with them. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (1/315), Ibn Nasr (46), and Al-Tahawi (391) from the path of Abu Mu'awiyah from Al-A'mash from Ibrahim from Alqamah from him. This is a Sahih chain on their condition. Al-Tirmidhi restricted himself to calling it Hasan, which is a shortcoming as clarified by the commentator on it. Ahmad (1/25-26) narrated it with two chains from Umar, saying: Abu Mu'awiyah told us: Al-A'mash told us from Ibrahim from Alqamah, he said: A man came to Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, while he was at Arafat. [Abu] Mu'awiyah said: And Al-A'mash told us from Khaythamah from Qays bin Marwan - or he said he came to Umar, may Allah be pleased with him... So he mentioned the Hadith at length. So Al-A'mash has two chains in the Hadith; the first is Sahih as we mentioned, and likewise...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the other is Sahih, and its men are the men of the two Sheikhs except Qays bin Marwan Abu Qays, and he is truthful (Saduq) as in (Al-Taqrib). (2) From Ibn Abbas, that he said: I slept in the house of Maimuna on a night when the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was with her, to look at how the prayer of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was at night. He said: So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, spoke with his family for a while then slept. Narrated by Muslim (2/182) and Ibn Nasr (46). (3) From Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that Usaid bin Hudair and another man from the Ansar spoke in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, one night regarding a need of theirs until a period of the night went, and the night was intensely dark. Then they left the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, returning, and in the hand of each one was a staff. The staff of one of them lit up for them until they walked in its light. When the road separated them, the staff of the other lit up for him, so each one of them walked in his light until he reached his family. Narrated by Ibn Nasr from Abdur-Razzaq: Ma'mar informed us from Thabit from him. This is a Sahih chain on the condition of the Six. What indicates the reconciliation we mentioned is: What Abu Sa'id, the freed slave of the Ansar, narrated; he said: Umar would not leave anyone talking (samir) after Isha, saying: Go back, perhaps Allah will grant you a prayer or night prayer (Tahajjud). He reached us while I was sitting with Ibn Masud, Ubayy bin Ka'b, and Abu Dharr. He said: What makes you sit? We said: We wanted to remember Allah. So he sat with them.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Narrated by Al-Tahawi (2/391) from the path of Sulayman bin Shu'ayb: Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad told us, he said: Shu'bah told us from Al-Jurayri, he said: I heard Abu Nadrah narrating from Abu Sa'id with it. This Abu Sa'id and Abdur-Rahman bin Ziyad, I did not know them. It is possible that this Abdur-Rahman is Ibn Ziyad bin An'um Al-Ifriqi, and he is weak in Hadith. It is disliked to name Isha 'Al-Atamah'. He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Let not the Bedouins overcome you regarding the name of your prayer: Al-Isha, for it is in the Book of Allah 'Al-Isha', and they milk [their camels] at nightfall (yu'timun) with the milk of camels). (M 118), D (2/312), N (93-94), Maj (239), Ham (2/10, 19, 49, and 144) from Abdullah bin Abi Labid from Abu Salamah bin Abdur-Rahman from Ibn Umar. And in a narration by Ahmad: (They only call it Al-Atamah because of their milking of camels at nightfall). Its chain is Sahih on the condition of Muslim. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Huraira narrated by Ibn Majah from the path of Abdur-Rahman bin Harmalah from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from him. Its chain is good (Jayyid). He said in (Al-Zawa'id): Sahih. It has another path from him narrated by him and Ahmad (2/433, 438) from Muhammad bin Ajlan: Sa'id - meaning Al-Maqburi - told me from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet] briefly. Its chain is Hasan also. There is no harm in that [using the name Atamah] rarely due to its being established from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (If they knew what is in Al-Atamah...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and Al-Subh, they would come to them even if crawling) Kh, M (2-31), N (93), Ham (2/278, 303, 374, and 533), Malik (1/87-88), all of them from him from Sumayy, the freed slave of Abu Bakr bin Abdur-Rahman, from Abu Salih Al-Samman from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet] with it in his Hadith. Ahmad added in a narration from Abdur-Razzaq from Malik: I said to Malik: Is it disliked that we say: Al-Atamah? He said: Thus said the one who told me. And that was established from some of the Companions like Jabir bin Samurah in Muslim (118) and Ahmad (5/89 and 105) and others, and Jabir bin Abdullah in Ahmad (3/348) and others. Ibn Al-Qayyim (2/12) said after mentioning the Hadith of Ibn Umar then this Hadith of Abu Huraira: (It was said: This abrogates the prohibition, and it was said the opposite. The correct view is contrary to both sayings, for knowledge of dates is impossible, and there is no contradiction between the two Hadiths. He did not forbid the utterance of the name Al-Atamah completely, but rather he forbade that the name Al-Isha be abandoned, which is the name Allah called it in His Book, and that the name Al-Atamah prevails over it. So if it is called Al-Isha and sometimes Al-Atamah is applied to it, there is no harm. And Allah knows best. This is preservation from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, of the names with which Allah named the acts of worship, so they are not abandoned and others preferred over them, as the later generations did in abandoning the words of the texts and preferring newly invented terminologies over them. And due to this, corruption arose of which Allah is Aware).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: 5 - Fajr 1 - Its first time is when the dawn rises as preceded in the Hadith of Abu Huraira. 2 - And (The dawn is not the one which says like this (and he gathered his fingers then inverted them towards the earth), but the one which says like this (and he placed the index finger upon the index finger and extended his hands). Muslim (3/129) and Kh, and he added: to his right and his left. 3 - He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to pray it in Ghalas (darkness of the end of night). (Agreed upon from Jabir). 4 - He did not enter it in Isfar (light) except once. Abu Masud Al-Ansari said in a Hadith of his: And he prayed Subh once in Ghalas, then prayed another time and made it Isfar (light); his prayer after that was Ghalas until he died, he did not return to making it Isfar. Narrated by Abu Dawood (65), Taha (104), Al-Daraqutni (93), and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) as in Nasb Al-Rayah (240) from the path of Usama bin Zaid Al-Laithi that Ibn Shihab informed him from Urwah: I heard Bashir bin Abi Masud say: I heard Abu Masud with it. This is a Hasan chain as Al-Nawawi said (3/52). Al-Khattabi said: (It is Sahih in chain). As for what Ahmad narrated (2/135-136) from the path of Abu Shu'bah Al-Tahhan, the neighbor of Al-A'mash, from Abu Al-Rabi', he said: I was with Ibn Umar... so I said to him: I pray Subh with you then I turn and do not see the face of my sitting companion, then sometimes you make it Isfar? He said: Thus I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, praying, and I loved to pray it as I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...pray it. It is weak and does not stand against it [the previous Hadith]. Its defect is this Abu Al-Rabi'. Al-Daraqutni said: (Unknown). Moreover, it is contradicted from Ibn Umar by what is stronger than it in chain. Nahik bin Yarim said: Mughith bin Sumayy told us, he said: I prayed Subh with Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr in Ghalas. When he said Salam, I turned to Ibn Umar and said: What is this prayer? He said: This was our prayer with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and Abu Bakr and Umar. When Umar was stabbed, Uthman made it Isfar. Narrated by Ibn Majah (229-230) and Al-Tahawi (104) from him. This is a Sahih chain as in (Al-Zawa'id) and in (Al-Majmu') (3/53). Al-Tirmidhi said in (Kitab Al-Ilal): Al-Bukhari said: This is a Hasan Hadith. 5 - Sometimes he would exit from it in Ghalas as Aisha said: The believing women used to witness the Fajr prayer with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, wrapped in their garments (muroot), then they would return to their houses when they finished the prayer, no one recognizing them due to the Ghalas. Kh, M (2/119), N (94), Mi (277), Ibn Majah (669), Taya (206), Ham (6/33, 37, and 248), and Al-Tahawi (104) from Al-Zuhri from Urwah from Aisha with it. It has two other paths from her: (1) Malik (21) from Yahya bin Sa'id from Amrah bint Abdur-Rahman from her. Muslim, Abu Dawood (69), N, and T (287) narrated it, and he [Tirmidhi] said: Hasan Sahih, and Al-Tahawi...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and Ahmad (1/178-179), all from Malik with it. (2) From Abdul Rahman bin Al-Qasim from Al-Qasim bin Muhammad from her. Narrated by Al-Tahawi and Ahmad (6/258-259). It has a witness from the Hadith of Qilah in Tab (230), Taha (105), and from Harmalah Al-Anbari with him, and likewise Al-Tayalisi (167). 6 - And sometimes he would exit from it in Isfar when a man recognizes the face of his sitting companion, as Abu Barza Al-Aslamis said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to turn away from the morning prayer (Ghadah) when a man recognized his sitting companion. Kh, M (119-120), D (66), N (92), Taha (105), Taya (124), Ham (4/420, 423, 424, and 425) from Sayyar bin Salamah from him. 7 - This Isfar is the intended meaning of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Make Fajr light (Asfiru), for it is greater in reward), meaning: exit from it at the time of Isfar, and that is by prolonging the recitation in it. This interpretation is necessary so that his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, agrees with his action which he persisted upon of entering it at the time of Ghalas as preceded. This is what Hafiz Ibn Al-Qayyim preferred in (I'lam Al-Muwaqqi'in). Imam Al-Tahawi from the Hanafis preceded him to that and elaborated on establishing that (1/104-109). He said: (It is the view of Abu Hanifa, Abu Yusuf, and Muhammad), even if what he reported from the three Imams contradicts what is famous from them in the books of the Madhhab regarding the recommendation of starting with Isfar. Among the later Hanafis, Allamah Abu Al-Hasanat Al-Lucknawi also inclined to this reconciliation in (Al-Ta'liq lil-Majd) (42-44). As for the mentioned Hadith, it is a Sahih Hadith but disputed in its wording. Al-Tirmidhi (289), Al-Darimi (277 T), Al-Tahawi (106), and Al-Tayalisi (129) narrated it with the mentioned wording, all from Muhammad bin Ishaq from Asim bin Umar bin Qatadah from Mahmoud bin Labid from Rafi' bin Khadij with it. This is a Hasan chain were it not for the 'an'anah (using 'from') of Muhammad bin Ishaq, for he is a Mudallis, so it is possible he heard it via an intermediary from Asim. What supports this possibility will come. Abu Dawood (69), Ibn Majah (230), and Ahmad (4/140) narrated it, all from Sufyan bin Uyaynah from Ibn Ajlan from Asim with it with the wording: Asbihu (Enter the morning). Instead of: Asfiru. Likewise, Ibn Ishaq narrated it from Ibn Ajlan, so Ahmad said (3/465): Yazid told us, he said: Muhammad bin Ishaq told us, he said: Ibn Ajlan informed us with it. Abu Khalid Al-Ahmar contradicted them from Ibn Ajlan, narrating it from him with the wording: (Asfiru). Ahmad narrated it from him (4/142), and likewise Yahya bin Sa'id in Al-Nasa'i, and Sufyan Al-Thawri in Al-Tahawi (105), and likewise Al-Darimi except he said: (Nawwiru - Illuminate). Ibn Ajlan was followed in it; Zaid bin Aslam narrated it from Asim bin Umar but there was disagreement on him regarding it in chain and text. As for the chain, Abu Ghassan narrated it: Zaid bin Aslam told me from Asim bin Umar from Mahmoud from Labid from men of his people from the Ansar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... so he mentioned it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Al-Nasa'i narrated it. And Al-Layth bin Sa'd and Asbat bin Muhammad narrated it. As for the first, he said: Hisham bin Sa'd told me from Zaid bin Aslam from Asim from men of his people from the Ansar from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said. Al-Tahawi (106) narrated it. As for the other, he said: Hisham bin Sa'd told us from Zaid bin Aslam from Mahmoud bin Labid from some Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... Ahmad narrated it (4/243). So the first dropped Mahmoud bin Labid, the Sheikh of Asim bin Umar, from the chain, and the other dropped Asim bin Umar, the Sheikh of Zaid bin Aslam. As for the text, Abu Ghassan said: (Whatever Isfar (light) you make with Fajr). Al-Layth said: (Asbihu (Enter morning) with Subh, for whenever you enter morning with it). And Asbat said: (Asfiru). Hafs bin Maysarah followed Hisham from Zaid like the narration of Al-Layth in chain and text. Al-Tahawi narrated it (105-106). And Abdul Rahman bin Zaid bin Aslam narrated it from his father from Mahmoud bin Labid Al-Ansari, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Asfiru...) The Hadith. This is another difference, but Abdul Rahman bin Zaid is weak. Shu'bah narrated it from Abu Dawood from Zaid bin Asqat from Mahmoud bin Labid from Rafi' bin Khadij raised [to the Prophet] with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This Abu Dawood is Nufay' Al-A'ma, and he is Matruk (abandoned), and Ibn Ma'in declared him a liar. There is another disagreement on Zaid bin Aslam mentioned in (Nasb Al-Rayah) (1/236), so refer to it. In summary, this is intense confusion in the Hadith. The correct view regarding the chain is the narration of Ibn Ajlan from Asim bin Umar from Mahmoud bin Labid from Rafi' bin Khadij due to two matters: For its connection, and for its agreement with the narration of Abu Ghassan from Zaid bin Aslam in text and chain, except for the ambiguity of its narrators from the Companions from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, which is not a grave contradiction as is obvious. Its chain is Sahih as in (Nasb Al-Rayah) (238). The Hadith has many witnesses whose chains are not free from criticism. Al-Zayla'i extracted them, and likewise Al-Haythami in (Al-Majmu') (1/315-317), so whoever wishes may refer to them. All of them are with the wording: (Asfiru). And some: (Nawwiru). So they generally support the wording which we preferred from the Hadith of Rafi', which is: Asfiru. However, you have known from what preceded that the meaning is not: Make it Isfar at the beginning, but at the end. Except that what Ibn Abi Hatim extracted in (Al-Ilal) (1/139 and 143-144), Al-Tayalisi (129), Ibn Abi Shaybah, Ishaq bin Rahwayh in his Musnads, and Al-Tabarani in his (Mu'jam) from the path of Ismail bin Ibrahim Al-Madini from Hurayr bin Abdul Rahman bin Rafi' bin Khadij from Rafi' bin Khadij disturbs this meaning. He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to Bilal: (Make the Subh prayer light (Asfir) until the people see the locations of their arrows). This is a chain whose men are trustworthy, but I do not see that this Hurayr bin Abdul Rahman heard it...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...from his grandfather Rafi', for he only narrates from his father Abdul Rahman. Al-Hafiz mentioned in (Al-Taqrib) that he is from the fifth class, meaning the minor class of Tabi'in who saw one or two Companions, and hearing from Companions is not established for some of them like Al-A'mash. Thus, it appears the Hadith is Munqati' (interrupted). Even if it were authentic, it could be interpreted like what preceded in the Hadith of Rafi', so his saying: 'Until the people see the locations of their arrows' means: at the time of finishing it, not the beginning. And what Al-Bukhari (3/427), M (4/76), D (1/305), N (2/47), Ham (1/426 and 434) narrated from the Hadith of Ibn Masud, who said: I never saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, pray a prayer except at its appointed time except two prayers: Maghrib and Isha at Jam' (Muzdalifah), and he prayed Fajr that day before its appointed time. And in a narration of Al-Bukhari (3/467) and Ahmad (418 and 449) from Abdul Rahman bin Yazid who said: I went out with Abdullah [bin Masud], may Allah be pleased with him, to Mecca, then we arrived at Jam'. So he prayed the two prayers, each prayer alone with Adhan and Iqamah, and dinner between them. Then he prayed Fajr when dawn rose. Someone said: Dawn has risen. And someone said: Dawn has not risen. Then he said: Indeed, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Indeed, these two prayers were shifted from their time in this place, Maghrib and Isha, so people should not arrive at Jam' until they pray Isha (yu'timu), and this Fajr prayer at this hour). This narration clarifies that his saying in the first narration: 'And he prayed Fajr that day before...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...its appointed time' is not upon its literal meaning, due to his saying in this one: 'Then he prayed Fajr when dawn rose'. This is like the statement of Jabir in his long Hadith: 'And he prayed Fajr when the dawn became clear to him'. Narrated by Muslim and others. So the meaning, therefore, is that he prayed Fajr before its usual appointed time [for him], meaning: he prayed in Ghalas (darkness) intensely, contradicting the usual Ghalas to the extent that some of them doubted the rising of dawn. Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) (3/413): (There is no proof in it for those who prevent Ghalas in Fajr prayer, because Ghalas in it is established from Aisha and others as preceded. Rather, the meaning here is that when the Mu'adhin came to him at the rising of dawn, he prayed the two Rak'ahs of Fajr [Sunnah] in his house then came out and prayed Subh with that in Ghalas. As for Muzdalifah, the people were gathered and the dawn was before their eyes, so they hastened to prayer as soon as it emerged, such that some of them did not perceive its rising as in the second narration). 1 - If it is the habit of the Imams to delay the prayer from its chosen time, the Muslim should pray it in the time in his house, then pray it with them whenever they pray, and it will be a voluntary prayer (Nafilah) for him. The Second: Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to me: (How will you be if there are rulers over you who delay the prayer from its time or kill the prayer from its time?) He said: I said: So what do you order me? He said: (Pray the prayer at its time, then if you catch it with them, pray, for it will be a voluntary prayer for you).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: M (2/120), D (70-71), T (1/232), Mi (279), Taha (1/263), Taya (60), Ham (5/149, 163, and 169) from paths from Abu Imran Al-Jawni from Abdullah bin Al-Samit from him. The context is Muslim's then Abu Dawood's, and the others do not have his saying: (or kill the prayer), which is doubt from some of the narrators with them. It appears to be Hammad bin Zaid, for everyone who narrated it from Abu Imran said: (Delay the prayer) without doubt. This, and Ahmad added in a narration from the path of Salih bin Rustum from him after his saying: (Pray the prayer at its time): And perhaps he said: (In your saddlebag/dwelling). Salih is from the men of Muslim, but some spoke about him; it is said in (Al-Taqrib): (He is truthful, frequent in mistakes). I found a witness for this addition from the Hadith of Ibn Masud as will come. Then the Hadith has other paths from Abdullah bin Al-Samit: M, N (138), Mi, Taha, Taya (61), Ham (5/168) narrated it from the path of Shu'bah from Budayl, he said: I heard Abu Al-Aliyah narrating from Abdullah bin Al-Samit from Abu Dharr, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said - and struck my thigh -: How will you be if you remain among a people who delay the prayer from its time?) He said: So he said: What do you order? He said: (Pray the prayer at its time then go for your need. If prayer is established while you are in the mosque, then pray). Then Al-Bukhari narrated it in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) (138 and 139) and Muslim and Ham (147, 160, and 168) from Ayyub from Abu Al-Aliyah with it. Similar to it with the wording: (So if you catch...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the prayer with them, pray and do not say: I have prayed so I will not pray). Then he also narrated it (5/159 Musnad) from the path of Abu Na'amah from Abdullah bin Al-Samit, so the addition: (Then pray with them for it is an increase of good). The Hadith has witnesses: (1) From Ubadah bin Al-Samit, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Indeed there will be rulers over you after me whom things will distract from prayer at its time until its time goes, so pray the prayer at its time). A man said: O Messenger of Allah, do I pray with them? He said: (Yes, if you wish). D (71), Ham (315) from Jarir and Sufyan Al-Thawri, both from Mansur from Hilal bin Yasaf from Abu Yasaf from Abu Al-Muthanna Al-Himsi from Abu Ubayy bin the wife of Ubadah bin Al-Samit from him. Then Ahmad narrated it (5/314-315 and 6/7) from the path of Shu'bah from Mansur from Hilal bin Yasaf from Abu Al-Muthanna bin the wife of Ubadah bin Al-Samit from him. Then Ahmad narrated it (5/314-315 and 6/7) from the path of Shu'bah from Mansur from Hilal bin Yasaf from Abu Al-Muthanna from Abu Ubayy bin the wife of Ubadah bin Al-Samit from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with it with the wording: (So pray the prayer at its time then make your prayer with them voluntary). So he made it from the Musnad of Abu Ubayy not from the Musnad of Ubadah bin Al-Samit. Likewise, Ahmad also narrated it (315) from the path of Ya'mar - meaning: Ibn Bishr -: Abdullah informed us: Sufyan informed us from Mansur with it with the wording: He said: We were sitting with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so he said... The Hadith. Then Ahmad said: And this is the correct view, meaning that it is from the Musnad of Abu Ubayy, not from the Musnad of Ubadah.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This Abu Ubayy is a Companion who prayed to the two Qiblas; his name is Abdullah. The men of his chain are trustworthy, men of Muslim, except this Abu Al-Muthanna, his name is Damdam Al-Amluki. Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy as in Al-Khulasah, and he said in (Al-Taqrib): (Al-Ajli declared him trustworthy). He did not add to that, so the chain is Hasan or acceptable for improvement. And Allah knows best. (2) From Ibn Masud, and it has two paths: The first: From Abdul Rahman bin Sabit from Amr bin Maymun Al-Awdi from him raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (How will you be when rulers come over you praying prayer at other than its appointed time). I said: So what do you order me if that catches me, O Messenger of Allah? He said: (Pray the prayer at its appointed time and make your prayer with them Subhah [voluntary]). Abu Dawood narrated it from Al-Walid: Al-Awza'i told us: Hassan bin Atiyyah told me from Abdul Rahman bin Sabit with it. This is a Sahih chain if it is safe from the Tadlis of Al-Walid - who is Ibn Muslim - for he used to do Tadlis Al-Taswiyah. Its men are all men of Muslim. The Second from Zirr from him, may Allah be pleased with him, with the wording: (Perhaps you will encounter peoples praying a prayer at other than its time. If you catch them, pray in your houses at the time you know, then pray with them and make it Subhah [voluntary]). Narrated by Ham (1/379) from Abu Bakr: Asim told us from Zirr with it. This is a Hasan chain.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: It has a third path stopped at him [Mawquf] with the wording: (Indeed there will be Imams who delay the prayer from its appointed times. If they do that, do not wait for them with it, and make the prayer with them Subhah [voluntary]). Narrated by Ahmad (1/455 and 459) from Muhammad bin Ishaq, he said: And Abdul Rahman bin Al-Aswad bin Yazid Al-Nakha'i told me from his father from him. This is a Hasan chain also. Harun bin Antarah followed him from Abdul Rahman bin Al-Aswad without his saying: (And make...) etc. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (128-129) and Ahmad also (1/424). This is a Sahih chain. Then Ahmad narrated it (1/405) from the path of Shu'bah from Abdul Rahman bin Abis, he said: A man from Hamdan from the companions of Abdullah told us from him. Its men are the men of the two Sheikhs except the Hamdani, for he was not named. A story occurred for Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding this which is fine to mention for benefit: (That Al-Walid bin Uqbah delayed the prayer once, so Abdullah bin Masud stood and called the Thawb (Iqamah/call) for prayer and prayed with the people. So Al-Walid sent to him: What drove you to what you did? Did an order come to you from the Commander of the Faithful regarding what you did, or did you innovate? He said: Nothing came to me from the Commander of the Faithful, nor did I innovate, but Allah the Mighty and Majestic and His Messenger refused for us that we wait for you with our prayer while you are on your need).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Imam Ahmad extracted it (1/450): Ibrahim bin Khalid told us: Rabah told us from Ma'mar from Abdullah bin Uthman from Al-Qasim from his father that Al-Walid bin Uqbah... etc. This is a Sahih chain, its men are men of the Sahih except Ibrahim bin Khalid, who is Al-San'ani, and he is trustworthy. And except Rabah, who is Ibn Zaid Al-Qurashi Al-San'ani, and he is a virtuous trustworthy person as in (Al-Taqrib). Abdullah bin Uthman is Ibn Khaytham, and Al-Qasim is Ibn Abdul Rahman bin Abdullah bin Masud. He said in (Al-Majma') (1/324) after citing it: (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and its men are trustworthy). (3) From Shaddad bin Aws raised [to the Prophet]: (There will be Imams after me who kill the prayer from its appointed times, so pray the prayer at its time and make your prayer with them Subhah [voluntary]). Narrated by Ahmad (4/124) from the path of Ibn Ayyash from Rashid bin Dawud from Abu Asma Al-Rahbi from him. This is a Hasan Levantine chain. He said in (Al-Majma') (1/325): Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Bazzar, and Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat. In it is Rashid bin Dawud; Al-Daraqutni declared him weak, and Ibn Ma'in, Duhaym, and Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy. (4) From Amir bin Rabi'ah raised [to the Prophet] similarly. Narrated by Ahmad (3/445 and 446) from Asim bin Ubaydullah, he said: Abd bin Amir bin Rabi'ah informed me from his father Amir bin Rabi'ah. In the chapter [there are narrations] from Abdullah bin Amr and Anas bin Malik with Al-Tabarani and others. See (Al-Majma').

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Benefit): Al-Nawawi mentioned in (Sharh Muslim) and in Al-Majmu' (3/48) that the meaning of his saying in these Hadiths: (They delay prayer from its time) is: from its chosen time, not from its entire time. For what is reported from the early and late rulers is only delaying it from its chosen time, and none of them delayed it from its entire (1) time. So it is obligatory to interpret these reports according to reality. The meaning of 'Pray prayer at its time' is at its first time. Then he said: In it is that if the Imam delays it from its first time, it is recommended for the follower to pray it in the first time individually then pray it with the Imam, thus combining praying at the first time and the congregation. If he wanted to restrict himself to one of them, is it better to restrict himself to performing it individually at the first time or restrict himself to performing it in congregation at the last time? There is a famous disagreement. He said: The chosen view is the recommendation of waiting if the delay is not excessive. Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) (p. 19): (The majority of scholars view that advancing prayer is better unless there is a preponderant benefit in delaying, like the one performing Tayammum delaying to pray at the end of time with Wudu, and the solitary person delaying to pray at the end of time with a congregation). I say: The correct view indicated by the Hadiths is what Al-Nawawi mentioned and chose of the recommendation of waiting if the delay is not excessive.
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: Ibn Abd Al-Barr said in (Al-Istidhkar): The rulers of Banu Umayyah, and most of them, used to pray Jumu'ah at sunset. Ibn Al-Qayyim quoted it in (Al-Salah) (99) and did not follow it with anything. It is a very strange report, so its authenticity should be examined.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This does not contradict his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (Do not pray a prayer in a day twice). Because he only intended by it that he prays both of them as obligatory, as Ibn Abd Al-Barr said. Or it is of the general specific to these Hadiths and their likes. Some of them will come in their places. This is more appropriate to me than what Ibn Abd Al-Barr said, because it necessitates the permissibility of repeating every prayer he prayed with the congregation to pray it again individually as voluntary, and I do not believe any scholar believes that. This Hadith was narrated by Abu Dawood (95), Al-Nasa'i (138), Al-Daraqutni (159 and 160), Al-Tahawi (1/187), and Ahmad (2/19 and 41) from the path of Husayn bin Dhakwan: Amr bin Shu'ayb informed me: Sulayman, the freed slave of Maimuna, informed me, he said: I came upon Ibn Umar one day while he was sitting on the pavement (Balat) and people were in Asr prayer. I said: O Abu Abdul Rahman, the people are in prayer? He said: I have prayed; I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saying: (An obligatory prayer is not prayed in a day twice). The context is Al-Daraqutni's and its chain is Sahih. Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban narrated it as in (Al-Talkhis) (4/298). 2 - And whoever catches a Rak'ah of prayer before its time exits, has caught the prayer in the time and must complete it. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Whoever catches a Rak'ah of prayer has caught the prayer [all of it]) Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim (102), Malik (1/28), and from him Muhammad (100), and likewise Abu Dawood (175), Al-Nasa'i (95), Al-Tirmidhi (2/403) and he authenticated it, Al-Darimi...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...(277), Ibn Majah (346), Ham (2/241, 271, 280, and 375) from paths from Al-Zuhri from Abu Salamah bin Abdul Rahman from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet] with it. The addition is a narration of Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad. He has another path extracted (2/265) from the path of Ibn Ishaq from Yazid bin Abi Habib from Arak bin Malik from him. Its men are trustworthy but Ibn Ishaq is a Mudallis and used 'an' (from). Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi extracted it in his (Tarikh) (3/69) from paths from Al-Zuhri with it and added: Ma'mar said: Al-Zuhri said: So we view that Jumu'ah is part of the prayer. I say: This indicates that whoever said from Al-Zuhri in this Hadith: (Whoever catches a Rak'ah of Jumu'ah prayer has caught [it]) as Al-Nasa'i narrated (1/210) from Sufyan from him, is only a narration by meaning because Jumu'ah is part of absolute prayer in the narration of the majority. They found fault with all narrations from Abu Huraira and Ibn Umar also which mention Jumu'ah, as I clarified in the commentary on Al-Tabarani number (555). 3 - This applies equally to Asr prayer and Fajr prayer. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Whoever catches a Rak'ah of Subh before the sun rises has caught Subh, and whoever catches a Rak'ah of Asr before the sun sets has caught Asr). Narrated by Malik (1/22-23), and from him Kh, M (2/102), N (90), T (1/253), Mi (277), Taha (1/90), Ham (2/462), all of them from Malik from Zaid bin Aslam...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...from Ata bin Yasar and from Busr bin Sa'id and from Al-A'raj, all of them narrating to him from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet] with it. Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad Al-Darawardi followed him from Zaid bin Aslam with it, narrated by Ibn Majah (1/237).
