Zuhair bin Muhammad also followed him but he placed Abu Salih instead of Ata, narrated by Al-Tayalisi (313) and his wording is: (So he did not miss it) instead of his saying: (So he has caught). Likewise, Abu Salamah narrated it from Abu Huraira, narrated by Ahmad (2/254) from Ali bin Al-Mubarak from Yahya bin Abi Kathir from him. Its chain is Sahih on the condition of the Six. From this aspect, Al-Tahawi extracted it (232) with the wording: (His prayer is complete). It is in Al-Bukhari from the path of Shayban from Yahya with the wording: (Let him complete his prayer). In Muslim (103), Ibn Majah (238), and Al-Musnad (254 and 260) from Al-Zuhri, and (Al-Musnad) (348) from Muhammad bin Amr, both from Abu Salamah similar to the Hadith of Malik. The Hadith of Abu Salih was narrated by Al-Tayalisi also (318), Ahmad (459), and Al-Tahawi (90) from Suhail bin Abi Salih from him similarly. The Hadith of Al-A'raj was narrated by Al-Nasa'i (94) and Ahmad (399 and 474) from two paths from him similarly, except that he said: (Sajdah) instead of: (Rak'ah)...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and likewise Abu Salamah in the narration of Al-Bukhari only. These are five paths for this Hadith of Abu Huraira, and all of them are Sahih. He has other paths: Muslim, Abu Dawood (68), and Ahmad (2/282) narrated it from Ma'mar from Ibn Tawus from his father from Ibn Abbas from him like the Hadith of Malik. Al-Tahawi (232), Al-Daraqutni (147), and Ahmad (2/236-489) narrated from Qatadah from Khilas from Abu Rafi' from him raised [to the Prophet]: with the wording: (Whoever prays a Rak'ah of Subh prayer before the sun rises then it rises, let him pray another to it). In a narration by Al-Daraqutni and Ahmad (490) from the path of Hammam, he said: Qatadah was asked about a man who prayed a Rak'ah of Subh prayer then the sun rose (In a narration by Ahmad: then the horn of the sun rose). He said: Khilas told me from Abu Rafi' that Abu Huraira told him that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (He completes his prayer). This is a Sahih chain on their condition. Qatadah has two other chains from Abu Huraira regarding it: (1) From Al-Nadr bin Anas from Bashir bin Nahik from him with it. Al-Daraqutni and Ham (2/306, 347, and 521) narrated it from Hammam from him. This is a Sahih chain also like the one before it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (2) From Udhrah bin Tamim from him. Qut from Mu'adh bin Hisham: My father told me from Qatadah from him. This Udhrah, I did not find anyone who mentioned him. Then I found Al-Hakim extracted it (274) from Qatadah with his two previous chains and said: Both chains are Sahih on their condition. Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. The Hadith has a witness from the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, M (102-103), N (94), Maj (237-238), Taha (90), Ham (6/78) from Al-Zuhri from Urwah bin Al-Zubayr telling him from her like the Hadith of Malik. Except that Muslim and Ahmad said: (Sajdah) instead of: (Rak'ah). Al-Khattabi said: The intended by Sajdah is the Rak'ah with its Ruku' and Sujud, and the Rak'ah is only completed by its Sujud, so it was named based on this as Sajdah. These Hadiths indicate that whoever catches a Rak'ah before the time exits, it is valid even if the second Rak'ah occurs in the prohibited time like Fajr and Asr prayer. This is the school of the majority. Abu Hanifa disagreed on some of that, saying: Whoever the sun rises upon while he is in Subh prayer, his prayer is invalid. Al-Tahawi argued for him with the Hadiths reported regarding the prohibition of prayer at sunrise, claiming that this argument abrogates the Hadith of Aisha and the Hadith of Abu Huraira before it, which is a claim that needs proof.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The truth is that the Hadiths of prohibition are general, encompassing every prayer except what the Lawgiver excluded, so it becomes a specification for these Hadiths. Of this type is this Hadith of Abu Huraira, for it is specific and takes precedence over the general as established in Principles (Usul). Furthermore, the concept of the Hadith implies that whoever catches less than a Rak'ah does not catch the time. The majority went to this view as in (Nail Al-Awtar). Refer to the completion of this discussion in it (2/19-20). 4 - This ruling is specifically for the one who deliberately delays prayer to this tight time. Otherwise, the sleeper and the forgetter never miss the prayer even if its entire time exits as long as he is heedless of it or forgetting it. For the time regarding them is when remembering. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said in his journey in which they slept until the sun rose: (Indeed you were dead, so Allah returned your souls to you. So whoever sleeps through a prayer, let him pray it when he wakes up, and whoever forgets a prayer, let him pray when he remembers). Abu Ya'la and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) narrated it from the Hadith of Abu Juhayfah. Its men are trustworthy as in (Al-Mu'jam). The Hadith has many witnesses, among them: From Abu Qatadah who said: They mentioned to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, their sleeping through prayer. So he said: (Indeed, there is no negligence in sleep; negligence is only in wakefulness. So if one of you forgets a prayer or sleeps through it, let him pray it when he remembers it).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (100-101), T (334), Maj (236-237) from Hammad bin Zaid from Thabit Al-Bunani from Abdullah bin Rabah Al-Ansari from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih). I say: And it is on the condition of Muslim, and he extracted it in his (Sahih) (2/138-139) and Al-Bayhaqi (2/216) from the path of Sulayman bin Al-Mughirah: Thabit told us with it at length similarly with the wording: (Beware, there is no negligence in sleep; negligence is only upon the one who does not pray the prayer until the time of the other prayer comes. So whoever does that, let him pray it when he wakes up for it) The Hadith. This amount was narrated by Al-Nasa'i (101) also and Abu Dawood (73) from this aspect. And Abu Dawood (72), Al-Tahawi (233), and Ahmad (5/298) narrated it from Hammad bin Salamah from Thabit with it at length. Likewise, Qatadah narrated it at length from Abdullah bin Abi Rabah with it, he said: So I said: O Messenger of Allah, we are ruined, we missed the prayer. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (You are not ruined nor did you miss the prayer. Indeed, the wakeful misses it, but the sleeper does not miss it) The Hadith. Narrated by Ahmad (5/302): Muhammad bin Ja'far told us: Shu'bah told us from Qatadah with it. This is a Sahih chain on the condition of Muslim also were it not for the 'an'anah of Qatadah. And among them: From Anas raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (If one of you sleeps through prayer or neglects it, let him pray it when he remembers it, for Allah says: (Establish prayer for My remembrance [Taha / 14]).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: M (2/142) from Al-Muthanna from Qatadah from him. Sa'id - who is Ibn Abi Arubah - narrated it from Qatadah with it with the wording: (Whoever forgets a prayer or sleeps through it...) And the rest is like it. Narrated by Al-Darimi (280): Sa'id informed us with it with the wording: (For its expiation is that he prays it when he remembers it). This wording exactly was narrated by Shu'bah from Qatadah. Ahmad extracted it (3/282). Hajjaj Al-Ahwal narrated it in Al-Nasa'i (100), Ibn Majah (235), and Ahmad (267), and Hisham in the latter (216), both from Qatadah from Anas that he asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, about the man who sleeps through prayer or neglects it. He said: (Let him pray it when he remembers it). It is in Al-Bukhari and Muslim also, D (73), Taha, Al-Bayhaqi (2/218), and Ham (269) from the path of Hammam from Qatadah with the wording: (Whoever forgets a prayer, let him pray it when he remembers it; there is no expiation for it except that). Qatadah said: (And establish prayer for My remembrance [Taha / 14]). Narrated by Abu Awanah from Qatadah briefly without his saying: (There is no expiation for it...) etc. Narrated by Muslim, N (100), T (335-336), Maj, Taha, and Al-Bayhaqi from paths from him. Qatadah explicitly stated his hearing from Anas in a narration of Al-Bukhari and Ahmad.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: M (2/142) via Al-Muthanna from Qatadah from him. And Sa'id - who is Ibn Abi Arubah - narrated it from Qatadah with it with the wording: (Whoever forgets a prayer or sleeps through it...) and the rest is like it. Al-Darimi narrated it (280): Sa'id informed us with it with the wording: (For its expiation is that he prays it when he remembers it). This exact wording was narrated by Shu'bah from Qatadah, extracted by Ahmad (3/282). And Hajjaj Al-Ahwal narrated it in Al-Nasa'i (100) and Ibn Majah (235) and Ahmad (267), and Hisham in the latter (216), both from Qatadah from Anas that he asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, about the man who sleeps through prayer or neglects it. He said: (Let him pray it when he remembers it). It is also in Al-Bukhari and Muslim, and D (73), and Taha, and Al-Bayhaqi (2/218), and Ham (269) via Hammam from Qatadah with the wording: (Whoever forgets a prayer, let him pray it when he remembers it, there is no expiation for it except that). Qatadah said: (And establish prayer for My remembrance [Taha / 14]). Abu Awanah narrated it from Qatadah briefly without his saying: (there is no expiation for it...) etc. Extracted by Muslim, N (100), T (335-336), Maj, Taha, and Al-Bayhaqi from paths from him. Qatadah explicitly stated his hearing from Anas in a narration of Al-Bukhari and Ahmad.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And among them: From Abu Hurairah, elevated [to the Prophet]: (Whoever forgets a prayer, let him pray it when he remembers it, for Allah said: {Establish prayer for My remembrance} [Taha / 14]). M (138), D (71-72), N (101) via Yunus from Ibn Shihab from Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib from him. It is in M and D in a lengthy form containing the story of their sleeping through the Fajr prayer. Al-Bayhaqi also narrated it (2/217). In the chapter, from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri who said: A woman came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while we were with him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, my husband Safwan bin al-Mu'attal beats me if I pray, makes me break my fast if I fast, and he does not pray the Fajr prayer until the sun rises.' He said: And Safwan was with him. He said: So he asked him about what she said. He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, as for her saying "he beats me if I pray," she recites two Surahs [in one Rak'ah] and I have forbidden her.' He said: So he said: (If it were one Surah, it would suffice the people). 'As for her saying "he makes me break my fast," she proceeds to fast [voluntarily] and I am a young man and I cannot have patience.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said on that day: (A woman should not fast except with the permission of her husband). 'As for her saying "I do not pray until the sun rises," we are a household for whom that is known; we hardly wake up until the sun rises.' He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (So when you wake up, pray). Narrated by D (1/385), Mas (1/436), Taha in (Al-Mushkil) (2/424), Ham (3/80) via Jarir from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from him. Mas said: (Authentic according to the conditions of the two Sheikhs), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is as they said. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Isabah): (Its chain is authentic). Then Ham narrated it (3/85) via Abu Bakr - who is Ibn Abi Ayyash - from Al-A'mash with a similar wording: (For I am heavy-headed, and I am from a household known for that, for heavy-headedness. He said: So when you rise, pray). It is on the condition of Kh. 5 - Whether the waking up and remembering is at sunrise or at sunset, he must pray it at this time, for it is its time, due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as mentioned previously: (Let him pray it when he remembers it, there is no expiation for it except that). This is the view of the majority of scholars. Al-Tirmidhi said (1/335): (The people of knowledge differed regarding a man who sleeps through prayer or forgets it, then wakes up or remembers while it is a non-prayer time, at sunrise or sunset. Some of them said: He prays it when he wakes up or remembers, even if it is at sunrise or sunset. This is the saying of Ahmad, Ishaq, Al-Shafi'i, and Malik. And some of them said: He does not

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: pray until the sun rises or sets). I say: This is the school of our Hanafi scholars. Muhammad stated it in (Al-Muwatta) (125). He said: (It is the saying of Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him). The commentator upon it, Abu al-Hasan al-Laknawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: (A group of our companions, including Al-Ayni and others, supported it with what was reported in the Hadith of Ta'rees [stopping for rest at night], that he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) moved from that place and prayed after that, and that could only have been because it was the time of sunrise. This is open to question: First, because the reasoning for the choice was explicitly reported as being a place of heedlessness and a place where Satan was present, so one should not deviate from that [reason]. Second, because it was reported in the narration of Malik and others: 'until the sun struck them.' And in some narrations of Al-Bukhari: 'he did not wake up until he felt the heat of the sun.' And that is not possible except some time after sunrise and after the time of dislike has passed). This is a good, strong critique from the strong author Abu al-Hasan, and his likes are few among the followers of the Madhhabs among the later generations. So may Allah Almighty have mercy on him and reward him with good. The reasoning he mentioned was reported in (Sahih Muslim) (2/138) and Al-Nasa'i (1/102) from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: We stopped for rest with the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and we did not wake up until the sun rose. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Let every man take hold of his riding animal's head, for this is a station where Satan attended us). He said: So we did. Then he called for water and performed ablution, then he prostrated two prostrations [Sunnah], then the prayer was established (Iqamah) and he prayed the Fajr prayer. Narrated by the two [Bukhari and Muslim] via Yahya bin Sa'id: Yazid bin Kaysan told us: Abu Hazim told us from him. It has another path narrated by D (72) from Ma'mar from Al-Zuhri from Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib from Abu Hurairah in this report, he said: (Move from your place in which heedlessness befell you). He said: So he ordered Bilal, who called the Adhan and Iqamah, and he prayed. Its chain is authentic according to their conditions. It has a third path with the wording: (This is a station where a devil is). Taha (234). 6 - And he prays it as he used to pray it every day, with Adhan and Iqamah, and reciting aloud in it if it is a loud prayer, and praying the Sunnah with it. Abu Qatadah said in his long hadith about their sleeping through the Fajr prayer: Then Bilal called the Adhan for prayer, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed two Rak'ahs, then he prayed the Morning prayer, doing as he does every day. Narrated by Muslim via Sulaiman bin al-Mughirah as previously mentioned. Similar to it is the hadith of Abu Hurairah: So he ordered Bilal, who called the Adhan and Iqamah, and he prayed.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And in a narration: So he performed ablution then prostrated two prostrations, then the prayer was established and he prayed the Morning prayer. We presented this shortly before. In the chapter, from Dhu Mikhmar al-Habashi - and he was one of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in this story: So he ordered Bilal who called the Adhan, then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stood and prayed the two Rak'ahs before Fajr without rushing, then he ordered him and he established the prayer, and he prayed without rushing. A sayer said to him: 'O Prophet of Allah, have we been negligent?' He said: (No, Allah Almighty took our souls and returned them to us, and we have prayed). Narrated by Ham (4/90-91) and D (73) without his saying: 'A sayer said to him... etc.', via Hariz bin Uthman: Yazid bin Subh - or said: Ibn Sulayh - told me from him. This is a good (Hasan) chain. And from Ibn Mas'ud who said: We came with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) during the time of Hudaybiyyah. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Who will guard for us?) Bilal said: 'I.' So they slept until the sun rose. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) woke up and said: (Do as you used to do). He said: So we did. He said: (Thus do for whoever sleeps or forgets). D (73-74) and Taha (269-270) via Jami' bin Shaddad from Abd al-Rahman bin Alqamah from him. This is an authentic chain. 7 - As for the one who delays a prayer beyond its time intentionally without intending to combine [prayers], it is not prescribed for him to make it up (Qada'), nor is he ever excused for it, because the one who forgets the prayer or sleeps

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: through it - and they are legally excused - have nothing upon them except performing it immediately upon remembering - which is its time. So where is the time regarding the intentional one? Due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): (Whoever misses the Asr prayer, it is as if he has lost his family and wealth). So what is missed, there is no way to retrieve it at all; if it were possible to retrieve it, it would not be called 'missed'. See (Al-Salah) by Ibn al-Qayyim. This is the school of Dawud al-Zahiri and also Ibn Hazm, who elaborated on establishing this in a way not preceded. He said: And among those who held our view in this are Umar bin al-Khattab, his son Abdullah, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, Salman (the Companion of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), Ibn Mas'ud, Al-Qasim bin Muhammad bin Abi Bakr, Budayl al-Uqayli, Muhammad bin Sirin, Mutarrif bin Abdullah, Umar bin Abd al-Aziz, and others. Al-Hasan al-Basri said it: If a man leaves a single prayer intentionally, he does not make it up. (Al-Salah) (107). Then he said: We do not know of any opponent from among the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them) whom we mentioned. Refer to (Al-Muhalla) (2/235-244). Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah chose this view, saying in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) (p. 19): (And the one who abandons prayer intentionally, it is not prescribed for him to make it up, nor is it valid from him; rather, he should increase in voluntary prayers. The same applies to fasting. This is the view of a group of the Salaf, such as Abu Abd al-Rahman the companion of Al-Shafi'i, Dawud, and his followers. There is nothing in the evidences that contradicts this; rather, it agrees with it. And his command (peace be upon him) to the one who had intercourse [during Ramadan fast] to make it up is weak due to Al-Bukhari and Muslim avoiding it).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Shawkani inclined towards this, saying regarding his statement (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): (Whoever forgets a prayer...) the Hadith: (Those who said: 'The intentional leaver does not make up the prayer' held onto the concept of the address [Dalil al-Khitab], because the negation of the condition implies the negation of the conditioned, which implies that whoever does not forget does not pray [make it up]. Dawud, Ibn Hazm, and some companions of Al-Shafi'i went to this view. It was narrated in (Al-Bahr) from the two Hadis and Al-Ustadh, and a narration from Al-Qasim and Al-Nasir. Ibn Taymiyyah (Sheikh al-Islam) said: Those who dispute with them have no proof whatsoever to refer to in case of dispute. Most of them say: Making up (Qada') is not obligatory except by a new command, and they have no command here. We do not dispute only the obligation of making up, but we dispute the acceptance of the makeup from him and the validity of the prayer outside its time). He elaborated on the discussion regarding that and chose what Dawud and those with him mentioned. And the matter is as he mentioned, for despite the intense research of those mandating makeup for the intentional leaver - and they are everyone other than those we mentioned - I have not come across a proof that holds value in the marketplace of debate or is suitable to rely upon in such a great principle, except the hadith: (So the debt of Allah is more deserving to be paid), considering the generality implied by the genitive noun. However, they did not pay attention to it. The strongest argument they brought in this position is their saying: The hadiths mandating makeup for the forgetful imply by the concept of their address the obligation of makeup for the intentional leaver, because it is alerting to the greater by the lesser, so it indicates the requirement by the tenor of the address and a fortiori analogy. This is rejected, because the one who says that the intentional leaver does not make up does not mean that his condition is lighter than the forgetful one; rather, [he means] that what prevents the obligation of makeup on the intentional leaver is that it does not drop the sin

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: from him, so there is no benefit in it, thus performing it without a textual proof would be futile, unlike the forgetful and the sleeper, for the Lawgiver commanded them to do so and stated that there is no expiation for them other than it. End quote. As for the hadith used as proof by those who say makeup is required: (So the debt of Allah is more deserving to be paid), he did not answer it with anything at all. That is why he said: (The station has straitened), and he blamed those who said: 'The chapter of makeup is built on no foundation, containing neither Book nor Sunnah,' attributing negligence to them due to his inability to answer the referred hadith. Ibn Abd al-Barr preceded him in this deduction. Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, answered it in the treatise (Al-Salah) with something that leaves absolutely no room for doubt that the hadith does not indicate that. Its summary is that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) only said the hadith regarding those with excuses, not the negligent one, and we say that such a debt is accepted to be paid. Also, he (peace be upon him) said this regarding the absolute vow which has no time limit on both ends, and regarding Hajj whose time does not expire except with the end of life. Refer to (pp. 109-110) of the mentioned treatise. He elaborated on the dispute regarding this issue and prolonged it in a way that cannot be added to, mentioning the proofs of both parties with verification and commentary not found in any book, so refer to it (85-122). 8 - If one forgets two prayers or more, he prays them in order (Tartib), then prays the present prayer. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did likewise in the Battle of the Trench when he was diverted from them by war.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Abu Sa'id al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) said: We were detained on the day of the Trench until a portion of the night had passed, until we were sufficed [from fighting], and that is the saying of Allah Almighty: {And Allah sufficed the believers the fighting, and Allah is ever Powerful, Exalted in Might} [Al-Ahzab / 25]. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) called Bilal and ordered him, so he established prayer and he prayed Dhuhr and perfected it as he used to pray it in its time. Then he established for Asr and he prayed it likewise. Then he established for Maghrib and he prayed it likewise. Then he established for Isha and he prayed it likewise. And that was before it was revealed regarding the Fear Prayer: {And if you fear [an enemy], then [pray] on foot or riding} [Al-Baqarah / 239]. Narrated by N (107), and from him Ibn Hazm (3/124), Mi (358), Al-Shafi'i in (Al-Umm) (1/75), Al-Tahawi (190), Al-Bayhaqi (1/402), Al-Tayalisi (295), Ham (3/25, 49, 67-68) via paths from Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Al-Maqburi from Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Sa'id al-Khudri from his father with it. The wording is Ahmad's. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban also narrated it in their (Sahihs), and Ibn al-Sakan authenticated it as in (Al-Talkhis) (3/149). Ibn Sayyid al-Nas said: (This is a majestic authentic chain) as in (Al-Nayl) (2/26). It has a witness from the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud narrated by N (102, 107), T (1/337), Taya (44), Ham (1/375, 423), Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and Al-Bayhaqi (2/219-220) via Abu al-Zubair from Nafi' bin Jubair bin Mut'im from Abu Ubaidah bin

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Abdullah bin Mas'ud from him similarly. Its wording will come in the eighth issue in Adhan. This chain is disconnected. Al-Tirmidhi said: (There is no harm in its chain except that Abu Ubaidah did not hear from Abdullah). It has another concise witness from the hadith of Jabir, agreed upon, and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it. Scholars differed regarding the obligation of order (Tartib) between missed prayers. The Shafi'is negated it and said: It is recommended. Tawus, Al-Hasan al-Basri, Muhammad bin al-Hasan, Abu Thawr, and Dawud said this. Abu Hanifa and Malik said: It is obligatory as long as the missed prayers do not exceed the prayers of one day and night. They said: If he is in a present prayer and remembers during it that he owes a missed prayer, the present one becomes invalid and he must prioritize the missed one then pray the present one. Zufar and Ahmad said: Order is obligatory whether the missed prayers are few or many. Ahmad said: If he forgot the missed prayers, the prayers he prayed after them are valid. Ahmad and Ishaq said: If he remembers a missed prayer while in a present prayer, he completes the one he is in, then makes up the missed prayer, then he must repeat the present prayer. They argued with a hadith from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: (Whoever forgets a prayer and does not remember it until he is with the Imam, when he finishes his prayer, let him repeat the prayer he forgot, then let him repeat the prayer he prayed with the Imam). This is a weak hadith. Musa bin Harun al-Hammal (with a Ha) al-Hafiz weakened it. Abu Zur'ah al-Razi and then Al-Bayhaqi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The correct view is that it is suspended [Mawquf]). Thus in (Al-Majmu') (3/70-71). Then he said: (Our companions also argued with weak hadiths. The relied-upon view in the issue is that they are debts upon him, so order is not obligatory for them except with clear evidence, and they have no clear evidence. And because whoever prays them without order has performed the prayer he was ordered to do, so an additional description is not binding upon him without clear evidence. And Allah knows best). 6 - The Adhan. 1 - Before that, they used to call one another when the time for prayer came. That was by a signal from Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) and his command (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) for that. Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) said: When the Muslims arrived in Medina, they used to gather and guess the times for prayers, and no one called for them. So they spoke one day about that. Some of them said: Adopt a bell like the bell of the Christians. And some of them said: A horn like the horn of the Jews. Umar said: Why do you not send a man to call for the prayer? The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (O Bilal, stand and call for the prayer). Kh, M, N, T, and he said: Hasan Sahih. Qat (88), Ham (2/148). Ibn Juraij: Nafi' informed me from him. He said in (Al-Majmu') (3/76): (This call was a summons to prayer other than the Adhan which existed before the legislation of the Adhan).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Mu'adh bin Jabal (may Allah be pleased with him) said: Prayer was shifted three times... For the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arrived in Medina and prayed for seventeen months towards Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem), then Allah revealed to him: {We have certainly seen the turning of your face toward the heaven...} (The verse [Al-Baqarah / 144]). He said: So Allah directed him towards Mecca. He said: This is one shift. He said: And they used to gather for prayer and call one another for it until they used bells [Naqas] or were about to use bells. He said: Then a man from the Ansar called Abdullah bin Zaid came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, I saw in what the sleeper sees - and if I said I was not sleeping I would be truthful - that while I was between sleeping and waking, I saw a figure wearing two green garments facing the Qiblah and saying: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah, Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah, two by two, until he finished the Adhan. Then he waited an hour. He said: Then he said the like of what he said, except that he added to it: Qad qamat is-salah, Qad qamat is-salah (Prayer has been established). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Teach it to Bilal, for let him call the Adhan with it). So Bilal was the first to call the Adhan with it. He said: And Umar bin al-Khattab came and said: O Messenger of Allah, there visited me the like of what visited him, except that he preceded me. So these are two shifts. The Hadith. Narrated by Ahmad (5/246) and Abu Dawood (82) via Al-Mas'udi: Amr bin Murrah told me from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla from him. Al-Hakim narrated a portion of it related to fasting (2/224) from this path and said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Authentic). And Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. I say: Al-Mas'udi had become confused (mixed up), but Shu'bah followed him from Amr (1) similarly. Abu Dawood also narrated it (83). Its wording will come in issue (13). So with this follow-up, it is authentic. His saying: 'Naqasu' (they used bells). In Al-Nihayah: Al-Naqs is striking the Naqus (bell), which is a long piece of wood struck by a smaller piece of wood, and the Christians use it to announce their prayer times. 2 - Then the Adhan was legislated by the angel teaching it to Abdullah bin Zaid bin Abd Rabbih in the dream and by his saying (peace be upon him): (It is indeed a true vision, if Allah wills). Abdullah bin Zaid said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered the bell to be made so that it could be struck for people to gather for prayer, a man carrying a bell in his hand walked around me while I was sleeping. I said to him: O servant of Allah, are you selling the bell? He said: What will you do with it? He said: I said: We call to prayer with it. He said: Shall I not guide you to what is better than that? He said: I said: Yes. He said: You say: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah, Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah, Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'ala as-salah, Hayya 'ala as-salah. Hayya 'ala al-falah, Hayya 'ala al-falah. Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illa Allah. Then he moved back not far and said: You say when the prayer is established (Iqamah):
foot_note: 1. (1) And Al-A'mash also followed him from him in a summarized form with the story of Adhan only. Narrated by Ahmad (5/232) with a good chain and (Qat) (89) and he faulted it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'ala as-salah. Hayya 'ala al-falah. Qad qamat is-salah, Qad qamat is-salah. Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illa Allah. When I woke up, I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and informed him of what I saw. He said: (It is indeed a true vision, if Allah wills. Stand with Bilal and cast upon him what you saw, and let him call the Adhan with it, for he has a louder voice than you). He said: So I stood with Bilal and began casting it upon him and he called the Adhan with it. He said: Umar bin al-Khattab heard that while he was in his house, so he came out dragging his cloak saying: By the One who sent you with the truth, I have seen the like of what was shown. He said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (So to Allah belongs the praise). Narrated by Abu Dawood (81), Al-Darimi (268-269), Ibn Majah (239-240), Al-Tirmidhi in summary (359), and Ahmad (4/43), and the context is his. And from him Al-Daraqutni (89), Ibn Khuzaimah, and Ibn Hibban as in (Al-Fath) (2/61-62) via Muhammad bin Ishaq who said: Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin al-Harith al-Taymi told me from Muhammad bin Abdullah ibn Zaid bin Abd Rabbih who said: Abdullah bin Zaid told me with it. This is a good chain. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih). Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu') (3/76): (Its chain is authentic). And in (Al-Talkhis) (3/161): (Al-Bukhari authenticated it as narrated by Al-Tirmidhi in (Al-Ilal) from him. And Muhammad

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: bin Yahya al-Dhuhli said: There is nothing in the reports of Abdullah bin Zaid more authentic than the hadith of Muhammad bin Ishaq from Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Taymi, meaning this one, because Muhammad heard from his father Abdullah. Ibn Khuzaimah said in his (Sahih): This is an authentic hadith, established by way of transmission, because Muhammad heard from his father, and Ibn Ishaq heard from Al-Taymi, and this is not among what he practiced Tadlis in). Ibn Ishaq has another chain for it narrated by Ahmad (4/42-43) from him, saying: Muhammad bin Muslim al-Zuhri mentioned from Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib from Abdullah bin Zaid bin Abd Rabbih who said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) resolved to strike the bell to gather the people for prayer, while he disliked it due to conformity with the Christians, a visitor walked around me at night while I was sleeping, a man wearing two green garments and carrying a bell in his hand. He said: So I said to him: O servant of Allah, are you selling the bell... The Hadith, similar to it. And he added at its end: So Bilal, the freed slave of Abu Bakr, used to call Adhan with that and call the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to prayer. He said: He came and called him one morning for Fajr, and it was said to him: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is sleeping. He said: So Bilal screamed at the top of his voice: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm (Prayer is better than sleep). Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib said: So this phrase was introduced into the Adhan for the Fajr prayer. This is also a good chain. And Ibn Ishaq, although he did not explicitly state his hearing from Al-Zuhri, has been followed in it by a group. Al-Hakim said (3/336): (The hadith of Al-Zuhri from Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib is famous; it was narrated by Yunus bin Yazid, Ma'mar ibn Rashid, Shu'ayb bin Abi Hamzah, Muhammad bin Ishaq, and others).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Shawkani said (2/31): (The follow-up of these for Muhammad bin Ishaq from Al-Zuhri removes the possibility of Tadlis which Ibn Ishaq's 'an'an [saying 'from'] implies). The hadith has a witness from the hadith of Abu Umair bin Anas from his uncles from the Ansar who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was concerned about prayer, how to gather people for it. It was said to him: Set up a flag when the prayer time comes; when they see it, they will inform one another. But that did not please him. He said: So the Qan' was mentioned to him - meaning the horn, and in a narration: the horn of the Jews - but that did not please him and he said: (It is from the matter of the Jews). He said: So the bell was mentioned to him and he said: (It is from the matter of the Christians). Abdullah bin Zaid left concerned due to the concern of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so he was shown the Adhan in his sleep. He said: So he went to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the morning and informed him. He said to him: O Messenger of Allah, I was between sleeping and waking when a comer came to me and showed me the Adhan. He said: Umar had seen it before that but concealed it for twenty days. He said: Then he informed the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and he said to him: (What prevented you from informing me?) He said: Abdullah bin Zaid preceded me, so I was shy. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (O Bilal, stand and look at what Abdullah bin Zaid orders you and do it). He said: So Bilal called the Adhan. Narrated by Abu Dawood (80-81) via Hushaym bin Abi Bishr from him. This is an authentic chain as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) (2/64). 3 - It is a communal obligation (Fard Kifayah): The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to Malik bin Huwayrith: [116] (Return to your families and stay

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: with them, teach them, command them, and pray as you have seen me pray. When the prayer becomes due, let one of you call the Adhan for you, and let the oldest of you lead you). And from Amr bin Salamah al-Jarmi from his father - who was the delegate of his people to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) - that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: (Pray such prayer at such time, and pray such prayer at such time. When the prayer becomes due, let one of you call the Adhan for you, and let the one with the most Quran lead you). Narrated by Al-Bukhari (2/87, 89, 239, 10/359, 13/198-199), Muslim (1/134), Al-Nasa'i (2/105), Qat (101), Al-Darimi (1/286), Ahmad (3/436, 5/53) via Abu Qilabah from Malik bin Huwayrith, and Al-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil) (2/296). And he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (There are no three in a village where no Adhan is called and prayer is not established among them except that Satan has overcome them. So stick to the congregation (Jama'ah), for the wolf eats the stray sheep). Narrated by Ahmad (5/196, 6/446) via Waki': Za'idah bin Qudamah told me: Al-Sa'ib bin Hubaish al-Kala'i told me from Ma'dan bin Abi Talha al-Ya'mari who said: Abu Darda' said to me: Where is your dwelling? He said: I said: In a village outside Homs. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say:... So he mentioned it. This is a good chain. D, N, and Mas narrated it without mentioning the Adhan. See our comment on (Al-Targhib) (1/156). It has another path in (Al-Musnad) (6/445-446).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Even if there were nothing but the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) considering lawful the blood, wealth, and captives of those with whom no Adhan was heard, it would suffice for the obligation of that being Fard, as Ibn Hazm said (3/125). He refers by that to the hadith of Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to, if he raided a people, not raid us at night until morning. If he heard Adhan, he refrained from them, and if he did not hear Adhan, he raided them. Kh in Adhan and Ham (3/159, 206, 236, 237) via paths from Humaid from him. And Muslim narrated it (2/3-4), and Al-Tirmidhi (1-305 Bulaq edition) and authenticated it, and Al-Darimi (2/217), Al-Tayalisi (271), and Ham (3/132, 229) via Hammad bin Salamah from Thabit from Anas with it. And they added - except Al-Darimi and Al-Tayalisi -: So he listened one day and heard a man saying: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (On the Fitrah). Then he said: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. He said: (You have exited the Fire). Muslim added: So they looked and behold, he was a goat herder. It has a witness from his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with the wording: (If you see a mosque or a caller [Mu'adhin], do not kill anyone). Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (1/292 Bulaq edition) and Ahmad (3/448) via Ibn Uyaynah from Abd al-Malik bin Nawfal bin Masahiq from Ibn Isam al-Muzani from his father - who was a Companion - who said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent an army or a detachment, he would say to them... so he mentioned it. Al-Tirmidhi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Hasan Hadith). Thus he said. And Ibn Isam's condition is unknown as in (Al-Taqrib). The view of its obligation - as we mentioned - is the saying of Ahmad and a view of the Shafi'is, and Dawud al-Zahiri and his companions held it. Ibn Hazm added to them (3/122-125) making it a condition for the validity of prayer, such that it is not valid without it, which is not apparent. Ibn Taymiyyah was asked about the Adhan: Is it Fard or Sunnah? He answered by saying: (The correct view is that the Adhan is a communal obligation (Fard Kifayah). It is not for the people of a city or a village to abandon the Adhan and Iqamah. This is the famous view in the Madhhab of Ahmad and others. Groups of scholars have loosely termed it a Sunnah, then among these are those who say if the people of a town agree to abandon it, they are fought. The dispute with these is close to a verbal dispute, for many scholars apply the term Sunnah to that whose abandoner is blameworthy in the Sharia and whose abandoner is punished in the Sharia. As for whoever claims it is a Sunnah for which there is no sin on its abandoner nor punishment, this saying is a mistake. For the Adhan is the symbol of the Abode of Islam, about which it is established in (Al-Sahih) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to condition the lawfulness of the people of the abode on its abandonment). Then he mentioned the hadith of Anas and the hadith of Abu Darda, then said: (And Allah Almighty has said: {Satan has overcome them and made them forget the remembrance of Allah. Those are the party of Satan. Unquestionably, the party of Satan - they will be the losers} [Al-Mujadilah / 19]). (Al-Fatawa) (1/67-68) and (4/20). See (Al-Majmu') (3/82). 4 - It has come in its description in three types: The first: Its words are nineteen words: Allahu 1 Akbar Allahu 2 Akbar Allahu 3 Akbar Allahu 4 Akbar

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Four times) Ashhadu 5 an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu 6 an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu 7 anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Ashhadu 8 anna Muhammadan Rasulullah (Lowering his voice with them twice. Then raising his voice returning and saying - which is Tarji') Ashhadu 9 an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu 10 an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu 11 anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Ashhadu 12 anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Hayya 13 'ala as-salah Hayya 14 'ala as-salah Hayya 15 'ala al-falah Hayya 16 'ala al-falah Allahu 17 Akbar Allahu 18 Akbar La ilaha 19 illa Allah. This is from the hadith of Abu Mahdhurah (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught him the Adhan as nineteen words and the Iqamah as seventeen words. Narrated by Abu Dawood (82), Al-Nasa'i (103), Al-Tirmidhi (367), Al-Darimi (271), Ibn Majah (242-243), Al-Tahawi (1/78), Al-Daraqutni (87, 88), Ibn Hazm (3/150), Al-Tayalisi (193), and Ahmad (3/409, 6/401), all via Hammad: Amir al-Ahwal told us: Makhul told me: That Abdullah bin Muhayriz told him from him with it. Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, Al-Daraqutni, Al-Tahawi, Ahmad, and Ibn Hazm added mentions of the words of the Adhan. It is strange that none of them except Qat, Ibn Hazm, and Taha reached the nineteen words in its wording as is the text of the hadith. For Abu Dawood did not mention the Tarji', so his words are seventeen. Ibn Majah did not mention the testimony 'La ilaha illa Allah' in the Tarji' except once, so his words are eighteen. And Ahmad did not mention the Takbir at its beginning except twice, so his words are seventeen as well. Then Al-Tirmidhi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (This is a Hasan Sahih hadith). It is on the condition of Muslim, and he narrated it in his (Sahih) as will come shortly. Ibn Khuzaimah narrated it in his (Sahih) with the wording: (So he taught him the Adhan and Iqamah two by two). Ibn Hibban also narrated it in his (Sahih). He said in (Al-Imam): This chain is on the condition of the Sahih; Hammad bin Yahya was used as proof by the two Sheikhs, and Amir bin Abd al-Wahid was used as proof by Muslim as in (Nasb al-Rayah) (1/268). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Talkhis) (3/164): (Al-Bayhaqi criticized it with aspects of weakening, which Ibn Daqiq al-Eid rebutted in Al-Imam and authenticated the hadith). Then Al-Darimi narrated the hadith: Sa'id bin Amir informed us from Hammad with it with the wording: (That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered about twenty men so they called Adhan, and he was pleased with Abu Mahdhurah's voice, so he taught him the Adhan). I say: So he mentioned it with nineteen words, then said: And the Iqamah is two by two. Its chain is also authentic on the condition of Muslim. He narrated it in his (Sahih) (2/3) via Mu'adh bin Hisham: My father told me from Amir al-Ahwal with it: That the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught him this Adhan: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Then he returns and says: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah... And the rest is like it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Thus it occurred in (Sahih Muslim): Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, only twice. Al-Nasa'i narrated it (1/103): Ishaq bin Ibrahim informed us, he said: Mu'adh bin Hisham informed us with it, except that he mentioned the Takbir at the beginning: four times. This Ishaq is one of Muslim's two teachers in this hadith; the other is Abu Ghassan al-Masma'i Malik bin Abd al-Wahid. Perhaps he is the one who narrated it with dual Takbir instead of Ishaq, for he [Ishaq] narrated it with quadruple Takbir as in Al-Nasa'i. Likewise, Abu Nu'aym narrated it in (Al-Mustakhraj) and Al-Bayhaqi via Ishaq bin Ibrahim from Mu'adh bin Hisham with his chain, and in it is the quadruple Takbir. Abu Awanah also narrated it in his (Mustakhraj) via Ali bin al-Madini from Mu'adh. That is why Ibn al-Qattan said: (The correct view in this is the quadrupling of Takbir, and with it, the Adhan being nineteen words becomes correct, and it was restricted by that in the hadith itself. He said: It may occur in some narrations of Muslim with quadruple Takbir, which is what should be counted in the Sahih). Ended from (Al-Talkhis) (3/160). The hadith has another path from Ibn Muhayriz. Ibn Juraij narrated it, saying: Abd al-Aziz ibn Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah told me that Abdullah bin Muhayriz informed him - and he was an orphan under the care of Abu Mahdhurah when he equipped him for Sham - he said: I said to Abu Mahdhurah: I am going out to Sham and I fear I will be asked about your Adhan. So inform me. Abu Mahdhurah said to him:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I went out with a group and we were on some road of Hunayn when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was returning from Hunayn. So we met the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on some road. The Mu'adhin of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) called the prayer in the presence of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). We heard the voice of the Mu'adhin while we were avoiding him. So we started imitating him and mocking him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) heard the voice and sent for us until we stood before him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Which of you is the one whose voice I heard rising?) The group pointed to me and told the truth. So he released all of them but detained me. He said: (Stand and call for the prayer). So I stood, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) cast the Adhan upon me himself. He said: (Say: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah). Then he said: (Return and extend your voice). Then he said: (Say: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'ala as-salah. Hayya 'ala as-salah. Hayya 'ala al-falah. Hayya 'ala al-falah. Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illa Allah). Then he called me when I finished the Adhan and gave me a pouch containing some silver. I said: O Messenger of Allah, order me to call Adhan in Mecca. He said: (I have ordered you with it). So I came to Attab bin Asid, the governor of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in Mecca, and I called Adhan with him for prayer by the command of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Al-Nasa'i (103-104), and the context is his. And from him Ibn Hazm (3/151), Ibn Majah (241-242), Al-Tahawi (78), Al-Daraqutni (86), Ham (3/409). They added - except Al-Nasa'i - at its end: And those whom I met of my family who met Abu Mahdhurah informed me

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: similarly to what Abdullah bin Muhayriz informed me. Abu Dawood (82-83) narrated it briefly, limiting it to casting the Adhan upon him only. All of them narrated it with quadruple Takbir at the beginning except Al-Tahawi and Ahmad, as it occurred with them as dual only. Likewise, Nafi' bin Umar al-Jumahi narrated it from Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah who informed him from Abdullah bin Muhayriz al-Jumahi from Abu Mahdhurah: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught him the Adhan saying: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah... Then he mentioned the like of the Adhan in the hadith of Ibn Juraij from Abd al-Aziz ibn Abd al-Malik and its meaning. Narrated by Abu Dawood (83). Abd al-Aziz ibn Abd al-Malik and his father are acceptable (Maqbul) as in (Al-Taqrib), so the chain is good (Hasan), for it appears that both of them narrated it from Ibn Muhayriz. Al-Daraqutni (89) narrated it via Al-Shafi'i: He said: I met Ibrahim bin Abd al-Aziz ibn Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah calling Adhan as Ibn Muhayriz narrated, and I heard him narrating from his father from Ibn Muhayriz from Abu Mahdhurah from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with the meaning of what Ibn Juraij narrated. And I heard him calling Iqamah: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Hayya 'ala as-salah Hayya 'ala al-falah Qad qamat is-salah Qad qamat is-salah Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar La ilaha illa Allah. Ibn Juraij has another chain for it from Abu Mahdhurah. He said: Uthman bin al-Sa'ib told me,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: their freed slave, from his father Al-Sa'ib, the freed slave of Abu Mahdhurah, and from the mother of Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah, that they heard it from Abu Mahdhurah. Abu Mahdhurah said: I went out among ten youths with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and he was the most hated of people to us. So they called Adhan, and we stood calling Adhan mocking them. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Bring me those youths). He said: (Call Adhan). So they called Adhan, and I was one of them. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Yes, this is the one whose voice I heard. Go and call Adhan for the people of Mecca). He wiped his forelock and said: (Say: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah (twice). Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah (twice). Then return and witness that La ilaha illa Allah (twice) and witness that Muhammadan Rasulullah (twice). Hayya 'ala as-salah Hayya 'ala as-salah. Hayya 'ala al-falah Hayya 'ala al-falah (twice). Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illa Allah. And if you call the first Adhan of the morning, say: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm. And if you call Iqamah, say it twice: Qad qamat is-salah Qad qamat is-salah. Did you hear?). He said: And Abu Mahdhurah used to not cut his forelock nor part it because the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) wiped over it. Narrated by Ahmad (3/408), and the context is his, Abu Dawood (82), Al-Nasa'i (104), Al-Tahawi (78, 80-82), and Al-Daraqutni (86) from him. Except that Al-Tahawi mentioned the Takbir at the beginning twice only, not four times, which is a narration of Ahmad. Its chain is acceptable. Al-Fakihi narrated it in (Tarikh Makkah) (p. 12-13) with the quadrupling.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He has a third path from Abu Mahdhurah narrated by Al-Harith bin Ubaid from Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik from Abu Mahdhurah from his father from his grandfather, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, teach me the Sunnah of Adhan. He said: So he wiped the front of my head and said: (You say: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, raising your voice with it. Then you say: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah, lowering your voice with it. Then you raise your voice with the testimony: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'ala as-salah Hayya 'ala as-salah. Hayya 'ala al-falah Hayya 'ala al-falah. Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illa Allah). Narrated by Abu Dawood (81-82) and Ahmad (3/408-409), except that he mentioned the Takbir twice at the beginning. Its chain is also acceptable. Al-Tirmidhi narrated it (1/366), and the wording is his, and Al-Nasa'i (103) via Bishr bin Mu'adh: Ibrahim bin Abd al-Aziz ibn Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah told us, saying: My father and my grandfather both informed me from Abu Mahdhurah that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sat him down and cast the Adhan upon him letter by letter. Ibrahim said: Like our Adhan. Bishr said: So I said to him: Repeat it to me. So he described the Adhan with Tarji' (repetition). This is a good chain. Al-Tirmidhi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The hadith of Abu Mahdhurah regarding Adhan is an authentic hadith and has been narrated from him through more than one way). Al-Daraqutni (87) narrated from Al-Humaidi: Abu Ismail Ibrahim bin Abd al-Aziz ibn Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah told us, saying: I heard my grandfather Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah narrate from his father Abu Mahdhurah with it similarly. This Adhan is the Adhan of the people of Mecca, and it is the saying of Al-Shafi'i as Al-Tirmidhi said, and Ibn Hazm chose it (3/150). The second type: Its words are seventeen. It is like the first except that the Takbir at the beginning is twice, not four times. This is a narration of Muslim and others like Malik in (Al-Mudawwanah) (1/57-58) from the hadith of Abu Mahdhurah, but it is a outweighed narration as previously mentioned, except that it has witnesses indicating it has an origin in the Sunnah. Among them is from Sa'd al-Qaraz, the Mu'adhin of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): That Bilal used to call Adhan two by two and testify doubly, facing the Qiblah, saying: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah (twice). Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah (twice). Then he returns and says: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah (twice). Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah (twice). Hayya 'ala as-salah (twice). Hayya 'ala al-falah (twice). Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illa Allah... The Hadith. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Saghir (240-241) via Hisham bin Ammar: told us

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Abd al-Rahman bin Sa'd bin Ammar bin Sa'd al-Qaraz: My father told me from my grandfather from his father Sa'd. This is a weak chain containing weakness and unknown narrators as I clarified in my commentary on (Al-Mu'jam). It is witnessed by the hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Adhan during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was two by two, and the Iqamah was one, except that the Mu'adhin when saying: Qad qamat is-salah, said: Qad qamat is-salah (twice). Narrated by Ahmad (2/85, 87), and the wording is his, Al-Tayalisi (160), Abu Dawood (85), Al-Nasa'i (103), Al-Daraqutni (88), Al-Hakim (1/197-198), Al-Tahawi (1/79-80), Al-Darimi (1/270) via Shu'bah from Abu Ja'far the Mu'adhin: I heard Abu al-Muthanna narrating from him with it. This is a good chain. Al-Nawawi said (3/95): It is an authentic chain. Al-Hakim said likewise and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban narrated it in their (Sahihs) as in (Nasb al-Rayah) (1/262). It has another path in Al-Daraqutni narrated via Sa'id bin al-Mughirah al-Sayyad: Isa bin Yunus told us from Ubaidullah bin Umar from Nafi' from Ibn Umar with it without his saying: Except that... etc. Ibn al-Jawzi said: (This is an authentic chain; Sa'id bin al-Mughirah was declared trustworthy by Ibn Hibban and others).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: And among those who declared him trustworthy is Abu Hatim as in (Al-Talkhis) (3/159), therefore he said in (Al-Taqrib): (He is Thiqah [trustworthy]). It has a witness from the hadith of Salamah bin al-Akwa' narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and its chain is good as in (Al-Majma') (1/331), and from the hadith of Bilal that he used to double the Adhan Qat (89) with an authentic chain, and he was ordered to do so in the (Two Sahihs). This Adhan is the Adhan of the people of Medina, and Malik said it in (Al-Mudawwanah) (1/57). The third type: Its words are fifteen. It is like the first except there is no Tarji' in it, based on the hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid bin Abd Rabbih. It has preceded. This is the Adhan of the Kufans, and Abu Hanifa and Sufyan Al-Thawri held it as in (Al-Majmu') (3/93). 5 - It is not prescribed to add to the Adhan except in two places within it: First: In the first Adhan of the Morning (Subh) specifically, saying after his saying: Hayya 'ala al-falah: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm (Prayer is better than sleep) (twice). There are hadiths regarding it: First: From Abu Mahdhurah: That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) taught him in the first Adhan of the Morning: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Al-Tahawi (1/82) from Ibn Juraij, he said: Uthman bin al-Sa'ib informed me from the mother of Abd al-Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah from him. It has passed in lengthy form with the wording: (And if you call the first Adhan of the Morning, say: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm). It has another path narrated by Al-Nasa'i (1/106) and Ahmad (3/408) via Sufyan from Abu Ja'far from Abu Salman from Abu Mahdhurah who said: I used to call Adhan for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and I would say in the first Adhan of Fajr: Hayya 'ala al-falah, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, La ilaha illa Allah. This Abu Ja'far is unknown as in (Al-Khulasah). He said: It was said: He is Abu Ja'far al-Farra', and Abu Dawood declared him trustworthy. Perhaps because of this saying Ibn Hazm authenticated it as in (Al-Talkhis) (3/172). Al-Zarkashi said in (Takhrij Ahadith al-Rafi'i): (Ibn Hazm said: Its chain is authentic) as in (Subul al-Salam) (1/167). I say: I have not found Ibn Hazm's authentication now while the hadith is in his book (Al-Muhalla); rather, he cited it (3/151) via Waki' from Sufyan Al-Thawri from Abu Ja'far the Mu'adhin from Abu Sulaiman from Abu Mahdhurah that if he reached: Hayya 'ala al-falah in Fajr, he said: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm) and he did not explicitly state its authentication. Al-Shawkani said (2/32): (Ibn Khuzaimah also authenticated it, and Baqi bin Makhlad narrated it).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: There are two observations regarding it: First: That his saying: (Khuzaimah), I fear it was misspelled and the correct is: (Hazm) as we quoted from (Al-Talkhis) and Al-Zarkashi. Second: That his saying: (And Baqi bin Makhlad narrated it) implies that he narrated it from the way Al-Nasa'i narrated it, but it is not so; rather, he narrated it from another path. He said - as in (Al-Talkhis) (3/172) -: Yahya bin Abd al-Hamid told us: Abu Bakr bin Ayyash told us: Abd al-Aziz ibn Rafi' told me: I heard Abu Mahdhurah say: I was a young boy, so I called the Adhan before the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) for Fajr on the day of Hunayn. When I reached: Hayya 'ala al-falah, he said: (Append to it: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm). I say: Al-Tahawi narrated it (1/82) via Khalid bin Yazid: Abu Bakr bin Ayyash told us with it similarly. This is a good chain. The Second Hadith: From Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: In the first Adhan after Al-Falah was: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm. Narrated by Al-Tahawi (1/82) via Sufyan from Muhammad bin Ajlan from Nafi' from Ibn Umar with it. This is a good chain as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Talkhis) (3/169), and he attributed it to Al-Sarraj, Al-Tabarani, and Al-Bayhaqi from the hadith of Ibn Ajlan.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Third Hadith: From Anas who said: It is from the Sunnah that if the Mu'adhin says in the Fajr Adhan: Hayya 'ala al-falah, he says: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, As-salatu khairun min an-nawm (twice). Narrated by Al-Daraqutni (90) via Abu Usamah: Ibn Awn told us from Muhammad from him. Ibn Khuzaimah also narrated it in his (Sahih), and Al-Bayhaqi in his (Sunan) (1/423) and said: (Its chain is authentic). Then Al-Daraqutni and Al-Tahawi also narrated it (1/82) via Hushaym from Ibn Awn with it with the wording: Tathwib [saying prayer is better than sleep] in the Morning prayer was when the Mu'adhin said: Hayya 'ala al-falah, he said: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm (twice). This wording was narrated by Ibn al-Sakan and he authenticated it as in (Al-Talkhis) (3/148). In the chapter there are other hadiths with weakness in their chains; whoever wishes to see them should refer to (Nasb al-Rayah) and (Al-Talkhis). Know that it has not been reported in any of the narrations - as far as we know - explicitly that this statement: (As-salatu khairun min an-nawm) was in the second Adhan of the Morning. Rather, the hadiths are of two types: Some are explicit that it is in the first Adhan, like the first and second hadiths. And some are absolute without restriction to the first or second, like the third hadith and other hadiths whose chains are not authentic. So these are interpreted based on

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the restricted hadiths as per established rules. Based on this, (As-salatu khairun min an-nawm) is not from the words of the Adhan prescribed to call for prayer and announce the entry of its time; rather, it is from the words prescribed to wake the sleeper. See the completion of this discussion in (Subul al-Salam) (167-168). (Note): Al-Tahawi (1/81-82) devoted a chapter to the Mu'adhin saying in the Morning Adhan: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm. Then he mentioned that some people disliked that, and others opposed them and recommended it. He said: (It is the saying of Abu Hanifa, Abu Yusuf, and Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on them. This contradicts what Imam Muhammad stated in his (Muwatta) where he said (84): (As-salatu khairun min an-nawm is in the Morning call after finishing the call, and nothing should be added to the call that is not part of it). This is explicit that it is not recommended to say it in the Morning Adhan as Al-Tahawi headed it, but after it. And Allah knows best. The Second Place: If there is severe cold or rain, he adds after saying: Hayya 'ala al-falah or after finishing the Adhan: Sallu fi ar-rihal (Pray in the dwellings). Or he says: Wa man qa'ada fala haraja 'alayh (And whoever sits [stays back] there is no blame on him). Regarding that are hadiths: (1) From Ibn Abbas, narrated from him by Abdullah bin al-Harith who said: Ibn Abbas delivered a sermon to us on a day of mud (rain). When the Mu'adhin reached Hayya 'ala as-salah, he ordered him to call: As-salatu fi ar-rihal (Prayer in the dwellings). The people looked at one another, so he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: One who is better than him did this, and it is a strict determination (Azmah). Kh (2/77, 78), M (2/148), Ibn Hazm (3/142) via paths from him. And Abu Dawood narrated it with the wording: That Ibn Abbas said to his Mu'adhin on a rainy day: When you say Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah, do not say Hayya 'ala as-salah; say: Sallu fi buyutikum (Pray in your houses). It was as if the people disapproved of that, so he said: One who is better than me has done this. Indeed, Jumu'ah is a strict determination, and I disliked bringing you out so you would walk in mud and rain. This is a narration of Al-Bukhari (2/307) and likewise Muslim. Ibn Majah narrated it similarly (300). (2) From Ibn Umar, narrated from him by Nafi' who said: Ibn Umar called Adhan on a cold night at Dhajnan (a mountain near Mecca), then said: Sallu fi rihalikum (Pray in your dwellings). He informed us that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to order a Mu'adhin to call Adhan then say following it: (Ala sallu fi ar-rihal / Indeed, pray in the dwellings) on a cold or rainy night while traveling. Narrated by Kh (2/89-90), M (2/147), D (1/167), Ham (2/53) via Ubaidullah bin Umar from him. Malik narrated it (1/94), and from him Muhammad (126), as well as Al-Nasa'i (107), Al-Darimi (292), and Muslim and Abu Dawood also (2-4, 10) via other paths from Nafi' similarly. (3) From Amr bin Aws who said: A man from Thaqif informed us that he heard the caller of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) - meaning on a rainy night

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: while traveling - saying: Hayya 'ala as-salah Hayya 'ala al-falah, Sallu fi rihalikum. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (106-107) and Ahmad (5/373) from Amr bin Dinar from him. This is an authentic chain, and Amr bin Aws is a major Tabi'i. (4) From Nu'aym bin al-Nahham who said: I heard the Mu'adhin of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on a cold night while I was in my quilt, and I wished he would say: Sallu fi rihalikum. When he reached Hayya 'ala al-falah, he said: Sallu fi rihalikum. Then I asked him about it, and indeed the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had ordered him to do that. Narrated by Ahmad (4/320): Abd al-Razzaq told us: Ma'mar informed us from Ubaid bin Umair from a sheikh he named from him. This is a chain whose narrators are narrators of the Six except the sheikh who was not named [in this version]. It has another path from him with a different wording which is: (5) From Nu'aym also who said: The Morning call was made on a cold day while I was in my wife's woollen wrap. I said: I wish the caller would say: Whoever sits [stays back], there is no blame on him. So the caller of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) called at the end of his Adhan: Wa man qa'ada fala haraja 'alayh (And whoever sits, there is no blame on him). Narrated by Ahmad also (5/320) via Ismail bin Ayyash who said: Yahya bin Sa'id told me, he said: Muhammad bin Yahya bin Habban informed me from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) except that he said: (When he said: As-salatu khairun min an-nawm, he said: And whoever sits, there is no blame on him). Ismail bin Ayyash is weak regarding the Hijazis, and this narration of his is from them. However, Al-Tabarani narrated it from another path whose narrators are narrators of (Al-Sahih) as stated in (Al-Majma') (2/47). Al-Hafiz mentioned it in (Al-Fath) (2/78) similar to the narration of (Al-Kabir) and said: (Narrated by Abd al-Razzaq and others with an authentic chain). After writing this, I returned to (Al-Mustadrak) and saw that he narrated the hadith in (3/259) via Abd al-Razzaq: Ibn Juraij informed us from Nafi' from Abdullah bin Umar from Nu'aym al-Nahham with it similarly. He said: (Authentic). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. I say: It is as they said, except that it contains the 'an'an [saying 'from'] of Ibn Juraij, and he is a Mudallis. (Note): The second narration of the first hadith indicates that the Mu'adhin deletes the two Hayya'alahs [Hayya 'ala as-salah/al-falah] and replaces them with: As-salatu fi ar-rihal. Some hadith scholars have held this view; Ibn Khuzaimah wrote a chapter on it followed by Ibn Hibban and then Al-Muhibb al-Tabari: Deletion of Hayya 'ala as-salah on the day of rain. This is what the hadith implies, were it not that it is not apparent, for the lifting [attribution] of that to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was narrated. If its attribution is established, the Mu'adhin would have the choice between deleting them based on this hadith and affirming them based on other hadiths. And Allah knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (6) From Abu Hurairah who said: When it was a cold or rainy night, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would order the Mu'adhin, so he would call the first Adhan, and when he finished, he called out: As-salatu fi ar-rihal or fi rihalikum. Narrated by Abu Ahmad bin Adi as in (Tarh al-Tathrib fi Sharh al-Taqrib) (1/319) by Al-Hafiz al-Iraqi, and he did not comment on its chain with anything. 6 - It is from the Sunnah to call Adhan for the Morning (Subh) twice: One of them after the break of dawn as is for other times, and the other before that by a short time so the sleeper may wake up and the night-prayer performer may sleep a moment to wake up energetic, or whoever wants to fast may take Suhoor. There are hadiths regarding that: First: From Ibn Umar, and there are paths from him: (1) From Ibn Shihab from Salim bin Abdullah from his father who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: (Indeed Bilal calls Adhan at night, so eat and drink until you hear the Adhan of Ibn Umm Maktum). Narrated by Kh (2/79), M (3/128-129), N (105), T (2/392), Al-Darimi (1/270), Al-Tahawi (1/82), Al-Tayalisi (250), Ahmad (2/9). (2) From Abdullah bin Dinar from him with it. Narrated by Malik (1/95), and from him Muhammad (176-177), Kh (2/81), and likewise N

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (105), Taha (1/82), Ham (2/64), all from Malik from him with it. And Ham narrated it (2/62, 73, 79) and Al-Tahawi also via paths from Abdullah bin Dinar with it. (3) From Ubaidullah bin Umar from Nafi' from him. Narrated by Kh (2/83, 4/109-110), M (3/129), Mi (1/270), Ham (2/57) via paths from him. Muslim added: And there was not between them except that this one descends and this one ascends. Second: From Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) elevated, like the narration of Ubaidullah bin Umar in Muslim. Narrated by the two Sheikhs, N (105), Al-Darimi (270), Al-Tahawi (82), Ahmad (6/44, 54) via Ubaidullah bin Umar: Al-Qasim told us from her. It has another path from her with variation in wording and meaning, and we will mention it shortly. Third: From Anisa bint Khubaib (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: Bilal and Ibn Umm Maktum used to call Adhan for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Indeed Bilal calls Adhan at night, so eat and drink until Ibn Umm Maktum calls Adhan). So we used to hold Ibn Umm Maktum back from the Adhan and say: Stay as you are until we take Suhoor. And there was not between their two Adhans except that this one descends and this one ascends. Narrated by Al-Tayalisi (231): Shu'bah told us from Khubaib bin Abd al-Rahim: My aunt Anisa told me with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is an authentic chain on their condition. Ahmad extracted it (6/433) and Al-Tahawi (1/82-83) via paths from Shu'bah with it with the wording: Bilal or Ibn Umm Maktum. Like this with doubt in both places. It is a narration of Shu'bah also from a narration from Abdullah bin Dinar from Ibn Umar narrated by Al-Tahawi. Then Al-Nasa'i (2/105), Al-Tahawi also, Ahmad, and Al-Tabarani narrated it via Hushaym from Mansur bin Zadhan from Khubaib with it, affirming the second with the wording: (If Ibn Umm Maktum calls Adhan, eat and drink, and if Bilal calls Adhan, do not eat or drink). The context is Ahmad's. And he added: If the woman had some of her Suhoor left, she would say to Bilal: Wait until I finish my Suhoor. Its chain is also authentic like the first. Ibn Khuzaimah, Ibn al-Mundhir, and Ibn Hibban also narrated it via paths from Shu'bah. Al-Hafiz said (2/81): (Ibn Abd al-Barr and a group of Imams claimed that it is inverted and that the correct version is the hadith of the chapter [i.e., Bilal calls at night]. I used to incline to that until I saw the hadith in (Sahih Ibn Khuzaimah) from two other paths from Aisha, and in some of its wordings is what makes the occurrence of illusion in it unlikely, which is his saying:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: If Amr calls Adhan, for he is blind, so do not let him deceive you. And if Bilal calls Adhan, let no one eat). And Ahmad narrated it. I say: It is in (Al-Musnad) (6/185) like this: Ismail bin Umar told us, he said: Yunus bin Abi Ishaq told us from Al-Aswad bin Yazid who said: I said to Aisha, Mother of the Believers: At what time do you pray Witr? Perhaps she said: I do not pray Witr until they call Adhan, and they do not call Adhan until dawn breaks. She said: And the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had two Mu'adhins: Bilal and Amr bin Umm Maktum. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (If Amr calls Adhan, eat and drink, for he is a blind man. And if Bilal calls Adhan, withhold your hands, for Bilal does not call Adhan - he said thus - until morning comes). This is a chain whose narrators are all narrators of Muslim, except that it is disconnected between Yunus bin Abi Ishaq and Al-Aswad bin Yazid, for between their deaths is (84) years. Perhaps Yunus narrated it from his father from Al-Aswad, and the mention of his father fell from the printer or the narrator. This is supported by the fact that Al-Aswad bin Yazid is narrated from by Abu Ishaq [Yunus's father]. And Allah knows best. Then Al-Hafiz mentioned the way to reconcile this narration and what contradicts it as preceded, so refer to it. Fourth: From Ibn Mas'ud from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) who said: (Let not the Adhan of Bilal prevent one of you - or anyone of you - from his Suhoor, for he calls Adhan or calls at night to return the one standing in prayer among you and to alert the one sleeping among you. And it is not to say Al-Fajr or Al-Subh). And he gestured with his fingers and raised them up and lowered them down until he says like this. And

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the narrator said: With his index fingers: one above the other then stretched them to his right and left. Kh (2/82-83), M (3/129), D (1/369), N (1/105, 305), Ibn Majah (1/518-519), Al-Tahawi (1/83), Ahmad (1/386) via Sulaiman al-Taimi from Abu Uthman al-Nahdi from him with it. The context is Al-Bukhari's. Al-Hafiz said: (Its meaning is: to return the standing one - i.e., the night prayer performer - to his rest so he may rise for the Morning prayer energetic, or have a need to fast so he takes Suhoor, and to wake the sleeper so he may prepare for it by bathing and the like). 7 - And one Adhan is called for combining two prayers, whether combining early (Taqdim) or late (Ta'khir). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did likewise in Arafat and Muzdalifah. In it is the long hadith of Jabir describing his Hajj (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), in which he said: So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed on until he came to Arafat and found the dome had been pitched for him at Namirah, so he dismounted there until the sun passed its zenith... He called Adhan then established prayer (Iqamah) and prayed Dhuhr, then established prayer and prayed Asr, and did not pray anything between them. Then he rode... until he came to Muzdalifah, so he prayed Maghrib and Isha there with one Adhan and two Iqamahs, and did not glorify [pray voluntary prayers] between them... The Hadith. Narrated at length by Muslim (4/39-43) and the authors of the Sunan and others. Al-Nasa'i (1/107) and Al-Tahawi (1/411) extracted this portion regarding prayer at Muzdalifah. This is the school of Abu Hanifa and his companions, and it is the saying of Al-Shafi'i, and Ibn Hazm went to this (7/125-129). He said: And it is authentic from Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) combining them with two Adhans and two Iqamahs.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
