text: I say: Al-Tahawi narrated it (1/409) from Al-Aswad: That he prayed with Umar bin al-Khattab two prayers twice at Jam' [Muzdalifah], each prayer with an Adhan and Iqamah, and dinner between them. Its chain is authentic as Al-Hafiz said (3/413). That is also authentic from Ibn Mas'ud narrated by Al-Bukhari (3/492) and Ibn Hazm (7/127) similar to Umar's narration. And it was narrated from Ali (may Allah be pleased with him), and it is the saying of Muhammad bin Ali bin al-Hasan, and he mentioned it from his household. And Malik says it. Ibn Hazm said: (There is no proof in this saying from a report from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him (1), and there is no proof in the saying of Umar, Ibn Mas'ud, and Ali in that because others from the Companions differed with them). He said: (And the like of our saying was narrated from Ibn Umar, his son Salim, and Ata). 8 - Likewise, one Adhan is called for prescribed missed prayers even if they are many, just as he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did. There are hadiths regarding this: First: From Abu Qatadah regarding their sleeping through the Morning prayer, and in it is that he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered Bilal to call Adhan for it.
foot_note: 1. (1) Ibn al-Qayyim said in (Al-Zad) (1/212), mentioning his descent (peace be upon him) in Muzdalifah: (Then he ordered the Mu'adhin so he called Adhan, then established prayer so he prayed Maghrib... When they unloaded their luggage, he ordered and the prayer was established, then he prayed Isha al-Akhirah with an Iqamah without an Adhan. And he did not pray anything between them. It was narrated that he prayed them with two Adhans and two Iqamahs. And it was narrated with two Iqamahs without two Adhans. The correct view is that he prayed them with one Adhan and two Iqamahs as he did at Arafat).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Muslim, and it passed shortly before Adhan in issue (6). Second: From Abu Hurairah similarly. And it also passed there. Third: From Ibn Mas'ud: That the polytheists diverted the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from four prayers on the day of the Trench until whatever Allah willed of the night had passed. So he ordered Bilal who called Adhan, then established prayer so he prayed Dhuhr. Then he established prayer so he prayed Asr. Then he established prayer so he prayed Maghrib. Then he established prayer so he prayed Isha. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and others, and the discussion on it passed in issue (8) before Adhan. 9 - Adhan is prescribed for the one who prays alone, for if he calls Adhan in a barren land, hosts of Allah's soldiers whom his two sides cannot see pray behind him. There are hadiths regarding it: First: From Anas: That he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) listened one day and heard a man saying: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (On the Fitrah). Then he said: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. He said: (You have exited the Fire). So they looked and behold, he was a goat herder. Narrated by Muslim and others, and it passed in issue (3) of Adhan. Ibn Khuzaimah narrated it similarly in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib) (1/110) and its wording is more complete from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) heard a man while he was on a march of his saying: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. The Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (On the Fitrah). Then he said: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. He said: (He has exited

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: from the Fire). So the people raced to the man and behold, a sheep herder whom prayer time had reached, so he stood calling Adhan. Second: From Abdullah bin Rabi'ah al-Aslami who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was on a journey and heard a Mu'adhin saying: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah). He said: Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Ashhadu anni Muhammadun Rasulullah). The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (You will find him a sheep herder or one away from his family). Narrated by Ahmad (4/336), and the wording is his, and Al-Nasa'i (1/108) and added: (So they looked and behold, he was a sheep herder). It is via Shu'bah from Al-Hakam from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla from him. This is an authentic chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs. Al-Hakam bin Abd al-Malik narrated it from Ammar bin Muhammad from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla from Mu'adh bin Jabal who said... so he mentioned it similarly. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir) (159) and Ahmad (5/248). This Al-Hakam is weak by agreement. It has a witness in (Al-Musnad) from the hadith of Ibn Mas'ud with an authentic chain on the condition of the Six, which I mentioned in the commentary on Al-Tabarani.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Third: From Uqbah bin Amir, elevated: (Your Lord marvels at a sheep herder on the peak of a mountain calling for prayer and praying. Allah Almighty says: Look at this servant of Mine; he calls Adhan and establishes prayer fearing Me. I have forgiven My servant and admitted him to Paradise). Narrated by Abu Dawood (1/188), Al-Nasa'i (1/108), Al-Bayhaqi (1/405), Ahmad (4/157, 158) via Abu 'Ushanah from him. Abu 'Ushanah - with Damma on the un-dotted letter [Ain] - his name is Hayy bin Yu'min, and he is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib), so it is an authentic hadith. Fourth: From Salman, elevated: (If a man is in a desolate land and prayer time comes, let him perform ablution. If he does not find water, let him perform Tayammum. If he establishes prayer [Iqamah], two angels pray with him. And if he calls Adhan and establishes prayer, hosts of Allah's soldiers whom his two sides cannot see pray behind him). Narrated by Abd al-Razzaq and Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah from Mu'tamir bin Sulaiman al-Taimi from his father from Abu Uthman al-Nahdi from him with it. This is an authentic chain on the condition of the Six. Al-Bayhaqi narrated it (1/405) elevated and stopped (Mawquf), and preferred the stopped version. It is not hidden that it has the ruling of being elevated, especially since it has a witness mentioned in (Al-Talkhis) (3/145). See (Al-Targhib) (11/153).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Shafi'i and his companions went to acting upon these hadiths, saying that Adhan is prescribed for the solitary person whether he is in a desert or in a town. Al-Shafi'i said in (Al-Umm): (A man's Adhan in his house and his Iqamah are like them outside his house, whether he hears the Mu'adhins around him or not). Thus in (Al-Majmu') (3/85-86). He said in (Sharh Muslim): (This is the correct famous view in our Madhhab and the Madhhab of others, that Adhan is prescribed for the solitary person). I say: It is the Madhhab of the Hanafis as well. 10 - It is obligatory upon the Mu'adhin to seek reward from Allah in his Adhan, not seeking a wage for it. Allah Almighty said: {And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, being sincere to Him in religion} [Al-Bayyinah / 5]. Uthman bin Abi Al-Aas said: Among the last things the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) covenanted to me was that I should take a Mu'adhin who does not take a wage for his Adhan. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (1/409-410), Ibn Majah (1/244), Ibn Hazm (3/145) via Ash'ath bin Abd al-Malik al-Humrani from Al-Hasan from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). I say: Its narrators are all trustworthy except that Al-Hasan is a Mudallis, but he was followed in it, for Hammad bin Salamah said: Sa'id al-Jariri informed us from Abu al-Ala from Mutarrif from Mutarrif bin Abdullah from Uthman bin Abi Al-Aas who said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I said: O Messenger of Allah, make me the Imam of my people. He said: (You are their Imam, and follow the weakest of them, and take a Mu'adhin who does not take a wage for his Adhan). Narrated by Abu Dawood (1/8), Al-Nasa'i (109), Al-Tahawi (2/270), Al-Hakim (1/199, 217) via paths from him. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of Muslim). And Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is as they said. Then Al-Tirmidhi said: (The practice is upon this according to the people of knowledge; they disliked that the Mu'adhin take a wage for Adhan and recommended for the Mu'adhin to seek reward from Allah in his Adhan). Some of them went to the view that it is not permissible, which is the school of Ibn Hazm (3/145-146). He said: (It is the saying of Abu Hanifa and others). It is a view of the Shafi'is; Sheikh Abu Hamid, Al-Qaffal, and others asserted it, and Al-Mahamili, Al-Baghawi, and others authenticated it as in (Al-Majmu') (3/127). He said: (Al-Awza'i, Abu Hanifa, Ahmad, and Ibn al-Mundhir said it). Al-Shawkani inclined to this in (Nayl al-Awtar), so refer to it (2/49-50). What supports what these went to is what Abd al-Razzaq narrated from Ja'far bin Sulaiman al-Duba'i from Yahya al-Bakka who said: I saw Ibn Umar say to a man: Indeed, I hate you for the sake of Allah. Then he said to his companions: He sings in his Adhan and takes a wage for it. Ibn Hazm mentioned it. Al-Shawkani said: Ibn Hibban extracted from Yahya al-Bakka (and in the original: Al-Bakali, which is a misspelling) who said: I heard a man say to Ibn Umar:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Indeed, I love you for the sake of Allah. Ibn Umar said to him: Indeed, I hate you for the sake of Allah. He said: Glory be to Allah! I love you for the sake of Allah and you hate me for the sake of Allah? He said: Yes, you ask for a wage for your Adhan. I say: Al-Tahawi extracted similar to it via Hammad bin Salamah from Yahya al-Bakka. Then Ibn Hazm said: (No opponent from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, is known for Ibn Umar in this). I say: But regarding the establishment of this report from Ibn Umar there is doubt, because it revolves around Yahya al-Bakka, and he is weak as in (Al-Taqrib). More than one of the Imams weakened him, like Al-Nasa'i and Al-Daraqutni. Ibn Hibban said: (He narrates conundrums from trustworthy narrators; it is not permissible to use him as proof). Al-Dhahabi mentioned him in (Al-Mizan) then cited this report for him from Ibn Umar. Then it is apparent that Ibn Hibban only extracted this report of his in his book (Al-Du'afa) [The Weak Narrators], not in his (Sahih) as Al-Shawkani's action implies. And Allah knows best. 11 - However, if something comes to him without asking or longing of the soul, he should accept it and not reject it, for it is provision Allah drove to him. There are hadiths regarding it: First: From Khalid bin Adi al-Juhani who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: (Whoever receives a favor from his brother without asking or longing of the soul, let him accept it and not

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: reject it, for it is only provision Allah Almighty drove to him). Narrated by Ahmad (5/320-321): Abdullah bin Yazid told us: Sa'id bin Abi Ayyub told us: Abu al-Aswad told me from Bukair bin Abdullah bin Busr bin Sa'id from him. This is an authentic chain as Al-Mundhiri said (2/16). I say: Its narrators are narrators of the Six. Abu Ya'la and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) narrated it except that they said: (From his brother). As in (Al-Majma') (3/100). And Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) and Al-Hakim, and he said: (Authentic chain). Second: From Abu Hurairah, elevated: (Whoever is presented with something without asking for it, let him accept it, for it is only provision Allah drove to him). Narrated by Ahmad also (2/323, 490) and Al-Tayalisi (325) similarly via Hammad: Qatadah informed us from Abd al-Malik from him. This also has narrators of the Six except this Abd al-Malik, for he is not specified to me right now. Al-Haythami made him one of the narrators of the Sahih where he said: (Narrated by Ahmad and its narrators are narrators of the Sahih). So perhaps he is Abd al-Malik bin Umair or Abd al-Malik bin Abi Sulaiman. And Allah knows best. Al-Mundhiri said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (And its narrators are used as proof in the Sahih). Third: From Aisha, elevated: (O Aisha, whoever gives you a gift without asking, accept it, for it is only provision Allah presented to you). Narrated by Ahmad via Layth (who is Ibn Sa'd) from Yazid bin al-Had from Amr from Al-Muttalib bin Hantab that Abdullah bin Amir sent expenses and clothing to Aisha. She said to the messenger: O my son, I do not accept anything from anyone. When he left, she said: Bring him back to me. So they brought him back. She said: I remembered something the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to me. He said:... so she mentioned it. Its narrators are narrators of the Six except this Al-Muttalib, who is Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah bin Al-Muttalib ibn Hantab, attributed to his great-grandfather. He is truthful (Saduq) but practices much Tadlis and Irsal as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Haythami said: (Its narrators are trustworthy except that Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah is a Mudallis and his hearing from Aisha is disputed). Amr is Ibn Dinar. Al-Mundhiri said: (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad's narrators are trustworthy). Then he said: (If Al-Muttalib heard from Aisha, then the chain is connected; otherwise, the messenger to her was not named. And Allah knows best).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Fourth: From Abu Darda, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked about the giving of the Sultan (ruler), so he said: (What Allah gave you from it without asking or longing/expecting (Ishraf), take it and own it). Narrated by Ahmad: Abu Mu'awiyah told us: Hisham bin Hassan Al-Qardusi told us from Qais bin Sa'd from a man who narrated to him from him with it. And he added: He said: Al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him, said: There is no harm in it as long as you do not travel for it or long for it. Its men are the men of Muslim except the man who was not named. The Fifth: From 'Aidh bin Amr raised [to the Prophet]: (Whoever is offered anything of this provision without asking or longing, let him expand his provision with it. If he is wealthy enough without it, let him direct it to someone who is in more need of it than him). Narrated by Ahmad from paths from Abu Al-Ashhab from Amir Al-Ahwal, he said: 'Aidh bin Amr said... so he mentioned it. Its men are the men of the Sahih, except that it is interrupted (Munqati'). This Amir is Amir bin Abdul Wahid Al-Ahwal, and he did not meet 'Aidh bin Amr as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib). From this, you know that Al-Mundhiri's statement: (Ahmad's chain is good and strong) is not good. And his Sheikh said in (Al-Majma'): (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and he said: (Whoever is offered anything of this provision) and Ahmad omitted (anything), and the men of Ahmad are the men of the Sahih). I say: This contains clear deficiency because he did not alert to the defect of interruption. Also, the word (anything) is established in Ahmad in all narrations.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This, and Abdullah bin Imam Ahmad commented on the Hadith saying: I asked my father: What is Ishraf? He said: You say to yourself: So-and-so will send to me, so-and-so will give to me. The Sixth: From Umar bin Al-Khattab with the meaning of the fourth Hadith, and it will come in [the chapter of] Zakat, if Allah the Exalted wills. Refer to: Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad. In the chapter, from Abu Mahdhurah in the Hadith of Adhan, he said: Then he, peace be upon him, called me when I finished the Adhan and gave me a pouch containing some silver. This has passed in Issue (4) of Adhan. It contains Abdul Aziz bin Abdul Malik bin Abi Mahdhurah, whose status is unknown as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Talkhis). So using this Hadith as evidence in this chapter for the permissibility of taking wages absolutely is not good. First: Due to what you know of its weakness. Second: Because it does not involve asking for wages; rather, it involves giving without asking, and this is permissible as indicated by the Hadiths before it. Refer to Al-Shawkani. 12 - It is appropriate that the one who has the best voice and whose voice carries further should call Adhan. Regarding this are two Hadiths: The First: From Abdullah bin Zaid in the Hadith of Adhan, he said: When I woke up, I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and informed him of what I saw. He said: (Indeed it is a true vision, if Allah wills. So stand with...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Bilal and cast to him what you saw, and let him call Adhan with it, for he has a voice that carries further (andaa) than you). The Hadith. Its chain is good (Jayyid) as preceded in the first issue. The Second: From Abu Mahdhurah: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered around twenty men, so they called Adhan, and the voice of Abu Mahdhurah pleased him, so he taught him the Adhan... The Hadith. It is Sahih and has preceded in the fourth issue. Ibn Khuzaymah narrated it in his (Sahih) as in (Bulugh Al-Maram) and (Al-Talkhis). Al-Nasa'i extracted it from another path with the wording: So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (I have heard among these the Adhan of a human with a beautiful voice). So he sent for us... The Hadith. Its chain is acceptable. Ahmad and others extracted it similarly, and it preceded there, and Ibn Al-Sakan authenticated it as in (Al-Talkhis). 13 - Several matters are recommended for him: (1) That he calls Adhan while in a state of purity: The evidence for it is his saying, peace be upon him: (I disliked mentioning Allah except in a state of purity - or he said: upon purity). It preceded in [the chapter of] Purity. Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban authenticated it as in (Al-Talkhis). Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Daraqutni in (Al-Afrad) and Abu Al-Sheikh in (Al-Adhan) narrated from...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the Hadith of Abdul Jabbar bin Wa'il from his father, who said: It is a right and a Sunnah that a man does not call Adhan except while he is pure, and does not call Adhan except while he is standing. He said in (Al-Talkhis): (Its chain is Hasan except that it has an interruption, because it is established from Abdul Jabbar in (Sahih Muslim) that he said: I was a boy and did not comprehend my father's prayer. Al-Nawawi reported the consensus of the Imams of Hadith that he did not hear from his father). As for the Hadith: (None calls Adhan except one with Wudu), it is weak and not authentic. Al-Tirmidhi extracted it from the path of Mu'awiyah bin Yahya Al-Sadafi from Al-Zuhri from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet] with it. This Mu'awiyah is weak as Al-Hafiz said. And Al-Zuhri did not hear from Abu Huraira as Al-Tirmidhi said. Then he extracted it from the path of Yunus from Ibn Shihab with it, he said: Abu Huraira said: None calls for prayer except one with Wudu. He said: (This is more correct than the first Hadith). I say: It is not authentic as raised (Marfu') nor as stopped (Mawquf) due to the presence of interruption in both paths. Then Al-Tirmidhi said: The people of knowledge differed regarding Adhan without Wudu. Some people of knowledge disliked it, and this is the view of Al-Shafi'i and Ishaq. Some people of knowledge permitted it, and this is the view of Sufyan Al-Thawri, Ibn Al-Mubarak, and Ahmad.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (2) And that he stands upright: Regarding this are Hadiths: The First: From Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila, he said: Prayer was changed three times. He said: Our companions told us that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (It would please me if the prayer of the Muslims - or he said: the believers - was one...) So he mentioned the Hadith. Then a man from the Ansar came and said: O Messenger of Allah, when I returned due to what I saw of your concern, I saw a man appearing to wear two green garments, so he stood on the mosque and called Adhan, then he sat for a sitting, then he stood [and said] the like of it except that he says: Kad Qamat Al-Salah (Prayer has been established). Were it not that people would say [I am lying], I was awake not asleep. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Indeed Allah has shown you good, so order Bilal to call Adhan). He said: Then Umar said: Beware, I indeed saw the like of what he saw, but when I was preceded, I was shy. Narrated by Abu Dawood from the path of Shu'bah from Amr bin Murrah: I heard Ibn Abi Laila with it. This is a Sahih chain, its men are the men of the Six. Al-Tahawi extracted it from the path of Zaid bin Abi Anisah from Amr bin Murrah with it similarly. Ibn Abi Shaybah extracted it in his (Musannaf) as in (Nasb Al-Rayah):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: He said: Waki' told us: Al-A'mash told us from Amr bin Murrah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila, he said: The Companions of Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, told us that Abdullah bin Zaid Al-Ansari came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah... The Hadith similarly, except he said: So he stood on a wall. Al-Tahawi and Ibn Hazm extracted it from Waki' with it briefly. Ibn Hazm said: (This chain is of utmost authenticity). Likewise, Ibn Khuzaymah and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from Waki'. This narration clarifies what was ambiguous in Shu'bah's narration, which is that his saying: 'Our companions', he only intended by it the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. For this reason, Ibn Hazm authenticated it, as well as Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid as in (Al-Talkhis) and (Nasb Al-Rayah). It refutes the statement of those who found fault with the Hadith claiming interruption or being Mursal due to the appearance of some narrations from Ibn Abi Laila. Al-Mas'udi narrated it from Amr bin Murrah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from Mu'adh bin Jabal similarly. It preceded in the first issue and will come shortly. Likewise, Abu Bakr bin Ayyash narrated it from Al-A'mash from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila with it. Ahmad and Al-Daraqutni narrated it with the wording: He descended upon the stump of a wall. Al-Tahawi extracted it from the path of Abdullah bin Dawud from Al-A'mash from Amr bin Murrah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila that Abdullah bin Zaid with it. So he dropped the mention of Mu'adh or any of the Companions from the chain.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Al-Daraqutni extracted similar to it from another path from Amr and said: (Ibn Abi Laila's hearing from Abdullah bin Zaid is not established. Al-A'mash and Al-Mas'udi said: From Amr bin Khalid bin Murrah from Ibn Abi Laila from Mu'adh bin Jabal, and it is not established. The correct view is what Sufyan and Shu'bah narrated from Amr bin Murrah and Husayn bin Abdul Rahman from Ibn Abi Laila as Mursal). This is what he said. You have known that Waki's narration from Al-A'mash is connected and has a Sahih chain; perhaps Al-Daraqutni did not come across it. What we are certain of is that Ibn Abi Laila heard this Hadith from a group of Companions whom he did not name, so sometimes he attributed it to them, sometimes he attributed it to the owner of the story who is Abdullah bin Zaid, and sometimes to some of its narrators from the Companions like Mu'adh. He used to do that even if he did not hear it from them directly, considering that he heard it attributed to them, so this Irsal (omission of link) does not harm then, as is obvious. Whoever wishes for more verification on that should refer to the commentary of Sheikh Ahmad Muhammad Shakir on the book (Usul Al-Ahkam) by Ibn Hazm. The Second Hadith: From Wa'il bin Hujr who said: It is a right and Sunnah that a man does not call Adhan except while pure, and does not call Adhan except while standing. It passed shortly. Ibn Al-Mundhir said: (The people of knowledge agreed that standing for Adhan is from the Sunnah). Refer to (Al-Fath).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (3) On a high place: Regarding this are Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid regarding the Adhan of the angel, he said: So he stood on the mosque and called Adhan. In a narration: On a wall. In another: Stump of a wall. Mention of this has preceded shortly. (Al-Jidhm) with Kasrah or Fathah: The root/base; he intended the remains of a wall. The Second: From a woman from Banu Najjar, she said: My house was among the tallest houses around the mosque, and Bilal used to call the dawn Adhan upon it. He would come at Sahar (pre-dawn), sit on the house looking at the dawn. When he saw it, he would stretch (tamat'ta) then say: O Allah I praise... The Hadith. Narrated by Abu Dawood from Muhammad bin Ishaq from Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Al-Zubayr from Urwah bin Al-Zubayr from her. This is a chain whose men are trustworthy except that Ibn Ishaq is a Mudallis. Therefore, Al-Nawawi said: (Its chain is weak). As for Al-Hafiz's saying in (Al-Fath): (Its chain is Hasan), it is not Hasan. Had he remained silent on it as he did in (Al-Talkhis), it would have been better.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: But I found another path for it. Ibn Sa'd said in (Al-Tabaqat): Muhammad bin Umar informed us: Mu'adh bin Muhammad told me from Yahya bin Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Sa'd bin Zurarah, he said: Whoever heard Al-Nawar, the mother of Zaid bin Thabit, informed me saying: My house was the tallest house around the mosque, so Bilal used to call Adhan on top of it from the first time he called Adhan until the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, built his mosque. Then he would call Adhan afterwards on the roof of the mosque, something having been raised for him above its roof. Muhammad bin Umar is Al-Waqidi: Weak. The Third: From Ibn Umar, he said: Ibn Umm Maktum used to call Adhan on top of the house. Narrated by Abu Al-Sheikh from Abdullah bin Nafi' from his father from him. Al-Zayla'i and Al-Asqalani mentioned it and remained silent on it. This Abdullah bin Nafi' is weak as in (Al-Taqrib). The meaning of the Hadith is supported by the Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, had two Mu'adhins: Bilal and Ibn Umm Maktum the blind. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Indeed Bilal calls Adhan at night, so eat and drink until Ibn Umm Maktum calls Adhan). He said: And there was nothing between them except that this one descends and that one ascends. (Agreed upon) and the wording is Muslim's.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: They also extracted it from the Hadith of Aisha, and its Takhrij preceded in Issue (6). The Fourth: From Abu Barza Al-Aslami, he said: It is from the Sunnah to have the Adhan in the minaret and the Iqamah in the mosque. Narrated by Abu Al-Sheikh in the Book of Adhan from Sa'id Al-Jurayri from Abdullah bin Shaqiq from him. It is in (Sunan Sa'id bin Mansur) similarly. The two aforementioned Hafizs remained silent on it. If the chain to Sa'id is free from defect, then it is a Sahih chain. Then I saw Al-Bayhaqi narrating it in his (Sunan) from the path of Khalid bin Amr, he said: (Sufyan told us from Al-Jurayri with it). And he said: (This is a Munkar Hadith; no one narrated it except Khalid bin Amr, and he is weak, Munkar in Hadith). The Fifth: From Uqbah bin Rafi' raised [to the Prophet]: (Your Lord marvels at a shepherd of sheep at the peak of a Shaziyya of a mountain calling for prayer...). The Hadith. It passed in the ninth issue. (Al-Shaziyya) is a raised piece at the head of the mountain. It contains an indication of the desirability of Adhan on a high place, even if it is on a mountain.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (4) And he faces the Qiblah: Regarding this are two Hadiths: The First: The Hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid regarding the descent of the angel with Adhan. He said: While I was between sleeping and wakefulness, I saw a figure wearing two green garments, so he faced the Qiblah and said: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar... The Hadith. It passed in the first issue. It is from the narration of Al-Mas'udi from Amr bin Murrah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from Mu'adh. Al-Mas'udi had become confused, except that he was followed up on this sentence. Ishaq said in his (Musnad) according to what is in (Al-Talkhis): Abu Mu'awiyah told us from Al-A'mash from Amr bin Murrah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila, he said: Abdullah bin Zaid came and said: O Messenger of Allah, indeed I saw a man descend from the sky, so he stood on the stump of a wall and faced the Qiblah... So he mentioned the Hadith. The Second: From Sa'd Al-Qaraz, the Mu'adhin of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: That Bilal used to call Adhan in pairs, repeat the Tashahhud, facing the Qiblah, saying... so he mentioned it. Narrated by Al-Tabarani, and its chain is weak as preceded in the second type of Adhan. Al-Hakim extracted it with the wording: Indeed Bilal, when he said Takbir for Adhan, faced the Qiblah... The Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: He and Al-Dhahabi remained silent on it. (5) And he raises his voice: (For no Jinn, nor human, nor anything hears the range of the Mu'adhin's voice except will testify for him on the Day of Resurrection) and (He has the reward of whoever prays with him). This is from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him. Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Abi Sa'sa'ah Al-Ansari narrated it from him: That Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri said to him: I see you love sheep and the desert. So if you are among your sheep or in your desert and you call for prayer, then raise your voice with the call, for no one hears... The Hadith. Abu Sa'id said: I heard it from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Agreed upon. I extracted it in (Al-Ta'liq Al-Raghib). The Hadith has witnesses from the Hadith of Ibn Umar with a Sahih chain, Abu Huraira with a Hasan chain, and Al-Bara' bin Azib with a Sahih chain. I extracted them there. The wording of Al-Bara's Hadith is: (And the Mu'adhin is forgiven as far as his voice reaches, and every wet and dry thing confirms him, and he has the reward of whoever prays with him). (6) And he puts his two fingers in his ears: Regarding this are Hadiths: The First: From Abu Juhaifa, he said: I saw Bilal calling Adhan and turning, and I followed his mouth here and there, and his two fingers were in his ears... The Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Narrated by Ahmad, he said: Abdul Razzaq told us: Sufyan informed us from Awn bin Abi Juhaifa from his father. Al-Hakim narrated it from Ahmad. Al-Tirmidhi narrated it from Mahmud bin Ghailan: Abdul Razzaq told us with it. Then he narrated it from the path of Ibrahim bin Utbah from Al-Thawri and Malik bin Mighwal from Awn bin Abi Juhaifa similarly. He said: (The two Sheikhs agreed on extracting the Hadith of Malik bin Mighwal and Umar bin Za'idah from Awn bin Abi Juhaifa from his father regarding the mention of his [Prophet's], peace be upon him, descent at Al-Abtah, except that they did not mention in it the insertion of the finger into the ears and the turning in Adhan. It is Sahih on their condition, and they are two Sunnah acts). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. That indicates that Abdul Razzaq was not alone in mentioning the two fingers and the turning in it; rather, Al-Husayn bin Ja'far followed him in all of that, and he is Al-Husayn bin Mansur bin Ja'far Al-Nisaburi, a trustworthy jurist. And Ibrahim bin Utbah - so in the original, and the correct is: Uyainah with an unpointed distinct letter then a double point letter underneath then a Nun, he is the brother of Sufyan bin Uyainah, and he is truthful but hallucinates (yahim) as in (Al-Taqrib). Mu'ammal bin Ismail also followed him from Sufyan. Abu Awanah narrated it in his (Sahih) similarly as in (Nasb Al-Rayah) and (Al-Fath). Likewise, Ibn Khuzaymah narrated it as in (Al-Talkhis). He said: And Abu Nu'aym narrated it in...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...his (Mustakhraj), and with him: (He saw Bilal calling Adhan and turning, and his two fingers were in his ears). Likewise, Al-Bazzar narrated it. Similarly, Al-Thawri was not alone in it from Awn; rather Malik bin Mighwal followed him as preceded in Al-Hakim's narration, and he is trustworthy and firm. Muslim extracted this Hadith of his, but it does not contain the placing of the two fingers. Hajjaj bin Artat also followed him in Ibn Majah, Al-Darimi, Sa'id bin Mansur, Ibn Abi Shaybah and others. And Idris Al-Awdi narrated by Al-Tabarani, and Hammad and Hushaym all from Awn with it. Abu Al-Sheikh Al-Asbahani narrated it in the Book of Adhan as in (Nasb Al-Rayah) and (Al-Talkhis). In summary, the Hadith with these two additions is Sahih. Al-Tirmidhi said after extracting it: (It is a Hasan Sahih Hadith). The intended meaning by turning in it is: Turning with the head only, not with the rest of the body. Thus it came explained in the (Two Sahihs) and others, and it will come shortly. The Second Hadith: From Abdullah Al-Hawzani: He said: I said to Bilal: How was the spending of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him... So he mentioned the Hadith. And in it Bilal said: So I put my finger in my ear and called Adhan. Al-Hafiz mentioned it in (Al-Fath) and said: (It is among the soundest witnesses for the first Hadith). And he said: (Abu Dawood and Ibn Hibban narrated it from the path of Abu Salam Al-Dimashqi that Abdullah Al-Hawzani narrated it to him).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: The Hadith is in (Sunan Abi Dawood) but he did not cite the Hadith in full. Rather he said in a place in it: So he mentioned the Hadith. And at its end: And he narrated the story. Indicating its abbreviation. Therefore, it does not contain Bilal's saying: (So I made...) etc. It appears it is among what was abbreviated by him. Its chain is thus: Abu Tawbah Al-Rabi' bin Nafi' told us: Mu'awiyah - meaning Ibn Salam - told us from Zaid that he heard Abu Salam: Abdullah Al-Hawzani told me with it. This is a Sahih chain, all its men are trustworthy men of Muslim except Abdullah Al-Hawzani, who is Ibn Luhai, and he is a trustworthy Mukhadram (lived in Jahiliyya and Islam). The Third: From Sa'd Al-Qaraz: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered Bilal to put his two fingers in his ears. He said: (It is louder for your voice). Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir) from the path of Abdul Rahman bin Sa'd bin Ammar bin Sa'd: My father told me from his father from his grandfather. Al-Hakim extracted it dropping Sa'd from the chain. This is a weak chain containing weakness and anonymity. Another Hadith with this chain preceded for him in the second type of Adhan. Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Kabir) with the wording: (If you call Adhan, put your two fingers in your ears, for it is louder for your voice).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Fourth: From Abdullah bin Zaid in the Hadith of the angel's vision, he said: When it was the night before Fajr, drowsiness overcame me, so I saw a man wearing two green garments while I was between sleeping and wakefulness. He stood on the roof of the mosque, put his two fingers in his ears, and called out... The Hadith at length. Narrated by Abu Al-Sheikh in the Book of Adhan from Yazid bin Abi Ziyad from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from him as in (Al-Talkhis) and (Nasb Al-Rayah). He said: (And Yazid bin Abi Ziyad is spoken about [criticized]). And Abdul Rahman from Abdullah bin Zaid, the statement of those who said: (There is interruption in it) has preceded. This, and Al-Tirmidhi said after citing the first Hadith: (And upon it is the practice among the people of knowledge; they recommend for the man that the Mu'adhin inserts his two fingers in his ears during Adhan. Some people of knowledge said: And in Iqamah also he inserts his two fingers in his ears, and it is the view of Al-Awza'i). In (Al-Fath): (The scholars said: There are two benefits in that: First: It may be louder for his voice. Second: It is a sign for the Mu'adhin so that one who sees him from a distance or is deaf knows that he is calling Adhan). (Alert): No designation of the finger recommended to be placed has been reported. Al-Nawawi asserted it is the index finger (Al-Musabbihah), and the usage of 'finger' is metaphorical for the fingertip.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (7) And he turns right with his head when saying: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah, and left when saying: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah, and does not rotate. In the Hadith of Abu Juhaifa, he said: I came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in Mecca while he was at Al-Abtah in a red leather tent of his. He said: So Bilal came out with his Wudu water; among [people] were those taking/receiving and those sprinkling. He said: Then the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out wearing a red suit; it is as if I am looking at the whiteness of his shins. He said: So he performed ablution and Bilal called Adhan. He said: So I began following his mouth here and there, saying right and left, saying: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah, Hayya 'ala Al-Falah... The Hadith. Narrated by Muslim from the path of Waki': Sufyan told us: Awn bin Abi Juhaifa told us from his father. With this chain Ahmad extracted it similarly. Abu Dawood extracted it from the path of Qais bin Al-Rabi' and Waki' from Sufyan together with the wording: When he reached Hayya 'ala Al-Salah, Hayya 'ala Al-Falah, he twisted his neck right and left and did not rotate... The Hadith. Its chain is Sahih as Al-Nawawi said. Al-Nasa'i narrated it from Waki' also briefly with the wording: So he called Adhan and began saying in his Adhan like this, turning right and left.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And Al-Bukhari and Al-Darimi from Muhammad bin Yusuf: Sufyan told us with it with the wording: That he saw Bilal calling Adhan, so I began following his mouth here and there in the Adhan. Likewise, Al-Nasa'i narrated it from Ishaq Al-Azraq from Sufyan. Al-Nawawi said: (Our Madhhab is that it is recommended to turn during the Haya'alah (Hayya 'ala...) right and left, and not to rotate nor turn his back to the Qiblah, whether he is on the ground or on a minaret. Al-Nakha'i, Al-Thawri, Al-Awza'i, and Abu Thawr said this. It is a narration from Ahmad. Ibn Sirin said: Turning is disliked. Malik said: He does not rotate or turn unless he wants to make people hear. Abu Hanifa, Ishaq, and Ahmad in a narration said: He turns and does not rotate unless he is on a minaret, then he rotates. Those who said he rotates argued with the Hadith of Hajjaj bin Artat from Awn bin Abi Juhaifa from Abu Juhaifa, he said: I saw the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, at Al-Abtah, so Bilal came out and called Adhan, so he rotated in his Adhan. Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Bayhaqi. Our companions argued with the authentic Hadith preceding that he did not rotate. As for the Hadith of Hajjaj, the answer to it is from several aspects: First: It is weak because Hajjaj is weak and a Mudallis (obfuscator), and the weak is not used as evidence. The Mudallis, if he says 'from' (an), is not used as evidence even if he were just and precise. The second answer: It contradicts the narration of the trustworthy narrators from Awn bin Abi Juhaifa from his father, so it must be rejected. Third: Rotation is interpreted as turning to reconcile between the narrations).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: This last answer is the one that must be resorted to. As for the first and second, they are weak due to the establishment of rotation from paths which explanation preceded shortly. It was differed: Does he rotate in the first two Haya'alahs once and in the second once? Or does he say: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah to his right then Hayya 'ala Al-Falah to his left, and likewise the other? Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid said: (The second is preferred because each direction gets a share of them). He said: (The first is closer to the wording of the Hadith) as in (Al-Fath). I say: The first is supported by the Hadith of Sa'd Al-Qaraz in the Adhan of Bilal: Then he turns to his right saying: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah twice, then he turns to his left saying: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah twice, then he faces the Qiblah saying: Allahu Akbar... The Hadith. It contains weakness and passed in the fourth issue. (8) And that his Adhan be at the beginning of the time, as Bilal used to do: He used to call Adhan when the sun passed the zenith, not omitting/delaying (yakhram), then he would not call Iqamah until the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out. He said: When he came out, he called Iqamah when he saw him. Narrated by Muslim and Ahmad, and the wording is his (1) from the path of Zuhair from...
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Tayalisi narrated it (105) from the path of Hammad bin Salamah from Simak without his saying: Then he would not call Iqamah... etc. Then he narrated it from the path of Sharik with the wording: Bilal used not to omit/delay Adhan, and he used to perhaps delay Iqamah a little.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Simak bin Harb from Jabir bin Samurah, he said... so he mentioned it. It is in (Al-Musnad) and (Sunan Abi Dawood) and others from other paths from Simak briefly. Perhaps it will come in [the chapter of] Iqamah. His saying: La yakhram means: He does not leave anything from its wordings, as in (Al-Nayl). This meaning is probable, but the more likely view to me is that the meaning of 'La yakhram' is: He does not decrease nor delay from the time, which is the time of the sun's zenith. The evidence for this is the second part of the Hadith, for he says: That Bilal used to delay the Iqamah until the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out. I found after that what supports this from the narration, which is what Al-Tayalisi narrated: Qais told us from Simak bin Harb from Jabir, he said: Bilal used to call Adhan when the sun declined (tadhad), and perhaps he delayed Iqamah a little and perhaps he hastened it a little. As for Adhan, he used not to omit/delay from the time. This is a text regarding what we preferred. And Allah knows best. The Hadith contains maintaining Adhan upon the entry of Dhuhr time without advancing or delaying. And so are the rest of the prayers except Fajr as preceded. 14 - Upon the one who hears the call are several matters: First: To say like what the Mu'adhin says: Regarding this are Hadiths:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The First: From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (If you hear the call, say like what the Mu'adhin says). Narrated by Malik, and from him Al-Bukhari, and likewise Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and from him Ibn Al-Sunni, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, Ahmad, and Al-Khatib, all of them from Malik from Al-Zuhri from Ata bin Yazid Al-Laithi from him. Al-Tahawi's narration is from Ibn Wahb, he said: Malik and Yunus informed me from Ibn Shihab with it. Likewise, Abu Awanah extracted it as in (Al-Fath). Similarly, Ahmad extracted it in a narration from the path of Uthman bin Umar: Malik and Yunus bin Yazid informed us from Al-Zuhri. From this path, Al-Darimi and Al-Tahawi also extracted it, but they did not mention Malik in the chain. Likewise, Al-Tayalisi narrated it from Ibn Al-Mubarak from Yunus alone. Abbad bin Ishaq or Abdul Rahman bin Ishaq contradicted Malik and Yunus bin Yazid, narrating it from Ibn Shihab from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet] similarly. Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Tahawi. Al-Tirmidhi mentioned it suspended and said: And the narration of Malik is more correct. Thus said Ahmad bin Salih, Abu Hatim, and Abu Dawood as in (Al-Fath).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Second: From Mu'awiyah raised [to the Prophet]: (If you hear the Mu'adhin calling Adhan, say like his saying or as he said). Narrated by Al-Tahawi from the path of Muhammad bin Amr Al-Laithi from his father from his grandfather, he said: We were with Mu'awiyah when the Mu'adhin called Adhan, so Mu'awiyah said: I heard the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say... so he mentioned it. Its men are trustworthy except this Amr, who is Ibn Alqamah bin Waqqas. Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy and authenticated his report as in (Al-Khulasah), and in (Al-Taqrib) [it says] he is Acceptable (Maqbul). From this path, Ahmad extracted it but made it from his [Prophet's], peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, action, not his saying. Likewise, it is in the (Sahih) from another path and will come shortly if Allah the Exalted wills. The Third: From Mu'adh bin Anas Al-Juhani who raised it: (If you hear the caller calling (yathuwib) for prayer, say as he says). Narrated by Ahmad from Ibn Lahi'ah from Zaban from Sahl bin Mu'adh from his father. This is a chain that is acceptable in witnesses. Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) as in (Al-Majma'). The Fourth: From Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas raised [to the Prophet]:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (If you hear the Mu'adhin, say like what he says...) The Hadith. It will come. Narrated by Muslim and others. And Abu Dawood and others narrated it similarly, and it will come. The Fifth: From Umm Habiba: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he was with her on her day and night and heard the Mu'adhin, said as the Mu'adhin said. Narrated by Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad - and the wording is his - from the path of Abu Al-Malih bin Usama, he said: Abdullah bin Utbah bin Abi Sufyan informed me: My paternal aunt Umm Habiba told me with it. This is a chain whose men are the men of the two Sheikhs except Abdullah bin Utbah. Al-Dhahabi said: (He is hardly known; Abu Al-Malih alone narrated from him). In (Al-Taqrib): (He is Acceptable). From this, you know that the statement of the author of (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is Sahih) is incorrect. And his saying (1): (Abdullah bin Utbah, Al-Nasa'i narrated from him and Ibn Khuzaymah extracted for him in his (Sahih), so he is trustworthy according to him, and the rest of his men are trustworthy) does not justify his authentication of the Hadith, because authenticity has established conditions in the terminology of Hadith. Some Imams might deviate regarding some of them, such as probity (Adalah); the narrator must be known by it for his Hadith to be authentic according to the majority, whereas Ibn Khuzaymah and his likes are satisfied with him not being known for disparagement (Jarh), and this is not sufficient according to the investigators among the Muhaddithin.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning Al-Busiri in his book (Misbah Al-Zujajah fi Zawa'id Ibn Majah). (Publisher)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Similarly, the silence of Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath) should not be passed over. He attributed it to Al-Nasa'i with the addition: (Until he falls silent). It is with Al-Tahawi also, and likewise Ahmad in a narration of his. Al-Hakim narrated it and said: Sahih on the condition of the two Sheikhs, and Al-Dhahabi did not critique him with anything, which is a clear error. Al-Nasa'i did not narrate it in his (Sunan), and apparently, it is in his book (Amal Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah). The Sixth: In (Al-Mustadrak) and Ibn Al-Sunni: (And he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to say: (Whoever says like what this one says [meaning the Mu'adhin] - with certainty - enters Paradise). It is from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so Bilal stood to call. When he fell silent, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... so he mentioned it. Al-Nasa'i and Al-Hakim extracted it from the path of Ibn Wahb from Amr bin Al-Harith that Bukayr bin Al-Ashajj told that Ali bin Khalid Al-Zurqi told him that he heard Abu Huraira with it. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Isnad), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is not as they said, for this Nadr [sic - likely referring to Ali bin Khalid or a mix-up in text] was authenticated only by Ibn Hibban. Therefore, Al-Hafiz limited himself to saying in (Al-Taqrib): (He is Acceptable). Ahmad narrated it, and his wording is more complete, which is:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, at the ravines of Yemen, so Bilal stood to call. When he fell silent, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Whoever says like what this one says - with certainty - enters Paradise). It has a witness from the Hadith of Anas extracted by Abu Ya'la. Al-Haythami said: (It contains Yazid Al-Raqashi; Shu'bah and others weakened him, and Ibn Adi and Ibn Ma'in authenticated him in a narration). Another witness is from the Hadith of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, in Muslim and others, and it comes shortly. (It is permissible, rather recommended, that he says sometimes: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah [Hawqala] in place of (Hayya 'ala Al-Salah Hayya 'ala Al-Falah). Regarding this are Hadiths: The First: From Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (If the Mu'adhin says: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, and one of you says: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar; then he says: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah, and he says: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah; then he says: Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasul Allah, and he says: Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasul Allah; then he says: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah, and he says: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah; then he says: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah, and he says: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah; then he says: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar, and he says: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar; then he says: La ilaha illa Allah, and he says: La ilaha illa Allah from his heart, he enters Paradise). Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Al-Tahawi from Ismail bin...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Ja'far from Umarah bin Ghaziyyah from Khubaib bin Abdul Rahman bin Ishaq from Hafs bin Asim bin Umar bin Al-Khattab from his father from his grandfather Umar. The Second Hadith: From Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan, and there are paths from him: 1 - From Alqamah bin Waqqas that Mu'awiyah heard the Mu'adhin say: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. So Mu'awiyah said: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. So the Mu'adhin said: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. So Mu'awiyah said: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. So the Mu'adhin said: Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasul Allah. So Mu'awiyah said: Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasul Allah. So the Mu'adhin said: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah. So he said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah. So he said: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah. So he said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah. Then the Mu'adhin said: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar La ilaha illa Allah. So he said: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar La ilaha illa Allah. Then he said: Thus did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, do. Narrated by Al-Darimi and Al-Tahawi from the path of Sa'id bin Amir: Muhammad bin Amr told us from his father from his grandfather with it. Ahmad and Ibn Khuzaymah also extracted it - as in (Al-Fath) - from the path of Yahya Al-Qattan from Muhammad bin Amr with it, except that he said: So he said: Allahu Akbar, so he said: Allahu Akbar, so he said: La ilaha illa Allah, so he said: La ilaha illa Allah. So he separated the Tahlil from the two Takbirs.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This chain contains anonymity due to this Amr, who is Ibn Alqamah bin Abi Waqqas - as mentioned shortly before - except that he was followed up on it. Ibn Jurayj said: Amr bin Yahya informed me that Isa bin Umar informed him from Abdullah bin Alqamah bin Waqqas from Alqamah bin Waqqas, he said: I was with Mu'awiyah when his Mu'adhin called Adhan. So Mu'awiyah said as the Mu'adhin said until when he said: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah, he said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah. When he said: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah, he said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah. And he said after that what the Mu'adhin said. Then he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say like that. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i, and from him Ibn Hazm, Al-Tahawi, Ahmad, and Ibn Khuzaymah also. Then Al-Tahawi extracted it from the path of Ibn Wahb, he said: Dawud bin Abdul Rahman told me from Amr bin Yahya from Abdullah bin Alqamah with it. So he dropped Isa bin Umar from between them. The men of this chain are trustworthy except Abdullah bin Alqamah; his condition is like the condition of his brother Amr, and it preceded. 2 - From Hisham Al-Dastawa'i from Yahya bin Abi Kathir from Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Al-Harith from Isa bin Talha, he said: I entered upon Mu'awiyah, and the caller called. He said: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. So Mu'awiyah said: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar. He said: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah. He said: And I testify that there is no god but Allah. He said: Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasul Allah. He said: And I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Yahya said: And some of our companions informed me that when he said: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah, he said: La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah. Then Mu'awiyah said: I heard your Prophet saying thus. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad. It has another path but abbreviated; narrated by Ahmad and Al-Nasa'i from Majma' bin Yahya Al-Ansari, he said: I was beside Abu Umamah bin Sahl while he was facing the Mu'adhin. The Mu'adhin said Takbir twice, so Abu Umamah said Takbir twice. He testified that there is no god but Allah twice, so Abu Umamah testified twice. The Mu'adhin testified that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah twice, so Abu Umamah testified twice. Then he turned to me and said: Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan told me from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. This is a Sahih chain. Then Ahmad extracted it from the path of Hammad bin Salamah from Asim bin Bahdalah from Abu Salih from Mu'awiyah with it similarly. This is a good (Jayyid) chain. Ibn Al-Sunni narrated it with a strange addition (32) from the path of Abu Dawood Sulayman bin Yusuf: Abdullah bin Wafid told us from Nusair bin Tarif from Asim bin Bahdalah with it with the wording he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he heard the Mu'adhin say: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah, said: (O Allah make us successful/Muflihin).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This is a weak chain. This Sulayman bin Yusuf, I do not know him now. And his Sheikh Abdullah bin Wafid - so in the original with Fa (F) - perhaps it is Waqid with Qaf (Q). Among the narrators with this name and lineage are four; perhaps this is Al-Harrani Abu Qatadah, and he is Matruk (abandoned) as in (Al-Taqrib). And Nusair bin Tarif, I did not find him. In the men of (Al-Mizan) is Nasr bin Mutarrif Kufi, in him is anonymity. Then he said: Rather he is Al-Nadr with the dotted Dad (D), then he mentioned him here and among those whose name is Al-Nadr, and reported his weakening from a group of Hafizs. The Third Hadith: From Abu Rafi', may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he heard the Mu'adhin, would say like what he says. And if he said: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah Hayya 'ala Al-Falah, he said: (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah). Narrated by Ibn Al-Sunni, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad from the path of Sharik from Asim bin Ubayd from Ali bin Al-Husayn from him. This is a weak chain. Know that scholars differed here in two places: The First: In the ruling of answering the Mu'adhin. A group of the Salaf and others went to its obligation upon the hearer, acting upon the apparent meaning of the command which necessitates obligation. The Hanafis, the Literalists (Ahl al-Zahir), and Ibn Rajab said this as in (Al-Fath). Others disagreed with them and said: That is upon recommendation, not obligation. Al-Tahawi reported all that in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani). In (Sharh Muslim): (The correct view which the majority is upon is that it is...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...recommended). This was said by the Shafi'is and some of our Hanafi scholars. Al-Hafiz said: (It was argued for the majority with a Hadith extracted by Muslim and others that he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, heard a Mu'adhin; when he said Takbir, he said: (Upon the Fitrah). When he testified, he said: (Exited from the Fire). He said: Since he, peace and blessings be upon him, said other than what the Mu'adhin said, we knew that the command for that is for recommendation. It was critiqued that the Hadith does not state that he did not say like what he said; it is possible he said it and the narrator did not convey it, sufficing with the habit, and conveyed the extra saying. It is possible that this occurred before the issuance of the command. And it is possible that the man, when commanded, did not intend for himself to be within the generality of those addressed by that). I say: Perhaps among the arguments of the majority is what is in (Al-Muwatta) that the Companions, when the Mu'adhin started the Adhan on Friday, would start talking. It is very unlikely that answering is obligatory yet the Companions would turn away from it to talking. So refer to (Al-Muwatta). Similar to it is what Ibn Sa'd narrated from Musa bin Talha bin Ubaidullah, he said: I saw Uthman bin Affan while the Mu'adhin was calling Adhan, and he was talking to people, asking them and inquiring about prices and news. Its chain is Sahih on the condition of the two Sheikhs.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Second Place: They differed on how the answer should be, upon four schools: (1) To say like the saying of the Mu'adhin even in the Haya'alah (Hayya 'ala...). It is the school of some Salaf as in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani) (86), acting upon his saying, peace be upon him: (So say like what he says). (2) To say like his saying except in the Haya'alah, so he says in their place: (La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah). This is the school of the majority Shafi'is and others, acting upon the detailed Hadith of Umar and Mu'awiyah. (3) To combine the Haya'alah and Hawqala. It is the school of some late Hanafis like Ibn Al-Humam and others, and it is a view among the Hanbalis. Al-Hafiz said: (Some later scholars reported from some people of Usul that if the Specific and General can be combined, it is obligatory to apply both). He said: (So why not say: It is recommended for the listener to combine the two Haya'alahs and the Hawqala, and it is a view among the Hanbalis). (4) To do Hawqala sometimes and Haya'alah sometimes. Ibn Hazm and some investigators from the late Hanafis said this. It is the truth, if Allah the Exalted wills, because it involves applying both the general and specific Hadiths, each within the limits of its meaning. As for combining them - as in the third school - it involves fabricating a meaning not stated by either the Specific or the General, as is obvious. Likewise, Ibn Al-Mundhir said: (It is possible that this is from the permissible variation, so he says this sometimes and that sometimes). This variation has many examples in the Sharia, like the opening supplications and others, as...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...clarification of that will come there. Similar to it preceded in the types of Adhan. Sheikh Muhammad Anwar Al-Kashmiri said in (Fayd Al-Bari): (The Sunnah to me is that he answers sometimes with Haya'alah and sometimes with Hawqala. What is imagined that Haya'alah in answer to Haya'alah resembles mockery is nothing, because in the sum of words it is likewise if he intended mockery by it - and refuge is sought in Allah - otherwise they are words of goodness intended for sharing in the deed to attain the reward by it, for it is like a remedy for what he missed of the Adhan, so he must act according to his action to share in his reward). He said in the footnote after mentioning Ibn Al-Humam's speech on (Combining): (In summary, for about fifteen years I stood upon what Ibn Al-Humam, may Allah have mercy on him, verified, so I would combine them in answering the Adhan. Then it became verified to me that the intent of the Sharia is choice, not combining, and it is the Sunnah in the chapter of Adhkar. Combining is nothing but the opinion of Ibn Al-Humam and the Grand Sheikh). (And he answers sometimes when he hears the Mu'adhin [testify] by saying: (And I testify that there is no god but Allah alone with no partner, and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger; I am pleased with Allah as Lord, with Muhammad as Messenger, and with Islam as religion), for whoever says that, his sin is forgiven). It is from the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who said: (Whoever says when he hears the Mu'adhin) so he mentioned it and said at its end: (his sin is forgiven). Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and from him Ibn Al-Sunni...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Al-Hakim and Ahmad, all from the path of Qutaibah bin Sa'id: Al-Layth told us from Al-Hakim bin Abdullah bin Qais from Amir bin Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). Al-Hakim said: (Sahih), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is as they said, but they erred in listing it as an addition to Muslim [Istidrak], for he extracted it with the same chain. Then Muslim, Ibn Majah also, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad extracted it from other paths from Al-Layth with it. Then Al-Tahawi extracted it from the path of Ubaydullah bin Al-Mughirah from Al-Hakim bin Abdullah bin Qais... so he mentioned it like it with his chain and added that he said: (Whoever says when he hears the Mu'adhin testify (yatashahhad)). Its chain is thus: Ruh bin Al-Faraj told us, he said: Sa'id bin Kathir bin Ufair told us, he said: Yahya bin Ayyub told me from Ubaydullah bin Al-Mughirah. This is a Sahih chain, all its men are trustworthy, biographies in (Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib). It contains this addition which specifies when this supplication is said, which is when the Mu'adhin testifies. It is a rare addition seldom found in a book, so cling to it. Al-Sindi said in his footnote on Ibn Majah: His saying: (Whoever says when he hears the Adhan), the apparent meaning is when he finishes hearing his Adhan, otherwise combining it with saying like what...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the Mu'adhin says during the state of Adhan is problematic). I say: That addition specified when he says that, and that it is before finishing the Adhan. The apparent meaning of the Hadith is that this suffices him from following the Mu'adhin in what he says, especially according to the view of those who say: Following is not obligatory, which is the view of the majority. In that case, there is no necessity to combine, and thus no problem. And Allah knows best the reality of the situation. What supports this apparent meaning and strengthens it is the apparent meaning of the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud raised [to the Prophet]: (There is no Muslim who says when he hears the call, so the caller says Takbir and he says Takbir, then he testifies that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, so he testifies to that, then he says: O Allah give Muhammad Al-Wasilah...) The Hadith. Its chain is Sahih as will come if Allah the Exalted wills. (And it is permissible for him to restrict himself sometimes to his saying: (And I, And I) instead of the saying of the Mu'adhin: Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah, Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasul Allah). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to do likewise. It is from the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he heard the Mu'adhin testify, said: (And I, And I). Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim from the path of Hisham bin Urwah from his father from her. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Isnad) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. I say: It is on the condition of Muslim, for he extracted it from the path of Sahl bin Uthman...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Al-Askari: Hafs bin Ghiyath told us from Hisham with it. This Sahl is from the Sheikhs of Muslim, and the rest of his men are men of the Six. As for Abu Dawood, he extracted it from Ibrahim bin Mahdi: Ali bin Mushir told us from Hisham. This Ibrahim was authenticated by Abu Hatim, and the rest of his men are men of the two Sheikhs. Ibn Hibban narrated it in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib) and titled it: (Chapter on the permissibility of restricting oneself upon hearing the Adhan to: And I, And I). Mentioned in (Fayd Al-Qadir) and he said: (Meaning he says at the testimony that there is no god but Allah: And I. And at Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasul Allah: And I). The Hadith has a witness from the narration of Abdullah bin Salam in (Al-Majma'). (Second: When he finishes answering, he sends blessings (Salah) upon the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, for whoever sends blessings upon him once, Allah sends blessings upon him ten times). It contains the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas: That he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saying: (If you hear the Mu'adhin, say like what he says, then send blessings upon me, for whoever sends blessings upon me once, Allah sends blessings upon him ten times. Then ask Allah for Al-Wasilah for me, for it is a station in Paradise that is not fitting except for a servant from the servants of Allah, and I hope that I am he. So whoever asks for Al-Wasilah for me, intercession becomes lawful for him). Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and from him Ibn Al-Sunni...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad from paths from Ka'b bin Alqamah who heard Abdul Rahman bin Jubair hearing Abdullah bin Amr. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). (And the forms of Salah on the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, established from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, are many; I collected them in the Book of Prayer in three forms. We mention here the briefest and most comprehensive, which is: (O Allah send blessings upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, and bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, as You sent blessings and blessed Ibrahim and the family of Ibrahim, indeed You are Praiseworthy, Glorious). Narrated by Al-Tahawi and others as will come, and its chain is Sahih. How excellent was the action of Al-Hafiz Ibn Al-Sunni, may Allah have mercy on him, when he dedicated a special chapter after the chapter of Salah on the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, at the Adhan, which he cited from the Hadith of Ibn Amr, so he said: (Chapter: How is Salah on the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him?). Then he cited his chain to Ka'b bin Ujrah, he said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, may Allah send blessings upon you, this Salam upon you we have known, so how is Salah upon you? He said: (Say: O Allah send blessings upon Muhammad...) The Hadith. Narrated by the Six and others, and it will come in [the chapter of] Prayer. Ibn Al-Sunni indicated by that that one should send blessings on the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, after Adhan with what is reported from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, of what he taught his Ummah. Although absolute Salah on him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, suffices in that, the discussion is regarding the best [form] which most people have neglected in this station.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Third: To ask for him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, after the Salah on him, Al-Wasilah, for it is a station in Paradise not fitting except for a servant from the servants of Allah. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (And I hope that I am he, so whoever asks for Al-Wasilah for me, intercession becomes lawful for him). Regarding it is the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr in Muslim and others, and it passed previously. In the chapter are other Hadiths: (1) From Abu Huraira, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Ask Allah for Al-Wasilah for me). They said: O Messenger of Allah, what is Al-Wasilah? He said: (The highest degree in Paradise, attained only by one man, and I hope that I am he). Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi from Sufyan from Al-Layth - who is Ibn Abi Sulaym -: Ka'b told me: Abu Huraira told me. And he said: (This is a Gharib Hadith, its chain is not strong, and Ka'b is not known, and we do not know anyone who narrated from him other than Layth bin Abi Sulaym). From this aspect Ahmad narrated it as in Ibn Kathir and (Hadi Al-Arwah) with the wording: (If you send blessings upon me, ask Allah for Al-Wasilah for me...) And the rest is like it. (2) From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri raised [to the Prophet]: (Al-Wasilah is a degree with Allah, there is no degree above it, so ask Allah to grant me Al-Wasilah). Narrated by Ahmad from the path of Ibn Lahi'ah from Musa bin Wardan from him. Likewise, Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Awsat) and added at its end: (Over His creation). As in (Al-Majma').

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This is a chain that is acceptable in witnesses and corroborations. Ibn Mardawayh narrated it with two chains from Umarah bin Ghaziyyah from Musa bin Wardan with it, and it contains the addition. Umarah bin Ghaziyyah is acceptable (La Ba'sa bihi) as in (Al-Taqrib). This is a strong corroboration for Ibn Lahi'ah indicating that he preserved the Hadith, so it is a good (Jayyid) chain. (3) From Ibn Abbas raised [to the Prophet]: (Ask Allah for Al-Wasilah for me, for no servant asks it for me in the world except that I will be a witness or intercessor for him on the Day of Resurrection). Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat), and its chain is thus: Ahmad bin Ali Al-Abbar informed us: Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik Al-Harrani told us: Musa bin A'yun told us from Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Muhammad bin Amr bin Ata from him. This is a good (Jayyid) chain if Allah the Exalted wills. Ahmad bin Ali Al-Abbar was authenticated by Al-Daraqutni, and Al-Khatib said: (He was a trustworthy Hafiz, precise, of good Madhhab, died in the year (290), and has a biography in his (Tarikh)). The rest of the men of his chain are men of the two Sheikhs except Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik Al-Harrani. Al-Haythami said: (Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat) and said: Straight in Hadith when he narrates from trustworthy narrators. I say: And this is from his narration from Musa bin A'yun, and he is trustworthy).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: This Al-Walid, Al-Tabarani narrated another Hadith for him in (Al-Mu'jam Al-Saghir) and named his grandfather Masrah - like Muhammad - narrating also from Makhlad bin Yazid, and from him his nephew Ahmad bin Khalid bin Masrah Al-Harrani. Then regarding the Hadith, Al-Tabarani said after citing it: (No one narrated it from Ibn Abi Dhi'b except Musa bin A'yun). Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir critiqued him saying: (Thus he said, and Ibn Mardawayh narrated it: Muhammad bin Ali bin Duhaym told us: Ahmad bin Hazim told us: Ubaydullah bin Musa told us: Musa bin Ubaidah told us from Muhammad bin Amr bin Ata, so he mentioned with his chain similar to it). (Benefit): (Since the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was the greatest of creation in servitude to his Lord, the most knowledgeable of them of Him, the most intense of them in fear of Him, and the greatest of them in love for Him, his station was the closest station to Allah, which is the highest degree in Paradise. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered his Ummah to ask it for him so that they may attain by this supplication nearness to Allah and increase in faith. Also, Allah the Glorious decreed it for him through causes, among them is the supplication of his Ummah for him for it, due to what they attained at his hand of faith and guidance, blessings of Allah and His peace be upon him). Thus in (Hadi Al-Arwah) by Ibn Al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him. (And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, taught us the supplication of Al-Wasilah, so one should not deviate from it, nor increase in it or decrease. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Whoever says when he hears the call: 'O Allah, Lord of this perfect call and established prayer, grant Muhammad Al-Wasilah and Al-Fadilah, and resurrect him...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...to a praised station which You promised him') my intercession becomes lawful for him on the Day of Resurrection). It is from the Hadith of Jabir bin Abdullah Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Bukhari extracted it, and in (Al-Tafsir) (1) and Ahmad, they said: Ali bin Ayyash told us: Shu'aib bin Abi Hamza told us from Muhammad bin Al-Munkadir from him. Abu Dawood extracted it from Ahmad, and Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, and from him Ibn Al-Sunni, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir), all from paths from Ali bin Ayyash with it. The addition is with Al-Bayhaqi, and it is among what was established for Al-Kushmihani in (Sahih Al-Bukhari) as Al-Sakhawi said. My opinion is that it is anomalous (Shadh). Al-Tahawi narrated it making it from his action, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he heard the Mu'adhin, used to say: (O Allah... etc). Its chain is thus: Abdul Rahman bin Amr Al-Dimashqi told us, he said: Ali bin Ayyash told us with it. This, as you see, is the chain of Al-Bukhari except Abdul Rahman bin Amr Al-Dimashqi, who is Abu Zur'ah the trustworthy Hafiz, so the chain is Sahih but the narration is anomalous. In this narration came: (Al-Maqam Al-Mahmud) with the definite article, and it is the narration of Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tabarani, and Al-Bayhaqi. It is in (Sahih Ibn Khuzaymah) and Ibn Hibban also as in (Al-Fath). He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (And in it is a critique of those who denied that, like Al-Nawawi). However, the correct view is the indefinite form (Maqaman Mahmudan) due to its establishment in (Sahih Al-Bukhari) and for its agreement with the wording of the Quran: {It is expected that your Lord will resurrect you to a praised station} [Al-Isra / 79] and for other reasons mentioned by the investigator Ibn Al-Qayyim in (Bada'i Al-Fawa'id), and he was brilliant, so let whoever wishes refer to it. (Alert): The addition of (Al-Darajah Al-Rafi'ah - The High Degree) has become famous on tongues in this supplication. It is an addition that has no basis in any of the useful sources. Al-Hafiz Al-Sakhawi said in (Al-Maqasid Al-Hasanah): (I did not see it in any of the narrations). His Sheikh Al-Hafiz Al-Asqalani said in (Al-Talkhis): (And there is no mention in any of its paths of: Al-Darajah Al-Rafi'ah). Yes, this addition was mentioned in the narration of Ibn Al-Sunni, but I am certain that it is interpolated (mudrajah) by some scribes, because if it were established in the correct copies of Ibn Al-Sunni, it would not have been hidden from the likes of these two Hafizs: Al-Asqalani and Al-Sakhawi. This is supported by the fact that Ibn Al-Sunni narrated it from the path of Al-Nasa'i as preceded, and this addition is not in his (Sunan), so it is proven that it is interpolated. Just as its mention occurred in the books of some investigating Hafizs; it occurred in the book (Al-Tawassul wa Al-Wasilah) by Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah and in the book (Hadi Al-Arwah) by Ibn Al-Qayyim. The first attributed it to Al-Bukhari and the other to the (Two Sahihs), and this is a double illusion. The Hadith was not narrated by Muslim at all...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...as explicitly stated in (Al-Muntaqa), and likewise Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath). (And he also said: (There is no Muslim who says when he hears the call, so the caller says Takbir and he says Takbir, then he testifies that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, so he testifies to that, then he says: O Allah give Muhammad Al-Wasilah [and Al-Fadilah] and place his degree among the highest, and his love among the chosen, and his mention among the drawn near, except that [my] intercession becomes obligatory for him on the Day of Resurrection). It is a Sahih Hadith narrated by Qais bin Muslim from Tariq bin Shihab from Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet] with it. Narrated by Al-Tahawi: Muhammad bin Al-Nu'man Al-Saqati told us: Yahya bin Yahya Al-Nisaburi told us, he said: Abu Umar Al-Bazzaz told us from Qais bin Muslim with it. Except that he said 'darahu' (his abode) instead of: 'dhikrahu' (his mention). Perhaps it is corrupted by some scribes. This is a good (Jayyid) chain. Muhammad bin Al-Nu'man is Ibn Bashir Al-Maqdisi. He said in (Al-Taqrib): (Trustworthy, from the Sheikhs of Abu Awanah and Al-Tahawi). The rest of the men of the chain are trustworthy men of the Six except Abu Umar Al-Bazzar; he is Dinar bin Umar Al-Asadi Al-Kufi, and he is Salih Al-Hadith (good in Hadith) as in (Al-Taqrib). It is possible that he is Hafs bin Sulayman Al-Asadi Al-Kufi, for he is also nicknamed Abu Umar...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Al-Bazzar, and he is Matruk Al-Hadith (abandoned in Hadith) despite his leadership in Recitation (Qira'ah). If it is this one, then the chain is weak. Whichever one he is, he was not alone in it. Abu Kuraib narrated it: Uthman bin Sa'id told us: Umar Abu Hafs told us from Qais bin Muslim with it.
