Narrated by Ibn Al-Sunni and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir). The first said: Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Hadrami told us. And the first said: Muhammad bin Jarir informed us. Then they agreed: Abu Kuraib told us with it. The first addition is with Al-Tabarani and the other with Ibn Al-Sunni. It is with Al-Tahawi also with the wording: (Except that the intercession of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, becomes obligatory for him). And with Ibn Al-Sunni also: (And place in the highest ('Illiyyin)) instead of: (And place in the highest (Al-A'layn)). And in Al-Tahawi: (And place in the highest (Al-A'layn)). This is a good (Jayyid) chain also. This Abu Hafs is Umar bin Abdul Rahman bin Qais Al-Abbar Al-Kufi, lived in Baghdad, truthful and used to memorize as in (Al-Taqrib). The rest of the men of the chain are trustworthy men of the Six except Uthman bin Sa'id, who is Al-Kufi Al-Zayyat the doctor. Abu Hatim said, and Al-Hafiz followed him in (Al-Taqrib): (There is no harm in him). The Hadith was cited by Al-Haythami in (Al-Majma') by the narration of Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (And its men are authenticated). And Al-Hafiz cited part of it in (Al-Fath) from the narration of Al-Tahawi and remained silent on it. In summary, the Hadith is fit for practice (So he says this sometimes and that sometimes). (Alert): As for the Hadith of Umm Salamah, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, taught me to say at the Maghrib Adhan: (O Allah, this is the approach of Your night, the retreat of Your day, and the voices of Your callers, so forgive me), its chain is not established. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, and Ibn Al-Sunni from Abdullah bin Al-Walid Al-Adani: Al-Qasim bin Ma'n Al-Mas'udi told us from Abu Kathir, the freed slave of Umm Salamah, from her. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih), Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and Al-Hafiz affirmed it in (Al-Talkhis). It is not good, for this Abu Kathir is unknown (Majhul), not recognized as will come from Al-Tirmidhi. He extracted it from the path of Hafsah bint Abi Kathir from her father Abu Kathir with it similarly and said: (This is a Gharib Hadith, we only know it from this aspect, and Hafsah bint Abi Kathir, we do not know her nor her father). Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu'): (Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Tirmidhi, and in its chain is an unknown narrator).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Fourth: To ask after that whatever he wills of the affairs of the world and the Hereafter, for he will be given it. A man said: O Messenger of Allah, indeed the Mu'adhins excel us. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Say as they say, so when you finish, ask and you will be given). It is from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ahmad from the path of Hayy bin Abdullah from Abu Abdul Rahman Al-Hubuli from him. This is a Hasan chain. Al-Mundhiri declared this chain Hasan in (Al-Targhib) repeatedly, and likewise Al-Haythami. Al-Hakim authenticated it in more than one Hadith, and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. He indicated in the biography of Hayy bin Abdullah in (Al-Mizan) that he is correct in Hadith (Sahih Al-Hadith). The truth is that he is good in Hadith (Hasan Al-Hadith), for some have spoken about him as he mentioned in (Al-Mizan) and others in other places. Regarding the Hadith, he said in (Al-Targhib): (Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Hibban in his Sahih). Likewise, Al-Hafiz attributed it to Al-Nasa'i in (Al-Talkhis). It is not in his (Sunan Al-Sughra), and Al-Nabulsi did not attribute it to him in (Al-Dhakhai'r). So apparently it is in his (Sunan Al-Kubra) or in (Amal Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah) by him, which is more likely. And Allah knows best. The Hadith has a witness from the narration of Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (If the caller calls, the doors of the sky are opened and supplication is answered. So whoever is befell by distress or...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...hardship, let him wait for the caller. When he says Takbir, he says Takbir; when he testifies, he testifies; when he says: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah, he says: Hayya 'ala Al-Salah; when he says: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah, he says: Hayya 'ala Al-Falah; then he says: O Allah, Lord of this true call, answered, for which response is made, the call of truth and the word of piety, keep us alive upon it and cause us to die upon it, resurrect us upon it, and make us among the best of its people, living and dead. Then he asks his need). Narrated by Al-Hakim and Ibn Al-Sunni from the path of Al-Walid bin Muslim from Ufair bin Ma'dan (And Ibn Al-Sunni said: From Abu 'Aidh) from Sulaym bin Amir from him. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Isnad). Al-Mundhiri critiqued him stating that this Ufair bin Ma'dan is flimsy (Wah), and [so did] Al-Dhahabi saying: (He is very flimsy). In (Al-Taqrib): (He is weak). (And he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to say: Two are not rejected - or rarely rejected -: Supplication at the call [Adhan], and at the battle when they clash with each other). It is from the Hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Darimi, and Al-Hakim from the path of Musa bin Ya'qub Al-Zam'i: Abu Hazim bin Dinar told me: Sahl bin Sa'd informed me with it. Al-Hakim said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Sahih Isnad), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Thus they said. And Musa bin Ya'qub Al-Zam'i is truthful with bad memory as in (Al-Taqrib), but he was not alone in it as will come, so the Hadith is strong. Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim added in a narration: Musa bin Ya'qub said: And Rizq bin Sa'id bin Abdul Rahman Al-Madani told me from Abu Hazim with it, he said: And the time of rain. This Rizq is unknown as in (Al-Taqrib). So do not be deceived by Al-Shawkani's saying in (Tuhfat Al-Dhakirin) after mentioning the Hadith with this addition at Abu Dawood's: (Al-Tabarani also extracted it in (Al-Kabir), Ibn Mardawayh, and Al-Hakim, and it is a Sahih Hadith). Yes, this addition came in other Hadiths, so see our commentary on (Al-Targhib). Then the Hadith was narrated by Ibn Hibban and Ibn Khuzaymah in their (Sahihs) as in (Al-Targhib) and (Al-Talkhis). Malik narrated it in (Al-Muwatta), and from him Al-Bukhari in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) from Abu Hazim with it stopped at Sahl [Mawquf] with the wording: (Two hours, the doors of the sky are opened for them, and rarely is a supplication rejected in them: Presence of the call to prayer, and the rank in the path of Allah). Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: (This Hadith is Mawquf in (Al-Muwatta) according to the group of narrators, and the like of it is not said from opinion. Ayyub bin Suwayd, Muhammad bin Makhlad...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and Ismail bin Amr narrated it from Malik raised [to the Prophet]. And it was narrated from multiple paths from Abu Hazim from Sahl bin Sa'd raised [to the Prophet]). (And at the time of answering from Adhan to Iqamah, so supplicate). It is from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are paths from him: 1 - From Isra'il from Abu Ishaq from Buraid bin Abi Maryam from him. Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Al-Sunni. Then Ahmad extracted it from the path of Ismail bin Umar, he said: Yunus told us: Buraid bin Abi Maryam told us with it. This is a Sahih chain, its men are men of the Sahih except Buraid (with Damma on Ba and Fatha on Ra) bin Abi Maryam, and he is trustworthy by agreement. (1) 2 - From Sufyan bin Uyaynah from Zaid Al-Ami from Abu Iyas Mu'awiyah bin Qurrah from him with it without his saying: (So supplicate). Narrated by Abu Dawood, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Tirmidhi and Ahmad from paths from him. Al-Tirmidhi said:
foot_note: 1. (1) And from this path Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban narrated it in their (Sahihs) and Al-Nasa'i as in (Al-Targhib) (115) and (Al-Talkhis) (3/206). Perhaps Al-Nasa'i narrated it in his (Sunan Al-Kubra) or in (Amal Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah) by him, for I did not find it in his (Sunan Al-Sughra).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). I say: It is Sahih from the first path. As for this one, it is weak due to the weakness of Zaid Al-Ami. Then Al-Tirmidhi extracted it from the path of Yahya bin Al-Nu'man: Sufyan told us with it. And he added: They said: So what should we say, O Messenger of Allah? He said: (Ask Allah for Afiyah (well-being/safety) in the world and the Hereafter). This addition is weak from two aspects: First: Because it is from this weak path. Second: Because Yahya bin Al-Yaman was alone in it from Sufyan contrary to all the trustworthy narrators who narrated it from Sufyan without this addition. Yahya bin Al-Yaman, although he is from the men of Muslim, is described with bad memory. In (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, worshipper, makes many mistakes, and had changed). 3 - From Ibrahim bin Al-Hasan Al-Allaf: Salam bin Abi Al-Sahba' told us from Thabit from Anas. Al-Khatib extracted it from two paths from Ibrahim with it. This Ibrahim, I did not know him. And his Sheikh Salam, Ahmad said: Good in Hadith, and others weakened him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: 4 - From Al-Fadl bin Al-Mukhtar from Humayd Al-Tawil from him with the wording: (Supplication is answered between the call...). Thus Al-Hakim extracted it as a witness for the Hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd previously mentioned, and he remained silent on it, and he is Al-Dhahabi. This Al-Fadl is Matruk (abandoned). (Alert): Al-Shawkani said: He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, specified what one should supplicate with when he said: (Supplication between Adhan and Iqamah is not rejected). They said: So what should we say, O Messenger of Allah? He said: (Ask Allah for pardon and well-being (Afiyah) in the world and the Hereafter). Ibn Al-Qayyim said: (It is a Sahih Hadith). I say: Yes, the origin of the Hadith is Sahih. As for this addition, it is weak. So it should not be said then that he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, specified what is to be supplicated with in this station. So take heed and do not be of the heedless. 7 - Iqamah: 1 - It is a communal obligation (Fard Kifayah) like Adhan if they are a group in residency and travel, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (If you two go out, call Adhan then call Iqamah, then let the oldest of you lead you). This Hadith was extracted by Al-Bukhari, and in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad), Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Tirmidhi.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and Ibn Majah and Ahmad via Abu Qilabah from Malik ibn Al-Huwayrith, and the wording is Al-Bukhari's. The wording of the others, except Al-Nasa'i and Al-Tirmidhi, is: (When the prayer becomes due, then call the Adhan...) etc. This is Al-Bukhari's wording. Abu Dawood added: And we were somewhat equal in knowledge that day. This is via Maslamah bin Muhammad from Khalid Al-Hadhdha from him, and this Maslamah is lenient in Hadith as in (Al-Taqrib). However, Abu Dawood and Ahmad narrated it via Isma'il bin Ulayyah from Khalid, who said: I said to Abu Qilabah: Then where is the Quran [memorization]? - and Ahmad said: The recitation - He said: They were close [in it]. Muslim narrated from Hafs from Khalid saying: They were close. And Muslim narrated from Hafs from Khalid saying: They were close in recitation. The wording of the others is: (If you two travel, then call the Adhan). Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). It has been presented at length in the third issue of Adhan. In it is evidence for the obligation of Iqamah like Adhan, a communal obligation (Fard Kifayah); if one performs it, it falls off the other. The meaning of the Hadith is not its apparent literal sense, which is that each of them should call Adhan and Iqamah, as Al-Hafiz clarified in (Al-Fath). Rather, the meaning is: Whoever of you likes to call Adhan, let him call Adhan, and whoever likes to call Iqamah, let him call Iqamah, due to their equality in merit. Age is not considered in Adhan, unlike Imamate [leading prayer]. This meaning is supported by his saying in a narration of the Hadith: (Let one of you call Adhan for you), as preceded in [the chapter of] Adhan.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Scholars have differed regarding the ruling of Iqamah. Ibn Rushd said in (Al-Bidayah): (According to the jurists of the major cities regarding individuals and congregations, it is a confirmed Sunnah, more so than the Adhan. According to the literalists (Ahl al-Zahir), it is obligatory (Fard). I do not know if it is Fard according to them absolutely or a Fard among the obligations of the prayer. The difference between the two is that on the first view, the prayer is not invalidated by leaving it, and on the second, it is invalidated. Ibn Kinanah from the companions of Malik said: Whoever leaves it intentionally, his prayer is invalid). He said: (The apparent meaning of the Hadith of Malik bin Al-Huwayrith necessitates it being Fard, either in congregation or upon the individual). I say: This is the truth, that it is Fard in the congregation, not upon the individual, because the Hadith did not refer to him. Furthermore, the literalists differ on whether it is absolutely Fard or a Fard among the obligations of prayer, as Al-Nawawi mentioned from Al-Mahamili. Then Al-Nawawi mentioned that Dawud said: (It is Fard for the congregational prayer but not a condition for its validity). I say: As for Ibn Hazm, he explicitly stated that it is a condition for the validity of the prayer like the Adhan. His predecessors in this were Ata and Al-Awza'i, for they said: If one forgets the Iqamah, he repeats the prayer. This is not apparent. The correct view - as Sheikh al-Islam said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat) - is that it is a communal obligation, which is the apparent view of Ahmad's school and others. Ibn Al-Mundhir said: It is Fard regarding the congregation in residence and travel.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ibn Hazm said: (Those who said that Adhan and Iqamah are obligatory Fard are Abu Sulaiman and his companions, and we do not know of any proof at all for those who do not see that as Fard). It is as he said, may Allah have mercy on him. Then he said: (Adhan and Iqamah are not binding on the individual; if he calls Adhan and Iqamah, it is good, because the text did not come mandating Adhan except upon two or more). (2 - As for the individual, it is recommended for him due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (If a man is in a desolate land and the time for prayer comes, let him perform ablution. If he does not find water, let him perform Tayammum. If he establishes prayer [Iqamah], his two angels pray with him...) The Hadith). This has passed in the ninth issue of Adhan. Al-Nasa'i dedicated a special chapter to this issue, saying: (Iqamah for the one who prays alone). Then he cited with his chain the Hadith of the one who prayed badly, saying: Ali bin Hajar informed us, he said: Isma'il informed us, he said: Yahya bin Ali bin Yahya bin Khallad bin Rifa'ah bin Rafi' Al-Zuraqi told us from his father from his grandfather from Rifa'ah bin Rafi': That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was sitting in the row of prayer... The Hadith. He said it like this and did not cite the Hadith in full; rather he referred to it. This is not good, for what is known among the Hadith scholars is that referring to the rest of the Hadith only happens after citing the portion of the Hadith containing the witness and the chapter heading, then referring to the rest.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I do not know what compelled Al-Nasa'i to this abbreviation which does not yield the intended benefit from this chapter. Al-Tirmidhi extracted the Hadith in his (Sunan) with this chain from this Sheikh, and its wording is: While he was sitting in the mosque one day - Rifa'ah said: And we were with him - a man like a Bedouin came and prayed, lightening his prayer, then left and greeted the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (And upon you. Go back and pray, for you have not prayed...) The Hadith. In it: The man said at the end of that: Show me and teach me, for I am but a human, I get things right and I make mistakes. He said: (Yes, when you stand for prayer, perform ablution as Allah ordered you, then testify [Shahadah] and establish the prayer [Iqamah], and if you have Quran, recite...) The Hadith. Abu Dawood extracted it from Abbad bin Musa Al-Khattali: Isma'il bin Ja'far told us with it. He added after saying: (and establish the prayer): (then say Takbir). Al-Tahawi and Al-Hakim narrated it from other paths from Isma'il with it, except they did not cite its wording. If you examine the context of the Hadith and its wording or part of it, you know that Al-Nasa'i indicated by citing the Hadith briefly that it contains mention of his command, peace and blessings be upon him, to the individual to perform Iqamah. However, establishing that in the Hadith is questionable. If it were established, Iqamah would be obligatory for the individual due to his command, peace and blessings be upon him, to him. But it is not established because Yahya bin Ali bin Yahya was alone in narrating it,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and he is not authenticated; rather, he is unknown (Majhul). Al-Dhahabi mentioned in (Al-Mizan) and cited this Hadith for him, then said: (Ibn Al-Qattan said: He is not known except by this report narrated from him by Isma'il bin Ja'far, and I do not know of any weakness in him. I [Dhahabi] say: But there is ignorance [of his condition] in him). This is Al-Dhahabi's statement. So the man is unknown, not recognized, so the Hadith of the likes of him is not established. Al-Tirmidhi's statement after citing it: (Hasan Hadith) only refers to the core of the Hadith, not all the wordings mentioned in it. What indicates this to you is that a group of trustworthy narrators narrated the Hadith from Ali bin Yahya, the father of Yahya bin Ali bin Yahya, and none of them mentioned Iqamah in the Hadith. They are Dawud bin Qays, Muhammad bin Ajlan, Muhammad bin Amr, Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talhah, and Muhammad bin Ishaq; all five of them from Ali bin Yahya did not mention Iqamah as we mentioned. The extraction of their paths will come in the Book of Prayer: Facing the Qiblah. Then I found the Hadith of this Yahya bin Ali bin Yahya in (Musnad Al-Tayalisi): Isma'il bin Ja'far Al-Madani told us, he said: Yahya bin Ali bin Khallad told me with it, except that he did not mention Iqamah. So his narration agreed with the narration of the trustworthy narrators. All of that indicates the lack of establishment of this addition in the Hadith. Let no one be deceived by its occurrence in the Hadith alongside Al-Tirmidhi declaring it Hasan, nor by the silence of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar regarding it in (Fath Al-Bari). This is a verification you will not see - in my opinion - in any book. Allah Almighty is the Inspirer of correctness.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 3 - Two types have come regarding its description: The First: Seventeen words: Allahu Akbar 1 Allahu Akbar 2 Allahu Akbar 3 Allahu Akbar 4, Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah 5, Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah 6, Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah 7, Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah 8, Hayya 'ala as-salah 9, Hayya 'ala as-salah 10, Hayya 'ala al-falah 11, Hayya 'ala al-falah 12, Qad qamat is-salah 13, Qad qamat is-salah 14, Allahu Akbar 15 Allahu Akbar 16, La ilaha illa Allah 17). There are Hadiths regarding it: First: From Abu Mahdhurah: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, taught him the Adhan as nineteen words and the Iqamah as seventeen words. In it is the narration of Ibn Khuzaimah in his (Sahih): So he taught him the Adhan and Iqamah two by two. It is an authentic Hadith, and its extraction has preceded in the fourth issue of Adhan. Al-Daraqutni added at its end: (He does not return from that place). I say: Meaning he does not repeat (Tarji') in the Iqamah. The Second Hadith: From Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla, he said: The Companions of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, told us that Abdullah bin Zaid Al-Ansari came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah, I saw in a dream as if a man stood wearing two green garments, so he stood on a wall and called Adhan two by two and called Iqamah two by two.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Its chain is extremely authentic as preceded in Issue (13). It is via Al-A'mash from Amr bin Murrah from him. Abu Dawood narrated it via Shu'bah from Amr with it similarly. It has preceded there. Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Daraqutni extracted it via Ibn Abi Layla from Amr bin Murrah from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla from Abdullah bin Zaid who said: (The Adhan of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was even, even [two by two] in Adhan and Iqamah). Al-Tirmidhi faulted it saying: (And Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla did not hear from Abdullah bin Zaid). I say: But the first narration clarifies that he heard it from some Companions, so his transmitting the Hadith in Mursal form sometimes does not harm. Additional verification of the Hadith preceded in the issue referred to just now. Then Al-Tirmidhi said: (Some people of knowledge said: The Adhan is two by two and the Iqamah is two by two. Sufyan Al-Thawri, Ibn Al-Mubarak, and the people of Kufa say this). I say: Ibn Hazm expressed a strange view, going to the opinion that doubling the Iqamah is abrogated by the Hadith of Anas coming later: 'Bilal was ordered to make the Adhan even and the Iqamah odd.' There is no need for the claim of abrogation as long as it is possible to reconcile the doubling and the singling by interpreting this for some times and that for others. The Hanafis and Shafi'is also expressed strange views; the former argued for doubling the Iqamah

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: using the Hadith of Abu Mahdhurah, even though it contains repetition (Tarji') in the Adhan and they do not accept it. The Shafi'is did the opposite; they took what is in it regarding repetition and left what is in it regarding doubling the Iqamah. Therefore, Al-Nawawi said: (We and the companions of Abu Hanifa have agreed that this Hadith of Abu Mahdhurah is not acted upon according to its literal meaning, because it contains repetition and doubling of Iqamah. They do not accept repetition, and we do not accept doubling of Iqamah. So we and they must interpret it. Adopting the singling [of Iqamah] was better because it agrees with the rest of the narrations and authentic Hadiths like the Hadith of Anas and others). I say: Al-Nawawi did not mention their interpretation of the Hadith, and it is not open to interpretation because it explicitly states that the words of Iqamah are seventeen words, while according to them they are eleven words as will come. Yes, Al-Nawawi and others mentioned from Al-Bayhaqi that he faulted the Hadith because Muslim narrated it in his (Sahih) as preceded without mentioning Iqamah, and due to other reasons he mentioned in (Nasb Al-Rayah) that do not scratch the authenticity of the Hadith at all. Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid refuted him sufficiently and held that the Hadith is authentic, so refer to Al-Zayla'i. The truth is that both the Hanafi and Shafi'i groups were fanatical about their schools and rejected the truth that their opponents took. Justice is taking what both of them took of the truth from what is established in the Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: So this truth has no obscurity, so leave aside the side roads. Then Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Ibn Khuzaimah who said: (Repetition in Adhan with doubling of Iqamah is of the type of permissible variation. It is permissible to repeat in Adhan and double the Iqamah, and it is permissible to double the Adhan and single the Iqamah, because both matters are authentic from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. As for doubling Adhan without repetition and doubling Iqamah, it is not established from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him). I say: There is something questionable in what Ibn Khuzaimah said, because the second Hadith - which is the Hadith of Abdullah ibn Zaid Al-Ansari regarding the dream - contains doubling of Iqamah and does not contain repetition by agreement. Therefore, Ibn Hazm went to the view that doubling is abrogated because it preceded singling as mentioned before. So how can it be said: That doubling Adhan without repetition along with doubling Iqamah is not established from him, peace and blessings be upon him? Especially since Ibn Khuzaimah is among those who narrated that as preceded in Adhan. Yes, it is problematic for this that the Hadith of the dream was narrated by Ibn Ishaq from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid directly, and it does not contain the doubling of the entire Iqamah, rather its words are eleven words as preceded in the second issue of Adhan and will come after this. So one must then resort to preferring one of the two narrations over the first in terms of chain because the Hadith is one. The preferable one to me is the narration of Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla due to it coming from authentic paths from him. As for the narration of Ibn Ishaq, it is a solitary narration not followed up on in this specific detail,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: even if the core of the Hadith is authentic and established and followed up on as preceded there. The discussion is only regarding what he contradicted therein one who is more retentive than him. Al-Hafiz Al-Dhahabi said at the end of the biography of Ibn Ishaq in (Al-Mizan): (So what appears to me is that Ibn Ishaq is good (Hasan) in Hadith, of righteous state, truthful. Whatever he is alone in narrating has weirdness (Nakara), for there is something in his memory. Imams have used him as proof, so Allah knows best. Muslim cited five Hadiths of Ibn Ishaq as witnesses which he mentioned in his Sahih). This is what appeared in this context, and I have not seen anyone precede me to it. And Allah knows best. (The Second Type: Eleven words: Allahu Akbar 1 Allahu Akbar 2, Ashhadu an la ilaha illa Allah 3, Ashhadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah 4, Hayya 'ala as-salah 5, Hayya 'ala al-falah 6, Qad qamat is-salah 7 Qad qamat is-salah 8, Allahu Akbar 9 Allahu Akbar 10, La ilaha illa Allah 11). There are Hadiths regarding it: First: From Abdullah bin Zaid bin Abd Rabbih in the Hadith of the dream, he said: Then he moved back - meaning the angel - not far, then said: You say when the prayer is established: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar... etc. Narrated by Ibn Ishaq who said: Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Al-Harith Al-Taymi told me from Muhammad ibn Abdullah bin Zaid from his father with it. It contains what was mentioned previously. However, it is witnessed by the Second Hadith: From Ibn Umar who said: The Adhan during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was two by two, and the Iqamah was once, once: except that you say: Qad qamat is-salah Qad qamat is-salah.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It is a Hasan Hadith narrated by the authors of the Sunan and others as preceded in the second type of Adhan. This is the wording of Al-Nasa'i. Third Hadith: From Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are paths from him: 1 - From Abu Qilabah from him, he said (1): Bilal was ordered to make the Adhan even and the Iqamah odd. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, Al-Daraqutni, Al-Hakim, Al-Tayalisi, Ahmad, and Al-Khatib, some from Khalid Al-Hadhdha and some from Ayyub, both from Abu Qilabah with it. The wording of Al-Nasa'i and Al-Hakim via Ayyub is: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered Bilal. This is a narration of Al-Daraqutni from Al-Nasa'i. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on their condition, and they did not extract it with this context). Ayyub also added at its end: Except the Iqamah [phrase]. It is in the (Two Sahihs) and others.
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered him. Ibn Hazm said, may Allah have mercy on him (3/152): (We have mentioned what no two people of transmission disagree upon, that Bilal, may Allah be pleased with him, never called Adhan for anyone after the death of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, except once in Sham, and he did not complete his Adhan therein. So this report becomes connected (Musnad) with an authentic chain, and it is correct that the Commander of him was the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, no one else). I say: This is supported by the narration of Ayyub which is explicit that the Commander is the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Some claimed that this addition is an interpolation (Idraj) from some narrators, not from the original Hadith. This was refuted by the fact that Abd al-Razzaq narrated it: Ma'mar from Ayyub from Abu Qilabah from Anas, he said: Bilal used to double the Adhan and make the Iqamah odd except his saying: Qad qamat is-salah. Narrated by Al-Daraqutni and Ibn Hazm via paths from Abd al-Razzaq. Al-Hafiz said: (And Abu Awanah extracted it in his (Sahih) and Al-Sarraj in his (Musnad), and likewise it is in the (Musannaf of Abd al-Razzaq) and Al-Isma'ili from this path, saying: Qad qamat is-salah twice. The principle is that what is in the report is part of it until proof is established to the contrary, and there is no proof). Second Path: From Qatadah from Anas with the first wording. Extracted by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir), he said: Musa bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Kathir Al-Surayni told us: Abd al-Malik bin Ibrahim Al-Juddi told us: Shu'bah told us from him. I did not know Al-Tabarani's Sheikh. The rest of his narrators are narrators of the Six except this Abd al-Malik; he is from the narrators of Al-Bukhari and others, and he was alone in narrating it as Al-Tabarani said. Ibn Hazm chose this Iqamah, and Umar bin Al-Khattab, his son, Anas, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, Makhul, Al-Zuhri, Al-Awza'i, Ahmad, Ishaq, Abu Thawr, Yahya bin Yahya, Dawud, Ibn Al-Mundhir, and others held it. Al-Baghawi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (It is the saying of the majority of scholars) as in (Al-Majmu'). They argued for it with these three Hadiths. As for the Hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid, you have known what is in it. As for the Hadith of Ibn Umar and Anas, their apparent meaning indicates that the Iqamah is nine words, not eleven words. They answered about them that they are interpreted based on predominance (Taghlib). Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (If it is said: You have said that the chosen view held by the majority is that the Iqamah is eleven words, including Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar at the beginning and end, and this is doubling. The answer is that this, even if it is a form of doubling, relative to the Adhan it is singling. Therefore our companions said: It is recommended for the Mu'adhin to say every two Takbirs in one breath, so he says at the beginning of Adhan: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar in one breath, then says: Allahu Akbar Allahu Akbar in one breath). Al-Hafiz said: (This is only possible in the beginning of Adhan, not in the Takbir at its end. According to what Al-Nawawi said, the Mu'adhin should single out each Takbir of the two at its end with a breath). This, and Malik went, as in (Al-Mudawwanah), to the view that the Iqamah is ten words, so he did not double the phrase: (Qad qamat is-salah). This is an old view of Al-Shafi'i as Al-Nawawi said. I did not find a chain for this view from the narrations; rather all of them are contrary to it because they state the doubling of Iqamah [phrase]. Perhaps whoever adopted it did so based on the practice of the people of Medina, and Ibn Hazm's speech indicates this. Then I saw Malik explicitly state that in (Al-Muwatta).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I also did not find anyone who went to taking the apparent meaning of the Hadith of Ibn Umar and Anas which implies that the Iqamah is nine words by making all of it odd except the phrase of Iqamah. If anyone from the Salaf is found who adopted it, we say it; otherwise, we are compelled to the view of interpreting them - as preceded - despite the affectation in it. And Allah knows best. (4 - Upon the one who hears the Iqamah is the like of what is upon the one who hears the Adhan, of responding, sending blessings upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and asking for Wasilah for him, as preceded in explanation in Issue (14) of Adhan. This is due to the generality of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (If you hear the Mu'adhin, say like what he says...) The Hadith. And because Iqamah is an Adhan linguistically and also legally due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Between every two Adhans is a prayer), meaning Adhan and Iqamah). Al-Hafiz said in the explanation of the Hadith: Meaning Adhan and Iqamah. He said: (The commentators concurred that this is from the chapter of Taghlib [predominance] like saying: The two moons for the sun and moon. And it is possible that Iqamah was called Adhan because it is an announcement of the presence of the prayer action just as the Adhan is an announcement of the entry of the time. There is no hindrance to interpreting his saying: (two Adhans) on its apparent meaning). Imam Ibn Hazm proceeded on this, for he understood from his saying, peace be upon him: (When the prayer becomes due, let one of you call Adhan for you...) The Hadith which passed, he understood from it that Iqamah is included in this command based on the evidence of the Hadith we are discussing. He said after mentioning the preceding Hadith: (So it is correct by this the obligation of Adhan, inevitably... And Iqamah entered into this command

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: as Abdullah bin Rabi' told us) then he cited his chain to Abdullah bin Mughaffal who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Between every two Adhans is a prayer for whoever wishes). The Shafi'is agreed on the recommendation of following the Muqim [one calling Iqamah], saying like what he says except in the Hay'alah [Hayya 'ala...], where he says the Hawqalah [La hawla...] instead, as is their view in Adhan. The correct view is that he says sometimes the Hay'alah and sometimes the Hawqalah as preceded in Adhan issue (14). Likewise, they excluded from following his saying: Qad qamat is-salah, so he says in its place: Aqamaha Allahu wa Adamaha (May Allah establish it and sustain it) due to a Hadith reported in that which is weak as will come shortly. But I have not found now anyone who explicitly stated the recommendation of sending blessings on the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and asking for Wasilah for him following the Iqamah as well, other than Ibn Al-Qayyim. For he said in (Jala' Al-Afham): (The sixth place of the places of prayer upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: After answering the Mu'adhin and at the Iqamah). Then he cited from the Hadith of Muslim mentioned previously: (If you hear the Mu'adhin, say like what he says then pray upon me...) The Hadith. Then he said: (And Al-Hasan bin Arafah said: Muhammad bin Yazid Al-Wasiti told me from Al-Awwam bin Hawshab: Mansur bin Zadhan told us from Al-Hasan who said: Whoever says like what the Mu'adhin says, then when the Mu'adhin says: Qad qamat is-salah, he says: O Allah, Lord of this true call and the established prayer, send blessings upon Muhammad Your servant and Messenger and grant him the degree of Wasilah in Paradise, enters into the intercession of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And Yusuf bin Asbat said: It reached me that if the prayer is established, a man should say: O Allah, Lord of this heard call which is answered, send blessings upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad and marry us to the Hoor Al-Ayn. The Hoor Al-Ayn say: How abstinent you are regarding us). I say: In these two reports is the affirmation of prayer upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, following the Iqamah textually, and that is what the Hadith of Muslim implied by its generality. (And answering the Muqim is like answering the Mu'adhin equally, except that he says like the saying of the Muqim: Qad qamat is-salah Qad qamat is-salah, due to the generality of his saying: Say like what he says). This is what the generality of this Hadith necessitates. As for the Hadith of Abu Umamah or some Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that Bilal began the Iqamah and when he said: Qad qamat is-salah, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Aqamaha Allahu wa Adamaha), and said in the rest of the Iqamah like the Hadith of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, in the Adhan, it is a weak Hadith by agreement. Even if the author of the book (Al-Taj Al-Jami' lil-Usul) claimed: (Its chain is Salih/Valid), that is only blind following from him of Abu Dawood's famous statement: (Every Hadith I remained silent upon in my Sunan is Salih). Every meticulous researcher knows that this statement of Abu Dawood is not general, and that he has been critiqued in many of the Hadiths he remained silent upon. Indeed, Al-Nawawi says regarding some Hadiths:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Abu Dawood only remained silent upon it due to the manifestness of its weakness). If this reasoning of Al-Nawawi is correct, we may say regarding this Hadith: Abu Dawood only remained silent upon it due to the manifestness of its weakness. That is because he extracted it in his (Sunan), and likewise Ibn Al-Sunni in (Amal Al-Yawm wal-Laylah), both via Muhammad ibn Thabit Al-Abdi: A man from the people of Sham told me from Shahr bin Hawshab from Abu Umamah or from some Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, with it. Ibn Al-Sunni does not have: (And said in the rest...) etc. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu'): (It is a weak Hadith because the man is unknown, and Muhammad bin Thabit Al-Abdi is weak by agreement, and Shahr is differed over regarding his integrity). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Talkhis): (It is a weak Hadith). Then Al-Nawawi said: (But the weak is acted upon in virtuous deeds by agreement of the scholars, and this is of that). I say: This weak Hadith contradicts the generality of the authentic Hadith: (Say like what he says). Such a Hadith cannot be acted upon according to those who say it is permissible to act upon weak Hadith. It is strange that the Shafi'is hold onto it despite its weakness and leave acting upon the generality of the authentic Hadith. Then regarding what he mentioned of consensus on acting upon weak Hadith in virtuous

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: deeds, it is not so. For there are scholars who do not act upon weak Hadith absolutely, neither in rulings nor in virtues. Ibn Sayyid Al-Nas narrated that in (Uyun Al-Athar) from Yahya bin Ma'in, and attributed it in (Fath Al-Mughib) to Abu Bakr bin Al-Arabi. The scholar Jamal Al-Din Al-Qasimi said in (Qawa'id Al-Tahdith fi Mustalah Al-Hadith): (And the apparent view is that the Madhhab of Al-Bukhari and Muslim is that as well; Al-Bukhari's condition in his (Sahih) indicates it, and Imam Muslim's denunciation of narrators of weak [Hadith] agreed upon as weak, as we mentioned. This is the Madhhab of Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, also, as he said in (Al-Milal wal-Nihal). Refer to his words there. And in (Al-Muhalla) as well. Added here are the conditions mentioned by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar in (Tabyin Al-Ajab fima Warada fi Fadl Rajab). What I believe and hold as religion before Allah is that the truth in this issue is with the scholars who went to abandoning action upon weak Hadith in virtuous deeds, for several reasons: First: That weak Hadith only yields conjecture (Dhann) by agreement, and acting upon conjecture is not permissible due to His saying, Exalted is He: {They follow not except assumption, and indeed, assumption avails not against the truth at all} [Al-Najm / 28] and his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Beware of suspicion, for suspicion is the falsest of speech). Second: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered us to avoid narrating from him except what we know to be authentic from him, saying: (Beware of narrating from me except what you know). It is known that narrating Hadith is only a means to act upon what is established in it. So if he, peace and blessings be upon him, forbids us from narrating what is not established from him, then it is more appropriate that he forbids acting upon it. This is plain and clear.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Third: That in what is established from him, peace and blessings be upon him, there is sufficiency from what is not established, as is the case in this issue, for this authentic Hadith with its generality suffices over the weak Hadith. (5 - One separates between Adhan and Iqamah) due to the Hadith of Abdullah bin Zaid regarding the angel's vision from the narration of Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla from the Companions from him, he said: (I saw a man as if wearing two green garments, so he stood on the mosque and called Adhan, then sat for a sitting, then said the like of it except that he says Qad qamat is-salah...) The Hadith. Its chain is authentic as preceded in Issue (13) of Adhan. In the narration of Ibn Ishaq with his chain from him with the wording: Then he moved back not far then said the like of what he said and made it odd except that he said: Qad qamat is-salah. Narrated by the authors of Sunan and others, and the wording is Al-Darimi's. It has preceded in Issue (2) in Adhan (by an amount such that the worshiper may pray two Rak'ahs at least, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Between every two Adhans is a prayer). This Hadith is from the narration of Abdullah bin Mughaffal and has passed in (The Times). It necessitates delaying the Iqamah until whoever wishes prays two Rak'ahs, even before Maghrib prayer as preceded. So if he initiated the Iqamah before the worshiper could pray two Rak'ahs,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: it would be a cause for him missing catching the opening Takbir with the Imam, otherwise he would be forced to initiate the prayer of two Rak'ahs when the Mu'adhin starts the Adhan, and in that is missing many Sunnahs like answering [the Adhan], praying upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and asking for Wasilah as preceded. All of this is contrary to His saying, Exalted is He: {And cooperate in righteousness and piety} [Al-Ma'idah / 2] and his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Whoever among you is able to benefit his brother, let him do so) narrated by Muslim. Scholars differed on this issue. The Shafi'is agreed on the recommendation of this sitting amounting to the time needed for the congregation to gather, except in Maghrib prayer, for he does not delay it due to the tightness of its time and because people usually gather for it before its time, and he who is late does not delay beyond the beginning of the prayer. But it is recommended to separate between its Adhan and Iqamah by a slight separation of sitting, silence, or similar. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu'): (This is our Madhhab, there is no disagreement on it among us. Ahmad, Abu Yusuf, and Muhammad said it, and it is a narration from Abu Hanifa. Malik and Abu Hanifa in the famous narration from him said: He does not sit between them). Al-Bukhari indicated, followed by Al-Bayhaqi, the meaning I mentioned, where he said: (Chapter: How much is between Adhan and Iqamah) then cited the mentioned Hadith of Ibn Mughaffal. As for the Hadith of Jabir that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Bilal: (Make between your Adhan and your Iqamah the amount that the eater finishes his eating, the drinker his drinking, and the one needing to relieve himself if he enters to relieve his need), it is weak. Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: via Yahya bin Muslim from Al-Hasan and Ata from Jabir elevated with it. Yahya bin Muslim is Al-Basri. Abu Zur'ah said about him: (I do not know who he is). Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Unknown, only Abd al-Mun'im bin Nu'aym narrated from him). Thus he said. It is in Al-Tirmidhi via this Abd al-Mun'im, he said: Yahya bin Muslim told us with it. He said: (We do not know it except from this way from the hadith of Abd al-Mun'im, and it is an unknown chain). As for Al-Hakim, he extracted it via Abd al-Mun'im bin Nu'aym Al-Riyahi: Amr bin Fa'id Al-Aswari told us: Yahya bin Muslim told us with it. Al-Hakim said: (There is no one in its chain who is impugned except Amr bin Fa'id, and the rest are Sheikhs of Basra). Al-Dhahabi said: (I say: Al-Daraqutni said: Amr bin Fa'id is abandoned [Matruk]). I say: Abd al-Mun'im bin Nu'aym Al-Riyahi in Al-Hakim's chain is the same Abd al-Mun'im bin Nu'aym in Al-Tirmidhi's chain, except that I did not find him in any of the books I have attributed to (Riyah) with the two dots below (Ya) or with the single dot below (Ba), rather they mentioned that he is Al-Aswari, and he is also abandoned as in (Al-Taqrib). If the matter is as I mentioned, then Abd al-Mun'im was confused in it; sometimes he narrates it from Yahya bin Muslim directly and sometimes he narrates it from him via Amr bin Fa'id. So it is a chain sequential with weak narrators. So one wonders at the statement of

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Hakim: (There is no one in its chain who is impugned except Amr) and at Al-Dhahabi's silence on this statement of his. As for Al-Bayhaqi, he said: (There is some question regarding its chain). (Note): The virtuous professor Sheikh Ahmed Muhammad Shakir mentioned in his commentary on Al-Tirmidhi that this Yahya bin Muslim (is Yahya Al-Bakka - with Fatha on Ba and Shadda on Kaf - and he is also weak) then he mentioned the statements of Imams regarding him. This is an illusion from him, for this Yahya is not Al-Bakka; rather he is another narrator of a later layer than the one he said, and he is unknown as preceded in Al-Dhahabi and others, while that one is known for weakness, not unknown. If the matter were as the mentioned professor said, Al-Tirmidhi's statement: (And it is an unknown chain) would have no meaning since all its narrators are known; rather he indicated by this statement that some of them are unknown, and there is no one among them who is such except Yahya bin Muslim Al-Basri. He said in (Al-Taqrib): (Yahya bin Muslim Al-Basri is unknown, from the sixth [layer]). Then he said: (Yahya bin Muslim or Ibn Sulaym in diminutive form... known as Yahya Al-Bakka is weak, from the fourth [layer]). Then regarding the Hadith, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (Its chain is weak. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah and from the Hadith of Salman extracted by Abu Al-Sheikh, and from the Hadith of Ubayy bin Ka'b extracted by Abdullah bin Ahmad in (Ziyadat Al-Musnad), and all of them are flimsy).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-San'ani said: (Except that they are strengthened by the meaning for which Adhan was legislated, for it is a call to those not present to attend the prayer, so a time must be estimated that accommodates the one going to prayer and his attendance, otherwise the benefit of the call would be lost. Al-Bukhari headed a chapter (Chapter: How much is between Adhan and Iqamah) but the estimation is not established). However, he indicated that by citing the Hadith mentioned in the beginning of the discussion. And the Hadith of Ubayy bin Ka'b in (Al-Musnad). Some argued for separation between Adhan and Iqamah with the Hadith of Abu Hurairah: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (When the call for prayer is made, Satan turns back passing wind so that he does not hear the Adhan. When the call is finished, he comes forward. Until when the Tathwib [Iqamah] for prayer is made, he turns back. Until when the Tathwib is finished, he comes forward until he crosses between a man and his self, saying to him: Remember such and such, remember such and such...) The Hadith is agreed upon and will come, Allah willing. Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in (Sharh Al-Taqrib): (In it is evidence that in his time, peace be upon him, there was a separation between Adhan and Iqamah by a time period. That is evidence that it is not a condition for obtaining the virtue of performing prayer at the beginning of its time that its beginning coincides with the beginning of the time, for if that were so, they would not have persisted in leaving this virtue. This is the known correct view. It was said: That is not obtained except by the first Takbir coinciding

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: with the beginning of the time, which is anomalous (Shadh), and this Hadith indicates the contrary). (6 - If the Mu'adhin begins the Iqamah, no one should commence any voluntary prayer, even if it is the Sunnah of Fajr; rather he must enter into the obligatory prayer which has been established, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (When the prayer is established, there is no prayer except the one established)). This Hadith is from the narration of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. Imam Ahmad extracted it with this wording: Hasan told us: Ibn Lahi'ah told us: Ayyash bin Abbas Al-Qitbani told us from Abu Tamim Al-Zuhri from him. This is an authentic chain; its narrators are narrators of Muslim except Ibn Lahi'ah, who is trustworthy but feared for poor memory, and he has been followed in this, indicating he preserved it. Al-Tahawi extracted it saying: Fahd told us, he said: Abu Salih told us, he said: Al-Layth told me from Abdullah bin Ayyash bin Abbas Al-Qitbani from his father from Abu Salamah from Abu Hurairah with it. This is also an authentic chain; its narrators are narrators of the Sahih except this Fahd, who is Ibn Sulaiman bin Yahya. Ibn Yunus said: (He was trustworthy, firm). Mentioned in (Kashf Al-Astar an Rijal Ma'ani Al-Athar) by Rashid Allah Shah Al-Sindi. They differed regarding Ayyash bin Abbas; Ibn Lahi'ah said: From him from Abu Tamim. His son Abdullah said: From him from Abu Salamah. Perhaps this is more correct, for Abdullah is in better

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: condition than Ibn Lahi'ah, and he is truthful (Saduq) who makes mistakes, and Muslim extracted from him in corroborations as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Tirmidhi mentioned this path from Abu Salamah in suspended form. The Hadith has other paths with a different wording narrated by Muslim and Abu Dawood, and from him Ibn Hazm, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir), Al-Tahawi also, Al-Bayhaqi, Ahmad, and Al-Khatib in his (Tarikh) via paths from Amr bin Dinar from Ata bin Yasar from him elevated with the wording: (There is no prayer except the obligatory one). Al-Bayhaqi added in a narration: It was said: O Messenger of Allah, not even the two Rak'ahs of Fajr? He said: (Not even the two Rak'ahs of Fajr). He extracted it via Abu Ahmad bin Adi Al-Hafiz: Muhammad bin Isma'il Al-Marwazi told us: Ahmad bin Sayyar told us: Yahya bin Nasr bin Hajib Al-Marwazi told us: Muslim ibn Khalid Al-Zanji told us from Amr bin Dinar with it. Abu Ahmad said: (I do not know anyone mentioning this addition in its text other than Yahya bin Nasr from Muslim bin Khalid from Amr). Al-Bayhaqi said: (Nasr bin Hajib Al-Marwazi is not strong, and his son Yahya likewise). I say: But this addition is correct in meaning even if it is weak in structure, for many authentic explicit Hadiths have come forbidding the two Rak'ahs of Fajr if

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the prayer is established. The clarification of that will come in its place, Allah willing. I found a third path for the Hadith extracted by Al-Khatib via Ahmed bin Bashar Al-Sayrafi: Abu Hafs Al-Abdi told us: Ayyub told us from Abu Qilabah from Sulaiman bin Bashar from Abu Hurairah elevated with it. This Ahmad narrated from a group and a group narrated from him; Al-Khatib wrote his biography and cited this Hadith for him and did not mention any criticism or praise. Abu Hafs Al-Abdi I did not know, unless he is Umar bin Hafs Al-Abdi or Hafs, but this one is of an earlier layer narrating from Thabit; if he is this one, he is flimsy (Wahin) as Al-Dhahabi said. Sulaiman bin Bashar I did not find; among the narrators of this layer is Sulaiman bin Bishr from the narrators of Ahmad in (Al-Ta'jil) and trustworthy according to Ibn Hibban. The Hadith is evidence that it is not permissible to enter into voluntary prayer for one who hears the Iqamah, whether it is the Sunnah of Fajr or otherwise. This is the school of the majority of scholars. Al-Tirmidhi said: (The practice is upon this according to some people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and others: if the prayer is established, a man should not pray except the obligatory one. Sufyan Al-Thawri, Ibn Al-Mubarak, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq say this). Perhaps further elaboration on this issue will come in the place referred to just now.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (7 - The prayer is not established until the Imam comes out to the mosque) due to the Hadith of Jabir bin Samurah: The Mu'adhin of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to call Adhan then wait and not call Iqamah until he saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had come out; he would establish prayer when he saw him. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad via Isra'il who said: Simak informed me that he heard Jabir bin Samurah with it. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). I say: It is on the condition of Muslim, and he extracted it in his (Sahih) from another path from Simak, and its wording preceded in Adhan in Issue (13). (8 - People do not stand until they see him come out, even if the prayer was established before that, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (If the prayer is established, do not stand until you see me [having come out]) [and upon you is tranquility])] This Hadith is from the narration of Abu Qatadah Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via paths from Yahya bin Abi Kathir from Abdullah bin Abi Qatadah from his father. The first addition is the narration of Al-Tirmidhi, and it is a narration of Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and Al-Bayhaqi via Ma'mar from Yahya. Abu Dawood said: (No one mentioned: 'having come out' except Ma'mar). I say: Yes, others mentioned it. Al-Walid bin Muslim narrated it from Shayban from Yahya with this addition. Extracted by Muslim. Al-Bayhaqi said after citing it via Ma'mar: (And likewise Al-Walid bin Muslim narrated it from Shayban from Yahya: 'until you see me having come out'. Likewise Al-Hajjaj Al-Sawwaf said it from Yahya from the narration of Muhammad bin Bashar from Yahya bin Sa'id from him. Sufyan bin Uyaynah narrated it from Ma'mar, Abu Nu'aym from Shayban, and Ubaidullah ibn Sa'id from Yahya Al-Qattan from Al-Hajjaj without saying: 'having come out'. As for what some pseudo-jurists narrate in this Hadith: (until you see me standing in the row), it has not reached us). In summary, this addition was mentioned by some and not by others, and those who mentioned it are trustworthy, and it is an addition of knowledge that must be accepted because the affirmer takes precedence over the negator, and he who knows is a proof over him who does not know. As for the second addition, it was narrated by Ali bin Al-Mubarak and Shayban together from Yahya bin Abi Kathir.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Extracted by Ahmad. Al-Bukhari narrated it separately. Mu'awiyah bin Salam also narrated it as Abu Dawood mentioned in suspended form, and Al-Isma'ili connected it via Al-Walid bin Muslim from Mu'awiyah bin Salam and Shayban together from Yahya as Abu Dawood said according to what is in (Al-Fath). The Hadith has two witnesses from the Hadith of Anas and Jabir bin Samurah: As for the first: Al-Tayalisi extracted it: Jarir bin Hazim told us from Thabit from him with the mentioned wording without the two additions. This is an authentic chain, its narrators are narrators of the Six, but Al-Tirmidhi said: (It is not preserved) and attributed the illusion in it to this Jarir, and transmitted that from Al-Bukhari. So Allah knows best. As for the Hadith of Jabir, Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Saghir), he said: Ahmad ibn Hamdun Al-Mawsili told us: Salih bin Abd al-Samad Al-Asadi Al-Mawsili told us: Al-Qasim ibn Yazid Al-Jarmi told us from Isra'il from Simak bin Harb from him elevated with it. He said: (No one narrated it from Simak except Isra'il, nor from Isra'il except Al-Qasim bin Yazid Al-Jarmi; Salih bin Abd al-Samad was alone in narrating it). I say: Salih this, I did not find a biography for him. As for his Sheikh Al-Qasim bin Yazid Al-Jarmi - with Fatha on Jim - he is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The rest of his narrators are narrators of Muslim. I suspect that this Salih was mistaken in his narration of this Hadith with this text, for a group of trustworthy narrators narrated it from Isra'il with this chain from Jabir saying: The Mu'adhin of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to call Adhan then wait and not call Iqamah until he saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had come out; he would establish prayer when he saw him. It preceded in the fourth issue. This is the origin of the Hadith of Jabir bin Samurah, so it got mixed up for this Salih or someone else with the mentioned Hadith of Abu Qatadah, so he narrated it with this chain. This is what appeared to me in this station. As for Al-Haythami, he said in (Al-Majma'): (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Awsat) and (Al-Saghir) and its chain is good). Thus he said, and Allah knows best. In the Hadith is evidence that people should not stand for prayer until they see the Imam in the mosque. The majority of scholars have taken this view as will come. Al-Tirmidhi said after citing the Hadith: (Some people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and others disliked that people wait for the Imam while standing. Some of them said: If the Imam is in the mosque and the prayer is established, they only stand when the Mu'adhin says: Qad qamat is-salah Qad qamat is-salah. This is the saying of Ibn Al-Mubarak). I say: It is also the saying of Ahmad. Abu Dawood said in his (Masa'il):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (I said to Ahmad: When do people stand for prayer? He said: If he says - meaning the Mu'adhin -: Qad qamat is-salah. I said: If the Imam has not come yet? He said: They do not stand until they see him). That is what is narrated from Anas. Al-Bayhaqi said: (We have narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that if it was said: Qad qamat is-salah, he jumped up and stood. And from Al-Husain bin Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he used to do that. It is the saying of Ata and Al-Hasan). Al-Hafiz said: (The majority went to the view that if the Imam is with them in the mosque, they do not stand until the Iqamah finishes. From Anas that he used to stand if the Mu'adhin said: Qad qamat is-salah; Ibn Al-Mundhir and others narrated it. Likewise Sa'id bin Mansur narrated it via Abu Ishaq from the companions of Abdullah. From Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib, he said: If the Mu'adhin says: Allahu Akbar, standing becomes obligatory. If he says: Hayya 'ala as-salah, the rows are straightened. If he says La ilaha illa Allah, the Imam says Takbir. From Abu Hanifa: They stand if he says: Hayya 'ala al-falah; if he says: Qad qamat is-salah, the Imam says Takbir. As for if the Imam is not in the mosque, the majority went to the view that they do not stand until they see him. Those we mentioned differed according to the detail we explained, and the Hadith of the chapter is a proof against them. In it is the permissibility of Iqamah while the Imam is in his house if he hears it and his permission for that preceded. Al-Qurtubi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The apparent meaning of the Hadith is that prayer was established before the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, came out of his house. This contradicts the Hadith of Jabir bin Samurah that Bilal would not establish prayer until the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, came out. Extracted by Muslim (1). They are reconciled by saying that Bilal used to watch for the exit of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him; as soon as he saw him, he would start the Iqamah before most people saw him. Then when they saw him, they stood, so he would not stand in his place until their rows were straightened). I say: Witness to this is what Abd al-Razzaq narrated from Ibn Juraij from Ibn Shihab: That the people, the moment the Mu'adhin said: Allahu Akbar, would stand for prayer, so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, would not come to his place until the rows were straightened. As for the Hadith of Abu Hurairah coming shortly with the wording: The prayer was established, so the people straightened their rows, then the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, came out. And its wording in (Mustakhraj Abi Nu'aym): So the people lined up in rows then he came out to us. And its wording in Muslim: The prayer was established, so we stood and straightened the rows before the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, came out to us. Then he came and stood in his place... The Hadith. And from him in the narration of Abu Dawood: That prayer was established for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and the people would take their places before the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, came (2). This is reconciled with the Hadith of Abu Qatadah by saying that this perhaps occurred to show permissibility, and that their action in the Hadith of Abu Hurairah was the cause of the prohibition of that in the Hadith of Abu Qatadah, and that they used to stand the moment prayer was established even if the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, had not come out, so he forbade them from that
foot_note:
1. (1) As preceded 
2. I say: Muslim also narrated it (2/101-102)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: due to the possibility that he might be occupied with something that delays his exit, making waiting difficult for them. This is not contradicted by the Hadith of Anas coming later that he stood in his place for a long time for the need of some people, due to the possibility that this occurred rarely or he did it to show permissibility). (9 - If one hears the establishment of prayer, he should not hasten to it; rather he should walk with tranquility and dignity upon him, as he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (If the prayer is established, do not come to it [while] running, but come to it [while] walking, and upon you is tranquility [and dignity]. Whatever you catch, pray, and whatever you miss, complete. [For one of you is in prayer as long as he is heading to prayer])). This Hadith is narrated by Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are paths from him with similar wordings: (1) and (2) From Al-Zuhri from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib and Abu Salamah, both from Abu Hurairah. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, as well as Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via paths from him, all with this wording except Ahmad, whose wording is: (If you hear the Iqamah, walk and do not rush, and upon you is tranquility. Whatever you catch, pray, and whatever you miss, complete). This is the wording of Al-Bukhari, and it contains the fourth addition. It was extracted from the first path by: Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad from Sufyan bin Uyaynah; and Al-Tahawi and Ahmad

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: from Yazid bin Al-Had; and Al-Tirmidhi and Ahmad also from Ma'mar; all three from Al-Zuhri from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib alone. In Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad from Sufyan is the first addition, and in Ahmad from Ma'mar is the second addition. Then it was extracted from the second path by: Al-Tirmidhi from Ma'mar, Al-Tayalisi from Ibn Abi Dhi'b, Ahmad from Uqayl, and Al-Tahawi from Yazid bin Al-Had; all four from Al-Zuhri saying: Abu Salamah bin Abd al-Rahman informed me with it. In Ma'mar's Hadith are the first, second, and third additions. Then Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad extracted it from another path from Abu Salamah with it similarly. In Ahmad in a narration is the fourth addition. And in a wording for him: (If one of you hears the Iqamah, let him come...) The Hadith similarly. (3) From Ma'mar from Hammam from Abu Hurairah. Extracted by Muslim and Ahmad similarly. (4) From Hisham bin Hassan from Muhammad bin Sirin from him. Extracted by Muslim, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad also, and it contains the second and fourth additions.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Awf followed him from Muhammad, extracted by Ahmad with an authentic chain on the condition of the Six, and Ayyub from Muhammad, extracted by Al-Tahawi. (5) and (6) From Abd al-Rahman bin Ya'qub and Ishaq bin Abdullah: That they heard Abu Hurairah say... so he mentioned it similarly elevated, and it contains the last addition. Extracted by Malik, and from him Ahmad and Al-Tahawi from Al-Ala' bin Abd al-Rahman bin Ya'qub from both of them. Then Al-Tahawi and Ahmad extracted it via Malik also from Al-Ala' bin Abd al-Rahman from his father alone. Muslim likewise extracted it from Isma'il bin Ja'far: Al-Ala' informed me from his father with it. (7) From Awf from Al-Hasan - who is Al-Basri - he said: It reached me that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said... so he mentioned it like the Hadith of Ibn Sirin. Extracted by Ahmad. In summary, the Hadith is Mutawatir from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. I found a witness for it from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, elevated with the wording: (If one of you comes and the prayer is established, let him walk at his ease, let him pray what he caught and make up what he missed).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Ahmad: Ali bin Asim told us from Humaid from him, and Khalid from Muhammad from Abu Hurairah with it. Then he, Abu Dawood, Abu Awanah, and Al-Tahawi extracted it from other paths from Humaid similarly. It contains a story that will come in (Opening of Prayer) number (8). The chain is authentic on the condition of Muslim. He extracted it without this sentence as will come there. It has another witness from the Hadith of Abu Qatadah similarly, and perhaps it will come. We cited it in what comes in (Rulings of Mosques) paragraph (3) of Etiquettes. In the Hadith is the emphasized recommendation to come to prayer with tranquility and dignity, and the prohibition of coming to it running, whether in Jumu'ah prayer or others, whether one fears missing the opening Takbir or not. Thus in (Sharh Muslim) by Al-Nawawi. Al-Tirmidhi said: (The people of knowledge differed regarding walking to the mosque. Some of them saw rushing if one fears missing the first Takbir, to the extent that it was mentioned about some of them that they used to jog to prayer. Others disliked rushing and chose that one walk with deliberation and dignity. Ahmad and Ishaq say this, and they said: The practice is on the Hadith of Abu Hurairah. Ishaq said: If he fears missing the first Takbir, there is no harm if he hurries in walking).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: The correct view is the dislike of rushing whether one fears missing the Takbir or not, due to the generality of the Hadith. It is the school of the Shafi'is. Ibn Al-Mundhir narrated it from Zaid bin Thabit, Anas, Ahmad, and Abu Thawr, and Ibn Al-Mundhir chose it. Al-Abdari narrated it from most scholars as in (Al-Majmu'). He mentioned in it a view of some Shafi'is - namely Abu Ishaq - like the view of Ishaq which Al-Tirmidhi cited. Al-Nawawi said: (It is very weak, contradicting the authentic Sunnah). Scholars said: The wisdom in coming to it with tranquility and the prohibition of running is: The one going to prayer is intending it and proceeding to it, so he should be disciplined with its etiquettes and in the most perfect of states. This is the meaning of his saying in the narration of Malik and others: (For one of you is in prayer as long as he is heading to prayer). His saying: (If the prayer is established) mentions Iqamah only to alert by it to other times, because if he forbade coming to it running during Iqamah despite fear of missing some of it, then before Iqamah is more worthy. He emphasized that by stating the reason, saying: (For one of you is in prayer as long as he is heading to prayer). This covers all times of coming to prayer. He emphasized that with another emphasis, saying: (Whatever you catch, pray, and whatever you miss, complete). So it contains alerting and emphasis lest someone imagine that the prohibition is only for one who does not fear missing part of the prayer, so he explicitly stated the prohibition even if whatever of the prayer is missed. He clarified what to do regarding what he missed. Scholars differed regarding what he missed of prayer: Is it the beginning of his prayer or the end of it?

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The truth is the first, as the explanation of that will come in its place, Allah willing. (Note): As for His saying, Exalted is He: {Then hasten to the remembrance of Allah} [Al-Jumu'ah / 9], the intended meaning is not the running prohibited in the Hadith; rather it means proceeding and going. Al-Nawawi said: (One says 'Sa'aytu' in such or to such: if he went to it and worked in it. From it is His saying, Exalted is He: {And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives} [Al-Najm / 39]. And like His saying, Exalted is He: {And when he goes away, he strives throughout the land} [Al-Baqarah / 205]. And His saying: {But as for he who came to you striving} [Abasa / 8]). (10 - It is permissible to separate between Iqamah and prayer with speech for a benefit - like ordering the straightening of rows as will come - or for a need, for (Prayer used to be established, then the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, would speak to a man regarding a need he had, so he would stand between him and the Qiblah. He would remain standing speaking to him - the narrator said -: so perhaps I saw some of the people dozing off from the length of the Prophet's standing, peace and blessings be upon him, for him) [then he prayed]). This is from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are three paths from him: First: From Thabit from him. Narrated by Ahmad: Abd al-Razzaq told us: Ma'mar informed us from Al-Zuhri from Thabit with it. This is an authentic chain on their [Bukhari and Muslim's] condition.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Likewise, Al-Tirmidhi extracted it from Abd al-Razzaq with it and said: (Hasan Sahih). Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad extracted it from Hammad bin Salamah from Thabit with it similarly. It contains the addition. Then Ahmad extracted it via Umarah bin Zadhan: Thabit told us with it similarly also with the wording: (So he stands with him until most of them nod their heads). Its chain is on the condition of Muslim. Al-Bukhari extracted it via Humaid who said: I asked Thabit Al-Bunani about a man speaking after prayer is established, so he told me from Anas bin Malik who said: Prayer was established, then a man presented himself to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so he detained him after prayer was established. Second: From Abd al-Aziz bin Suhayb from him who said: Prayer was established and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was whispering [speaking privately] to a man at the side of the mosque, so he did not stand for prayer until the people slept. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via paths from him. Third: From Humaid from him. Narrated by Ahmad via paths from him with the wording: Bilal established

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: prayer, then a man presented himself to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. He said: So he stopped him until some of the people dozed off, then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came and prayed with the people. Ibn Hibban extracted it via Hushaym from him. Ahmad's chain is authentic tripartite (Thulathi). However, it preceded that Al-Bukhari narrated it via Humaid from Thabit from him, which is from the narration of Abd al-A'la from him. Here he narrated it from Anas directly without the intermediary. But Al-Hafiz said: (I did not find in any of its paths an explicit statement of his hearing it from Anas, and he is a Mudallis, so it appears that the narration of Abd al-A'la is the connected one). Al-Hafiz said: (In it [i.e., the Hadith] is the permissibility of separating between Iqamah and Ihram [Takbir] if it is for a need. As for if it is for other than a need, it is disliked. It was used as evidence to refute those among the Hanafis who generalized that if the Mu'adhin says: Qad qamat is-salah, the Imam must say Takbir). In (Al-Majmu'): (Our Madhhab and the Madhhab of the majority of the people of Hijaz and others is: permissibility of speaking after Iqamah of prayer before Ihram, but it is better to leave it except for a need. Abu Hanifa and others from the Kufans disliked it whether the speech was long or short. The Iqamah is not repeated for that. Our evidence is these authentic Hadiths). Ibn Hazm went to this in (Al-Muhalla), then said: (There is no evidence necessitating repetition of Iqamah at all. There is no disagreement among any of the Imams that

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: whoever speaks between Iqamah and prayer or passes wind performs ablution and Iqamah is not repeated for that. Whoever differentiates between little action and much, and little speech and much, is tasked to bring proof for the correctness of his saying, then for the limit of the little of that from the much, and he has no way to that at all). He indicates by that the refutation of some of our Hanafi scholars. Sheikh Al-Kashmiri admitted that defining the little and much is difficult. After writing what preceded, I found a fourth path for the Hadith containing benefits not found in other paths. Al-Bukhari extracted it in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) Chapter: Generosity of the Soul. He said: Ibn Abi Al-Aswad told us, he said: Abd al-Malik bin Amr told us, he said: Sahamah bin Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Asam told us, he said: I heard Anas bin Malik say: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was merciful. No one came to him except he promised him and fulfilled it for him if he had it. Prayer was established and a Bedouin came to him and took hold of his garment and said: Only a little remains of my need and I fear I will forget it. So he stood with him until he finished his need then came and prayed. This chain is potentially Hasan. Its narrators are narrators of Al-Bukhari in his (Sahih) except Sahamah - with Fatha on the two un-dotted letters and the second is doubled [Sahhamah] - Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy, and Waki' also narrated from him. In (Al-Taqrib) he is: (Acceptable). You see that the man, the owner of the story, was not named in this path like the other paths,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: at most he was described in this as a Bedouin. So the statement of Sheikh Al-Kashmiri in (Fayd Al-Bari): (As for the man, the two commentators did not realize who he was, and I found his name mentioned in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) by Al-Bukhari) is not correct as is apparent. (11 - Whoever combines two prayers, combining early or late, performs Iqamah for each prayer, as the Messenger of Allah did in the Battle of the Trench and in Arafat and Muzdalifah). There are Hadiths regarding it: First: From Jabir in his long Hadith about Hajj: That he, peace and blessings be upon him, established prayer for Dhuhr, then established prayer for Asr, and that was at Arafat. Then he came to Muzdalifah and prayed Maghrib and Isha there with one Adhan and two Iqamahs. It preceded in the seventh issue of Adhan. Second: From Usamah bin Zaid, that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, pushed on from Arafat and alighted at the ravine, urinated, then performed ablution but did not complete the ablution fully. I said to him: The prayer. He said: (The prayer is ahead of you). So he came to Muzdalifah, performed ablution and completed it fully. Then prayer was established so he prayed Maghrib. Then every person made his camel kneel in his place. Then prayer was established so he prayed and did not pray between them. Extracted by Al-Bukhari via Malik, and this is in (Al-Muwatta), Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Kurayb the freed slave of Ibn Abbas from him. Third: From Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, combined Maghrib and Isha at Jam' [Muzdalifah], each one of them with an Iqamah, and he did not glorify [pray voluntary prayers] between them nor following either one of them. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Al-Zuhri from Salim bin Abdullah from him. Malik narrated it from Al-Zuhri with it briefly: He prayed Maghrib and Isha at Muzdalifah together. And from him Ahmad and Muslim. This Hadith came from Ibn Umar via other paths with the wording: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, combined Maghrib and Isha at Jam', praying Maghrib three [Rak'ahs] and Isha two [Rak'ahs] with one Iqamah.
