Extracted by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via paths from Sa'id bin Jubair from him with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad extracted it via Abu Ishaq: I heard Abdullah bin Malik say: I prayed with Ibn Umar at Jam' so he established prayer and prayed Maghrib three, then prayed Isha two with one Iqamah. He said: Khalid bin Malik asked him, so he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did like this in this place. This Abdullah bin Malik is Ibn Al-Harith. He said in (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable). So they differed regarding Ibn Umar. In these two narrations [it says] that he, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed Maghrib and Isha with one Iqamah. And in the narration of Salim bin Abdullah [it says] that he prayed them with one Iqamah for each of them. This narration is given precedence over the narration of Ibn Jubair and Ibn Malik because with it is an addition of knowledge, and the addition of a trustworthy narrator is accepted. Also, it agrees with the narration of Usamah bin Zaid and Jabir bin Abdullah which agree on two Iqamahs. Thus the narration of Ibn Umar agreeing with them is more worthy of acceptance and reliance. Al-Nawawi went to this in (Sharh Muslim), and Ibn Hazm preceded him to that, preferring the narration of Salim over its contrary. Ibn Hazm held this ruling - that he calls Iqamah for each prayer in combining, whether early or late - and it is the old saying of Al-Shafi'i and a narration from Ahmad. Ibn Al-Majishun Al-Maliki said it, and Al-Tahawi Al-Hanafi, contrary to Abu Hanifa and his two companions. That is because they held regarding combining two prayers that they

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: make it with one Adhan and one Iqamah, arguing for that with the second narration from Ibn Umar. Al-Tahawi explicitly stated all of that in his explanation and strengthened what he chose by analogy with combining Dhuhr and Asr at Arafat. Then he said: (And what we narrated from Jabir regarding this is more beloved to us because of what observation testifies for it). Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (This is the correct view of our Madhhab: that Adhan is recommended for the first of them and he performs Iqamah for each one, so he prays them with one Adhan and two Iqamahs. The Hadith of (one Iqamah) is interpreted as meaning each prayer has an Iqamah. This reconciliation is necessary between it and the first narration (meaning: from the Hadith of Ibn Umar) and between it also and the narration of Jabir). I say: It is strange that our scholars took the Hadith of Jabir regarding combining at Arafat with one Adhan and two Iqamahs and abandoned it regarding combining at Muzdalifah with one Adhan and two Iqamahs. This is among the wonders of Fiqh. No wonder Imam Al-Tahawi opposed them, followed by Sheikh Ibn Al-Humam then Abu Al-Hasanat Al-Laknawi in (Al-Ta'liq Al-Mumajjad), and they were correct. (12 - Likewise, he performs Iqamah for each prayer of the prescribed missed prayers, one Iqamah [each], as the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did in the Battle of the Trench). In the chapter from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were detained on the day of the Trench until a portion of the night had passed, until we were sufficed [from fighting], and that is the saying of Allah Almighty: {And Allah sufficed the believers the fighting, and Allah is ever Powerful, Exalted in Might} [Al-Ahzab / 25].

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, called Bilal and ordered him, so he established prayer and he prayed Dhuhr... Then he established for Asr and he prayed it likewise. Then he established for Maghrib and he prayed it likewise. Then he established for Isha and he prayed it likewise... The Hadith. It is authentic in chain and its extraction preceded in what is before Adhan, Issue (8). We mentioned there a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud and we cited its wording in Adhan Issue (8) similar to this Hadith of Abu Sa'id. Al-Bayhaqi added to it in a narration: (He followed some of them with others with an Iqamah, an Iqamah). The Shafi'is went to this, saying: If he wants to make up missed prayers all at once, he calls Iqamah for each one, without disagreement among them as in (Al-Majmu'). (13 - If he finishes the prayer and leaves the mosque having forgotten a Rak'ah or other than that without which the prayer is not complete, and wants to return to complete it, he must repeat the Iqamah. For (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed one day, said Taslim and left, and a Rak'ah of prayer remained. A man caught him and said: You forgot a Rak'ah of the prayer. So he returned and entered the mosque and ordered Bilal, so he established prayer and he prayed one Rak'ah with the people)). This is from the Hadith of Mu'awiyah bin Hudayj - with un-dotted Ha and Jim in diminutive form - extracted by Ahmad: Hajjaj told us: Layth told us: Yazid bin Abi Habib told me that Suwayd bin Qais informed him from him that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed one day... etc. He added at its end: So I informed the people of that and they said: Do you know the man? I said: No, unless I see him

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: So he passed by me and I said: It is this one. They said: Talhah bin Ubaidullah. This is an authentic chain; its narrators are narrators of the Two Sheikhs except Suwayd bin Qais, and he is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). Abu Dawood and Al-Nasa'i extracted it from Qutaibah bin Sa'id, Al-Tahawi from Shu'ayb bin Al-Layth, and Al-Bayhaqi from Yahya ibn Bukair, all three from Al-Layth with it. Al-Hakim extracted it, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, via Wahb bin Jarir bin Hazim: My father told us, he said: I heard Yahya bin Ayyub narrating from Yazid bin Abi Habib with it. He said: (Authentic chain). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Ibn Khuzaimah also extracted it as in (Al-Fath). Al-Nasa'i wrote a chapter for it: Chapter (Iqamah for the one who forgets a Rak'ah of prayer). 8 - Obligation of Covering the Awrah Alone. (1 - It is an obligation from the obligations of prayer by the Book and the Sunnah. As for the Book, His saying, Exalted is He: {O children of Adam, take your adornment at every mosque} [Al-A'raf: 31]. The intended meaning is: covering the Awrah, evidenced by the reason for revelation. Ibn Abbas said: They used [in Jahiliyyah] to circumambulate naked: Men by day and women by night. The woman used to [circumambulate the House while she was naked] [exposing her chest and what is there] [and saying: Who will lend me

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: a garment for Tawaf to place over her private part, and] she says: Today some or all of it appears, and what appears of it I do not make lawful. So Allah revealed: {Take your adornment at every mosque}). This Hadith was extracted by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Jarir in his (Tafsir), Al-Hakim, and from him Al-Bayhaqi via paths from Shu'bah from Salamah bin Kuhail from Muslim Al-Batin from Sa'id bin Jubair from him with it. The context is Ibn Jarir's. The first addition is Al-Hakim's, the second is Muslim and Al-Nasa'i's, the fourth [third] is Al-Bayhaqi's in a narration, and the fourth is Muslim's also. Hisham bin Urwah said from his father: The Arabs used to circumambulate the House naked except the Hums - and the Hums are Quraish and their offspring - they used to circumambulate naked unless the Hums gave them clothes, so men would give to men and women to women. Extracted by Muslim. Regarding their circumambulation, His saying, Exalted is He, was also revealed: {And when they commit an immorality, they say, "We found our fathers doing it, and Allah has ordered us to do it." Say, "Indeed, Allah does not order immorality. Do you say about Allah that which you do not know?"} [Al-A'raf / 28]. Mujahid said it as in (Tafsir Ibn Kathir). So Allah Almighty named their circumambulation naked: Immorality (Fahisha). This is the view of most commentators as Al-Qurtubi said, and it is famous from Ibn Abbas as in (Al-Majmu'). This, and our saying 'The intended meaning is covering the Awrah' is agreed upon among scholars as Ibn Hazm transmitted

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: in (Al-Muhalla) and Al-Hafiz affirmed it in (Al-Fath). (As for the Sunnah, from it is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Guard your nakedness except from your wife or what your right hand possesses) and his saying: (Do not walk naked). The first Hadith passed completely extracted in (Etiquettes of Bathing). The second Hadith is from the narration of Al-Miswar bin Makhramah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I came carrying a heavy stone, and upon me was a light waist wrapper. He said: My waist wrapper came loose while the stone was with me; I could not put it down until I reached its place with it. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Return to your garment and take it, and do not walk naked). Extracted by Muslim, and from his path Ibn Hazm, and Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi via Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Umawi from Uthman bin Hakim from Abu Umamah bin Sahl from him. In the chapter from Jabir bin Abdullah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was moving stones with them for the Kaaba and his waist wrapper was on him. His uncle Al-Abbas said to him: O nephew, if you would untie your waist wrapper and place it on your shoulders under the stones. He said: So he untied it and placed it on his shoulders, then he fell unconscious. He was not seen naked after that, peace and blessings be upon him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari and Muslim

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and from his path Ibn Hazm and Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Zakariya bin Ishaq: Amr bin Dinar told us from him. Then Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad extracted it via Ibn Juraij, he said: Amr bin Dinar informed me with it similarly with the wording: (So he fell to the ground and his eyes gazed toward the sky, then he said: My waist wrapper, my waist wrapper! So he tightened his waist wrapper on himself). Al-Bayhaqi and Ibn Hazm likewise extracted it. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Al-Tufayl, and he mentioned the building of the Kaaba in Jahiliyyah, he said: So Quraish demolished it and began building it with stones of the valley which Quraish carried on their necks. They raised it into the sky twenty cubits. While the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was carrying stones from Ajyad and upon him was a Namirah [striped garment], the Namirah became tight on him, so he went to place the Namirah on his shoulder, and his nakedness was seen due to the smallness of the Namirah. It was called out: O Muhammad, cover your nakedness. He was not seen naked after that. Thus Ahmad extracted it: Abd al-Razzaq told us: Ma'mar informed us from Ibn Khuthaym from him. This is an authentic chain; its narrators are all narrators of Muslim. Al-Hafiz cited it in (Al-Fath) at length and said: Extracted by Abd al-Razzaq. And from his path Al-Hakim and Al-Tabarani. It is in (Al-Mustadrak), and he authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: These hadiths—and likewise the Verse—contain evidence for the obligation of covering the awrah (intimate parts) in prayer and outside of it. As for the obligation of covering it outside of prayer, it is agreed upon; this agreement was reported by Ibn Rushd in (Al-Bidayah), and Al-Nawawi reported the consensus (Ijma) on it in (Al-Majmu). As for the obligation of covering it within prayer, it is disputed. The majority hold that it is obligatory, and this is the school of Abu Hanifa, Al-Shafi'i, Dawud, and Ibn Hazm. He said in (Al-Bidayah): (The apparent view of Malik's school is that it is among the Sunan [recommended practices] of prayer), and this was the view taken by Ismail Al-Qadi as in (Tafsir Al-Qurtubi). This is a weak view, refuted by those explicit commands to cover the awrah, and prayer is more deserving of that, as is not hidden. From what we have mentioned, you know that Ibn Hazm's statement in Maratib Al-Ijma: (They agreed that covering the awrah in it [prayer] for one who is able to find a lawful garment to wear is a Fard [obligation]) is not correct in reporting this agreement. Furthermore, those who held its obligation in prayer made it a condition among the conditions for the validity of prayer; so whoever prays naked, his prayer is void according to them. Al-Nawawi said: (Some of Malik's companions said: Covering the awrah is a duty (Wajib) and not a condition; if one prays with it exposed, his prayer is valid whether he did so intentionally or out of forgetfulness).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: This is the truth, that it is a duty (Wajib) and not a condition, for conditionality requires evidence beyond a mere command, and we have not found any evidence for those who claim conditionality, except what Al-Nawawi mentioned where he said: (Our proof is that the obligation of covering is established by the hadith of Aisha: 'Allah does not accept the prayer of a menstruating woman except with a Khimar [head cover]'... and it will come. He said: 'And there is no difference between men and women by agreement'). This hadith, as you see, is specific to women, but Al-Nawawi analogized men to them, which is a corrupt analogy due to the clear difference between the awrah of a man and the awrah of a woman, as is obvious. Al-Shawkani argued well in this regard in (Al-Nayl); after mentioning the hadiths used by the majority to prove conditionality, he said: (The answer to these evidences is that their limit is to indicate obligation. As for conditionality, where the absence of the condition effects the absence of the conditioned, they are not suitable for deducing it, because a condition is a positive legal ruling that is not established by mere commands. Yes, one could argue for conditionality using the hadith of the chapter (meaning Aisha's hadith), but referencing that is not free from impurity. First, it is said: We deny that negating acceptance indicates conditionality, because acceptance has been negated for the prayer of a runaway slave, one who has alcohol in his belly, and one who visits a fortune teller, despite the validity [of the prayer] being established by consensus.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Secondly: The utmost this proves is that covering is a condition for the validity of a woman's prayer, which is more specific than the claim, and appending men to women is incorrect here due to the existence of a difference, which is the temptation (Fitnah) in the exposure of a woman, a meaning not found in the awrah of a man. Thirdly: The hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd in the two Sahihs, Abu Dawood, and Al-Nasa'i with the wording: The men used to pray with the Prophet (peace be upon him) tying their lower garments on their necks like children, and it was said to the women: Do not raise your heads until the men are seated upright. Abu Dawood added: Due to the tightness of the garments. This indicates the lack of obligation to cover [fully], let alone its conditionality. Fourthly: The hadith of Amr bin Salama, which states: 'I used to lead them in prayer while wearing a cloak that was split open; when I prostrated, it would retract from me.' In one narration: 'My posterior would emerge, so a woman from the tribe said: Will you not cover the posterior of your reciter from us...' The hadith was recorded by Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, and Al-Nasa'i. So the truth is that covering the awrah in prayer is obligatory only, like in all other states, not a condition whose omission necessitates invalidity. Those who argue against conditionality supported their claim with weak jurisprudential arguments, such as saying: 'If covering were a condition in prayer, it would be exclusive to it and would require intention.' The first is refuted by faith (Iman), as it is a condition for prayer but not exclusive to it. The second by facing the Qiblah, as it does not require intention. The third by the inability to recite and glorify, for one prays silently [in that case].) End of his words, may Allah have mercy on him.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (2 - It [the awrah] for a man is the two private parts [As-Saw'atan] only, and the previous evidences apply to them). That the two private parts are awrah is agreed upon by scholars, as stated in (Maratib Al-Ijma) by Ibn Hazm. In Al-Majmu: (The linguists said: It was named 'Awrah' because of the ugliness of its appearance and for lowering the gaze from it; it is taken from 'Al-Awar', which is deficiency, defect, and ugliness. From it is the blindness of one eye (Awar Al-Ain) and the ugly word (Al-Kalima Al-Awra)). There is no doubt that this meaning is realized only in the two private parts. As for other than them, such as the thigh, navel, and knee, this meaning is not clearly realized in them. Therefore, scholars differed regarding them. The truth is what we mentioned due to what follows: (As for the thigh, knee, and navel, they are not of the forbidden awrah because the Prophet (peace be upon him) intentionally exposed them on various occasions in the presence of people. If they were forbidden awrah, he would not have exposed them. Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was lying down in his house, exposing his thighs, and Abu Bakr asked for permission to enter, so he permitted him while remaining in that state. Then Umar asked for permission, and he permitted him while remaining like that, and he spoke. Then Uthman asked for permission, so the Prophet (peace be upon him) sat up and arranged his clothes, then he entered and spoke. When he left, Aisha said to him: Abu Bakr entered and you did not stir, then Uthman entered and you sat up and arranged your clothes? He said: 'Should I not be shy of one from whom the angels are shy?') This is a generic authentic hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tahawi recorded it in (Mushkil Al-Athar): Narrated to us Yusuf bin Yazid: Narrated to us Hajjaj bin Ibrahim: Narrated to us Ismail bin Ja'far from Muhammad bin Abi Harmalah from Ata bin Yasar and Sulaiman bin Yasar and Abu Salamah bin Abdul Rahman from her. This is a Sahih chain; its men are all trustworthy and virtuous. Muslim recorded it in his (Sahih), as did Al-Bayhaqi, and likewise Al-Bukhari in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) via paths from Ismail bin Ja'far with similar wording, containing: (exposing his thighs or shanks), with doubt. The correct version in my view is Al-Tahawi's narration which has no doubt, for several reasons: First: Doubt is not knowledge, so it does not oppose what a trustworthy narrator has asserted with certainty. Second and Third: It has another path and corroborating evidences from Al-Tahawi's narration. As for the path, Ahmad said: Narrated to us Marwan: Informed us Ubaydullah bin Sayyar: I heard Aisha bint Talha mentioning from Aisha, Mother of the Believers: That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was sitting exposing his thighs, and Abu Bakr asked for permission, so he permitted him... the hadith is similar. This is a chain whose men are trustworthy men of the Six Books except Ubaydullah bin Sayyar. Al-Husayni said: (Unknown) as in (Al-Ta'jeel). Al-Husayni indicated that he narrated this hadith in (Musnad Ahmad), but Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: "I did not see it in the Musnad of Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) from Musnad Ahmad," so he said. But it is in the (Musnad) as Al-Husayni said, and we have specified the page for you. The hadith was referenced by Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath) and he remained silent on it, as will be mentioned. As for the corroborating evidences (Shawahid), they are three: First: From Hafsa bint Umar (may Allah be pleased with him), she said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was sitting one day with his garment placed between his thighs, and Abu Bakr came and asked for permission, so he permitted him... The hadith. Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Tahawi in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani) and in (Al-Mushkil), and Al-Bayhaqi via Ibn Jurayj who said: Informed me Abu Khalid from Abdullah bin Abi Saeed Al-Madini who said: Hafsa narrated to me... Then Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi recorded it via Shayban from Abu Al-Yafoor from Abdullah bin Abi Saeed Al-Muzani with it. Al-Bukhari also recorded it in (Al-Tarikh) from the two paths from this Abdullah. Its men are trustworthy except Abdullah bin Abi Saeed. Al-Husayni said: (It is not known who he is). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Ta'jeel) after mentioning the hadith from the two paths from him: (It is summarized from this that Abdullah bin Abi Saeed has two narrators, and he was not criticized, nor did he bring...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...a rejected text, so he is [acceptable] according to the rule of Ibn Hibban regarding trustworthy narrators, but I did not see him mentioned in the copy I have) - meaning from Ibn Hibban's Thiqat. In summary: It is a chain that is acceptable for corroboration. Al-Hafiz remained silent on it in (Al-Fath) where he said after citing Aisha's hadith via Muslim: (And it is in Ahmad with the wording: 'exposing his thighs' without hesitation, and he has a similar narration from the hadith of Hafsa. And Al-Tahawi and Al-Bayhaqi recorded it). His teacher Al-Haythami said in (Al-Majma): (Ahmad recorded it, and Al-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' and 'Al-Awsat', and Abu Ya'la significantly summarized, and its chain is Hasan). Second: From Anas bin Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) entered a garden of the Ansar, and there was a well in the garden. He sat on its edge and dangled his legs, and part of his thigh was exposed. He ordered me to sit at the door. Shortly after, Abu Bakr came, so I informed him, and he said: Permit him and give him glad tidings of Paradise... The hadith is similar. Al-Tahawi recorded it in (Al-Mushkil): Narrated to us Fahd bin Sulaiman: Narrated to us Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Yunus: Narrated to us Abu Muawiyah: Narrated to me Amr bin Muslim, owner of the Maqsura, from Anas with it. He said at the end: When the Prophet (peace be upon him) saw him, he covered his thigh. They said: Why, O Messenger of Allah, did you cover your thigh when Uthman came? He said: (Indeed, I am shy of one from whom the angels are shy).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a chain whose men are all trustworthy except this Amr bin Muslim. He listed him in (Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib) and mentioned that Abu Muawiyah Al-Darir and Abu Alqama Al-Farawi narrated from him, then he did not recount any criticism or endorsement regarding him. Third: From Abu Saeed Al-Khudri who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) stood in the markets with Bilal, then he dangled his legs into the well and exposed his thighs. Abu Bakr came asking for permission, so he said: O Bilal, permit him and give him glad tidings of Paradise... The hadith is similar. In it is that each of Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman dangled his legs into the well and exposed his thighs. Al-Tabarani recorded it in (Al-Awsat), and its men are deemed trustworthy as in (Al-Majma). He said in another place in it: (Its men are the men of the Sahih except Al-Tabarani's sheikh Ali bin Saeed, who is Hasan in hadith). It has a fourth corroborating evidence from the hadith of Ibn Abbas recorded by Al-Tabarani and Al-Bazzar, but in their chains is Al-Nadr Abu Amr, who is Matruk (abandoned) as Al-Haythami said. (And from Anas that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) raided Khybar, so we prayed the morning prayer there in the darkness. Then the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) rode, and Abu Talha rode, and I was riding behind Abu Talha. The Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him) galloped in the alley of Khybar, and my knee was touching the thigh of the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him). Then he lifted the Izar (lower garment) from his thigh until I could look at the whiteness of the thigh of the Prophet (peace be upon him)... The hadith). Recorded by Al-Bukhari, and from him Ibn Hizam, and Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad from...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Ismail bin Ulayyah who said: Narrated to us Abdul Aziz bin Suhayb from him with it. The context is from Al-Bukhari. The others said: 'And the Izar became uncovered' (Inhasara) instead of 'He uncovered' (Hasara). Al-Tabarani also narrated it like this as in (Al-Fath). Al-Nasa'i narrated it briefly mentioning the uncovering. The Zahiris went to this view—that the awrah is only the two private parts—and it is a narration from Ahmad and Malik as in (Al-Fath) from Al-Nawawi, and he mentioned it in (Sharh Muslim) from the companions of Malik. Abu Saeed Al-Istakhri from the Shafi'is held this view, and Al-Suyuti chose it as will come. Ibn Hazm said (It is the saying of Ibn Abi Dhi'b, Sufyan Al-Thawri, and Abu Sulaiman, and we take it). He said: (It is the saying of the majority of the Salaf). Then he narrated from Jubayr bin Al-Huwairith who said: I saw Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq standing on [Mount] Quzah saying: O people, enter the morning... and I was looking at his thigh which had become exposed. Al-Bukhari narrated from Musa bin Anas bin Malik mentioning the Day of Yamama, saying: Anas came to Thabit bin Qais bin Al-Shammas while he had uncovered his thighs and was applying Hanut—meaning perfume for death. And Ata bin Al-Saib said: I entered upon Abu Ja'far—he is Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Hussein bin Ali bin Abi Talib—while he was feverish and had exposed his thighs... and he mentioned the report.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Among the proofs for these people is the hadith of Aisha and this hadith of Anas. The deduction from the first is apparent because it says that he (peace be upon him) uncovered his thighs intentionally. As for the hadith of Anas, the direction of deduction is also apparent based on Al-Bukhari's narration: 'Then he lifted the Izar.' Its meaning is that he did that intentionally as well, unless the narration of others: 'And the Izar became uncovered' is used to explain this, for their apparent meaning is that the Izar became uncovered by itself. However, Al-Hafiz said: (It is possible to deduce that the thigh is not awrah from the aspect of his continuing in that state, because even if its occurrence was permissible without intent, if it were awrah, he would not have been affirmed in that state due to the status of his infallibility (peace be upon him). And if it were assumed that this happened to demonstrate legislation for the non-choosing person, it would be possible, but it is questionable because clarification would have been required immediately after, as in the case of forgetfulness in prayer. Its context in Abu Awana and Al-Jawzaqi via Abdul Warith from Abdul Aziz is apparent in the continuation of that, and its wording is: 'So the Messenger of Allah galloped in the alley of Khybar, and my knee was touching the thigh of the Prophet of Allah (peace be upon him), and I could see the whiteness of his thighs'). He said: (The apparent meaning of Anas's statement implies that the touching was without a barrier, and touching the awrah without a barrier is not permissible) (1). Ibn Hazm said: (So it is correct that the thigh is not awrah. If it were awrah, Allah Almighty would not have uncovered it from His Messenger (peace be upon him), the purified and infallible from the people, in the state of Prophethood and Messengership, nor would Anas bin Malik or others have seen it, while He the Exalted had protected him from uncovering the awrah during childhood...
foot_note: 1. (1) Therefore, Al-Suyuti said in his footnote on Al-Nasa'i (2/92) - commenting on this statement of Anas -: This is evidence for those who say: The thigh is not awrah. And it is the chosen view.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...and before Prophethood). Then he narrated via Muslim the hadith of Jabir mentioned previously which says: 'He was not seen naked after that.' Abu Hanifa and Al-Shafi'i held that the thigh is awrah and used the hadith: (The thigh is awrah) as proof. They responded to Aisha's hadith with what is in Muslim's narration regarding the doubt whether the exposed part was the thigh or the shank. In Al-Majmu it says: (There is no indication in it that the thigh is not awrah because there is doubt about what was exposed). I say: We have explained that all other narrations in this story confirm with certainty that what was exposed was the thigh, so Muslim's narration must be interpreted based on them. Then Al-Nawawi said: (Our companions said: Even if certainty of thigh exposure were valid, we would interpret it to mean uncovering some of his garments, not all. They said: Also, it is a specific incident concerning a specific person, so it has no generality and is no proof). I say: The proof in it is from the aspect that this action is from our Prophet (peace be upon him) who is our example and model in everything except what is excluded by evidence, due to His saying: {Indeed, in the Messenger of Allah you have a good example} [Al-Ahzab / 21]. And the evidence for specification is not valid as will come, so the evidence of following him (peace be upon him) in this regard remains general and inclusive for his Ummah, thus proving the requirement. As for interpreting it as uncovering some of his garments, it is of no use at all, because it implies admitting that he uncovered some of his thigh. If it were awrah, how could uncovering...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...some of it be permissible? If Al-Nawawi meant by that that uncovering part of it is permissible unlike the whole, then he contradicted his own school, where he said: (If any part of the worshiper's awrah is exposed, his prayer is not valid, whether the exposed part is large or small, even if it is the slightest part, and this applies equally to men and women...) etc. They answered the hadith of Anas by saying that the Izar became uncovered by itself from his thigh (peace be upon him) without his intent, as Muslim's narration 'Inhasara' (became uncovered) implies. However, the hadith indicates the permissibility of uncovering from another perspective, which is his (peace be upon him) remaining in that state of exposure as previously mentioned from Al-Hafiz. Likewise, Anas's statement: 'And I could see the whiteness of his thighs' indicates that looking at the thigh was not forbidden to them; otherwise, Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) would not have looked at it. Since the matter is so, it indicates that it is not awrah, which is the desired conclusion. Thus, it is established by what we mentioned that all their objections to the two hadiths are invalid upon investigation. Furthermore, other hadiths have come in this chapter, though they are lesser than these two in indicating the requirement. Among them is the hadith of Abu Al-Aliyah Al-Bara who said: Abdullah bin Al-Samit struck my thigh and said: I asked Abu Dharr, and he struck my thigh just as I struck your thigh, and said: I asked the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) just as you asked me, and he struck my thigh just as I struck your thigh, and said: (Pray the prayer at its time, and if the prayer with them catches you, then pray, and do not say: I have already prayed so I will not pray). Recorded by Al-Bukhari in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) and Muslim. From him...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Ibn Hazm said: If the thigh were awrah, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) would not have touched it from Abu Dharr at all with his holy hand. And if the thigh were awrah to Abu Dharr, he would not have struck it with his hand, nor would Abdullah bin Al-Samit and Abu Al-Aliyah - so he said. A Muslim does not consider it lawful to strike the penis of a person with his hand over clothes, nor the ring of a person's anus over clothes, nor the body of a foreign woman over clothes at all. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade retaliation (Qawad) from a kick (Kas'ah), which is striking the buttocks over clothes with the bottom of the foot, and said: (Leave them, for they are foul). Among them is the hadith of Zaid bin Thabit that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) dictated to him: {Not equal are those believers sitting [at home] and those who strive in the cause of Allah} [An-Nisa / 95]. He said: Ibn Umm Maktum came while he was dictating it to me and said: O Messenger of Allah, if I were able to strive, I would have striven - and he was a blind man. So Allah blessed and exalted sent down revelation to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) while his thigh was on my thigh, and it became so heavy on me that I feared my thigh would be crushed. Then it was lifted from him, and Allah Almighty revealed: {except those with a disability}. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Tirmidhi who said: (Hasan Sahih), and Ahmad from Salih bin Kaysan from Ibn Shihab who said: Sahl bin Sa'd narrated to me from Marwan bin Al-Hakam from him. Al-Tahawi also narrated it in (Al-Mushkil) from Salih.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And Abdul Rahman bin Ishaq followed him from Ibn Shihab; recorded by Al-Nasa'i and Al-Tabari as in (Al-Fath). Ma'mar contradicted them saying: From Al-Zuhri from Qabisah bin Dhu'ayb from Zaid bin Thabit; recorded by Ahmad. Perhaps Al-Zuhri has two chains for it. And Allah knows best. The hadith has another path from him. Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi, and Al-Hakim who authenticated it, and Al-Dhahabi agreed, and Ahmad from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad from his father from Kharijah bin Zaid from Zaid bin Thabit with it. Al-Bukhari suspended (Mu'allaq) this hadith in the chapter 'What is mentioned regarding the thigh', and he also suspended the aforementioned hadith of Anas in it, indicating thereby that the thigh is not awrah. Therefore, Sheikh Muhammad Anwar Al-Kashmiri said in (Faidh Al-Bari): (What appears from the action of the author [Al-Bukhari] may Allah be pleased with him is that he leaned towards the school of Malik may Allah be pleased with him, and interpreted the view of the Hanafis as precaution). As for the hadith: (The thigh is awrah), it is a weak hadith. Al-Bukhari indicated its weakness in his (Sahih) saying: It is mentioned from Ibn Abbas, Jarhad, and Muhammad bin Jahsh from the Prophet (peace be upon him): (The thigh is awrah). It is necessary here to speak extensively on the defects of this hadith so the reader may verify...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...that it is not strong enough to oppose those hadiths indicating that the thigh is not awrah. So we say: First: The hadith of Ibn Abbas: Narrated by Abu Yahya Al-Qattat from Mujahid from him, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (The thigh is awrah). Its defect is this Abu Yahya; his name is most famously Dinar, and he is weak as stated by Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla) and Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath). Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Tahawi in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani), Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, all from him. Second: The hadith of Jarhad: Its defect is Jahalah (being unknown) and Idtirab (disorder/inconsistency) leading to a lack of trust in it. Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil), Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad recorded it via Malik from Abu Al-Nadr from Zur'ah bin Abdul Rahman bin Jarhad from his father from Jarhad. Al-Darimi and Al-Tahawi in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani) recorded it via Malik from Abu Al-Nadr from Zur'ah bin Abdul Rahman from his father raised (Marfu) to the Prophet. Thus making it from the Musnad of Abdul Rahman bin Jarhad. Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Hakim, and Ahmad recorded it via Sufyan bin Uyaynah from Abu Al-Nadr from Zur'ah bin Muslim bin Jarhad from his grandfather from Jarhad.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Daraqutni recorded it from Sufyan with it, except he added to it saying: From Zur'ah bin Muslim from his father from his grandfather. So there was disagreement about it upon Sufyan just as there was disagreement upon Malik. These two differed; Malik says: Zur'ah bin Abdul Rahman bin Jarhad, and Sufyan says: Zur'ah bin Muslim bin Jarhad. Abu Al-Zinad contradicted them saying: From his uncle Zur'ah bin Abdullah bin Jarhad from his grandfather Jarhad. So he named him Zur'ah bin Abdullah. Al-Tahawi recorded it in (Al-Mushkil) and in (Al-Sharh) from... (1) from him. And Al-Tirmidhi and Ahmad narrated it from Ma'mar saying: From Abu Al-Zinad: Ibn Jarhad informed me from his father with it. In a narration of Ahmad and Al-Daraqutni from Sufyan from Abu Al-Zinad (2). Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil narrated it from Abdullah bin Jarhad from his father. Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Tahawi in them, and Ahmad from Al-Hasan bin Salih from him. Al-Tahawi added in a narration of his saying: From Abdullah bin Muslim bin Jarhad from his father that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said... and he mentioned it. Thus he made it from the Musnad of Muslim bin Jarhad.
foot_note:
1. (1) Not clear in the original. (Publisher) 
2. He said: Informed me Abu Jarhad from Jarhad.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a severe disorder (Idtirab) due to which the researcher cannot be guided to prefer one narration over another. This necessitates the weakness of the hadith because it indicates it was not preserved properly, as scholars mentioned in (Mustalah Al-Hadith). Al-Hafiz said in (Sharh Al-Bukhari): (The author weakened it in 'Al-Tarikh' due to the disorder in its chain, and I have mentioned many of its paths in 'Taghliq Al-Ta'liq'). I say: Ibn Al-Qattan also weakened it. In (Nasb Al-Rayah) by Al-Zayla'i, Ibn Al-Qattan said: (The hadith of Jarhad has two defects: Disorder leading to the loss of trust in it. That is because they differ regarding it; some say Zur'ah bin Abdul Rahman, some say Zur'ah bin Abdullah, and some say Zur'ah bin Muslim. Then among these, some say: From his father from the Prophet (peace be upon him), and some say: From his father from Jarhad from the Prophet (peace be upon him), and some say: Zur'ah from the family of Jarhad from Jarhad from the Prophet (peace be upon him). The second defect: That Zur'ah and his father are not known in status nor famous in narration). From this, you know that Al-Hakim's statement: (It is a hadith with a Sahih chain) is incorrect, even if Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Third: The hadith of Muhammad bin Jahsh. Abu Kathir, the client of Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Jahsh, narrated it raised (Marfu) with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Its defect is this Abu Kathir, for he is unknown (Majhul) as Ibn Hazm said. Al-Hafiz said: (I did not find any explicit modification/authentication for him). Al-Tahawi recorded it in (Al-Sharh) and (Al-Mushkil), as did Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, and also Al-Bukhari in (Al-Tarikh) as in (Al-Fath). It is strange that Al-Bayhaqi said - after citing these three hadiths with their chains -: (These are Sahih chains that can be used as proof), even though it is not hidden from a beginner in this science - let alone someone like Al-Bayhaqi - that none of them is authentic as we have explained. Therefore, Ibn Al-Turkmani critiqued him in (Al-Jawhar Al-Naqi) with arguments similar to the defects we mentioned, then said: (Ibn Al-Salah mentioned that the three fall short of authenticity). Fourth: The hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him). Ibn Jurayj narrated it from Habib bin Abi Thabit from Asim bin Damrah from him. Recorded by Ibn Majah in Funerals, Chapter: What came regarding washing the deceased in his (Sunan) - from Bishr bin Adam; and Al-Hakim from Al-Harith bin Usama; and Al-Bayhaqi from Muhammad bin Sa'd Al-Awfi; all three of them from Ruh bin Ubadah. And Al-Tahawi in (Sharh Al-Athar) and (Al-Mushkil) from Yahya bin Saeed; and Al-Daraqutni from Abdul Majid bin Abdul Aziz bin Abi Rawad; all three from Ibn Jurayj with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The defect of this chain is the disconnection (Inqita) between Ibn Jurayj and Habib bin Abi Thabit on one side, and between this Habib and Asim bin Damrah on the other side. Ibn Jurayj and Ibn Abi Thabit are known for Tadlis (obfuscation in transmission) despite their high status. Ibn Jurayj explicitly stated in a narration from him that he heard it through an intermediary from Ibn Abi Thabit. Abu Dawood narrated it, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi, via Hajjaj from Ibn Jurayj who said: I was informed from Habib bin Abi Thabit from Asim with it. Therefore, Abu Hatim said in (Al-Ilal): (Ibn Jurayj did not hear this hadith from Habib; it is from the hadith of Amr bin Khalid Al-Wasiti, and a narration for Habib from Asim is not established). Ibn Ma'in said the same as in (Al-Talkhis), that Habib did not hear it from Asim and that there is a man between them who is not trustworthy. Al-Bazzar clarified that the intermediary between them is Amr bin Khalid Al-Wasiti. I say: It seems it was for this reason that Abu Dawood said after citing the hadith: (This hadith contains Nakara [deniability/strangeness]). Then Al-Hafiz said: (In the additions of the Musnad, and in Al-Daraqutni and Musnad Al-Haitham bin Kulayb, there is a declaration by Ibn Jurayj of Habib informing him, which is an illusion (Wahm) in my critique, and I have discussed it in the dictation on the hadiths of Mukhtasar Ibn Al-Hajib). I say: We will clarify the illusion indicated by Al-Hafiz, so we say:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Daraqutni recorded it via Ahmad bin Mansour bin Rashid: Narrated to us Ruh bin Ubadah: Narrated to us Ibn Jurayj: Informed me (Akhbarani) Habib bin Abi Thabit from Asim with it. This is a Shadh (anomalous) narration, for Ahmad bin Mansour contradicted all the trustworthy narrators who reported it from Ruh bin Ubadah. They all said: From Ruh: Narrated to us Ibn Jurayj from Habib, as previously mentioned. They did not explicitly state hearing (Sama'). The narration of these people takes precedence over this Shadh narration of Ahmad bin Mansour, especially since he is not known for preservation and precision in narration; the most that was said of him is that he is Saduq (truthful) as in (Tarikh Baghdad) from Abu Hatim, and a truthful person may err. Abdullah, son of Imam Ahmad, recorded it in his father's Musnad saying: Narrated to me Ubaydullah bin Umar Al-Qawariri: Narrated to me Yazid Abu Khalid Al-Baysari Al-Qurashi: Narrated to us Ibn Jurayj: Informed me Habib bin Abi Thabit from Asim with it. This is a weak chain from Ibn Jurayj, for this Abu Khalid - Ibn Hazm said: (It is not known who he is). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Ta'jeel): (He is unknown). As for Al-Dhahabi's statement in (Al-Mizan): (Ibn Adi listed him and let him pass, saying: He is not Munkar in hadith), it is not an explicit authentication.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is indicated by the fact that Al-Hafiz quoted this statement of Al-Dhahabi in (Al-Lisan) despite saying in (Al-Ta'jeel): (He is unknown) as preceded. So there is no contradiction between the two statements then. Even if we admitted that Ibn Jurayj's explicit statement of hearing from Habib is established, the hadith would still not be established thereby because the other defect still remains, which is the disconnection between Habib and Asim as previously quoted from the two Hafizs, Ibn Ma'in and Abu Hatim. Whether the intermediary between them is truly Amr bin Khalid Al-Wasiti or not, the hadith is disconnected (Munqati') and incorrect due to the ignorance of the intermediary between them. As for the objection of Professor Ahmad Muhammad Shakir in his commentary on the Musnad that the meeting between them is established (so how can we claim he didn't hear this hadith from him), this would only be valid if Habib bin Abi Thabit were not a Mudallis (one who obfuscates transmission). But since he is known for Tadlis, mere contemporaneity and established meeting are not sufficient; rather, the Mudallis must explicitly state his hearing from the one he narrated from for his narration to be valid and accepted. This is a matter agreed upon among scholars and is not hidden from the referenced Professor. I do not know how he went there to authenticate the connection based on mere contemporaneity despite his knowledge that it is conditional for that that the narrator not be a Mudallis (refer to the introduction of Sahih Muslim). Perhaps he did not recall at the time of writing that this Habib is a Mudallis, and Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib) that he is: (Trustworthy, a jurist, majestic, but was frequent in Irsaal and Tadlis).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Thus, the correctness of the statement of those who defected the hadith due to disconnection is established, and that it is weak and not suitable to be used as proof, let alone to oppose those authentic hadiths mentioned previously in the (Two Sahihs) and others. (Note): We specified the chapter in which Ibn Majah recorded the hadith in his (Sunan) contrary to our habit in what we write of Takhrij, because I saw the previously mentioned Professor saying in the Takhrij of the hadith: (It was attributed in 'Al-Muntaqa' and 'Dhakha'ir Al-Mawarith' and by Al-Mundhiri as quoted by the commentator of Abu Dawood and Ibn Hajar in Al-Talkhis to Ibn Majah; indeed, the author of 'Al-Dhakha'ir' specified that it is in the Book of Funerals, but I did not find it after a long search). In this chapter there is also a narration from Amr bin Shu'ayb from his father from his grandfather. And it will come shortly. (And from Abu Musa that the Prophet (peace be upon him) was sitting in a place where there was water and had uncovered his knees or his knee. When Uthman entered, he covered them). Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Al-Tabarani, and Al-Bayhaqi via Sulaiman bin Harb: Narrated to us Hammad bin Zaid: Narrated to me Ali bin Al-Hakam and Asim Al-Ahwal: That they heard Abu Uthman narrating from Abu Musa with it. In the chapter, there are other hadiths: Among them from Abu Darda who said: I was sitting with the Prophet (peace be upon him) when Abu Bakr approached holding the hem of his garment so that his knees were exposed. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: (Your companion has had an adventure/dispute). He greeted and said: O Messenger of Allah, there was something between me and Ibn Al-Khattab, so I hastened against him then regretted it, so I asked him to forgive me but he refused, so I came to you. He said: (May Allah forgive you, O Abu Bakr (three times)). Then Umar regretted and came to Abu Bakr's house and asked: Is Abu Bakr there? They said: No. So he came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and greeted him, and the face of the Prophet (peace be upon him) began to change [in anger] until Abu Bakr felt fear, so he knelt on his knees and said: O Messenger of Allah, by Allah, I was more unjust (twice). The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: (Allah sent me to you and you said: You lied, but Abu Bakr said: He spoke the truth, and he supported me with himself and his wealth. Will you then leave my companion for me? (twice)). He was not harmed after that. Recorded by Al-Bukhari and Al-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil) from him. And among them from Amr bin Al-Sharid from his father that the Prophet (peace be upon him) followed a man from Thaqif until he hurried after him and grabbed his garment saying: (Raise your Izar). The man uncovered his knees and said: O Messenger of Allah, I am Ahnaf (Hanaf: turning of the foot with toes towards the other foot) (and my knees knock together). The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (All of Allah's creation is beautiful). He said: That man was never seen except with his Izar to the middle of his shanks until he died. Recorded by Ahmad who said: Narrated to us Ruh: Narrated to us Zakariya bin Ishaq: Narrated to us Ibrahim bin Maysarah: That he heard Amr bin Al-Sharid with it. And Al-Tahawi recorded it in (Al-Mushkil): Narrated to us Abu Umayyah: Narrated to us Ruh bin Ubadah with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the two Sheikhs. (Benefit): The name of the man, the owner of the Izar, is Amr bin Zurara as in a narration by Al-Tabarani from the hadith of Abu Umamah. He narrated it with chains from him, and the men of one of them are trustworthy as in (Al-Majma). Ahmad narrated it from this Amr himself but named him Amr bin So-and-so Al-Ansari. Its chain is Sahih, its men are men of the Six Books except Al-Walid bin Salman, who is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Haythami said: (And its men are trustworthy). In the chapter from Ali bin Abi Talib that Hamza (may Allah be pleased with him) raised his gaze to the knees of the Prophet (peace be upon him) then raised his gaze to his navel. And it will come in full shortly, God willing. In these hadiths is [evidence] that the knee is not awrah due to two matters: First: That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) uncovered it without necessity. Al-Shawkani's statement: (Using the hadith as proof that the knee is not awrah is not complete because the uncovering was for the excuse of entering the water, and also covering it from Uthman implies it is awrah, and even if covering could be explained by other reasons, the utmost is probability) is rejected.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: As for the first: Because the hadith states that he (peace and blessings be upon him) was sitting in a place with water and uncovered his knees. This means he (peace be upon him) was sitting dangling his legs in the water. Therefore, what excuse is there for uncovering the knees if they were awrah? Was the Prophet (peace be upon him) not able to suffice with dangling the shanks without uncovering the awrah? What guides you to the meaning I went to is that Imam Ahmad recorded the hadith from another path from Abu Musa: That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was in a garden in Medina on the Quff of the well (meaning: the ledge built around it) dangling his legs, and Abu Bakr knocked on the door... The hadith. Muslim narrated it similarly from a third path with the wording: He sat in the middle of its ledge and uncovered his shanks and dangled them into the well. There is no contradiction between this narration and Al-Bukhari's narration explicitly mentioning uncovering the knee, because it contains an addition from a trustworthy narrator and is accepted by agreement. Just as there is no contradiction between this narration of Al-Bukhari and the narration of Aisha and others explicitly mentioning uncovering the thigh for the same reason. This is assuming the story is one. But if they are multiple, there is no issue. As for the second: Covering it from Uthman was a special treatment from him (peace be upon him) for him (Uthman) due to his intense shyness, just as he (peace be upon him) covered his thighs from him as previously mentioned. That does not indicate at all that he covered it only because it is awrah. How could that be when he (peace and blessings be upon him) uncovered it in front of others besides Uthman, as is clear in the hadith of Aisha and others, and as is apparent...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...from this hadith of Abu Musa, for he narrates the story as an eyewitness; meaning that he (peace be upon him) did not cover it from Abu Musa as he covered it from Uthman. This is what appeared from the critique of Al-Shawkani's words. Even if we assume his words are correct, the evidence that the knee is not awrah is the second matter: That is Abu Bakr uncovering his knees, as well as Amr bin Zurara in his presence (peace be upon him), and he did not rebuke them. If it were awrah, he (peace be upon him) would have rebuked that, just as he rebuked Jarhad Al-Aslami when he passed by him while his thigh was exposed, saying: (peace be upon him): (Cover your thigh for the thigh is awrah) - if the hadith were authentic, but it is not authentic as previously explained in detail. So his silence (peace be upon him) regarding that indicates that the knee is not awrah. Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in the explanation of Abu Darda's hadith: (In it is that the knee is not awrah). There is a third proof: That Hamza (may Allah be pleased with him) raised his gaze to the knee of the Prophet (peace be upon him). In this—in addition to him (peace be upon him) uncovering it—is someone else looking at his knee. If it were awrah, Hamza nor anyone else would have been free to look at it, as Ibn Hazm said similarly regarding the navel as will come. So the truth is that these [proofs] stand for the knee not being awrah. This was stated by Al-Shafi'i. Al-Nawawi said: (It is the famous view of our school, and Malik and a group said it, and it is a narration from Ahmad. Abu Hanifa and Ata said: It is awrah).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a weak opinion contradicting those authentic hadiths. Al-Tahawi opposed them with what he recorded in (Al-Mushkil): Narrated to us Ali bin Abi Shaybah: Narrated to us Yazid bin Harun: Narrated to us Hammad bin Salamah from Hakim Al-Athram from Abu Tamimah Al-Hujaymi: I heard Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari saying: I will not know of anyone who looked at a slave girl except what is above her navel and below her knee, I will not know of anyone who did it except that I punished him (1). Abu Ja'far said: (So based on what we mentioned, it is permissible to oppose with this hadith the hadiths we mentioned before it that contradict it). He indicated by his saying: (based on what we mentioned) to his words introducing this hadith, which is: (And we found that Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari has narrated words mixed with a threat to those who oppose him, which cannot be said by mere opinion, because a threat cannot be regarding something said by opinion where it is possible for someone else to say the opposite of this meaning). As you see, he claims that the hadith, even if it is suspended (Mawquf), has the ruling of being raised (Marfu) because of the threat in it which—according to him—cannot be said by mere opinion. This is not necessarily true in rulings, for a threat is permissible regarding a matter one has reached through his Ijtihad (independent reasoning), even if he might possibly be mistaken in it.
foot_note: 1. (1) See the Sheikh's comment on this Athar two pages later. (Publisher)

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In summary, using this hadith as proof that the knee is awrah is incorrect for several reasons: First: It is Mawquf (stopped at the companion). Second: It contradicts what is more authentic than it. Third: It is concerning a slave girl, so it is more specific than the claim. They differed regarding the awrah of a slave girl on many opinions that may be mentioned later; the most correct evidence is that she is like a free woman, with no difference between them. Al-Tahawi's action here in analogizing a free man and others to a slave girl regarding the knee being awrah completely resembles Al-Nawawi's analogy of a man to a woman regarding the invalidity of prayer with exposed awrah, and the rebuttal to it has passed sufficiently. Perhaps the author of (Al-Hidayah) and other jurists did not rely on Abu Musa's hadith because of the matters we mentioned, but rather argued with the hadith: (The knee is awrah). This, if authentic, would be clear evidence for them, but it is not authentic; rather, it is agreed upon to be weak. Al-Daraqutni recorded it via Al-Nadr bin Mansour Al-Fazari: Informed us Abu Al-Janub - his name is Uqba bin Alqama - said: I heard Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) saying... so he mentioned it raised (Marfu). Al-Zayla'i said in (Nasb Al-Rayah): (Our Sheikh Al-Dhahabi said in his 'Mizan': Al-Nadr bin Mansour is flimsy (Wah). Ibn Hibban said: He is not used as proof. And this Uqba bin Alqama was weakened by Al-Daraqutni and Abu Hatim Al-Razi. The author repeated it in 'Al-Karahiyah' from Abu Huraira, but we did not find it from him. In 'Al-Imam', Abu Hatim Al-Razi said: Uqba is weak in hadith, and Al-Nadr bin Mansour is unknown).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Zayla'i also said in the Takhrij of the hadiths of Karahiyah (I say: It is strange (Gharib) from the hadith of Abu Huraira, and it was presented from the hadith of Ali in Al-Daraqutni, and it contains weakness). We missed discussing the chain of Abu Musa's hadith, so we say: Its men are all trustworthy men of the Sahih except Ali bin Shaybah and Hakim Al-Athram. As for the first, he is Ali bin Shaybah bin Al-Salt bin Asfour Abu Al-Hasan Al-Sadusi, their client, and he represents Yaqub bin Shaybah. He was Basran, lived in Baghdad for a while, then moved to Egypt and lived there. Abdul Aziz bin Ahmad Al-Ghafiqi and others from the Egyptians narrated upright hadiths from him. He died in the year 272. Thus in Tarikh Baghdad with modification. As for the other, Al-Nasa'i said: (There is no harm in him), and Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat). In (Al-Taqrib): (He has leniency). (And from Ali bin Abi Talib may Allah be pleased with him in a hadith of his, saying: Then Hamza looked at the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), then raised his gaze and looked at his knees, then raised his gaze and looked at his navel... The hadith). Recorded by Al-Bukhari and Muslim, and from him Ibn Hazm, and Al-Tahawi in...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...(Al-Mushkil) Yunus from Al-Zuhri who said: Ali bin Al-Hussein informed me that Hussein bin Ali (peace be upon them) informed him that Ali said: I had a she-camel from my share of the spoils on the Day of Badr, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) had given me a she-camel from the Khums. When I wanted to consummate the marriage with Fatima, daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), I agreed with a goldsmith from Bani Qaynuqa to travel with me so we could bring Idhkhir (lemon grass) which I wanted to sell to the goldsmiths and use [the money] for the wedding feast. While I was gathering equipment for my she-camel, such as saddles, sacks, and ropes, and my two she-camels were kneeling next to the room of a man from the Ansar, I returned after collecting what I collected, and found my two she-camels with their humps cut off and their flanks ripped open and their livers taken. I could not control my eyes [from tears] when I saw that sight of them. I said: Who did this? He said: Hamza bin Abdul Muttalib did it, and he is in this house among drinkers from the Ansar. I went until I entered upon the Prophet (peace be upon him) and Zaid bin Harithah was with him. The Prophet (peace be upon him) recognized in my face what I had encountered. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: What is wrong with you? I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have never seen the like of today; Hamza attacked my she-camels, cut off their humps, and ripped open their flanks, and there he is in a house with drinkers. The Prophet (peace be upon him) called for his cloak and put it on, then proceeded walking, and I and Zaid bin Harithah followed him until he came to the house where Hamza was. He asked for permission, and they permitted them. There were drinkers. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) began blaming Hamza for what he did. Hamza was intoxicated, his eyes red. Hamza looked at the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), then raised his gaze and looked at his knees, then raised his gaze and looked at his navel, then raised his gaze and looked at his face. Then Hamza said: Are you anything but...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...slaves to my father? The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) realized that he was intoxicated, so the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) retreated backwards on his heels, and we went out with him. This is the wording of Al-Bukhari. The hadith clearly indicates that the navel is not awrah because the Messenger uncovered it and because someone else looked at it. Ibn Hazm said: (If the navel were awrah, Allah would not have allowed Hamza or anyone else to look at it). Abu Hanifa and Al-Shafi'i held that the navel is not awrah, and this is the famous view of his companions. Some claimed consensus on that, but there is questionable validity in that. In the chapter there are other hadiths: Among them from Umair bin Ishaq who said: I was with Al-Hussein bin Ali when Abu Huraira met him and said: Come close to me so I may kiss from you where I saw the Messenger of Allah kissing you. So he lifted his garment and he kissed his navel. Recorded by Al-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil) via Uthman bin Umar, and Al-Bayhaqi via Yahya bin Yahya: Informed us Azhar Al-Samman, and Ahmad via Ismail and via Muhammad bin Abi Adi, and Ibn Abi Shaybah in his (Musnad) and via him Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) as in (Nasb Al-Rayah) via Sharik; all four of them from Ibn Awn from him with it. The context is for the first of them.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ismail differed in his wording, narrating it as: Uncover your belly so I may kiss where I saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) kissing. He said: So he uncovered his belly and he kissed it. Perhaps there is no difference between this narration of Ismail and the narration of the others, because this one is general and the other is detailed, and the detailed governs the general. Ismail's narration: 'I saw the Messenger of Allah kissing him' indicates this. The other narration clarified that the place of kissing is the navel. The chain of the hadith is Hasan; its men are trustworthy men of the Six Books except this Umair. In (Al-Mizan) it says: He was trusted by whoever narrated from him except Ibn Awn. Yahya bin Ma'in said: (His hadith is worth nothing, but his hadith is written). This is Abbas's narration from him. As for Uthman, he narrated from Yahya that he is trustworthy. Al-Nasa'i and others said: (There is no harm in him). He narrated from Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad, Amr bin Al-Aas, and a group. Yahya bin Yahya was contradicted regarding Azhar, for Al-Khadir bin Aban Al-Hashimi narrated it: Narrated to us Azhar bin Sa'd Al-Samman: Narrated to us Ibn Awn from Muhammad from Abu Huraira similar to Ismail's narration. Al-Hakim recorded it: Narrated to us Abu Al-Abbas Muhammad bin Yaqub: Narrated to us Al-Khadir bin Aban Al-Hashimi with it. And he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Correct according to the condition of the two Sheikhs), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. This is something to be amazed at, for Al-Khadir bin Aban, besides not being among the sheikhs of the two Sheikhs nor their men, is weak; both Al-Hakim and Al-Dhahabi weakened him. He said in his biography in (Al-Mizan): (Al-Hakim and others weakened him. He is Kufan from the clients of Bani Hashim, and he heard Azhar Al-Samman... Al-Daraqutni spoke against him). So the correct version is the narration of Yahya bin Yahya from Azhar from Ibn Awn from Umair as is the narration of the majority from Ibn Awn. This Yahya is Al-Nisaburi, a trustworthy Hafiz. However, Abu Salamah—who is Musa bin Ismail—followed Al-Khadir bin Aban from Azhar bin Sa'd Al-Samman from Ibn Awn from Muhammad. He said: Narrated to us Hammad bin Salamah: Informed us Ibn Awn from Muhammad—he is Ibn Sirin—with it with the wording: So he kissed his navel. Al-Bayhaqi recorded it then said: Thus he said from Hammad. Others said from Hammad and from Ibn Awn from Abu Muhammad, who is Umair bin Ishaq. Among them is from Abu Mahdura in the hadith of Adhan: That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) placed his hand on the forelock of Abu Mahdura then passed it over his face, then between his nipples, then on his hand, then the hand of the Messenger of Allah reached the navel of Abu Mahdura.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Recorded by Al-Tahawi in (Al-Mushkil) and likewise Ibn Majah, Al-Daraqutni, and Ahmad via Ibn Jurayj: Informed me Abdul Aziz bin Abdul Malik bin Abi Mahdura that Abdullah bin Muhayriz informed him from him. They recorded it at length, as did Al-Nasa'i, except he does not have the witness point from it. Its wording preceded in the fourth issue of Adhan. This Abdul Aziz is acceptable (Maqbul). (Note: The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, retracted his mentioned choice regarding the matter of the awrah. Refer, for example, to Tamam Al-Minnah...). (3 - However, a measure exceeding the covering of awrah is appropriate for him in prayer due to the generality of His saying: {Take your adornment at every masjid}. Sheikh Al-Islam said in Al-Ikhtiyarat (4/24): (And Allah Almighty commanded a measure exceeding the covering of awrah in prayer, saying {Take your adornment at every masjid}, linking the command to the name of adornment, not to covering the awrah, to indicate that the servant should wear his finest and most beautiful clothes in prayer). His student Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in the Tafsir of the mentioned verse: (For this verse and what has been narrated in its meaning from the Sunnah, it is recommended to beautify oneself for prayer, especially on Friday and the Day of Eid, and perfume because it is part of adornment, and the Siwak because it is part of its completion. Among the best clothing is white. Then he mentioned the hadith regarding the command for white clothes, and perhaps it will come). Then he said: (Al-Tabarani narrated with a Sahih chain from Qatada from Muhammad bin Sirin that Tamim...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Al-Dari bought a cloak for a thousand and used to pray in it). (The Prophet (peace be upon him) emphasized that and clarified it, forbidding a man to pray in trousers while not having a Rida [upper garment] on him). This hadith was recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi, and Al-Hakim, and from him Al-Bayhaqi from Abu Al-Munib from Abdullah bin Buraydah from his father who said: (The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade a man to pray in a blanket without wrapping it [crosswise], and forbade a man to pray in trousers...) etc. This is a Hasan chain. As for Al-Hakim's statement - and likewise Al-Dhahabi - that it is: (Correct according to the condition of the two Sheikhs), it is one of their illusions, for this Abu Al-Munib - his name is Ubaydullah bin Abdullah Al-Ataki - is not among the men of the two Sheikhs. Moreover, he is spoken against. Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Ibn Ma'in and others declared him trustworthy. Al-Bukhari said: He has Munkar [denounced] reports. Abu Hatim began criticizing Al-Bukhari for mentioning Abu Al-Munib in the weak narrators and said: He is Salih [passable] in hadith. Ibn Hibban said: He is unique in narrating inverted reports from trustworthy narrators. Al-Nasa'i said: Weak. Ibn Adi said: In my view, there is no harm in him). I say: It is summarized for me from the sum of their statements about him that he is Hasan in hadith as long as he does not narrate Munkar or contradict others. In Al-Taqrib it says regarding him:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Truthful but errs). (Al-Rida): It says in (Al-Nihayah): (It is the garment or cloak that a person places on his shoulders and between his shoulder blades over his clothes). In (Al-Munjid): (Al-Rida: What is worn over clothes like an Abaya and Jubbah). (And that is because of what is in it of abandoning the adornment commanded, as he (peace be upon him) said: (If one of you prays, let him wear his two garments, for Allah is more deserving that one adorns oneself for Him...) The hadith). The completion of the hadith is: (If he does not have two garments, let him wrap it around his waist (Itzar) when he prays, and let not one of you wrap himself in his prayer like the wrapping of the Jews). It is from the hadith of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him). Al-Tahawi recorded it in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani) via Hafs bin Maysarah from Musa bin Uqba from Nafi from him who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said. Al-Bayhaqi recorded it via Anas bin Ayyash from Musa with it except he said: And Nafi did not see it except from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) who said... so he mentioned it. This is a Sahih chain, its men are men of the Six Books. Then Al-Tahawi and Ahmad recorded it via Ibn Jurayj who said: Informed me...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Nafi that Ibn Umar clothed him while he was a boy, then he entered the mosque and found him praying while wrapping himself [in one cloth]. He said: Do you not have two garments? He said: Yes. He said: Do you think if I sent you to [do something] behind the house, would you wear them? He said: Yes. He said: Is Allah more deserving that you adorn yourself for Him or people? Nafi said: Rather Allah. So he informed him from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) or from Umar (may Allah be pleased with him). Nafi said: I became certain that it is from one of them, and I do not see it except from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). He said: (Let not one of you wrap himself in prayer like the wrapping of the Jews. Whoever has two garments, let him wrap his waist and wear the upper garment (Rida). And whoever does not have two garments, let him wrap his waist then pray). Then he narrated it via Abdullah bin Abdul Wahhab Al-Hajabi who said: Narrated to us Hammad bin Zaid from Ayyub from Nafi... so he mentioned with his chain equally. I say: Al-Bayhaqi likewise recorded it via Yusuf bin Yaqub Al-Qadi: Narrated to us Sulaiman bin Harb: Narrated to us Hammad bin Zaid with it without the story. Abu Dawood also narrated it: Narrated to us Sulaiman bin Harb with it without the story. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu): (Its chain is Sahih). Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said the same in (Al-Iqtida). Then Al-Bayhaqi recorded it via Abu Al-Rabi: Narrated to us Hammad bin Zaid with it with the wording saying: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said, or he said: Umar said. And my strongest thought is that he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ahmad recorded it from Ibn Ishaq: Narrated to me Nafi with it similarly as Mawquf (suspended). In it: Nafi said: If I told you that he attributed that to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), I would hope not to be lying. This is a good (Jayyid) chain. This shows that the hesitation occurring in raising it (Raf') or suspending it (Waqf) is from Nafi himself, but at the same time he leans towards it being raised to the Prophet (peace be upon him). It seems that because of this, some narrators asserted its raising from him, as in the first narration from Hafs bin Maysarah from Musa bin Uqba. Likewise, Taubah Al-Anbari asserted raising it from Nafi with the wording: (If one of you prays, let him wrap his waist and wear the upper garment). Recorded by Al-Tahawi and Al-Bayhaqi via Ubaydullah bin Muadh who said: Narrated to me my father who said: Narrated to me Shu'bah from Taubah Al-Anbari with it. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the two Sheikhs. (If he has nothing but one garment, he must cover his shoulders with it as well by crossing the two ends of the garment, due to his saying (peace and blessings be upon him): (If one of you prays in one garment, let him cross its two ends (on his shoulders)). In a wording: (Let not one of you pray in a single garment with nothing of it on his shoulder). This hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira (may Allah be pleased with him), and it has three paths from him:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: First: From Yahya bin Abi Kathir from Ikrimah from him with the first wording. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, and the wording is his via paths from Yahya. The addition is with all of them except Al-Bukhari, and it is in (Mustakhraj Al-Ismaili) and Abu Nuaym as in (Fath Al-Bari). Second: From Abdullah bin Ayyash from Ibn Hormuz from him. Recorded by Al-Tahawi. Third: From Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from him with the second wording. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Dawood, as well as Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi, and Al-Bayhaqi via paths from him. The wording of Al-Darimi and Al-Bayhaqi is: (La Yusallianna) with the Noon of emphasis. Al-Shafi'i also recorded it in (Al-Umm) via Malik, and Al-Daraqutni narrated it in (Ghara'ib Malik) from Abdul Wahhab bin Ata from him as in (Al-Fath). (The image of the mentioned crossing (Mukhalafa) is to take the end of his garment under his right hand and place it on his left shoulder, and take the other end under his left hand and place it on his right shoulder, then knot them on his chest). Mentioned in Tanwir Al-Hawalik Sharh Muwatta Malik from Al-Baji without the knotting. As for the knotting, Al-Nawawi mentioned it from Ibn Al-Sikkit. Then Al-Baji said: (This is a type of wrapping called Tawshih and is called Idtiba, and it is permissible...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...in prayer and other [occasions] because one cannot bring out his hand for prostration and other actions without uncovering his awrah). (This is if the garment is wide. As for if it is tight/narrow, it suffices him to wrap his waist with it by tying it on his waist due to his saying (peace be upon him): (If you pray and you have one garment, if it is wide then wrap yourself with it, and if it is tight then wrap your waist with it)). This hadith is from the narration of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him), and it has four paths from him: First: From Fulaih bin Sulaiman from Saeed bin Al-Harith who said: We entered upon Jabir bin Abdullah while he was praying in one garment wrapped in it, and his Rida was nearby; if he reached for it, he could grasp it. When he finished, we asked him about that, so he said: I only do this so that fools like you see me and spread from Jabir a license granted by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Then Jabir said: I went out with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in some of his travels, and I came to him one night while he was praying in one garment, and I had one garment, so I wrapped myself in it then stood by his side. He said: (Jabir, what is this wrapping? If you pray...) The hadith. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, and the context is his. In the narration of the others, there is a clarification that he (peace be upon him) said that after finishing the prayer. Second: From Hatim bin Ismail from Yaqub bin Mujahid bin Abi Hazrah from Ubadah bin Al-Walid bin Ubadah bin Al-Samit who said: We came to Jabir bin Abdullah in his mosque while he was praying... so he mentioned it similarly. The wording of the raised (Marfu) part is:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (If it is wide, cross its ends, and if it is tight, tie it on your waist). Recorded by Muslim in his long hadith, and Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi. Al-Hakim said: (Correct according to the condition of Muslim), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him; they erred in thinking it was missed by Muslim. Third: From Shurahbil bin Sa'd: That he entered upon Jabir while he was praying... The hadith similarly. Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Tahawi in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani) - only the raised part - and its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Shurahbil, who is truthful (Saduq) but became confused at the end of his life as in (Al-Taqrib). Fourth: From Ibn Jurayj who said: Abu Al-Zubayr said: Jabir said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: (Whoever prays in one garment, let him wrap himself with it). Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Tahawi as well. Its men are all men of Muslim except that Ibn Jurayj and Abu Al-Zubayr are Mudallisin (obfuscators). The hadith is a clear text on the obligation of wrapping (Iltihaf) if the garment is wide. The absolute hadith of Abu Huraira should be interpreted based on this. The obligation is supported by his (peace be upon him) prohibition of abandoning that, and prohibition implies unlawfulness (Tahrim). A group of the...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Salaf (may Allah be pleased with them) held this view which we mentioned, including Imam Ahmad. The famous view from him is that if one prays with exposed shoulder while able to cover, his prayer is not valid, making it a condition. This is the school of Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla). In a narration from Ahmad: His prayer is valid but he sins by omitting it. This is the truth, God willing. The majority - Malik, Abu Hanifa, Al-Shafi'i, and others - held that the prohibition is for dislike (Tanzih) and the command is for recommendation (Istihbab). So if one prays in one garment covering his awrah with nothing of it on his shoulder, his prayer is valid with dislike (Karahah), whether he was able to put something on his shoulder or not. Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (And the proof of the majority...) And in (Al-Majmu): (Our proof is the hadith of Jabir regarding his saying (peace be upon him): (Then wrap your waist with it). Al-Shafi'i used this as proof in (Al-Umm), and the Companions and others used it as proof. And Allah knows best). I say: This is something of endless wonder. His command (peace be upon him) to wrap the waist is only if the garment is tight/narrow as per the text of the hadith, whereas the majority say wrapping the waist is permissible even if the garment is wide. So how could Al-Nawawi and his predecessors justify taking the mere command to wrap the waist without paying attention to the condition with which the Prophet (peace be upon him) restricted it? The truth is that the hadith is decisive evidence for Ahmad's school and others, which is differentiating between wide and tight garments; wrapping (Iltihaf) is obligatory in the first case but not the second. Al-Bukhari leaned towards this...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...as indicated by his arrangement in his (Sahih) as stated in (Al-Fath) by Al-Hafiz. Then he said: (It is the choice of Ibn Al-Mundhir and Taqi al-Din al-Subki from the Shafi'is). The researcher Al-Shawkani also leaned towards it. As for the invalidity of prayer by omitting wrapping, it is not apparent from the hadith. And Allah knows best. Here is an issue: Is it obligatory for one who has a tight Izar which he cannot wrap [over shoulders] to wear a wider one or wear a Rida over it if he has one to cover the upper part of his body?
