The apparent view to me is: Yes, it is obligatory upon him, contrary to Ibn Hazm where he said in (Al-Muhalla): (If it is tight, he wraps his waist with it and it suffices him, whether he has other clothes or not). I say: This is rigidity from him on the apparent meaning of the hadith without observing the intended meaning, which is covering the body. The Prophet (peace be upon him) confirmed this meaning by forbidding a man to pray in trousers without a Rida on him, as previously mentioned. And Allah knows best. As for the prayer of the Prophet (peace be upon him) in a single garment, he prayed wrapped in it, as stated by a group of Companions, including Amr bin Abi Salamah, Umm Hani, and Jabir bin Abdullah in the two Sheikhs and others, Abu Saeed Al-Khudri in Muslim, Anas in Al-Tahawi, Kaysan in Ibn Majah, and many others. I have referenced their hadiths in our book: (The Prayer of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: These hadiths have been used as evidence for the permissibility of praying in a single garment. Al-Nawawi said: (There is no disagreement on that except what is narrated from Ibn Masud may Allah be pleased with him regarding it, and I do not know its authenticity). I say: It seems he is referring to what Ibn Abi Shaybah recorded from Ibn Masud who said: Do not pray in a single garment even if it is wider than what is between the heaven and the earth. Al-Hafiz mentioned it in (Al-Fath) and remained silent on it. Perhaps this statement of Ibn Masud is interpreted as applying when one has another garment, evidenced by his other hadith, which is what Abdullah bin Ahmad recorded in (Zawa'id Al-Musnad) via two paths from Abu Masud Al-Jariri from Abu Nadrah bin Baqiyyah who said: Ubayy bin Ka'b said: Prayer in a single garment is a Sunnah; we used to do it with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and we were not criticized. Ibn Masud said: That was when there was scarcity in clothes; but if Allah expands [provision], then prayer in two garments is purer. Its men are trustworthy men of Muslim. However, in (Majma Al-Zawa'id) it says: (Abu Nadrah did not hear from Ubayy nor from Ibn Masud).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: Al-Bayhaqi connected it via Yazid bin Harun: Informed us Dawud from Abu Nadrah from Abu Saeed who said: Ubayy bin Ka'b and Ibn Masud differed regarding prayer in a single garment... The hadith similarly. This is a Sahih chain. Al-Bayhaqi said: (This indicates that what Ibn Masud commanded regarding prayer in two garments is recommendation, not obligation). That prayer in two garments is purer and better is agreed upon, as mentioned by Al-Nawawi in (Sharh Muslim). This is indicated by the command to wear the Rida and wrap the waist as previously mentioned. In summary, interpreting the consensus claimed by Al-Nawawi applies to the single garment with which one can cover the upper body; otherwise, you have known Ahmad's school and others regarding the obligation of covering [the shoulders]. And Allah knows best. (4 - This, and whoever prays in a shirt (Qamis) with a wide collar (Jayb) and has no other [garment] must button it even with a thorn, fearing his awrah might be seen from it... Salama bin Al-Akwa said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, I am on a hunt and I pray with nothing on me but a single shirt? He said: (Button it, even if you do not find anything but a thorn). In a wording: (Button it even with a thorn). Recorded by Imam Ahmad: Narrated to us Hashim bin Al-Qasim who said: Narrated to us Attaf from...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Musa bin Ibrahim bin Abi Rabiah who said: I heard Salama bin Al-Akwa say... so he mentioned it. Then Ahmad recorded it from Hammad bin Khalid, and Al-Nasa'i from Qutaibah, both from Attaf bin Khalid with it. Attaf was followed in narrating it; Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi recorded it via Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad Al-Darawardi: Narrated to us Musa bin Ibrahim with it using the second wording. Ibn Khuzaima and Ibn Hibban recorded it in their (Sahihs) as in (Al-Fath) and (Al-Tahdhib). Al-Shafi'i recorded it in (Al-Umm) from the two paths saying: Informed us Al-Attaf bin Khalid and Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad Al-Darawardi from Musa with it. This is a Hasan chain as Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu), for two trustworthy narrators narrated it from Musa bin Ibrahim. Ibn Al-Madini said regarding him: (Average/Wasat). Ibn Hibban mentioned him in Al-Thiqat. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Hadith), and Al-Dhahabi agreed. As for Al-Bukhari, he said in his (Sahih): (In its chain there is a matter for consideration).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The reason for this is that Al-Bukhari narrated it in his (Tarikh) via Ismail bin Abi Owais from his father from Musa bin Ibrahim from his father from Salama. Thus he added a man to the chain. Al-Hafiz said: (So it implies it could be from 'More in Connected Chains' (Mazid fi Muttasil al-Asanid) or that the explicit mention [of hearing] in Attaf's narration is an illusion; this is the aspect of 'consideration' in its chain. As for those who authenticated it, they relied on Al-Darawardi's narration and made Attaf's narration a witness for its connection). I say: Musa bin Ibrahim explicitly stated his hearing from Salama in Al-Darawardi's narration as well in Al-Hakim. Unlike Al-Tahawi's narration, for it is from Al-Darawardi from Musa bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim from Abu Salama. (And this Musa bin Muhammad is Musa bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim Al-Taimi Abu Muhammad Al-Madani, who is other than Musa bin Ibrahim; that Musa bin Ibrahim is weak). So Al-Tahawi narrated a Shadh (anomalous) narration, narrating it via Ibn Abi Qabilah from Al-Darawardi, and I do not know this Ibn Abi Qabilah right now. It has a Mursal and disconnected witness. Al-Bayhaqi said after citing the hadith: (And Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak narrated from Ibn Jurayj who said: I was told from Yahya bin Abi Kathir that the Prophet (peace be upon him) forbade a man to pray in a shirt with unbuttoned buttons, lest...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...his private parts be seen when he bows, until he buttons it). Yahya said: (If he does not have an Izar). Al-Bayhaqi said: (This, even if disconnected, agrees with the connected narration before it). In its meaning is the hadith of Abu Huraira: That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) forbade a man to pray until he girds/ties his waist (Yahtazim). Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad from Shu'bah from Yazid bin Khumair who said: I heard a client of Quraish say: I heard Abu Huraira narrating to Muawiyah with it. This is a chain whose men are trustworthy men of Muslim except the client of Quraish, who was not named. (Note): The author of (Al-Muntaqa) attributed this hadith of Abu Huraira to Ahmad and Abu Dawood, so his commentator Al-Shawkani said: (This hadith was searched for in 'Sunan Abu Dawood', 'Musnad Ahmad', and 'Al-Jami Al-Kabir' and 'Majma Al-Zawa'id', but was not found with this wording; so the author's attribution to Ahmad and Abu Dawood should be looked into). I say: This is strange from him, for it is in the (Musnad) in three places, as we have clarified the page numbers for you; so how did he not find it despite searching for it therein? As for Abu Dawood, he is excused for not finding it with him because he recorded it in a place not expected for its presence, which is the Book of Sales, as it is a fragment of a hadith with him.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith indicates that it is not permissible for the worshiper to be negligent in covering the awrah; rather, he must take precautions so he does not see it nor does anyone else see it from him. Scholars differed regarding the worshiper who prays in a shirt with a wide collar such that his awrah is seen from it. Al-Shafi'i and his companions held that the prayer is void and does not suffice him, and this is the text of the Imam in (Al-Umm). According to Abu Hanifa and Malik: His prayer is valid, just as if someone else saw it from under his hem. Mentioned in (Al-Majmu). (5 - As for the woman, she is all awrah except her face and palms. As for her being awrah, it is due to His saying: {And let them not display their adornment except what appears thereof, and let them draw their veils over their bosoms, and let them not display their adornment except to their husbands} to His saying: {And let them not stamp their feet to make known what they conceal of their adornment} The Verse [24 Surah An-Nur]). Ibn Hazm said in (Al-Muhalla): (So Allah Almighty commanded drawing the Khimar (veil) over the Juyub (bosoms/collars), and this is a text on covering the awrah, the neck, and the chest. And it contains a text on the permissibility of uncovering the face; it cannot be otherwise. And His saying: {And let them not stamp their feet to make known what they conceal of their adornment} is a text that the feet and shanks are of what is concealed and is not lawful to display). Regarding his saying: 'And it contains a text on the permissibility of uncovering the face', there is a point of view, because scholars differed regarding the meaning of His saying: {except what appears thereof}. Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said: (Meaning: They should not show anything of the adornment to strangers except what cannot be concealed. Ibn...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Masud said: Such as the Rida and clothes. Meaning what the women of the Arabs used to wear of the veil (Miqna'ah) that covers her clothes, and what appears from the lower edges of the clothes; there is no harm on her in that because this cannot be concealed. Similar to it in women's clothing is what appears of her Izar and what cannot be concealed. Al-Hasan, Ibn Sirin, Abu Al-Jawza, Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, and others held the view of Ibn Masud. Al-A'mash said from Saeed bin Jubair from Ibn Abbas: {And let them not display their adornment except what appears thereof} he said: Her face, her palms, and the ring. It was narrated from Ibn Umar, Ata, Ikrimah, Saeed bin Jubair, Abu Al-Sha'tha, Al-Dahhak, Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, and others similar to that. This interprets it as being an explanation of the adornment they were forbidden to display, as Abu Ishaq Al-Sabi'i said from Abu Al-Ahwas from Abdullah regarding His saying: {And let them not display their adornment}: Adornment is the earring, bracelet, anklet, and necklace. Al-Hafiz said: It is probable that Ibn Abbas and those who followed him meant the interpretation of 'what appears thereof' as the face and palms. This is the famous view among the majority, and it is supported by the hadith recorded by Abu Dawood in his (Sunan): Narrated to us Yaqub bin Ka'b Al-Antaki and Mu'ammal bin Al-Fadl Al-Harrani who said: Narrated to us Al-Walid from Saeed bin Bashir from Qatada from Khalid bin Durayk from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): That Asma bint Abi Bakr entered upon the Prophet (peace be upon him) wearing thin clothes, so he turned away from her and said: (O Asma, indeed when a woman reaches menstruation, it is not correct that anything be seen of her except this) - and he pointed to his face and palms. But Abu Dawood and Abu Hatim said: It is Mursal; Khalid bin Durayk did not hear from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her). I say: And all these reports and statements, or most of them, were mentioned by Ibn Jurayj with their chains in...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Masud: Such as the Rida (cloak) and clothes. Meaning what the women of the Arabs used to wear of the veil (Miqna'ah) that covers her clothes, and what appears from the lower edges of the clothes; there is no harm on her in that because this cannot be concealed. Similar to it in women's clothing is what appears of her Izar and what cannot be concealed. Al-Hasan, Ibn Sirin, Abu Al-Jawza, Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, and others held the view of Ibn Masud. But Abu Dawood and Abu Hatim said: It is Mursal; Khalid bin Durayk did not hear from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her). I say: And all these reports and statements, or most of them, were mentioned by Ibn Jurayj with their chains in

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Interpretation) Then he chose the opinion of Ibn Abbas and those who followed him, saying: (The most correct of the opinions regarding that is the opinion of those who meant by that the face and the two hands. Included in that—if it is so—are kohl, rings, bracelets, and dye. We said that this is the most correct opinion because of the consensus of everyone that every worshiper must cover his awrah in his prayer, and that a woman may uncover her face and hands in her prayer, and that she must cover the rest of her body besides that, except for what was narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he permitted her to show of her forearm up to about half. Since this is the case by the consensus of all of them, it became known thereby that she may show of her body what is not awrah, just as it is for men; because what is not awrah is not forbidden to expose. And if she is permitted to expose that, it is known that it is among what Allah the Exalted made an exception for by His saying: {except what appears thereof}, because all of that appears from her). Al-Qurtubi also leaned towards this opinion, for he mentioned in his (Tafsir) the saying of Ibn Atiyyah: (It appears to me, by the ruling of the wording of the verse, that the woman is commanded not to display and to strive to conceal whatever is adornment. The exception occurred regarding what appears by the necessity of movement in what is unavoidable, or fixing a matter, and the like. So {what appears} in this manner is what necessity leads to for women, and it is what is pardoned). Al-Qurtubi said: (I say: This is a good opinion, except that since the face and hands usually appear by custom and in worship—that is in prayer and Hajj—it is appropriate that the exception

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: refers to them. Indicating this is what Abu Dawood narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her...). Then he mentioned the previous hadith found in Ibn Kathir. Then he said: (This is stronger on the side of precaution and to guard against the corruption of people; so a woman should not display of her adornment except what appears of her face and hands). Know that the scholars have agreed, as in (Maratib Al-Ijma), that the hair of a free woman and her body—except for her face and hand—are awrah. They differed regarding the face and the hands, up to their fingernails: Are they awrah or not? It has become clear to you from the interpretation of the noble verse that it indicates precisely that the face and hands are not awrah. This is also what the Sunnah indicates, as follows: (And his saying, peace be upon him: (The woman is awrah), which is from the hadith of Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, and its completion is: (so when she goes out, the Satan looks at her [to tempt others]). Al-Tirmidhi recorded it via Hammam from Qatada from Murra from Abu Al-Ahwas from him. He said: (Hasan hadith). And in a copy: (Hasan Sahih) (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) And likewise in Al-Iraqi's citation in Al-Takhrij (2/53).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of Muslim. Al-Munawi said in (Fayd Al-Qadir): (Al-Tabarani narrated it from him with the mentioned wording and added: (And she is closest to Allah when she is in the depth of her house). Al-Haythami said: Its men are trustworthy. Ibn Hibban also narrated it from him). I say: Al-Khatib recorded it with the mentioned addition in his (Tarikh) via Mu'tamir bin Sulaiman who said: I heard my father narrating from Qatada from Abu Al-Ahwas with it, so he dropped Murra from the chain. (As for her face and hands not being awrah, it is due to His saying in the previous verse: {except what appears thereof} according to the opinion of Ibn Abbas and others: that the intended meaning is the face and the two hands. Witnessing to this from the Sunnah are: (1) From Ibn Abbas, who said: A woman used to pray behind the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, a beautiful woman, among the most beautiful of people. [Ibn Abbas said: No, by Allah, I have never seen the like of her]. So some of the people would move forward to be in the first row so they would not see her, and some would move back to be in the last row, so when they bowed, they would look from under their armpits [and he spread his arms]. So Allah the Exalted revealed: {And We have known those who precede among you and We have known those who stay behind} [Al-Hijr / 24]. As for the statement of Ibn Abbas, Ibn Jarir narrated it as previously mentioned. Al-Tahawi narrated similarly in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani) and Al-Bayhaqi in his (Sunan) from Saeed bin Jubayr from him. Then Al-Bayhaqi narrated it via Ikrimah from him, then said: We were narrated from Anas bin Malik similar to this.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then he narrated with a chain from Uqba bin Al-Asam from Ata bin Abi Rabah from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: {what appears thereof}: The face and the two hands. But Uqba bin Al-Asam is weak. Then Al-Bayhaqi said: And we were narrated from Ibn Umar that he said: The apparent adornment: The face and the two hands. And we were narrated its meaning from Ata bin Abi Rabah and Saeed bin Jubayr, and it is the opinion of Al-Awza'i. Ibn Hazm said: (We have been narrated from Ibn Abbas regarding {and let them not display their adornment except what appears thereof}, he said: The hand, the ring, and the face. And from Ibn Umar: The face and the two hands. And from Anas: The hand and the ring. All of this from them is of the utmost authenticity, and likewise from Aisha and others from the Tabi'in). Then Al-Bayhaqi narrated the hadith of Aisha raised to the Prophet (Marfu'): (Indeed, when a woman reaches menstruation, it is not correct that anything be seen of her except this and this - and he pointed to his face and hands). Al-Bayhaqi said: (With this Mursal [report] is the statement of those who passed of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, in explaining what Allah permitted of apparent adornment, so the opinion became strong thereby). And Allah the Exalted knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: As for the hadith of Ibn Abbas, it is a good (Jayyid) hadith. It was narrated by Noah bin Qais Al-Haddani from Amr bin Malik Al-Nukari from Abu Al-Jawza from him. This is a good chain; its men are trustworthy men of Muslim, except Amr bin Malik, who is trustworthy as stated in (Al-Mizan). It was recorded by Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, Al-Tayalisi, Ahmad, Ibn Jarir in his (Tafsir), and Al-Tabari in (Al-Kabir) via paths from him. The addition and the first [part] are in Ibn Jarir, and the other is in Al-Hakim, who said: (Correct chain). Amr bin Ali said: (No one spoke against Noah bin Qais Al-Tahi with proof). Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Talkhis): (I say: He is truthful (Saduq); Muslim narrated from him). As for Al-Tirmidhi, he noted a defect saying: (Ja'far bin Sulaiman narrated this hadith from Amr bin Malik from Abu Al-Jawza similarly, but did not mention 'from Ibn Abbas' in it. This is likely more correct than the hadith of Noah). I say: This narration of Ja'far was recorded by Ibn Jarir via Abdul Razzaq from him, supported (Musnad) from Abu Al-Jawza, who said regarding the saying of Allah: {And We have known those who precede among you and We have known those who stay behind}. He said: The preceding among you in prayer and the staying behind.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: This Mursal (hurried/disconnected) and Mawquf (stopped) narration does not, in my view, defect the first connected (Mawsul) and raised (Marfu') narration, because the narrator has additional knowledge, and accepting it is obligatory as established in the terminology [of Hadith]. Also, the wording of the Mursal narration indicates it is an independent narration from the raised one because it is very brief. It appears that when Abu Al-Jawza narrated the hadith as raised (Marfu'), he narrated it completely regarding the reason for the revelation of the verse, and when he mentioned the verse interpreting it, he narrated it briefly without raising it or attributing it to Ibn Abbas, even though he originally took it from him. Thus, it appears that the Mursal narration does not defect the connected narration. And Allah knows best. As for the statement of Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir in his (Tafsir): (This hadith contains severe Nakara [strangeness/deniability]), it is not conceded, because that 'some' who used to look from under his armpit could have been from the hypocrites or ignorant Bedouins; this is clear and not hidden. Therefore, there is no strangeness or problem. That is why we did not see anyone who extracted the hadith or mentioned it describe it with severe Nakara, not even Al-Hafiz Al-Dhahabi, known for his precise critique of texts; rather, he authenticated it as you learned. He is the one about whom Ibn Kathir says in his (Tarikh) when mentioning his death year: (The Sheikhs of Hadith and its memorizers ended with him, may Allah have mercy on him). The hadith is evidence that women used to pray behind the Prophet, peace be upon him, with uncovered faces. Witnessing to this is the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: The believing women used to witness...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the Fajr prayer with the Prophet, peace be upon him, wrapped in their woolen garments, then they would return to their homes when they finished the prayer; no one would recognize them due to the darkness. Recorded by the two Sheikhs and others, and it passed in the Timings No. (5) regarding Fajr. Its implication is that they would be recognized if it weren't for the darkness, and they are usually not recognized except by faces. So it contains evidence that the woman's face is not awrah in prayer, which is a consensus as indicated by Ibn Jarir's previous words in interpreting the verse. If the matter is so, then her face is not awrah outside of prayer a fortiori, because scholars agree that what is required in prayer is [often] what is not required outside of it. So if the permissibility of a matter inside it is established in the Law, that is evidence for its permissibility outside it, as is not hidden. Furthermore, explicit evidence has come that it is not awrah outside of prayer as well, which is our saying: (2) From Jabir bin Abdullah who said: I witnessed the prayer with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on the day of Eid. He started with the prayer before the sermon, without Adhan or Iqamah. Then he stood leaning on Bilal, commanded the fear of Allah, urged obedience to Him, preached to the people and reminded them. Then he moved on until he came to the women, preached to them and reminded them, saying: (Give charity, for most of you are fuel for Hell). A woman from the middle class/status (Sita) of women with dark cheeks stood up and said: Why, O Messenger of Allah? He said: (Because you complain frequently and are ungrateful to the husband). He said: So they began giving charity from their jewelry, throwing their earrings and rings into Bilal's garment).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a Sahih hadith recorded by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad via paths from Abdul Malik bin Abi Sulaiman who said: Narrated to us Ata from him regarding the word: (Sita). Thus it is in Muslim. The narration of the others is: (Sifla) [meaning lowest/lower class]. Perhaps that narration is distorted or misspelled from this one. Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (Thus it is in the copies (Sita) with a Kasra on the Sin and a Fatha on the lightened Ta. In some copies: Wasita [middle] of women. Al-Qadi said: It means among the best of them; 'Al-Wast' is the just and the best. He said: The skillful among our Sheikhs claimed that this letter is changed in the book of Muslim and that its correct form is: From the 'Sifla' [lowest] of women. Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated it likewise in his (Musnad) and Al-Nasa'i in his (Sunan). In a narration of Ibn Abi Shaybah: A woman not from the elite of women. This is contrary to the first interpretation and is supported by his saying after it: 'Dark in the cheeks'). This is the speech of Al-Qadi. This claim of changing the word is not accepted; rather it is correct, but it does not mean 'from the best of women' as he interpreted, but rather 'a woman from the middle of the women', sitting in their midst. Al-Jawhari and others of the linguists said: 'Wasattu al-qawm, asituhum, wastan wa sitatan', meaning: I sat in their midst. His saying: (Saf'aa al-khadayn) [dark/changed cheeks] with a Fatha on the un-dotted Sin means: There is a change and blackness in them). End of Al-Nawawi's speech. This hadith indicates that women used to attend prayer with uncovered faces; that is why the narrator was able to describe one of them as having dark cheeks.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (3) And from Ibn Abbas that a woman from Khath'am asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for a verdict during the Farewell Pilgrimage [on the Day of Sacrifice] while Al-Fadl bin Abbas was riding behind the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him... The hadith. Al-Fadl bin Abbas began turning to look at her, and she was a beautiful woman [and she was looking at him], so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, took Al-Fadl and turned his face to the other side. Others added: Al-Abbas said to him: O Messenger of Allah, why did you twist the neck of your cousin? He said: (I saw a young man and a young woman, and I did not trust Satan with them). The hadith was recorded by Ahmad and Al-Nasa'i, and from him Ibn Hazm via Salih bin Kaysan from Ibn Shihab that Sulaiman bin Yasar informed him that Ibn Abbas informed him with it. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the two Sheikhs. Al-Bukhari recorded it via Shu'aib from Al-Zuhri with it similarly, containing the first addition. Al-Bayhaqi also recorded it. Malik narrated it in (Al-Muwatta) from Ibn Shihab with it similarly, containing the second addition. It is in Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Al-Nasa'i as well, and Ahmad; all from Malik with it. Then Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad narrated it from other paths from Al-Zuhri similarly, containing the first addition.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: As for the last addition, it is from a path other than Ibn Abbas; it is from the hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi, Ahmad, and his son Abdullah in (Zawa'id Al-Musnad) via paths from Abdul Rahman bin Al-Harith from Ibn Ayyash bin Abi Rabiah from Zaid bin Ali bin Hussein bin Ali from his father Ali bin Hussein from Ubaidullah bin Rafi', the client of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from him in a hadith of his describing the Hajj. This is a good (Jayyid) chain; its men are trustworthy. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih). The hadith contains clear evidence that the woman's face is not awrah because (If the face were awrah that must be covered, he, peace be upon him, would not have approved her uncovering it in the presence of people, and would have ordered her to draw [a veil] over it from above. And if her face were covered, Ibn Abbas would not have known if she was beautiful or ugly). This was stated by Ibn Hazm. Thus, it is established by all of this that her face is not awrah, neither in prayer nor outside of it. This is the opinion of the majority of scholars in (Bidayat Al-Mujtahid), and it is the school of the three Imams: Abu Hanifa, Malik, Al-Shafi'i, and others as in (Al-Majmu). Some jurists argued for this by observation as well, which is that need calls for exposing the face for buying and selling, and exposing the palm for taking and giving; so that was not made awrah.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (4) From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: That Hind bint Utbah said: O Prophet of Allah, accept my pledge? [So he looked at her hand and] said: (I will not accept your pledge until you change your palms, for they look like the paws of a predatory beast). This is a Hasan hadith recorded by Abu Dawood in (Al-Sunan): Narrated to us Muslim bin Ibrahim: Narrated to me Ghibtah bint Amr Al-Mujashi'iyyah who said: Narrated to me my aunt Umm Al-Hasan from her grandmother from her [Aisha]. This is a chain consisting of unknown women (Majhulat), but Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (A chapter on unknown women: I do not know of any woman who was accused [of lying] nor anyone whom they abandoned). It has another path and corroborating evidences that strengthen it. Ibn Abi Hatim said, as in (Tafsir Ibn Kathir): Narrated to us Nasr bin Ali: Narrated to me Umm Attiyah bint Sulaiman: Narrated to me my aunt from my grandmother from Aisha who said: Hind bint Utbah came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to pledge allegiance to him. He looked at her hand and said: (Go and change your hand). So she went and changed it with henna, then came back. He said: (I accept your pledge on the condition that you do not associate anything with Allah). She pledged allegiance to him, and in her hand were two gold bracelets. She said: What do you say about these two bracelets? He said: (Two coals from the fire of Hell). Ibn Kathir remained silent on it, and its chain is like the one before it. Al-Haythami cited it in (Al-Majmu) in a more complete form, then said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Recorded by Abu Ya'la, and it contains women I do not know). Among its corroborating evidences: (1) From Ibn Abbas regarding a woman who came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, to pledge allegiance, and she said... and she was not dyed [with henna], so he did not accept her pledge until she dyed [her hands]. Recorded by Al-Bazzar; in it is Laith bin Abi Sulaim who is a Mudallis, but the rest of its men are trustworthy as in (Al-Majmu). (2) From Muslim bin Abdul Rahman who said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, accepting the pledge of women in the Year of the Conquest on Al-Safa. A woman came whose hand was like a man's hand, so he refused to accept her pledge until she went and changed her hand with yellow [dye]. Al-Haythami said: (Recorded by Al-Tabarani and Al-Bazzar, and in it is Sumaisah bint Nabhan, whom I do not know, and the rest of its men are trustworthy). I say: Thus it is in the original (Sumaisah) with an un-dotted Sin, but perhaps it is with dots (Shumaisah) as in (Al-Isti'ab) and (Al-Isabah). However, it appeared there with the un-dotted Sin before the Ya, and apparently, it is also a distortion. Regarding the hadith, Al-Hafiz said: (Recorded by Abu Ali bin Al-Sakan, and Al-Bukhari as well, and Al-Tabarani via Abbad bin...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Kathir Al-Ramli from Shamsiyyah bint Nabhan from her master Muslim bin Abdul Rahman with it). Then he said: (Ibn Hibban said: I do not see her hadith as preserved). (3) From Muhammad bin Ishaq from Ibn Damrah bin Saeed from his grandmother from a woman among their women who had prayed towards the two Qiblas with the Prophet, peace be upon him. She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, entered upon me and said: (Dye [your hands], for one of you abandons dyeing until her hand becomes like the hand of a man). She said: So I did not abandon dyeing until I met Allah the Exalted, even if she were to dye while eighty years old. Recorded by Ahmad: Narrated to us Yazid bin Harun: Informed us Muhammad bin Ishaq with it. Al-Haythami said: (Recorded by Ahmad, and in it are those I do not know, and Ibn Ishaq who is a Mudallis). I say: Ibn Damrah bin Saeed was listed in (Al-Ta'jeel), then he said: (Thus it appeared in a copy. In the reliable copies: Muhammad bin Ishaq from Damrah bin Saeed; it does not contain 'Ibn', and that is the correct version). I say: Based on this, there is no one unknown in it except the grandmother of Damrah bin Saeed, for she was not named. As for him—meaning Damrah bin Saeed—he is trustworthy, one of the men of Muslim. (4) From Al-Sawda' who said: I came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, to pledge allegiance, so he said: (Go and dye [your hands], then come so I may accept your pledge). Al-Haythami said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and (Al-Kabir) and in it is someone I do not know). I say: Ibn Sa'd recorded it in (Al-Tabaqat) from his two Sheikhs Abdul Aziz bin Al-Khattab and Ismail bin Aban Al-Warraq, both from Na'ila Al-Kufiyyah, client of Abu Al-Aizar, from Umm Asim from her. This Na'ila, I did not find anyone mentioning her. Umm Asim is perhaps the client of Salama bin Al-Muhabbaq, and she is acceptable (Maqbulah) as in (Al-Taqrib). (5) From Aisha who said: A woman extended a hand with a book from behind a curtain to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The Prophet, peace be upon him, withdrew his hand and said: (I do not know if it is a man's hand or a woman's hand). She said: Rather, a woman. He said: (If you were a woman, you would have changed your fingernails with henna). Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ahmad, and Al-Bayhaqi via Muti' bin Maimun Al-Anbari, kunya Abu Saeed, who said: Safiyyah bint Ismah narrated to me from her. This is a lenient (Layyin) chain. In these hadiths, there is apparent indication that the palm of a woman is not awrah because he, peace be upon him, looked at it and ordered dyeing it so it would be a distinguishing feature between men and women. In that, there is an approval from him, peace be upon him, for her exposing it. In the chapter, from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, it was said to him: Did you witness the Eid with the Prophet, peace be upon him? He said: Yes, and were it not for my status of young age, I would not have witnessed it. Until he came to the marker which...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...is at the house of Kathir bin Al-Salt, so he prayed, then preached. Then he came to the women with Bilal, preached to them, reminded them, and commanded them to give charity. I saw them reaching out with their hands throwing [jewelry] into Bilal's garment. Then he and Bilal went to his house. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, and from his path Ibn Hazm. And Abu Dawood, and from him Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Nasa'i via Sufyan Al-Thawri who said: Narrated to me Abdul Rahman bin Abis from him. Ibn Hazm did not include any other [hadith] in the chapter. He said: (So this is Ibn Abbas in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, seeing their hands. So it is correct that the hand of the woman and the face are not awrah, and whatever is besides them, it is obligatory (Fard) upon her to cover). (6 - If a woman prays without a Khimar (veil) covering her head, her prayer is not accepted, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (Allah does not accept the prayer of a menstruating woman except with a Khimar)). The hadith is Sahih; recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Hammad bin Salamah, and Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla) via Hammad bin Zaid, both from Qatada from Ibn Sirin from Safiyyah bint Al-Harith from Aisha raised (Marfu'). Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan hadith), and Al-Hakim: (Correct according to the condition of Muslim), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It was also narrated by Ibn Khuzaima and Ibn Hibban in their (Sahihs), and Ishaq bin Rahwaih as in (Nasb Al-Rayah). He attributed it to Al-Tayalisi as well in his (Musnad), but I did not find it there. And Allah knows best. Some defected the hadith saying it was narrated from Ibn Sirin from Aisha without mentioning Safiyyah between them, so it is disconnected (Munqati'). Recorded by Ahmad. And from Al-Hasan that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said... so he mentioned it. Recorded by Al-Hakim and Al-Bayhaqi; so it is Mursal. It is not hidden that this does not impugn the narration of the one who narrated it connected (Mawsul) because he is trustworthy and brought an addition which is accepted as established in the terminology. The hadith has a witness from the hadith of Abu Qatada with the wording: (Allah does not accept a prayer from a woman until she covers her adornment, nor from a girl who has reached menstruation until she wears a Khimar). Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir) and in (Al-Awsat) as well; in its chain is someone unknown. The 'menstruating woman' in the hadith: is one who has reached the age of menstruation, not one who is experiencing menstruation, for she is forbidden from prayer. This is clarified in Ibn Khuzaima's narration with the wording: (Allah does not accept the prayer of a woman who has [reached the age to have] menstruated except with a Khimar). Al-Tirmidhi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The practice according to the people of knowledge is that if a woman reaches maturity and prays with any of her hair exposed, her prayer is not valid. This is the opinion of Al-Shafi'i. He said: The prayer of a woman is not valid while any part of her body is exposed. Al-Shafi'i said: It was said: If the top of her feet is exposed, her prayer is permissible). (7 - And it is not permissible for her clothes—whether a veil, socks, or otherwise—to be flimsy or transparent, revealing what is underneath and describing it, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (There will be in the end of my nation women who are clothed yet naked, on their heads are like the humps of camels; curse them for they are cursed). Added in another hadith: (They will not enter Paradise nor smell its fragrance, even though its fragrance can be found from a distance of such and such). The first hadith was narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir) from Ibn Amr with a Hasan chain, and the other is in Muslim and others from Abu Huraira. Both are referenced in (Al-Musannaf), so there is no need to reference them here. The hadith is among the miracles of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his truthful prophecies which Allah informed him of, such that you see its content applying perfectly to most women of our time. There is no power or strength except with Allah. (If she fears any of what I mentioned, let her place a slip (Ghalalah) under the clothes, as he, peace be upon him, said, and he gave the reason for that in the same hadith saying: (For I fear it may describe the size of her bones).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith has a Hasan chain, and it is from the narration of Usama bin Zaid who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, clothed me with a thick Coptic garment (Qibtiyyah) from what Dihyah Al-Kalbi gifted to him, so I clothed my wife with it. He said: (Why do you not wear the Qibtiyyah?) I said: I clothed my wife with it. He said: (Order her to place a slip (Ghalalah) under it, for I fear it may describe the size of her bones). Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi via Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil from Muhammad bin Usama bin Zaid from him. Al-Haythami cited the hadith in (Al-Majmu) and said: (Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani, and in it is Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil; his hadith is Hasan but has weakness). I say: It has a witness from the hadith of Dihyah himself recorded by Al-Bayhaqi via Yahya bin Ayyub: Narrated to me Musa bin Jubair that Abbas bin Abdullah bin Abbas bin Abdul Muttalib narrated to him from Khalid bin Yazid bin Muawiyah from Dihyah bin Khalifa with it similarly. In it: That Dihyah himself was given the Qibtiyyah by the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and he, peace be upon him, said to him: (Make a shirt from a part of it, and give your wife a part to use as a veil). When he turned away, he called him and said: (Order her to place something under it so it does not describe [her shape]). Perhaps it is another story. Then Al-Bayhaqi said: (Some of them said: Abbas bin Ubaidullah). Al-Bukhari said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Those who said: Ibn Ubaidullah are more [numerous]). Among those who said Ibn Ubaidullah are Yahya bin Ayyub and Ibn Jurayj. Al-Bayhaqi said: (Abdullah bin Lahi'ah narrated it from Musa bin Jubair that Ubaidullah bin Abbas narrated to him). I say: The hadith of Ibn Lahi'ah was recorded in his (Sunan), and he said after it: (Yahya bin Ayyub narrated it saying Abbas bin Ubaidullah bin Abbas), which is the correct version as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib). He said: (He is acceptable (Maqbul), and the narrator from him, Musa bin Jubair, is hidden (Mastur)). So the hadith with this chain is weak, but it is strengthened by the one before it. And Allah knows best. Al-Hakim also recorded it and authenticated it, but Al-Dhahabi defected it due to disconnection. (8 - It is permissible for her, rather obligatory upon her, to lengthen her hem by a handspan from the ankles or two handspans, not exceeding that. This is to cover their feet due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Whoever drags his garment out of pride, Allah will not look at him on the Day of Resurrection). Umm Salama said: So what should women do with their hems? He said: (They should slacken it by a handspan). She said: Then their feet will be uncovered. He said: (Then they should slacken it by a cubit, not exceeding that). The hadith was recorded by Al-Nasa'i and Al-Tirmidhi via Abdul Razzaq

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He said: Narrated to us Ma'mar from Ayyub from Nafi from Ibn Umar raised (Marfu') with it (1). Al-Tirmidhi said: (This is a Hasan Sahih hadith), and it is as he said. Its men are all trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs. However, there was disagreement regarding it upon Nafi. Ma'mar narrated it from Ayyub from him like this. Al-Umari followed him from Nafi from Ibn Umar: That the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, granted a concession to women to slacken by a handspan... The hadith similarly. Recorded by Ahmad. Yahya bin Abi Kathir narrated it from Nafi from Umm Salama: That she mentioned to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the hems of women... The hadith. Recorded by Al-Nasa'i. Then he recorded it from Ayyub bin Musa from Nafi from Safiyyah from Umm Salama: That when the Prophet, peace be upon him, mentioned regarding the Izar what he mentioned, Umm Salama said... The hadith. Abu Bakr bin Nafi followed him from his father from Safiyyah bint Abi Ubaid that she informed him of it. Recorded by Malik, and from his path Abu Dawood. And Muhammad bin Ishaq followed him from Nafi with it. Recorded by Al-Darimi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad.
foot_note: 1. (1) And Al-Bayhaqi recorded it (2/233) via Hammad bin Zaid from Ayyub with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad recorded it via paths from Ubaidullah bin Umar from Nafi from Sulaiman bin Yasar from Umm Salama with it. In a narration of Ahmad via Yahya from Ubaidullah: Informed me Nafi from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (Whoever drags his garment out of pride, Allah will not look at him on the Day of Resurrection). He said: And informed me Sulaiman bin Yasar that Umm Salama mentioned women... The hadith. So these are four aspects of disagreement upon Nafi: 1 - From him from Ibn Umar directly. 2 - From him from Umm Salama directly. 3 - From him from her via Safiyyah bint Abi Ubaid. 4 - From him from her via Sulaiman bin Yasar. The most likely correct in my view are the last two narrations. As for the first of the two [latter ones], it is due to the agreement of three trustworthy narrators on it: Ayyub bin Musa, Abu Bakr bin Nafi, and Muhammad bin Ishaq. As for the other, its narrator from Nafi is Ubaidullah bin Umar, who is trustworthy and firm (Thabt). Ahmad bin Salih prioritized him over Malik regarding Nafi, as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib). So he is more worthy and deserving to be prioritized over Ayyub, especially since his narration is detailed, where he explicitly stated that...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the first hadith: Whoever drags his garment... etc., is from the narration of Nafi from Ibn Umar. While the other hadith, he explicitly stated that its narrators are Nafi from Sulaiman bin Yasar from her. The narration of Ayyub is summarized without this detail. Al-Umari's following of him does not strengthen it because he is weak in memory—he is Abdullah bin Umar 'The Elder'—especially since his brother Ubaidullah 'The Younger', the trustworthy and firm one, contradicted him. Then I found evidence that Ayyub's narration was also reported in detail. Imam Ahmad said: Narrated to us Ismail: Informed us Ayyub from Nafi from Ibn Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (Indeed, the one who drags his garment...). The hadith. Nafi said: So I was informed that Umm Salama said... The hadith. So this Ismail—who is Ibn Ibrahim bin Ulayyah, the trustworthy Hafiz—clarifies also that Ayyub's narration is like Ubaidullah's narration regarding detail, except that he named the intermediary which Ayyub left obscure, and this is a definitely accepted addition. What appears is that all these narrations are authentic, and that Nafi sometimes sent the hadith [Mursal] and sometimes connected it, and that he had two Sheikhs in it: Sulaiman bin Yasar, who is a virtuous trustworthy narrator and one of the seven jurists used as proof by the two Sheikhs; and Safiyyah bint Abi Ubaid, who is trustworthy from the narrators of Muslim, and she is the wife of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. The hadith has another path from Ibn Umar recorded by Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad via Zaid Al-Ammi from Abu Al-Siddiq Al-Naji from Ibn Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, granted a concession to the Mothers of the Believers regarding the hem for a handspan. Then they asked for more, so he increased it for them...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: by a handspan. So they used to send [their garments] to us, and we would measure for them a cubit. Its men are trustworthy men of Muslim except Zaid Al-Ammi, who is weak as in (Al-Taqrib). If this narration is authentic from Ibn Umar, perhaps he took it from his wife Safiyyah bint Abi Ubaid who narrated the hadith from Umm Salama as previously mentioned. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (This narration benefited the amount of the permitted cubit, and that it is two handspans by the moderate handspan). It has a witness from the hadith of Abu Huraira: That the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered Fatima or Umm Salama, may Allah be pleased with them, to drag her hem by a cubit. Recorded by Ibn Majah and Ahmad via Hammad bin Salamah from Abu Al-Muhazzim from him. Habib Al-Mu'allim contradicted him, narrating it from Abu Al-Muhazzim from Abu Huraira from Aisha similarly. Recorded by Ibn Majah also, as well as Ahmad. Abu Al-Muhazzim is agreed upon to be weak as in (Al-Zawa'id). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (Matruk [abandoned]) (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Hammad has another chain for it recorded by Al-Tirmidhi (1/323) from him from Ali bin Zaid from Umm Al-Hasan from Umm Salama similarly. And he said: Some of them narrated it from Hammad bin Salamah from Ali bin Zaid from Al-Hasan from his mother from Umm Salama. I say: Ali bin Zaid is Ibn Jud'an, weak.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith indicates the obligation of covering a woman's feet, and this is the school of Al-Shafi'i and others. Know that there is no difference in this between a free woman and a slave woman due to the lack of evidence for a difference. Yes, some hadiths came regarding the difference, but they have weak chains and do not constitute proof. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar explained their weakness in (Al-Talkhis), so whoever wishes may check them. How excellent is what Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, said: (As for the difference between the free woman and the slave woman, the religion of Allah is one, and creation and nature are one. So all of that applies equally to free women and slave women, unless a text comes differentiating between them in something, then one stops at it). Then he said: (And no two people of Islam differed that the prohibition of adultery with a free woman is like the prohibition with a slave woman, and that the Hadd punishment on the fornicator with a free woman is like the Hadd on the fornicator with a slave woman, with no difference. And that the exposure of a free woman to prohibition is like the exposure of a slave woman, with no difference. Because of this and similar matters, it is obligatory not to accept the saying of anyone after the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, unless he attributes it to him, peace be upon him. 9 - Purification of the Body, Garment, and Place for Prayer (1 - It is obligatory to purify the body from every impurity due to his saying, peace be upon him: (Most of the punishment of the grave is from urine, so clean yourselves from urine). And his saying: (When the menstruation comes, leave the prayer, and when it departs, wash the blood from yourself and pray). The first hadith is Hasan as Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu), and it is from the hadith of Ibn Abbas in Al-Daraqutni, who said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (There is no harm in it). It has two paths we mentioned in (Al-Ta'liq Al-Raghib). The second hadith is Sahih agreed upon, and it has passed. In the chapter are the hadiths of Istinja (cleaning oneself). It might be said: The first hadith is specific to urine and the second to women's blood. It is not hidden that analogizing other impurities to them is a correct analogy due to the commonality of the cause of impurity; so avoiding every impurity and washing it if it touches the body is obligatory. Al-Khattabi said: (All impurities are like blood; there is no difference between it and them by consensus) as quoted in (Al-Fath). (2 - Therefore, it is obligatory to purify garments from every impurity due to His saying: {And your clothing purify} [Al-Muddathir / 4]). Meaning: Wash them with water. Ibn Zaid said: (The polytheists did not purify themselves, so Allah commanded him to purify himself and to purify his clothes). There are other opinions regarding the verse cited by Ibn Kathir and others. The mentioned opinion is the most apparent, and it is the one preferred by Al-Nawawi in (Al-Majmu) following Al-Bayhaqi, and chosen by Ibn Jarir, and likewise Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla). He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Whoever claims that the meaning is the heart has specified the verse with his claim without proof. The principle in the language in which the Quran was revealed is: That 'Thiyab' (clothes) are what is worn and stepped on, and it is not transferred from that to the heart and honor except with evidence). Ibn Kathir held that the verse might include the opinions he mentioned, including this opinion rejected by Ibn Hazm, meaning purification of the heart. He said: (For the Arabs apply 'Thiyab' to it). Ibn Hazm did not deny this; rather, he denied limiting the verse to the heart. Ibn Al-Qayyim went to what Ibn Kathir held, and perhaps they took it from their Sheikh Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him. Ibn Al-Qayyim said in (Ighathat Al-Lahfan) - after citing the referenced opinions -: (I say: The verse encompasses all of this - and indicates it by way of alert and implication even if it doesn't cover that literally. For if the command is purification of the heart, then purification of the garment and the goodness of its earning are a completion of that. For the filth of the clothing earns the heart a filthy state, just as filth of food earns it that. Therefore, wearing skins of leopards and predatory beasts was forbidden by the Prophet's prohibition, peace be upon him, in several authentic hadiths with no contradiction, because of the state resembling those animals that the heart acquires. For the external association permeates to the internal. Therefore, wearing silk and gold was forbidden for males because of the state the heart acquires which belongs to those who wear that among women and people of pride and arrogance. The point is that purification of...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...the garment and it being from good earnings is part of the completion of the heart's purification and its perfection. If the command is that, then it is a means intended for something else, and what is intended for itself is more worthy of being commanded. Even if the command is purification of the heart and purification of the soul, it is not complete except with that. So the indication of the Quran on this and that becomes clear). (And his saying, peace be upon him: (If menstrual blood hits the garment of one of you, let her scratch it off, then sprinkle/wash it with water, then pray in it)). This is from the hadith of Asma bint Abi Bakr Al-Siddiq who said: A woman asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saying: What do you think if menstrual blood hits the garment of one of us, how should she deal with it? The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said... The hadith. Recorded by Malik, and from him Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Dawood via Hisham bin Urwa from Fatima bint Al-Mundhir bin Al-Zubayr from her. Al-Bukhari also recorded it, along with Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi who authenticated it, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad. Al-Tayalisi recorded via Hisham and Muhammad bin Ishaq from Fatima with it similarly. It has a witness from the hadith of Umm Qais bint Mihsan that she asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, about menstrual blood hitting the garment? He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Scrub it with a rib-bone and wash it with water and Sidr [lote tree leaves]). Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Sufyan who said: Narrated to me Thabit Al-Haddad from Adi bin Dinar from her. This is a Hasan chain; its men are trustworthy except Thabit, who is Ibn Hormuz, truthful (Saduq) but errs (Yahim) as in (Al-Taqrib). The hadith indicates the obligation of purifying clothes from impurities. Although it was narrated regarding blood, all other impurities are like it; there is no difference between them in analogy as Al-Khattabi said in (Al-Ma'alim). In the chapter is the command to wash the garment from the urine of a female child, and it passed in the beginning of the book. (And a man asked the Prophet, peace be upon him: May I pray in the garment in which I approach [have intercourse with] my wife? He said: (Yes, unless you see something in it, then wash it)). This is from the hadith of Jabir bin Samura who said: A man asked... etc. Recorded by Ahmad and Ibn Majah via Ubaidullah bin Umar and via Abdul Malik bin Umair from him. He said in (Al-Zawa'id): (This is a Sahih chain and its men are trustworthy). I say: And its men are men of the two Sheikhs. In the chapter from Muawiyah that he asked his sister Umm Habiba, wife of the Prophet, peace be upon him: Did...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, use to pray in the garment in which he had intercourse? She said: Yes, if there was no harm [impurity] on it. Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Yazid bin Abi Habib from Suwaid bin Qais from Muawiyah bin Hudaij from him. This is a Sahih chain; its men are all trustworthy. Ibn Khuzaima and Ibn Hibban authenticated it as in (Al-Fath). Muhammad bin Abi Sufyan narrated it from his sister Umm Habiba with the wording: She said: I saw the Prophet, peace be upon him, praying while I and he had a single garment in which was whatever was [of intimacy]. Recorded by Ahmad via Muawiyah bin Salih who said: Narrated to us Damrah bin Habib from him. Its men are trustworthy except Muhammad bin Abi Sufyan. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable. It was said: The correct is Anbasa bin Abi Sufyan). I say: Al-Khazraji asserted that in (Al-Khulasa). If that is correct, then the chain is Sahih because Anbasa bin Abi Sufyan is trustworthy from the men of Muslim. And from Aisha who said: I and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to sleep in a single cover while I was menstruating. If anything from me hit him, he washed its place and did not change it, and prayed in it. Then he would return, and if anything from me hit him...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: he did the same and did not change it, and prayed in it). Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Darimi via Yahya bin Saeed Al-Qattan: Narrated to me Jabir bin Subh said: I heard Khilas bin Amr say: I heard Aisha with it. This is a Sahih chain connected by hearing. Its men are all trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Jabir bin Subh - with a Damma on the un-dotted letter and Su-kun on the Ba - Ibn Ma'in declared him trustworthy, and in (Al-Taqrib) he is truthful. Ahmad narrated it from another path summarized with the wording: (He used to pray in the garment in which he had intercourse). He narrated it via Burd bin Sinan from Sulaiman bin Musa from her. Its men are trustworthy, but it is disconnected between Sulaiman and Aisha; there are sixty years or more between their deaths. In these hadiths and the preceding hadiths in the first issue, there is evidence for the obligation of purifying the body and clothes from impurity. Scholars differed regarding that. The Shafi'is held that removing it is a condition for the validity of prayer. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu): (And this was said by Abu Hanifa, Ahmad, and the majority of scholars from the Salaf and Khalaf. Regarding Malik, there are three narrations concerning removing impurity: The most correct and famous is that if he prays knowing of it, his prayer is not valid, and if he was ignorant or...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: forgetfully, it [the prayer] is valid; this is an old saying of Al-Shafi'i. The second: The prayer is invalid whether he knew, was ignorant, or forgot. The third: The prayer is valid with the impurity even if he was aware and deliberate, and removing it is a Sunnah. Our companions reported from Ibn Abbas and Sa'id bin Jubair something similar). Then Al-Nawawi argued for the view of the majority with the previously mentioned verse and the commands mentioned in the preceding Hadiths. It is not hidden that the utmost these commands imply is obligation (Wujub), and obligation does not necessitate conditionality (Shartiyyah). This is because something being a condition is a declarative legal ruling (Hukm Shar'i Wad'i) that is not established except by the Lawgiver's explicit statement that it is a condition, or by suspending the action upon it using a conditional particle, or by negating the action without it (1) a negation directed at validity, not perfection, or by negating the reward. It is not established merely by the command for it, as Al-Shawkani, may Allah have mercy on him, said. So the truth is that removing impurity is not a condition for the validity of prayer—which is Al-Shafi'i's saying in the old [school]—but rather it is obligatory due to these commands, and the one who opposes it sins. So whoever prays while there is impurity on his body or garment has abandoned an obligation, but as for his prayer being void as is the case with the loss of a condition of validity, then no, based on what you have known. The Hadith of Abu Sa'id coming next indicates this.
foot_note: 1. (1) Then some brothers noted that the Hadith of Ibn Samurah contains a negation of the action, meaning leaving the prayer if he sees something, and thus establishing the conditionality of the purity of the garment becomes necessary. This is apparent at first glance, so let it be contemplated and then edited.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (3 - Whoever knows while he is praying that he carries impurity, he must remove it and continue in his prayer and build upon what he had already prayed before removal, and his prayer is valid. For it is authentic from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he prayed one day, and when he was in part of his prayer, he removed his sandals and placed them to his left. When the people saw that, they removed their sandals. When he finished his prayer, he said: 'What is the matter with you that you cast off your sandals?' They said: 'We saw you cast off your sandals, so we cast off our sandals.' The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed Jibril came to me and informed me that there was filth - or he said: harm, and in a narration: impurity - in them, so I cast them off. So when one of you comes to the mosque, let him look at his sandals; if he sees filth - or he said: harm, and in a narration: impurity - in them, let him wipe them and pray in them.') It is from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, led us in prayer one day... etc. It was extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Darimi, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi, as well as Al-Tahawi in (Sharh al-Ma'ani), Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad, and the context belongs to him. The other narration in both places is a narration of his and a narration of others. They all extracted it via Hammad bin Salamah, except Abu Dawood, who [extracted it] from Hammad bin Zaid, both from Abu Na'ama al-Sa'di from Abu Nadra from him. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of Muslim), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, as well as Ibn al-Wazir in (Al-Rawd al-Basim), and it is as they said. Al-Nawawi also authenticated it in (Al-Majmu').

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban also extracted it. As for Al-Bayhaqi, he weakened it or attempted to weaken it by saying: (Hammad bin Salamah from Abu Na'ama from Abu Nadra; every one of them is differed over regarding his integrity). Thus he said, yet the three of them are trustworthy narrators relied upon by Muslim, and Al-Hafiz [Ibn Hajar] declared them trustworthy in (Al-Taqrib). Ibn al-Turkumani refuted this statement of Al-Bayhaqi in (Al-Jawhar al-Naqi) and elaborated on that well. Furthermore, Hammad bin Salamah was not alone in narrating it; rather, Ibn Zaid followed him [in narrating it] as preceded. Moreover, Al-Bayhaqi himself narrated a witness for it from the Hadith of Anas and said: (And its chain is acceptable [la ba'sa bihi]). He extracted it via Al-Hakim - and it is in (Al-Mustadrak) - Musa ibn Isma'il and Ibrahim bin al-Hajjaj said: Abdullah bin al-Muthanna told us from Thumamah from Anas bin Malik that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, never removed his sandals in prayer except once, so the people removed [theirs]. He said: ('What is the matter with you?') They said: 'You removed [yours], so we removed.' He said: ('Indeed Jibril, peace be upon him, informed me that there was filth in them'). Al-Bayhaqi said: (Abdullah bin al-Muthanna was alone in narrating it). I say: He is one of the narrators of Al-Bukhari, as is Thumamah, so it is authentic on his condition (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) And Al-Hakim also authenticated it, and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Even if Ibn al-Muthanna was spoken about regarding his memory, such that it was said in (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, makes many mistakes). I say: His Hadith in corroboration (Shawahid) is acceptable. Al-Haythami cited it in (Al-Majmu') and said: (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Awsat) and its narrators are the narrators of the Sahih, and Al-Bazzar narrated it briefly). It has another witness, which is Mursal, extracted by Abu Dawood: Musa - meaning Ibn Isma'il - told us: Aban told us: Qatadah told us: Bakr bin Abdullah told me from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding this. He said: In them was impurity (Khabath). And in both places: (Khabath). This is an authentic chain; all its narrators are trustworthy narrators of the Two Sheikhs. It has other connected witnesses with weakness in their chains; whoever wishes may review them in (Al-Talkhis). In summary, the Hadith, with these witnesses, is authentic and a proof with no doubt in it, and those whom you know among the Imams have authenticated it. The Hadith is clear evidence for what we argued. In the chapter, there is [a report] from Aisha, and it will come at the conclusion of the discussion on the fourth issue. Al-Khattabi said in (Al-Ma'alim): (I say: In it is jurisprudence that whoever prays while there is impurity on his garment of which he is unaware, his prayer is sufficient and there is no repetition upon him).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is what Al-Shafi'i held in the old [school], as Al-Bayhaqi said. The action of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, indicates this. Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Yazid bin Harun: Muhammad bin Mutarrif informed us from Zaid bin Muslim who said: I saw Ibn Umar praying in his Rida (upper garment) while there was blood on it, so Nafi' came to him, removed his Rida from him, placed his [own] Rida on him, and he continued in his prayer. And from Abdur-Razzaq: Ma'mar informed us from Al-Zuhri from Salim that while Ibn Umar was praying, he saw blood on his garment, so he left, signaled to them, they brought him water, he washed it, then completed what remained based on what had passed of his prayer and did not repeat. I say: This is the choice of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him. He said in (Chapter on Avoiding Impurity) from (Al-Ikhtiyarat Al-Ilmiyyah): (Whoever prays with impurity forgetfully or ignorantly, there is no repetition upon him. A group of scholars said this, because he whose intention is to avoid the prohibited, if he does it by mistake or forgetfulness, the act of worship is not invalidated by it). Ibn al-Qayyim said in (Ighathat al-Lahfan): (And from that - meaning what the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, made easy and the whisperers [those with OCD] made difficult - is what was given as a verdict by Abdullah bin Umar, Ata bin Abi Rabah, Sa'id bin al-Musayyib, Tawus, Salim, Mujahid, Al-Sha'bi, Ibrahim al-Nakha'i, Al-Zuhri, Yahya bin Sa'id al-Ansari, Al-Hakam, Al-Awza'i, Malik, Ishaq bin Rahwayh, Abu Thawr, Imam Ahmad in the most correct of the two narrations, and others: That if a man sees impurity on his body or garment after prayer, while not

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: knowing of it, or he knew of it but forgot it, or he did not forget it but was unable to remove it, that his prayer is valid and there is no repetition upon him). Al-Nawawi attributed the saying of this to the majority of scholars, then said in (Al-Majmu'): (Ibn al-Mundhir said: And I say this, and it is the school of Rabi'ah and Malik, and it is strong in evidence, and it is the chosen view). If what we went to is correct, the Hadith is evidence that removing impurity is not a condition for the validity of prayer, because he, peace and blessings be upon him, built upon what he had prayed before taking off [the sandals]. If it were a condition, he would have restarted the prayer, because the absence of the condition affects the absence of the conditioned, as established in the principles (Usul). Al-Shawkani said: (Those who say that removing impurity is one of the conditions for the validity of prayer used the Hadith as evidence, but it is as we informed you: against them, not for them. Because his continuation of the prayer he prayed before removing the sandals and not restarting it indicates that purity is not a condition. The majority answered this by saying that the intended meaning of 'filth' (Qadhar) is something repulsive like mucus, spittle, and the like, and it does not necessitate that 'filth' be impure (Najis), and that it is possible it was a small amount of blood which is pardoned, and Jibril informing him of it was so his garments would not be soiled by something repulsive. This answer is refuted by what was said in (Al-Bari') in his interpretation of His saying, Exalted is He: {Or one of you comes from the place of relieving himself (Al-Gha'it)} [Al-Ma'idah / 6] that He used 'Gha'it' as a metonym for filth (Qadhar), and the statement of

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Azhari: 'Najis (impure) is the filth (Qadhar) exiting from the human body.' So making the repulsive thing non-impure or a pardoned impurity is arbitrary. Jibril's informing during the state of prayer about the filth is apparently because of the impurity in it which must be avoided in prayer, not for fear of soiling, because if it were for that, he would have informed him before entering prayer, since sitting while wearing them is a likely time for soiling by what is on them. Furthermore, such an answer is not possible regarding the narration of 'impurity' (Khabath) mentioned in the chapter, due to the agreement among linguistic Imams and others that 'Al-Khabathayn' (the two impurities) are urine and feces). Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Ighathat al-Lahfan) after citing the Hadith: (Interpreting that as referring to repulsive pure things like mucus or similar is incorrect for several reasons: First: That is not called 'Khabath'. Second: One is not ordered to wipe that for prayer, for it does not invalidate it. Third: Sandals are not removed in prayer [for that], for it is an action without need, so its lowest state is dislike (Karahah). Fourth: Al-Daraqutni narrated in his (Sunan) in the Hadith of removal from the narration of Ibn Abbas that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed Jibril came to me and informed me that there was tick blood on them,' and 'Halam' are large ticks).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (4 - Prayer is permissible in several situations: First: In clothes that are suspected of impurity, like the clothes of a menstruating woman, a nanny, a wet nurse, and a child. For (He, peace and blessings be upon him, used to pray at night while Aisha was by his side and she was menstruating, and she had a sheet (Mirt) on her, and part of it was on him) and (He used to pray while carrying Umamah bint Zainab; when he bowed and prostrated, he put her down, and when he stood, he carried her [so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed while she was on his shoulder until he finished his prayer doing that with her]). The first Hadith is from the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, with the wording: (and I) using the first-person pronoun instead of: (and Aisha), and (and she), and with the wording: (and upon me) instead of: and upon her. It was extracted by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Ubaidullah ibn Abdullah bin Utbah from her. It has another path briefly with the wording: The Prophet of Allah used to pray while part of my sheet was upon him. Extracted by Al-Hakim and Ahmad from Qatadah from Kathirah bin Abi Kathir from Abu Iyad from her. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic chain), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Its narrators are all trustworthy narrators of the Two Sheikhs except Kathir bin Abi Kathir, who is the client of Abd al-Rahman bin Samurah, and Al-Ijli declared him trustworthy, and Ayyub also narrated from him. Abu Ya'la narrated it from her with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was praying and felt cold, so he said: ('O Aisha, drape your sheet over me'). She said: I am menstruating. He said: ('Indeed your menses is not in your hand'). Al-Haythami said: (Its chain is Hasan). It has a witness from the Hadith of Maimunah: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed while wearing a sheet, and [part of it] was upon some of his wives while she was menstruating and he was praying and it was upon him. Extracted by Abu Dawood and Abu Awanah, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad via Sufyan bin Uyaynah from Al-Shaibani from Abdullah bin Shadad from her. The wording belongs to Abu Dawood, and Ahmad has similar. Ibn Majah said: (Part of it upon him and upon her part of it). Al-Bayhaqi narrated it via Al-Shafi'i from Sufyan with the wording: (Part of it upon me and part of it upon him). Its chain is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. It is in Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad via other paths from Al-Shaibani with the wording: He used to pray while I was opposite him and I was menstruating, and perhaps his garment would touch me when he prostrated. The Hadith has another witness from the narration of Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman, who said: I spent the night with the family of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, one night. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood praying having the edge of the quilt upon him, and upon Aisha was [the other] edge of it, and she was menstruating, not praying.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Extracted by Ahmad: Abu Nu'aym told us: Yunus told us from Al-Walid bin Al-Aizar who said: Hudhayfah said. Al-Haythami said: (Narrated by Ahmad and its narrators are trustworthy). I say: All of them are narrators of the Two Sheikhs, but it has apparent disconnection. However, Ahmad also extracted it: Waki' told us from Yunus from Al-Aizar bin Hurayth from Hudhayfah with it briefly. So this is an authentic chain whose narrators are narrators of Muslim if Yunus heard it from Al-Aizar, and perhaps he heard it from his son Al-Walid bin Al-Aizar as in the first narration. And Allah knows best. (Al-Mirt): With Kasra on Meem and Sukoon on Ra. It says in (Al-Ma'alim): (A garment worn by men and women; it can be a waist wrapper (Izar) or a cloak (Rida), and it may be made of wool or silk mixture (Khazz) and other materials). The other Hadith is from the narration of Amr bin Sulaim Al-Zuraqi from Abu Qatadah Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, as well as Malik, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via paths from him. What is between the brackets is an addition in a narration of Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad, and it is authentic in chain on the condition of the Two Sheikhs.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Muslim extracted it but did not cite its wording. In a narration of his: I saw the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, leading the people. And in another of his and Abu Dawood's: Praying for the people. And in another for Abu Dawood that it was Dhuhr or Asr. Something similar to this story was reported from Abu Bakrah: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was praying: When he prostrated, Al-Hasan jumped onto his back and onto his neck, so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would lift him gently so as not to throw him. He said: He did that more than once... The Hadith. Extracted by Al-Tayalisi and Ahmad via Mubarak ibn Fadalah from Al-Hasan: Abu Bakrah informed me. This is a Hasan chain. They have another path from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah similar to it in Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in the biography of Al-Hasan bin Ali from (Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir) and Al-Hakim via Kamil bin Al-Ala' from Abu Salih from Abu Hurairah. Thus they said. Its narrators are narrators of Muslim except this Abu Salih; he is not Dhakwan but the client of Duba'ah. Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy, and in (Al-Taqrib): (Lenient in Hadith).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Haythami cited the Hadith in (Al-Majmu') and said: (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Bazzar briefly, and Ahmad's narrators are trustworthy). There is another story for Al-Hasan and Al-Husain; perhaps it will come in [the chapter of] Prostration, Allah willing. The Hadith, said Ibn al-Qayyim in (Al-Ighathah): (Is evidence for the permissibility of praying in the clothes of the nanny, the wet nurse, the menstruating woman, and the child as long as their impurity is not verified). Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (In it is evidence for the validity of the prayer of one who carries a human or a pure animal like a bird or sheep and others, and that the clothes of children and their bodies are pure until their impurity is verified... etc.). Then he said: (And it supports the school of Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, and those who agreed with him, that it is permissible to carry a boy or girl and other pure animals in obligatory and voluntary prayers, and that is permissible for the Imam, the follower, and the solitary worshiper. The companions of Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, interpreted it as applying to voluntary prayers and forbade permissibility of that in obligatory prayers. This interpretation is corrupt because the saying: (leading the people) is explicit or like explicit that it was in an obligatory prayer. Some Malikis claimed it is abrogated, some that it is specific to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and some that it was for necessity. All these claims are false and rejected, for there is no evidence for them nor necessity for them; rather the Hadith is authentic and explicit in the permissibility of that. It contains nothing contradicting the rules of Sharia, because the human is pure, and the impurity inside him is pardoned because it is in his stomach, and the clothes of children

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and their bodies are presumed pure. The evidences of Sharia mutually support this. Actions in prayer do not invalidate it if they are few or separated). Then he said: (So the correct view from which there is no deviation: The Hadith was to show permissibility and alert to these benefits, so it is permissible for us and a continuing law for Muslims until the Day of Judgment). This may be contradicted by the Hadith of Aisha also, who said: He used not to pray in the quilts of his wives. Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Bayhaqi via Ash'ath bin Abd al-Malik from Muhammad bin Sirin from Abdullah bin Shaqiq from her. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). I say: And its narrators are all trustworthy narrators of Muslim except this Ash'ath, who is trustworthy [Thiqah], so it is in (Al-Taqrib). Then Abu Dawood narrated it from Hammad from Hisham from Ibn Sirin from Aisha, and this is disconnected.
