Hammad said: (And I heard Sa'id bin Abi Sadaqah say: I asked Muhammad about it but he did not tell me, saying: I heard it a long time ago and I do not know from whom I heard it, nor do I know if I heard it from a reliable source or not, so ask about it).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: Likewise, Salamah bin Alqamah narrated it from Ibn Sirin and did not mention Shaqiq in its chain. Al-Bayhaqi extracted it. Ahmad also extracted it from him from Ibn Sirin who said: I was informed that Aisha said. And Qatadah narrated it from Ibn Sirin: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, disliked praying in the quilts of women. Extracted by Ahmad: Affan told us, he said: Hammam told us, he said: Qatadah told us with it. Its narrators are trustworthy narrators of the Six, but it is Mursal (disconnected), so it is weak, especially with this anomalous wording. Perhaps it is a narration by meaning, and this meaning is not correct, because his abstaining, peace and blessings be upon him, from a matter does not indicate his dislike, especially if it is established that he did it repeatedly as preceded in those Hadiths from Aisha, Maimunah, and Hudhayfah, which are affirmative (Muthbitah), while Aisha's Hadith is negating (Nafi), and the affirmative takes precedence over the negating in case of contradiction and inability to reconcile. Perhaps reconciliation here is possible by saying: Aisha in this Hadith of hers only negated the Prophet's, peace and blessings be upon him, *continuation* of praying in the quilts of his wives, based on what the form (Kana / He used to) indicates. 'Kana' does not negate that he used to do that sometimes. This reconciliation is strengthened by the fact that Aisha herself narrated his doing so, as in the first Hadith of this section. More explicit than it is what preceded in the second issue from her also with the wording: I and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to sleep in one sheet (Shi'ar) while I was menstruating. If

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: anything from me touched him, he washed its place and did not go beyond it and prayed in it... The Hadith. For its implication is that he used to pray in the Shi'ar if nothing from her touched it. (Shi'ar): is the garment that the human makes touch his body (hair/skin). And (Dithar): is what he wears over the clothes, which is the quilt. More explicit than all this is her other Hadith; she said: I was with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and upon us was our Shi'ar, and we had cast a garment (Kisa') over it. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, woke up, he took the Kisa' and wore it, then went out and prayed the Morning prayer. Then he sat, and a man said: O Messenger of Allah, this is a spot of blood. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, grabbed what was around it and sent it to me bundled in the hand of the boy and said: ('Wash this and dry it, then send it back to me'). So I called for my vessel, washed it, dried it, and returned it to him. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came at midday while it was upon him). But it is from the narration of Umm Yunus bint Shaddad, who said: My mother-in-law Umm Jahdar al-Amiriyyah told me from her. And their condition is not known as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (I do not know among women anyone accused [of lying] or anyone they abandoned). The Hadith was extracted by Abu Dawood. It is explicit regarding his prayer, peace be upon him, in the Kisa' in which he and his wife were wrapped until it became clear to him that there was a spot of blood in it, so he ordered it washed and did not repeat the prayer because of it. For if he had repeated it, it would have been transmitted to us. So - if authentic - it is

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: another proof that removing impurity is not a condition for the validity of prayer, which is the truth, Allah willing, as previously explained. In summary, the Hadith of Aisha which we are discussing does not imply negating the Prophet's, peace and blessings be upon him, prayer in the quilts of women and their clothes absolutely; rather, the intended meaning is negating his, peace and blessings be upon him, *persistence* in that. This is what the collection of Hadiths reported on this subject and the method of reconciling them indicate. And Allah knows best. (Second: On a mount that has been affected by impurity, because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed on a donkey while heading to Khaybar [voluntarily]). The Hadith has an authentic chain. It was extracted by Malik, and from him Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, all from Malik from Amr bin Yahya Al-Mazini from Abu Al-Hubab Sa'id bin Yasar from Abdullah bin Umar that he said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, praying on a donkey... etc. Malik was followed in it; Ahmad extracted it from Al-Thawri, Hammad bin Salamah, and Za'idah, all three from Amr bin Yahya with it. The addition between the brackets is Al-Thawri's. This Hadith was faulted due to Amr bin Yahya being alone in mentioning the 'donkey' in it, as Ibn Abd al-Barr said, because what is known and established in the (Two Sahihs) and others from Ibn Umar

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and others is prayer on the camel. This is not a damaging flaw in my view because Amr bin Yahya is trustworthy as Al-Nawawi, Al-Dhahabi, and Al-Asqalani in (Al-Taqrib) said. He narrated a matter that is possible to occur, so it must be accepted. The narration of others from the trustworthy narrators using the word 'camel' does not contradict or oppose it due to the possibility that the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, rode on this one time and on that another time. I detailed the discussion on the authenticity of the Hadith and refuting its flaw in (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad 'ala Zad Al-Ma'ad), so let it be reviewed. The Hadith has a witness from the Hadith of Anas bin Malik: That he saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, praying on a donkey while riding to Khaybar, and the Qiblah was behind him. Extracted by Al-Nasa'i via Muhammad bin Ajlan from Yahya bin Sa'id from him. This is a Hasan chain; all its narrators are trustworthy except Ibn Ajlan, regarding whom there is some discussion, but he is Hasan in Hadith. Al-Hafiz attributed the Hadith in (Al-Fath) to Al-Sarraj only, then said: (Its chain is Hasan). I say: Except that Al-Nasa'i said after citing it: (The correct view is that it is stopped [Mawquf] at Anas). I say: Malik extracted it likewise as Mawquf via Yahya bin Sa'id who said: I saw Anas bin Malik on a journey praying on a donkey facing other than

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the Qiblah, bowing and prostrating by gesturing without placing his face on anything). Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad extracted it from another path via Anas bin Sirin who said: We received Anas when he arrived from Sham, so we met him at Ain al-Tamr. I saw him praying on a donkey and his face was to that side - meaning to the left of the Qiblah - so I said: I saw you praying to other than the Qiblah? He said: Had I not seen the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, doing it, I would not have done it. Al-Bukhari wrote a chapter for it (Chapter: Voluntary Prayer on a Donkey). Ibn Rashid said: (His intent is that it is not a condition for voluntary prayer on an animal that its excrement be pure; rather, the ruling for riding beasts is one, provided he does not touch the impurity. Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid said: It is taken from this Hadith the purity of the donkey's sweat because avoiding touching it is impossible, especially if the riding time is long and sweat is probable). Thus in (Al-Fath) by Ibn Hajar. Then he said: (In this Hadith are benefits other than what passed: that whoever prays on a place containing impurity which he does not touch directly, his prayer is valid, because the animal is not free of impurity even if on its outlet). The Hadith was given a chapter by Abu Al-Barakat Majd ad-Din Ibn Taymiyyah in (Al-Muntaqa) as (Chapter: Whoever prays on an impure mount or one affected by impurity) and he cited in it

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the Hadith of Ibn Umar and the Hadith of Anas. Al-Shawkani said in (his explanation): (The author argued with the two Hadiths for the permissibility of praying on an impure mount and a mount affected by impurity. This only holds based on the view that the donkey is essentially impure. Yes, it is valid to use it as evidence for the permissibility of praying on what contains impurity because the donkey is never free from being soiled by it). The Hadith also contains evidence for the permissibility of voluntary prayer on a riding beast, which is agreed upon, and the discussion will come in its place. (Third: In the two sandals, for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed in them, and that has been transmitted via Tawatur (successive narration) from him. However, one must look at them before starting the prayer; if he sees filth, he rubs them on the ground then prays in them). Know that the prayer of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in sandals was narrated from him by a group of Companions. I have mentioned the Hadiths of those whose chain to him is established in our large book (Sifat Salat al-Nabi, peace and blessings be upon him). They are Anas bin Malik, Abu Hurairah, Aisha, Ibn Mas'ud, Abdullah bin al-Shikhkhir, Abdullah bin Amr, and Aws bin Abi Aws. Therefore, Imam Al-Tahawi explicitly stated that: (The reports are Mutawatir from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding his prayer in his sandals). He cited many of them with their chains. We mention here one Hadith from them and refer for the rest to our book referred to.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Sa'id bin Yazid Al-Azdi said: I asked Anas bin Malik: Did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, use to pray in sandals? He said: Yes. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad. Al-Tirmidhi said: (The Hadith of Anas is Hasan Sahih, and the practice is upon this according to the people of knowledge). The scholar Professor Ahmad Muhammad Shakir said in his commentary on Al-Tirmidhi: (Yes, we know of no disagreement among the people of knowledge regarding the permissibility of praying in sandals in the mosque and outside the mosque. But look at the state of the common Muslims now, even those who attribute themselves to knowledge: How they disapprove of one who prays in his sandals! Yet he was not ordered to take them off for prayer; rather he was ordered to look at them, and if there was harm in them, to rub them on the ground, and that is their purification. They were not ordered regarding them with other than that). Ibn al-Qayyim said in (Ighathat al-Lahfan min Maka'id al-Shaytan) summarized: (And among the things that the hearts of the whisperers [people with OCD] do not find comfort in: Prayer in sandals. Yet it is the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, by action from him and by command). Then he mentioned the Hadith of Anas and the Hadith of Shaddad bin Aws coming shortly, then said: (Imam Ahmad was asked: Does a man pray in his sandals? He said: Yes, by Allah. You see the people of whispers, if one of them is tested with funeral prayer in his sandals, he stands on his heels as if standing on hot coals so as not to pray in them).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Prayer in them is a choice due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (If one of you prays, let him wear his sandals or put them between his legs and not harm others with them). It is from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi via Al-Awza'i: Muhammad bin Al-Walid told us from Sa'id bin Abi Sa'id Al-Maqburi from his father from him. This is an authentic chain on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. Then Al-Hakim extracted it via Iyad bin Abdullah Al-Qurashi from Sa'id from Abu Hurairah and did not say: (from his father). He said: (Authentic on the condition of Muslim), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Al-Iraqi said: (Abu Dawood narrated it with an authentic chain, and Al-Mundhiri weakened it, which is not good). I say: Perhaps Al-Mundhiri's weakening of it is due to this variation regarding Sa'id, which is a variation that does not harm, Allah willing, as I clarified in (Sifat Salat al-Nabi, peace and blessings be upon him). (However, it is recommended to pray in them sometimes to differ from the Jews and those who are excessive like them, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Differ from the Jews, for they do not pray in their sandals nor their leather socks). The Hadith has an authentic chain. Extracted by Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim, and from him Al-Bayhaqi from Qutaibah bin Sa'id: Marwan bin Mu'awiyah Al-Fazari told us

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: from Hilal bin Maimun Al-Ramli from Ya'la bin Shaddad bin Aws from his father elevated with it. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic chain). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. I say: All its narrators are trustworthy. Ibn Hibban also extracted it in his (Sahih). There is no defect in its chain as Al-Shawkani said. Al-Munawi transmitted in (Sharh Al-Jami') from Zain Al-Iraqi that he said: (Its chain is Hasan). It has a witness from the Hadith of Anas which I mentioned in (Sifat Salat al-Nabi, peace and blessings be upon him). The Hadith is evidence for what we mentioned of the recommendation of praying in sandals. What prevented us from asserting obligation is the Hadith of Abu Hurairah before it, as well as some Hadiths referred to shortly, such as the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr who said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, praying barefoot and wearing sandals. Extracted by Abu Dawood, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad via Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather. This is a Hasan or Sahih chain according to the famous difference regarding it. Similar to it is the Hadith of Abu Hurairah and Aisha. His praying, peace and blessings be upon him, barefoot sometimes is evidence for the lack of obligation. Al-Shawkani said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The Hadiths of the chapter are reconciled by making the Hadith of Abu Hurairah and what follows it divert the mentioned commands reasoned by differing from the People of the Book from obligation to recommendation, because giving choice and delegating to will after those commands does not negate recommendation, as in the Hadith: (Between every two Adhans is a prayer for whoever wishes). This is the most just of the schools and strongest in my view). Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said: (The wisdom of praying in sandals is differing from the People of the Book as established, and fear that one might be harmed by his sandals if he takes them off, along with [the benefit] in wearing them of protecting them from a thief or animal that might soil his sandal). Al-Munawi quoted him in (Fayd al-Qadir). (5 - Purity of the place is also obligatory due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, to the Bedouin who urinated in the mosque: (Indeed these mosques are not suitable for anything of filth, urine, and toilet needs). So he ordered a man who brought a bucket of water and poured it over it). The Hadith is authentic. Extracted by Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Ikrimah bin Ammar: Ishaq bin Abi Talhah told us: Anas bin Malik - who is Ishaq's uncle - told me, saying: While we were in the mosque with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, a Bedouin came and stood urinating in the mosque. The Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Mah Mah (Stop, Stop)! He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Do not interrupt him, leave him). So they left him until he urinated. Then the Messenger of Allah called him and said to him... The Hadith. And its completion:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (They are only for the remembrance of Allah Almighty, prayer, and reading the Quran) or as the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said. He said: So he ordered a man from the people, who brought a bucket of water and poured it over it. The context is Muslim's, and it does not contain: (and toilet needs); rather that is in Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi in a narration of his. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah who said: A Bedouin entered the mosque while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was sitting. He said: (O Allah forgive me and Muhammad and do not forgive anyone with us). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, laughed and said: (You have restricted something vast). Then he turned away, until he was in a corner of the mosque, he spread his legs and began urinating. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood up to him and said: (Indeed this House was built for the remembrance of Allah and prayer, and it is not to be urinated in). Then he called for a bucket of water and poured it over it. He said: The Bedouin says after he understood: So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, stood up to me - may my father and mother be his ransom - he did not curse, nor scold, nor hit. Extracted by Ibn Majah and Ahmad via Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah from him. This is a Hasan chain. Ibn Hibban also narrated it as in (Al-Fath). The two Hadiths are in the (Two Sahihs) and others from Anas and Abu Hurairah in brief without the point of witness from it, and it has passed.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Hadith is evidence for what we mentioned of the obligation of the purity of the place. Sheikh al-Islam said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat): (Purity of the spot is evidenced by the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in the Hadith of the Bedouin: (Indeed these mosques are not suitable for anything of urine and excrement) and his command to pour water over the urine. He, peace be upon him, ordered the purification of the place of prayer, and the command implies obligation). Also indicating that is the Hadith of Jabir, which is: (And his saying: (And the earth was made for me [good/pure], a means of purification and a mosque, so any man whom prayer reaches, let him pray where it reaches him). It is a portion of the Hadith of Jabir with the wording: (I was given five things no one before me was given: I was aided with awe for a month's journey. The earth was made for me a mosque and a means of purification, so any man of my nation whom prayer reaches, let him pray. Spoils of war were made lawful for me and were not lawful for anyone before me. I was given intercession. And the Prophet used to be sent to his people specifically, and I was sent to mankind generally). Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad from him. The context is Al-Bukhari's, and the sentence mentioned above is Ahmad's. What is between the brackets is an addition for Muslim and Al-Darimi, and it is established in the Hadith of Anas also with the wording: (Every good/pure land was made for me a mosque and a means of purification).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Ibn Al-Mundhir and Ibn Al-Jarud with an authentic chain as in (Al-Fath). Al-Iraqi also authenticated it as in (Al-Nayl) where he said: (It is established with the addition (Tayyibah / Good) from the narration of Anas in Ibn Al-Sarraj in his (Musnad). Al-Iraqi said: With an authentic chain). Then Al-Shawkani said: (It indicates that the intended meaning of the earth mentioned in the Hadith is the pure permissible earth, because impure earth is not 'Tayyibah' linguistically, and usurped land is not 'Tayyibah' legally). So the implication of the Hadith is that one must avoid foul land in prayer, but neither it nor the Hadith of the Bedouin before it indicates the conditionality (Shartiyyah) of the purity of the place. The statement regarding it is like the statement regarding the conditionality of the purity of the body and garment, and the detailed discussion on them has preceded. I did not find for those who say it is a condition any authentic evidence other than what preceded there. As for the Hadith of Ibn Umar with the wording: He forbade praying in six places... The Hadith, which Al-Rafi'i and the author of (Al-Muhadhdhab) used as proof for conditionality, it is weak and not permissible to use as proof, as clarified by Al-Nawawi and Al-Asqalani, and we discussed it in (Naqd al-Taj). Therefore, Al-Nawawi said after discussing the Hadith: (The evidence for conditionality is what preceded at the beginning of the chapter. As for the Hadith mentioned here, it is not valid to use as proof. Among what is used as proof is the Hadith of the Bedouin's urine in the mosque and the Prophet's saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Pour over it a bucket of water). Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: This does not imply conditionality but rather implies obligation as preceded. Likewise is what he referred to from before; all of that are commands that imply nothing but obligation. We have quoted Al-Nawawi's words which he referred to at the conclusion of the second issue and clarified there what is sufficient, so review it. (6 - Prayer is not valid in ten places: First: The Graveyard, which is the place where one human or more is buried, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (The earth is all a mosque except the graveyard and the bathhouse). It is the same in that whether the grave is his Qiblah, or to his right, or to his left, or behind him. But facing it in prayer is more severe due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (The curse of Allah is upon the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques) and his saying: (Indeed, among the worst of people are those whom the Hour overtakes while they are alive, and those who take graves as mosques)). The first Hadith is from the narration of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Hazm, and Ahmad via Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad; and Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Al-Hakim also, and Al-Bayhaqi via Abd al-Aziz bin Muhammad Al-Darawardi; and Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Hazm, and Ahmad via Hammad bin Salamah; all three from Amr bin Yahya Al-Ansari from his father from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri elevated with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then Ahmad extracted it via Muhammad bin Ishaq from Amr with it with the wording: (Every earth is a mosque and a means of purification except the graveyard and the bathhouse). So Ibn Ishaq added in it: (and a means of purification), which is an anomalous weak addition. The Hadith without it is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs as Al-Hakim said and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. As for Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Bayhaqi, they faulted it because Al-Thawri narrated it from Amr bin Yahya from his father from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in Mursal form without mentioning Abu Sa'id. Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad extracted it thus via Yazid bin Harun from Al-Thawri. This fault-finding is strange after the agreement of those four trustworthy narrators on connecting it (Wasl). Connection is an addition that must be accepted. Moreover, Al-Thawri connected it in some narrations. Al-Daraqutni said in (Al-Ilal) as in (Al-Talkhis): Ja'far bin Muhammad the Mu'adhin - trustworthy - told us: Al-Sari bin Yahya told us: Abu Nu'aym and Qabisah told us: Sufyan told us from Amr bin Yahya from his father from Abu Sa'id connected. He said: (The Mursal is the preserved one). Thus he said. Even if that is correct specifically regarding Al-Thawri's narration, it is not correct in the narration of others. Therefore, the author of (Al-Imam) said: (The gist of what Mursal is faulted with, if the one connecting it is trustworthy, then it is accepted). Al-Hafiz said: (Ibn Dihyah erred grossly saying in his book (Al-Tanwir): This is not authentic from any path.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Thus he said: He was not correct). He said in (Al-Fath): (Its narrators are trustworthy, but there is difference regarding its connection and disconnection (Irsal), yet Al-Hakim and Ibn Hibban judged it authentic despite that). Therefore Ibn Hazm strengthened the Hadith and refuted those who faulted it with Irsal. The Hadith has another path via Yahya Al-Ansari which is safe from all this difference. Al-Hakim extracted it, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, via Umarah bin Ghaziyyah from Yahya bin Umarah Al-Ansari from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri elevated with it. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. Then Al-Hafiz said: (I say: And it has witnesses, among them the Hadith of Abdullah bin Umar elevated: He forbade prayer in the graveyard. Extracted by Ibn Hibban. And among them the Hadith of Ali: Indeed my beloved forbade me to pray in the graveyard. Extracted by Abu Dawood). I say: Ali's Hadith will be discussed shortly, Allah willing. Among its witnesses also is the Hadith of Anas: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade prayer between graves. Al-Haythami said: (Al-Bazzar narrated it and its narrators are narrators of the Sahih). After writing what preceded, I saw Al-Munawi in (Fayd al-Qadir) quoting from Ibn Hibban that he authenticated the Hadith. And from Ibn Taymiyyah that he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Its chains are good, and whoever spoke regarding it did not exhaust its paths). Then I saw it in (Al-Iqtida) by Sheikh al-Islam. The Second Hadith is from the narration of Aisha and Ibn Abbas together, who said: When death descended upon the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he began casting a Khamisah (sheet) of his over his face. When he felt distressed by it, he uncovered it from his face and said while he was like that... so he mentioned it. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad via Ubaidullah bin Abdullah bin Utbah from her. Ahmad added in a narration of his: He forbids that for his Ummah. It contains Ibn Ishaq, and he used 'an'an (from). It has another path from her alone with the wording (May Allah curse) and the rest is like it. She added: She said: Had it not been for that, his grave would have been made prominent, but he feared it would be taken as a mosque. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad via Urwah from her. It has a third path in Ahmad via Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from her, and its chain is authentic on the condition of the Six. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah like the Hadith of Aisha, extracted by Muslim via Yazid bin Al-Asamm from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: It is also with Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Ahmad, and Muhammad in his (Muwatta), all of them from Malik from Al-Zuhri from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from Abu Huraira, raised [to the Prophet] with the wording (May Allah fight [curse]...). Yunus followed him [narrating] from Al-Zuhri in Muslim, and a group of trustworthy narrators in Ahmad. Qatadah followed Al-Zuhri [narrating] from Sa'id, extracted by Ibn Abi Shaybah in (Al-Musannaf). It has a third path from Abu Huraira with the wording: (O Allah, do not make my grave an idol. Allah cursed a people who took the graves of their prophets as mosques). Ahmad extracted it: Sufyan told us from Hamzah bin Al-Mughirah from Suhail bin Abi Salih from his father from him. This is a Sahih chain; all its men are trustworthy men of Muslim, except Hamzah bin Al-Mughirah, who is Al-Makhzumi, and he is trustworthy without dispute. Al-Haythami attributed it to Abu Ya'la only and said: (It contains Ishaq bin Abi Isra'il, and there is speech regarding him due to his pausing regarding the Quran [createdness issue], but the rest of his men are trustworthy).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: He is trustworthy in himself, and Ibn Ma'in, Ahmad, and others have declared him trustworthy. The mentioned speech does not harm him regarding narration. Moreover, Al-Haythami overlooked the fact that the Hadith is in (Al-Musnad) via a path other than this one, as you saw. So Glory be to Him who does not err or forget. The Hadith has other witnesses which I cited and extracted in (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad) from the Book of Funerals, so we will not prolong by mentioning them here. The third Hadith is from the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him. Ahmad and Ibn Abi Shaybah in (Al-Musannaf) extracted it from the path of Asim bin Abi Al-Nujud from Shaqiq from him. This is a Hasan chain; its men are the men of the two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim], except that they narrated from Ibn Abi Al-Nujud in conjunction with others, and he is good (Hasan) in Hadith. Regarding the Hadith, Al-Haythami said: (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) and its chain is Hasan), and he overlooked its presence in (Al-Musnad). Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah attributed it in many of his books - like (Minhaj Al-Sunnah) - to Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih). He also attributed it in (Iqtida' Al-Sirat Al-Mustaqim) and said: (Its chain is good). I say: I found another path for the Hadith extracted by Ahmad as well: 'Affan told us: Qais told us: Al-A'mash informed us from Ibrahim from Ubaidah Al-Salmani from Abdullah bin Mas'ud raised [to the Prophet] with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Indeed, some eloquence is magic. And the worst of people are those whom the Hour overtakes while they are alive, and those who take graves as mosques). This is also a Hasan chain; all its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Qais, who is Ibn Al-Rabi', and he is good (Hasan) in Hadith, especially in corroborations. So the Hadith, with the sum of the two paths, is Sahih to me. And Allah knows best. Know that using the Hadith as evidence for what we mentioned is based on one of the two opinions in interpreting it, which is that the meaning of "taking" is: facing the grave. Al-Baidawi said: (Since the Jews and Christians used to prostrate to the graves of their prophets out of glorification for their status and make them a Qiblah turning towards them in prayer, and they took them as idols - the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, cursed them and forbade the Muslims from the like of that). The Hadith, according to us, has a more general meaning than what Al-Baidawi mentioned, as will be clarified shortly, Allah willing. Among the wonders of understanding that clashes with the intent of the Hadith of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him - if we do not say with the text itself - is Al-Baidawi's statement at the end of his speech, which is: (As for the one who takes a mosque near a righteous person or prays in a graveyard intending by it to seek blessings from his spirit or the arrival of an effect from the effects of his worship to him, not glorification for him nor turning towards him, then there is no harm upon him). Thus he said, and what it contains of the traces of paganism and misguidance is not hidden. And the infallible is he whom Allah protects.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Therefore, the scholars critiqued him. Al-Munawi said after quoting this statement of his: (However, in the report of the two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim], there is a dislike for building a mosque over graves absolutely, and the intended is the graves of Muslims, fearing that the graves would be worshipped in them, due to the context of the report: 'O Allah, do not make my grave an idol to be worshipped'). Imam Muhammad, the student of Abu Hanifa, explicitly stated the dislike of taking a mosque *near* a grave, as his text on that will come. The expression (near/at) is more general than his saying: (above) or (on), as is obvious. So whoever builds a mosque beside a righteous person has built it *near* him. Therefore, the words of Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, are a refutation of Al-Baidawi in this innovated opinion of his. Al-San'ani also refuted him in (Subul al-Salam), saying: (His saying: 'not for glorification for him', it is said: taking mosques near him and intending to seek blessings by him is glorification for him. Furthermore, the Hadiths of prohibition are absolute, and there is no evidence for the reasoning he mentioned. The apparent meaning is that the reason is blocking the means [to Shirk] and distancing from resembling the idol worshippers who glorify inanimate objects that neither benefit nor harm, and because spending money on that is futility and waste devoid of benefit entirely). He said: (The evils of what is built over graves, such as shrines and domes, cannot be counted). The first Hadith indicates the prohibition of prayer in the graveyard according to the mentioned detail, due to the generality of the Hadith and because prohibition primarily implies forbiddenness (Tahrim). Some went to the invalidity of prayer therein, which is probable, and Allah knows best. Ibn Hazm adopted this in (Al-Muhalla), and narrated from Ahmad that he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Whoever prays in a graveyard or towards a grave must repeat it forever). Then he said: (And Abu Hanifa, Al-Awza'i, and Sufyan disliked praying towards a grave, in a graveyard, and on a grave. Malik did not see any harm in that, and some of his imitators argued for him that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed over the grave of the poor black woman). Ibn Hazm said: (This is strange indeed, that these people oppose this report in what came in it, so they do not permit the funeral prayer over one who has been buried, yet they deem permissible - with what has no trace or indication from Him - opposing the established Sunan). He said: (All these reports are truth, so prayer is not lawful where we mentioned except the funeral prayer, for it is prayed in the graveyard and on the grave whose owner has been buried, as the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did. We forbid what he forbade, and we count it as closeness to Allah Almighty to do as he did. His command and prohibition are truth, and his action is truth, and whatever is other than that is falsehood, and praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds). Al-Shawkani said after recounting the schools of scholars on the issue: (The mutawatir [widely transmitted] Hadiths of prohibition, as that Imam [Ibn Hazm] said, do not fall short of indicating prohibition (Tahrim), which is the true meaning for it. It is established in the principles (Usul) that prohibition indicates the corruption (fasad) of the prohibited act. So the truth is prohibition and invalidity, because the corruption implied by prohibition is synonymous with invalidity, without differentiating between praying *on* the grave or [in] graveyards and everything to which the term graveyard applies). Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Prayer is not valid in a graveyard nor towards it, and the prohibition of that is to block the means to Shirk. A group of our companions mentioned that a graveyard is three graves or more, but there is no such distinction in the words of Ahmad and the generality of his companions. Rather, the generality of their words, their reasoning, and their evidence necessitate the prevention of prayer at a single grave among the graves, and this is the correct view. A 'Maqbara' (graveyard) is wherever burial takes place, not [necessarily] that it is the plural of grave. Our companions said: Everything included in the name of graveyard from what is around the graves, one does not pray in it. This determines that the prohibition encompasses the sanctity of the single grave and its courtyard added to it. Al-Amidi and others mentioned that prayer is not permissible in it, i.e., the mosque whose Qiblah is towards the grave, unless there is another barrier between the wall and the graveyard. Some mentioned: This is the explicit text of Ahmad). They differed regarding the cause (Illah) of the prohibition of prayer in a graveyard. It was said: Impurity. And it was said: Resemblance to the People of the Book and blocking the means to Shirk, as preceded in the words of Sheikh Al-Islam and others. This is what is apparent from the sum of Hadiths reported in this chapter. Some have passed and some will come. Our later scholars from the Hanafis proceeded upon this. Ibn Abidin said in his (Hashiyah): (They differed regarding its cause (meaning: the dislike). It was said: Because therein are the bones of the dead and their pus, which is impure. And there is a view regarding this (1). And it was said: Because the origin of idol worship is taking the graves of the righteous as mosques. And it was said: Because it is a resemblance to the Jews. And he followed this in the Hashiyah).
foot_note: 1. (1) Perhaps its basis is that transformation (Istihala) according to us is a purifier. End quote from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This last opinion is the one relied upon by Al-Tahtawi in his (Hashiyah 'ala Maraqi Al-Falah). The text of his words is: (His saying: 'And in the Maqbara' (graveyard) with the three vowellings of the Ba [Maqbara, Maqbira, Maqbura], because it is a resemblance to the Jews and Christians. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Allah's curse be upon the Jews and Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques). Whether it [the grave] is above him, behind him, or under what he stands upon. The graves of the Prophets, peace be upon them, are excepted; prayer in them is not disliked absolutely, whether dug up or not, provided the grave is not in the direction of the Qiblah, because they are alive in their graves. Do you not see that the resting place of Ismail, peace be upon him, is in the Hijr under the water spout, and that between the Black Stone and Zamzam are the graves of seventy prophets? Furthermore, that mosque is the best place to seek for prayer, unlike the graves of others. Stated in (Sharh Al-Mishkat)). All this is the speech of Al-Tahtawi, and it is flawed speech that contradicts itself. For if he explicitly states and reasons the dislike with resemblance to the Jews and Christians - and they used to take the graves of their prophets as mosques - how can he except the graves of Prophets when resemblance to the disbelievers is realized by praying in them? Yes, perhaps this exception would be valid if the cause of dislike was impurity, due to the purity of their graves, peace be upon them. However, this exception is not valid absolutely after his cursing, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, of those who took the graves of Prophets as mosques and his forbidding his Ummah from that, as will come.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I fear that Al-Tahtawi was led into this clear contradiction from the direction of blind imitation (Taqleed), which often does not let its owner think about what he writes or says. He apparently quoted the correct reasoning from some scholars who cannot be imagined to allow the exception, then he quoted the exception from some who hold the other cause, which is impurity, and it is reported from them. What indicates this is his saying: (dug up or not), for this is only valid to be said based on holding the view of this outweighed cause. From it branches the saying of the difference between a dug-up graveyard and a non-dug-up one regarding other than the graves of Prophets. If what we went to is not the truth, then what is the meaning of this statement here? And what is the meaning of the exception that clashes with the text? It might be said: The text's meaning according to Al-Tahtawi is not general, but rather means facing [the grave], as previously mentioned from Al-Baidawi. His saying after the exception indicates this: (provided the grave is not in the direction of the Qiblah). So with this restriction, he did not clash with the text according to his understanding. So I say: But his saying is problematic for him: (Whether it was above him or behind him...) etc. He said that about the Hadith in a way that implies it is general to him. Then what is the reasonable difference between preventing all of that in the graves of non-Prophets and permitting it in their graves with the mentioned restriction, knowing that the danger to the creed (Aqidah) from praying at them absolutely is greater than praying at others? After writing the above, I returned to the explanation of (Al-Mishkat) named: (Mirqat Al-Mafatih Sharh Mishkat Al-Masabih) by Sheikh Ali Al-Qari, and it became clear to me that Al-Tahtawi quoted most of...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...his words, but he did a poor job in quoting and rearranged [the text] such that he corrupted the meaning, leading to the cautions we pointed out. It also became clear and verified from it that he only quoted the exception from some of those who went to the reasoning of impurity. Upon this [reasoning] came the detail mentioned by Al-Tahtawi in his saying: (Whether...) etc. He quoted it from the speech of Ibn Hajar - meaning Al-Haytami - and the text of his words regarding that is: (The commentator pointed out the problem of praying at the grave of Ismail, peace be upon him, while it is disliked in a graveyard. He answered that its place is a dug-up graveyard due to its impurity. All this is heedlessness of their saying: The graves of Prophets are excepted, so prayer in them is not disliked absolutely because they are alive in their graves. Even conceding [the argument], his answer is incorrect due to their explicit statement of the dislike of prayer in the graveyard of non-Prophets even if not dug up, because it is adjacent to impurity, and adjacency to it in prayer is disliked whether it is above him, behind him, or under what he is standing on). End of what is in (Al-Mirqat). As for what Al-Tahtawi argued, following the explanation of (Al-Mishkat), regarding the superiority of prayer at the grave of Ismail, peace be upon him, and the grave of the seventy prophets, Al-Qari himself answered it in the mentioned explanation by saying: (And in it is that the trace of the grave of Ismail and others is obliterated, so it is not valid to use it as evidence). We say: Suppose it is not obliterated, that does not indicate that the virtue of the prayer is because of it. Do you not see that the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayer in it is worth a thousand prayers in...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...other than it of mosques except Al-Masjid Al-Haram, as is authentically reported from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him? It is known that he said that before he, peace be upon him, was buried in the Noble Chamber and before it was incorporated into the Prophetic Mosque. So does the presence of the Noble Grave in it now necessitate saying: The virtue of prayer in it is because of the Noble Grave? No! Only the ignorant commoners say that. Likewise, the virtue of prayer at the grave of Ismail and others does not imply that it is because of the graves. How could it be when he, peace be upon him, forbade taking them as mosques and cursed those who did that? All this is said assuming the establishment of those graves in that place, which is not established according to the Muhaddithin (Hadith scholars). Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in (Al-Mawdu'at): (The scholar Sheikh Muhammad bin Al-Jazari said: Specifying the grave of a prophet other than our Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, is not authentic. Yes, our master Ibrahim, peace be upon him, is in that village, but not specifically in that spot. End quote). I say: Sheikh Al-Islam reported similar to this in (Al-Iqtida') from more than one scholar. Then he mentioned: (Indeed the Muslims have agreed upon what they knew by necessity from the religion of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, that prayer at a grave - whatever grave it may be - has no virtue for that reason, nor does prayer in that spot have any merit of good at all; rather, it has the merit of evil). He said before that by a page: (Know that some jurists believed that the reason for the dislike of prayer in a graveyard is only due to it being a place of impurity because of what mixes with the soil from the pus of the dead. He built upon this...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...belief the difference between a new and old graveyard, and whether there is a barrier between him and the soil or not. The impurity of the ground prevents prayer on it whether it is a graveyard or not. But the greater intent of the prohibition of prayer at graves is not this; for he clarified that the Jews and Christians, when a righteous man among them died, would build a mosque over his grave). Then he said: (And it was narrated from him that he said: 'O Allah, do not make my grave an idol to be worshipped. Allah's anger is intense upon a people who took the graves of their prophets as mosques.'). Then he mentioned the Hadith of Aisha and others which preceded, and the Hadith of Jundub which will come: (Those before you used to take graves as mosques. Beware, do not take graves as mosques, for I forbid you from that). Then he said: (So all this clarifies to you that the reason is not the presumption of impurity, but rather the presumption of taking them as idols, as Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'And I dislike that a creature be magnified until his grave is made a mosque, fearing Fitnah (temptation/trial) for him and for those after him among the people.' Abu Bakr Al-Athram mentioned this meaning in (Nasikh Al-Hadith wa Mansukhuhu) and others from the companions of Ahmad and all scholars. For the grave of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, or a righteous man was not dug up, and a single grave has no impurity on it. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, alerted to the cause by saying: 'O Allah, do not make my grave an idol to be worshipped' and by his saying: 'Those before you used to take graves as mosques, so do not take them as mosques.' Those people used to take graves where there was no impurity. And because Muslim narrated in his (Sahih) from Abu Marthad Al-Ghanawi that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Do not pray towards graves and do not sit on them.' And because he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'When...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the righteous man among them died, they built a mosque over his grave and depicted those images in it. Those are the worst of creation with Allah on the Day of Resurrection.' So he combined statues and graves. Also, Al-Lat was worshipped due to the glorification of the grave of a righteous man who was there). He said later, after mentioning the first cause: (This cause [impurity] has a dispute regarding its correctness due to the difference of scholars regarding the impurity of grave soil. It is from the issues of transformation (Istihala), and most Muslim scholars say: Impurity becomes pure by transformation. This is the school of Abu Hanifa, Ahl al-Zahir, and one of the two views in the school of Malik and Ahmad. It is established in the (Sahih) that the mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was a garden for Banu Najjar containing graves of the polytheists, palm trees, and ruins. So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered regarding the palm trees and they were cut, the ruins and they were leveled, and the graves and they were dug up. He placed the palm trees in the direction of the Qiblah. If the soil of graves were impure, the soil of the polytheists' graves would be impure, and the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, would have ordered the removal of that soil, for that soil must have mixed with other soil). Then he mentioned the second cause, then said: (This cause is correct by their agreement. Those who reasoned with the first - like Al-Shafi'i and others - also reasoned with this one and disliked it because of the Fitnah in it. Likewise, the Imams from the companions of Ahmad and Malik, like Abu Bakr Al-Athram the companion of Ahmad and others, reasoned with this second one as well, even if some of them might reason with the first. Allah the Exalted said: {And said, 'Never leave your gods and never leave Wadd or Suwa' or Yaghuth and Ya'uq and Nasr. And already they have misled many.} [Nuh / 23-24]. Ibn Abbas and others from the Salaf mentioned that these are names of righteous people who were in the people of Noah. When...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...they died, they devoted themselves to their graves and made statues of them. Then when a long time passed over them, they worshipped them. Al-Bukhari mentioned this in his (Sahih) and the exegetes like Ibn Jarir and others). (Second: Mosques built on graves, because praying in them involves resembling the Jews and Christians. He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said regarding them: (Indeed those, when a righteous man among them died, they built a mosque over his grave and depicted those images in it. Those are the worst of creation with Allah on the Day of Resurrection). And he said: (Beware, those before you used to take the graves of their prophets and righteous people as mosques. Beware, do not take graves as mosques; indeed, I forbid you from that). The first Hadith is from the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that Umm Habiba and Umm Salama mentioned a church they saw in Abyssinia containing images. So they mentioned it to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so he said... then he mentioned it. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Ahmad, and Ibn Abi Shaybah in (Al-Musannaf). The second Hadith is from the narration of Jundub bin Abdullah Al-Bajali, he said: I heard the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, five [days] before he died, saying: (I declare innocence to Allah that I should have a Khalil (close friend) from among you, for Allah the Exalted has taken me as a Khalil just as He took Ibrahim as a Khalil. If I were to take a Khalil from my Ummah, I would have taken Abu Bakr as a Khalil. Beware, indeed those before you...) The Hadith. Muslim solely extracted it without the Six. Al-Shawkani attributed it to Al-Nasa'i as well, and perhaps he means his (Sunan Al-Kubra), otherwise I did not find it...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...in his (Al-Sughra), and he did not attribute it in (Al-Dhakhai'r) except to Muslim. In the chapter [there are narrations] from Aisha and Ibn Abbas together, from Abu Huraira, and from Ibn Mas'ud, and their Hadiths have passed shortly. And from Ibn Abbas also with the wording: (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, cursed the women who visit graves and those who take mosques and lamps over them). Extracted by the Four except Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad. With this wording, it is weak except for the first sentence of it, which is authentic due to it coming from another path from Abu Huraira and Hassan bin Thabit. I have detailed the discussion on that in (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad) with what is not found in any book, and praise be to Allah. Know that the first Hadith indicates the prohibition of building mosques on graves, and that necessitates the prohibition of praying in them by greater reason (a fortiori), because it is - as is obvious - of the type of forbidding the means - which is the building - so that the end - which is worship in this building established on disobedience to Allah the Exalted - is not realized, due to the doctrinal corruptions resulting from that as is the reality. As for the second Hadith, it is more general than the first because by its wording it encompasses the means and the end. Taking a place as a mosque means praying in it (1) and means building on it for the...
foot_note: 1. (1) Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Iqtida'): Every place where prayer is intended has been taken as a mosque; rather, every place where prayer is performed is called a mosque even if there is no building, as he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (The earth has been made for me a mosque and pure).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...sake of prayer and prostration in it. So each of them implies the other, as Al-Munawi stated in (Al-Fayd). It is known by self-evidence that the cursed Jews and Christians only built those mosques to pray in them. So whoever prays in a mosque containing a grave, even if he does not intend the grave, has resembled those upon whom is anger and the astray. We have been forbidden from resembling them in general and specific texts. Therefore, the scholar Ibn Al-Malik - who is from our Hanafi scholars - said in the explanation of the Hadith of Ibn Abbas mentioned previously: (Taking mosques over them was forbidden only because praying in them is following the Sunnah of the Jews). Quoted by Sheikh Ali Al-Qari in (Al-Mirqat). Added to the above is that prayer in mosques built on graves may lead its doer or the commoners and ignorant people who follow him to single out the dead with some acts of worship specific to Allah the Exalted, such as seeking aid (Istighatha) and prostration, as is happening in most mosques built on graves, and it is witnessed. So it was forbidden to block the means (Saddan Lil-Dhari'ah). It is like the prohibition of prayer in the three strictly disliked times; rather, the corruption in those mosques is clearer and more apparent than in these times, as reality bears witness. All this applies to one who did not intend prayer in those mosques. As for the one intending them for the sake of the grave's occupant, seeking blessings by him, believing that prayer near him is better than prayer in mosques devoid of graves, this is the essence of opposing and defying Allah and His Messenger. This prayer is worthy of the saying of those who said it is invalid, as will come from some scholars.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And indeed, among what the insightful believer wonders at regarding his religion is the negligence of most jurists regarding this serious issue, as they did not address it with explicit mention in their books and fatwas as far as I know. Therefore, it became difficult to convince the blind followers (Muqallidin) of it despite the clarity of the proof in it. And how could they accept it when they - or most of them - prioritize the saying of the Imam - nay, the saying of some of his followers even if from the late ones - over the saying of Allah the Exalted and the saying of His Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him? And there is no power nor strength except by Allah. Therefore, I will take special care to quote some sayings of the investigating scholars regarding this issue so that the one examining this book of ours knows that we did not bring anything from ourselves as an innovation in religion, nor did we misunderstand the Hadiths of the Master of Messengers; rather, it is the truth from your Lord, so do not be of the doubters. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, gave this issue special attention - may Allah reward him with good on behalf of the Muslims - so you rarely see a book of his that does not address this issue at length or briefly. Therefore, I will quote from him what suits the context from his sayings and fatwas with some abbreviation and summarization. He, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Al-Qa'idah Al-Jalilah fi Al-Tawassul wa Al-Wasilah): (Taking a place as a mosque is to use it for the five prayers and others, just as mosques are built for that. The place taken as a mosque is intended only for the worship of Allah and supplicating to Him, not supplicating to the creation. So he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade that their graves be taken as mosques with the intent of praying in them just as...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...mosques are intended, even if the one intending that only intends the worship of Allah alone, because that is a means (Dhari'ah) to intending the mosque for the sake of the grave's occupant, supplicating to him, supplicating by him, and supplicating near him. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade taking this place for the worship of Allah alone lest that be taken as a means to what is forbidden, just as he forbade prayer in the three times due to the preponderant corruption in that, which is resembling the polytheists which leads to Shirk. There is not in the intent of prayer at those times... Therefore, scholars disputed regarding prayers with specific causes (dhawat al-asbab), so many of them permitted them in these times, and it is the more apparent of the two scholarly opinions. This is because if the prohibition is for blocking the means, it is permitted for a preponderant interest. Performing prayers with specific causes is needed in these times, and is missed if not done in them, so their interest is missed; thus they were permitted due to the preponderant interest in them. This is contrary to what has no cause, for it is possible to do it in other than these times, so no preponderant interest is missed by prohibiting it, and it contains corruption necessitating its prohibition. So if his prohibition of prayer in these times was to block the means to Shirk lest that leads to prostrating to the sun, supplicating to it, and asking it as the people of the call to the sun, moon, and stars do who supplicate to them and ask them - it was known that calling upon the sun and prostrating to it is forbidden in itself, greater in prohibition than the prayer which he forbade lest it leads to calling upon the stars. Likewise, when he forbade taking the graves of Prophets and righteous people as mosques, and forbade intending them for prayer near them lest that leads to calling upon them and prostrating to them - calling upon them and prostrating to them was...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...greater in prohibition than taking their graves as mosques). And he said in (Al-Iqtida'): (So these mosques built on the graves of Prophets, righteous people, kings, and others must be removed by demolition or otherwise. This is something I know of no disagreement in among the known scholars. Prayer in them is disliked without any disagreement I know of, and it is not valid according to us in the apparent view of the Madhhab due to the prohibition and curse reported regarding that, and due to other Hadiths. There is no disagreement in this issue due to the buried person being one. Our companions only differed regarding the graveyard devoid of a mosque: is it defined by three graves, or is prayer forbidden at a single grave even if there is no other grave near it? On two views. (I say: Sheikh Al-Islam preferred in another book the prohibition even at a single grave, and that preceded. Then he said:) The structure that is on the grave of Ibrahim, peace be upon him, was closed and not entered until around the fourth century. It was said: Some women connected to the Caliphs saw a dream regarding that, so it was breached for that reason. And it was said: When the Christians took over these areas, they breached that. Then it was left as a mosque after the later conquests. The people of virtue among our sheikhs used to not pray in the totality of that structure and forbade their companions from praying in it, following the command of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and avoiding his disobedience as preceded). Then he said in it: (For his prohibition of taking graves as mosques implies the prohibition of building mosques on them and intending prayer near them. Both are forbidden by the agreement of scholars. They forbade building mosques on graves; rather, they explicitly stated the prohibition (Tahrim) of that as indicated by the text. They also agreed that it is not legislated to intend prayer and supplication at graves, and...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...not one of the Muslims said: Prayer at them and supplication at them is better than in mosques free of graves. Rather, the scholars of Muslims agreed that prayer and supplication in mosques that were not built on graves are better than prayer and supplication in mosques built on graves. Nay, prayer and supplication in these [latter ones] is forbidden and disliked by their agreement. Many of them explicitly stated the prohibition of that, and even the invalidity of prayer therein, although there is dispute regarding this [invalidity]. The intent here is that this is not obligatory nor recommended by their agreement; rather, it is disliked by their agreement). He said in (Al-Jawab Al-Bahir fi Zuwwar Al-Maqabir): (Prayer in mosques built on graves is forbidden absolutely, unlike his mosque, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, for prayer in it is worth a thousand prayers, as it was founded on piety. Its sanctity existed during his life, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and the life of his Rightly Guided Caliphs before the Chamber entered it). Then he said: (Whoever believes that before [the inclusion of] the grave there was no virtue in it, and that virtue only occurred for it during the Caliphate of Al-Walid when the Chamber was entered into it, he is ignorant, excessive in ignorance, or a disbeliever denying what he, peace be upon him, brought, deserving of being killed). He, may Allah have mercy on him, issued fatwas repeatedly regarding the dislike of prayer in mosques built on graves. It came in his Fatwas, the text of which is: (Issue: Regarding a mosque if there is a grave in it and people gather in it for congregational prayer, is prayer permissible in it or not? And should the grave be leveled or not?
foot_note: 1. (1) A comprehensive treatise of what was scattered in his many books regarding this subject. It is among the manuscripts of Al-Zahiriyyah Library under number (129) collection. What we quoted from it is in folio (22 and 55).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Answer: The Imams agreed that a mosque is not to be built over a grave, because of the one who said: (Indeed those before you used to take graves as mosques. Beware, do not take graves as mosques, for I forbid you from that). And that it is not permissible to bury a dead person in a mosque. If the mosque was before the burial, it [the grave situation] is changed: either by leveling the grave or by digging it up if it is new. If the mosque was built after the grave, either the mosque is removed or the image of the grave is removed. The mosque built on the grave, neither obligatory nor voluntary prayer is prayed in it, for it is forbidden. And Allah knows best). He has another Fatwa similar to this; see it - if you wish - in Volume Two, page (192) (1). Sheikh Muhammad Yahya Al-Kandahlawi Al-Hindi Al-Hanafi said in his book (Al-Kawkab Al-Durri 'ala Jami' Al-Tirmidhi), the text of which is: (As for taking mosques over them, it involves resemblance to the Jews in their taking mosques over the graves of their prophets and elders, and because it involves glorification of the dead and resemblance to idol worshippers if the grave is in the direction of the Qiblah. The dislike of it being in the direction of the Qiblah is greater than the dislike of...
foot_note: 1. (1) And his student, the investigator Ibn Al-Qayyim, said in (Zad Al-Ma'ad) (3/22): (So the mosque is demolished if built on a grave, just as [the grave] is dug up if buried in the mosque. Imam Ahmad and others explicitly stated this. A mosque and a grave do not coexist in the religion of Islam; rather, whichever one occurred upon the other is prevented from it, and the ruling is for the former. If they were placed together, it is not permissible, nor is this endowment (Waqf) valid, nor is prayer permissible or valid in this mosque due to the prohibition of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, of that, and his cursing of the one who takes a grave as a mosque or lights a lamp on it. This is the religion of Islam with which Allah sent His Messenger and Prophet, and its strangeness among people is as you see).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...it being on the right or left. If it is behind the praying person, it is lighter in dislike than all that, but it is not free from dislike). Al-Hafiz mentioned in (Al-Fath) and Al-Ayni in (Al-Umdah): (That if the grave in the mosque is in the direction of the Qiblah, the dislike increases). This is the truth in the issue according to the detail mentioned by Al-Hindi. The reference for that is resemblance to the Jews and Christians in their praying in mosques built on graves, and the resemblance occurs in all the forms he mentioned, as is obvious. This is for one who does not intend prayer in them. As for the one intending [prayer there], hear what the Jurist Ibn Hajar Al-Haytami quoted in his book (Al-Zawajir): (Some Hanbalis said: A man's intention to pray at the grave seeking blessing by it is the essence of opposing Allah and His Messenger and innovating a religion Allah did not authorize, due to the prohibition of it. Then, by consensus, the greatest prohibitions and causes of Shirk are: Praying at them, taking them as mosques, and building over them. The saying of 'dislike' is interpreted as other than that, for scholars are not thought to allow an action for which the doer was cursed in Mutawatir reports from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. It is obligatory to hasten to demolish them and demolish the domes that are on the graves, as they are more harmful than the Mosque of Harm (Masjid Al-Dirar), because they were founded on disobedience to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, because he forbade that and ordered, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, the demolition of raised graves). This, and the previous Hadiths have indicated the prohibition of building mosques on graves as well, which is another issue we discussed in (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad) and mentioned in it the sayings of...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...scholars regarding the prohibition of that. Perhaps we will mention them in (Rulings of Mosques) from this book, if Allah the Exalted wills. (Third: Camel kneeling places (Ma'atin) and resting places (Mubarak), due to his saying, peace be upon him: (If prayer becomes due and you find nothing but sheepfolds and camel kneeling places, pray in the sheepfolds and do not pray in the camel kneeling places). He reasoned that in another Hadith by his saying: (For they were created from devils [do you not see their eyes and their agitation when they are startled?])). The first Hadith is from the Hadith of Abu Huraira extracted by Al-Darimi - and the wording is his - Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, Ahmad, and Ibn Hazm from paths from Hisham bin Hassan from Muhammad bin Sirin from him. This is a Sahih chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs. Al-Tirmidhi extracted it from the path of Abu Bakr bin Ayyash from Hisham with it briefly with the wording: (Pray in sheepfolds and do not pray in camel kneeling places), which is a wording of Ahmad. Then Al-Tirmidhi extracted it from the path of Abu Bakr bin Ayyash also from Abu Hasin from Abu Salih from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, similarly or like it. And he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (A Gharib Hadith. And Isra'il narrated it from Abu Hasin from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira as Mawquf (stopped) and did not raise it). I say: It was also reported from the first path as Mawquf. Imam Ahmad extracted it from the path of Ayyub Al-Sakhtiyani from Muhammad bin Sirin from Abu Huraira that he said... so he mentioned it exactly like the wording of Abu Bakr, except that he said: (or camel resting places (Mubarak)). Its chain is also Sahih on their condition. However, Hisham bin Hassan is trustworthy, one of the most reliable people in [narrating from] Ibn Sirin as in (Al-Taqrib), and he narrated it from him as Marfu' (raised). Raising is an addition that must be accepted as established in the terminology (Mustalah). The same is said regarding the other path from Abu Hasin from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira. Isra'il narrated it as Mawquf and Abu Bakr bin Ayyash as Marfu', and both are trustworthy. However, when Abu Bakr grew old, his memory worsened, so that prevents us from preferring his narration over Isra'il's narration, although the Hadith is Sahih as Marfu' from the first path, and the discussion is only regarding the other path. The Hadith has witnesses, including: From Uqbah bin Amir, extracted by Ahmad from Yahya bin Abi Amr Al-Shaibani - so in the original, and the correct is: Al-Saybani with the unpointed Seen - from his father from him as Marfu' like the Mawquf Hadith of Abu Huraira. This is a Hasan chain; all its men are trustworthy except Abu Amr Al-Saybani, and he was authenticated by...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Ibn Hibban and Ya'qub bin Sufyan. In (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable). Al-Tabarani also narrated it in (Al-Kabir) as in (Al-Majma'). Among them: From Usaid bin Hudair, extracted by Ahmad also from Hammad bin Salamah: Al-Hajjaj bin Artat informed us from Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from his father from him with it, except that he said: (Mubarak). Al-Hajjaj is a Mudallis and used 'an' (from). From a path narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) as in (Al-Majma'), and he and Al-Shawkani restricted attribution to him, which is a shortcoming. Abdullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila, I did not know him, and Al-Hafiz did not include him in (Al-Ta'jil) even though he meets his condition. Abbad bin Al-Awwam narrated it from Al-Hajjaj, he said: Abdullah bin Abdullah, the freed slave of Banu Hashim - and he was trustworthy and Al-Hakam used to take from him - told us from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila with it. Perhaps this is the correct view. It is a Hasan chain in which Al-Hajjaj explicitly stated hearing (Tahdith). Al-Tahawi extracted it. Ubaidah bin Humaid Al-Dabbi narrated it from Abdullah bin Abdullah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from Dhu Al-Ghurrah, he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: A Bedouin appeared to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was traveling. He said: O Messenger of Allah, prayer overtakes us while we are in camel kneeling places (A'tan), so do we pray in them? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (No). He said: Do we perform ablution from their meat? He said: (Yes). He said: Do we pray in sheepfolds? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Yes). He said: Do we perform ablution from their meat? He said: (No). Extracted by Abdullah bin Ahmad in (Zawa'id Al-Musnad), he said: Amr bin Muhammad bin Bakr Al-Naqid told us: Ubaid bin Humaid told us from Ubaid Al-Dabbi from Abdullah bin Abdullah - meaning the Judge of Rayy - with it. Thus it appeared in the original: From Ubaidah Al-Dabbi. It is apparent that his saying: 'From Ubaidah' is an addition from the pen of some scribe. It appeared in another place in (Al-Musnad) like this correctly, but it has other corruptions. Abdullah bin Ahmad said: My father told me: Amr bin Muhammad Al-Naqid told us, he said: Ubaidah bin Humaid Al-Dabbi told us from Ubaidullah - sic - bin Abdullah with it. So his saying: 'My father told me' is also a meaningless addition, for Al-Naqid narrates to Abdullah bin Ahmad directly as in the first narration, and I do not know that Ahmad narrates from him. And Allah knows best. In summary, the chain of this Hadith is Sahih; its men are men of Al-Bukhari except Abdullah bin Abdullah, who is Al-Razi, the freed slave of Banu Hashim, and he is trustworthy. It appears he has two chains from his Sheikh Ibn Abi Laila. He has a third chain from him; Imam Ahmad said: Abdul Razzaq told us: Sufyan informed us...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Sufyan from Al-A'mash from Abdullah bin Abdullah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from Al-Bara' bin Azib that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked: Do we pray in camel kneeling places? He said: (No). He said: Do we pray in sheepfolds? He said: (Yes). He said: Do we perform ablution from camel meat? He said: (Yes). He said: Do we perform ablution from sheep meat? He said: (No). Abdullah bin Ahmad said: (Abdullah bin Abdullah is Razi, and he was the judge of Rayy, and his grandmother was a freed slave of Ali or a bondmaid). Abdullah said: (My father said: And Adam and Sa'id bin Masruq narrated from him, and he was trustworthy). I say: And the rest of his men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs, so the chain is Sahih as well. Al-Tahawi extracted it from Abdullah bin Idris from Al-A'mash with it. It was reported from him with an addition in it, and it will come shortly. Among them: From Sabrah bin Ma'bad like the Hadith of Abu Huraira with the wording: (Murah) instead of: (A'tan). Extracted by Ibn Majah, Al-Daraqutni, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad from the path of Abdullah bin Al-Rabi' bin Sabrah bin Ma'bad Al-Juhani: My father informed me from his father raised [to the Prophet]. This is a Hasan chain, and it is on the condition of Muslim, except that this Abdul Malik has some speech regarding him, and Al-Ajli declared him trustworthy. Among them: From Abdullah bin Mughaffal Al-Muzani, which is:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Second Hadith: Extracted by Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, as well as Al-Tayalisi and Al-Ruyani in his (Musnad) from paths from Al-Hasan Al-Basri from him (1). He said in (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is Sahih). It is as he said, except that Al-Hasan Al-Basri is a Mudallis. However, in (Al-Musnad) there is what implies that he heard it from Abdullah bin Mughaffal. He cited with this chain three Hadiths, this being the last of them. The first is the Hadith: (Were it not that dogs are a community among communities, I would have ordered killing them...) The Hadith. Then he narrated it in another place from Al-Hasan that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... so he mentioned it. In it: A man said to him: O Abu Sa'id, from whom did you hear this? He said: So he said: It was narrated to me - and he swore - by Abdullah bin Mughaffal from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, since such and such time, and he narrated to us in that gathering. This indicates that he heard from him other Hadiths in that gathering, so it appears this is one of them. And Allah knows best. Al-Nasa'i narrated from it the prohibition of prayer in camel kneeling places.
foot_note: 1. (1) Raised [to the Prophet]: with the wording: (Pray in sheepfolds and do not pray in camel kneeling places, for they were created from devils). Al-Nawawi said (3/160): (Its chain is Hasan). This is a shortcoming, and I do not know what prevented him from authenticating it? If it is what we pointed out regarding Tadlis, if established here, it prevents judging it as Hasan, so reflect.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: As for the addition between the two brackets, it is a narration of Ahmad from the path of Ibn Ishaq: Ubaidullah bin Talha bin Ubaidullah bin Kariz Al-Khuza'i told me from Al-Hasan with it with the wording: (Do not pray in the camel kneeling place ('Atan), for it is created from Jinn. Do you not see...) etc. And he added: (And pray in the sheep resting place (Murah), for it is closer to mercy). In (Al-Majma'): (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and the men of Ahmad are trustworthy, and Ibn Ishaq explicitly stated: He told me). I say: So the chain is Hasan. Ubaidullah bin Talha, although authenticated by no one but Ibn Hibban, two trustworthy narrators narrated from him: One is Safwan bin Sulaym and the other is Hammad bin Zaid. In (Al-Taqrib) he is: (Acceptable). As for Al-Shawkani's saying: (Its chain is Sahih), it is not correct. Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from the path of Al-Shafi'i: Ibrahim bin Muhammad informed us from Abdullah bin Talha with it similarly. The Hadith has a witness from the Hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked about prayer in camel resting places (Mubarak)? He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ((Do not pray in the kneeling places of camels, for they are from devils). And he was asked about prayer in sheepfolds? He said: (Pray in them, for they are a blessing)). Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad from the path of Abu Mu'awiyah: Al-A'mash told us from Abdullah from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from him. This is a Sahih chain; its men are the men of the two Sheikhs except Abdullah bin Abdullah, and he is trustworthy. Others have narrated it briefly as preceded shortly. (Ma'atin): Plural of Ma'tan with Fatha on Mim and Kasra on Ta. (A'tan) is plural of 'Atan with Fatha on Ain and Ta (unpointed letters). Al-Azhari said: (The 'Atan is the place where camels are led to after drinking the first drink, so they kneel in it, then the trough is filled for them a second time, so they return from their 'Atan to the trough to drink again (ta'all), which is the second drink/Al-'Alal). He said: (Camels are not put to 'Atan away from water except in the intensity of summer heat - with light Mim and heavy Ra -). He said: (And its place where it is left at the water is called 'Atan and Ma'tan). Quoted by Al-Nawawi in (Al-Majmu'). So (Al-Ma'tan) is a specific place for the camel's kneeling. Accordingly, (Al-Mabrak) is more general. Ibn Hazm said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ((And every 'Atan is a Mabrak, but not every Mabrak is an 'Atan, because the 'Atan is the place where they are made to kneel when arriving at water only, while the Mabrak is more general because it is the place taken for their kneeling in every situation)).
