The two Hadiths and what is in their meaning indicate the prohibition of prayer in camel kneeling places (Mubarak). This is the school of Ibn Hazm. It was narrated from Ahmad that he said: (Whoever prays in a camel 'Atan must repeat forever). Malik was asked about one who found nothing but a camel 'Atan. He said: (He does not pray in it). It was said: What if he spreads a cloth over it? He said: (No, also). Al-Tirmidhi said after citing Abu Huraira's Hadith: (And upon it is the practice among our companions, and Ahmad and Ishaq say it). Al-Shawkani said: (The majority went to interpreting the prohibition as dislike (Karaha) given the absence of impurity, and as prohibition (Tahrim) given its presence. This is only complete based on the statement that the cause of prohibition is impurity, and that depends on the impurity of camel urine and dung. You have known what we presented regarding it. Even if we concede that impurity is in it, it is not valid to make it a cause, because if the cause were impurity, the situation would not differ between their A'tan and sheepfolds, since no one says there is a difference between the dung and urine of each of the two species, as Al-Iraqi said. Also, it has been said: Its ruling is prohibition...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: due to the possibility of them bolting (being startled), for perhaps they might bolt while he is in prayer, leading to cutting it off, or harm befalling him from them, or the distraction of the mind which diverts from Khushu (humility/focus) in prayer. The companions of Al-Shafi'i and the companions of Malik reasoned the prohibition with this. Based on this, a distinction is made between the camels being present in their kneeling places (Ma'atin) and their absence from them, as their bolting is secured against in that case [absence]. Guiding to the correctness of this is the Hadith of Ibn Mughaffal in Ahmad with a Sahih chain with the wording: (Do not pray in the kneeling places of camels, for they were created from Jinn; do you not see their eyes and their appearance when they bolt?). I say: What contradicts this is that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to pray facing a camel, as will come in its place, if Allah the Exalted wills. This indicates that the prohibition is not due to the possibility of bolting, because this is also probable in this scenario which is permissible by agreement. Therefore, I see that the prohibition is specifically regarding the place - the Ma'tan (kneeling place) and the Mabrak (resting place) - whether camels are present therein or not at the time of prayer. The speech of Ibn Hazm indicates this; he said, may Allah have mercy on him: (Prayer is absolutely not permissible in a place taken for the kneeling of one camel or more, nor in a place taken as a Ma'tan for one camel or more. Prayer facing a camel is permissible. Based on this, if camels cease to seek shelter in that place until the name 'Ma'tan' no longer applies to it, prayer in it becomes permissible). Thus, the Hadith does not imply the differentiation that Al-Shawkani inclined towards. And Allah the Exalted knows best. Then Al-Shawkani mentioned other opinions explaining the cause, all of which are flimsy with no proof for them. Then he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (If you know this difference regarding the cause, it becomes clear to you that the truth is to stand with the implication of the prohibition, which is Tahrim (forbiddenness), as Ahmad and the Zahiris went to. As for the command to pray in sheepfolds, it is a command of permissibility (Ibahah), not obligation, by agreement). Clarification of this will come in its place, if Allah the Exalted wills. (Fourth: The Bathroom (Hammam), due to the previous Hadith), which is his saying, peace be upon him: (The earth is all a mosque except the graveyard and the bathroom). The ruling of prayer in the bathroom is like that in the graveyard - meaning: Prohibition - due to the apparent meaning of the Hadith. It is the school of Ahmad and Ibn Hazm; rather, they went to the invalidity of prayer in it. It says in (Al-Nayl): (Abu Thawr said: One does not pray in a bathroom based on the apparent meaning of the Hadith. The Zahiris went to this. It was narrated from Ibn Abbas that he said: One does not pray facing a latrine, nor in a bathroom, nor in a graveyard. Ibn Hazm said: We do not know of any opponent to Ibn Abbas regarding this among the Companions. We narrated the like of that from Nafi' bin Jubayr bin Mut'im, Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, Khaythamah, and Al-Ala' bin Ziyad from his father. Ibn Hazm said: Prayer is not lawful in a bathroom, whether that is the beginning of its door to all its borders, nor on its roof, the roof of its furnace, and the tops of its walls, whether ruined or standing. If part of its building collapses such that the name 'bathroom' falls from it, prayer is permissible in its land then. End quote. The majority went to the validity of prayer in the bathroom with purity [from filth], and it is disliked (Makruh). They held to general texts like the Hadith: (Wherever prayer overtakes you, then pray), and they interpreted the prohibition to apply to a bathroom that is impure...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...The truth is what the former group said, because the Hadiths of the graveyard and the bathroom specify that generality). They differed regarding the wisdom of the prohibition of prayer in the bathroom. It was said: Because impurities abound in it. And it was said: Because it is the shelter of devils. Al-Nawawi said: (It is the more correct view). And Allah knows best. (Fifth: Every place where Satan seeks shelter, such as places of immorality and debauchery, and like churches and synagogues and similar places, due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when they camped during their travel and slept through the Fajr prayer: (Let every man take hold of the head of his mount, for this is a place where Satan attended us), so he did not pray in it). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We camped with the Prophet of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and we did not wake up until the sun rose. So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... so he mentioned it. He said: So we did so, then he called for water and performed ablution, then prostrated two prostrations [Sunnah], then prayer was established and he prayed the Morning Prayer. Extracted by Muslim and Al-Bayhaqi. Abu Qatadah and others from the Companions narrated this story in detail, but it does not contain the point of evidence from it, and it has preceded in (The Times). Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu'): (Prayer in the shelter of Satan is disliked by agreement. That is like places of wine, bars, places of unjust taxes (Muks), and similar places of obscene sins, and churches and synagogues...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and latrines and similar places. If he prays in any of that without impurity touching his body or his clothes, his prayer is valid with Karaha (dislike)). Then he said: (Know that the bottoms of valleys are not disliked for prayer, just as it is not disliked in other places. As for Al-Ghazali's statement: 'Prayer is disliked in the bottom of the valley,' it is false and they rejected it from him. Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, only disliked prayer in the valley where the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, slept through the prayer, not in every valley. Some scholars said: Prayer is not disliked in that valley either, because we cannot verify the continued presence of that Satan. And Allah knows best. It is recommended not to pray in a place where Satan attended him due to this Hadith). I say: The apparent meaning of the Hadith implies what is higher than recommendation - meaning obligation - because of his command, peace be upon him, to them to leave. If there is anyone who holds this view, then it is our view. And Allah knows best. He said: (And prayer is disliked in the church and the synagogue. Ibn Al-Mundhir narrated it from Umar bin Al-Khattab, Ibn Abbas, and Malik, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Bukhari narrated via suspension (Ta'liq) from Umar that he said: We do not enter your churches because of the statues and images in them. Ibn Abbas used to pray in the synagogue unless there was a synagogue with statues. Al-Baghawi connected this in (Al-Ja'diyat) and added in it: If there were statues in it, he would go out and pray in the rain. As for Umar's statement, Abdul Razzaq connected it from the path of Aslam, the freed slave of Umar, who said: When he arrived in Sham (Syria), a man from the Christians made food for him - and he was one of their grandees - and said: I would love for...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...you to come to me and honor me. Umar said to him: We do not enter your churches because of the images that are in them - meaning statues). End quote from (Al-Fath). Then Al-Nawawi narrated from some scholars the license to pray in the church and the synagogue. Perhaps that is when they are free of images and statues, as indicated by the report of Ibn Abbas. Otherwise, taking it absolutely is far from correct, because angels do not enter a house containing images as established from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and because the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did not enter the Kaaba until he erased the images inside it. Furthermore, it is like the mosque built on a grave, as Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Fatawa) regarding the previous Hadith: (Indeed those, when a righteous man among them died, they built a mosque over his grave and depicted those... [images]). The Companions prayed in the church. And Allah knows best. He said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat): (The Madhhab which the general companions are upon is the dislike of entering a church with images. Thus, prayer in it and in every place with images is more intensely disliked. This is the correct view in which there is no doubt or suspicion). (Sixth: Usurped land, because staying in it is forbidden outside of prayer, so for it to be forbidden during prayer is more fitting. Allah The Exalted said: {O you who have believed, do not enter houses other than your own houses until you ascertain welcome...} [An-Nur / 27-28])

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: So Allah, Glory be to Him, forbade the believers from mere entry without permission and made that prohibited for them. Thus, usurping a house or land and staying in it is more fitting [to be prohibited], and the prohibition of prayer in it is even more fitting. Therefore, prayer in usurped land is prohibited (Haram) by consensus, as quoted by Al-Nawawi. They only differed regarding the validity of prayer in it. The majority holds that it is valid. Ahmad and Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla) and (Al-Ahkam fi Usul Al-Ahkam) said: (It is invalid). The closest to the truth is what the majority went to, because the prohibition is not specific to the prayer itself, so it does not prevent its validity. And Allah The Exalted knows best. (Seventh: Masjid Al-Dirar (The Mosque of Harm) which is near Quba, and every mosque built for harm and division among Muslims, due to His saying, The Exalted: {And those who took for themselves a mosque for causing harm and disbelief and division among the believers and as a station for whoever had warred against Allah and His Messenger before...} to His saying: {Do not stand [for prayer] within it - ever. A mosque founded on righteousness from the first day is more worthy for you to stand in...} [At-Tawbah / 107-108]). The scholars of Tafsir said in summary: (Banu Amr bin Auf adopted the Quba Mosque and asked the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to come to them. So he prayed in it, peace and blessings be upon him. Their brothers Banu Ghanm bin Auf envied them and said: We will build a mosque and send for the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to come and pray for us as he prayed...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...in the mosque of our brothers, and Abu Amir will pray in it when he arrives from Sham (1). So they came to him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, while he was preparing for Tabuk and said: O Messenger of Allah, we have built a mosque for the needy, the ill, and the rainy night, and we love that you pray for us in it and supplicate for blessing - they only intended by that to use his prayer in it as an argument for its approval and establishment, so Allah protected him from praying in it. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (I am traveling and in a state of busyness, so if we return, we will come to you and pray for you, if Allah wills). When he returned from Tabuk, they came to him, having finished it and prayed Jumu'ah, Saturday, and Sunday in it. He called for his shirt to wear it and go to them, but the Quran descended upon him with the news of Masjid Al-Dirar. So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, called a group of Companions and said: (Go to this mosque whose people are unjust, destroy it and burn it). So they went out rushing, burned the mosque, and destroyed it). In the verse is evidence that prayer is not permissible in Masjid Al-Dirar and mosques with similar meaning. The Malikis and others held this view. Ibn Hazm stated in (Al-Muhalla) regarding His saying in the verse: {Do not stand in it ever}, he said: (So it is correct that it is not a place for prayer).
foot_note: 1. (1) A man from Khazraj who had become a Christian in the Jahiliyya, read the knowledge of the People of the Book, and had devotion in Jahiliyya and great honor among Khazraj. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, had called him to Allah and read the Quran to him, but he refused to submit and rebelled. When the people finished with Uhud and he saw the affair of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, rising and appearing, he went to Heraclius, King of Rome, seeking his support against the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. He promised him and gave him hopes, and he stayed with him. He wrote to a group of his people from the Ansar among the people of hypocrisy and doubt, promising them and raising their hopes that he would come with an army to fight the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and ordered them to make a stronghold for him to be an observation post for him when he comes to them.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: Although the verse is specific to Masjid Al-Dirar, it is not intended for itself alone, as is obvious. Rather, the intent is the qualities it was described with: harm and division. Every mosque in which these qualities or some of them are found takes the ruling of Masjid Al-Dirar. Therefore, Al-Qurtubi said in his (Tafsir): (Our scholars said: Every mosque built for harm, or showing off (Riya') and reputation (Sum'ah), is in the ruling of Masjid Al-Dirar; prayer is not permissible in it). He also said: (Our scholars said: It is not permissible to build a mosque next to a mosque; it must be demolished and its building prevented so that the people of the first mosque do not leave it, leaving it empty, unless the neighborhood is large and one mosque does not suffice its people, then it is built. Likewise, they said: It is not appropriate to build two or three Jami's (congregational mosques) in one city; the second must be prevented, and whoever prays Jumu'ah in it, it does not suffice him. The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, burned Masjid Al-Dirar and demolished it. Al-Tabari narrated from Shaqiq that he came to pray in the mosque of Banu Ghadirah and found the prayer had finished. It was said to him: The mosque of Banu Fulan has not been prayed in yet. He said: I do not like to pray in it because it was built on harm). (Eighth: Places of Khasf (earth swallowing) and Torment, for entering them is not permissible absolutely except with weeping and fear of Allah The Exalted, due to his saying, peace be upon him [when he passed Al-Hijr]: (Do not enter the houses upon these people who were punished [the companions of Al-Hijr] unless you are weeping. If you are not weeping, do not enter upon them, for I fear that there might befall you...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the like of what befell them) [Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, covered his head [with his cloak while on the saddle] and hastened the pace until he crossed the valley]). The Hadith is from the narration of Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are three paths from him: First: From Abdullah bin Dinar, and the Marfu' wording from his speech, peace be upon him, belongs to him. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Ahmad - and the context is his - in a narration, and Al-Bayhaqi extracted it from paths from him. Some of its chains in Ahmad are thulathi (having only three narrators). In a narration by Al-Bukhari from the path of Sulayman - who is Ibn Bilal - from Abdullah bin Dinar with the wording: When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, camped at Al-Hijr in the expedition of Tabuk, he ordered them not to drink from its well nor draw water from it. They said: We have kneaded dough from it and drawn water. So he ordered them to throw away that dough and spill that water. Second: From Nafi' with the wording: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, camped with the people in the year of Tabuk. He camped with them at Al-Hijr near the houses of Thamud. The people drew water from the wells from which Thamud used to drink, kneaded dough from it, and set up pots with meat. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered them, so they spilled [the pots] and fed the dough to the camels. Then he traveled with them until he camped with them at the well from which the She-Camel used to drink. He forbade them from entering upon the people who were punished, saying: (I fear that...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...what befell them might befall you, so do not enter upon them). Ahmad extracted it: Abdul Samad told us: Sakhr - meaning Ibn Juwayriyah - told us from him. This is a Sahih chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs. They extracted it from the path of Ubaydullah from Nafi' similarly without their saying: And he forbade them... etc. Al-Bukhari said: (Usama followed him [narrating] from Nafi'). Third: From Salim bin Abdullah from Ibn Umar with it like the Hadith of Ibn Dinar. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad extracted it from the path of Al-Zuhri from him. The first addition is with everyone, and the other is with Al-Bukhari and Al-Bayhaqi, except his saying: (with his cloak while on the saddle) is in a narration by Ahmad and likewise Al-Bukhari in a narration. The Hadith contains the prohibition of entering places of the tormented and staying there unless weeping. Al-Bayhaqi said: (So entering that place for prayer and other things is included). A explicit Hadith has come regarding that, but it is spoken about [criticized]. Abu Dawood extracted it, and from him Al-Bayhaqi from two paths: Ibn Lahi'ah and Yahya bin Azhar from Ammar bin Sa'd Al-Muradi from Abu Salih Al-Ghafari: That Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, passed by Babylon while traveling, and the Mu'adhin came to him calling the Asr prayer...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...When he emerged from it, he ordered the Mu'adhin, so he established the prayer. When he finished, he said: Indeed my beloved, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade me to pray in the graveyard, and forbade me to pray in the land of Babylon, for it is cursed. Then he extracted it from them also from Al-Hajjaj bin Shaddad from Abu Salih Al-Ghafari with it in its meaning. Al-Khattabi said: (In the chain of this Hadith is speech). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (In its chain is weakness). I say: Perhaps its defect is the interruption between Abu Salih - whose name is Sa'id bin Abdul Rahman - and Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. Ibn Yunus said: (His narration from Ali is Mursal). Its men are authenticated. It has been reported as Mawquf (stopped) on Ali. Al-Bukhari said: (It is mentioned that Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, disliked prayer in the Khasf (sinking place) of Babylon). Al-Hafiz said: (This report was narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah from the path of Abdullah bin Abi Al-Mulaih - with Damma on Mim, Kasra on unpointed letter, and Shadda on Lam - he said: We were with Ali and passed by the Khasf in Babylon, so he did not pray until he passed it, i.e., crossed it. And from another path from Ali, he said: I would not pray in a land Allah caused to sink). Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in (Al-Iqtida') after citing the raised Hadith of Ali from the path of Abu Dawood:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Imam Ahmad narrated in the narration of his son Abdullah with a clearer chain than this from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, something similar to this: That he disliked prayer in the land of Babylon and the land of Khasf or similar to that. Imam Ahmad disliked prayer in these places following Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. His saying: 'He forbade me to pray in the land of Babylon for it is cursed' decrees that one does not pray in a cursed land. The famous Hadith regarding Al-Hijr agrees with this, for if entering the land of torment is forbidden, prayer and other things are included in that. Agreeing with that is His saying, The Exalted, regarding Masjid Al-Dirar: {Do not stand in it ever}, for it was among the places of torment. He, The Exalted, said: {Then is one who laid the foundation of his building on righteousness [with fear] from Allah and [seeking] His approval better or one who laid the foundation of his building on the edge of a bank about to collapse, so it collapsed with him into the fire of Hell?} [At-Tawbah / 109]. It has been narrated that when it was demolished, smoke came out of it). The narration he attributed to Ahmad, perhaps it is in the questions of Abdullah from him or others, for I did not find it in (Al-Musnad). Then Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat): (The implication of the speech of Al-Amidi and Abu Al-Wafa bin Aqil is that prayer is not valid in the land of Khasf, and it is strong. The text of Ahmad: He does not pray in it). I say: We did not find evidence for the invalidity of prayer. The Hadith forbidding entry into the land of torment is not specific to prayer such that it is said it is invalid therein. Similarly, the Hadith of Ali, if authentic, does not indicate invalidity. Therefore, Al-Bayhaqi said after citing it: (This prohibition of prayer in it - if established as Marfu' - is not for a meaning returning to...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the prayer, so if he prays in it, he does not repeat. Rather it is - and Allah knows best - as narrated to us...) Then he cited the Hadith of Ibn Umar from the path of Ibn Dinar, containing the indication of the cause of prohibition, which is his saying, peace be upon him: (For I fear that what befell them might befall you). Yes, the apparent prohibition implies prohibition (Tahrim) of prayer in it, but Al-Khattabi said in (Al-Ma'alim): (I do not know of anyone among the scholars who forbade prayer in the land of Babylon). (Ninth: The elevated place where the Imam stands while he is higher than the place of the Ma'mumin (followers); it is not permissible for him to pray in it, for (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade that the Imam stands on top of something while the people are behind him - meaning: below him -)). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Mas'ud Al-Badri, he said: (He forbade...) etc. Extracted by Al-Daraqutni from the path of Ziyad bin Abdullah bin Al-Tufayl from Al-A'mash from Ibrahim from Hammam from him. He said: (No one narrated it other than Ziyad Al-Bakka', and no one narrated it other than Hammam as far as we know). I say: From this aspect, Al-Hakim also extracted it more completely from Hammam, he said: Hudhayfah prayed with the people in Al-Mada'in, so he advanced onto a bench (Dukkan). Abu Mas'ud took hold of his clothes and pulled him, so he returned. When he finished the prayer, Abu Mas'ud said to him: Did you not know that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade that the Imam stands above while the people remain behind him? He said: Did you not see me answer you when you pulled me? Its chain is Hasan and its men are trustworthy. There is speech regarding Ziyad bin Abdullah regarding his memory, and he is Salih (good) as Ibn Abi Hatim said from his father, and he mentioned this Hadith for him. He said in (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, firm in Maghazi, and in his hadith from other than Ibn Ishaq there is softness). I say: But he was not alone in it. Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim also extracted it from the path of Ya'la bin Ubayd: Al-A'mash told us with it like the first narration of Al-Hakim except that he said: Did you not know that they used to be forbidden from that? This has the ruling of Marfu' as established in the Terminology, so it is synonymous with Ziyad's explicit narration of raising it. Then Al-Hakim said: (Sahih on the condition of the two Sheikhs) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Ibn Khuzaymah also authenticated it, and Ibn Hibban as in (Al-Talkhis). Likewise, Al-Nawawi authenticated it in (Al-Majmu') and attributed it to Al-Shafi'i and Al-Bayhaqi as well. Then Abu Dawood extracted it from another path with similar meaning with the wording: (If a man leads a people, let him not stand in a place higher than their station).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: In it is that the Imam was Ammar bin Yasir and the one who pulled him was Hudhayfah. Al-Hafiz said: (But it contains an unknown narrator, and the first is stronger). The Hadith is evidence for the prohibition of the Imam standing in an elevated place. Scholars differed regarding that. Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Al-Majmu'): (Our companions said: It is disliked that the place of the Imam or the Ma'mum be higher than the place of the other. If it is needed to teach them the actions of prayer or to convey the Imam's Takbirs to the people and similar reasons, elevation is recommended to achieve this purpose. This is our Madhhab. It is a narration from Abu Hanifa. And from him is a narration that he dislikes elevation absolutely. Malik and Al-Awza'i said this. Sheikh Abu Hamid narrated from Al-Awza'i that he said: The prayer becomes invalid). I say: Perhaps his basis for that is that the reported prohibition is specific to prayer, and that implies invalidity. And Allah knows best. It would have been appropriate for this opinion to be the Madhhab of Ibn Hazm, but - contrary to that - he went to its permissibility, arguing with the Hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd which will come. There is no evidence in it as will be explained. He weakened the mentioned Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud where he said: (It is a fallen report; Ziyad bin Abdullah Al-Bakka' was alone in it, and he is weak). Thus he said, but he is not at this level of weakness such that his weakness is definitive. Furthermore, he was not alone in it as previously explained. This, and Al-Tabari narrated in (Al-Kabir) from Abdullah bin Mas'ud that he disliked that...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...he leads them on an elevated place. He said in (Al-Majma'): (Its men are the men of the Sahih). Some went to saying that the prohibited is only if the elevation of the place is the amount of a stature (qamah) and more, provided it is in the mosque, and the opposite is permissible according to them. There is no evidence for this detail in the Sunnah; it is merely opinion. Rather, every place regarding which it can be validly said linguistically and customarily: 'It is higher than the place of the followers' is prohibited. Therefore, Al-Shawkani said after recounting the scholars' sayings regarding the referenced difference: (The conclusion from the evidences is the prevention of the Imam's elevation over the followers without differentiating between the mosque and others, nor between a stature, less than it, or more than it, due to Ibn Mas'ud's saying: 'They used to be forbidden from that' and Ibn Mas'ud's saying: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, forbade...' The Hadith). Then he said: (As for the elevation of the follower, if it is excessive such that it is over three hundred cubits in a way that the follower cannot know the Imam's actions, it is prohibited by consensus without difference between the mosque and others. If it is less than that amount, the default is permissibility until evidence of prohibition stands. This principle is supported by the action of Abu Huraira mentioned, and it was not denounced against him). I say: The trace of Abu Huraira referred to was suspended by Al-Bukhari in his (Sahih) and connected by Ibn Abi Shaybah from the path of Salih, the freed slave of Al-Taw'amah, he said: I prayed with Abu Huraira on top of the mosque following the Imam's prayer. Al-Hafiz said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Salih has weakness in him, but Sa'id bin Mansur narrated it from another aspect from Abu Huraira, so it is strengthened). Al-Shafi'i and Al-Bayhaqi also extracted it as in (Al-Nayl). I also say: If the follower is praying in an elevated place, it is either due to necessity like lack of space or otherwise, or it is without necessity. If it is the first, there is no discussion, for necessities permit prohibitions. If it is the latter and it results in cutting the rows and separating from the row - as many people, Mu'adhins and others, do who pray on the Suddah (raised platform) while in front of them is empty space accommodating many rows - it is prohibited and not permissible, as will be explained in leveling the rows, Allah willing. So Al-Shawkani's absolute statement of permissibility, knowing that usually the caution we pointed out accompanies the mentioned matter, is not hidden in what it contains [of error], so reflect. (Except that exempted from this is if standing in this place is for the Imam's actions and movements in prayer to be visible to the followers so they can learn that from him; then it is permissible, rather recommended, because the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed once on the Minbar (so he said Takbir and the people behind him said Takbir, and he ascended the Minbar [then bowed while on it] then raised [his head] then descended backwards until he prostrated at the base of the Minbar, then returned until he finished his prayer. Then he turned to the people and said: O people, I only did this so you may follow me and learn my prayer). It is from the Hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd, he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Sahih) The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, sent to a woman: Tell your carpenter slave to make wooden steps for me to speak to the people upon. So he made these three steps. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered them, so they were placed in this spot; they are from the Tamarisk of Al-Ghabah. I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, stand upon them and say Takbir... The Hadith. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad from him. The context is Muslim's, and the addition between the brackets is Al-Bukhari's and others. The Hadith clearly indicates what we mentioned due to his saying, peace be upon him: (So you may follow me and learn my prayer). The Shafi'is and others used this as evidence. As for using it as evidence for the permissibility of an elevated place absolutely, as Al-Darimi inferred saying after citing the Hadith: (In that is a license for the Imam to be higher than his companions), and as Ibn Hazm did where he said: (There is no clearer statement than this regarding the permissibility of the Imam's prayer in a place higher than the place of the followers), and Al-Bukhari reported from his Sheikh Ali bin Abdullah Al-Madini from Ahmad bin Hanbal that he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (There is no harm in the Imam being higher than the people due to this Hadith). This is a strange inference from these Imams; my amazement at it almost never ends. How can they use it as evidence for absolute permissibility when it is restricted to teaching by text from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him? Is this anything but like someone using it as evidence for the permissibility of ascending the Minbar and descending from it during prayer absolutely without the intent of teaching? Would a rational person say this? So Glory be to Him who singled out the Prophets alone for infallibility. Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (In it is the permissibility of the difference in the standing of the Imam and Ma'mum in height and lowness. The author [Bukhari] explicitly stated that in a story from his Sheikh Ali bin Al-Madini from Ahmad bin Hanbal. Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid has a discussion on that, for he said: Whoever wants to deduce from it the permissibility of elevation without the intent of teaching, it does not hold straight, because the wording does not cover it, and because the basis is unique with a significant description that appropriateness dictates considering, so it is necessary). May Allah have mercy on Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid, for he was precise in observation regarding inference, fair in research, not deterred in Allah by the blame of a blamer. (Tenth: The place between the pillars (Sawari) where the followers line up. Abdul Hamid bin Mahmud said: (Hasan Sahih) We prayed behind an Amir of the Amirs, so people forced us, and we prayed between the two pillars. [So Anas bin Malik began delaying]. When we prayed, Anas said: We used to avoid this at the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family). The Hadith was extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Hakim, and Ahmad from Sufyan Al-Thawri from...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Yahya bin Hani bin Urwah Al-Muradi from Abdul Hamid with it. The context is Al-Tirmidhi's, and he said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). What is between the brackets is Al-Nasa'i's. Al-Hakim has the meaning and said: (Sahih). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Al-Hafiz also authenticated it in (Al-Fath). It has a witness from the Hadith of Harun bin Muslim from Qatadah bin Mu'awiyah bin Qurrah from his father, he said: (Sahih Isnad) (We used to be forbidden from lining up between the pillars at the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and we were driven away from them strictly). Extracted by Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, and Al-Tayalisi. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Isnad) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is Hasan to me, for all its men are trustworthy except Harun bin Muslim; Abu Hatim said: (Unknown), and Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat), and in (Al-Taqrib) he is: (Mastur - hidden). Al-Dhahabi said in Al-Mizan after mentioning Abu Hatim's saying that he is unknown:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (I say: Abu Dawood, Al-Tayalisi, Salam bin Qutaibah, and Umar bin Sinan narrated from him). I say: He indicated by this that he is known by the narration of these trustworthy narrators from him, except that Umar bin Sinan, I did not find a biography for him. Al-Shawkani said after discussing it and the Hadith of Anas before it: (And it is witnessed by what Al-Hakim extracted and authenticated from the Hadith of Anas with the wording: (We were forbidden from prayer between the pillars and driven away from them, and he said: Do not pray between the pillars and complete the rows).) I say: With this wording it is Gharib (strange), and I did not find it in (Al-Mustadrak), and he cited it in it from his Hadith in two places as previously indicated with other than this wording. Furthermore, Al-Shawkani's words imply that it is a different Hadith than the Hadith of Anas he discussed earlier. And Allah knows best. Then Al-Shawkani said: (The two Hadiths mentioned in the chapter indicate the dislike of prayer between the pillars. The apparent meaning of the Hadith of Mu'awiyah bin Qurrah from his father and the Hadith of Anas mentioned by Al-Hakim is that it is forbidden (Haram). The cause for dislike is what Abu Bakr Ibn Al-Arabi said, that it is either due to the cutting of the row or because it is the place for collecting shoes. Ibn Sayyid Al-Nas said: The first is more likely because the second is innovated. Al-Qurtubi said: It was narrated that the cause of dislike for that is that it is the prayer place of the believing Jinn. Some people of...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...knowledge went to the dislike of prayer between pillars. Al-Tirmidhi said: A group of the people of knowledge disliked lining up between pillars, and this is the view of Ahmad and Ishaq. A group of the people of knowledge permitted that. End quote. Al-Nakha'i held the view of dislike. Sa'id bin Mansur narrated in his (Sunan) the prohibition of that from Ibn Mas'ud, Ibn Abbas, and Hudhayfah. Ibn Sayyid Al-Nas said: No opponent is known to them among the Companions. Abu Hanifa, Malik, Al-Shafi'i, and Ibn Al-Mundhir permitted it by analogy to the Imam and the individual. Ibn Al-Arabi said: There is no dispute regarding its permissibility in case of narrowness. As for in spaciousness, it is disliked for the congregation. As for the individual, there is no harm in it; the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed in the Kaaba between its pillars. End quote. In it is that the Hadith of Anas mentioned in the chapter was reported in a state of narrowness due to his saying: 'So the people forced us.' It can be said: The necessity indicated in the Hadith did not reach the level of necessity where hardship is lifted. The Hadith of Qurrah only contains the mention of prohibition from lining up between pillars and did not say: We were forbidden from prayer between pillars. So in it is evidence for differentiating between the congregation and the individual. However, the Hadith of Anas which Al-Hakim mentioned contains prohibition of absolute prayer, so the absolute is carried on the restricted. What indicates this is his prayer, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, between the two pillars. So the prohibition based on this is specific to the prayer of followers [in congregation] between pillars, not the prayer of the Imam and the individual. This is the best of what is said. What preceded of analogizing the followers to the Imam and individual is invalid consideration (Fasid Al-I'tibar) due to its clashing with the Hadiths of the chapter). End of Al-Shawkani's words with some abbreviation, and it is all truth with no dust on it, except his saying: (That the Hadith of Anas in Al-Hakim...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...contains prohibition of absolute prayer) is not apparent to me as absolute; rather, it is restricted to congregational prayer like the Hadith of Mu'awiyah bin Qurrah, evidenced by his saying: (Do not pray between the pillars and complete the rows). This, to me, is like an explanation for the prohibition mentioned before it. And Allah knows best. If this is authentic and the Hadith of Anas is authentic with this addition, then in it is the indication to the cause of prohibition, which is cutting the rows. Therefore, he ordered completing them in the Hadith itself. And Allah knows best. Imam Ahmad explicitly stated this; Abu Dawood said in his (Masa'il): (I heard Ahmad being asked about prayer between pillars? He said: It is only disliked because it cuts the row; if there is distance between them, I hope [it is fine]). Therefore, I say: It is appropriate for one who wants to build a mosque or Jami' to order the engineer to make a plan for him where pillars are few as possible to minimize the corruption resulting from their presence in mosques regarding cutting rows and narrowing the space for worshipers. It is indeed possible today to build a mosque without any pillar by means of cement and iron (concrete) if the mosque is not very wide. Several mosques have been built in Damascus on this model, like the (Lala Pasha) Mosque in Baghdad Street and Al-Murabit Mosque in Al-Muhajirin and others. The rows in them are all connected except the front rows; they are cut, unfortunately, due to this innovation that has pervaded almost all mosques. I mean by that the tall, long Minbar with many steps. Despite being an innovation contrary to his guidance, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding his Minbar of three steps, and despite what it contains of decoration, engravings, extravagance, and wasting...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...money (1) - it is like the pillar in cutting rows; rather, it is more harmful than it because it cuts many rows proportional to its length. So scholars must clarify that and call in their lessons and sermons for the removal of these Minbars and returning them to what his Minbar, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was upon. Those in authority must execute that to save the worshipers from its corruptions. Among its corruptions which are not found in pillars is that it leads in some cases to the corruption and invalidity of prayer as we have witnessed repeatedly. It often happens that the Imam forgets...
foot_note: 1. (1) How excellent is what Sheikh Jamal al-Din al-Qasimi, may Allah have mercy on him, cited in his book (Islah al-Masajid min al-Bida' wa al-Awa'id) where he said: (A scholar said: Who among the people of insight would dare, in generations where competition reached its limit in erecting mosque walls and domes and decorating them and spending heaped talents on their furniture and furnishings? Who would dare in those times to say to those donors: You are only building edifices to entrap the common people in the traps of innovation and spending your money to transform religion into formal worships, just as happened in the polytheism of all past nations who substituted the beauty of creed with the beauty of temple walls and the light of faith with the lights of altars, until they made the rites of religion resemble celebration banquets and closer to banquet gatherings due to the intensity of minds being distracted by inscriptions and decorations, and thoughts wandering in contemplation inside niches and creating Minbars? While the intent of those gatherings was to strip the mind of the distractions of the material world and save it from the charming clay appearance, and for the soul to go on the wings of that merged gathering to the door of Divine Mercy to knock on it with the hand of abstraction and pure servitude, to return to its world with light from the world of Holiness that stabilizes it in its struggle, establishes it on its path, and protects it from the trials of the world and its slippery slopes, until if it performs its function in this life, it ascends to its world with that strength it acquired and enters the gardens of Divine Emanation in the state prepared for it. End quote.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the first Tashahhud and stands up saying Takbir for the third Rak'ah, and those behind him follow him. As for those behind the Minbar on the right side, they have no knowledge of the forgetfulness that occurred to the Imam, so they think he said Takbir correctly [for sitting], so they sit for Tashahhud while the Imam is standing. When he says Takbir for bowing (Ruku'), these people say Takbir for standing. They do not realize the opposition and lack of following they are in until the Imam raises his head from bowing saying (Sami' Allahu liman hamidah). Here begins the funny yet weeping scene; you see one of them cutting the prayer and renewing the start, another trying in his claim to catch the Imam and follow him so he stands from Tashahhud then stands for a moment then bows then raises then catches the Imam in prostration or after that. What is stranger than that may happen; sometimes it happens that some of them prompt the Imam if he intends to stand before Tashahhud to the third [Rak'ah] forgetfully by saying: (Subhan Allah). Those behind the Minbar hear it, so they know the Imam forgot, but they are ignorant of what happened to the Imam: Did he return to Tashahhud so they remain sitting, or had he stood up fully so it is not permissible for him then to return to Tashahhud so he remains standing and they stand with him? Therefore, you see them in confusion (Hais Bais); some sitting, some standing, another sat then stood, and a fourth conversely stood then sat thinking the Imam did likewise. All these farces resulted from opposing his guidance, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding his Minbar. Perhaps those in charge of mosques will notice this and undertake what is incumbent upon them of reform therein: And {Indeed in that is a reminder for whoever has a heart or who listens while he is present [in mind]} [Qaf / 37]. Therefore, some scholars from the Salaf went to say that the first row cut by the Minbar...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...is not the row; rather, it is the continuous row in front of the Minbar. Al-Ghazali said in (Al-Ihya): (One should not overlook three matters in seeking the first row (he mentioned the first and second then said:) The third: That the Minbar cuts some rows. The first row is only the single continuous one in the courtyard of the Minbar, and what is on its sides is cut. Al-Thawri used to say: The first row is the one appearing in front of the Minbar. This is plausible because it is connected and because the one sitting in it faces the Khatib (preacher) and hears from him. It is not far-fetched to say: The closest to the Qiblah is the first row, and this meaning is not observed). Al-Nawawi asserted this in (Al-Majmu') where he said: (Know that the intended is the first row which follows the Imam whether a Minbar, compartment, columns, or others intervene or not). In any case, prayer behind the Minbar is not free of dislike due to the exposure of prayer in it to corruption and invalidity. So either he prays in the row on the other side of the Minbar where the Imam's movements are not hidden from him, or he prays in the other row. We do likewise, if Allah wills; we do not pray between pillars but move back from them or advance as Anas bin Malik did. There is no difference for us between that and prayer behind the Minbar because the cause is one, and because in this prayer there is exposure to its corruption which is not in the prayer between pillars as preceded. And Allah the Exalted knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (7 - And whatever is other than these ten places, prayer in it is permissible without the slightest dislike. Text has come regarding some of them so it was necessary to clarify them, and they are: First: The place which impurity affected then its trace went away by drying, for (Dogs used to urinate and go back and forth in the mosque during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and they would not sprinkle anything over that) knowing that they used to stand in it for prayer and others). The Hadith is from the narration of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood - and the context is his - and Al-Bayhaqi extracted it from the path of Yunus from Ibn Shihab: Hamzah bin Abdullah bin Umar told me, he said: Ibn Umar said: I used to sleep in the mosque during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and I was a young, bachelor lad, and dogs used to... The Hadith. It is suspended (Mu'allaq) with Al-Bukhari where he said: And Ahmad bin Shabib said: My father told me from Yunus with it. The word: 'urinate' is not in some copies, but it is with Al-Bayhaqi connected from Ahmad bin Shabib. Salih bin Abi Al-Akhdar followed him [narrating] from Al-Zuhri but differed with him in the chain saying: From Al-Zuhri from Salim bin Abdullah from his father with it. Ahmad extracted it. Salih bin Abi Al-Akhdar is weak due to his memory, especially if he contradicts a trustworthy narrator as here.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Abu Dawood used the Hadith as evidence for what we mentioned, as he said: (Chapter on the purity of the ground if it dries). Then he mentioned the Hadith. Ibn Al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Al-Ighatha): (Ahmad stated regarding the rope of the washer that if he spreads impure clothes on it then the sun dries it, then he spreads pure clothes on it, he said: There is no harm in it. This is like the saying of Abu Hanifa: The impure ground is purified by wind and sun. It is a view for the companions of Ahmad, such that even Tayammum is permissible with it. The Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, is like a text on that). I say: Then he mentioned it and said: (This is not directed except to the view of the purity of the ground by wind and sun). Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in (Al-Mawdu'at) after mentioning the Hadith: (Were it not for the consideration that it becomes pure by drying, that would have been a remnant on it with the description of impurity, knowing that they stood on it for prayer certainly due to the smallness of the mosque and the large number of worshipers. This is like consensus in the position of realizing the dispute). More elaboration on the issue preceded in purifying impurities. (Second: Sheepfolds, for (He, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked about prayer in sheepfolds? So they said: Pray in them, for they are a blessing)). The Hadith has a Sahih chain and it is from the Hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: It preceded in full with discussion on it regarding extraction and authentication in the prohibition of prayer in camel pens. (And in another Hadith: (And pray in sheep resting places (Murah), for they are closer to mercy)). This is from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Mughaffal. Ahmad extracted it with a Hasan chain as preceded there. (And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Pray in sheep resting places and wipe their mucus/dust (Rugham), for they are from the animals of Paradise)). This is from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are three paths from him: First: From Ya'qub bin Kasib: Ibn Abi Hazim told us from Kathir bin Zaid from Al-Walid bin Rabah from him raised [to the Prophet] with it. Al-Bayhaqi extracted it. This is a Hasan chain; all its men are trustworthy except that Ya'qub bin Kasib - who is Ibn Humaid - and Kathir bin Zaid have some speech regarding them due to their memory, but that does not lower their Hadith from the rank of Hasan, especially if they are not alone in it. He said in (Al-Taqrib): (Kathir bin Zaid is truthful but errs, and Ya'qub bin Humaid bin Kasib, and he was attributed to his grandfather, is truthful, perhaps hallucinates/errs).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Second Path: Muslim bin Ibrahim narrated it from Sa'id bin Muhammad Al-Zuhri (and in the copy: Al-Jawhari) from Ibn Al-Musayyib from Abu Huraira from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Al-Bayhaqi mentioned it like this suspended. These are all trustworthy men of the Six except Sa'id bin Muhammad or Al-Zuhri or Al-Jawhari, for I did not find a biography for him. Third: From Ibrahim bin Uyaynah, he said: I heard Abu Hayyan mentioning from Abu Zur'ah bin Amr bin Jarir from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Indeed sheep are from the animals of Paradise, so wipe their mucus/dust and pray in their resting places). Al-Bayhaqi extracted it. This is a Hasan chain as well; its men are trustworthy except Ibrahim bin Uyaynah, who is truthful but hallucinates as in (Al-Taqrib), except that the narrator of this Hadith from him, Sakhtawayh bin Mazyar, I did not find anyone who wrote his biography. The Hadith was cited in (Al-Majma') with the wording: (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was asked about prayer in sheepfolds? He said: Wipe their mucus/dust and pray in their resting places, for they are from the animals of Paradise). Al-Bazzar narrated it. It contains Abdullah bin Ja'far bin Najih, who is weak. Ahmad bin Adi said: (His Hadith is written but not used as evidence).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: But it is strengthened by the paths before it, so the Hadith is Sahih through them. It is not harmed that it came as Mawquf (stopped) as Al-Bayhaqi said: (Humaid bin Malik narrated it from Abu Huraira stopped at him [Mawquf], and it was said: Raised [Marfu'], and the Mawquf is more correct). For raising is an addition that must be accepted, especially since the Mawquf has the ruling of Marfu' here because it is not said by mere opinion, for it is not permissible for anyone to say: Such animal is from the animals of Paradise, except by text from the Infallible, as is obvious and not hidden. This, and there are other Hadiths regarding prayer in sheepfolds mentioned previously where indicated. Ibn Al-Qayyim said in (Ighathat Al-Lahfan): (And from that is that the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, is prayer wherever he was and in any place that happened, except what he forbade). He said: (He used to pray in sheepfolds and ordered that, and did not stipulate a barrier. Ibn Al-Mundhir said: Everyone preserved from the people of knowledge agreed on the permissibility of prayer in sheepfolds except Al-Shafi'i, for he said: I dislike that unless it is free of their dung). Then Ibn Al-Qayyim mentioned the Hadith of Abu Huraira and Ibn Mughaffal and indicated some of what we indicated, then said: (So where is this guidance compared to the action of one who only prays on a rug spread over the carpet...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...over the mat, and places a handkerchief on it, and does not walk on the mat nor on the carpet; nay, he walks on it pecking like a sparrow? How worthy are these of the saying of Ibn Mas'ud: You are more guided than the companions of Muhammad, or you are upon a branch of misguidance) End quote abbreviated. Know that the command to pray in sheepfolds in these Hadiths is for permissibility (Ibahah), not obligation. Al-Iraqi said: (By agreement. He, peace be upon him, only alerted to that so it would not be thought that its ruling is the ruling of camels, or it came out in answer to the questioner when he asked him about both matters, so he answered regarding camels with prevention and regarding sheep with permission. As for the encouragement mentioned in the Hadiths with the wording: (for they are a blessing), it was mentioned to distance them from the ruling of camels, just as he described camel owners with harshness and cruelty and described sheep owners with tranquility). Mentioned by Al-Shawkani. We only said that prayer is permissible in places other than those previously mentioned due to the lack of prohibition regarding them or lack of its authenticity, like prayer on the main road, on top of the Kaaba, in the bottom of the valley, and similar places, and due to the generality of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (So whichever man prayer overtakes, let him pray where it overtook him). This is general and must be adhered to in every place except what was excluded from it of what was previously mentioned. And success is by Allah. (Third: Inside the Kaaba voluntarily, for the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he entered Mecca on the Day of Conquest (prayed in [the interior of] the Kaaba [two rak'ahs] between the two pillars [and between him and the Qiblah was three cubits]).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Then the Hadith, even if it was reported regarding voluntary prayer, the apparent view is that obligatory prayer is like it in this permissibility due to the equality of rulings for obligatory and voluntary prayers in obligation, prohibition, and permissibility except what the Lawgiver excluded, and there is no exclusion here). The Hadith is from the narration of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Malik, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from many paths, at length and briefly, from Nafi' from him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, arrived on the Day of Conquest and dismounted at the courtyard of the Kaaba and sent for Uthman bin Talha. He came with the key and opened the door. He said: Then the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, entered along with Bilal, Usama bin Zaid, and Uthman bin Talha, and ordered the door to be closed. So they stayed in it for a long time then opened the door. Abdullah said: So I rushed to the people and met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, coming out with Bilal following him. I said to Bilal: Did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, pray in it? He said: Yes. I said: Where? He said: Between the two columns facing him. He said: And I forgot to ask him how much he prayed. The context is Muslim's. It is with Al-Tirmidhi very briefly except for the prayer, and it contains the first addition. It is with Muslim also from another path from Ibn Shihab: Salim bin Abdullah informed me from his father similarly.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This path is with Al-Bukhari and Al-Nasa'i also, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi - attributing it to Al-Bukhari - and Ahmad, and likewise Al-Darimi. The last addition is with Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tahawi, Ahmad, and Al-Bayhaqi from the first path with a Sahih chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs, and Al-Bukhari has its meaning. As for the middle addition, it is from another path from Ibn Umar. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad from paths from Sufyan bin Sulayman, he said: I heard Mujahid say: Ibn Umar was approached - while he was in his house - and told: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, has entered the Kaaba. He said: So I came and found the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, had come out, and I found Bilal standing between the two doors. I said: O Bilal, did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, pray in the Kaaba? He said: Yes, he prayed (rak'a) two rak'ahs between these two pillars - and he pointed for him between the two pillars on your left when you enter. He said: Then he came out and prayed facing the Kaaba two rak'ahs. The context is Ahmad's. Layth and Awn bin Abi Sulaym and Khasif followed him on this addition: (two rak'ahs), both from Mujahid; Ahmad extracted them. Mujahid was not alone in it from Ibn Umar; rather, Abdullah bin Abi Mulaikah followed him in Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad, and its chain is Sahih. And Amr bin Dinar also briefly...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...in Ahmad, and its chain is also Sahih on the condition of the Six. Likewise, Al-Tahawi narrated it. The Hadith has witnesses, including: From Abdul Rahman bin Safwan, he said: I said to Umar bin Al-Khattab: How did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, do when he entered the Kaaba? He said: He prayed two rak'ahs. Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad from Yazid bin Abi Ziyad from Mujahid from him. This Yazid is Al-Hashimi, and he is weak due to bad memory. However, Al-Hafiz cited the Hadith in (Al-Fath) with the wording: (He said: When he came out, peace and blessings be upon him, I asked those who were with him, so they said: He prayed two rak'ahs at the middle pillar. Al-Tabarani extracted it with a Sahih chain). So it appears that it is with Al-Tabarani from a path other than this Yazid, otherwise Al-Hafiz would not have authenticated it while he is the one who says in his biography in (Al-Taqrib): (Weak, grew old and changed and accepted prompting). Al-Tahawi also narrated it from his path similar to Al-Tabarani's narration. Among them is from Shaybah bin Uthman, narrated from him by Abdul Rahman bin Al-Rajjaj, he said: I came to Shaybah bin Uthman and said: O Abu Uthman, Ibn Abbas says: Indeed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Did he enter the Kaaba and not pray? He said: Yes, he prayed two rak'ahs at the two front pillars, then he pressed his back against them. Al-Tahawi recorded it via Abdullah bin Muslim bin Hormuz from him, and this Abdullah was weakened by Ahmad, Ibn Ma'in, Al-Nasa'i, and others. As for Abdul Rahman bin Al-Rajjaj, I did not know him. Al-Haythami cited it in (Al-Majmu) similarly and said: (Al-Tabarani recorded it in (Al-Kabir) and in it is Abdul Rahman bin Al-Zajjaj - thus with a Zain, and in Al-Tahawi with a Ra - and I did not find anyone who wrote his biography). I say: Perhaps Al-Hafiz Al-Asqalani knew him, for he said: (Al-Tabarani recorded it with a good (Jayyid) chain). However, it is problematic that it is via Ibn Hormuz, and he [Al-Hafiz] weakened him in (Al-Taqrib), though it is possible that Al-Tabarani narrated it from a path other than his. And Allah knows best. Among them is from Uthman bin Talha: That the Prophet (peace be upon him) entered the House and prayed two rak'ahs facing you when you enter between the two pillars. Recorded by Al-Tahawi, Ahmad, and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) via Hammad bin Salamah from Hisham bin Urwa from his father from him. This is a strong chain as Al-Hafiz said, and its men are the men of Muslim.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tayalisi narrated from it the prayer in the Kaaba from this aspect. Al-Bayhaqi narrated from him and said: (There is Irsal [disconnection] in it between Urwa and Uthman). Ibn Al-Turkmani refuted him saying: (I say: Urwa heard from his father Al-Zubayr, and his hadith from him is recorded in (Sahih Al-Bukhari) in places, and Al-Zubayr died earlier than Uthman bin Talha, so there is nothing preventing Urwa from hearing from Uthman. Furthermore, the author of (Al-Kamal) explicitly stated his hearing from him). Among them is from Jabir who said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) entered the House on the Day of Conquest and prayed two rak'ahs in it. Recorded by Al-Tahawi via Abu Al-Zubayr from him. Its men are trustworthy, but Abu Al-Zubayr is a Mudallis and he used the 'An'ana [saying 'from']. This has been problematized by Ibn Umar's statement in the previous narrations from him regarding Bilal that he said: Yes, he prayed two rak'ahs; along with his statement in the first narration via Nafi from him: And I forgot to ask him how much he prayed. Al-Bayhaqi and others answered this by saying that it (is possible that Ibn Umar reported the minimum of what prayer constitutes and remained silent about what exceeded that because he did not ask Bilal). Based on this, his saying: 'Two rak'ahs' is from the words of Ibn Umar, not from the words of Bilal, which is far-fetched as you see. Nevertheless, Al-Hafiz said after mentioning a similar reconciliation: (I found what supports this and provides another reconciliation between the two hadiths, which is what Umar bin Shabba recorded in Kitab Makkah via Abdul Aziz bin Abi Rawad from Nafi...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...from Ibn Umar in this hadith: (Bilal met me, so I said: What did the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, do here? He signaled with his hand, meaning he prayed two rak'ahs, using the index and middle fingers). Based on this, his saying: 'I forgot to ask him how much he prayed' carries the possibility that he did not ask him verbally and he [Bilal] did not answer him verbally; rather, he benefited the knowledge of the two rak'ahs from his gesture, not his speech). I say: This is closer than the first reconciliation. Furthermore, Al-Hafiz went too far afield when he attributed the hadith of Ibn Abi Rawad to Ibn Shabba while it is in the (Musnad) with the exact mentioned wording. The hadith of Ibn Umar has other abbreviated paths in Al-Tayalisi, Ahmad, Al-Bayhaqi, and Al-Tahawi with the wording: (He prayed in the House). Added in a narration: (And there will come to you one who forbids you from it, so you will listen to him. He meant - Ibn Abbas). Ahmad added: (He said: And Ibn Abbas was sitting near him). Its chain is Sahih according to the condition of Muslim. It is via Shu'bah from Simak Al-Hanafi: I heard Ibn Umar with it. Sa'd narrated from Simak saying: I heard Ibn Abbas saying: Do not place anything of the House behind you... and he completed it entirely. And I heard Ibn Umar saying: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) prayed in it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Its chain is also Sahih according to his condition. This statement of Ibn Abbas was also narrated by Al-Tabarani with the wording: I do not like to pray in the Kaaba; whoever prays in it has left something behind him. However, my brother told me that the Prophet (peace be upon him), when he entered it, fell prostrate between the two pillars, then sat and supplicated and did not pray. He said in (Al-Majmu): (Al-Tabarani recorded it in (Al-Kabir) and in it is Ibn Ishaq, who is trustworthy but a Mudallis). I say: It is authentically established from Ibn Abbas that he used to deny that the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed in the Kaaba, although he did not witness that. He would narrate that sometimes from his brother Al-Fadl as in this narration—and it is likewise in the (Musnad) and others from other paths—and sometimes he narrates it from Usama bin Zaid as in Muslim and others. Perhaps his hadith regarding facing the Qibla will come, God willing. However, scholars adopted the narration of Bilal and those with him from the Companions because it is an addition from a trustworthy person, and because he is an Affirmer (Muthbit), and the Affirmer takes precedence over the Negator (Nafi), as is the rule in such differences. The meaning of Usama's saying: 'He did not pray' is: 'I did not see him pray'. So he did not know, while the others knew, and he who knows is a proof against he who does not know. Therefore, the majority went to the permissibility of prayer in the House [Kaaba], both obligatory (Fard) and voluntary (Nafl). Abu Hanifa, Al-Thawri, and the majority of scholars held this view, as Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu). Al-Tirmidhi said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The hadith of Bilal is a Hasan Sahih hadith, and the practice is according to it among most people of knowledge; they see no harm in praying in the Kaaba. Malik bin Anas said: There is no harm in voluntary prayer in the Kaaba, but he disliked that the obligatory prayer be prayed in the Kaaba. Al-Shafi'i said: There is no harm in praying the obligatory and voluntary prayer in the Kaaba because the ruling of voluntary and obligatory regarding purity and Qibla is the same). This which Al-Shafi'i said is the truth, God willing, because although the hadith appeared regarding voluntary prayer, it is apparent that the obligatory is like it in this permissibility due to the equality of rulings for voluntary and obligatory prayers in obligation, prohibition, and permissibility, except what the Lawgiver excluded, and there is no exception here. Due to the clarity of what Al-Shafi'i said, Ibn Hazm adopted it, and he is who he is in his literalism. He said in (Al-Muhalla) responding to the followers of Malik, the text of which is: (No one ever said: That his prayer, peace be upon him, mentioned was towards other than the Qibla. He, peace be upon him, has stated that the entire earth is a place of prayer (Masjid), and the interior of the Kaaba is the best of the earth and the most excellent, so it is the best of mosques and the most worthy for obligatory and voluntary prayer. It is not permissible for other than a rider, fearful person, or sick person to pray voluntary prayer towards other than the Qibla. Differentiating between the obligatory and voluntary without Quran, Sunnah, or Consensus is an error. And success is with Allah). Despite the clarity and obviousness of this, Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, differed in this, choosing what Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, went to. He said in (Al-Ikhtiyarat):

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The obligatory prayer is not valid in the Kaaba, but the voluntary is; this is the apparent view of Ahmad's school. As for the Prophet's prayer, peace be upon him, in the House, it was voluntary, so the obligatory is not appended to it, because he, peace be upon him, prayed inside the House two rak'ahs then said: This is the Qibla. It is likely - and Allah knows best - that his mention of this statement immediately after the prayer outside the House was an explanation that the Qibla commanded to be faced is the entire structure, lest someone imagine that facing part of it was [sufficient] in the obligatory prayer because he prayed the voluntary prayer in the House. Otherwise, all people knew that the Kaaba, in general, is the Qibla. So this statement must have a benefit and teach something that might be hidden and be a place of doubt. Ibn Abbas narrated this hadith and understood this meaning from it, and he is most knowledgeable of the meaning of what he heard). I say: Ibn Abbas who narrated the hadith did not understand this meaning with this detail that the Sheikh went to regarding the prayer of voluntary in the Kaaba exclusive of the obligatory. For he [Ibn Abbas] denied that he [the Prophet], peace be upon him, prayed in the House at all, as he said: 'And he did not pray until he exited from it; when he exited, he prayed two rak'ahs facing the Kaaba and said: This is the Qibla.' Furthermore, he, may Allah be pleased with him, did not hear this statement from him, peace be upon him, directly as the Sheikh's words imply; rather, he took it from Usama or others from the Companions as previously mentioned. In that case, he is equal to others who did not hear that from the Prophet, peace be upon him. Moreover, the Sheikh's words imply the permissibility of facing part of the structure of the Kaaba in voluntary prayer, but in obligatory prayer, one must face all of it. I wish I knew how it is possible to face all of it practically! For it is axiomatic that one facing the Kaaba from outside it only faces...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...what is aligned in front of him, while most of it remains to his right and left, not facing it? In that case, what is the difference between this and praying inside it, for in both cases he is only facing part of it? Therefore, Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, said: (The followers of Malik argued by saying: Whoever prays inside the Kaaba has turned his back on part of the Kaaba. [He said:] Allah Almighty only said: {And from wherever you go out [for prayer], turn your face toward al-Masjid al-Haram. And wherever you [believers] may be, turn your faces toward it} [Al-Baqarah: 150]. If what the Malikis mentioned were a proof, it would not be lawful for anyone to pray in the Masjid Al-Haram because it is the Qibla by the text of Allah's speech in the Quran, and whoever prays in it must inevitably turn his back on some of it; so the corruption of this saying is apparent. Also, anyone who prays towards the Masjid Al-Haram or towards the Kaaba must inevitably leave some of it to his right and some to his left. There is no difference according to any of the people of knowledge between turning one's back to the Qibla in prayer and placing it on his right or his left. So it is correct that Allah Almighty never tasked us with observing this; He only tasked us to face with our faces what faces us of the wall of the Kaaba or the wall of the Mosque facing the Kaaba wherever we are only). As for the Sheikh's saying, may Allah have mercy on him: (This statement must have a benefit), it is true, but it is not apparent from this statement what Sheikh Al-Islam understood regarding the difference between voluntary and obligatory in facing [the Qibla]. It seems that for this reason, none of the commentators went to it. Al-Hafiz mentioned regarding the meaning of his saying, peace be upon him: (This is the Qibla) four opinions of scholars, none of which contain this view that the Sheikh went to. And it will come...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...to be mentioned, God willing, where previously indicated. Also indicating the permissibility of prayer is this coming hadith: (And Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: (I loved to enter the House and pray in it, so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, took my hand and entered me into the Hijr and said: Indeed your people, when they built the Kaaba, shortened its building and excluded the Hijr from the House. So if you wish to pray in the House, pray in the Hijr, for it is a piece of it). The hadith was recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i as well, Al-Tahawi - and the context is his - and Ahmad via Alqama bin Abi Alqama from his mother from her. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih). I say: This Umm Alqama is named Murjana and she is famous. In (Al-Taqrib): (She is acceptable/Maqbula). She was followed by Safiyyah bint Shaybah, who is trustworthy and famous from the men of the two Sheikhs. Recorded by Al-Nasa'i and Al-Tayalisi briefly with the wording: I said: O Messenger of Allah, will you not enter the House? He said: (Enter the Hijr for it is from the House). Its chain is Sahih according to their condition.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It has another path from her narrated by Ata bin Al-Saib from Saeed bin Jubair from Aisha similar to the first. Recorded by Al-Bayhaqi and Ahmad, and its men are trustworthy except that Ata had become confused (Ikhtalat). (And he, peace be upon him, said to Uthman bin Talha: (If I had seen the two horns of the ram when I entered the House, I forgot to order you to cover them; so cover them, for there should not be anything in the House that distracts the worshiper). Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad via Sufyan who said: Narrated to me Mansour from his maternal uncle Musafi' from Safiyyah bint Shaybah, mother of Mansour, who said: A woman from Bani Sulaim who delivered most of the people of our house informed me: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent to Uthman bin Talha saying... so he mentioned it. This is a Sahih chain; its men are all trustworthy men of Muslim. Al-Tahawi does not have: 'from his maternal uncle Musafi'. The hadith with him is from Mansour bin Safiyyah from Safiyyah bint Shaybah who said... His brother Muhammad bin Abdur Rahman narrated it from Mansour, making part of the hadith from Mansour from his mother directly, and part of it from Mansour from Musafi' from Umm Mansour. Imam Ahmad recorded it saying: Narrated to us Ali bin Ishaq said: Informed us Abdullah said: Informed us Muhammad bin Abdur Rahman from Mansour bin Abdur Rahman from his mother from...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Umm Uthman bint Sufyan - and she is the mother of the elder Bani Shaybah - Muhammad bin Abdur Rahman said: She had pledged allegiance to the Prophet, peace be upon him - that the Prophet, peace be upon him, called Shaybah so he opened [the door]. When he entered the House and returned, and Shaybah finished and returned, suddenly the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, [said]: Answer. So he came to him and he said: I saw a horn in the House so hide it. Mansour said: Abdullah bin Musafi' narrated to me from my mother from Umm Uthman bint Abi Sufyan that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him in the hadith: For there should not be in the House anything that distracts the worshipers. Ibn Hibban mentioned Muhammad bin Abdur Rahman in (Al-Thiqat), and Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (He is weak). I say: He contradicted Sufyan in several places in this hadith: First: He made part of the hadith from Mansour from his mother and part of it from him from Abdullah bin Musafi' from his mother. Second: He named the intermediary between Mansour and his mother as Abdullah bin Musafi', while Sufyan said: Musafi' bin Shaybah. He said: He named the Companion of the hadith who narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) as Shaybah, while Sufyan named him: Uthman bin Talha. The correct version is Sufyan's narration, which indicates the weakness of this Muhammad bin Abdur Rahman. And Allah knows best. The two hadiths indicate what the previous hadith indicated regarding the permissibility of prayer inside the Kaaba:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: As for the first of them: It is from the aspect that the Prophet, peace be upon him, approved Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, in her love to pray in it, except that he, peace be upon him, ordered her to pray in the Hijr and reasoned that it is part of the House. This indicates the permissibility of prayer in the entire House, and the Hijr is in it. Perhaps he, peace be upon him, ordered her to pray in it rather than the interior of the Kaaba at that time because the Hijr was more spacious for her and further from mixing with men. As for the second: He, peace be upon him, indicated in it the permissibility of prayer in it, as he ordered the removal of what distracts the worshiper therein from humility (Khushu'). Al-Tahawi, may Allah have mercy on him, deduced the permissibility we mentioned from the two hadiths, and quoted the opinion from Abu Hanifa and his two companions. It is the school of the majority as previously mentioned. In fact, the Shafi'is went so far as to say that voluntary prayer in the Kaaba is better than outside it, and likewise the obligatory if a congregation is not hoped for [outside] and the present congregation can pray inside it; if not possible, then outside is better. Al-Shafi'i said: (There is no place better or purer for prayer than the Kaaba).
