Thus Al-Nawawi mentioned it in (Al-Majmu), then he said in it: (If it is said: How did you assert that prayer in the Kaaba is better than outside it when there is disagreement among scholars regarding its validity, and exiting from disagreement is recommended? The answer is that we only recommend exiting from a respected disagreement, which is the disagreement in issues of Ijtihad. As for if the disagreement contradicts a Sahih Sunnah as in this issue, it has no sanctity and...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...it is not recommended to exit from it because its proponent was not reached by this Sunnah, and if it reached him and he opposed it, then the proof is established against him. And Allah knows best). This is true speech that must be preserved, for many Sheikhs are lenient in many Sunnahs merely because there is a disagreement from some scholars. Ibn Al-Qayyim mentioned in (Al-Zad) similar to what we quoted from Al-Nawawi, and the text of his words in that is: (Precaution is only prescribed if the Sunnah is not clear. But if it is clear, then precaution is to follow it and leave what opposes it. If leaving it is for the sake of disagreement as a precaution, then leaving what opposes it and following it is more cautious and more cautious. So precaution is two types: precaution to exit from the disagreement of scholars, and precaution to exit from the disagreement of the Sunnah. And the preponderance of one over the other is not hidden). (8 - And prayer is permissible on what is spread on the ground of rugs and the like which are permissible to sit on and are pure, for (he, peace be upon him, used to pray on the Khummrah [small palm-leaf mat])). This hadith is established from a group of Companions: (1) Maimuna, wife of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and it has two paths from her: The first recorded by: Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from Sulaiman Al-Shaibani from Abdullah bin Shaddad from her.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The other path was recorded by: Ahmad, and likewise Al-Nasa'i similarly. (2) Abdullah bin Abbas: Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via Ikrimah from him. Al-Hakim's wording is: Carpet (Bisat) instead of: Al-Khummrah. It is a narration of Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi. Ibn Majah also narrated it, as did Al-Bayhaqi via Zam'a bin Salih from Amr bin Dinar from Ibn Abbas. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih). (3) Aisha: Recorded by Al-Tayalisi and Ahmad via Hammad bin Salamah from Al-Azraq bin Qais from Dhakwan from her. This is a Sahih chain; its men are men of the Sahih. It has another path in (Al-Musnad) via Urwa from her, which is also Sahih according to the condition of the Six. (4) Anas bin Malik: It has two paths from him: First: Via Qatada from him, recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The other: Via Anas bin Sirin from him, recorded by Al-Bayhaqi. (5) Umm Sulaim: Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Bayhaqi via Affan said: Narrated to us Wuhaib said: Narrated to us Ayyub from Abu Qilaba from Anas bin Malik from her. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the Six. (6) Umm Salama: Recorded by Ahmad also: Narrated to us Affan: Narrated to us Wuhaib said: Narrated to us Khalid from Abu Qilaba from some of the children of Umm Salama from her. Its chain is like the one before it, were it not for this 'some' who was not named. However, Al-Haythami cited it in (Al-Majmu) and said: (Recorded by Abu Ya'la and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Awsat), and the men of the first are men of the Sahih). Perhaps he came named in Abu Ya'la. And Allah knows best. (7) Ibn Umar: Recorded by Ahmad via Sharik from Abu Ishaq from Al-Bahi from him. Then he recorded it from another aspect via Sharik with it except that he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (From Aisha or from Ibn Umar. Sharik doubted). And Sharik has poor memory. (8) Umm Habiba, wife of the Prophet, peace be upon him: Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and Abu Ya'la. Its men are men of the (Sahih). (9) Jabir bin Abdullah: In Al-Bazzar, and in it is Al-Hajjaj bin Artat, and there is disagreement regarding him as in (Al-Majmu). Know that (Al-Khummrah) with a Damma on the dotted Kha and Sukun on the Mim: is the size of what a man places his face on in his prostration, made of a mat or palm-leaf weave and the like of plants. It is not a Khummrah unless it is of this size. It was named Khummrah because its threads cover one another. Thus said Ibn Al-Athir in (Al-Nihayah). In (Al-Fath): (Al-Khattabi said: It is the prayer rug the worshiper prostrates on. Then he mentioned the hadith of Ibn Abbas regarding the mouse that dragged the wick until it threw it on the Khummrah which he, peace be upon him, was sitting on. In this is a clear statement applying Khummrah to what exceeds the size of the face). I say: This hadith of Ibn Abbas was recorded by Al-Bukhari in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad), Abu Dawood, and Al-Hakim via Amr bin Talha said: Narrated to us Asbat from Simak bin Harb from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas with it. Its completion is:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: So it burned a spot the size of a dirham from it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (When you sleep, extinguish your lamps, for Satan guides the like of this to the like of this so it burns you). This is a good (Jayyid) chain. Al-Hakim said: (Correct chain), and Al-Dhahabi agreed. (And on the Hasir [reed mat]), there are hadiths: (1) From Anas bin Malik, and it has paths and wordings from him: First: Via Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talha from him that the Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed on a Hasir. Recorded like this briefly by Al-Darimi and Ahmad, and it is in the (Two Sahihs) and others at length, and will come later. Second: Via Shu'bah from Anas bin Sirin who said: I heard Anas bin Malik say: A man from the Ansar said: I cannot pray with you - he was a large man - so he made food for the Prophet, peace be upon him, and invited him to his house. He spread a Hasir for him and sprinkled the edge of the Hasir, and he prayed two rak'ahs on it... The hadith. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tayalisi recorded it from this aspect briefly with the wording: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed two rak'ahs on a Hasir. Third: Via Thabit from him briefly without saying: two rak'ahs. Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir). (2) From Abu Saeed Al-Khudri: That he entered upon the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and found him praying on a Hasir, prostrating on it. Recorded by Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via Al-A'mash from Abu Sufyan from Jabir from him. His saying: (prostrating on it) is unique to Muslim and Ahmad. (3) From Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba with the wording: He used to pray on the Hasir and the tanned sheepskin (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Recorded by Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi via Yunus bin Al-Harith from Abu Awn Muhammad bin Ubaidullah Al-Thaqafi from his father from him. Al-Hakim said: (Correct according to the condition of the two Sheikhs). Al-Dhahabi said: (According to the condition of Muslim). This is an illusion, for Yunus bin Al-Harith and Ubaidullah Al-Thaqafi are not from the men of the two Sheikhs. Furthermore, the first of them is weak and the other is unknown; Ibn Hibban indicated that his hadith from Al-Mughira is disconnected as in (Al-Taqrib). The hadith was recorded by Ahmad from this aspect with the wording: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to pray or liked to pray on a tanned sheepskin.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (4) From Aisha with the wording: He had a Hasir that he would spread by day and make a barrier of by night, so people gathered to him and prayed behind him. Recorded by Al-Bukhari via Al-Maqburi from Abu Salamah from her. Al-Hafiz mentioned it in (Al-Fath) with the wording: He had a Hasir that he would spread and pray on. Perhaps he mentioned it by meaning or it is a narration of Al-Bukhari. As for what Abu Ya'la narrated from Shuraih that he asked Aisha: Did the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to pray on the Hasir, for I heard in the Book of Allah: {And We made Hell a prison-bed (Hasir) for the disbelievers} [Al-Isra: 8]? She said: He did not use to pray on it. There is a question regarding its establishment, even if Al-Haythami said: (Its men are trustworthy). His Sheikh Al-Iraqi said: (Its men are trustworthy), but this does not necessitate the authenticity of the chain as is not hidden to critics. Al-Shawkani said: (The way to reconcile between her hadith here and the other hadiths is that she only denied her knowledge, and he who knows his prayer on the Hasir takes precedence over the negator. Also, her hadith, even if its men are trustworthy, contains anomaly (Shudhudh) as Al-Iraqi said).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: This is the correct answer. As for the answer before it, it is based on the premise that Aisha did not narrate prayer on the Hasir, which is not the case as you learned. (And once (he prayed on a Hasir that had turned black from length of wear)). It is from the hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, that his grandmother Mulaikah invited the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for food, so he ate from it then the Messenger of Allah said: Stand so I may pray with you). Anas said: So I stood up to a Hasir of ours that had turned black from length of wear, so I sprinkled it with water. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, stood on it, and I and the orphan aligned behind him, and the old woman behind us. So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed two rak'ahs for us then left. Recorded by Malik, Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad; all three from Malik from Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talha from him. The wording is Al-Bukhari's. Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad narrated it from other paths from Ishaq similarly. In it: So he prostrated on it. He also narrated it briefly, and it passed in the first hadith. (And (on the bedding (Firash) which he and his family sleep on) and (It was of leather stuffed with palm fiber)). It is from the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. Recorded by Ahmad: Narrated to us Ibn Numair said: Narrated to us Hisham from his father from her, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to pray while I was lying transversely between him and the Qibla on the bedding

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: which he and his family sleep on. When he wanted to perform Witr, he woke me so I performed Witr. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the Six. Then he recorded it via Yahya from Hisham with it similarly. Likewise, Al-Bukhari recorded it from Yahya with it. Muslim recorded it from Waki' bin Hisham with it without mentioning the bedding. Then Al-Bukhari recorded it via Al-Zuhri: Informed me Urwa bin Al-Zubayr with it similar to the hadith of Ibn Numair. The hadith has other paths from Aisha similar to the narration of Waki' from Hisham. It will come, God willing, in (The Sutrah). Then Ahmad narrated with the first chain from Aisha who said: The bedding of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was of leather stuffed with palm fiber. Then he, Muslim, and Al-Tirmidhi in (Al-Shama'il) recorded it via paths from Hisham with it. In a wording of Ahmad: The bedding of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, which he and his family used to sleep on, was of leather stuffed with palm fiber. It has another path in Al-Tirmidhi; he narrated it from Abdullah bin Maimun who said: Informed us Ja'far bin Muhammad from his father from her.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a weak chain due to the weakness of Abdullah bin Maimun and its disconnection between Muhammad - who is Al-Baqir - and Aisha. Al-Bukhari narrated it suspended (Mu'allaq), and Ibn Abi Shaybah and Saeed bin Mansour connected it, both from Ibn Al-Mubarak from Humaid who said: Anas used to pray on his mattress. In these hadiths is clear evidence for the permissibility of praying and prostrating on everything spread on the ground other than the earth. Al-Tirmidhi recounted it from most people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and those after them; they did not see harm in praying on the carpet and rug (Tanfasah). It is the opinion of Al-Awza'i, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, Ishaq, and the majority of jurists. In it is a refutation of those among the predecessors who denied it, like Al-Aswad and his companions. Malik agreed with them, for he said in (Al-Mudawwanah): (Malik used to dislike that a man prostrate on rugs, hair carpets, clothes, and leather. He used to say: There is no harm in standing on them, bowing on them, and sitting on them, but he should not prostrate on them nor place his palms on them). Ibn Hazm said: (This is a saying with no evidence for its correctness. Prostration is obligatory on seven limbs: the feet, the knees, the hands, the forehead, and the nose. He permits placing all these limbs on what we mentioned except the forehead; so what is the difference between the limbs of prostration? There is no way to find a difference between them, neither from Quran, nor Sahih or weak Sunnah, nor Consensus, nor analogy, nor a Companion's saying, nor a plausible opinion).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Perhaps Malik and those who agreed with him were not reached by these Sahih hadiths; otherwise, the opinion of disliking what he, peace be upon him, did repeatedly is problematic, since he, peace be upon him, does not do a disliked act except for clarification occasionally, as explained by some scholars: such as forbidding something then doing it to indicate that the prohibition is not for unlawfulness but for dislike (Tanzih). So where is the prohibition here? The truth is what the majority went to regarding permissibility without the slightest dislike. {Indeed, in the Messenger of Allah you have a good example} [Al-Ahzab / 21]. This, and as for prayer in sandals, it is permissible with its condition, and the discussion on it has passed in the third matter of what is permissible to pray in, so check it. (9 - And it is obligatory to build mosques in every village or locality that has no mosques while they are in need of them, for (he, peace be upon him, ordered the building of mosques in the Dour), meaning: the localities which contain houses). The hadith is from the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said... so she mentioned it, and its completion is: and that they be cleaned and perfumed. Recorded by Abu Dawood, and from him Ibn Hazm and Ibn Majah, both from Zaida bin Qudamah; and Al-Tirmidhi and Ahmad, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, both from Salih bin Amir Al-Zubairi; and Ibn Majah also from Malik bin Saeed; all three from Hisham bin Urwa from his father from her. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the two Sheikhs. It is not harmed by the narrators who narrated it from Hisham from his father as Mursal, as Al-Tirmidhi recorded and said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (This is more correct than the first hadith). For Zaida and Malik bin Saeed are trustworthy authorities used as proof by the two Sheikhs and others, and they connected it [Mawsul], and connection is an addition that must be accepted. Ibn Khuzaima also narrated it connected in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib). The hadith has witnesses, among them: From Samura bin Jundub that he wrote to his son: As for what follows, indeed the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to order us to make them in our dwellings, and to improve their making and purify them. Recorded by Abu Dawood, and from him Al-Bayhaqi via Ja'far bin Sa'd bin Samura: Narrated to me Khubaib bin Sulaiman from his father Sulaiman bin Samura from his father Samura. This is a weak chain due to the weakness of this Ja'far and the anonymity of those above him. But it has another path that strengthens it recorded by Ahmad via Baqiyyah from Ishaq bin Tha'labah from Makhul bin Samura bin Jundub who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered us to adopt mosques in our dwellings and ordered us to clean them. This is a weak chain; Baqiyyah is a Mudallis and he used 'An'ana. Ishaq bin Tha'labah - Abu Hatim said: (Unknown, Munkar in hadith). And Makhul did not hear from Samura as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Ta'jeel).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Here are two illusions into which some illustrious scholars fell that must be pointed out. Majd al-Din mentioned the hadith with this wording in (Al-Muntaqa) and said: (Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Tirmidhi who authenticated it). Al-Shawkani said: (Recorded by Ahmad with a Sahih chain. And others recorded it with good (Jayyid) chains). I say: The first illusion is attributing it to Al-Tirmidhi, for we did not find it in his (Sunan), nor did Al-Nabulsi mention it in (Al-Dhakha'ir). The other: That Ahmad narrated it with a Sahih chain. It is not Sahih, nor even Hasan. How could it be when it contains Tadlis, disconnection, and ignorance? Yes, it has a strong witness in Ahmad: Narrated to us Yaqub: Narrated to us my father from Abu Ishaq - thus, and the correct is: Ibn Ishaq - Narrated to me Amr - thus with a Waw, and the correct is: Umar by deleting the Waw - bin Abdullah bin Urwa bin Al-Zubayr from his grandfather Urwa from one who narrated to him from the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to order us to make mosques in our dwellings (Dour) and to improve their making and purify them. This is a Hasan chain; its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Ibn Ishaq, who is trustworthy and has explicitly stated narrating (Tahdith). As for Al-Haythami's statement: (Recorded by Ahmad and the chain is Sahih), it contains some leniency. His saying: (Al-Dour). Ibn Hazm said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It means the localities and the suburbs. You say: The Dar (abode/locality) of Bani Abdul Ashhal and the Dar of Bani Al-Najjar, meaning the locality of each group of them). Al-Baghawi said in (Sharh Al-Sunnah): (He means the localities which contain houses. From it is His saying: {I will show you the home (Dar) of the defiantly disobedient} [Al-A'raf: 145], because they used to call the locality where a tribe gathered: a Dar. From it is the hadith: No Dar remained but a mosque was built in it). Al-Shawkani quoted it. Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in (Al-Mishkat): (Al-Dour) is plural of (Dar): It is a comprehensive noun for the building, the courtyard, and the locality. The intended meaning: The localities, for they used to call the locality where a tribe gathered a Dar. Or it is interpreted as adopting a room in the house for prayer like a mosque where the people of the house pray; Ibn Al-Malik said this. The first interpretation is the reliable one upon which practice is based. Then I saw Ibn Hajar mention that the meaning here is the localities and tribes. The wisdom of his command for the people of every locality to build a mosque therein is that it might be impossible or difficult for the people of a locality to go to another, thus being deprived of the reward of the mosque and the virtue of establishing the congregation in it. So they were ordered to do that so worship in their mosque would be facilitated for the people of every locality without hardship befalling them. Al-Baghawi said: Ata said: When Allah Almighty opened the garrison cities for Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, he ordered the Muslims to build mosques and ordered them not to build two mosques where one harms the other. Among the harm is the act of splitting the congregation if there is a mosque that accommodates them. If it becomes tight, he prescribed expanding it or adopting a mosque that accommodates them). Ibn Hazm said after citing the following hadith of Ibn Abbas with the wording: (I was not commanded to build up mosques high), he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (So he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not order the building of mosques in every place, but he ordered the building of mosques in the houses [tribal quarters]. So it is correct that what he, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade is other than what he ordered. Since that is the case, the correct manner of building mosques is as he, peace and blessings be upon him, clarified by his command and action. And he said: (And according to the extent that he, peace and blessings be upon him, built them. And the 'houses' are the localities...). Their mosque is the one regarding which there is no hardship upon them in answering its caller [Mu'adhin] for the five prayers. So whatever exceeds that or falls short of what he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not do is false and an evil (Munkar), and the evil must be changed...). He said: (And Ibn Mas'ud demolished a mosque built by Amr bin Utbah at the back of Kufa and returned it [the congregation] to the mosque of the community) (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) And in the book (Islah al-Masajid min al-Bida' wal-Awa'id) by Sheikh Jamal al-Din al-Qasimi, may Allah have mercy on him (pp. 103-104): (Al-Suyuti said in the book (Al-Amr bil-Ittiba' wal-Nahi 'an al-Ibtida'): (And among those innovated matters is the abundance of mosques in a single locality. That is because of what it contains of dividing the gathering, scattering the unity of the worshipers, dissolving the bond of joining in worship, the loss of the splendor of the abundance of worshipers, the diversity of the word, the difference of orientations, and opposing the wisdom of the legislation of congregations - meaning the unification of voices in performing acts of worship and their returning to one another with benefits and assistance - and harming the old mosque or resembling harm, or the love of fame and reputation, and spending money where there is no necessity). And Sheikh al-Islam, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Tafsir Surat al-Ikhlas) (pp. 172-173) after mentioning the Mosque of Harm (Masjid al-Dirar): (For this reason, the Salaf disliked praying in what resembled that and considered the ancient [mosque] better than the new one, because the ancient is further from being built for harm than the new one regarding which the intent is feared. And the age of the mosque is something for which it is praised. For this reason He said: {Then their place of sacrifice is at the Ancient House} and He said: {Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Bakkah}. For its antiquity implies the abundance of worship in it as well, and that implies an increase in its merit).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Therefore, when he, peace and blessings be upon him, migrated to Medina, he did not stay there but a few days until he built his noble mosque, as Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, said: (The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, arrived in Medina and alighted in the upper part of Medina in a tribe called Banu Amr bin Auf. He stayed with them for fourteen nights. Then he ordered the building of the mosque, so he sent for a group of Banu Najjar and said: 'O Banu Najjar, name a price to me for this enclosure of yours.' They said: 'No, by Allah, we do not seek its price except from Allah.' He said: It contained graves of the polytheists, ruins, and palm trees. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered the graves of the polytheists, so they were dug up; then the ruins, so they were leveled; and the palm trees, so they were cut down. They aligned the palm trunks towards the Qiblah of the mosque and made its jambs of stone. They began moving the rock while reciting poetry (Rajaz), and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was with them saying [while carrying the bricks: This burden (1) is not the burden of Khaybar, this is more righteous to our Lord and purer] 'O Allah, there is no good but the good of the Hereafter, so forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirah.' And in a narration: 'O Allah, indeed the reward is the reward of the Hereafter, so have mercy on the Ansar and the Muhajirah'). We cited the Hadith briefly, for in it after his saying 'fourteen nights': (Then he sent for Banu Najjar, and they came wearing swords. It is as if I am looking at the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, on his mount, and Abu Bakr is behind him, and the assembly of Banu Najjar is around him until he arrived at the courtyard of Abu Ayyub. He used to love to pray wherever prayer overtook him, and he would pray in the sheepfolds. And that he ordered... etc.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tayalisi, Ahmad, and Al-Bayhaqi via paths from Abu Al-Tayyah from him with it. Ibn Majah narrated it via Hammad bin Salamah from Abu Al-Tayyah briefly, which is a narration of Ahmad and Al-Tirmidhi from him via Shu'bah from him that he used to pray in the sheepfolds. And the other narration of Al-Bukhari is from the Hadith of Aisha in the Hadith of the Migration similar to the Hadith of Anas, containing the addition between the brackets. (And regarding building them is great merit and a large reward. Allah Almighty said: {The mosques of Allah are only to be maintained by those who believe in Allah and the Last Day and establish prayer and give zakah and do not fear except Allah, for it is expected that those will be of the [rightly] guided} [At-Tawbah: 18]. And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Whoever builds a mosque for Allah Almighty [even if like a sandgrouse's nest] [or smaller] [in which the name of Allah is mentioned], Allah builds for him the like of it in Paradise). The Hadith was narrated by Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Al-Bayhaqi via Ibn Wahb: Amr informed me that Bukair told him that he heard Ubaidullah Al-Khawlani mention:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: That he heard Uthman bin Affan, upon the people's talk about him when he built the Mosque of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him: 'You have spoken much, and indeed I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: (Whoever builds a mosque - Bukair said: I think he said: - seeking thereby the Face of Allah, Allah builds for him the like of it in Paradise).' It has other paths from Uthman: Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi also, and Ahmad narrated it from Abd al-Hamid bin Ja'far: My father told me from Mahmud bin Labid: That Uthman bin Affan wanted to build the mosque, but the people disliked that and wanted him to leave it in its [original] state. So he said... then he mentioned it with the wording mentioned above without the three additions between the parentheses, for they are in a Hadith other than the Hadith of Uthman, except for the first addition, for it is in Ibn Abi Shaybah in the Hadith of the chapter from another perspective from Uthman as in (Al-Fath). It has also come from others. Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Saghir) and Al-Bayhaqi via paths from Al-A'mash from Ibrahim Al-Taymi from his father from Abu Dharr, elevated [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Whoever builds a mosque for Allah, even if like a sandgrouse's nest, Allah builds a house for him in Paradise). This is an authentic chain. Al-Bazzar also narrated it, and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Fath)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and (Al-Targhib). Al-Tayalisi narrated it from Qais from Al-A'mash with it as Mawquf (stopped at the Companion), but the Marfu' (elevated to the Prophet) is more correct. Then Al-Tayalisi and Ahmad narrated it from the Hadith of Jabir from Ammar from Sa'id bin Jubair from Ibn Abbas, elevated, like the Hadith of Abu Dharr, and he added: (for her eggs). And Jabir is Al-Ju'fi, who is weak. Al-Bazzar also narrated it. As for the second addition, it is from the Hadith of Jabir, elevated: (Whoever builds a mosque for Allah like a sandgrouse's nest or smaller, Allah builds a house for him in Paradise). Narrated by Ibn Majah via Ibrahim bin Nashit from Abdullah bin Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Husain Al-Nawfali from Ata bin Abi Rabah from him. He said in (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is authentic and its narrators are trustworthy). I say: They are from the men of Muslim except Ibrahim bin Nashit, and he is trustworthy. Al-Mundhiri said: (Its chain is authentic, and Ibn Khuzaimah narrated it in his (Sahih)). It is witnessed by the Hadith of Anas in Al-Tirmidhi via Nuh bin Qais from Abd al-Rahman the freed slave of Qais from Ziyad Al-Numairi from him with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Whoever builds a mosque for Allah, be it small or large...) and the rest is like it. Al-Mundhiri pointed to its weakness because this Abd al-Rahman is unknown, and Ziyad Al-Numairi - who is Ibn Abdullah - is weak as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Shawkani said: (It has other paths from Anas, some in Al-Tabarani and some in Ibn Adi, and there is criticism in them). I say: Perhaps some of them strengthen others. As for the third addition: It is from the Hadith of Umar bin Al-Khattab, elevated: (Whoever builds a mosque for Allah in which the name of Allah Almighty is mentioned, Allah builds a house for him in Paradise). Narrated by Ibn Majah and Ahmad via Uthman bin Abdullah bin Suraqah from him. Its chain is authentic, its narrators are men of the Sahih. Ibn Hibban narrated it in his (Sahih). Al-Mizzi found a defect in it due to disconnection between this Uthman and Umar. Al-Hafiz refuted this in (Al-Tahdhib) saying it is based on the statement of Al-Waqidi, which is a mistake from him, and that Uthman explicitly stated his hearing from Umar in the narration of Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari in (Tahdhib Al-Athar). It is witnessed by the Hadith of Amr bin Abasa, elevated with this wording, except that he said: (For Allah Almighty to be mentioned in it).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad via Baqiyyah: Buhair ibn Sa'd told us from Khalid bin Ma'dan from Kathir bin Murrah from him. This is an authentic chain; all its narrators are trustworthy, and Baqiyyah explicitly stated narration (Tahdith). Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: (His saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (like it) bears two meanings: First: That its meaning is: Allah Almighty builds for him the like of it in terms of the name 'house'. As for its description in vastness and other things, its superiority is known, being what no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and has not occurred to the heart of a human. Second: That its meaning is that its superiority over the houses of Paradise is like the superiority of the mosque over the houses of the world). The first view is the more apparent, and Al-Hafiz approved of it in (Al-Fath). And Allah Almighty knows best. Furthermore, what must be noted is that this merit is only for one who builds a mosque seeking thereby the Face of Allah Almighty, as indicated by his saying in the Hadith: (for Allah). This is also indicated by the general texts from the Book and the Sunnah. As for one who intends by that boasting, showing off, and ingratiating himself to the masses as many emirs and notables do, there is nothing in it but sin. Therefore Al-Hafiz said: (Benefit: Ibn al-Jawzi said: Whoever writes his name on the mosque he builds is far from sincerity. End quote. And whoever builds it for a wage does not obtain this specific promise

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: due to the lack of sincerity, even if he is rewarded in general). (It is recommended to personally undertake the building of the mosque as much as possible, following his example, peace and blessings be upon him, for he used to build his mosque while the Companions handed him mud and stones, and he was saying: 'Verily, there is no life but the life of the Hereafter, so forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirah'). The Hadith is a piece from the Hadith of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The location of the mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, belonged to Banu Najjar, and in it were palm trees and graves of the polytheists. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to them: ('Name a price to me for it'). They said: We do not take a price for it. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to build it while they handed him [materials] and he was saying... etc. He said: And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to pray before building the mosque wherever prayer overtook him. Narrated by Ibn Majah and Ahmad via Waki': Hammad bin Salamah told us from Abu Al-Tayyah from him. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. He, Al-Bukhari, and others narrated it from other paths from Abu Al-Tayyah with it at length, but it does not contain the point of witness from it, and its wording preceded shortly. And Ahmad narrated via Amr bin Abi Amr from Ibn Abdullah bin Hantab from Abu Hurairah: That they were carrying bricks for building the mosque, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was with them. He said: I met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was holding a brick against his belly, and I thought it was difficult for him. I said: Hand it to me, O Messenger of Allah. He said: ('Take another one, O

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Abu Hurairah, for there is no life but the life of the Hereafter'). He said in (Al-Majmu'): (Narrated by Ahmad and its men are men of the Sahih). Thus he said, but absolutely it is not correct, for this Ibn Abdullah - whose name is Al-Muttalib - Al-Bukhari did not narrate for him in his (Sahih) nor did Muslim. He only narrated the first one for him in (Juz' al-Qira'ah). Furthermore, he is truthful (Saduq) but practices much Tadlis (concealing defects in the chain) and Irsal (omitting the first narrator). The rest of his men are trustworthy men of the Six. (And matters should be observed in its building: First: That he perfects its craftsmanship and builds it well, for he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to command us to build mosques in our houses [quarters] and to perfect their craftsmanship). This is from the Hadith of some Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, with a good chain, and he was named in some narrations as Samurah bin Jundub as preceded shortly, and the discussion and sourcing of it passed there. (Second: That he does not raise it high (Tashyeed) or elevate its building, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (I was not commanded to raise (Tashyeed) the mosques). It is from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, elevated. And its completion: Ibn Abbas said: (You will surely decorate them as the Jews and Christians decorated). Narrated by Abu Dawood, and from him Ibn Hazm and Al-Bayhaqi

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: via the path of Sufyan bin Uyaynah from Sufyan Al-Thawri from Abu Fazarah from Yazid ibn Al-Asamm from him with it. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. Ibn Hibban authenticated it as in (Bulugh Al-Maram). Al-Bukhari narrated the mentioned statement of Ibn Abbas in a suspended form (Ta'liq). Al-Hafiz said: (Al-Bukhari did not mention the elevated part of it due to the difference regarding Yazid bin Al-Asamm in connecting it and disconnecting it). I say: Whoever connected it brought an addition, so it must be accepted if it is from a trustworthy person as is the case here. Abu Fazarah - whose name is Rashid bin Kaisan - is trustworthy as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib) and Muslim used him as proof. Furthermore, this statement of Ibn Abbas, Al-Qari said: (It is stopped [Mawquf] but has the ruling of being elevated [Marfu']). Al-San'ani said: (It is as if he understood from the Prophetic reports that this nation will follow the path of the Children of Israel). It has been narrated as elevated but its chain is weak. Narrated by Ibn Majah: Jibara bin Al-Mughallis told us: Abd al-Karim bin Abd al-Rahman Al-Bajali told us from Laith from Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas elevated with the wording: (I see that you will elevate your mosques after me just as the Jews elevated their synagogues and the Christians elevated their churches).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And Laith - who is Ibn Abi Sulaim - is weak, and Jibara bin Al-Mughallis is weaker than him. Then Ibn Majah narrated it from this Jibara from Abd al-Karim bin Abd al-Rahman from Abu Ishaq from Amr bin Maimun from Umar bin Al-Khattab elevated. In (Al-Fath): (Its men are trustworthy except his Sheikh Jibara bin Al-Mughallis, for there is criticism about him). He said in his biography in (Al-Taqrib): (He is weak). Therefore Ibn Kathir said: (And in its chain is weakness). Al-Khattabi said in (Ma'alim Al-Sunan): (Al-Tashyeed is raising the building and making it tall). Al-Baghawi said likewise as in (Al-Nayl) and added: (From it is His saying, Exalted is He: {Lofty towers (Buruj Mushayyadah)} [An-Nisa: 78], which are those whose building is made tall. It is said: 'Shidtu ash-shay' ushiduhu' like 'bi'tuhu abi'uhu': if I built it with 'Sheed' which is gypsum. And 'Shayadttuhu tashyeedan': I lengthened and raised it). It was said: The intended meaning of 'lofty towers' is plastered ones. Ibn Ruslan said: (The famous view in the Hadith is that the intended meaning of raising mosques here is raising the building and making it tall, as Al-Baghawi said. In it is a refutation of those who interpreted His saying, Exalted is He: {In houses which Allah has permitted to be

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: raised} [An-Nur / 36] as raising their physical structure, claiming that is the literal meaning. Rather, the meaning is that they be honored, so obscenity of speech is not mentioned in them, they are purified from filth and impurities, and voices are not raised in them. End quote). The meaning of the Hadith is: (I was not commanded to raise their structure so that it becomes a means to ornamentation and decoration, which is the action of the People of the Book. In it is a type of rebuke and reprimand), said Al-Munawi in (Al-Fayd). Al-San'ani said: (And in his saying: 'I was not commanded' is an indication that it is not good, for if it were good, Allah would have commanded it). (Third: That he does not ornament and decorate it, because it is a waste of wealth in what has no benefit, due to what it contains of distracting the worshiper from humility (Khushu') which is the spirit and core of prayer. Therefore he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (It is not fitting that there be anything in the House (Kaaba) that distracts the worshiper). And it has preceded). The Hadith was said by him, peace and blessings be upon him, when he saw the two horns of the ram - as preceded in 'Prayer in the Kaaba'. So what would he, peace and blessings be upon him, say if he saw these engravings and decorations by which some Muslim emirs and kings have been tempted? Explicit Hadiths have been narrated regarding the prohibition of decorating mosques, but none of them are free from weakness. Therefore, we preferred this authentic Hadith as it stands in their place in meaning. There is no harm in citing what is available of them.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Among them: From Anas, elevated (Marfu'): (Build mosques and make them Jamma [without battlements]). Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi via the path of Laith from Ayyub from him. Laith - who is Ibn Sulaim - is weak. Furthermore, it is disconnected, for Ibn Abd al-Barr said as in (Zad al-Ma'ad): (Ayyub did not hear anything from Anas according to them). From this you learn that Al-Suyuti's symbol indicating it is Hasan is not good. His commentator Al-Munawi quoted its weakening from Ibn Al-Qattan, Mughlatay, and Al-Dhahabi. Al-Suyuti mentioned a witness for it from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas with the wording: (Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah) and symbolized its goodness (Hasan) as well, and the commentator did not critique it with anything. And Allah knows best. Among them: From Ibn Umar who said: He forbade us - or we were forbidden - to pray in a decorated/crenellated (Musharraf) mosque. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi also via the path of Laith from Mujahid from him. It is weak due to what you know of Laith's condition. In (Majma' al-Zawa'id): (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and its men are men of the Sahih except Laith bin Abi Sulaim, who is trustworthy but a Mudallis and used 'an'an).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Abu Ubaid that he said regarding the hadith of Ibn Abbas: We were ordered to build mosques 'Jamma' and cities 'Shurafa' [with battlements]. His saying: ('Jamma'): The Jamm are those which have no battlements (Sharaf). Likewise, a building if it has no battlements is 'Ajamm', and its plural is 'Jumm'). Among them: From Ubadah bin As-Samit who said: The Ansar said: Until when shall the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, pray towards these palm branches? So they collected Dinars for him and brought them to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: Should we repair this mosque and decorate it? He said: (I have no desire to differ from my brother Moses; a trellis like the trellis of Moses). Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir). It contains Isa bin Sinan: Ahmad and others weakened him, while Al-Ijli, Ibn Hibban, and Ibn Kharash in a narration declared him trustworthy. I say: In (Al-Taqrib): (He is lenient in Hadith). Among them: From Abu Darda, elevated: (If you decorate your mosques and adorn your Mushafs, then destruction is upon you). Narrated by Al-Hakim Al-Tirmidhi and likewise Ibn Al-Mubarak in (Al-Zuhd) with a weak chain as in (Al-Fayd). Ibn Abi Al-Dunya narrated it in (Al-Masahif) from Abu Hurairah as Mawquf with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (If you decorate your mosques and adorn your Mushafs, then destruction is upon you). As in (Muntakhab Kanz Al-Ummal). Among them: From Umar bin Al-Khattab, elevated: (No people's deeds ever became bad except they decorated their mosques). Its chain is weak as preceded shortly. Al-Bukhari narrated in a suspended form from him that he: (Ordered the building of the mosque and said: Shelter the people from the rain, and beware of painting red or yellow lest you tempt the people). Al-Hafiz said: (It is part of a story mentioning the renovation of the Prophet's Mosque). In (Al-Mirqat): (Ibn Mas'ud passed by a decorated mosque and said: May Allah curse whoever did this). He did not attribute it to anyone. In summary, the collection of these Hadiths indicates the establishment of his prohibition, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding decorating mosques. He indicated that in the following Hadith: (He said: (The Hour will not be established until people boast about mosques). The Hadith was narrated by Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via paths from Hammad bin Salamah from Ayyub from Abu Qilabah from Anas, elevated with it. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. The wording of Al-Nasa'i: (From the signs of the Hour is that [people] boast...). Qatadah followed him from Anas, narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir) via the path of Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Khuza'i: Hammad bin Salamah told us from Ayyub from Abu Qilabah from Anas, and Qatadah from Anas, elevated with the first wording. Al-Tabarani said: (Al-Khuza'i was alone in narrating it). I say: He is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Bukhari said in his (Sahih): (And Anas said: They boast about them then they do not inhabit/maintain them except a little). Al-Hafiz said: (We narrated this suspended narration connected in (Musnad Abu Ya'la) and (Sahih Ibn Khuzaimah) via the path of Abu Qilabah: That Anas said: I heard him say: A time will come upon my nation when they will boast about mosques then they will not inhabit/maintain them except a little. Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Hibban narrated it from another path from Abu Qilabah from Anas from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, with the first wording. And in Abu Nu'aym in Kitab al-Masajid from the way that is in Ibn Khuzaimah: They boast about the abundance of mosques).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In this Hadith and the one before it is the dislike of ornamenting mosques and decorating them with engravings, red and yellow colors, and everything that distracts the worshiper and occupies him from humility (Khushu'), which is the spirit and body of worship as Al-San'ani said. Above this, it is a waste of money without any benefit to the mosque. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade gossip (Qil wa Qal), excessive questioning, and wasting money. That is because the purpose of building mosques is only to shelter people from heat and cold as preceded from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, and decorating them is not part of that at all. Therefore, Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, forbade it by saying: And beware of painting red or yellow. Ibn Battal said: (It seems Umar understood that from the Lawgiver returning the Khamisah (patterned garment) to Abu Jahm due to the markings on it, saying: (It distracted me from my prayer). Al-Hafiz said: (It is possible that Umar had specific knowledge regarding this issue). Then he mentioned the Hadith mentioned shortly before from Umar, elevated with the wording: (No people's deeds ever became bad except they decorated their mosques). Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad narrated, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him: That the mosque in the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was built with mud bricks, its roof was palm branches, and its pillars were palm trunks. Abu Bakr did not add anything to it. Umar added to it and built it upon its foundation in the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, with mud bricks and palm branches, and restored its pillars with wood. Then

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Uthman changed it, so he added to it a great increase and built its wall with engraved stones and gypsum (Al-Qassah) and made its pillars of engraved stone and its roof of teak. Al-Hafiz said: (And (Al-Saj): A known type of wood brought from India. Ibn Battal and others said: This indicates that the Sunnah in building the mosque is moderation and abandoning exaggeration in improving it. For Umar, despite the abundance of conquests in his days and the abundance of wealth with him, did not change the mosque from what it was. He only needed to renew it because the palm branches had decayed in his days. Then Uthman was - and wealth in his time was more abundant - so he improved it with what did not necessitate decoration. Yet despite that, some Companions objected to him as will come shortly. The first to decorate mosques was Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, and that was at the end of the era of the Companions. Many people of knowledge remained silent about denying that for fear of Fitnah... Ibn al-Munir said: When people raised their houses and decorated them, it was appropriate to do that with mosques to protect them from disdain. This was refuted by saying: If the prohibition was to encourage following the Salaf in abandoning luxury, then it is as he said. But if it was for fear of occupying the worshiper's mind with decoration, then no, because the cause remains. In the Hadith of Anas is a sign from the signs of Prophethood due to his informing, peace and blessings be upon him, of what would happen, and it happened as he said). Al-Shawkani said: (Among what those who permit decoration relied upon is that the Salaf did not

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: perform denial against those who did that, and that it is a good innovation (Bid'ah Hasanah), and that it encourages [people] to the mosque. These are arguments that cannot be relied upon by one who has a share of success, especially when contradicted by Hadiths indicating that decoration is not from the command of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and that it is a type of prohibited boasting, and that it is from the signs of the Hour as narrated from Ali, peace be upon him, and that it is from the work of the Jews and Christians, and he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to love differing from them generally and specifically. The claim that the Salaf left denial is forbidden [incorrect], because decoration is an innovation introduced by the people of unjust states without permission from the people of knowledge and virtue. They introduced innovations that cannot be counted, and no one denies them. Scholars remained silent about them out of Taqiyyah (caution), not approval. Rather, a group of the scholars of the Hereafter stood in the face of their falsehood and shouted among them denouncing that against them. The claim that it is a good innovation is false, and we have informed you of the reason for its falsehood in the explanation of the Hadith: (Whoever does an action not in accordance with our matter, it is rejected) in the chapter of Prayer in Silk Garments and Usurped [Clothes]. The claim that it encourages to the mosque is corrupt, because being a caller to the mosque and encouraging to it only applies to one whose purpose and ultimate goal is looking at those engravings and decoration. As for one whose purpose is intending the mosques for the worship of Allah - which is not true worship except with Khushu', otherwise it is like a body without a soul - then they are nothing but a distraction from that, as he, peace and blessings be upon him, did with the Anbijaniyyah which he sent to Abu Jahm, and as preceded regarding his tearing down of curtains containing images, and as will come in (Chapter on Purifying the Qiblah of the worshiper from what distracts). Prioritizing crooked innovations introduced by kings causes people of knowledge to fall into narrow

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: paths, so they burden themselves for that with flimsy arguments that are not current except with a beast). And among what indicates to you that the claim that the Salaf did not object to those who did decoration is a generally false claim: What Sa'id bin Mansur narrated: Sufyan told us from [Ibn] Abi Najih from Isma'il bin Abd al-Rahman bin Dhu'aib who said: I entered a mosque in Al-Juhfah with Ibn Umar. He looked at its battlements (Shurufat), then went out to a place and prayed in it. Then he said to the owner of the mosque: Indeed I saw in this mosque of yours - meaning the battlements - I likened them to the altars of the Jahiliyyah, so order that they be broken). I quoted it from (Iqtida' al-Sirat al-Mustaqim Mukhalafat Ashab al-Jahim) by Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah). This is an authentic chain; its narrators are trustworthy men of the Six except this Isma'il, who is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). In (Al-Mudawwanah) by Ibn al-Qasim: (He said: I heard Malik mention the Mosque of Medina and what was done in its Qiblah of decoration and other things. He said: People disliked that when they did it, and that distracts people in their prayers; they look at it and it distracts them). Because of that, many scholars disliked praying in decorated and ornamented mosques. Al-Munawi said in (Al-Fayd): (The Shafi'is said: Prayer is disliked in a decorated/crenellated (Musharraf) mosque due to what is in (Sunan Al-Bayhaqi)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: from Ibn Umar: He forbade us - or we were forbidden - to pray in a decorated/crenellated mosque. It is taken from this that it is disliked in ornamented and engraved ones a fortiori, due to what it contains of occupying the worshiper's heart. It is prohibited to engrave it and make battlements for it from the yield of what is endowed for its construction or interests). Ibn Hazm exaggerated and said: (And prayer is not valid in a mosque created for boasting or harm to another mosque if its people can hear the call of the first mosque and there is no hardship on them in attending it. It is obligatory to demolish it and demolish every mosque created so people isolate themselves in it like monks or which the ignorant seek out seeking its merit while it does not have traces of a Prophet from the Prophets, peace be upon them. In his last statement is an indication of the permissibility of seeking out traces of Prophets to pray at them. This is an issue scholars differed on in the past. What is preferable to us is preventing the seeking of them, because there is no evidence from the Book and Sunnah for its permissibility, and because it may lead to excessiveness which is forbidden, and due to the prohibition of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. Sa'id bin Mansur narrated in his (Sunan): Abu Mu'awiyah told us: Al-A'mash told us from Al-Ma'rur bin Suwayd from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We went out with him in a Hajj he performed. He recited to us in Fajr: {Have you not considered how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant} [Al-Fil: 1] and {For the accustomed security of the Quraysh} [Quraish: 1] in the second. When he returned from his Hajj, he saw people rushing to the mosque. He said: What is this? They said: A mosque the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed in. He said: Thus perished the People of the Book before you; they took the traces of their prophets as churches/synagogues. Whoever is overtaken by prayer in it, let him pray, and whoever is not overtaken by prayer, let him pass on).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is an authentic chain on the condition of the Six. He [Umar], may Allah be pleased with him, disliked taking the place of prayer of the Prophet as a site of festival (Eid) and clarified that the People of the Book only perished by such things. This is the school of Malik and others from the people of Medina, for they used to dislike coming to those mosques and traces in Medina except Quba' and Uhud. Refer to the detailed discussion in this station in (Iqtida' al-Sirat al-Mustaqim). What we preferred of prevention applies to places where the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed coincidentally. As for places he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to seek out for prayer and supplication at them, seeking them out for that sake is a Sunnah following his example, peace be upon him. Furthermore, that prevention applies if it is not accompanied by setting out on a journey (Shadd al-Rahl). As for if it is accompanied by that, it is strictly prohibited due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Do not set out on a journey except to three mosques...) The Hadith. And it will come, Allah willing. This, and as for the Mihrab (niche) in the mosque, it is apparent that it is an innovation (Bid'ah) because we have not come across any trace indicating it existed in the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. I say this, although the statement of Ibn Al-Humam in (Al-Fath) is not hidden from us: (Indeed Mihrabs were built in mosques from the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him). This requires a chain and knowledge of who narrated that from the Muhaddithin and early Huffaz. Indeed, one who is more retentive than Ibn Al-Humam refuted that, for

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Suyuti said, in what Al-Munawi transmitted: (It was hidden from a people that the Mihrab in the mosque is an innovation, and they thought it existed in the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. It did not exist in his time nor in the time of any of his successors; rather it appeared in the second century despite the establishment of prohibition against adopting it). Then he critiqued Al-Zarkashi's famous statement: (That adopting it is permissible not disliked, and people's practice has continued on it without denial). [Saying] that: (There is no transmission in the Madhhab regarding it, and prohibition of it has been established). It is as if he means by the prohibition he referred to what Al-Bayhaqi extracted via Abd al-Rahman bin Maghra from Ibn Abjar from Nu'aym bin Abi Hind from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd from Abdullah bin Amr who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Beware of these slaughterhouses (Madhabih) - meaning Mihrabs). This is a good (Hasan) chain; all its narrators are trustworthy men of Muslim except Abd al-Rahman bin Maghra, who was only criticized regarding his narration from Al-A'mash, and this is not one of them as you see. Al-Dhahabi said in his biography in (Al-Mizan): (There is no harm in him, Allah willing. Al-Kudaymi narrated that he heard Ali say: He is nothing; we abandoned him; he was not that [strong]). Ibn Adi said following this: (This which Ali said is as he said. He only denounced Abu Zuhair - Ibn Maghra's Kunya - for Hadiths he narrates from Al-A'mash which trustworthy narrators do not follow him in. And Abu Zur'ah said: Truthful [Saduq]).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: And this statement of Abu Zur'ah is what Al-Hafiz relied upon in (Al-Taqrib), so he said: (Truthful, his hadith from Al-A'mash was spoken about). Al-Haythami said in (Al-Majmu') after citing the Hadith with its wording: (Al-Tabarani narrated it and in it is Abdullah bin Maghra; Ibn Hibban and others declared him trustworthy, and Ibn Al-Madini weakened him in his narration from Al-A'mash, and this is not one of them) (1). Al-Suyuti said in what Al-Munawi transmitted: (It is an established Hadith. According to Abu Zur'ah opinion and his follow-ups, it is Sahih, and according to Ibn Adi's opinion, it is Hasan). Hence he symbolized it in (Al-Jami') as Hasan. Al-Munawi critiqued him with what he quoted from Al-Dhahabi that he said in Al-Madhhab regarding Al-Bayhaqi: (I say: This is a denounced (Munkar) report; Abd al-Rahman bin Maghra was alone in narrating it, and he is not a proof). I say: The truth is that the Hadith is Hasan, and judging it as Munkar is not apparent. Al-Dhahabi himself said regarding Ibn Maghra that there is no harm in him as preceded just now. The least this statement implies is that his Hadith is Hasan if he is alone in narrating it. The statement that he is not a proof absolutely contradicts this which is in (Al-Mizan). As for if it is said: He is not a proof if he contradicts [others], then it is true, and here he did not contradict, so his Hadith is Hasan. And Allah Almighty knows best.
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: If he meant by Ibn Al-Madini's weakening of him that narration mentioned previously from Al-Dhahabi via Al-Kudaymi, then it is not permissible to use it as proof because Al-Kudaymi - whose name is Muhammad bin Yunus - is one of the abandoned narrators (Matrukin) as in (Al-Mizan); in fact, some called him a liar.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: However, using the Hadith as evidence for the prohibition of the innovated Mihrabs in mosques - as Al-Suyuti understood according to what Al-Munawi explicitly transmitted from him and his previously mentioned words indicate - is not apparent, even if Al-Bayhaqi preceded him in that where he cited the Hadith in (Chapter on How to Build Mosques). Al-Munawi said, critiquing Al-Suyuti's statement referred to: (I say: This is based on his understanding from the wording of the Hadith that his intent by 'Mihrab' is nothing but what is known in the mosque now. But it is not so, for the famous Imam known as Ibn Al-Athir has stated that the intended meaning of 'Mihrabs' in the Hadith is the front seats of assemblies. He said: And from it is the Hadith of Anas: He used to dislike Mihrabs. Meaning: He did not like to sit in the front of assemblies and elevate himself above people. End quote). I say: In this is that Ibn Al-Athir did not explicitly state what Al-Munawi mentioned. For the text of his words in Al-Nihayah is: ((Al-Mihrab): The high, overlooking place, and it is also the front of the assembly. From it the Mihrab of the mosque was named, which is its front and most noble place. And from it is the Hadith of Anas...) etc. of his words which Al-Munawi quoted. So you see that he did not address the mention of the Hadith we are discussing at all. So how can Al-Munawi say: (He explicitly stated that the intended meaning of Mihrabs in the Hadith is the front of assemblies)? Rather, he stated that this is the intended meaning of Mihrabs in the Hadith of Anas which he himself cited - meaning: Ibn Al-Athir. It is not hidden that the occurrence of this word

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Al-Maharib) in the Hadith of Anas is in the meaning of the forefronts of gatherings, [so] that this meaning is the intended one from every Hadith in which this word appears, including this Hadith. However, what made me prefer that the two Hadiths share one meaning is the occurrence of the demonstrative noun in the Hadith of the chapter: (These Madhabih - meaning Al-Maharib), which indicates that what is pointed to - which are the Maharib - were present during his time, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, whereas the Mihrabs of mosques in the conventional meaning were not present in his time, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, by the admission of Al-Suyuti. So how is it permissible then to interpret the Hadith as referring to them [architectural niches] when it contains a reference to them while they were non-existent? Thus, it is determined that the intended meaning of Al-Maharib in this Hadith is the forefronts of gatherings as is the intended meaning in the Hadith of Anas. And Allah knows best. This, and it has been narrated what indicates that Maharib in mosques were not known in his time, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Al-Tabarani narrated in (Al-Awsat) and (Al-Kabir) from Jabir bin Usama Al-Juhani who said: I met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with his companions in the market, so I said: Where does the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, intend to go? They said: He wants to mark out a mosque for your people. He said: So I came and he had marked out a mosque for them and planted a piece of wood in its Qibla and set it up as a Qibla. He said in (Al-Majma'): (It contains Mu'awiyah bin Abdullah bin Habib, and I did not find anyone who wrote his biography). And in my memory, some scholars who hold the view of the permissibility of the Mihrab in...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the mosque mentioned that among its benefits is indicating the direction of the Qibla. We say: That is only needed if there is no Minbar (pulpit) in the mosque. If there is no Minbar in it, there is no objection to placing a piece of wood indicating the Qibla as in this Hadith. That is better than the Maharib, in the adoption of which is a resemblance to the Christians. For Al-Bazzar narrated from Abdullah bin Masud that he disliked prayer in the Mihrab and said: 'They were only in the churches, so do not resemble the People of the Book.' Meaning: He disliked prayer in the arch (Al-Taq). He said in (Al-Majma'): (And its men are trustworthy). I say: Sa'id bin Mansur also narrated it with the wording that he used to dislike prayer in the arch (Al-Taq) and said: 'It is from the churches, so do not resemble the People of the Book.' And it was narrated from Ubaid bin Abi Al-Ja'd, who said: The companions of Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to say: 'Indeed, among the signs of the Hour is that Madhabih (altars) are adopted in the mosque - meaning the arches (Taqat) (1). It is noticeable in this report that he interpreted 'Al-Madhabih' in the mosque as 'Al-Taqat', which are the Mihrabs in the conventional sense, just as 'Al-Madhabih' was interpreted in the Hadith as 'Al-Maharib', which indicates that they are the arches. This strengthens what Al-Suyuti understood from the Hadith, were it not for the demonstrative noun in it.
foot_note: 1. (1) Sheikh Al-Islam cited it and the one before it in (Al-Iqtida') (p. 63).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The issue - still - needs verification and scrutiny beyond what has been presented. So whoever has something regarding that, let him write it, and Allah does not waste the reward of the one who does good deeds. Ibn Hazm explicitly stated the dislike of Mihrabs in mosques and said: (We have narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib that he disliked the Mihrab in the mosque, and from Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i (1)...
foot_note: 1. (1) that he used to dislike praying in the Imam's arch. Sufyan Al-Thawri said: (And we dislike it). Therefore, Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in (Al-Mirqat) (1/473) in the explanation of the Hadith of Anas: (The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saw sputum in the Qibla): (Meaning the wall of the mosque that is towards the Qibla, and the intended is not the Mihrab which people call Qibla, because Mihrabs are innovations after him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Hence, a group of the Salaf disliked adopting them and praying in them. Al-Quda'i said: The first to introduce that was Umar bin Abdul Aziz while he was the governor for Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik over Medina when he established the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, demolished it, and added to it. The standing place of the Imam in the mosque is called a Mihrab because it is the most noble of the sitting places of the mosque. From it, a palace is called Mihrab because it is the most noble of dwellings. And it was said: The Mihrab is the king's assembly, named so because of his seclusion in it. Likewise, the Mihrab of the mosque is due to the Imam's seclusion in it. And it was said: It was named so because the worshiper fights (yuharib) Satan in it). As for what is in (Awn Al-Ma'bud 'ala Sunan Abi Dawood): (What Al-Qari said that Mihrabs are innovations after him, peace be upon him, is questionable, because the existence of the Mihrab in his time, peace be upon him, is proven by some narrations. Al-Bayhaqi extracted in (Al-Sunan Al-Kubra) from Wa'il bin Hujr who said: I attended the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, he rose to the mosque and entered the Mihrab then raised his hands for Takbir). Sheikh Abdul Hayy Al-Kattani quoted it in (Al-Taratib Al-Idariyah) and affirmed it. I say: This is a critique and affirmation that is futile, because the mentioned Hadith is very weak because Al-Bayhaqi =

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Fourth: That he does not build it [the mosque] over a grave, for that is forbidden due to what Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, narrated, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said during his illness from which he did not recover: (Allah cursed the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques). She said: (Had it not been for that, his grave would have been made prominent, but he feared that it might be taken as a mosque). And he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (O Allah, do not make my grave an idol. Allah cursed a people who took the graves of their prophets as mosques). The first Hadith is from the narration of Aisha and the other is from the narration of Abu Huraira.
foot_note: 1. = extracted it from the path of Muhammad bin Hujr Al-Hadrami: Sa'id bin Abdul Jabbar bin Wa'il told us from his father from his mother from Wa'il with it. This chain has three defects: The weakness of some of its narrators, interruption, and anomaly (Shudhudh) in its text. As for the first, it is Muhammad bin Hujr Al-Hadrami; Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (He has objectionable reports (Manakir), and Al-Bukhari said: There is some concern regarding him). Al-Hafiz confirmed him in (Al-Lisan) and quoted Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim saying: (He is not strong according to them). I say: And his Sheikh Sa'id bin Abdul Jabbar is also weak as in (Al-Taqrib). As for the second, Abdul Jabbar bin Wa'il is not known to have heard from his mother, and it was said: He did not hear from his parents as in (Al-Tahdhib). As for the third, the Hadith of Wa'il, may Allah be pleased with him, describing his prayer, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, has come in (Sahih Muslim), the Sunan, the Musnads, and others from many paths with various wordings, and none of them mention the Mihrab except in this weak narration, which indicates its anomaly, or rather its objectionability (Nakara). See the paths referred to in Al-Bayhaqi (2/24, 25, 26, 28, 30, 57, 58, 72, 81, 98, 99, 111, 112, 131, 132, and 178).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And both are Sahih. Their extraction has preceded along with other Hadiths reported in the chapter in (Prayer in Mosques Built on Graves). These Hadiths contain the prohibition of building mosques on graves, for building is one of the meanings of taking mosques on graves as previously explained there. It has appeared in some narrations explicitly with the wording: (Sahih) (They built a mosque over his grave and depicted those images in it. Those are the worst of creation in the sight of Allah on the Day of Resurrection). Extracted by both [Bukhari and Muslim]. Many scholars have held the view of prohibition. Imam Muhammad said in his book (Al-Athar): (We do not see that anything should be added to what came out of it (the grave), and we dislike that it be plastered or covered with clay, or that a mosque be made near it). And 'dislike' according to him implies prohibition when used absolutely. As for Al-Shafi'i, he said in (Al-Umm): (And I dislike that a mosque be built over the grave. He said: I dislike this due to the Sunnah and traditions (Athar), and he disliked - and Allah knows best - that any of the Muslims be glorified - meaning his grave be taken as a mosque - and fitnah (temptation) and misguidance for those who come after him is not secured against in that). And in (Al-Majmu'):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (The texts of Al-Shafi'i and the companions [of the Shafi'i school] agreed on the dislike of building a mosque over a grave, whether the deceased was famous for righteousness or otherwise, due to the generality of the Hadiths). I say: But the 'dislike' according to them is for discouraging (Tanzih). Evidence for this is that they said: 'And it is disliked to pray upon a grave.' Al-Nawawi said: (Thus they said: (It is disliked). If it were said: It is prohibited (Haram) due to the Hadith of Abu Marthad and others as preceded, it would not be far-fetched). If Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, had said the like of this regarding the saying of his companions about the dislike of building, it would have been more worthy and appropriate, because the prohibition of building is more severe and stern than that of praying towards a grave, as is not hidden to anyone who has examined the Hadiths reported on this subject. Therefore, Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Iqtida'): (As for building mosques over graves, the general groups [of scholars] have explicitly stated its prohibition in following the Hadiths. Our companions and others from the companions of Malik and Al-Shafi'i and others explicitly stated its forbidden nature (Tahrim). Some scholars used the term 'dislike' (Karaha) regarding it (as if referring to Al-Shafi'i), so I do not know if he meant Tanzih (discouragement) or Tahrim (prohibition)? And there is no doubt in asserting its prohibition). Then he cited the Hadiths reported in this chapter. Al-Qurtubi said in his (Tafsir) in summary: (So taking mosques on graves, praying in them, and building over them, and other things included in the Sunnah regarding prohibition, is forbidden).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Then he mentioned the last Hadith of Aisha, then said: (Our scholars (the Malikis) said: And this makes it forbidden for Muslims to take the graves of prophets and scholars as mosques). Sheikh Al-Islam also said in (Tafsir Surat Al-Ikhlas): (The scholars said: It is forbidden to build mosques over graves. And every mosque built over a grave must be demolished. Even if the deceased was buried in a mosque and his stay has been long, the grave should be leveled so that its form does not appear, for Shirk only occurs if its form appears. For this reason, the mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was initially a graveyard for the polytheists containing palm trees and ruins. So he ordered the graves and they were exhumed, and the palm trees and they were cut, and the ruins and they were leveled. So it exited from being a graveyard and became a mosque. And since taking graves as mosques and building mosques over them was forbidden, nothing of that existed during the time of the Companions and the Tabi'in (Successors) who followed them in goodness, and a mosque over a grave was never known). This, and it might be imagined that the prohibition is only taking mosques over graves after burial, not if the mosque was built first and the grave was placed in its side for the endower of the mosque or someone else to be buried in. Al-Shawkani said: (Al-Iraqi said: The apparent meaning is that there is no difference, and that if the mosque is built with the intention that someone be buried in part of it, it enters under the curse. Rather, burial in the mosque is forbidden, and if they stipulated that he be buried in it, the condition is invalid for contradicting the implication of its endowment as a mosque. And Allah knows best).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: If it is said: Then what is the story of the grave of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, for we see it now in his mosque, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him? I say: The answer is in Sharh Muslim by Al-Nawawi where he said: (The scholars said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, only forbade taking his grave and the grave of others as a mosque out of fear of exaggeration in glorification and being tempted by it, for that might lead to disbelief as happened to many past nations. When the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them all, and the Tabi'in needed to increase the [size of the] Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when the Muslims increased in number, and the increase extended to include the houses of the Mothers of Believers, including the chamber of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, the burial place of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and his two companions Abu Bakr and Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, they built high, circular walls around the grave so it would not appear in the mosque for the common people to pray towards it and lead to the prohibited matter. Then they built two walls from the two northern corners of the grave and slanted them until they met so that no one could face the grave. For this reason, she said in the Hadith: (Had it not been for that, his grave would have been made prominent, but he feared that it might be taken as a mosque)). There is a reservation in his mentioning of the Companions in this story, even if Al-Ayni followed him in that in (Al-Umdah), because that did not happen in the presence of any Companion. Ibn Abdul Hadi said in (Al-Sarim Al-Munki): (And during the time of the Rightly Guided Caliphs and the Companions, his chamber was outside the mosque, and there was nothing between them and it except the wall. Then the chamber was only incorporated into the mosque during the caliphate of Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik after the death of the generality of the Companions who were in Medina. And among the last of them to die was Jabir bin Abdullah, and he died during the caliphate of Abdul Malik, for he died in the year...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...seventy-eight, and Al-Walid took charge in the year eighty-six and died in the year ninety-six. So the building of the mosque and the incorporation of the chamber into it was between that. Abu Zaid Umar bin Shabbal Al-Numayri mentioned in the book (Akhbar Al-Madinah) - the City of the Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him - from his sheikhs and from those they narrated from: That Umar bin Abdul Aziz, when he was deputy for Al-Walid over Medina in the year ninety-one, demolished the mosque and built it with engraved stones and made its roof with teak and gold water, and demolished the chambers of the wives of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and incorporated them into the mosque and incorporated the grave into it). Then Ibn Abdul Hadi mentioned from Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah: (That when Al-Walid added to the mosque and the chamber was incorporated into it, the generality of the Companions had died, and none remained except those who realized the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, but had not reached the age of discernment where one is commanded with purity and prayer. It is known by concurrent reports (Tawatur) that this was during the caliphate of Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik. They mentioned that this was in the year ninety-one, and that Umar bin Abdul Aziz remained building it for three years. And in the year ninety-three, many people from the Tabi'in died, such as Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib and others from the Seven Jurists, and it is called: The Year of the Jurists). In summary, they only incorporated the grave of the Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, into his mosque due to the need to expand it, and evidently, they did not find space from other directions to add to the mosque. Umar and Uthman, may Allah be pleased with them, had already added to it from the Qibla direction, so they were forced to take the increase from the direction of the chambers, thus his grave became in...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...the Noble Mosque. However, despite their need for this action, they took precautions for the matter, as they separated the grave from the mosque completely with raised walls to cut off the forbidden matter, as previously mentioned from Al-Nawawi. And Allah The Exalted knows best. (Fifth: That pillars in it be minimized as much as possible, and everything that causes cutting of the rows, due to what preceded of the prohibition of lining up between pillars).
