(Sixth: That a specific door be made in it for women, due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (If we left this door for women) The Hadith. Narrated by Abu Dawood from the path of Abdul Warith: Ayyub told us from Nafi' from Ibn Umar raised [to the Prophet] with it. Nafi' said: (So Ibn Umar never entered through it until he died). This is a Sahih chain, all its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs. Abu Dawood said: (And other than Abdul Warith said: Umar said. And this is more correct). Then he cited it from the path of Ismail from Ayyub from Nafi' who said: Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said... with its meaning. And it is more correct. Then he narrated from Bukayr from Nafi' that Umar bin Al-Khattab used to forbid entering through the women's door. Its chain is also Sahih.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Then I realized and said: It is disconnected (Munqati'). Ahmad bin Hanbal said: (Nafi' from Umar is disconnected). I say: This does not negate the authenticity of the raised Hadith of Ibn Umar, because the one who raised it has additional knowledge, so it must be accepted if it is from a trustworthy narrator, and the matter is so here, for this Abdul Warith is Ibn Sa'id bin Dhakwan Al-Anbari, and he is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). And the prohibition of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding entering from the women's door supports the raised report and does not weaken it. And Allah knows best. Abu Dawood titled the Hadith with (Chapter on the Separation of Women in Mosques from Men). (Seventh: That no Khawkhat (wickets/small doors) or doors be made in it through which those residing in surrounding houses pass into it, due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (Let no Khawkha remain in the mosque except the Khawkha of Abu Bakr). And in a wording: (Door) in both places). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, sat on the pulpit and said: (A servant whom Allah gave the choice between giving him the splendor of the world and what is with Him, so he chose what is with Him). So Abu Bakr wept and wept, and said: We ransom you with our fathers and mothers. He said: So the Messenger of Allah was the one...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...given the choice, and Abu Bakr was the most knowledgeable of us about him. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Indeed, the most generous of people to me in his wealth and companionship is Abu Bakr. If I were to take a close friend (Khalil), I would have taken Abu Bakr as a close friend, but the brotherhood of Islam [is better]. Let no [door] remain...) etc. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Al-Tirmidhi with their wording, and Ahmad, and the other wording is his, which is a narration of Al-Bukhari. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). It has a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas with similar meaning, extracted by Al-Bukhari and Ahmad, and its wording will come in (Al-Manahi), paragraph (12). And in the chapter is his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (Close the doors of the mosque except the door of Ali). Narrated by Ahmad from the path of Abu Awanah: Abu Balj told us: Amr bin Maymun told us from Ibn Abbas with it raised [to the Prophet]. Al-Tirmidhi extracted it from the path of Shu'bah from Abu Balj with it similarly. And he said: (A strange (Gharib) Hadith; we do not know it from Shu'bah with this chain except from this aspect). Then he said: (And Abu Balj's name is Yahya bin Sulaym).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: He is disputed over. In Al-Mizan: (Ibn Ma'in and others, and Muhammad bin Sa'd, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Daraqutni declared him trustworthy. Abu Hatim said: Good (Salih) in Hadith, no harm in him. Al-Bukhari said: There is some concern about him. Ahmad said: He narrated a objectionable (Munkar) Hadith. Ibn Hibban said: He used to make mistakes. Al-Juzjani said: Not trustworthy. And among his objectionable narrations is this Hadith). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, perhaps he erred). I say: The rest of the men of Ahmad are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs, so the chain is Hasan to me. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (Ahmad and Al-Nasa'i narrated it, and their men are trustworthy). It is with Al-Nasa'i from the path of Abu Awanah as in (Al-Bidayah), and they added: (So he used to enter the mosque while in a state of Junub (major ritual impurity) having no other path). Al-Dhahabi judged the Hadith as Munkar because Abu Balj was not alone in it; rather, it has many witnesses. Among them: From Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered the closing of the doors opening into the mosque and left the door of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Narrated by Ahmad from the path of Abdullah bin Sharik from Abdullah bin Al-Raqim Al-Kinani from him. Its men are trustworthy except Ibn Al-Raqim; no one narrated from him except this Ibn Sharik. Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib) and Al-Khazraji in (Al-Khulasah) that he is unknown (Majhul). As for Al-Haythami, he claimed it is Hasan where he said: (Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, Al-Bazzar, and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) narrated it, and they added: They said: O Messenger of Allah, you closed all our doors except the door of Ali? He said: It was not I who closed your doors, but Allah closed them. And Ahmad's chain is Hasan). Al-Hafiz followed him in (Al-Fath) saying: (And its chain is strong, and the narration of Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat), its men are trustworthy). I say: So Al-Hafiz contradicted himself, for his statement: (Its chain is strong) contradicts his statement regarding some of its narrators: that he is unknown, as preceded. As for the path of Al-Tabarani and those mentioned with him, it appears it is another path from Sa'd, for Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir cited it from the path of Abu Ya'la with another chain containing someone I did not recognize, and most likely a typographical error occurred in the names of its men. And Allah knows best. Among them: From Zaid bin Arqam who said: A group of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah had doors opening into the mosque. So he said one day: (Close these doors except the door of Ali). He said: So the people spoke about that. He said: So the Messenger of Allah stood...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, praised Allah The Exalted and extolled Him. Then he said: (As for what follows, I was ordered to close these doors except the door of Ali, and your speaker spoke about it. By Allah, I did not close anything nor open it, but I was ordered with something so I followed it). Narrated by Ahmad: Muhammad bin Ja'far told us: Awf told us from Maymun Abu Abdullah from him. Its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except this Maymun, who is Al-Basri, the freed slave of Ibn Samurah, and he is weak as in (Al-Taqrib). In (Al-Majma'): (Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy and a group weakened him, and the rest of his men are men of the Sahih). Al-Dhahabi cited this Hadith for him and said: (Al-Uqayli said following it: And it was narrated from a path sounder than this, and in it there is softness as well). As for Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath), he said: (Ahmad, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Hakim narrated it, and their men are trustworthy). Thus he said, and he also contradicted himself. It is in (Mustadrak Al-Hakim) from the path of Ahmad, and he said: (Sahih Isnad), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Among them: From Ibn Umar, he said: Indeed Ibn Abi Talib was given three qualities, if I had one of them it would be more beloved...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...to me than red camels: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, married his daughter to him and she bore him children, and the doors were closed except his door in the mosque, and he gave him the banner on the Day of Khaybar). Narrated by Ahmad from Hisham bin Sa'd from Umar bin Usaid from him. This is a Hasan chain as Al-Hafiz said. I say: Its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Hisham bin Sa'd, who is from the men of Muslim only, and he is truthful having delusions as said in (Al-Taqrib). Umar bin Usaid is Amr bin Abi Sufyan bin Usaid as in the books of Rijal. In the chapter, there are [narrations] from Ali himself, Jabir bin Samurah, and Ibn Abbas as well, but their chains are not worthy of mention, so we restricted ourselves to what preceded. The Hadith of Ibn Umar has another path narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and likewise Al-Nasa'i as in (Al-Fath) from the path of Al-Ala' bin 'Arar (with unpointed letters), he said: I said to Ibn Umar: Tell me about Ali and Uthman... So he mentioned the Hadith. In it: (Its men are men of the Sahih except Al-Ala', and Yahya bin Ma'in and others declared him trustworthy. These Hadiths strengthen each other, and every path among them is valid for argumentation, let alone their sum. Ibn Al-Jawzi included this Hadith in (Al-Mawdu'at) [Fabricated Hadiths], extracting it from the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, Zaid bin Arqam, and Ibn Umar, restricting himself...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...to some of its paths from them. He faulted it by some of those spoken about among its narrators, and that is not a valid criticism due to what I mentioned of the abundance of paths. He also faulted it claiming it contradicts the authentic established Hadiths regarding the door of Abu Bakr, and claimed it was fabricated by the Rafidah to counter the authentic Hadith regarding the door of Abu Bakr. End quote. He erred in that a grievous error, for he followed the path of rejecting authentic Hadiths by imagining contradiction, whereas reconciling the two stories is possible). Then he mentioned the way of reconciling them, the summary of which is: (That the door of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, was towards the mosque and his house had no other door, so he was not ordered to close it. When they closed the doors by his command, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, they created wickets (Khawkha) to shortcut entry to the mosque from them, so they were ordered to close them afterwards). Al-Hafiz found this reconciliation good. I say: There is clear questionable aspect in it to me, because according to this, there is no merit for Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, in keeping his door as long as he had no other, so from where would he enter and exit? He is compelled, so his permission, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to him would be for necessity, and there would be no difference then between him, may Allah be pleased with him, and anyone else if he were in a house like his. While the previous Hadiths indicate that it is a merit for Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, such that Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, wished he had this merit as preceded. So the closer view in reconciliation is what Ibn Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned where he said after citing some paths of this Hadith:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (This does not contradict what is established in (Sahih Al-Bukhari) of his command, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, during his death illness to close the doors opening into the mosque except the door of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq. Because the exception of this in Ali's right was during his [Prophet's] life due to Fatima's need to pass from her house to her father's house, so this was made as a gentleness to her. As for after his death, this reason ceased, so there was a need to open Al-Siddiq's door for his exit to the mosque to lead the people in prayer, since he was the Caliph over them after his death, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. In this is an indication to his Caliphate). This, and it appears that his command, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to close the wickets and doors is of the type of blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhara'i), because their existence leads to using the mosque as a passageway, which is forbidden as will come in (Al-Manahi), paragraph (12). Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in the context of mentioning the benefits in the Hadith: (And that mosques are to be protected from being used as thoroughfares without necessity). Al-Qurtubi mentioned something similar regarding what we pointed to. (And it is permissible to build them on: (A) The places of worship of disbelievers after breaking them and changing their features. Talq bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: We went out as a delegation to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, swore allegiance to him, prayed with him, and informed him that in our land we have a synagogue (Bi'ah) belonging to us... He said: (Go out, and when you come to your land, break your synagogue... and take it as a mosque). The Hadith is abbreviated, and its completion after his saying: 'a synagogue belonging to us': So we asked him for some of his leftover purification water. He called for water, performed ablution and rinsed his mouth, then poured it into a vessel and ordered us, saying:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Go out, and when you come to your land, break your synagogue, sprinkle its place with this water, and take it as a mosque). We said: The land is far, the heat is intense, and the water dries up. He said: (Extend it with water, for it increases it only in goodness). So we went out until we arrived at our town, broke our synagogue, then sprinkled its place and took it as a mosque. We called the Adhan in it. He said: And the monk was a man from Tayy, so when he heard the Adhan he said: 'A call of truth.' Then he faced a ravine among our ravines and we never saw him again. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i: Hannad bin Al-Sari informed us from Mulazim, he said: Abdullah bin Badr told me from Qais bin Talq from his father Talq bin Ali. This is a Hasan chain; all its men are trustworthy except Mulazim - who is Ibn Umar - and Qais bin Talq, and they are truthful (Saduq) as in (Al-Taqrib). There is disagreement regarding Qais bin Talq that does not lower his Hadith from the rank of Hasan. Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Ahmad and Yahya weakened him in one of the two narrations from him, and in the narration of Uthman bin Sa'id from him: Trustworthy. Al-Ajli declared him trustworthy. Ibn Abi Hatim said: I asked my father and Abu Zur'ah about him, so they said: He is not one whose [Hadith] stands as proof. Ibn Al-Qattan said: It implies that his report is Hasan, not Sahih). Ibn Hibban extracted the Hadith in his (Sahih) at length from Abu Khalifa: Musaddad bin Musarhad told us: Mulazim told us with it, as in (Al-Mirqat) and (Nasb Al-Rayah).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And Ahmad from Muhammad bin Jabir from Abdullah bin Badr with it briefly. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Umair Al-Sadusi: That he came with a vessel from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, had washed his face and rinsed his mouth in it and spat in the water, then washed his hand, then filled the vessel and said: (Do not approach water except you fill the vessel upon what remains in it. When you come to your country, sprinkle that spot with it and take it as a mosque). He said: So they took it as a mosque. Umar said: And I have prayed in it. Al-Haythami said: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Awsat). Umar bin Shaqiq was mentioned by him and his father Ibn Abi Hatim and no disparagement or otherwise was mentioned regarding them). The Hadith indicates the permissibility of taking synagogues as mosques; and others like churches and such are appended to it by analogy. Al-Shawkani said: (Likewise, many of the Companions did when they stormed the lands; they made their places of worship into places of worship for Muslims and changed their Mihrabs). In the chapter [there is a report] from Uthman bin Abi Al-Aas: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered him to place the mosque of Taif where their idol (Taghiyah) used to be. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi from the path of Abu Hamam Al-Dallal: Sa'id bin Al-Sa'ib told us from Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Iyad from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Al-Hakim and Al-Dhahabi remained silent on it. Al-Shawkani said: (The men of its chain are trustworthy, and Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Iyad was mentioned by Ibn Hibban in (Al-Thiqat), and likewise Abu Hamam is trustworthy, and his name is Muhammad bin Muhammad Al-Dallal Al-Basri). I say: Al-Shawkani did nothing, for this Ibn Iyad, although mentioned by Ibn Hibban in (Al-Thiqat), it is according to his rule of authenticating unknown narrators (Majahil). In such cases, it is not befitting for investigators to rely on his authentication alone. Therefore, Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Not known; Sa'id bin Al-Sa'ib narrated from him). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable). All this indicates that the man is not well-known, making his Hadith invalid for argumentation. Therefore, we turned away from mentioning it in the original text and cited it here as a witness. Furthermore, his saying: (And his name is Muhammad bin Muhammad) is not correct; rather, it is Muhammad bin Muhabbab - with Fatha on the unpointed [Ha] and the first Ba, like Mu'azzam - so I do not know if it was misspelled by Al-Shawkani himself or by some of those who copied his book. He is trustworthy, and so are the rest of the narrators except Ibn Iyad. (B) Graves of the polytheists after exhuming them, for the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when (he ordered the building of the mosque in the garden (Ha'it) which contained graves of polytheists, he ordered regarding them, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so they were exhumed) as preceded). The Hadith is from the narration of Anas, and its mention in full preceded shortly. We only cited from it here...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...what suits the context. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (In the Hadith is the permissibility of disposing of a graveyard owned by gift or sale, the permissibility of exhuming obliterated graves if they are not respected [i.e., non-Muslim], the permissibility of prayer in the graveyards of polytheists after exhuming them and removing what is in them, and the permissibility of building mosques in their places). (Then, mosques are the most beloved of places to Allah The Exalted, as he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (The most beloved of lands to Allah The Exalted are its mosques). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet], and it has a completion: (And the most hated of lands to Allah are its markets). Narrated by Muslim from the path of Abdul Rahman bin Mahran, the freed slave of Abu Huraira, from him. It has witnesses, among them: From Jubair bin Mut'im that a man said: O Messenger of Allah, which lands are most beloved to Allah? And which lands are most hated to Allah? He said: (I do not know until I ask Gabriel, peace be upon him). So Gabriel came to him and informed him that the most beloved of spots to Allah are the mosques and the most hated of spots to Allah are the markets). Al-Mundhiri said: (Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Bazzar - and the wording is his - Abu Ya'la, and Al-Hakim, and he said: Sahih Isnad). Al-Haythami said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (The men of Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and Al-Bazzar are the men of the Sahih except Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil, and he is good (Hasan) in Hadith and there is speech regarding him). I say: It is with Al-Hakim and Ahmad from the path of Zuhair bin Muhammad from Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil from Muhammad bin Jubair bin Mut'im from his father with it without mentioning the mosques. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Isnad. Qais bin Al-Rabi' and Amr bin Thabit bin Abi Al-Miqdam narrated it from Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil). Al-Dhahabi said: (I say: Zuhair has objectionable reports (Manakir), this is one of them, and Ibn Aqil has softness). I say: But his Hadith does not fall below the rank of Hasan, especially if followed up (corroborated). Zuhair bin Muhammad was not alone in it as Al-Hakim stated, so he is absolved of responsibility for it (1). Among them is from Abdullah bin Amr similarly. Al-Mundhiri said: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani (Al-Kabir) and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih). Al-Haythami said: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and it contains Ata bin Al-Sa'ib, who is trustworthy but became confused in the end of his life, and the rest of his men are trustworthy).
foot_note: 1. (1) Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) (4/269): (Ahmad and Al-Bazzar narrated it, and Al-Hakim authenticated it, and its chain is Hasan).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: Al-Hakim also extracted it from the path of Jarir from Ata bin Al-Sa'ib from Muharib bin Dithar from Abdullah bin Umar, who said: A man came to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah, which spots are best? He said: (I do not know). He said: Which spots are worst? He said: (I do not know). So Gabriel came to him, so he said: Ask your Lord. Gabriel said: We do not ask Him about anything. So he trembled a trembling that Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, almost fell unconscious from it. When Gabriel ascended, Allah The Exalted said: Muhammad asked you: Which spots are best? And you said: I do not know. And he asked you which spots are worst? And you said: I do not know? He said: So he said: Yes. He said: So He told him that the best of spots are the mosques and the worst of spots are the markets. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It contains what Al-Haythami mentioned regarding Ata. Al-Dhahabi himself mentioned in (Al-Mizan) from Ahmad that he said: (Whoever heard from him (meaning Ata) early, it is correct, and whoever heard from him recently, it is nothing). Ahmad explicitly stated - as in Al-Tahdhib or others - that Jarir is among those who heard from him recently. Ibn Ma'in said: (He became confused, and what Jarir and his ilk heard from him is not from his sound Hadith). In this Hadith of his, there are wordings of apparent objectionability (Nakara) which did not appear in the other Hadiths...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and that indicates his confusion. However, the origin of the Hadith is Sahih with its preceding witnesses. (Regarding coming to them [mosques] and going [to them] are many virtues about which Prophetic Hadiths have come; we will suffice by mentioning some of them: (A) (Whoever performs ablution in his house and perfects the ablution then comes to the mosque, he is a visitor of Allah, and it is a right upon the Host to honor the visitor). The Hadith. Al-Mundhiri said: (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) from Salman, may Allah be pleased with him, with two chains, one of them is good (Jayyid). And Al-Bayhaqi narrated similar to it stopped (Mawquf) at the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with a Sahih chain). Al-Haythami said: (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) and the men of one of its two chains are the men of the Sahih). I say: It has a witness from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masud raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Indeed the houses of Allah on earth are the mosques, and indeed it is a right upon Allah to honor the visitor). Al-Haythami said: (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) and it contains Abdullah bin Ya'qub Al-Kirmani, and he is weak). I say: Its chain in (Al-Kabir) is thus: Al-Abbas bin Hamdan Al-Asbahani told us: Abdullah bin Abi - sic - Ya'qub Al-Kirmani told us: Abdullah bin Yazid Al-Muqri told us:...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Masoudi from Ibn Ishaq from Amr bin Maimun from him. This Al-Abbas bin Hamdan is Al-Hanafi; Al-Tabarani narrates from him frequently and extracted one hadith for him in his (Al-Mu'jam Al-Saghir). I did not find anyone who wrote his biography, perhaps he is in (Tabaqat Al-Asbahaniyyin) by Ibn Hayyan, and there is a copy of it in the Al-Zahiriyah Library, so let it be checked. The rest of the men of the chain are trustworthy except Al-Karmani, for he is weak as Al-Haythami said, preceded by Al-Dhahabi. (b): (Whoever goes to the mosque in the morning or evening, Allah prepares for him a hospitality in Paradise every time he goes in the morning or evening). The Hadith was recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad via Yazid bin Harun - Ahmad's Sheikh in it -: Muhammad bin Mutarrif informed us from Zaid bin Aslam from Ata bin Yasar from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet]. Al-Hafiz said: (The apparent meaning of the Hadith is the attainment of virtue for anyone who comes to the mosque absolutely, but the intended meaning is its restriction to those who come to it for worship, and prayer is the head of that. And Allah knows best). (c): (Whoever goes to the congregation mosque, one step wipes out a sin and one step writes for him a good deed, going and returning). It is from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas, recorded by Imam Ahmad via the path of Ibn Lahi'ah: Hayy bin Abdullah narrated to us that Abu Abdul Rahman narrated to him that he heard Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas narrate it raised [to the Prophet].

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a Hasan chain. Ibn Lahi'ah is only feared for his uniqueness due to his poor memory, but he himself is trustworthy, and he has been corroborated. Al-Haythami said after citing the Hadith: (Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and the men of Al-Tabarani are the men of the Sahih, and the men of Ahmad include Ibn Lahi'ah). Al-Mundhiri said: (Recorded by Ahmad with a Hasan chain, and Al-Tabarani, and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih). It appears that Ibn Hibban also narrated it from a path other than Ibn Lahi'ah, for this one is weak according to him. He said about him: (I have examined his reports from the narration of the early and late narrators from him, and I saw confusion present in the narration of the late narrators from him, and much that has no basis in the narration of the early narrators. So I returned to consideration and saw that he used to commit Tadlis [obfuscation] from weak people onto people Ibn Lahi'ah saw as trustworthy, so he attached those fabricated narrations to them). Then, perhaps Al-Tabarani narrated it from a path other than that of Hayy bin Abdullah, for he is not among the men of the Sahih, and Al-Haythami says regarding his men: (That they are the men of the Sahih) without exception. And Allah knows best. (d): (Whoever walks in the darkness of the night to the mosque will meet Allah Almighty with light on the Day of Resurrection). Al-Mundhiri cited it from the Hadith of Abu Darda raised [to the Prophet] and said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) with a Hasan chain and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih), and his wording is: Whoever walks in the darkness of the night to the mosques, Allah gives him light on the Day of Resurrection). Al-Haythami said: (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and its men are trustworthy). It has many witnesses with its meaning that elevate it to the degree of Sahih. Among them: From Abu Huraira: Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) with a Hasan chain as Al-Mundhiri said, and Al-Haythami followed him. And among them from Buraydah: Recorded by Abu Dawood via Ismail Abu Salman Al-Kahhal from Abdullah bin Aws from him. Al-Mundhiri said: (And its men are trustworthy). I say: Nay, for Abdullah bin Aws was not authenticated by anyone other than Ibn Hibban, and his authentication in such a case is not a proof as we have informed you repeatedly, the last of which was shortly before [the chapter of] building mosques over the graves of polytheists. Therefore, Ibn Al-Qattan said about him: (Unknown condition [Majhul al-Hal], and we do not know of a narration for him except this Hadith from this aspect). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (Lenient in Hadith [Layyin al-Hadith]). Then, the Hadith was attributed by Al-Mundhiri and others to Al-Tirmidhi, but I did not find it in his (Sunan), even though...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Nabulsi mentioned in (Al-Dhakha'ir) that it is in (Prayer) from his (Sunan). Despite that, I did not find it. And Allah knows best (1). Among them is from Anas, recorded by Ibn Majah and Al-Hakim via Sulaiman bin Dawood Al-Sa'igh from Thabit from him. Al-Hakim said: (It is a narration of unknown status [Majhula]), and that is sufficient as weakening. Its defect is this Sulaiman; Al-Uqayli said: (He is not to be followed in his Hadith). And among them is from Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi with them both as well via the path of Ibrahim bin Muhammad Al-Basri: Yahya bin Al-Harith Al-Shirazi informed us - and he was trustworthy and Abdullah [bin] Dawood used to praise him - he said: Zuhair bin Muhammad Al-Taimi and Abu Ghassan Al-Madani narrated to us from Abu Hazim from him. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, but they erred, because Ibrahim bin Muhammad Al-Basri and his Sheikh Yahya bin Al-Harith Al-Shirazi are not from the men of the Two Sheikhs. Furthermore, the first of them was not authenticated by anyone other than Ibn Hibban, who said: (He makes mistakes).
foot_note: 1. (1) Then I found it in the chapter (What came regarding the virtue of Isha and Fajr in congregation) (1/435) and he said: (A Gharib Hadith from this aspect).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: However, a group narrated from him, and he said in (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, makes mistakes [Saduq Yukhti']). His Sheikh Yahya is not known to be authenticated except in this chain and context by Al-Hakim, and no one narrated from him except this Ibrahim. In (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable [Maqbul]), meaning: Unknown. From that, you know that the chain is weak, so the statement of the one who said: It is Hasan, like the author of (Al-Zawa'id), is not good. So how can the statement of the one who authenticated it be correct? Ibn Khuzaima recorded it in his (Sahih) as in Al-Targhib. In the chapter, there is [a report] from Abu Huraira in Ibn Majah, and from Abu Ya'la, and from Zaid bin Harithah in Al-Tabarani's (Al-Awsat) and (Al-Kabir), and from Aisha in (Al-Awsat), and Ibn Abbas in (Al-Kabir), and Ibn Umar in it, and Abu Musa in it. The chains of all of them are not free from weakness. (And the best of mosques and the greatest in sanctity are four: A - Al-Masjid Al-Haram, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (A prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is better than one hundred thousand prayers in other mosques). It is from the Hadith of Abu Darda raised [to the Prophet].

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ibn Khuzaima recorded it with this wording in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib), and its completion is: (And a prayer in the Mosque of Medina is better than one thousand prayers elsewhere, and a prayer in the Mosque of Bayt al-Maqdis [Jerusalem] is better than five hundred prayers in other mosques). Al-Tabarani recorded it in (Al-Kabir) similarly. Al-Haythami said: (Its men are trustworthy, and there is discussion regarding some of them, and it is a Hasan Hadith). Al-Mundhiri said: (Al-Bazzar recorded it and said: Its chain is Hasan. Thus he said). In this, there is an indication that it is not as Al-Bazzar said. Al-Hafiz also quoted this statement of his in (Al-Fath) and affirmed it, as he did not critique it with anything. And Allah knows best. The Hadith has witnesses: Among them from Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (A prayer in this mosque of mine is better than one thousand prayers in other mosques except Al-Masjid Al-Haram, and a prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is better than one hundred prayers in this one). Al-Tahawi and Ahmad recorded it via the path of Hammad bin Zaid who said: Habib Al-Mu'allim narrated to us from Ata from him. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the Six [Books]. Ibn Hibban authenticated it, so he and Ibn Khuzaima narrated it in their (Sahihs) as in (Al-Targhib). He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Al-Bazzar recorded it and its chain is also Sahih). Al-Tabarani also recorded it as in (Al-Majma') and said: (The men of Ahmad and Al-Bazzar are the men of the Sahih). Al-Tayalisi recorded it from Al-Rabi' bin Sabih who said: I heard Ata bin Abi Rabah with it similarly. Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: (There is disagreement regarding Ibn Al-Zubayr as to whether it is raised [Marfu'] or stopped [Mawquf], and the one who raised it is more memorizing and firm, and something like this is not said by opinion). Ata has another chain for it; he narrated it from Jabir bin Abdullah raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (And a prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is better than one hundred thousand prayers elsewhere). The rest is exactly like it. Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad recorded it via the path of Ubaidullah bin Amr Al-Raqqi from Abdul Karim bin Malik from him with it. This is also a Sahih chain like the one before it. Al-Mundhiri said: (Ahmad and Ibn Majah recorded it with two Sahih chains). Thus he said, which gives the illusion that it has two paths from Jabir, but it is not so. If he had said: "with a Sahih chain," as is the practice, it would have been more correct in expression and further from illusion. Al-Hafiz said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (The men of its chain are trustworthy, but it is from the narration of Ata regarding that from him. Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: It is possible that Ata had it from both of them, and this is how the scholars of Hadith interpret it. This is supported by the fact that Ata is an Imam of wide narration, known for narrating from Jabir and Ibn Al-Zubayr). Ata has a third chain for it; Ibn Umar also narrated it, and it will be discussed in the section on the Prophetic Mosque. As for what Al-Tabarani recorded in (Al-Awsat) from the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (A prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is better than one hundred prayers in other [mosques]), its chain contains Suwayd bin Abdul Aziz, who is weak as Al-Haythami said. Al-Hafiz said: (This Hadith was used as evidence for the preference of Mecca over Medina, because places are honored by the virtue of worship in them over others where worship is outweighed. This is the view of the majority. It was narrated from Malik, and Ibn Wahb, Mutarrif, and Ibn Habib from his companions held it. However, what is famous from Malik and most of his companions is the preference of Medina. They used as evidence his saying, peace be upon him: (What is between my grave and my pulpit is a garden from the gardens of Paradise) (and its extraction will come) along with his saying: (The space of a whip in Paradise is better than the world and what is in it). Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: This is inferring using a report in a context other than what it was revealed for, and it does not stand against the text revealed regarding the virtue of Mecca. Then he cited...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the Hadith of Abu Salamah from Abdullah bin Adi bin Al-Hamra who said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, standing at Al-Hazwarah saying: (By Allah, you are the best of Allah's earth, and the most beloved of Allah's earth to Allah, and were it not that I was expelled from you, I would not have left). It is a Sahih Hadith recorded by the authors of the Sunan, and authenticated by Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Khuzaima, Ibn Hibban, and others. Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: This is a text on the point of dispute, so one should not deviate from it. And Allah knows best. Many of the Maliki authors retracted from this view [preferring Medina]. He said: It was used to evidence the multiplication of prayer absolutely in the two mosques. It has been previously quoted from Al-Tahawi and others that this is specific to obligatory prayers due to his saying, peace be upon him: (The best prayer of a man is in his house except the obligatory). It can be said: There is nothing preventing keeping the Hadith on its generality, so the voluntary prayer in a house in Medina or Mecca is multiplied over prayer in a house elsewhere, and likewise in the two mosques, even if prayer in the houses is better absolutely). (And his saying: (The best for which mounts are saddled are the Mosque of Ibrahim, peace be upon him, and my Mosque). Imam Ahmad recorded it via the path of Ibn Lahi'ah: Abu Al-Zubayr narrated to us from Jabir raised [to the Prophet]. Ibn Lahi'ah has a poor memory, and Abu Al-Zubayr is a Mudallis and used 'an'ana [saying 'from']. Despite that, Al-Haythami said: (Recorded by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and its chain is Hasan).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Perhaps that is because it came via another path, for he himself repeated it after a page with the wording: (And the Mosque of Muhammad, peace be upon him). The rest is like it. Then he said: (Al-Bazzar recorded it, and in it is Abdul Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad; more than one person authenticated him and a group weakened him, and the rest of his men are the men of the (Sahih). Al-Suyuti cited it in (Al-Jami') with the wording (This Mosque of mine and the Ancient House [Al-Kaaba]). He said: (Recorded by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih), and he indicated it is Sahih) (1). It has a witness from the Hadith of Aisha with the wording: (I am the seal of the prophets and my mosque is the seal of the mosques of the prophets. The most worthy of mosques to be visited and for mounts to be saddled to are: Al-Masjid Al-Haram and my mosque. A prayer in my mosque is better than a thousand prayers elsewhere except Al-Masjid Al-Haram). He said in (Al-Majma'): (Al-Bazzar recorded it and in it is Musa bin Ubaidah, and he is weak). (And it is the first mosque built on the face of the earth, as Abu Dharr said:
foot_note: 1. (1) Then I found it in (Al-Musnad) (3/350) with this wording via the path of Al-Laith bin Sa'd from Abu Al-Zubayr with it. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of Muslim, and Al-Laith does not narrate from Abu Al-Zubayr except what he heard from Jabir as established in its place. Al-Hafiz narrated it in (Al-Rahma Al-Ghaythiyah) and authenticated it; see (2/254) of Al-Majmu'a Al-Muniriyyah).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (I said: O Messenger of Allah, which mosque was placed in the earth first? He said: (Al-Masjid Al-Haram. I said: Then which? He said: Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa). The completion of the Hadith: I said: How long was between them? He said: (Forty years. And wherever the prayer catches you, pray, for it is a mosque). Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via paths from Al-A'mash from Ibrahim Al-Taimi from his father from him. Abu Awanah - his name is Al-Waddah bin Abdullah Al-Yashkuri - followed him from Ibrahim; Ahmad recorded it. The Hadith is explicit evidence that the Mosque of Mecca is the first house placed for worship. Ibn Al-Arabi said in (Ahkam Al-Quran): (This is a refutation of those who say: There was a house on earth before it that the angels made pilgrimage to). Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in (Al-Bidayah): (It has not come in a Sahih report from an infallible one that the House was a house before Al-Khalil [Abraham], peace be upon him. Whoever clings in this to His saying: {The place of the House} [Al-Hajj: 26]...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...it is not a strong proof nor apparent, because the meaning is its place decreed in the knowledge of Allah, established in His power, venerated by the prophets; its location from the time of Adam to the time of Abraham. We have mentioned that Adam set up a dome over it and that the angels said to him: We circumambulated this House before you, and that the Ark circumambulated it for forty days or so. But all these reports are from the Children of Israel, and we have established that they are neither believed nor disbelieved, so they are not used as proof. But if the Truth rejects them, they are rejected. Allah has said: {Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Bakkah...} [Al Imran: 96] the verse). It was narrated in a Hadith that the first one to build it was Adam, peace be upon him, but it is weak as will come. A problem was raised from the Hadith stating: (That between the two mosques, Al-Masjid Al-Haram and Al-Aqsa, was forty years), because the builder of Al-Aqsa was Solomon, peace be upon him, as indicated by the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr coming soon, God willing. And between him and Abraham, peace be upon him, is more than a thousand years according to what historians say. Furthermore, the text of the Quran - as Al-Hafiz said - states that the story of David killing Goliath was after Moses by a period. This has been answered with several answers; perhaps the closest is the statement of Al-Khattabi: (It is likely that Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa was first founded by some of the Awliya [allies] of Allah before David and Solomon, then David and Solomon added to it and expanded it, so its building was attributed to them). See the full discussion and answers to the problem in (Al-Fath) and (Al-Mirqat).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir asserted in (Al-Bidayah) (That Israel - who is Jacob bin Isaac bin Abraham - is the first who built Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa, and that Solomon, peace be upon him, renewed it after that). If this is correct, it is close to what the Hadith indicated regarding the period between the two mosques. And Allah knows best. (This Hadith clarifies the intended meaning of His saying: {Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Bakkah - blessed and a guidance for the worlds}, meaning: The first house placed for worship). Al-Hafiz said in the explanation of the previous Hadith: (This Hadith interprets the meaning of His saying: {Indeed, the first House...} the verse, and indicates that the intended meaning by 'the House' is the House of Worship, not houses absolutely. This has been reported explicitly from Ali; recorded by Ishaq bin Rahwaih, Ibn Abi Hatim, and others with a Sahih chain from him. He said: Houses existed before it, but it was the first House placed for the worship of Allah). I say: Al-Hakim narrated it similarly and said: (Sahih according to the condition of Muslim), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in (Al-Tafsir): (Al-Suddi claimed that it is the first house placed on the face of the earth absolutely, but the correct view is the statement of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. As for the Hadith recorded by Al-Bayhaqi regarding the building of the Kaaba in his book (Dala'il Al-Nubuwwah) via the path of Ibn Lahi'ah from Yazid bin Abi Habib from Abu Al-Khayr from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas raised [to the Prophet]:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Allah sent Gabriel to Adam and Eve and ordered them to build the Kaaba, so Adam built it, then he was ordered to circumambulate it, and it was said to him: You are the first of people and this is the first House placed for people). For it is - as you see - from the unique narrations of Ibn Lahi'ah, and he is weak. It is more likely - and Allah knows best - that this is stopped [Mawquf] at Abdullah bin Amr, and it is from the two loads [Zamilatayn] which he acquired on the Day of Yarmouk from the speech of the People of the Book). (Among what it is distinguished by over other mosques is the permissibility of voluntary prayer in it at all times, even the disliked times, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (O Banu Abd Manaf, if you have authority over the matter, do not prevent anyone from praying at this House at any hour he wishes of night or day)). The Hadith is from the narration of Jubayr bin Mut'im raised [to the Prophet]. Al-Daraqutni recorded it in his (Sunan) and Ahmad via Ibn Jurayj who said: Abu Al-Zubayr informed me that he heard Abdullah bin Babiyah reporting from him. This is a Sahih chain connected by hearing, and it is according to the condition of Muslim. Ibn Hibban recorded it in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Talkhis), and the authors of the four Sunan and others recorded it via Ibn Uyaynah from Abu Al-Zubayr with it similarly. Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim authenticated it. Its mention will come, God willing, with its witnesses in its place. [End of the first volume of the book (Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab), followed by the second volume beginning with the virtue of the Prophetic Mosque]. Publisher).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (b): Then the Prophetic Mosque due to his saying: (A prayer in this mosque of mine is better than a thousand prayers in any other mosque except the Sacred Mosque [for it is better]). The Hadith was narrated by a group of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them: (1) Among them is Abu Hurairah, and there are many paths from him: 1 - From Abu Abdullah Al-Aghar - and his name is Salman - from him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/51), Muslim (4/124), Al-Nasa'i (1/113, 2/34), Al-Tirmidhi (2/147) who authenticated it, Al-Darimi (1/330), Ibn Majah (1/428), as well as Malik (1/201), Al-Tahawi (2/73), and Ahmad (2/256, 386, 468, 473, 485) via paths from him. And Al-Khatib narrated it in his (Tarikh) (14/145). 2 - From Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from him. Extracted by Muslim, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad (2/239) from Al-Zuhri from him. Likewise, Al-Khatib extracted it (9/222). 3 - From Abdullah bin Ibrahim bin Qariz from him. Narrated by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad (2/251, 473) via paths from him. Muslim and Al-Nasa'i added: (For I am the last of the Prophets and my mosque is the last of the mosques). 4 - From Muhammad bin Hilal from his father from him. Extracted by Al-Tahawi and Ahmad (2/499) via two paths from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a good (Hasan) chain in corroborations. Muhammad bin Hilal and his father were declared trustworthy by Ibn Hibban. 5 - From Ibn Ishaq who said: Khubaib bin Abd al-Rahman bin Khubaib al-Ansari told me from Hafs bin Asim bin Umar bin al-Khattab from Abu Hurairah elevated [to the Prophet]. Narrated by Ahmad (2/397). This is a good (Hasan) or authentic (Sahih) chain; its men are men of the Six except Ibn Ishaq, who is trustworthy and explicitly stated narration. 6 - From Sufyan from Salih Mawla al-Taw'amah from him. Extracted by Ahmad (2/466, 484), and its chain is also good in corroborations. 7 - From Hassan bin Ghalib who said: Ya'qub bin Abd al-Rahman told us from Musa bin Uqbah from Nafi' from Abu Hurairah elevated. Extracted by Al-Tahawi. Its men are trustworthy except this Hassan, who is weak. What is known is from the hadith of Nafi' from Ibn Umar as will come shortly. 8 - From Kathir bin Zaid from Al-Walid bin Rabah from him. Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi (2/326 - Bulaq edition) with a good chain. (2) Among them is Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, and there are two paths from him: 1 - From Ubaidullah bin Umar from Nafi' from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Extracted by Muslim, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Ahmad (2/16, 52, 101-102), and Al-Khatib (4/162) via paths from him. This path from Nafi' missed Imam Al-Nasa'i, for he extracted it (2/34) as did Muslim, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad (2/53-54) via Musa bin Abdullah Al-Juhani from Nafi' with it. Then Al-Nasa'i said: (I do not know anyone who narrated this hadith from Nafi' from Ibn Umar other than Musa Al-Juhani, and Ibn Juraij and others differed with him). Then he cited it from his path from Nafi' from Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Ma'bad from Maimunah elevated with it. It will come after this. We say: Nafi' has two chains for it, both authentic: The first: From Ibn Umar as Musa Al-Juhani narrated it, and Ubaidullah bin Umar, the trustworthy and firm, followed him as in the first narration. His brother Abdullah bin Umar also followed him in Al-Tayalisi (p. 251 no. 1826) and Ahmad (2/68). The second: Ibn Juraij's narration from him. And it is coming. 2 - From Abd al-Malik from Ata from Ibn Umar with it. And the addition is his. Extracted by Ahmad (2/29, 155). This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. Ata has two other chains for it: One: From Jabir,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And the other: From Ibn Al-Zubair. Indicating this addition is his saying: (And a prayer in the Sacred Mosque is better than a hundred prayers in this one), meaning: the mosque of Medina. Its extraction has preceded. (Note): Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) (3/52): (And in Al-Nasa'i from the narration of Musa Al-Juhani from Nafi' from Ibn Umar like the wording of Abu Hurairah, and at its end: except the Sacred Mosque, for it is better than it by a hundred prayers). I say: This addition is not in Al-Nasa'i, nor is it in any of the advanced paths. Perhaps it is in (Al-Sunan Al-Kubra) of Al-Nasa'i. And Allah knows best. (3) Among them is Maimunah, the wife of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: Narrated by Ibn Juraij, who said: I heard Nafi' saying Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Ma'bad told us that Ibn Abbas narrated from her with it. Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (2/34), Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad (6/334). Al-Layth bin Sa'd followed him: Nafi' told me with it. Extracted by Muslim (4/125-126), Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad. In his hadith is a story in Muslim from Ibn Abbas who said: (That a woman complained of an illness and said: If Allah cures me, I will go out and pray in Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem). She recovered and prepared to leave, then came to Maimunah, the wife of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: to greet her and informed her of that. She said: Sit and eat what you prepared, and pray in the Mosque of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, for I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say... and she mentioned the Hadith. (4) Among them is Abu Sa'id al-Khudri: Narrated by Jarir from Mughirah from Ibrahim from Sahm bin Minjab from Quza'ah from him who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, bade farewell to a man and said to him: Where do you want to go? He said: I want Bayt al-Maqdis. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him... so he mentioned it. Extracted by Ahmad (3/77), and the context is his, and Al-Tahawi (2/72). This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. Al-Haythami cited it in (Al-Majmu') (4/6) with the wording: (hundred) instead of: (thousand) and said: (Abu Ya'la and Al-Bazzar narrated it similarly except he said: Better than a thousand prayers. And the men of Abu Ya'la are men of the Sahih). (5) Among them is Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas: Narrated by Abd al-Rahman bin Abi al-Zinad from Musa bin Uqbah from Abu Abdullah al-Qaraz from him. Extracted by Ahmad (1/184). This is a good chain, were it not that I did not know Abu Abdullah al-Qaraz. In the Kunyas of (Al-Mizan):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Abu Abdullah Al-Qazzaz from Salim bin Abdullah and from him Al-Darawardi: Unknown). It might be this one (1). In (Al-Majmu') (4/5): (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and Al-Bazzar, and in it is Abd al-Rahman bin Abi al-Zinad, who is weak). I say: He was not alone in it, for Al-Tahawi narrated it (2/72) via Hassan bin Ghalib who said: Ya'qub bin Abd al-Rahman told us from Musa bin Uqbah: Abu Abdullah told me with it. But this Hassan is weak as preceded. He has another path in it, extracted from Shu'bah from Abu Abd al-Aziz al-Zubaydi from Amr bin al-Hakam from Sa'd elevated. Its men are all trustworthy except Abu Abd al-Aziz al-Zubaydi, whom I did not know. Then I referred to the section of Kunyas in the book (Kashf al-Astar an Rijal Ma'ani al-Athar), and lo, in it: (Abu Abd al-Aziz al-Rabadhi - with Fatha on Ra and Ba then Dhal Mu'jamah - is Musa bin Ubaidah - with Damma on the first - weak). So it became clear that what is in the original: Al-Zubaydi is a misspelling, and the correct is: Al-Rabadhi. Likewise occurred in it: Amr bin al-Hakam, and the correct is: Umar, with Damma on the un-dotted [Ayn] and without Waw.
foot_note: 1. (1) Then it became clear to me that it is not him, but rather Dinar al-Khuza'i al-Madani, who is from the men of Muslim, trustworthy, narrates Mursal hadiths as in (Al-Taqrib).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Musa bin Ubaidah has another chain which is: (6) Among them is Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, and there are two paths from her: 1 - From Musa bin Ubaidah from Dawud bin Mudrik from Urwah from her. Musa is weak as preceded, and his Sheikh Dawud bin Mudrik is unknown as in (Al-Taqrib). 2 - From Ibn Juraij: Ata informed me that Abu Salamah informed him from Abu Hurairah and Aisha elevated. This is an authentic chain on the condition of the Six. Extracted by Ahmad (2/278). (7) Among them is Jubayr bin Mut'im: Narrated by Husayn bin Abd al-Rahman from Muhammad bin Talha bin Yazid bin Rakanah from Jubayr bin Mut'im elevated. Its men are trustworthy except that it is disconnected between Muhammad bin Talha and Jubayr bin Mut'im. Extracted by Al-Tayalisi (p. 128 no. 950) and Ahmad (4/80). It was narrated connected, so Al-Haythami said (4/5): (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, Al-Bazzar, and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir). The chains of the three - thus - are Mursal, and in Al-Tabarani it has a chain whose men are men of the Sahih and it is connected).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It was narrated that prayer in his mosque, peace and blessings be upon him, is worth fifty thousand prayers. It is not authentic as will be explained in the conclusion of the discussion on Quba Mosque. (Benefit): It is known that his mosque, peace and blessings be upon him, has been increased from what it was in his time, peace be upon him. Its length was equal to its width, one hundred cubits by one hundred, and it was said: seventy by sixty. Then Uthman added to it, making its length one hundred and sixty cubits and its width one hundred and fifty. Then Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik added to it, making its length two hundred cubits and its width at the front two hundred and at the back one hundred and eighty. Then Al-Mahdi added one hundred cubits from the northern side only, not the three directions, and no one added anything after him as in (Shadd al-Athwab fi Sadd al-Abwab) by Al-Suyuti (p. 175-167) from his (Al-Hawi lil-Fatawi) (Vol. 2). If you know that, and know the merit of prayer in his mosque, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned in the previous Hadiths, does that include those many additions which are approximately double the Prophetic Mosque? Al-Nawawi answered in the negative, as he said in (Sharh Muslim): (Know that this virtue is specific to his mosque itself, peace and blessings be upon him, which existed in his time, excluding what was added to it afterwards. So the worshiper should be keen on that and be aware of what I mentioned). He added in (Al-Majmu') after mentioning this meaning (8/277): (But if he prays in congregation, advancing to the first row then what follows it is better, so let one be aware of this).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, disagreed with him and stated that the ruling of the addition to his mosque, peace and blessings be upon him, is the ruling of the added-to [original], in strong, solid speech as is his habit, may Allah have mercy on him. He said: (The traditions have come that the ruling of the addition to his mosque is the ruling of the added-to [original]; prayer is multiplied therein by a thousand prayers, just as the Sacred Mosque's addition has the ruling of the added-to [original], so Tawaf is permissible in it, and Tawaf is only in the mosque, not outside it. For this reason, the Companions agreed that they pray in the first row of the addition added by Umar then Uthman, and all Muslims acted upon that. Were it not that its ruling is the ruling of his mosque, that would be a prayer in other than his mosque, and the Companions and all Muslims after them would not maintain turning away from his mosque to other than his mosque and order that. Abu Zaid (Umar bin Shabbah al-Numayri in the book (Akhbar al-Madinah) said: Muhammad bin Yahya told me: One whom I trust told me that Umar added to the mosque from the Qiblah side up to the place of the enclosure (Maqsurah) which is there today. He said: As for what the people of our city do not doubt, it is that Uthman is the one who placed the Qiblah in its place today, then it was not changed after that. Abu Zaid said: Muhammad bin Yahya told us from Muhammad from Uthman (thus, and perhaps: Muhammad bin Uthman) from Mus'ab bin Thabit from Khabbab that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said - while in his prayer place one day -: If we were to add to our mosque. And he pointed with his hand towards the Qiblah. Muhammad bin Yahya told us from Muhammad bin Ismail from Ibn Abi Dhi'b who said: Umar said: If the mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, were extended to Dhu al-Hulayfah, it would be part of it. Muhammad bin Yahya told us from Sa'd bin Sa'id from his brother from his father

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: from Abu Hurairah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (If this mosque were built up to Sana'a, it would be my mosque). Abu Hurairah used to say: By Allah, if this mosque were extended to my house, I would not exceed praying in it. Muhammad told us: Abd al-Aziz bin Imran told us from Fulayh bin Sulaiman from Ibn Amrah who said: Umar added to the mosque on its Shami [northern] side, then said: If we were to increase in it until it reaches the graveyard, it would be the mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Sheikh al-Islam said: (This is what the traditions brought, which is indicated by the speech of the early Imams and their action. For they said: Obligatory prayer behind the Imam is better, and this which they said is what the Sunnah brought. Likewise was the matter during the time of Umar and Uthman, for both of them added to the Qiblah side of the mosque, so his [the Imam's] standing place in the five prayers was in the addition, as well as the place of the first row which is the best place to stand in by Sunnah and consensus. Since it is so, it is impossible that prayer in other than his mosque be better than in his mosque, and that the Caliphs and the first rows were praying in other than his mosque. I have not heard from any of the Muslims differing with this, but I saw some later scholars (it seems he means Al-Nawawi) mentioned that the addition is not from his mosque, and I do not know of anyone from the scholars of the Salaf who mentioned that. He said: We alerted to these matters here because knowledge of them is needed, and most people do not know how the matter was, nor the ruling of Allah and His Messenger in much of that). This is the end of Sheikh al-Islam's words, may Allah have mercy on him, as quoted by Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Hadi in his book (Al-Sarim al-Munki) (pp. 139-140). The elevated Hadith of Abu Hurairah narrated by Umar bin Shabbah has a weak chain, for

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Sa'd bin Sa'id al-Maqburi is lenient in Hadith, and his brother Abdullah is abandoned as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Suyuti cited it in (Al-Jami') and said (1): (Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar narrated it in (Akhbar al-Madinah) from Abu Hurairah, and he did not symbolize anything for it in our copy, nor did the commentator address that. Rather he said: The apparent meaning of the author's words is that he did not see it extracted by any of the famous ones, which is strange, for Al-Daylami extracted it with the mentioned wording, as did Al-Tayalisi). I say: If he means it is in (Musnad Al-Tayalisi) from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, I have checked it and did not find it in his Musnad. And Allah knows best. (And he said: (I am the Seal of the Prophets and my mosque is the seal of the Prophets' mosques). The Hadith is from the narration of Aisha and has a completion, and it was mentioned in full in the discussion on the Sacred Mosque. We quoted there that Musa bin Ubaidah is in it and he is weak. But his Hadith came from other than his path with an authentic chain with the wording: (For I am the last of the Prophets and my mosque is the last of the mosques). Narrated by Muslim and Al-Nasa'i. It has preceded. Also, the completion we referred to has many witnesses previously mentioned there. All this indicates that Musa bin Ubaidah preserved this which he narrated. Perhaps due to what we mentioned, Al-Mundhiri cited it in (Al-Targhib) (2/136) saying: (And Al-Bazzar narrated from Aisha))

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: So he mentioned the Hadith. And he did not weaken it as is his custom. (From its virtues is his saying: (Whoever comes to this mosque of mine, and only comes to it for good he learns or teaches, he is in the station of the Mujahid in the path of Allah. And whoever comes for other than that, he is in the station of a man looking at the goods of another). Extracted by Ibn Majah (1/100-101), Al-Hakim (1/91), and Ahmad (2/418, 526) via Abu Sakhr Humaid bin Sakhr al-Kharrat that Sa'id al-Maqburi informed him that he heard Abu Hurairah saying: He heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say... so he mentioned it. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. But it is on the condition of Muslim alone, for Humaid bin Sakhr - and it is said: Ibn Ziyad - Al-Bukhari did not narrate for him in his (Sahih) but narrated for him in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad). Therefore he said in (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is authentic on the condition of Muslim. And Al-Hafiz's saying then that it is on the condition of the two Sheikhs is a mistake, for Al-Bukhari did not use Humaid bin Sakhr as proof nor extract for him in his (Sahih), but extracted for him in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad), and only Muslim used him as proof). I say: Al-Shawkani also erred where he said (2/132): (And Humaid bin Sakhr is Humaid Al-Tawil the great Imam). For Humaid Al-Tawil is other than this one; he is Humaid bin Abi Humaid Abu Ubaidah Al-Tawil, and he is of a higher layer than this one.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Mundhiri cited the Hadith in (Al-Targhib) (1/62) and said: (Narrated by Ibn Majah and Al-Bayhaqi, and there is no one in its chain who is abandoned or agreed upon as weak). His saying: (this mosque of mine). Al-Shawkani said: (It contains an explicit statement that the reward consequent upon entering is only obtained for one who is in his mosque, peace and blessings be upon him, and it is not correct to append others to it from mosques that are below it in virtue because it is analogy with a difference (Qiyas ma'a al-Fariq). His saying: And whoever enters for other than that... etc. Its apparent meaning is that everything that does not involve teaching or learning types of good is not permissible to do in the mosque. It must be restricted to what excludes prayer, remembrance, I'tikaf, and similar acts reported to be done in the mosque or guidance to do in the mosque). (And his saying: (What is between my house and my pulpit is a garden from the gardens of Paradise). The Hadith was narrated by a group of Companions, therefore Al-Suyuti said in Al-Munawi's transmission: (This is a Mutawatir Hadith). We cite here the Hadiths of those whose chains we have come across: First: Abdullah bin Zaid al-Mazini. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/54), Muslim (4/123), Malik (1/202), Al-Nasa'i (1/113), and Ahmad (4/39, 40) via paths from Abdullah bin Abi Bakr from Abbad ibn Tamim from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then Ahmad narrated it (4/40-41) via Fulayh from Abdullah bin Abi Bakr with it with the wording: (What is between the houses - meaning: his houses - to my pulpit...) and the rest is like it. And he added: (And the pulpit is upon a canal from the canals of Paradise). Fulayh - who is Ibn Sulaiman - although the two Sheikhs used him as proof, there is weakness in his memory, and he was alone in this wording and no one agreed with him on it as you will see. Second: Abu Hurairah: At Al-Bukhari (3/54, 4/79, 11/401) and Ahmad (2/376, 438) via Ubaidullah bin Umar who said: Khubaib bin Abd al-Rahman told me from Hafs bin Asim from him elevated with it. And it contains the addition with the wording: (And my pulpit is upon my Pool). Malik narrated it (1/202) from Khubaib with it except he said: From Abu Hurairah or from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri. Thus with doubt. Likewise Ahmad narrated it (2/465, 533) from Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi from Malik with it. Ibn Abd al-Barr said: (Thus the narrators of (Al-Muwatta) narrated it with doubt except Ma'n bin Isa and Rawh bin Ubadah, for they said in it: From Abu Hurairah and Abu Sa'id together, combining not doubting. And Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi narrated it from Malik and said: From Abu Hurairah alone and did not mention Abu Sa'id).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: This narration of Abd al-Rahman from Abu Hurairah alone was extracted by Al-Bukhari (13/263) from Amr bin Ali: Abd al-Rahman told us with it (1). Ahmad differed with him and said: From Abd al-Rahman from Abu Hurairah or Abu Sa'id as preceded. In summary, the narration from Malik from Khubaib is confused (Mudtarib). The correct [chain] is from Khubaib from Hafs from Abu Hurairah as Ubaidullah bin Umar narrated it. A group followed him, including his brother Abdullah bin Umar al-Umari in Ahmad (2/401), Muhammad bin Ishaq also in Ahmad (2/397, 528), and Shu'bah in Al-Tabarani's (Al-Saghir) (p. 230). However, it seems the Hadith has an origin from the narration of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, which is coming. It has other paths from Abu Hurairah: Among them via Hammad bin Salamah from Suhail bin Abi Salih from his father from him elevated. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. Ahmad extracted it (2/412, 534).
foot_note: 1. (1) And Ahmad also narrated it once from Ibn Mahdi (2/236).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Among them via Abdullah from Abu al-Zinad and from Al-A'raj from him. Its men are trustworthy. Ahmad extracted it also (2/401). Among them via Kathir bin Zaid from Al-Walid bin Rabah from him. Al-Tirmidhi extracted it (2/326 Bulaq edition) and remained silent on it. Its chain is good; its men are trustworthy except Kathir bin Zaid who is truthful (Saduq) with some leniency as Abu Zur'ah said, and in (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, makes mistakes). Among them is the coming one: Third: Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, in Al-Tirmidhi (2/326) via Salamah bin Wardan from Abu Sa'id bin al-Mu'alla from Ali bin Abi Talib and Abu Hurairah together. He said: (Hasan Hadith). It is as he said. Fourth: Jabir bin Abdullah. Extracted by Ahmad (3/389): Suraij told us: Hushaym told us: Ali bin Zaid informed us from Muhammad bin al-Munkadir from him elevated.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a good chain; its men are men of the Two Sheikhs except Ali bin Zaid, who is Ibn Jad'an, and he is good in Hadith in corroborations. Al-Khatib extracted it (3/360) via Muhammad bin Hisham al-Marwazi: Hushaym told us with it. He said: (No one narrated it from Hushaym other than him, it is said). I say: This is refuted by Ahmad's narration via Suraij from him. Regarding the Hadith, it is said in (Al-Majmu') (4/8-9): (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, and Al-Bazzar, and in it is Ali bin Zaid, and there is talk about him, but he has been declared trustworthy). I say: It has two other paths in Al-Khatib: First: Extracted (11/228) via Umar bin Ibrahim bin Al-Qasim bin Bashar Abu Hafs Al-Baghdadi: Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Hafs bin Umar told us by dictation: Muhammad ibn Kathir Al-Kufi told us: Sufyan Al-Thawri told us from Abu al-Zubair from Jabir with it. This is a weak chain. Umar this, Al-Khatib wrote his biography and did not mention criticism or praise. Muhammad bin Hafs bin Umar Abu Abdullah, it appears he is the one in Al-Mizan: (Muhammad bin Hafs Al-Taliqani, resident of Egypt, Abu Abdullah. Al-Daraqutni said: Weak).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The rest of the men of the chain are trustworthy. The other path: Narrated (11/390) via Muhammad bin Yunus Al-Kudaymi: Abdullah bin Yunus bin Ubaid told us: My father told me from Muhammad bin al-Munkadir from Jabir. This Al-Kudaymi is one of the abandoned narrators as Al-Dhahabi said. Then I realized and said: This is not a third path, but rather a follow-up to Ali bin Zaid from Muhammad bin al-Munkadir, which is the first path. Fifth: Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas. Extracted by Al-Khatib (11/290) via Ishaq bin Muhammad Al-Farawi who said: Ubaidah bin Na'il told us from Aisha bint Sa'd from her father. This is a good chain; its men are all authenticated. Al-Haythami said (4/9): (Narrated by Al-Bazzar and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and its men are trustworthy). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) (4/79): (Its men are trustworthy). Sixth: Abdullah bin Umar. Extracted by Al-Khatib also (12/160) via Abu Al-Fadl Al-Abbas bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Tamim Al-Anmati: Musa bin Ishaq Al-Qadi Al-Ansari told us: Ahmad ibn Yahya bin Al-Mundhir bin Abd al-Rahman told us: Malik bin Anas told us from Nafi' from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is an unknown chain to me; I did not know anyone in it other than Malik bin Anas and Nafi'. But Al-Haythami said: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Awsat) and its men are trustworthy). It was narrated from Ibn Umar from Abu Sa'id, which is: Seventh: Abu Sa'id al-Khudri. Extracted by Al-Khatib (4/403) via Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Jahwar: Affan told us: Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad told us: Ishaq bin Sharqi Mawla Ibn Umar told us, he said: Abu Bakr bin Abd al-Rahman told me from Ibn Umar, he said: Abu Sa'id al-Khudri told me elevated with it. He mentioned it in the biography of this Ibn Jahwar and did not mention criticism or authentication. Ishaq bin Sharqi, I did not find a biography for him. But Al-Haythami said: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and it is a good Hadith, Allah willing). I say: Ahmad extracted it (3/4): Rawh told us: Malik bin Anas told us from Khubaib ibn Abd al-Rahman that Hafs bin Asim informed him from Abu Hurairah and Abu Sa'id elevated with it. This is a chain whose men are men of the Two Sheikhs, but there is difference in it regarding Malik as previously explained, and the correct view is from Abu Hurairah alone (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Then I found the Hadith in (Al-Musnad) (3/64) from the first path. He said: Abd al-Wahid bin Ziyad told us: Ishaq bin Sharqi Mawla Abdullah bin Umar told us from Abdullah bin Umar who said: Abu Sa'id al-Khudri told me elevated with the wording: (What is between my grave and my pulpit).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In the chapter from Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, Al-Zubair bin Al-Awwam, and Anas bin Malik. See their extraction if you wish in (Majma' Al-Zawa'id). Know that it occurred in the narration of Ibn Asakir for the Hadith of Al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah with the wording: (my grave) instead of: (my house). Al-Hafiz said: (It is a mistake). Likewise, it occurred in some previously mentioned narrations in Al-Khatib and others with the wording: (my grave). We do not doubt that it is a narration by meaning, as Al-Qurtubi (1) and others held. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah clarified the reason for that in (Al-Qa'idah Al-Jalilah) (p. 58): (He, peace and blessings be upon him, when he said this statement, had not been buried yet, may Allah's blessings and peace be upon him. Therefore, none of the Companions used it as evidence when they disputed about his burial place. If this were with them, it would have been a text in the place of dispute. But he was buried in Aisha's room in the place where he died - may my father and mother be his ransom - Allah's blessings and peace be upon him). Then know that (The intended meaning of naming that place a garden is that that spot will be transferred to Paradise, so it will be a garden from its gardens. Or that it is metaphorical because worship in it leads to
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Qurtubi said: (The correct narration: (my house), and (my grave) is narrated, and it seems it is by meaning because he was buried in his dwelling house). Mentioned in (Al-Fath) (3/54).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the worshiper entering the Garden of Paradise. This is open to question as that is not specific to that spot, and the report is driven to show extra honor of that spot over others. It was said: It contains a simile with the particle omitted, i.e., it is like a garden because those who sit in it of angels and believing humans and jinn increase in remembrance and other types of worship). Thus in (Al-Fath) (11/401-402). Is the intended meaning by 'the house' all the houses that belonged to his wives, peace be upon them, or is the intended meaning one house among them, which is Aisha's house where his grave came to be? The apparent is the second. This is indicated by the fact that the Salaf who narrated the Hadith with the wording: (my grave) instead of (my house) understood it as referring to the house in which is his grave, as previously mentioned. Al-Hafiz inclined to this in (Al-Fath) where he said after ruling the mistake of Ibn Asakir's narration mentioned previously: (Yes, it occurred in the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas in Al-Bazzar with a chain whose men are trustworthy, and in Al-Tabarani from the Hadith of Ibn Umar with the wording: The Grave. Based on this, the intended meaning by 'the house' in his saying: 'my house' is one of his houses, not all of them, which is Aisha's house where his grave came to be. The Hadith was reported with the wording: What is between the pulpit and Aisha's house is a garden from the gardens of Paradise. Extracted by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat). I say: It is from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, and Al-Haythami declared it good as preceded. And Allah Almighty knows best. (It is the Mosque that was founded on piety like the Mosque of Quba. Abu Sa'id al-Khudri said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (I said: O Messenger of Allah, which of the two mosques is the one founded on piety? He took a handful of pebbles and struck the ground with it and said: (It is this mosque of yours [Medina], [and in that one is much good]). The Hadith has paths from him: 1 - From Yahya bin Sa'id from Humaid al-Kharrat who said: I heard Abu Salamah bin Abd al-Rahman say: Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Sa'id al-Khudri passed by me, so I said to him: How did you hear your father speak about the Mosque founded on piety? He said: My father said: I entered upon the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in the house of one of his wives, so I said... The Hadith. Extracted by Ahmad (3/24) and Muslim (4/126) from him. Al-Nasa'i (1/113), Al-Tirmidhi (2/185 Bulaq edition), and Ahmad (3/8, 89) extracted it from Laith bin Sa'd from Imran bin Abi Anas from Ibn Abi Sa'id al-Khudri that he said: Two men disputed about the Mosque founded on piety from the first day. One man said: It is the Mosque of Quba. The other said: It is the Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (It is this mosque of mine). Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). Al-Hakim narrated it (2/334) via Usamah bin Zaid from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Sa'id from his father that he said: The Mosque founded on piety is the Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Usamah narrated it stopped [Mawquf] like this, and he is weak in his memory. 2 - From Anis bin Abi Yahya from his father from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri similar to the Hadith of Al-Laith, and it contains the addition between the parentheses. Extracted by Al-Tirmidhi (2/144-145), Al-Hakim (1/487), and Ahmad (3/23, 91). Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of Muslim). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is not as they said; rather it is only authentic (Sahih), not on the condition of Muslim, for he did not extract for Anis bin Abi Yahya nor for his father anything, and they are trustworthy. His brother Muhammad bin Abi Yahya followed him from his father. Al-Hakim extracted it (2/334) and authenticated it. Al-Dhahabi said: (Its chain is good). The Hadith has a witness from the narration of Sahl bin Sa'd who said: Two men differed during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the Mosque founded on piety. One of them said: It is the Messenger's Mosque. The other said: It is the Mosque of Quba. So they came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and asked him. He said: (It is this mosque of mine). Extracted by Ahmad (5/331): Waki' told us: Rabi'ah bin Uthman al-Taymi told us from Imran bin Abi Anas from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim. Ibn Hibban narrated it in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib) (2/137). Abdullah bin Amir al-Aslami followed him from Imran with it. Extracted by Ahmad (5/335). This Abdullah is weak as in (Al-Majmu') (4/10) and (Al-Taqrib). He was confused in it; sometimes he makes it from the Musnad of Sahl bin Sa'd as in this narration, and sometimes he makes it from the Musnad of Ubayy bin Ka'b as Ahmad (5/116) and Al-Hakim (2/334) narrated from Abu Nu'aym Al-Fadl bin Dukain: Abdullah bin Amir al-Aslami told us from Imran bin Abi Anas from Sahl bin Sa'd from Ubayy bin Ka'b briefly. It is strange that Al-Hakim said about it: (This is an authentic chain), and stranger is Al-Dhahabi's agreement with him on authentication even though he wrote a biography for Abdullah bin Amir with weakness that has no authentication. Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (This is a text that it is the Mosque founded on piety mentioned in the Quran, and a refutation of what some commentators say that it is the Mosque of Quba.
