As for his taking, peace and blessings be upon him, the pebbles and striking the ground, the intent is exaggeration in clarification to show that it is the Mosque of Medina).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: The apparent meaning of the verse which Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, referred to, which is His saying in Surat At-Tawbah: {A mosque founded on righteousness from the first day is more worthy for you to stand in. Within it are men who love to purify themselves; and Allah loves those who purify themselves} [At-Tawbah / 108], implies that the intended mosque is the Mosque of Quba, because there are two pronouns in the verse referring to a single antecedent without dispute. The pronoun of the adverb which requires the purified men is the Mosque of Quba, so it is the one founded on piety. The evidence for this is the reason for the revelation of the verse. It is what Ahmad extracted (3/422) via Abu Owais: Shurahbil told us from Uwaym bin Sa'idah al-Ansari that he told him: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, came to them in the Mosque of Quba and said: (Indeed Allah Blessed and Exalted has praised you well regarding purification in the story of your mosque, so what is this purification that you purify yourselves with?) They said: By Allah, O Messenger of Allah, we do not know anything except that we had Jewish neighbors who used to wash their posteriors from excrement, so we washed as they washed. This is a good chain. Ibn Khuzaimah narrated it in his (Sahih) as in (Tafsir Ibn Kathir) (2/389). It has a witness with a good chain also as in (Nasb al-Rayah) (1/219) from the Hadith of Abu Ayyub al-Ansari, Jabir bin Abdullah, and Anas bin Malik. Extracted by Ibn Majah (1/146) and Al-Hakim (2/334-335) who said: (Authentic chain) and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In the chapter from Abu Hurairah, Ibn Abbas, Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Salam, and others. We have previously mentioned, Allah willing, their hadiths at the beginning of the book. Al-Hafiz claimed in (Al-Fath) (7/195) that the Hadith of Abu Hurairah referred to has an authentic chain in Abu Dawood. That is not correct, for it is with him (1/8) like others via Yunus bin Al-Harith, who is weak as Al-Hafiz himself said in (Al-Taqrib), and likewise Ibn Kathir said. Ibn Al-Arabi also erred in his (Tafsir) (1/415) where he said: (This hadith is not authentic). For it is authentic by the sum of its paths, even if he referred to the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, he should have gathered with it its witnesses which we mentioned some of and referred to others; then he would not be permitted to say what he said. If you know what preceded, that the apparent meaning of the verse and the reason for revelation imply it is the Mosque of Quba, and that the Hadith contrary to that implies it is the Prophetic Mosque, then reconciliation between them is necessary. Ibn Kathir said: (There is no contradiction between the verse and this, because if the Mosque of Quba was founded on piety from the first day, then the Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, is so by greater reason and priority). It is like the words of his Sheikh Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, for he said in (Tafsir Surat Al-Ikhlas) (p. 172):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (It is established from him, peace and blessings be upon him, in the (Two Sahihs) that he used to come to Quba every Saturday riding and walking. That is because Allah revealed to him: {A mosque founded on righteousness from the first day is more worthy for you to stand in}. And his mosque was more worthy of this description. It is established in (Al-Sahih) that he was asked about the Mosque founded on piety, so he said: (It is this mosque of mine), meaning that it is more perfect in this description than the Mosque of Quba. And the Mosque of Quba was also founded on piety and because of it (thus) [was] the verse. Therefore He said: {Within it are men who love to purify themselves; and Allah loves those who purify themselves}. The people of Quba used to clean themselves with water along with Wudu and Ghusl, and they learned that from their Jewish neighbors, and the Arabs did not do that. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, wanted no one to think that the one founded on piety was other than his mosque, so he mentioned his mosque is more worthy to be the one founded on piety. So His saying: {A mosque founded on righteousness} [At-Tawbah / 108] encompasses his mosque and the Mosque of Quba and encompasses every mosque founded on piety, unlike the mosques of harm (Dirar)). Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar adopted this reconciliation and reported similar from Al-Dawudi, Al-Suhaili, and others. It is the truth that must be resorted to, because the contrary necessitates either rejecting what the Quran implies for the sake of the Hadith or vice versa, and both matters are error, nay misguidance. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Indeed I have been given the Quran and its like with it). What indicates that it is the Mosque of Quba in addition to what preceded will come: (c): Then Al-Aqsa Mosque. Allah Almighty said: {Exalted is He who took His Servant by night...} the verse. And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Come to it and pray in it, for

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: a prayer in it is like a thousand prayers in other than it. It was said: What if one cannot travel to it or come to it? He said: Then let him gift to it oil to be lit in it, for whoever gifts to it is like one who prayed in it). The Hadith is from the narration of Maimunah bint Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with her, the freed slave of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. She said: O Prophet of Allah, give us a verdict regarding Bayt al-Maqdis. He said: (The land of Gathering and Resurrection. Come to it...) etc. Extracted by Ahmad (6/463) and Ibn Majah (1/429-430) via Isa ibn Yunus who said: Thawr told us from Ziyad bin Abi Sawdah from his brother Uthman bin Abi Sawdah from her. This is a good (Hasan) or authentic (Sahih) chain; its men are trustworthy men of Al-Bukhari except Ziyad bin Abi Sawdah and his brother Uthman, and they are trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). Ibn Hibban and others declared them trustworthy, and a group of trustworthy narrators narrated from each of them. Al-Haythami cited it (4/6-7) from Abu Ya'la and said: (Its men are trustworthy). As for Al-Dhahabi, he differed, saying in the biography of Uthman bin Abi Sawdah: (Marwan Al-Tahiri - thus, perhaps the correct is: Al-Tatiri - and Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy. I say: There is something in the soul about using him as proof). And he said in the biography of his brother Ziyad - having cited this Hadith for him -:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (This is a very Munkar [denounced] Hadith. Abd al-Haqq said: This Hadith is not strong. Ibn al-Qattan said: Ziyad and Uthman are among those whose narration should be paused upon). Thus they said, and they did not mention their proof for what they went to, and I did not find a precedent for them in that from the early scholars of Jarh and Ta'dil. You have known from what we cited that they are trustworthy according to Ibn Hibban and others from the early and later scholars like Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar and his Sheikh Al-Haythami and others as will come. The reason for the judgment of Nakarah (denounced nature) asserted by Ibn Hibban and others from the early and later scholars like Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar and his Sheikh Al-Dhahabi did not appear to me. Therefore, I go - after seeking guidance from Allah Almighty - to the view that the Hadith is strong and established, and whoever criticized it has no proof with him. Yes, some narrated it and faulted it. Abu Dawood (1/75) extracted it, and from his path Al-Bayhaqi (2/441) from Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz from Ziyad bin Abi Sawdah from Maimunah, the freed slave of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that she said... The Hadith briefly, and it does not contain that prayer in it is like a thousand - and its wording will come in (Etiquettes of Mosques). Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz dropped Uthman bin Abi Sawdah from the chain, so it became disconnected. But Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz, although a trustworthy Imam, became confused in his old age, so he is not a proof if he contradicts, as in this narration. For Thawr - who is Ibn Yazid Al-Himsi - is trustworthy and firm as in (Al-Taqrib) and in (Al-Khulasah): (One of the firm ones).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He connected it by mentioning Uthman in it, which is an acceptable addition from him even if his opponent were his peer and equal. How so when you have known his condition? And how so when Mu'awiyah bin Salih also differed with him and narrated it connected like the narration of Thawr bin Yazid as Al-Hafiz mentioned in (Al-Isabah). Therefore, Al-Turkumani said in (Al-Jawhar al-Naqi): (I say: The Hadith is not strong, as Abd al-Haqq said in his (Ahkam). Perhaps what led him to that is the difference in its chain, for Abu Dawood extracted it as Al-Bayhaqi mentioned, and Ibn Majah extracted it from the hadith of Thawr bin Yazid from Ziyad bin Abi Sawdah from his brother Uthman bin Abi Sawdah from Maimunah). For this reason, the author of (Al-Kamal) said: (Ziyad narrated from Maimunah and from his brother from her, and it is the correct view). Therefore, he said in (Al-Zawa'id): (Abu Dawood narrated part of it, and the chain of Ibn Majah's path is authentic and its men are trustworthy. It is more correct than Abu Dawood's path because between Ziyad bin Abi Sawdah and Maimunah is Uthman bin Abi Sawdah, as explicitly stated by Ibn Majah in his path, as Salah al-Din mentioned in (Al-Marasil), and he was omitted in Abu Dawood). After writing what preceded, I returned to (Al-Majmu') by Al-Nawawi, and found he also went to strengthening the Hadith, where he said (8/278) in summary: (Ahmad narrated it in his (Musnad) with this wording, and Ibn Majah also narrated it with it with an acceptable (La ba'sa bihi) chain, and Abu Dawood narrated it briefly with a good (Hasan) chain).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Thus he said. But Abu Dawood's chain has disconnection as preceded, so how can it be good? Then Al-Nawawi said: (Scholars agreed on the recommendation of visiting Al-Aqsa Mosque and praying in it and on its merit. Allah Almighty said: {Exalted is He who took His Servant by night from al-Masjid al-Haram to al-Masjid al-Aqsa, whose surroundings We have blessed} [Al-Isra / 1]). Then he mentioned the Hadith of setting out on a journey, and it is coming. This Hadith and the one after it (And he said: (Indeed Solomon son of David, when he built Bayt al-Maqdis, asked Allah Almighty for three characteristics: He asked Allah Almighty for judgment that coincides with His judgment, and he was given it. And he asked Allah Almighty for a kingdom that no one after him would have, and he was given it. And he asked Allah Almighty when he finished building the Mosque that no one comes to it, urged by nothing but prayer in it, except that He takes him out of his sin like the day his mother bore him. [So we hope that Allah Almighty has given him that]). The Hadith was extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/112-113) via Abu Idris Al-Khawlani, and the context is his; Ibn Majah (1/430) via Abu Zur'ah Al-Shaybani Yahya bin Abi Amr; Ahmad (2/176) via Rabi'ah bin Yazid; and Al-Hakim (1/30) via him and Al-Shaybani together - and the addition is theirs - all three from Abdullah bin Fairuz Al-Daylami from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas elevated with it. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on their condition and I do not know any defect in it). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. I say: As for the Hadith being authentic, it is as they said without doubt. As for being on

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: their condition, there is reservation, because Ibn Al-Daylami is not of their men; he is a trustworthy major Tabi'i as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib). He said: (Some counted him among the Companions). The Hadith was also extracted by Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their (Sahihs) as in (Al-Targhib) (2/137-138). Al-Nawawi authenticated it in (Al-Majmu') (8/278) and Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath) (6/316). The Hadith has a witness but it contains a very denounced (Munkar) addition along with severe weakness in its chain. I cite its wording to warn against it, for we have often heard it from some preachers on pulpits. And there is no power nor strength except by Allah. Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Kabir) from Rafi' bin Umair elevated: (Allah said to David: Build for Me a House on earth. So David built a house for himself before building the House he was ordered to. So Allah revealed to him: O David, did you erect your house before My House? He said: O Lord, thus I said in what I judged: (Whoever possesses, appropriates). Then he started building the Mosque. When the wall was complete, two-thirds of it fell. He complained of that to Allah Almighty. Allah Almighty revealed to him: (It is not fitting for you to build a House for Me). He said: O Lord, why? He said: Because of the blood that flowed on your hands. He said: O Lord, was that not for Your sake and love? He said: Yes, but they are My servants and I have mercy on them. That distressed him, so Allah Almighty revealed to him: Do not grieve, for I will decree its building at the hands of your son Solomon. When

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: David died, Solomon took up its building. When it was complete, he offered sacrifices and slaughtered animals and gathered the Children of Israel. Allah Almighty revealed to him: I have seen your joy in building My House, so ask Me and I will give you. He said: I ask You for three characteristics: Judgment that coincides with Your judgment, a kingdom no one after me should have, and whoever comes to this House intending nothing but prayer leaves his sins like the day his mother bore him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (As for two, he was given them, and I hope he was given the third). End quote from (Al-Majmu') (4/7-8) and (Al-Muntakhab) (5/369). Al-Haythami said: (In it is Muhammad bin Ayyub bin Suwayd, and he is accused of fabrication). Then I saw Al-Dhahabi judged the Hadith as fabricated, and he was correct, as he said in the biography of this Ibn Ayyub: (Al-Daraqutni weakened him and Ibn Hibban said: Narrating from him is not lawful. Abu Zur'ah said: I saw him inserting fabricated things into his father's books. I say: From that is the Hadith: When David built the Mosque and it fell, it was said to him: It is not fitting that you undertake its building. He said: Why, O Lord? He said: Because of the blood that flowed on your hands. He said: Was it not for Your sake? He said: Yes, but they are My servants, I have mercy on them... The Hadith at length). I say: Ayyub bin Suwayd, the father of this Muhammad, narrated it from Abu Zur'ah Al-Shaybani with his previous chain from Ibn Umar elevated without this denounced fabricated addition. Ibn Majah extracted it from Ubaidullah bin Al-Jahm Al-Anmati from him. This is evidence

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: that this addition was inserted by Muhammad bin Ayyub - may Allah disgrace him - upon his father. In the chapter from Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were discussing while with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: Which is better: The Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, or the Mosque of Bayt al-Maqdis? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (A prayer in this mosque of mine is better than four prayers in it. And what an excellent place of prayer it is. And soon there will be (in original: will not be) for a man a space like the rope (Shatan) of his horse from the land where he sees Bayt al-Maqdis from it, which is better for him than the whole world - or he said: better than the world and what is in it). Extracted by Al-Hakim (4/509) via Al-Hajjaj bin Al-Hajjaj from Qatadah from Abu Al-Khalil from Abdullah bin Al-Samit from him. He said: (Authentic chain). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Al-Tabarani also extracted it in (Al-Awsat) and its men are men of the Sahih as in (Al-Majmu') (4/7). Al-Mundhiri said (2/138): (Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi with an acceptable (La ba'sa bihi) chain, and in its text is strangeness). Ibn Asakir narrated it via Sa'id bin Bashir from Qatadah from Abdullah bin Al-Samit with it. He omitted Abu Al-Khalil between Qatadah and Ibn Al-Samit, and the correct is to affirm him. His name is Salih bin Abi Maryam, a trustworthy narrator of the Six.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: Perhaps the aspect of strangeness is that it is established in the Hadith of Maimunah previously mentioned that prayer in Al-Aqsa Mosque is worth a thousand prayers, and in the Hadith of Abu Darda - which preceded in the extraction of the first Hadiths of the mosque - that prayer in it is worth five hundred prayers. In this Hadith of Abu Dharr, a prayer in his mosque, peace and blessings be upon him, is better than four prayers in Al-Aqsa Mosque. This does not agree in meaning with the two referred Hadiths, for it implies that the merit of prayer in it is four times the prayer in Al-Aqsa, resulting in prayer in Al-Aqsa Mosque being a quarter of prayer in the Prophetic Mosque, i.e., worth two hundred and fifty prayers. This result does not agree with what is established in the many previous Hadiths that prayer in Al-Aqsa is worth a thousand or five hundred. It is said: Allah Glorified and Exalted made the virtue of prayer in Al-Aqsa two hundred and fifty prayers first, then brought it to five hundred, then to a thousand, as a bounty from Him Exalted upon His servants and a mercy. And Allah Almighty knows best the reality of the matter. (And from the virtue of these three mosques is that it is not permissible to intend travel to a mosque or place among the virtuous places and prayer in them except to them, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Do not set out (and in a narration: Do not set out [plural]) on a journey except (and in a wording: Travel is only undertaken) to three mosques: this mosque of mine, the Sacred Mosque, and Al-Aqsa Mosque). The Hadith was narrated by a group of Companions:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: First: Abu Hurairah, and there are three paths from him: 1 - From Al-Zuhri from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/49), Muslim (4/126), Abu Dawood (1/318), Al-Nasa'i (1/114), Ibn Majah (1/430), Ahmad (2/234, 238, 278), and Al-Khatib (9/222) via paths from him. 2 - From Ibn Wahb: Abd al-Hamid bin Ja'far told me that Imran bin Abi Anas told him that Salman Al-Aghar told him from him. The second wording is his. Extracted by Muslim alone. 3 - From Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah from him. Extracted by Al-Darimi (1/330) and Ahmad (2/501). They said: Yazid bin Harun told us from him. This is a good chain; its men are men of the Six except that Al-Bukhari extracted for Muhammad bin Amr as coupled (Maqrun) and Muslim as a follow-up. Second: Abu Sa'id al-Khudri: And there are four paths from him: 1 - From Quza'ah from him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (4/62-63, 195) and Muslim (4/102). The second narration

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...for him, and Al-Tirmidhi (2/148) who authenticated it, and Ibn Majah (1/430), and Ahmad (3/7, 34, 45, 77, and 78), and Al-Khatib (11/194-195) from paths from him. Al-Bayhaqi also extracted it (2/452). 2 - From Mujalid: Abu Al-Waddak told me from him. Ahmad extracted it (3/53) and its chain is Hasan. 3 - From Abdul Malik bin Umair, he said: I asked Ikrimah, the freed slave of Ziyad, he said: I heard Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri say... so he mentioned it. Ahmad extracted it (3/71). Its men are trustworthy men of the Six [Books] except Ikrimah the freed slave of Ziyad, for I did not know him, and Al-Hafiz did not include him in (Al-Ta'jil) even though he meets his condition. 4 - From Layth from Shahr, he said: We met Abu Sa'id while we intended [to go to] Al-Tur. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: (Do not saddle the mounts except...) The Hadith. Ahmad extracted it (3/93) and its chain is Hasan. Its men are the men of the Six, except that Muslim narrated from Layth - who is Ibn Abi Sulaym - in conjunction with others, and Al-Bukhari narrated from him in a suspended form (Ta'liq). Shahr was not narrated from in his [Bukhari's] Sahih, but rather he narrated from him in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad), and he is truthful but has many Mursal narrations and delusions as in (Al-Taqrib).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: He explicitly stated in this narration his meeting with Abu Sa'id. Furthermore, it agrees with the other preceding narrations, so we are safe thereby from his delusion and his Irsal. Yes, Abdul Hamid narrated it from Shahr, he said: I heard Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri - and prayer at Al-Tur was mentioned in his presence - so he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (It is not fitting for mounts to have their saddles fastened to a mosque where prayer is sought other than Al-Masjid Al-Haram...) The Hadith. Ahmad extracted it (3/64) and Umar bin Shabbah in the book (Akhbar Al-Madinah) as in (Al-Sarim Al-Munki) (241). So Abdul Hamid - who is Ibn Bahram - explicitly mentioned from Shahr the exclusion which was not mentioned in all the narrations of the Hadith, those preceding and those to come, which is his saying: (to a mosque where prayer is sought). He contradicted Layth in that, and both are spoken about [criticized], but Abdul Hamid is in a better state than him, especially in his narration from Shahr. In (Al-Taqrib) [: (He is truthful). If he preserved this addition from Shahr, then Shahr narrated the Hadith according to the meaning he understood from the Hadith, and he is not agreed upon in this meaning. Or it could be that it came from his poor memory, so he brought it unintentionally, not deliberately, which is more likely to me because whoever tracks his Hadiths finds in them many such additions that the trustworthy Hafizs did not narrate. Whichever it is, this addition is not permissible to use as proof due to its contradiction of the narrations of the trustworthy narrators and Shahr's solitary narration of it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And you will know in what follows - if Allah the Exalted wills - the status of this addition in determining and preferring one of the two meanings of the Hadith and the battle that took place between scholars regarding it, so let this be in your memory. The Third: Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas. Ibn Majah extracted it (1/430) from the path of Yazid (and in the original: Yazid, which is a typographical error) Ibn Maryam from Qaza'ah from Abu Sa'id and Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas together, raised [to the Prophet]. Its chain is Sahih; its men are the men of Al-Bukhari except Muhammad bin Shu'ayb, who is Ibn Shabur, and he is trustworthy. The Fourth: Abu Basrah Al-Ghifari, and there are three paths from him: 1 - From Abdul Malik bin Umair from Umar bin Abdul Rahman bin Al-Harith bin Hisham Al-Makhzumi: That Abu Basrah met Abu Huraira while he was coming. He said: From where did you come? He said: I came from Al-Tur, I prayed in it. He said: Beware, if I had caught you, you would not have gone. I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: (Do not saddle the mounts...) The Hadith. Al-Tayalisi (No. 1348 and 2506) and Ahmad (6/7) extracted it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This is a Sahih chain; its men are the men of the two Sheikhs except Umar bin Al-Harith here, who is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). In (Al-Majma') (4/3): (Ahmad and Al-Bazzar narrated it similarly, and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Awsat), and the men of Ahmad are trustworthy and firm. 2 - From Ibn Ishaq, he said: Yazid bin Abi Habib told me from Marthad bin Abdullah Al-Yazani from Abu Basrah Al-Ghifari, he said: I met Abu Huraira... The Hadith. Ahmad extracted it (6/397) and its chain is Hasan. 3 - From Yazid bin Abdullah bin Al-Had from Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Al-Harith Al-Taymi from Abu Salamah bin Abdul Rahman bin Awf from Abu Huraira, he said: I went out to Al-Tur (I say: He mentioned a long Hadith then said:) Then I met Basrah bin Abi Basrah Al-Ghifari. He said: From where did you come? I said: From Al-Tur. He said: If I had caught you before you went out to it, you would not have gone out. I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: (Do not work the mounts except to three mosques...) The Hadith similarly. Malik extracted it (1/131-132), Al-Nasa'i (1/210), Al-Tirmidhi (2/362-363), and Ahmad (6/7) from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). I say: It is on the condition of the two Sheikhs, except that some narrators in it erred in two places:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The First: In the text of the Hadith where he said: (Do not work the mounts), and the correct is: (Do not saddle the mounts/Do not travel). The Other: That he made it from the Musnad of Basrah bin Abi Basrah, and the correct view is that it is the Musnad of his father Abu Basrah as in the first two paths. Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib) and Al-Khazraji in (Al-Khulasah) in the biography of this Basrah: (A Companion, son of a Companion, and what is preserved is that the Hadith belongs to his father Abu Basrah). The Fifth: Abdullah bin Umar. Abu Zaid Umar bin Shabbah Al-Numayri extracted it in the book (Akhbar Al-Madinah), he said: Ibn Abi Al-Wazir told us: Sufyan told us from Amr bin Dinar from Talq from Qaza'ah, he said: I came to Ibn Umar and said: I intend [to go to] Al-Tur. He said: Saddles are only fastened [travel is only undertaken] to three mosques... The Hadith. So leave Al-Tur and do not come to it. Ahmad bin Hanbal narrated it in his (Musnad) as in (Al-Sarim Al-Munki) (p. 241). I say: It is not in (Al-Musnad). I think that this sentence: (Ahmad narrated it in his Musnad) occurred here inadvertently by some scribes or the printer, and its place is after the Hadith which he cited in (Al-Sarim) after this Hadith, which is the Hadith of Abdul Hamid bin Bahram: Shahr bin Hawshab told us, he said: I heard Abu Sa'id... The Hadith. It passed shortly before. He attributed it to Umar bin Shabbah Abu Zaid: Hisham bin Abdul Malik told us: Abdul Hamid told us with it. Then he did not attribute it to Al-Musnad, yet it is in it as preceded. It is unlikely that this would be hidden from Al-Hafiz Ibn

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Abdul Hadi. Therefore, I concluded that the matter was reversed for some. And Allah knows best. Furthermore, this Hadith is Mawquf (stopped at the Companion), and its chain is Sahih. All its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Ibn Abi Al-Wazir, who is Muhammad bin Umar bin Mutarrif Abu Al-Mutarrif Ibn Abi Al-Wazir Al-Basri, and he is trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib). It has come as Marfu' (raised to the Prophet); Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Awsat) with the wording: (Do not saddle the mounts). Al-Haythami said (4/4): (And its men are trustworthy). Then I came across its chain as Marfu'. Al-Azraqi said in (Akhbar Makkah) (p. 304): My grandfather told me, he said: Sufyan told us from Amr bin Dinar from Talq bin Habib from Qaza'ah, he said: I wanted to go out to Al-Tur, so I asked Ibn Umar. Ibn Umar said: Did you not know that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Do not saddle the mounts except to three mosques: Al-Masjid Al-Haram, the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa; and leave Al-Tur and do not come to it). I say: This is a Sahih chain; its men are trustworthy men of the Sahih. The grandfather of Al-Azraqi is named Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Al-Walid Al-Ghassani, and he is trustworthy from the men of Al-Bukhari. The Sixth: Ali bin Abi Talib. Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Saghir) (p. 98) and likewise in (Al-Awsat) from the path of Ibrahim bin Ismail bin Yahya bin Salamah bin Kuhayl Al-Hadrami Al-Kufi from his father

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Ismail from his grandfather Yahya from Salamah bin Kuhayl from Hijiyyah bin Adi from Ali, raised with it. This is a weak chain, sequential with weak narrators: Ibrahim, Ismail, and Yahya. Al-Haythami restricted his weakening to this Ibrahim, which is a shortcoming. The Seventh: Abu Al-Ja'd Al-Damri. Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Awsat) and its men are men of the (Sahih). Al-Bazzar also narrated it. Thus in (Al-Majma'). I say: If this is established, it contains a correction to Al-Bukhari's statement in the biography of Abu Al-Ja'd Al-Damri: (I do not know of any Hadith for him except this Hadith) meaning the Hadith that will come in (Al-Jumu'ah) regarding the intimidation against abandoning the Friday prayer. It is strange that Al-Hafiz in (Al-Isabah) approved Al-Bukhari on this statement of his, even though Al-Khazraji said in the biography of the mentioned person in (Al-Khulasah): (He has four Hadiths). The Eighth: Umar bin Al-Khattab. Al-Bazzar narrated it, and its men are men of the (Sahih), except that Al-Bazzar said: (Hibban bin Hilal erred in it).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: Hibban bin Hilal was trustworthy, firm, and a proof (Hujjah) as Ibn Sa'd said. In (Al-Taqrib): (Trustworthy, firm). So attributing error to him is difficult. And Allah knows best. In summary, the Hadith is Mutawatir (consecutive) or nearly so. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in the third treatise of (Majmu' Al-Rasa'il Al-Kubra) (3/53): (It is a widespread (Mustafid) Hadith; the people of knowledge have agreed on its authenticity and receiving it with acceptance and belief). His saying: (Do not saddle the mounts - La Tushaddu Al-Rihal): Al-Hafiz said: (With a Damma on the first letter in the wording of negation. The intended meaning is the prohibition of traveling to other than them. Al-Tibi said: It is more eloquent than explicit prohibition, as if he said: It is not correct that one intends to visit except these places due to the exclusivity they are distinguished with. Al-Rihal is the plural of Rahl: which is for the camel like the saddle is for the horse. He used 'saddling the mounts' as a metonymy for travel because it is its requisite. Mentioning them came out as the dominant case in riding for travel, otherwise there is no difference between riding mounts, horses, mules, donkeys, and walking regarding the mentioned meaning. His saying in the second wording indicates this: (One only travels)). His saying: (Except to three mosques): Al-Hafiz said: (The exception is emptied (Mufarragh), and the estimation is: Mounts are not saddled to any place; its implication is the prevention of travel to every place other than them because the excluded-from in the emptied exception is estimated by the most general of the general, but

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: it is possible that the intended meaning by the general here is the specific place, which is the mosque, as will come). I say: This is weak, and the correct view is the first, as we will mention. Then he said: (In this Hadith is the virtue of these mosques and their merit over others due to them being the mosques of the Prophets, and because the first is the Qibla of the people and to it is their Hajj, and the second was the Qibla of past nations, and the third was founded on piety. There is a difference of opinion regarding saddling mounts to [places] other than them, such as going to visit the righteous, alive and dead, and to virtuous places intending blessing by them and prayer in them. Sheikh Abu Muhammad Al-Juwayni said: (It is forbidden to saddle mounts to other than them, acting upon the apparent meaning of the Hadith). Judge Husayn indicated his choice of this, and Iyad and a group said it. What indicates this is what the authors of the Sunan narrated of Abu Basrah Al-Ghifari's denunciation of Abu Huraira's exit to Al-Tur, and he said to him: (If I had caught you before you went out, you would not have gone out). He used this Hadith as evidence, which indicates that he sees carrying the Hadith on its generality, and Abu Huraira agreed with him. The correct view according to Imam Al-Haramain and others among the Shafi'is: That it is not forbidden. They answered the Hadith with answers, among them: That the meaning is: Complete virtue is only in saddling mounts to these mosques, contrary to others, for it is permissible. It occurred in a narration by Ahmad which will be mentioned with the wording: (It is not fitting for the mounts to work), which is a wording apparent in other than prohibition [i.e., dislike].

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Among them: That the prohibition is specific to one who vows upon himself to pray in a mosque from the rest of the mosques other than the three, for fulfillment is not obligatory upon him. Ibn Battal said this. Among them: That the intended is the ruling of mosques only, and that mounts are not saddled to a mosque among the mosques to pray in it other than these three. As for intending other than mosques to visit a righteous person, a relative, a companion, seeking knowledge, trade, or recreation, it does not enter into the prohibition. This is supported by what Ahmad narrated from the path of Shahr bin Hawshab, he said: I heard Abu Sa'id, and prayer at Al-Tur was mentioned in his presence, so he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (It is not fitting for the worshiper (1) to saddle his mount to a mosque where prayer is sought other than Al-Masjid Al-Haram, Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa, and my Mosque). And Shahr is good (Hasan) in Hadith, even if there is some weakness in him). I say: Al-Hafiz, may Allah have mercy on him, softened his speech here regarding Shahr and deemed his Hadith Hasan with this wording, even though he judged him to be frequent in delusions as previously quoted from him. So how can the Hadith of someone like that be Hasan? Especially if he was alone in it excluding everyone who narrated the Hadith. For it was reported from three other paths from Abu Sa'id, and they do not contain this addition which Al-Hafiz used as proof, which is: (to a mosque). Added to that, the Hadith was reported from seven Companions other than Abu Sa'id from many paths via trustworthy narrators, and none of them said what Shahr said. Is there, after this, proof and evidence for Shahr's error in this addition?
foot_note: 1. (1) Thus in the original, and perhaps it is a misspelling from some narrators, and the correct is: (It is not fitting for the mounts to imply saddling) as in (Al-Musnad) and others as preceded.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Moreover, there is disagreement regarding it from Shahr; some mentioned it from him and not others, as previously explained when discussing the Hadith from the fourth path from Abu Sa'id. Because of that, we held the view there that it is not permissible to use this narration as proof. Another argument appeared to me supporting Shahr's error, so I say: What indicates to you the weakness of this addition, rather its invalidity: That in the Hadith of Shahr himself, Abu Sa'id denied him going to Al-Tur and argued against him with this Hadith. If it contained this addition which restricts its meaning to mosques excluding other virtuous places, it would not have been permissible for Abu Sa'id - and he is the pure Arab - to argue with it, because Shahr only intended to go to Al-Tur, and it is not a mosque, but rather a holy mountain upon which Allah The Exalted spoke to Musa, peace be upon him. So the Hadith would not include it if the addition were in it. So his denial of going to it is the biggest proof of the invalidity of attributing it to his Hadith, and also proof that the Hadith is upon its generality and that it includes virtuous places, because that is what Abu Sa'id understood. Likewise, Abdullah bin Umar and Abu Basrah Al-Ghifari understood from it, and Abu Huraira agreed with him. All of them denied going to Al-Tur, arguing with the Hadith as preceded in the extraction of their Hadiths. So these are four of the Companions - with no opponent from among them - who understood that, and they are more knowledgeable of what they heard from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and more aware of what he says. Then, reasoning dictates the correctness of the Hadith's generality, because if travel was prevented to a mosque other than the three mosques, with the knowledge that worship in all mosques is better than in non-mosques and houses, and he, peace be upon him, said: (The most beloved of spots

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: to Allah are the mosques) as passed, and travel was also prevented to Al-Tur which Allah The Exalted named the Holy Valley, then prevention from travel to other than them is more fitting. Especially if the intended place is graves of Prophets and righteous people, for building mosques on them was forbidden as passed, so how can going to them be permitted when travel to mosques built on piety was not permitted? This - praise be to Allah - is clear and not hidden. As for the other two answers which Al-Hafiz narrated, they are also weak. Here is the explanation: As for the first answer, the Hadith, even if it is with the wording of negation, implies prohibition (Nahy) as Al-Hafiz himself narrated from Al-Tibi. Two things support this: First: That it came explicitly as prohibition in the second narration: (Do not saddle). The other: That it is what the Companions understood, so they forbade going to Al-Tur as preceded. There is a third matter that strengthens this: That the Hadith from the narration of Abu Sa'id in the (Two Sahihs) and others is a piece of a Hadith in which prohibition was mentioned regarding four matters: (A) Saddling mounts (B) Travel of a woman without a Mahram (C) Fasting the days of Fitr and Adha (D) Prayer after Subh and Asr. The prohibition in this is for forbiddenness (Tahrim), so interpreting the prohibition of saddling mounts specifically as discouragement (Tanzih)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: is contrary to the immediate apparent meaning, and it involves combining the literal and the metaphorical, and this is not permissible except with a diverting evidence (Sarif), and there is no diverting evidence here. The narration of Ahmad which Al-Hafiz used as proof with the wording: (It is not fitting for the mounts to work) is not authentic as previously explained repeatedly, so there is no proof in it. Furthermore, even if this narration were authentic, it does not indicate permissibility stripped of dislike; rather, it is a text for dislike. Thus, Al-Nawawi's statement in the explanation of the Hadith from Abu Sa'id's narration: (The correct view according to our companions is that it is neither forbidden nor disliked) is incorrect. Al-Nawawi also said in the explanation of the Hadith from Abu Huraira's narration, the text of which is: (Its meaning according to the majority of scholars: There is no virtue in saddling mounts to a mosque other than them). This is an admission from him that travel to other than the three mosques has no virtue in it, so it is not a righteous deed, nor an act of closeness, nor obedience. It is known and witnessed that whoever intends travel to others seeks by that closeness to Allah The Exalted, and this is forbidden by agreement because he worships Allah The Exalted with what He did not make worship. Therefore, scholars mentioned that (if one vows to pray in a mosque or shrine, or perform I'tikaf in it, or travel to it, other than these three, this is not obligatory upon him by the agreement of the Imams. Contrary to if he vows to come to Al-Masjid Al-Haram for Hajj or Umrah, that is obligatory by the agreement of scholars. If he vows to come to the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, or Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa for prayer or I'tikaf, fulfilling this vow is obligatory upon him according to Malik, Al-Shafi'i, and Ahmad

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: and it is not obligatory according to Abu Hanifa because according to him, nothing becomes obligatory by a vow unless its genus is obligatory in the Sharia. As for the majority, they obligate the fulfillment of every act of obedience due to what Al-Bukhari and others narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, raised [to the Prophet]: (Whoever vows to obey Allah, let him obey Him, and whoever vows to disobey Allah, let him not disobey Him). Traveling to the two mosques is obedience, so fulfilling it is obligatory. As for traveling to a spot other than the three mosques, no scholar has obligated traveling to it if one vows it. Scholars even stated that one does not travel to the Quba Mosque because it is not one of the three, even though visiting it is recommended for one who is in Medina because that is not saddling a mount [travel], as will come. They said: Because traveling to visit the graves of Prophets and righteous people is an innovation not done by any of the Companions and Tabi'in, nor did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, command it, nor did any of the Imams of the Muslims recommend it. So whoever believes that is worship and does it, he is opposing the Sunnah and the consensus of the Imams. This is among what Abu Abdullah bin Batta mentioned in his (Al-Ibanah Al-Sughra) regarding innovations contrary to the Sunnah and Consensus) (1). It remains for us to answer the second answer cited by Al-Hafiz. We say: It is a specification of the Hadith without any specifier, and the Hadith is more general than that. Anyone can claim specification of any general text from the Book or Sunnah, but that is not accepted from him unless accompanied by proof and evidence. So where is the proof here for this claim?
foot_note: 1. (1) I quoted it from (Al-Fatawa) by Sheikh Al-Islam (1/119-120).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Therefore, the investigator Al-San'ani said in (Subul Al-Salam) (2/251): (The majority went to the view that it is not forbidden, and they argued with what does not stand up [to scrutiny], and interpreted the Hadiths of the chapter with far-fetched interpretations. This is not appropriate unless evidence stands against what they interpreted). Abu Al-Tayyib Siddiq Hasan Khan added in (Fath Al-Allam) (1/310): (And there is no evidence. The Hadiths reported regarding the encouragement of the Prophetic Visit and its virtue do not contain the command to saddle mounts to it, alongside the fact that they are all weak or fabricated, none of which are suitable for evidence. Most people did not notice the difference between the issue of visiting and the issue of traveling for it, so they diverted the Hadith of the chapter from its clear logic without evidence calling for it). I say: Visiting the grave of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, does not need evidence from the weak Hadiths referred to. In the chapter, there is what suffices instead of them. Even if there were nothing in the chapter except the general Hadiths on visiting graves, it would suffice to establish the visiting of his grave, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and that is a fortiori as is not hidden. Perhaps clarification and explanation of that will come in the appropriate place. The Summary: What Abu Muhammad Al-Juwayni and those who agreed with him went to regarding the prohibition of traveling to virtuous places other than the three mosques is the truth which must be resorted to. Contrary to travel for trade, seeking knowledge, and the like, for travel is to seek that need wherever it is. Likewise, travel to visit a brother in Allah, for he is the intended one wherever he is.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: As Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Fatawa) (2/186). Great trials occurred to him, may Allah have mercy on him, because of his fatwa prohibiting saddling mounts to visit the graves of Prophets and righteous people, even the grave of our Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. His books are overflowing with evidence for what he held. Imam Al-Subki - who was his contemporary - refuted him and authored for that his book named: (Shifa' Al-Siqam fi Ziyarat Khair Al-Anam), in which he cited the Hadiths reported regarding visiting his grave, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and the sayings of scholars regarding its legislation. He committed a grave error in it where he attributed to Sheikh Al-Islam the view of denying the Prophetic Visit absolutely - meaning without saddling a mount - even though he is among those who advocate it and mention its virtue and manners. He mentioned that in more than one of his books. Therefore, the Hafiz Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Abdul Hadi undertook the refutation of Al-Subki in a large work of his which he named: (Al-Sarim Al-Munki fi Al-Radd 'ala Al-Subki). It is a valuable book containing many jurisprudential, Hadith, and historical benefits. He clarified in it extensively and in detail the status of the referenced Hadiths and what they contain of weakness and fabrication, and absolved Ibn Taymiyyah from what was attributed to him of denial by what he quoted from him of many texts. So whoever wishes, let him refer to it. It is strange that such erroneous attribution to Ibn Taymiyyah circulated among many scholars and sheikhs who came after him. The last of them - if Allah the Exalted wills - was Sheikh Yusuf Al-Nabhani, for he blackened many pages attacking Ibn Taymiyyah with ignorance

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: and misguidance. So one of the virtuous scholars stood up and refuted him in a huge book named: (Ghayat Al-Amani fi Al-Radd 'ala Al-Nabhani). He exposed in it Al-Nabhani's ignorance and misguidance and supported Ibn Taymiyyah with truth and justice. So whoever wishes to stand on the truth, let him return to it and place all his reliance on it. This, and there is no harm in quoting to you what Waliullah Al-Dahlawi mentioned regarding the issue of saddling the mount because it is not devoid of new benefit. He said, may Allah have mercy on him, in (Hujjat Allah Al-Balighah) (1/192): (The people of Jahiliyya used to intend places glorified according to their claims, visiting them and seeking blessings by them. This contains distortion and corruption that is not hidden. So he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, blocked the corruption so that non-rituals are not appended to rituals and so it does not become a means to worshiping other than Allah. The truth to me is that the grave, the place of worship of a Wali (saint) among the Awliya, and Al-Tur, all of that is equal in prohibition). (D): Then Masjid Quba, and it is the intended by His saying, The Exalted: {A mosque founded on righteousness from the first day is more worthy for you to stand in. Within it are men who love to purify themselves; and Allah loves those who purify themselves} [At-Tawbah / 108]. For when it was revealed (He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came to them in Masjid Quba and said: Indeed Allah, Blessed and Exalted, has praised you well regarding purity in the story of your mosque. So what is this purity which you purify yourselves with? They said: By Allah, O Messenger of Allah, we know nothing except that we had neighbors from the Jews, and they used to wash their posteriors from feces, so we washed as they washed. [He said: That is it, so adhere to it]). The Hadith is from the narration of Uwaym bin Sa'idah, and Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari and Jabir narrated it similarly...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and Anas, and what is between the brackets is from their Hadith. The chain of both Hadiths is Hasan. Their extraction preceded in the discussion on the Prophetic Mosque and that it was founded on piety as well, as came from him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. We mentioned there the way of reconciling his Hadith, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding that and this noble verse, so there is no need to repeat. It [the verse], along with the Hadith mentioned after it, is an explicit text that the mosque mentioned in it is Masjid Quba. So the saying that it is the Mosque of Medina is an error. What indicates that it is the mosque founded on piety is what is in Al-Bukhari (7/195) in the Hadith of the migration of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and his companions to Medina: (So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, stayed in Banu Amr bin Auf for ten-odd nights and founded the mosque which was founded on piety, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed in it). Al-Hafiz said: (Meaning Masjid Quba. In the narration of Abdul Razzaq from Ma'mar from Ibn Shihab from Urwah, he said: Those among whom the mosque founded on piety was built are Banu Amr bin Auf. Likewise in the Hadith of Ibn Abbas with Ibn 'Aidh, and its wording is: (And he stayed in Banu Amr bin Auf for three nights and took its place as a mosque, so he used to pray in it. Then Banu Amr bin Auf built it; it is the one founded on piety). These reports indicate that it was known among them that it is the mosque founded on piety). Then Al-Hafiz said: (Yunus bin Bukayr narrated in Ziyadat Al-Maghazi from Al-Mas'udi from Al-Hakam bin Utaybah, he said: (When the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, arrived and stayed at Quba, Ammar bin Yasir said: The Messenger of Allah cannot do...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...without making a place for himself to shade under when he wakes up and to pray in. So he gathered stones and built Masjid Quba. It is the first mosque built - meaning in Medina -). In reality, it is the first mosque in which the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed with his companions in congregation openly, and the first mosque built for the general community of Muslims, even if the building of other mosques preceded it, but [this priority is] regarding the one who built it, as preceded in the Hadith of Aisha regarding Abu Bakr building his mosque). A Hadith came regarding the story of his building, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, of Masjid Quba which contains strangeness. Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) from Al-Shamus bint Al-Nu'man, she said: (I looked at the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he arrived and dismounted and founded this mosque, Masjid Quba. I saw him taking the stone or rock until the stone bent (leaned) him, and I look at the whiteness of the dust on his stomach or navel. A man from his companions comes and says: May my father and mother be your ransom, O Messenger of Allah, give me your palms [let me carry it]. He says: No, take another like it. Until he founded it and said: Indeed Gabriel, peace be upon him, is leading [setting the direction towards] the Kaaba. He said: So it used to be said: It is the most accurately oriented mosque in Qibla). Al-Haythami said (4/11): (And its men are trustworthy). I do not believe it is authentic, for it is from the path of Asim bin Suwayd from Ubaid bin Wadi'ah from her. Ibn Abi Asim and Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar narrated it from two paths from Asim, briefly and at length. Likewise, Al-Hasan bin Sufyan and Ibn Mandah extracted it from the path of Salamah bin Asim Ibn Suwayd. But he differed regarding Asim's Sheikh, so he said: From his father from Al-Shamus with it...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...at length. Al-Hafiz cited its wording in (Al-Isabah) (4/343). For this Asim is Ibn Suwayd bin Yazid bin Jariyah Al-Ansari, the Imam of Masjid Quba. Ibn Ma'in said: (I do not know him). Ibn Adi said: (Very rare in narration). Al-Dhahabi said: (He cited an objectionable (Munkar) Hadith for him, and Abu Hatim said: He narrated two objectionable Hadiths). In (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable). As for his father Suwayd according to the last narration, I did not find a biography for him. Likewise Ubaid Ibn Wadi'ah or Utbah as it appeared in (Al-Isabah) in two places: Ubaid, and in another: Utbah, for I did not know him. And Allah knows best. (And for prayer in it there is a great reward, for he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Whoever goes out until he comes to this mosque - meaning Masjid Quba (and in a wording: Whoever purifies himself in his house then comes to Masjid Quba) and prays in it, it will be like the equivalent of an Umrah (and in the other wording: He will have like the reward of an Umrah)). The Hadith is from the narration of Muhammad bin Sulayman Al-Kirmani, he said: I heard Abu Umamah bin Sahl bin Hunaif say: My father said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... so he mentioned it. Al-Nasa'i (1/113-114), Al-Hakim (2/12), and Ahmad (3/487) extracted it from the path of Majma' bin Ya'qub Al-Ansari from him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Ibn Majah (1/431) extracted it from the path of Hatim bin Ismail and Isa bin Yunus, they said: Muhammad bin Sulayman Al-Kirmani told us with it with the other wording. Ahmad also extracted it from Hatim. Then Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Isnad). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said, for its men in Ibn Majah and Ahmad are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Muhammad bin Sulayman Al-Kirmani. Although they only quoted his authentication from Ibn Hibban, a group of trustworthy narrators narrated from him as you see. Furthermore, it appears he was not alone in it. Al-Mundhiri said (2/139): (Al-Bayhaqi narrated it and said: Yusuf bin Tahman narrated it from Abu Umamah bin Sahl from his father from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with its meaning and added: (And whoever goes out in a state of purity intending nothing but this mosque of mine - meaning the Mosque of Medina - to pray in it, it will be of the status of a Hajj). Al-Mundhiri said: (Yusuf bin Tahman was alone in this addition, and he is flimsy (Wah). And Allah knows best). I say: Likewise, Al-Dhahabi said regarding Yusuf bin Tahman that he is flimsy, then he cited this Hadith of his from the path of Zaid bin Al-Hubab from Musa bin Ubaidah: Yusuf bin Tahman, a freed slave of the family of Mu'awiyah, told me from Abu Umamah with it raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: Whoever performs ablution in his house then comes to Masjid Quba and prays four Rak'ahs in it, it is like the equivalent of an Umrah. It is narrated similarly with a good (Salih) chain) referring to the narration of Muhammad bin Sulayman Al-Kirmani. Al-Haythami cited it in (Al-Majma') (4/11) with the last wording except that he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Like the equivalent of [freeing] a slave) instead of: (Umrah). Then Al-Haythami said: (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) and it contains Musa bin Ubaidah, and he is weak). I say: It appears he is among those who narrated it from the path of Ibn Tahman as Al-Dhahabi mentioned, but neither he nor Al-Haythami mentioned that addition which Al-Mundhiri cited from Al-Bayhaqi, so perhaps it is a narration from Ibn Tahman. And Allah knows best. Moreover, the Hadith has a witness from the Hadith of Usaid bin Zuhair Al-Ansari raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Prayer in Masjid Quba is like an Umrah). Al-Tirmidhi (2/145-146), Ibn Majah, and Al-Hakim (1/487) extracted it from the path of Abdul Hamid bin Ja'far, he said: Abu Al-Abrad, the freed slave of Banu Khatmah, told us from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Gharib Hadith, and we do not know anything authentic for Usaid bin Zuhair other than this Hadith). Al-Hakim said: (Sahih Isnad except that Abu Al-Abrad is unknown). Al-Dhahabi said likewise. He said in (Al-Mizan): (No one narrated from him except Abdul Hamid bin Ja'far). In (Al-Taqrib) he is: (Acceptable). His name is disputed; it was said: Ziyad, and it was said: Musa bin Sulaym. And Allah knows best. It has another witness from the Hadith of Ka'b bin Ujrah. Al-Haythami said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Kabir) and it contains Yazid bin Abdul Malik Al-Nawfali, and he is weak). Then Al-Hakim extracted (2/12) from the path of Hashim bin Hashim, he said: I heard Amir bin Sa'd and Aisha bint Sa'd saying: We heard Sa'd say: For me to pray in Masjid Quba is more beloved to me than to pray in the Mosque of Bayt Al-Maqdis (Jerusalem). He said: (Sahih on the condition of the two Sheikhs). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and Al-Mundhiri affirmed it (2/139). It is as they said. Al-Hafiz cited it in (Al-Fath) (3/53) with the addition: (Two Rak'ahs) after Quba, and at its end: (Twice. If they knew what is in Quba, they would beat the livers of camels [travel fast] to it). He said: (Umar bin Shabbah narrated it in (Akhbar Al-Madinah) with a Sahih chain). I say: It is a Mawquf Hadith. If it were Marfu', it would indicate the preference of Masjid Quba over Bayt Al-Maqdis. Al-Hafiz said that: (Multiplication [of reward] in prayer in it is not established, unlike the three mosques). I say: Because of that, we made it the fourth of the four mosques. Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Majmu' Al-Rasa'il Al-Kubra) (2/54): (Al-Masjid Al-Haram is the best of mosques, followed by the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, followed by Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa). He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (And what the majority of scholars are upon is that prayer in Al-Masjid Al-Haram is better than in the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. (Therefore (he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to come to Quba [every Saturday] riding and walking [and pray two Rak'ahs in it]). The Hadith is from the narration of Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are three paths from him: 1 - From Nafi' from him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (3/53), Muslim (4/127), Malik (1/181), Abu Dawood (1/319), Al-Tayalisi (p. 252 No. 1839), and Ahmad (2/4, 57, 58, 65, 101, 155) from paths from him. The second addition is for the two Sheikhs. 2 - From Abdullah bin Dinar from him in the two Sheikhs, Al-Nasa'i (1/113), and Ahmad (2/30, 58, 65, 72, 108) from paths also from him. The first addition is for the two Sheikhs as well. Al-Hakim extracted it (1/487) from this aspect with the wording: (He used to frequent Quba walking and riding). And he said: (Sahih on the condition of the two Sheikhs, and they did not extract it with this wording). 3 - Ibn Ishaq narrated it: Abu Ishaq bin Yasar told me from Abdullah bin Qais bin Makhramah, he said: I came from the Mosque of Banu Amr bin Auf in Quba on a mule of mine, having prayed in it, when I met Abdullah bin Umar walking. When I saw him, I got off my mule then...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I said: Ride, O uncle. He said: O nephew, if I wanted to ride animals I would have found them, but I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, walking to this mosque to pray in it, so I love to walk to it as I saw him walk. He said: So he refused to ride and went on his way). Ahmad extracted it (2/119) and its chain is Hasan. Ibn Hibban narrated in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib) (2/139) from Ibn Umar also that he attended a funeral at Al-Awsat in the house of Sa'd bin Ubadah, then came walking to Banu Amr bin Auf in the courtyard of Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj. It was said to him: Where are you heading, O Abu Abdul Rahman? He said: I am heading to this mosque in Banu Amr bin Auf, for I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: Whoever prays in it, it is like the equivalent of an Umrah). Al-Hafiz said: (In this Hadith - despite its differing paths - is evidence for the permissibility of specifying some days for some good deeds and persisting in that. In it also is that the prohibition of saddling mounts to other than the three mosques is not for prohibition (Tahrim), because the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to come to Masjid Quba riding. This was critiqued [by saying] that his coming, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to Quba was only to maintain ties with the Ansar and inspect their condition and the condition of those of them who were late for attending Jumu'ah with him. This is the secret in specifying that to Saturday). I say: Based on this, his going, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, on Saturday was not intended for itself, but to observe the interest of the mentioned inspection. Thus, all days are equal in...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The virtue in visiting Quba is due to the lack of intention for specification. So what Al-Qari mentioned in (Al-Mirqat) (1/448) from Al-Tibi that: (Visiting on Saturday is a Sunnah) is not as it should be (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) I remember reading from some scholars that they held the view that the meaning of his saying in the Hadith: (Every Saturday) means every week, and that the intent is not Saturday itself. He argued for that linguistically with what I do not recall now, nor do I remember now in which book I read that. Whoever finds it, let him write [it down]. If that is correct, there is no indication in the Hadith for specification at all. Then I came across who mentioned that, which is Imam Abu Shama Al-Shafi'i in his book (Al-Ba'ith 'ala Inkar Al-Bida' wal-Hawadith). He mentioned in it what agrees with what we went to regarding the impermissibility of specification. Here is his entire statement on that. He said, may Allah have mercy on him (p. 34): (It is not appropriate to specify acts of worship to times not specified by the Sharia. Rather, all types of righteousness should be general in all times, with none having preference over another except what the Sharia preferred and specified with a type of worship. If that is the case, that specific worship is distinguished by that virtue over others, like fasting the day of Arafah and Ashura, praying in the depths of the night, and Umrah in Ramadan. And among times is what the Sharia made preferred for all acts of righteousness, like the ten of Dhul-Hijjah and the Night of Decree which is better than a thousand months, meaning deeds in it are better than deeds in a thousand months that do not contain the Night of Decree. Similarly, any act of righteousness performed in it has preference over its counterpart in another time. In summary, the legally responsible person (Mukallaf) does not have the position of specification; rather, that belongs to the Lawgiver. This was the characteristic of the worship of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Then he cited the Hadith of the (Two Sahihs) from Aisha that she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to fast until we would say: He does not break fast, and break fast until we would say: He does not fast. And the Hadith of Alqamah who said: I said to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: Did the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, specify anything of the days? She said: No, his deed was continuous. Then he said: (Muhammad bin Salamah said: No mosque is come to believing there is virtue in it after the three mosques except the Mosque of Quba. He said: And it is disliked to set a specific day for it to be come to, for fear of innovation and that time might prolong

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Similarly, using the Hadith as evidence for the permissibility of the mentioned specification is also not good, unless the intent by specification is observing public interest (Maslahah), not preferring one day over another without a text from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. An example of that is specifying a day for teaching or delivering a lecture so people gather to hear that. There is no objection to this because the day is not intended for itself, therefore it is moved from it to another repeatedly in pursuit of interest. This is unlike specifying some days for some acts of worship claiming they are better in them than in others, like specifying the night of the two Eids for standing [in prayer] and worship, and specifying their day for visiting - meaning visiting graves - and specifying the month of Rabi' al-Awwal for reading the story of the birth of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. All this and its likes are innovations and evils that must be rejected and forbidden. Therefore, when Al-Nawawi used the Hadith in (Sharh Muslim) as evidence for the permissibility of specification, he said: (Ibn Maslamah Al-Maliki disliked that, and perhaps these Hadiths did not reach him). I say: This is far-fetched. More likely, they reached him but he did not understand from them what Al-Nawawi and others went to. We have clarified what is the truth to us regarding the issue. And Allah knows best.
foot_note: 1. = for people, so that is made an Eid to be relied upon or an obligation to be taken. There is no harm in coming to it at any time as long as no innovation occurs in it. I say: It is authentic that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to come to Quba every Saturday. But the meaning of this is that he used to visit it every week, and Saturday was used to express the week just as Friday is used to express it. Its parallel is what is in the (Two Sahihs) from the Hadith of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding the Prophet's seeking rain (Istisqa) on Friday; he said in it: So by Allah, we did not see the sun for a Saturday [week]. And Allah knows best).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Benefit): Sheikh al-Islam said in (Al-Fatawa) (2/186): (Some later scholars mentioned that there is no harm in traveling to shrines (Mashahid) and argued that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to come to Quba every Saturday riding and walking. They have no proof in it because Quba is not a shrine but a mosque, and traveling to it [shrines] is forbidden by agreement of the Imams because that is not a prescribed travel. Rather, if one traveled to Quba from his family's house, it would not be permissible. But if he traveled to the Prophetic Mosque then went from there to Quba, this is recommended, just as visiting the graves of the people of Baqi' and the martyrs of Uhud is recommended). I say: For this reason we said: (But it is not permissible to set out on a journey to it due to the previous Hadith) which is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Do not set out on a journey except to three mosques...) The Hadith. And this is not one of them. Those are the four mosques regarding which the text came favoring them over other mosques. As for these, they are equal in merit, although the older of them is better for being further from having been built for harm, pride, and boasting, as previously indicated. As for what Ibn Abidin quoted in (Al-Hashiyah) (1/14) from the book (Akhbar al-Duwal) with a chain to Sufyan Al-Thawri that: (Prayer in the Mosque of Damascus is worth thirty thousand prayers), even though it is stopped (Mawquf) at Sufyan Al-Thawri, it is not authentic from him and is denounced (Munkar).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ibn Asakir narrated it in his (Tarikh) via Ahmad bin Anas bin Malik: Habib the Mu'adhin informed us: Abu Ziyad Al-Sha'bani or Abu Umayyah Al-Sha'bani informed us, he said: We were in Mecca and there was a man in the shade of the Kaaba, and lo, it was Sufyan Al-Thawri. A man said: O Abu Abdullah, what do you say about prayer in this town? He said: One hundred thousand prayers. He said: And in the Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him? He said: Fifty thousand prayers. He said: And in Bayt al-Maqdis? He said: Forty thousand prayers. He said: And in the Mosque of Damascus? He said: Thirty thousand prayers. Then Ibn Asakir narrated it from another path from Ahmad bin Anas, saying in it: (From Abu Ziyad and Abu Umayyah without doubt). In any case, this is a weak unknown chain: Abu Ziyad Al-Sha'bani, apparently he is Khiyar bin Salamah Abu Ziyad Al-Shami. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable, from the third [layer]). As for his peer Abu Umayyah Al-Sha'bani, he is Yahmad - with Damma on the Ya, Sukun on the Ha, and Kasra on the Meem, and it is said: with Fatha on the first and the Meem - and it is said: his name is Abdullah. Al-Hafiz said: (Acceptable, from the second [layer]). As for Ahmad bin Anas bin Malik and Habib the Mu'adhin, I did not find anyone who wrote their biographies other than this latter one; Ibn Asakir mentioned him and described him saying: (He used to call Adhan in the mosque of Suq al-Ahad) and did not add to that.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Furthermore, Sufyan Al-Thawri, may Allah have mercy on him, is among those who narrated the previously mentioned Hadith of Abu Hurairah No. (6) with the wording: (A prayer in this mosque of mine is better than a thousand prayers in other mosques except the Mosque...). It is unlikely that a statement contradicting what he himself narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, would be authentic from him. So it is overwhelmingly likely that this narration is fabricated against him due to its contradiction of authentic Hadiths. Yes, it was narrated from Anas elevated (Marfu') with the wording: (A man's prayer in his house is one prayer, his prayer in the tribal mosque is twenty-five prayers, his prayer in the mosque where Friday prayer is held is five hundred prayers, his prayer in Al-Aqsa Mosque is fifty thousand prayers, his prayer in my mosque is fifty thousand prayers, and his prayer in the Sacred Mosque is one hundred thousand prayers). Extracted by Ibn Majah (1/431-432) via Abu Al-Khattab Al-Dimashqi: Zuraiq Abu Abdullah Al-Alhani told us from him. He said in (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is weak because Abu Al-Khattab Al-Dimashqi's condition is unknown, and there is talk about Zuraiq. It was narrated from Abu Zur'ah that he said: There is no harm in him. Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat) and in (Al-Du'afa) and said: He is alone in things that do not resemble the Hadith of the established narrators; it is not permissible to use him as proof except when corroborated).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib) that he is: (Truthful, has illusions). I say: This Hadith is one of his illusions if Abu Al-Khattab preserved it from him, otherwise Abu Al-Khattab is unknown as preceded. Al-Hafiz said: (He is unknown). Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Not famous), then cited this Hadith for him, then said: (This is very denounced [Munkar]). And excellent is what he said. Ibn Asakir also extracted the Hadith in the biography of the Mosque of Damascus via paths from Abu Al-Khattab with it. Of this type is what Ibn Asakir also extracted via Hisham bin Ammar: Al-Hasan bin Yahya Al-Khushani informed us: (That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, on the night he was taken on the Night Journey, prayed in the place of the Mosque of Damascus). He said: (This is disconnected [Munqati']). I say: Rather, it is perplexing (Mu'dal), for between the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and this Al-Khushani are deserts [huge gaps]. Al-Hafiz said about him in (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, makes many mistakes, from the second [layer], died after ninety. Meaning: and one hundred).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Dhahabi cited denounced narrations for him in (Al-Mizan), among them what he narrated with his chain from Anas elevated: (No Prophet dies and stays in his grave except forty days until Allah returns his soul to him). Then he said: (I passed by Moses on the night I was taken on the Night Journey while he was standing praying between Aliyah and Uwayliyah). Ibn Hibban narrated it and cited his chain to him and said: (This is false, fabricated). Ibn Al-Jawzi extracted it in (Al-Mawdu'at). Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, was asked about (Two men differed regarding prayer in the Umayyad Mosque: Is it worth ninety prayers as they claimed or not? And they mentioned that three hundred Prophets are buried in it, is that correct or not? And they mentioned that the sleeper in Sham is like the one standing in prayer at night in Iraq, and they mentioned that the voluntary faster in Iraq is like the one breaking fast in Sham, and they mentioned that Allah created blessing in seventy-one parts, one part in Iraq and seventy in Sham, is that correct or not?). He answered: (Praise be to Allah, no Hadith has been reported regarding the Mosque of Damascus from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, about multiplying prayer in it, but it is one of the mosques where Allah Almighty is mentioned most. It is not established that the mentioned number of Prophets are in it. As for the one standing in prayer in Sham or elsewhere, actions are by intentions. If the resident

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: is there with a righteous intention, he is rewarded for that. Every place where the servant is more obedient to Allah, his residence is better. Authentic Hadiths have come regarding the virtue of Sham and its people. The Quran indicated that blessing is in four places. There is no doubt that the manifestation of Islam and its supporters in it by heart, hand, and tongue is stronger than in others, and in it is a manifestation of faith and suppression of disbelief and hypocrisy not found elsewhere. As for what was mentioned of the Hadith of breaking fast and fasting and that blessing is seventy-one parts in Sham and Iraq as mentioned, we have not heard this from any of the people of knowledge. And Allah knows best). (Al-Fatawa) (1/311). I say: Even if it were established that the mentioned Prophets are in it, it does not necessitate the virtue of seeking to pray in it as some people imagine; rather, it is forbidden most strictly because it is taking graves as mosques, and we have been forbidden from that as preceded. Therefore, Sheikh al-Islam also said, may Allah have mercy on him, in (Al-Fatawa) (4/310): (And what some people do of seeking prayer and supplication at what is said to be the grave of a Prophet or the grave of one of the Companions and relatives or what is close to that, or pressing one's body or part of one's body against the grave or against what is adjacent to the grave of wood and the like, like the one who seeks prayer and supplication in the south-east of the Mosque of Damascus at the place said to be the grave of Hud - which scholars agree is the grave of Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan - or at the wooden likeness said to have the head of Yahya bin Zakariya beneath it and similar things, he is mistaken, an innovator, opposing the Sunnah. For prayer and supplication at these places has no merit according to any of the Salaf of the Ummah and its Imams, nor did they used to do that. Rather, they used to forbid the likes of

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: that, just as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade them from the causes of that and its motives, even if they did not intend invoking the grave or invoking by it, so how if they intended that?) Then he said: (As for supplication because the place contains the grave of a Prophet or Wali, none of the Salaf of the Ummah and its Imams said that supplication there is better than elsewhere. But this is among what some people of the Qiblah innovated in imitation of the Christians and other polytheists. So its origin is from the religion of the polytheists, not from the religion of the sincere servants of Allah, like taking graves as mosques. For this was not recommended by any of the Salaf of the Ummah and its Imams, but some people of the Qiblah innovated it in imitation of those whom the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, cursed from the Jews and Christians). This, and since we have finished explaining the best mosques and what relates to them, let us begin by mentioning the general etiquettes and rulings specific to mosques. So I say: (That, and since mosques in general are the most beloved places to Allah Almighty as preceded, the Wise Lawgiver has prescribed for them specific rulings not for other places, and they are of three types: (a) Etiquettes (b) Prohibitions (c) Permissible acts. Here is their explanation in this order:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (a) Etiquettes: They include obligations and recommendations: (1 - Purifying them, sweeping them, and perfuming them with Khaluq [perfume] and others is obligatory, for (he, peace be upon him, ordered building mosques in the houses [quarters] and that they be cleaned and perfumed). The Hadith is from the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. It is authentic and its mention with its witnesses preceded at the beginning of the chapter. Ibn Majah extracted (1/253) via Al-Harith bin Nabhan: Utbah bin Yaqzan told us from Abu Sa'id from Makhul from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' elevated: (Keep your mosques free of your children, your insane, your evil ones, your buying, your disputes, raising your voices, executing your hudud [punishments], and drawing your swords. Establish ablution places at their doors and perfume them on Fridays). He said in (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is weak because Al-Harith bin Nabhan is agreed upon as weak). Therefore Ibn Kathir said (3/293): (And in its chain is weakness). Al-Mundhir indicated that and said: (1/120): (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) from Abu Darda, Abu Umamah, and Wathilah. And narrated in (Al-Kabir) also with advancing and delaying from the narration of Makhul from Mu'adh, and he did not hear from him). I say: In Al-Tabarani's first path is Al-Ala' bin Kathir Al-Laythi Al-Shami, who is weak as in (Al-Majmu') (2/26). Therefore also (Ibn al-Jawzi cited it in (Al-Wahiyat) and said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Not authentic). Ibn Hajar said in (Takhrij Al-Hidayah): (It has paths and chains all of which are flimsy). Abd al-Haqq said: (It has no basis). Thus in (Al-Fayd). Abu Ya'la extracted via Abdullah bin Umar from Nafi' from Ibn Umar that Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, (used to perfume the mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, every Friday).
