Al-Haythami said (2/11): (In it is Abdullah bin Umar Al-Umari: Ahmad and others declared him trustworthy, and using him as proof is disputed). Ibn Kathir said: (Its chain is Hasan, acceptable [La ba'sa bihi]. Allah knows best). I say: Ibn Abi Shaybah also narrated it as in (Al-Muntakhab) (3/261). He said in (Al-Mirqat) (1/459) after mentioning the Hadith of Aisha: (Ibn Hajar said: From it is known that it is recommended to perfume the mosque with incense, contrary to Malik where he disliked it. Abdullah bin Umar used to perfume the mosque when Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, sat on the pulpit. Some of the Salaf recommended saffron and perfume. It was narrated from him, peace and blessings be upon him, that he did it. Al-Sha'bi said: It is a Sunnah. Ibn Abi Shaybah extracted: That Ibn Al-Zubair when he built the Kaaba coated its walls with musk. It is also recommended to sweep

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the mosque and clean it. Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated that he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to trace the dust of the mosque with a palm branch). I say: The Hadith indicates the obligation of purification and perfuming because he ordered them, and the command implies obligation. Ibn Hazm stated this regarding the first of them but not the other, saying (4 and / 239): (Mihrabs are disliked in mosques, sweeping them is obligatory, and it is recommended that they be perfumed). I say: I do not know what led him to divert the command to recommendation regarding perfuming. And Allah knows best. (And he said: (The rewards of my nation were presented to me, even the speck of dust a man removes from the mosque) The Hadith has a completion which is: (And the sins of my nation were presented to me, and I did not see a sin greater than a Surah from the Quran or an Ayah given to a man then he forgot it). Extracted by Abu Dawood (1/76) and Al-Tirmidhi (2/150). They said: Abd al-Wahhab bin Abd al-Hakam Al-Warraq Al-Baghdadi told us: Abd al-Majid bin Abd al-Aziz told us from Ibn Juraij from Al-Muttalib bin Hantab from Anas elevated with it. Al-Tirmidhi said: (A Gharib (strange) Hadith, we do not know it except from this perspective). He said: (I discussed it with Muhammad bin Ismail (meaning: Al-Bukhari), and he did not know it and found it strange.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Muhammad said: I do not know for Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah hearing from anyone of the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, except his saying: One who witnessed the sermon of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, told me. He said: And I heard Abdullah bin Abd al-Rahman say: We do not know for Al-Muttalib hearing from anyone of the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Abdullah said: And Ali bin Al-Madini denied that Al-Muttalib heard from Anas). Al-Mundhiri said after quoting this statement of Al-Tirmidhi (1/119): (Abu Zur'ah said: Al-Muttalib is trustworthy, I hope he heard from Aisha. Despite this, its chain contains Abd al-Majid bin Abd al-Aziz bin Abi Rawad, and there is disagreement regarding his trustworthiness). I say: In (Al-Taqrib) Abd al-Majid is: (Truthful, makes mistakes). For this and that, he said in (Al-Fath) (9/70): (In its chain is weakness). Al-Bayhaqi narrated the Hadith (2/440) via Abu Dawood then said: (Muhammad bin Ishaq bin Khuzaimah narrated it from Abd al-Wahhab bin Al-Hakam Al-Warraq). I say: He is trustworthy. Muhammad bin Yazid Al-Adami, who is also trustworthy, differed with him in its chain, saying: Abd al-Majid bin Abd al-Aziz bin Abi Rawad told us from Ibn Juraij from Al-Zuhri from Anas with it. Extracted by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir) (p. 113). He placed Al-Zuhri in place of Al-Muttalib ibn Abdullah, and Al-Zuhri heard from Anas. And Allah knows best what is correct.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In any case, the Hadith has a Mursal witness similar to it extracted by Ibn Abi Dawood as in (Al-Fath), so with it, it is Hasan, Allah willing. Ibn Khuzaimah authenticated it. Then I retracted this and held that the Hadith is weak, so see (Da'if Abi Dawood) (No. 71). (Note): Al-Mundhiri attributed the Hadith (1/119, 212-213) to Ibn Majah as well. I think he was mistaken, for I did not find it with him, nor did anyone I saw extracting it attribute it to him, like Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath) (1), Abu Al-Barakat in (Al-Muntaqa), and Al-Suyuti in (Al-Jami'). Also, Al-Nabulusi in (Al-Dhakha'ir) (1/46) did not attribute it except to Abu Dawood alone. His saying: (Al-Qadhash) with lightening the dotted Dhal and shortening: Singular of straw, dust, and other things. Linguists said: (Al-Qadha): In the eye and drink is what falls into it, then used for everything that falls in the house and elsewhere if it is small. Ibn Ruslan said in (Sharh Al-Sunan): (In it is encouragement to clean mosques from small garbage that occurs in them, that they are written in their rewards and presented to their Prophet. If this little is written and presented, then the large is written and presented a fortiori. In it is alerting to the greater by the lesser, to the impure by the pure, and rewards according to deeds). He said:
foot_note: 1. (1) And in (Bulugh Al-Maram), and the text of his words in it: (Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Tirmidhi and he found it strange, and Ibn Khuzaimah authenticated it).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (I heard some Sheikhs say that it is appropriate for one who removes a speck from the mosque or harm from the Muslims' path to say when taking it: La ilaha illa Allah, to combine the lowest branch of faith (removing harm) and its highest: the word of Tawhid, and between actions and sayings. If the heart combines with the tongue, that is more perfect. End quote. However, it is not hidden that legal rulings require evidence, and his saying: 'It is appropriate' is a legal ruling). Thus in (Nayl Al-Awtar) (2/128). (Therefore, (When the black woman who used to sweep the mosque and pick up rags and sticks from it died, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, asked about her after some days. It was said to him: She died. He said: Why did you not inform me? They said: It was night. He said: It was as if they belittled her affair. He said: Show me her grave. So he came to the grave and prayed over her). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. There are two paths from him: First: From Hammad bin Zaid from Thabit from Abu Rafi' from him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (1/438-439, 440, 3/159), Muslim (3/56), Ibn Majah (1/465), Al-Tayalisi (321 no. 2446), and Ahmad (2/353, 388), some adding to others. Abu Amir Al-Khazzaz Salih bin Rustam followed him from Thabit in Al-Tayalisi paired with Hammad bin Zaid. All of them said: A black man or woman. Thus with doubt, except Ibn Majah, who said: Indeed a black woman. Without doubt.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Its chain is authentic as Al-Mundhiri said (1/118). This narration is strengthened by the path: Second: From Al-Ala' bin Abd al-Rahman from his father from Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, missed a black woman who used to pick up rags and sticks from the mosque. He said: Where is so-and-so? They said: She died... and he mentioned the Hadith. Extracted by Al-Bayhaqi (2/440). Ibn Khuzaimah also extracted it in his (Sahih) from this perspective as in (Al-Fath). He said: (Al-Bayhaqi narrated it with a good chain from the Hadith of Ibn Buraidah from his father, naming her Umm Mihjan, and stating that the one who answered the Prophet's question, peace and blessings be upon him, was Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq. In it: (She was fond of picking up specks from the mosque). I say: The Hadith was also narrated from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri in Ibn Majah, Ibn Abbas in Al-Tabarani, and Ubaid bin Marzuq in Mursal form in Al-Asbahani. In their chains is weakness. In all of them is the assertion that the person in the story was a woman. Refer - if you wish - to (Al-Targhib). Al-Hafiz said: (In the Hadith is the merit of cleaning the mosque, asking about the servant and friend if absent, rewarding with supplication, and encouragement to attend the funerals of people of good... etc.) (And (He saw sputum in the Qiblah of the mosque, so he became angry until his face turned red. A woman from the Ansar stood up, scraped it off, and put perfume (Khaluq) in its place. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: How good is this).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Hadith is from the narration of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Al-Nasa'i (1/119) and Ibn Majah (1/257) via A'idh bin Habib who said: Humaid Al-Tawil told us from him. This is an authentic chain; its narrators are narrators of the Two Sheikhs except A'idh bin Habib, who is truthful as in (Al-Taqrib). He indicated it in (Al-Fath) (1/403) and remained silent on it. It is in Al-Bukhari and others with another wording from Humaid, and perhaps it will come. It has a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Umar briefly with the wording: He saw sputum in the Qiblah of the mosque, so he scraped it off and perfumed its place. Extracted by Ahmad (2/18, 34-35) via Ibn Abi Rawad: Nafi' told me from him. This is a good chain. Abu Dawood extracted it (1/78) via Ayyub from Nafi' with it, except he said: And I think he said: So he called for saffron and daubed it with it. Al-Isma'ili narrated it likewise as in (Al-Fath) (1/404). It is in the (Two Sahihs) without mentioning perfuming. It will come, Allah willing, in (Prohibitions) (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) In the chapter from Jabir bin Abdullah: Ubadah bin Al-Walid bin Ubadah bin Al-Samit said: We came to Jabir while he was in his mosque. He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came to us in this mosque of ours with a branch of Ibn Tab palm in his hand. He looked and saw sputum in the Qiblah of the mosque. He approached it and scraped it with the branch, then said: (Which of you likes Allah to turn away from him?) Then he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Al-Khaluq) with Fatha on the dotted Kha: A compound perfume made from saffron and other types of scent. In the Hadith is evidence for cleaning the mosque, purifying it from what is repulsive, and perfuming it with Khaluq or other things. Ibn Abd al-Barr said: (Under the ruling of spitting in the mosque is purifying it from eating things like acorns and raisins due to their pits, fat, and stickiness, and grains of flour, and what a person sweeps from his house). Al-Iraqi mentioned it in (Sharh Al-Taqrib) (2/385). (Therefore, it is not permissible to throw anything of insects and the like from his body in the mosque, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (If one of you finds a louse in his garment, let him bundle it and not throw it in the mosque). The Hadith was extracted by Ahmad (5/410): Isma'il told us: Al-Hajjaj Al-Sawwaf told me from Yahya bin Abi Kathir from Al-Hadrami bin Lahiq from a man from the Ansar: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said... so he mentioned it.
foot_note: 1. = (Indeed when one of you stands to pray...) The Hadith. In it: Then he said: Show me Abir (scent). A youth from the tribe stood up and ran to his family and came with Khaluq in his palm. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, took it and put it on the head of the branch, then daubed it over the trace of the sputum. Jabir said: So from there you put Khaluq in your mosques. Extracted by Muslim (8/232), Abu Dawood (1/78-79), and Al-Bayhaqi (2/294). It will come in (Prohibitions) paragraph (10) Fourth Hadith First Path.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a chain whose narrators are all trustworthy narrators of the Six except Al-Hadrami bin Lahiq, who is acceptable [La ba'sa bihi] as in (Al-Taqrib), but he mentioned he is from the sixth layer, i.e., those for whom meeting any Companion is not established. Based on this, the Hadith is disconnected (1). Al-Haythami said (2/20): (Narrated by Ahmad and its narrators are authenticated). I say: But it is strengthened by its witness which he cited in (Al-Majmu') following this (From a Sheikh from the people of Mecca from Quraish who said: A man found a louse in his garment and took it to throw it in the mosque. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him: (Do not do it; return it to your garment until you leave the mosque). Narrated by Ahmad and its narrators are trustworthy except Muhammad bin Ishaq used 'an'an and is a Mudallis). I say: I did not find it now in (Al-Musnad). (2 - Lighting it without extravagance due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding Bayt al-Maqdis: (Come to it and pray in it. If you do not come to it and pray in it, then send oil to be lit in its lamps). And it has passed). The Hadith was narrated by Abu Dawood, and this is his wording. Ahmad and Ibn Majah narrated it with another wording previously mentioned with its extraction in the discussion on Al-Aqsa Mosque.
foot_note: 1. (1) Then I saw Al-Bayhaqi explicitly stating that, for he said (2/294) after citing the Hadith from this perspective: (This is Mursal Hasan in the likes of this).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In the Hadith is the legislation of lighting lamps in mosques to illuminate them, and the least it implies is recommendation. Abu Dawood, as well as Al-Bayhaqi, titled it: (Chapter: Lamps in Mosques). Ibn Majah extracted (1/356) from Khalid bin Iyas from Yahya bin Abd al-Rahman ibn Hatib from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri who said: The first to light lamps in mosques was Tamim Al-Dari. He said in (Al-Zawa'id): (It is Mawquf, and in its chain is Khalid bin Iyas; they agreed on his weakness). This was narrated in detail in (Tafsir Al-Qurtubi) (12/274): (Sa'id bin Zabban narrated: My father told me from his father from his grandfather from Abu Hind, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: Tamim - meaning Al-Dari - carried from Sham to Medina lamps, oil, and a rope (Muqatt). When he reached Medina, it coincided with Friday night. He ordered a boy called Abu Al-Bazad, so he tied the rope, hung the lamps, poured water and oil in them, and placed the wicks. When the sun set, he ordered Abu Al-Bazad, so he lit them. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came out to the mosque and found it shining with them. He said: (Who did this?) They said: Tamim Al-Dari, O Messenger of Allah. He said: (You illuminated Islam, may Allah illuminate you in this world and the Hereafter. Verily, if I had a daughter, I would have married her to you). Nawfal bin Al-Harith said: I have a daughter, O Messenger of Allah, named Al-Mughirah bint Nawfal, so do with her what you wish. So he married her to him. Zabban (with Fatha on Zai and Shadda with one dot underneath) Sa'id is unique in being named (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) Thus in Al-Qurtubi. Perhaps the correct is: The father of Sa'id. For you see that Zabban is his father's name. Al-Hafiz Abd al-Ghani bin Sa'id mentioned in (Al-Mu'talif wal-Mukhtalif) (p. 59) that Zabban bin Qa'id's Kunya is Abu Juwayn Hamrawi.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: by it alone. He is Abu Uthman Sa'id bin Zabban bin Fa'id bin Zabban Abi Hind. Abu Hind is the freed slave of Ibn Bayadah, the cupper of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. (Al-Muqatt): Plural of Al-Miqat: which is the rope, so it is as if it is the inversion of Al-Qimat. And Allah knows best). I say: This is all Al-Qurtubi's speech, and he remained silent on the Hadith. He should not have remained silent on it for it is extremely weak. Al-Dhahabi listed this Sa'id in (Al-Mizan) and named his father Ziyad - with Ya - and cited Hadiths for him with the chain of this mentioned one from his fathers from Abu Hind elevated: (Whoever is not pleased with My decree, let him seek a Lord other than Me). And in it: (The best food is raisins; it strengthens the nerves, removes fatigue, extinguishes anger, improves breath, removes phlegm, and clears the color). Al-Azdi said: (Abandoned. Ibn Hibban cited this for him and said: I do not know who the calamity is from? From him or his father or his grandfather). I say: It is apparent that lamps were not commonly used in his time, peace and blessings be upon him, neither in mosques nor in houses, except rarely. No Hadith establishing that has been transmitted to us - as far as I know. Rather, what negates that has come in Hadiths:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: First: From Aisha who said: I used to sleep in front of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, with my legs in his Qiblah. When he prostrated, he pinched me... The Hadith. In it Aisha said: And the houses at that time did not have lamps. Agreed upon. Second: From Abu Barza Al-Aslami, may Allah be pleased with him: That he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to finish the Morning prayer when a man could recognize his sitting companion. Also agreed upon. It is apparent that there were no lamps in the mosques by which they could know each other's faces. Therefore, he, peace and blessings be upon him, made the end of his prayer of Fajr when the darkness departed and the light began to spread, revealing faces. And Allah knows best. (Refer to (Al-Taratib Al-Idariyyah) Chapter: Were candles lit in Medina during his time, peace and blessings be upon him. Vol 1 p 85). But that does not negate the legitimacy of lighting the mosque as long as he, peace and blessings be upon him, encouraged that in the previous Hadith, and practice continued upon it afterwards. We only restricted that (to what is not extravagant) because there is no good in extravagance and because it is a waste of money in vain, and we have been forbidden from it. So what people are accustomed to of increasing the fuel of many lamps of electric lights in many mosques on the occasion of some seasons and Eids

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: - like the first Friday of Rajab, the night of mid-Sha'ban, the whole month of Ramadan, and the two Eids - is forbidden and prevented, especially in the two Eids, for the lights in them remain lit until the forenoon. Ibn Al-Hajj, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Al-Madkhal) while discussing the innovations of the night of mid-Sha'ban (1/308): (Do you not see what they have done of excessive extraordinary lighting until not a lamp remains in the mosque nor anything that can be lit except they lit it? They even put ropes on the columns and balconies and hung lamps on them and lit them. The reasoning has preceded for which the scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, disliked wiping the Mushaf, the pulpit, and the walls... etc., since that was the cause of the beginning of idol worship. Excessive lighting contains resemblance to fire worshippers in appearance, even if they do not believe that, because fire worshippers light them until when they are strong and radiant, they gather to them with the intention of worshiping them. The Lawgiver, peace and blessings be upon him, urged abandoning Muslims' resemblance to the actions of people of false religions even in their specific dress. Added to that is the gathering of many women, men, and young children who often soil the mosque with their waste, and much noise and clamor which is more severe, more frequent, and greater than the night of the twenty-seventh of Rajab. The evils in that have preceded, and in this night it is more, more hideous, and greater, due to the increase of lighting in it. Look, may Allah have mercy on us and you, at these innovations, how some drag to others until they end up in prohibitions). End of his words.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In (Al-Ba'ith 'ala Inkar Al-Bida' wal-Hawadith) (pp. 22-23) quoting Abu Bakr Al-Turtushi, may Allah have mercy on him, that he said: (Among what the innovators introduced and by which they exited what the legislated ones are characterized by, and in which they followed the ways of the Majus (Zoroastrians) and took their religion as amusement and play, is the lighting on the night of mid-Sha'ban. Nothing regarding it is authentic from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, nor did he speak of prayer in it. Regarding the lighting, [no] truthful narrator spoke. No one introduced it [except] one playing with the Muhammadan Sharia, desiring the religion of the Majus because fire is their object of worship. The first time this happened was in the time of the Barmakids; they introduced into the religion of Islam what they disguised to the commoners, which is their making the lighting in Sha'ban as if it were from the Sunnahs of faith, while their intent was worshiping fires and establishing their religion, which is the most losing of religions. Even when Muslims prayed, bowed, and prostrated, it was towards the fire they lit. Years and ages passed on that, Baghdad was followed in it by other regions. This is alongside what gathers in that night of men and women and their mixing. It is obligatory on the ruler to prevent them and on the scholar to deter them. Sha'ban was only honored because the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to fast it. The Hadith is authentic regarding his fasting, peace and blessings be upon him, all of Sha'ban or most of it). Then Ibn Abi Shama said (p. 25): (All this is corruption arising from the direction of misguided ascetics, so how about what occurs of the corruption of degenerate sinners and reviving that night with types of outward and inward sins? All of them are because of the lighting exceeding the usual, which is thought to be an act of closeness, while it is assistance in disobedience to Allah Almighty, manifesting evil, and strengthening the rituals of the people of innovation. It did not come in the Sharia

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: recommendation of increasing lighting beyond the amount of need in any place at all. What the common pilgrims do on the day of Arafah on the mountains of Arafat and the night of the day of Sacrifice at the Sacred Mash'ar is of this type. It must be denied and described as innovation, evil, and contrary to the purified Sharia). (3 - To walk to the mosque with tranquility and dignity and not rush, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (When you come to prayer, [adhere] to tranquility (added in another Hadith: and dignity). Whatever you catch, pray, and whatever you miss, complete). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Qatadah Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: While we were praying with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he heard the clamor of men. When he prayed, he said: (What is your matter?) They said: We rushed to prayer. He said: (Do not do that. When you come to prayer...) The Hadith. Extracted by Al-Bukhari (2/92), Muslim (2/100-101), Al-Darimi (1/294), Al-Bayhaqi (2/298), and Ahmad (5/306) via Yahya bin Abi Kathir: Abdullah bin Abi Qatadah informed me that his father informed him with it. The addition in the other Hadith is from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, and its wording preceded in (Iqamah) in the ninth issue with mention of its paths, so it suffices against repeating it. Al-Tirmidhi said (2/149): (The people of knowledge differed regarding walking to the mosque. Some of them saw rushing if one fears missing the first Takbir, to the extent that it was mentioned about some of them that they used to jog to

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The prayer. Among them are those who disliked rushing and chose to walk with calmness and dignity. This is the opinion of Ahmad and Ishaq, and they said: 'The practice is based on the hadith of Abu Huraira.' Ishaq said: 'If he fears missing the opening Takbir, there is no harm if he hastens his walk.' I say: The correct view is the dislike of rushing absolutely, whether he misses the Takbir or not. The explanation for this has preceded in what was indicated earlier, so let it be reviewed there. (4 - He must rub his sandals with soil if he intends to enter with them, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'If one of you comes to the mosque, let him look; if he sees filth or harm on his sandals, let him wipe it and pray in them.') The hadith is from the narration of Abu Saeed Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, and it has preceded with a different wording which belongs to Abu Dawood, and its chain is Sahih as we mentioned there in the third issue of the purity of the place. (5 - To begin his entry with the right foot, for that is from the Sunnah, as Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'It is from the Sunnah that when you enter the mosque, you start with your right foot, and when you exit, you start with your left foot.') Recorded by Al-Hakim (1/218) and via his path Al-Bayhaqi (2/) from Shaddad Abu Talha who said: 'I heard Muawiyah bin Qurra narrating it from him.' They differed regarding him; Al-Hakim said: 'Sahih according to the condition of Muslim, for he used Shaddad bin Saeed Abu Talha Al-Rasibi as proof,' and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: His student Al-Bayhaqi disagreed with him, saying: 'Shaddad bin Saeed Abu Talha Al-Rasibi is unique in this, and he is not strong.' The truth is what Al-Hakim said, that he is according to the condition of Muslim, but this Al-Rasibi is spoken of [criticized], so his hadith descends from the rank of Sahih to the status of Hasan. Al-Dhahabi said about him that he is: 'Salih al-Hadith' (passable in hadith). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): 'He is Saduq (truthful) but errs.' He cited this hadith of his in (Al-Fath) (1/415) and did not weaken it, so the hadith is Hasan. It has a suspended (Mawquf) witness; Al-Bukhari said: 'Chapter: Starting with the right when entering the mosque and other places: Ibn Umar used to start with his right foot, and when he exited, he started with his left foot.' He recorded it like this in a suspended form. Al-Hafiz said: 'I did not see it connected (Mawsul).' The first part of it is supported by the generality of the hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: 'The Prophet, peace be upon him, used to love starting with the right as much as he could in all his affairs: in his purification, his combing, and his putting on sandals.' Recorded by Al-Bukhari (1/216 and 415) and Muslim (1/155-156), and Al-Bukhari used it as evidence in this chapter.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Hafiz said after citing the previous hadith of Anas: 'The correct view is that the Companion's statement: "It is from the Sunnah such-and-such" is interpreted as being raised (Marfu' - to the Prophet). However, since the hadith of Anas was not according to the author's condition, he indicated it with the report of Ibn Umar. The generality of Aisha's hadith indicates starting with the right when exiting the mosque as well. It is possible to say regarding her statement "as much as he could" that it is a precaution against what cannot be done with the right side according to Sharia, such as entering the toilet and exiting the mosque, and likewise handling filthy things with the right hand like cleaning oneself (Istinja) and blowing the nose. Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, knew his love, peace be upon him, for what she mentioned either by his informing her of that or by contextual indications.' (6 - That he says upon entering, as a recommendation: 'I seek refuge in Allah the Mighty, and in His Noble Face, and His Eternal Authority, from the accursed Satan' [A'udhu Billah al-Azim wa bi-Wajhihi al-Karim wa Sultanihi al-Qadim min al-Shaitan al-Rajim]). He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'If he says that, Satan says: He has been protected from me for the rest of the day.' The hadith was recorded by Abu Dawood (1/76) via the path of Uqba bin Muslim from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that when he entered the mosque, he used to say... and he mentioned it. And at its end is the mentioned statement: 'If he says that...' etc. Its chain is Sahih; its men are trustworthy men of the Two Sheikhs except Uqba bin Muslim and Ismail bin Bishr bin Mansour, Abu Dawood's Sheikh in it, and they are both trustworthy. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Adhkar): 'A Hasan hadith, its chain is good (Jayyid).'

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir attributed it in his (Tafsir) (3/293) to (Sahih Al-Bukhari), and that is an error from him, may Allah have mercy on him. (And he also says as he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say: 'In the name of Allah, O Allah send blessings upon Muhammad and grant him peace, O Allah open for me the doors of Your mercy' [Bismillah Allahumma Salli 'ala Muhammad wa Sallim Allahumma Iftah li Abwaba Rahmatik]). This came in several hadiths: First: From Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when he entered the mosque, said: "In the name of Allah, O Allah send blessings upon Muhammad," and when he exited he said: "In the name of Allah, O Allah send blessings upon Muhammad."' Recorded by Ibn Al-Sunni in (Amal Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah) (p. 31, no. 86). He said: Al-Hasan bin Musa Al-Rasa'ni narrated to me: Ibrahim bin Al-Haytham Al-Baladi narrated to us: Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Al-Bahtari - a righteous Sheikh from Baghdad - narrated to us: Isa bin Yunus narrated to us from Ma'mar from Al-Zuhri from him. This is a Hasan chain or potentially Hasan. Al-Hasan bin Musa is Ibn Nasih bin Yazid Abu Saeed Al-Khaffaf. Al-Khatib said (7/429): 'He came to Baghdad and narrated there from Ibn Sulaiman, Saeed bin Abdul Malik Al-Harrani, Al-Hasan bin Umar bin Shaqiq Al-Balkhi, and Uqba bin Mukram Al-Dabbi. Muhammad bin Khalaf bin Waki', Yahya bin Muhammad bin Sa'i, Muhammad bin Makhlad, Ubaidullah...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...bin Abdul Rahman Al-Sukkari and Abu Dharr Al-Qaratisi narrated from him.' Then he cited one hadith for him via the path of Saeed bin Abdul Malik Al-Harrani: Al-Walid bin Muslim narrated to us from Abu Ishaq Al-Fazari from Ibn Jurayj from Ata from Ibn Umar who said: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out with Bilal and said: "O Bilal, call out among the people that the Caliph after Umar is Uthman." He said: So he raised his head to the sky then said: "O Bilal, proceed, Allah refused but that." Three times).' He did not mention any criticism or praise regarding him. A group of trustworthy narrators reported from him as you saw, but this hadith is very rejected (Munkar), rather fabricated. However, the blame in it is not on him but on his Sheikh Saeed bin Abdul Malik Al-Harrani. In his biography, Al-Dhahabi cited it via the path of Al-Khatib then said: 'This is fabricated, and Al-Rasa'ni, God willing, his status is truthfulness.' And Ibrahim bin Al-Haytham Al-Baladi, Al-Khatib said (6/207): 'Trustworthy and firm, our Sheikhs do not differ regarding him.' The rest of the men of the chain are trustworthy men of the Six Books except Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Al-Bahtari; I did not find anyone who mentioned him, and Al-Khatib did not include him in his (Tarikh) despite him being according to his condition, yet he was authenticated in this narration as you see. And Allah knows best. Second: From Fatimah, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, who said: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when he entered the mosque, sent blessings upon Muhammad and granted peace, and said: "My Lord, forgive me my sins and open for me...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...the doors of Your mercy," and when he exited, he sent blessings upon Muhammad and granted peace, and said: "My Lord, forgive me my sins and open for me the doors of Your bounty."' Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi (2/127-128), Ibn Majah (1/259), and Ahmad (6/282-283 and 283) via the path of Ismail bin Ibrahim from Laith bin Abi Sulaim from Abdullah bin Hasan from his mother Fatimah bint Hussein from her grandmother Fatimah Al-Kubra, may Allah be pleased with her. The wording belongs to Al-Tirmidhi and Ahmad. They added: Ismail bin Ibrahim said: 'I met Abdullah bin Al-Hasan in Mecca and asked him about this hadith, so he narrated it to me saying: "When he entered he said: 'My Lord open for me the door of Your mercy,' and when he exited he said: 'My Lord open for me the door of Your bounty.'"' The wording of Ibn Majah is like their wording except that he said: 'In the name of Allah and peace be upon the Messenger of Allah' instead of: 'May Allah send blessings upon Muhammad and grant peace,' in both places. This is a narration of Ahmad. Ibn Al-Sunni recorded it (p. 31, no. 85) via the path of Su'air bin Al-Khams from Abdullah bin Al-Hasan with it, with the wording: 'He praised Allah and said the Bismillah' in both places as well, and the rest is exactly like it. The mention of 'Praise' (Hamd) in it is anomalous (Shadh), rather rejected (Munkar), for it is from the narration of Ibrahim bin Yusuf Al-Kindi from Su'air. Although he is 'Saduq' (truthful) according to Mutayyin and others, Al-Nasa'i said: 'He is not strong.'

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): 'Saduq (truthful) but has leniency.' So what he narrates uniquely is not used as evidence. Furthermore, Al-Tirmidhi said about the hadith that it is: 'A Hasan hadith, but its chain is not connected, and Fatimah bint Al-Hussein did not reach Fatimah Al-Kubra; she only lived for months after the Prophet, peace be upon him.' I say: So the chain is weak due to its disconnection. Al-Tirmidhi only classified its hadith as Hasan due to its witnesses which we are about to mention. And Allah knows best. After writing the above, I found a corroborator for Ibrahim bin Yusuf Al-Kindi regarding the mention of 'Praise' in it, which is Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad Al-Darawardi. Abu Al-Abbas Al-Thaqafi said: Abu Raja narrated to us: Qutaybah bin Saeed narrated to us: Abdul Aziz - meaning Ibn Muhammad - narrated to us from Abdullah bin Hasan from his mother: That the Prophet, peace be upon him, said to Fatimah his daughter, may Allah be pleased with her: 'When you enter the mosque, say: In the name of Allah, and praise be to Allah, O Allah send blessings upon Muhammad and grant peace, O Allah forgive me and make easy for me the doors of Your mercy. And when you exit the mosque, say likewise, except that he said: And make easy for me the doors of Your provision.' (1) So Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad corroborated him and added to him and to those before that he combined Praise and Bismillah, and Prayer and Peace. This is a contradiction...
foot_note: 1. (1) Ibn al-Qayyim cited it in (Jala' al-Afham fi al-Salat 'ala Khayr al-Anam) (p. 52).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...the second one from Al-Darawardi. Even though he is trustworthy and Muslim used him as proof, there is something about him. It says in (Al-Taqrib): 'Saduq (truthful), he used to narrate from the books of others so he would err.' Thus, he is not used as proof if he contradicts trustworthy narrators like Ismail bin Ibrahim, who is Ibn Ulayyah the trustworthy Hafiz. Al-Darawardi erred another error where he made the hadith a teaching from the Prophet, peace be upon him, to his daughter Fatimah, while the hadith is her narration from him, peace be upon him, regarding his action, as other narrators reported it. So be aware. Third: From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, raised to the Prophet with the wording: 'If one of you enters the mosque, let him send peace upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, and let him say: O Allah open for me the doors of Your mercy. And when he exits, let him send peace upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, and let him say: O Allah protect me from the accursed Satan.' Recorded by Ibn Majah (1/260) and Al-Hakim (1/207), and from him Al-Bayhaqi (2/442) and Ibn Al-Sunni (p. 31, no. 84) via the path of Abu Bakr Al-Hanafi: Al-Dahhak bin Uthman narrated to us: Saeed Al-Maqburi narrated to me from him. Al-Hakim said: 'Sahih according to the condition of the Two Sheikhs.' Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, but it is not as they said; rather it is according to the condition of Muslim alone, for Al-Bukhari did not record narrations for Al-Dahhak bin Uthman.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith was also recorded by Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban in their (Sahihs) as in (Al-Jala') (p. 262) and (Tafsir Ibn Kathir) (3/294). Al-Shawkani attributed it in (Tuhfat Al-Dhakirin) (p. 94) to Muslim, which is an error from him or a slip of the pen. It says in (Al-Zawa'id): 'Its chain is Sahih, its men are trustworthy.' Fourth: From Abu Humaid or from Abu Usaid raised to the Prophet with the wording: 'If one of you enters the mosque, let him say: O Allah open for me the doors of Your mercy. And when he exits, let him say: O Allah I ask You from Your bounty.' Recorded by Muslim (2/155), Al-Darimi (2/293), and Al-Bayhaqi (2/441) via paths from Sulaiman bin Bilal from Rabiah bin Abi Abdul Rahman from Abdul Malik bin Saeed from Abu Humaid or from Abu Usaid. Abdul Aziz Al-Darawardi followed him from Rabiah with it with doubt; recorded by Abu Dawood (1/76), Al-Darimi (1/324), and Al-Bayhaqi. And Umarah bin Ghaziyah in Muslim and Al-Bayhaqi from Bishr bin Mufaddal from him. Ismail bin Ayyash contradicted him from Umarah bin Ghaziyah saying: From Abu Humaid alone; recorded by Ibn Majah (1/259). Ismail bin Ayyash is weak in his narration from the Hijazis, and this is one of them. It is from the first path in Al-Nasa'i (1/119) and Ahmad (3/497 and 5/425).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: From Abu Amir who said: Sulaiman bin Bilal narrated to us with it, except he said: I heard Abu Humaid and Abu Usaid saying: He combined them together. Perhaps the first narration is closer to being correct and more likely because most narrators from Sulaiman bin Bilal are upon it, and because Al-Darawardi followed him on it without disagreement upon him, unlike the other narrations. And Allah knows best. This, and in Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, Al-Darimi in one narration, and Al-Bayhaqi, there is an addition: 'Let him send peace upon the Prophet, peace be upon him' upon entering only. Likewise, Abu Awana recorded it in his Sahih Musnad (Vol 1, p 414) similar to Abu Dawood's narration and added in it: 'And when he exits, let him send peace upon the Prophet, peace be upon him' as in (Nuzul Al-Abrar) (p. 72). Based on this, it is exactly like the hadith of Abu Huraira, and both indicate the obligation of this remembrance. Therefore we said: (And this supplication is obligatory due to his command, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding it in his saying: 'If one of you enters the mosque, let him send peace upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, and let him say: O Allah open for me the doors of Your mercy. And when he exits, let him send peace upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, and let him say: O Allah protect me from the accursed Satan'). The hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, and it has a witness from the hadith of Abu Humaid or Abu Usaid, may Allah be pleased with him, and their referencing has just preceded.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): 'It contains the recommendation (Istihbab) of this remembrance.' I say: The saying of 'recommendation only' requires evidence to divert the command, which apparently implies obligation, to recommendation, and there is no evidence as far as we know. If there were any evidence, Al-Nawawi himself or others would have mentioned it. Therefore, Imam Ibn Hazm held the view of its obligation. He said in (Al-Muhalla) (4/60): 'It is obligatory upon whoever enters the mosque to say: O Allah open for me the doors of Your mercy. And when he exits from it, let him say: O Allah I ask You from Your bounty. This is only one of the conditions of entering the mosque whenever he enters it, not one of the conditions of prayer. The prayer of one who does not say that is valid, but he has disobeyed in leaving his saying what he was commanded with.' Then he cited the hadith via the path of Muslim from Abu Humaid or Abu Usaid. The phrase: 'Let him send peace' did not occur in Muslim's narration as previously indicated. It seems Ibn Hazm did not come across it in the other narrations nor across the hadith of Abu Huraira which contains the two additions; otherwise, he would have mentioned them and stated the obligation of sending peace (Salam) as well. Furthermore, the apparent meaning of the hadith implies the obligation of sending peace upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, only, without sending blessings (Salah) upon him, for that is recommended due to its establishment from his action, peace and blessings be upon him, as preceded. However, it might be said: The Salam in it is general, and he, peace and blessings be upon him, clarified it by his action where he used to combine Salah and Salam, and that is the requirement of His saying: {Indeed...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Allah and His angels send blessings upon the Prophet. O you who have believed, ask [Allah to confer] blessings upon him and ask [Allah to grant him] peace} [Al-Ahzab / 56]. So just as sending blessings upon him, peace be upon him, includes sending peace upon him as clarified by the noble verse and as in the Tashahhud, perhaps sending peace upon him includes sending blessings upon him as well when mentioned generally. This is what occurred to me to mention in this place. If it is correct, it is from Allah Almighty, and if it is otherwise, I seek Allah's forgiveness and hope for its correction by those capable of it. Al-Sindi said: 'Sending peace (Salam) upon the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was prescribed when the worshiper enters the mosque and when he exits because he is the cause of his entering the mosque and attaining great good, so he should be mentioned with goodness. Specifying mercy for entry and bounty for exit is because entry is established to acquire mercy and forgiveness, while outside the mosque is the place for seeking provision, which is what is meant by bounty.' (Note): Sheikh Al-Islam said in (Al-Radd 'ala Al-Akhna'i) (p. 150): 'In (Sunan Abu Dawood) and others, it is said upon entering the mosque: (O Allah I ask You for the best entry and the best exit, in the name of Allah we enter and in the name of Allah we exit, and upon Allah we rely).' I say: The hadith is in the [Book of] Adab in (Sunan Abu Dawood) from the hadith of Abu Malik Al-Ash'ari who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: 'If a man enters his house, let him say: O Allah...'

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: etc. Its chain is weak, and it is, as you see, from the supplications of entering the house, not the mosque. Therefore, Abu Dawood placed it under the chapter (What is said by one who enters his house). Apparently, Sheikh Al-Islam erred in making it one of the supplications for entering the mosque, and I did not find anyone else who mentioned that. Yes, Sheikh Al-Islam commented some of it from Ibn Sirin: 'People used to say when they entered the mosque - then he mentioned Salah and Salam on the Prophet, peace be upon him - and in the name of Allah we entered and in the name of Allah we exited and upon Allah we relied. And they used to say the like of that when they exited.' (7 - That he prays two Rak'ahs before sitting, obligatorily, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'If one of you enters the mosque, let him bow two Rak'ahs before he sits.') And in a wording: 'Let him not sit until he bows two Rak'ahs [then let him sit afterwards if he wishes or let him go for his need].' The hadith is from the narration of Abu Qatada Al-Ansari. Recorded by Malik in (Al-Muwatta) (1/176) and from his path Muhammad (p. 150), and likewise Al-Bukhari (1/426), Muslim (2/155), Abu Dawood (1/76), Al-Nasa'i (1/119), Al-Tirmidhi (2/129) who said: Hasan Sahih, Al-Darimi (1/323), Ibn Majah (1/317), Al-Tahawi (1/217), Ahmad (5/295 and 303), and Al-Khatib (5/236 and 12/318); all of them via the path of Malik from Amir bin Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr from Amr bin Sulaim Al-Zuraqi from him. He was followed regarding Amir by: Abdullah bin Saeed in Al-Bukhari (3/37) - and the second wording is his - and Abu Umays Utbah bin Abdullah in Abu Dawood and Ahmad (5/311) - and the addition is his...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: in the first of them [Abu Dawood] with a Sahih chain according to their condition; and Fulaih bin Sulaiman in Al-Darimi; and Uthman bin Abi Sulaiman and Muhammad bin Ajlan in Al-Tahawi and Ahmad (5/296 and 305); and Yahya bin Saeed Al-Ansari in Al-Tabarani's (Al-Saghir) (p. 76) with the second wording as well. All of them said: From Amir bin Abdullah from Amr bin Sulaim from Abu Qatada. Suhail bin Abi Salih contradicted them saying: From Amir bin Abdullah from Amr bin Sulaim Al-Zuraqi from Jabir bin Abdullah raised to the Prophet with it. Recorded by Al-Tahawi and Al-Khatib (3/47) who said: 'It is an error; Suhail contradicted the people in his narration, and the correct version is: From Abu Qatada.' Al-Tirmidhi mentioned something similar and quoted it from Ibn Al-Madini. I say: The hadith of Jabir is actually regarding prayer in the mosque upon arriving from travel, as will come God willing. Muhammad bin Yahya bin Hibban followed Amir: From Amr bin Sulaim bin Khaldah Al-Ansari from Abu Qatada who said: I entered the mosque... the hadith. It comes in the original; recorded by Muslim and Ahmad with the second wording. It contains a benefit regarding the reason for the hadith's occurrence, which is rare. It has another path with a different wording; Al-Hafiz said after mentioning the reason for occurrence:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 'In Ibn Abi Shaybah from another perspective from Abu Qatada: Give the mosques their right. It was said to him: And what is their right? He said: Two Rak'ahs before you sit.' I say: Al-Khatib recorded it via the path of Abdullah bin Abi Qatada from his father raised to the Prophet with the wording: 'If you enter the mosque, greet it with two Rak'ahs before the Imam.' Its chain is weak containing a group who are not known. It has a witness from the hadith of Abu Huraira raised to the Prophet like the narration of Abdullah bin Saeed. Recorded by Ibn Majah via the path of Kathir bin Zaid from Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah from him. In (Al-Zawa'id): 'Its men are trustworthy except that it is disconnected (Munqati'). Abu Hatim said: Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah from Abu Huraira is Mursal.' The hadith is evidence by its apparent meaning for the obligation of the two Rak'ahs of greeting the mosque, because in the first narration he commanded them, and the command implies obligation. In the other, he forbade sitting before prayer, and that implies prohibition. The Zahiris (Literalists) adopted this apparent meaning, except Ibn Hazm among them, for he explicitly stated in (Al-Muhalla) that it is a Sunnah. It is the opinion of the Majority, and they answered the hadith saying the command in it is for recommendation (Nadb). They argued for that with proofs that do not support what they claimed. The researcher Al-Shawkani cited them and refuted them, showing their unsuitability to divert the command from obligation to recommendation. For example, his saying, peace be upon him, to the one he saw stepping over people:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 'Sit, for you have caused harm,' and he did not order him to pray. Al-Hafiz said: 'Thus Al-Tahawi and others used it as evidence, and it is questionable.' Al-Shawkani said: 'Perhaps the reason is that there was nothing preventing him from having performed it in a part of the mosque before the stepping over occurred from him, or that this was before the command for it and the prohibition of leaving it.' Likewise, everything they argued with has no proof in it; see the detail of that in (Nayl Al-Awtar). (This prayer is known as 'Greeting of the Mosque' [Tahiyatul Masjid] (1), and it is not missed by sitting, even without the excuse of forgetfulness and the like. This is indicated by the reason for the hadith's occurrence. Abu Qatada, may Allah be pleased with him, said: I entered the mosque of the Messenger of Allah while he was sitting among people. He said: So I sat. The Messenger of Allah said: 'What prevented you from bowing two Rak'ahs before you sat?' He said: So I said: O Messenger of Allah, I saw you sitting and the people sitting. He said... and he mentioned the hadith). The hadith was narrated by Muslim and Ahmad as preceded shortly. In the chapter from Jabir, and it comes after this.
foot_note: 1. (1) Ahmad narrated in (Al-Zuhd) from Maymun bin Mihran (he is a Faqih Tabi'i who died in the year 117) that he used to say: 'The greeting of the mosque when you enter is that you bow two Rak'ahs.' Al-Najm said: 'This speech runs on the tongues of the Jurists. It is strange that some pretended-jurists of the age claimed that one should not say "Greeting of the Mosque" despite the occurrence of the like of that and its currency on the tongues of Jurists, ancient and modern.' Thus in (Kashf Al-Khafa') (1/299).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And from Abu Dharr: That he entered the mosque, so the Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: 'Did you bow two Rak'ahs?' He said: No. He said: 'Stand and bow them.' Recorded by Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Fath). I say: Al-Tayalisi and Ahmad also recorded it via the path of Al-Mas'udi from Abu Amr Al-Shami from Ubaid bin Al-Khashkhash from him. This is a weak chain. Al-Mas'udi had become confused (mixed up), and his Sheikh Abu Amr - also said: Abu Umar - is weak. Ubaid bin Al-Khashkhash - with dotted letters, and it was said: undotted - is lenient as in (Al-Taqrib). The hadith was also narrated by Al-Bazzar and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) as in (Al-Majma'), and he said: 'It contains Al-Mas'udi, and he is trustworthy but he became confused.' I say: He limited the weakening of the hadith to this, which is a deficiency. If he had added to it his [Al-Mas'udi's] Sheikh and the one above him, or limited it to them, it would have been more appropriate due to what you know of their condition, while Al-Mas'udi is better than them.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This hadith was used by Ibn Hibban for a chapter heading that the Greeting of the Mosque is not missed by sitting. Al-Hafiz said: 'A group explicitly stated that if he contravenes and sits, it is not prescribed for him to make it up. This is questionable due to this hadith of Ibn Hibban, and similar to it is the story of Sulaik as will come. Al-Muhibb Al-Tabari said: It is possible to say: Their time is before sitting as a time of virtue, and after it as a time of permissibility. Or it is said: Their time before is performance (Ada'), and after is makeup (Qada'). And it is possible that their prescription after sitting is interpreted as being when the interval is not long.' I say: This last possibility is the closest because he, peace and blessings be upon him, in these hadiths hastened to command and did not delay. And Allah knows best. Furthermore, the hadith indicates by its generality the permissibility of the Greeting of the Mosque in the disliked times. Scholars differed regarding that, and the most likely view is what the generality of the hadith implies, because nothing came that is strong enough to specify it, as its explanation and detail will come God willing. (Likewise, it does not drop from the one entering on Friday while the preacher (Khatib) is on the pulpit preaching; rather, he must perform it, except that he should shorten it. For: Sulaik Al-Ghatafani came on Friday while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was preaching, so he sat [before praying]. He said to him: O Sulaik [did you pray two Rak'ahs? He said: No. He said:] 'Stand and bow two Rak'ahs and be brief in them' (Added in another hadith: So he prayed two Rak'ahs while the Prophet, peace be upon him, was preaching). Then [he turned to the people and] said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 'If one of you comes on Friday while the Imam is preaching, let him bow two [light] Rak'ahs and be brief in them [then let him sit].') The hadith was reported from a group of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, at length and briefly. Among them: (1) Jabir bin Abdullah Al-Ansari, and his hadith is the most complete. There are paths from him, the most perfect and complete path is: 1 - Al-A'mash from Abu Sufyan from him. Recorded by Muslim - and the context is his - Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad. The last two additions belong to them. Al-Walid Abu Bishr narrated it from Sufyan - his name is Talha Al-Iskaf - and it contains the addition before them. Recorded by Abu Dawood, Ahmad, and Al-Daraqutni. 2 - Amr bin Dinar from him briefly: A man came while the Prophet, peace be upon him, was on the pulpit preaching on Friday. He said to him: 'Did you bow two Rak'ahs?' He said: No. He said: 'Then bow.' Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i,

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad via paths from him. Some of his chains in Ahmad are tripartite. Shu'bah narrated it from Amr bin Dinar who said: I heard Jabir bin Abdullah say: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said while he was preaching: 'If one of you comes while the Imam is preaching or has come out, let him pray two Rak'ahs.' Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Tayalisi, Ahmad, and Al-Daraqutni (1). 3 - From Al-Laith from Abu Al-Zubayr from Jabir: Similar to the narration of Amr bin Dinar, adding the naming of the man as Sulaik, and it contains the first addition. Recorded by Muslim, as well as Al-Tahawi. Yazid bin Ibrahim followed him from Abu Al-Zubayr; recorded by Al-Tahawi and Ahmad, adding: He said: Jabir used to say: If he prayed in his house, he liked for him to pray them when he entered (2). Among them is Sulaik himself. Hisham bin Hassan narrated from Al-Hasan from him that he came while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was preaching
foot_note: 1. (1) He has a fourth path with him from Ibn Ishaq from Aban bin Salih from Mujahid from him. In it after: 'Bow two Rak'ahs: Do not repeat the like of this.' This chain has trustworthy men but Ibn Ishaq is a Mudallis and used 'an'ana. With this addition, Ibn Hibban recorded it in his (Sahih) and said: 'He meant the delay, not the prayer' as in (Nasb Al-Rayah) (2/203).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: on the pulpit on Friday. He said to him: 'Did you bow two Rak'ahs?' He said: No. He said: 'Pray two Rak'ahs and be brief in them.' Recorded by Al-Tahawi: Yazid bin Sinan narrated to us: Safwan bin Isa narrated to us: Hisham bin Hassan narrated to us. This is a Sahih chain; its men are men of the Two Sheikhs except Yazid bin Sinan and his Sheikh Safwan, and they are both trustworthy as in (Al-Taqrib), if Al-Hasan - who is Al-Basri - heard it from Sulaik. It was reported from him as Mursal. Al-Rabi' bin Sabih Al-Basri said: I saw Al-Hasan praying two Rak'ahs while the Imam was preaching. Al-Hasan said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: 'If one of you comes while the Imam is preaching, let him pray two light Rak'ahs and be brief in them.' Recorded by Al-Darimi via Sufyan Al-Thawri from him. Al-Rabi' bin Sabih is Saduq (truthful) but has poor memory as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Ala' bin Khalid Al-Qurashi followed him in the stopped (Mawquf) part; he said: I saw Al-Hasan Al-Basri enter the mosque on Friday while the Imam was preaching, so he prayed two Rak'ahs then sat. Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi then he said: 'Al-Hasan only did that following the hadith, and he narrated from Jabir from the Prophet, peace be upon him, this

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: hadith.' This Al-Ala' was accused of lying by Abu Salamah (Al-Tabudhaki), and Ibn Hibban contradicted himself regarding him. (3) Among them is Abu Huraira. Recorded by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah via the path of Al-A'mash from Abu Sufyan from Jabir and from Abu Salih from Abu Huraira with it similar to the hadith of Sulaik himself. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of Muslim, and his hadith from Abu Sufyan from Jabir preceded. (4) Among them is Abu Saeed Al-Khudri, and he has two paths: 1 - From Muhammad bin Ajlan from Iyad bin Abdullah bin Abi Sarh: That Abu Saeed Al-Khudri entered on Friday while Marwan was preaching, so he stood to pray. The guards came to make him sit, but he refused until he prayed. When he finished, we came to him and said: May Allah have mercy on you, they almost fell upon you. He said: I would not leave them after something I saw from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Then he mentioned that a man came on Friday in a shabby state while the Prophet, peace be upon him, was preaching on Friday, so he ordered him and he prayed two Rak'ahs while the Prophet, peace be upon him, was preaching. Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi - and the wording is his - Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad via paths from him. Also recorded by Al-Tahawi, Ibn Khuzaimah, and Ibn Hibban as in (Al-Fath). Al-Darimi and Ibn Majah narrated it briefly.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The chain is Hasan. Al-Tirmidhi said: 'Hasan Sahih Hadith.' 2 - From Ibn Lahi'ah from Musa bin Wardan from Abu Saeed Al-Khudri that he said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on Friday, when a Bedouin entered while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was on the pulpit. The Bedouin sat at the back of the people. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: 'Did you bow two Rak'ahs?' He said: No. He said: So he ordered him, and he went to the courtyard near the pulpit and bowed two Rak'ahs. Recorded by Ahmad, and its chain is Hasan in corroborations and witnesses. Then Al-Tirmidhi said: 'The practice is upon this according to some people of knowledge; Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and Ishaq say it. Some of them said: If he enters while the Imam is preaching, he sits and does not pray. This is the opinion of Sufyan Al-Thawri and the people of Kufa. The first opinion is more correct.' I say: Al-Darimi, the author of the (Sunan), also said it. It is as Al-Tirmidhi, may Allah have mercy on him, said, that it is the more correct view. Imam Al-Tahawi, may Allah have mercy on him, went to great lengths to reject this explicit text. The utmost that he argued with from tradition is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'If you say...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: to your companion: "Listen," while the Imam is preaching, you have engaged in idle speech.' This is because enjoining good is higher than the two Rak'ahs of greeting, so if he is prevented from it, he is prevented from them a fortiori. This is the viewpoint of the Hanafis in their argumentation with the mentioned hadith, as established by Al-Sindi. However, he, may Allah have mercy on him, was not satisfied with that but rejected it saying: 'There is discussion regarding it: First: Because it is reasoning by implication or analogy in opposition to the text, so it is not heard. Second: Because continuing in prayer for one who started it before the sermon is permissible, unlike continuing in enjoining good for one who started it before. So just as the analogy of prayer to enjoining good is not valid in continuation, it is not valid in initiation. And Allah Almighty knows best.' I say: We do not concede that the command [to listen] is higher than the greeting of the mosque; rather we say the opposite, which is the apparent meaning of the text. Meaning: The greeting is higher than enjoining good at that time; therefore, he ordered it and not this, and that is among the proofs of its obligation as established recently. So reflect. Due to the clarity of the proof in this issue, I refrain from addressing the remaining aspects and opinions pointed to earlier and refuting them, and I refer whoever wants to view them in detail to (Fath Al-Bari) and (Nayl Al-Awtar). I only point out here what was narrated as raised (Marfu') which, if authentic, would be a proof for the Hanafis. It is what Al-Tabarani recorded in (Al-Kabir) from Ibn Umar raised to the Prophet: 'If one of you enters the mosque while the Imam is preaching on the pulpit, there is no prayer and no speech until the Imam finishes.' Al-Haythami said (2/184):

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 'It contains Ayyub bin Nahik, and he is Matruk (abandoned), weakened by a group. Ibn Hibban mentioned him in Al-Thiqat and said: He errs.' Al-Hafiz indicated his weakness in (Al-Fath). The author of (Al-Hidayah) cited it raised with the wording: 'If the Imam comes out, there is no prayer and no speech.' Its researcher Al-Zayla'i said: 'I say: Strange as raised. Al-Bayhaqi said: Raising it is a grave error; it is only from the speech of Al-Zuhri.' Then he said (p. 204): 'Abu Muhammad Abdul Haq mentioned in his (Ahkam) saying: And Abu Saeed Al-Malini narrated in his book from Muhammad bin Abi Mutee' from his father from Muhammad bin Jabir from Abu Ishaq from Al-Harith from Ali raised to the Prophet: Do not pray while the Imam is preaching.' Al-Zayla'i remained silent on it, perhaps due to the obviousness of its weakness. For this Al-Harith is Al-A'war, and he is weak. Likewise, Muhammad bin Jabir - who is Al-Suhaimi - and Abu Mutee' - who is Al-Balkhi and his name is Al-Hakam bin Abdullah - all of them are weak. Therefore, Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Dirayah): 'Its chain is flimsy.'
foot_note: 1. (1) Rather he explicitly stated that, saying: 'Weak, containing Ayyub bin Nahik, and he is Munkar al-Hadith (rejected in hadith), as said by Abu Zur'ah and Abu Hatim.'

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (8 - To begin with it [the mosque] and pray in it the prayer of arrival from travel, for: (He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he arrived from travel, used to begin with the mosque and pray two Rak'ahs in it, then sit for the people). The Hadith is from the narration of Ka'b bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad extracted it from the path of Abdullah bin Ka'b and Ubaidullah bin Ka'b from him. It is part of his long Hadith regarding the story of his staying behind from the Battle of Tabuk and his repentance. It has a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Umar: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when he returned from his Hajj, entered Medina and made his camel kneel at the door of his mosque, then entered and prayed two Rak'ahs in it, then went to his house. Nafi' said: And Ibn Umar used to do likewise. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ahmad from Ibn Ishaq: Nafi' told me from Ibn Umar. This is a Hasan chain. And another [witness] from the Hadith of Abu Tha'labah with the wording: He used to, when he arrived from travel, begin with the mosque and pray two Rak'ahs in it, then he would second [visit] with Fatimah, then come to his wives. And in a wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Then he began with the house of Fatimah then came to the houses of his women. Narrated by Al-Tabarani and others as in (Al-Fath). In our copy, there is a blank space instead of 'others'. The apparent meaning of the first Hadith is that this prayer was for the sake of sitting in the mosque, not for arrival from travel. However, its two witnesses are explicit - especially the latter of them - that it was for arrival from travel. Similar to it is the Hadith of Jabir coming above. Therefore, Al-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim) commenting on it and on the Hadith of Ka'b: (In these Hadiths is the recommendation of two Rak'ahs for the one arriving from his travel in the mosque upon his first arrival. This prayer is intended for the arrival from travel, not that it is Tahiyyat Al-Masjid (greeting of the mosque), and the mentioned Hadiths are explicit regarding what I mentioned). Ibn Al-Qayyim said in the context of mentioning the rulings and benefits contained in the story of the three who were left behind: (And among them is that the Sunnah for the one arriving from travel is to enter the town in a state of Wudu and to begin with the House of Allah before his house, pray two Rak'ahs in it, then sit for the Muslims, then go to his family). (And he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered that, so care should be given to it. Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: (We were on a journey with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and when we arrived in Medina he said to me: Go to the mosque and pray two Rak'ahs in it [He said: So I entered and prayed then returned]).)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Hadith was extracted by Al-Tayalisi: Shu'bah told us from Muharib bin Dithar, he said: I heard Jabir say... so he mentioned it. This is a very Sahih chain. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad extracted it from paths from Shu'bah with it. Mis'ar followed him: Muharib told us with it similarly; Al-Bukhari and Ahmad extracted it. Wahb bin Kaysan followed him from Jabir similarly, and it contains the addition; Muslim extracted it. The apparent meaning of the command implies the obligation of the prayer of arrival from travel in the mosque, but I do not know of anyone among the scholars who held this view. If someone is found who said it, we would adopt it. And Allah knows best. (9 - To begin exiting from it with the left foot, contrary to entering, for it is from the Sunnah as preceded there) in entering the mosque paragraph (5), so refer to it. (10 - And to say upon that: (In the name of Allah, O Allah send blessings upon Muhammad and grant him peace, O Allah I ask You from Your bounty). And sometimes he says: (O Allah protect me ('Isimni) (and in a wording: grant me refuge (Ajirni), and in another: I seek refuge with You (A'idhni)) from the accursed Satan). All this is obligatory to say due to the command for it as preceded).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: in the sixth paragraph. And take note here of what is necessary, which is: That the first wording: ('Isimni) is the narration of Ibn Majah, and likewise Ibn Al-Sunni in a narration. The second wording: (Ajirni) is the narration of Al-Hakim and Al-Bayhaqi. The third: (A'idhni) is a narration of Ibn Al-Sunni. It appears to be a variation from the narrators, so he [the worshiper] uses this sometimes and that sometimes, because the most correct among them has not become preponderant to me. (11 - To exit from it while intending to return to it, perhaps he becomes one of the seven about whom the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Seven whom Allah will shade [on the Day of Resurrection] in His shade (and in another Hadith: the shade of His Throne) on a day when there is no shade but His shade: A just Imam; a youth who grew up in the worship of Allah the Mighty and Majestic [until he died upon that]; a man whose heart is attached to the mosque (and in a wording: as if his heart is suspended in the mosque, added in the other Hadith: out of love for it) when he exits from it until he returns to it; two men who loved each other for Allah, gathered upon that and separated upon that; a man who remembered Allah in solitude (and in a wording: in private) and his eyes overflowed [out of fear of Allah]; a man whom a woman of rank (and in a wording: of position) and beauty called [to herself] and he said: Indeed I fear Allah; and a man who gave charity and hid it so that his left hand would not know what his right hand spent (and in a wording: gave charity as if he hid his right hand from his left)).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The Hadith was extracted by Malik in (Al-Muwatta), and from his path Al-Tirmidhi who said: (Hasan Sahih), and Muslim also, and Al-Bayhaqi in (Al-Asma' wa Al-Sifat), all of them from him from Khubaib bin Abdul Rahman Al-Ansari from Hafs bin Asim from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri or from Abu Huraira that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said... so he mentioned it with doubt between Abu Sa'id and Abu Huraira. Ubaidullah bin Umar narrated it from Khubaib with it and said: (From Abu Huraira) alone. Al-Bukhari extracted it, and it has the first addition. Likewise Al-Nasa'i, Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi who also authenticated it, and Ahmad from paths from him similarly. It contains in all [narrations] the third wording. With Al-Bukhari and Al-Nasa'i is the second wording. Hammad bin Zaid added from Ubaidullah bin Umar the second addition, and he has the first wording and the fourth which is the last one; Al-Jawzaqi extracted it as in (Al-Fath). The fourth addition, which is the last one also, is with Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad. The third addition is with Al-Jawzaqi, as well as the second. The Hadith was also extracted by Al-Tayalisi and Al-Khatib from the path of Al-Mubarak bin Fadalah; the first said: From Khubaib bin Abdul Rahman, and the others said: From Ubaidullah from Khubaib with it similarly.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: With the first is the third addition, and with the other is the second wording. With the first: (Until he returns (yarji'u) to it) instead of his saying: (When he exits from it until he returns (ya'udu) to it). Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in (Al-Asma') from the path of Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Al-Layth: Umar bin Marzuq told us: Shu'bah informed us from Khubaib with it with variation in some sentences in wording and meaning, and he said: (Under His Throne). Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Al-Layth is weak, but he was not alone in mentioning the Throne in it. Al-Bayhaqi said: (The wording of the Throne was narrated in the raised (Marfu') Hadith). Then he cited this Hadith, then said: (That was also narrated from Abdullah bin Umar bin Hafs from Khubaib, and it was also narrated from Muhammad bin Sirin from Abu Huraira). I say: I found a third path for it from Abu Huraira extracted by Al-Khatib from the path of Abdullah bin Amir Al-Aslami from Suhail bin Abi Salih from his father from him raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Under the shade of His Throne). Abdullah bin Amir Al-Aslami is weak. From a path extracted by Al-Bayhaqi in (Al-Shu'ab) as in (Al-Fath), he did not cite its wording, then said: (And Abdullah bin Amir is weak but not abandoned (Matruk), and his Hadith is Hasan in corroborations (Mutaba'at)).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: It is strengthened by the other Hadith referred to which contains this addition, which is from the Hadith of Salman from Sa'id bin Mansur with a Hasan chain stopped (Mawquf) at him. Al-Hafiz said: (But its ruling is raised (Raf')). I say: Al-Bayhaqi also narrated it from the path of Qatadah that Salman said: (The truthful merchant is with the seven in the shade of Allah's Throne on the Day of Resurrection), then he mentioned the seven mentioned in the raised report. In (Al-Jami' Al-Saghir) the Hadith: (Seven are in the shade of the Throne on a day when there is no shade but His shade...) The Hadith. In it: (And a man whose heart is attached to mosques due to his intense love for them...) The Hadith. Narrated by Ibn Zanjawayh from Al-Hasan as Mursal, and Ibn Asakir from Abu Huraira. In summary, these additions which we included in the body of the Hadith are established in the sum of the Hadith's paths, and they reveal the meaning or close to it and repel the difference that might revolve around it, as becomes clear to you by referring to the explanations. The intent of citing the Hadith here is his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: (And a man whose heart is attached to the mosque when he exits from it until he returns to it). Al-Munawi said: (He used it as a metonymy for frequenting it at all prayer times, so he does not pray a prayer except...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...in the mosque, and he does not exit from it except while waiting for another to return and pray it in it. So he is attached to the mosque with his heart; the intent is not perpetual sitting in it). (12 - It is better for one who is free with no work or is wealthy enough not to earn to remain in it waiting for the other prayer, for there is great virtue in it due to his saying, peace be upon him: (Whoever sits in the mosque waiting for prayer, he is in prayer). The Hadith is the narration of Sahl bin Sa'd Al-Sa'idi. Extracted by Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad from the path of Ayyash bin Uqbah, he said: Yahya bin Maymun told me, he said: Sahl bin Sa'd stopped by us and said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say... so he mentioned it. The wording is Ahmad's. Al-Nasa'i said: (Was) instead of: (Sat). This is a good (Jayyid) chain: Ayyash bin Uqbah and his Sheikh Yahya bin Maymun, Al-Nasa'i said regarding each of them: (There is no harm in him). In (Al-Taqrib) that they are: (Truthful). (And his saying: (The one waiting for prayer after prayer is like a horseman whose horse intensified with him in the path of Allah on his flank (Kashh)) (meaning: his enemy). Allah's angels send blessings upon him as long as he does not invalidate his ablution or stand up, and he is in the Greater Ribat).)

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: It is from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. Ahmad extracted it from the path of Nafi' bin Sulayman from Abdul Rahman bin Mahran from him. This is a Sahih chain; all its men are men of Muslim except Nafi' bin Sulayman, and Ibn Ma'in declared him trustworthy, and Abu Hatim said: (Truthful) as in (Al-Ta'jil). In (Al-Targhib): (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and Ahmad's chain is good (Salih)). I say: The Hadith after it witnesses to it, and his saying, peace be upon him: (Shall I not guide you to what Allah erases sins with and raises ranks?) They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said: (Performing Wudu thoroughly despite difficulties, taking many steps to the mosques, and waiting for prayer after prayer. That is the Ribat, that is the Ribat, that is the Ribat). Extracted by Muslim and Malik, and from him Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad from Al-Ala' bin Abdul Rahman from his father from Abu Huraira also. (And his saying: (One of you ceases not to be in prayer as long as he waits for it [nothing prevents him from returning to his family except the prayer]. And the angels cease not to send blessings upon one of you as long as he is in the mosque: O Allah forgive him, O Allah have mercy on him [O Allah accept his repentance as long as he does not harm in it] as...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...long as he does not invalidate his ablution (ahdatha)). A [non-Arab] man from Hadramout said: And what is Hadath, O Abu Huraira? He said: [Indeed Allah is not shy of the truth] passing wind soundlessly or with sound (Fusa' or Dirat)]). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira also, and there are more than ten paths from him regarding it: 1 - Hammam bin Munabbih from him. Extracted by Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi - and the context is his - Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad. The last addition is for him and Al-Tirmidhi, and he does not have: (Indeed Allah is not shy of the truth). 2 - Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from him. It contains the first addition. Extracted by Malik, and from him Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, all from Malik with it. 3 - Sa'id bin Abi Sa'id Al-Maqburi from him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, and it contains the addition: (non-Arab) and the explanation of Hadath, and Ahmad. 4 - Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from him. Extracted by Muslim, and it contains the second addition, and Ibn Majah, and likewise Al-Bukhari and Ibn Majah also, and Ahmad.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: 5 - Ayyub Al-Sakhtiyani from Ibn Sirin from him. Narrated by Muslim and Ahmad. 6 - Hammad bin Salamah from Thabit from Abu Rafi' from him. It contains the explanation of Hadath. Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad. 7 - Ibn Shihab from Ibn Hormuz from him. Muslim and Ahmad. 8 - Abu Salamah from him. Extracted by Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad, and it is Sahih on their condition. Malik also extracted it. 9 - Muhammad bin Ishaq from Al-Ala' bin Abdul Rahman from his father from him. Extracted by Ahmad, and its men are trustworthy except that Ibn Ishaq used 'an' (from). 10 - Kathir bin Zaid from Al-Walid bin Rabah from him. Extracted by Ahmad and its chain is Hasan. 11 - Muhammad bin Humaid said: Sa'id bin Al-Mahdi told us from his father from him. Extracted by Al-Tayalisi.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This is a weak, unknown chain: Muhammad bin Humaid is Al-Razi, a weak Hafiz, and Ibn Ma'in had a good opinion of him as in (Al-Taqrib). Sa'id bin Al-Mahdi and his father, I did not know them. Al-Nasa'i argued for non-obligation with what Al-Shawkani did not address mentioning, so I saw benefit in citing what he argued with to draw attention to it. It is what he extracted from the path of Abdullah bin Ka'b, he said: I heard Ka'b bin Malik narrating his Hadith when he stayed behind from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in the Battle of Tabuk. He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, arrived in the morning. Whenever he arrived from travel, he would begin with the mosque and pray two Rak'ahs in it, then sit for the people... The Hadith. In it: When I greeted him, he smiled the smile of the angry one, then said: (Come). So I came until I sat before him. He said to me: (What held you back? Did you not buy your mount?) I said: O Messenger of Allah, by Allah, if I were sitting before anyone else from the people of the world, I would have seen that I would exit from his anger. I have been given argumentation skills. But by Allah, I have known that if I tell you today a lying speech to please you with me, Allah the Mighty and Majestic will soon make you angry with me. And if I tell you a truthful speech in which you find [something] against me, I hope in it for Allah's pardon. By Allah, I was never stronger nor more wealthy than when I stayed behind you. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (As for this one, he has spoken the truth. So stand until Allah judges regarding you). So I stood and went. He titled it with:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
