text: (The concession for sitting in the mosque and exiting from it without prayer). However, the Hadith, like the one before it, is not explicit that he sat without prayer or that it was after his command, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, for Tahiyyat (greeting prayer). Rather, it bears the opposite possibility, and there is nothing in it to repel this possibility. Since probability has entered it, deduction by it falls. And Allah knows best. Therefore, Al-Shawkani said after refuting all what they argued with: (If you know this, it becomes clear to you that the apparent view is what the Zahiris said of obligation). Al-Amir Al-San'ani preceded him in choosing obligation in (Subul Al-Salam). He said: (Due to the abundance of commands reported regarding it). I say: This is supported by what follows of his command, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, while he was on the pulpit delivering the Friday sermon to Sulaik Al-Ghatfani for this prayer, then he ordered that to everyone who enters the mosque even if the Imam is delivering the sermon. This is among the strongest evidences for its obligation due to several matters: First: His interrupting the sermon, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Second: His command for it after Sulaik sat down. Third - and it is the strongest -: That he ordered it during the sermon, for it is known that in this state it is not permissible for anyone to enjoin good or forbid evil, due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (If you say to your companion on Friday: 'Listen' while the Imam is preaching, you have engaged in idle talk). Narrated by the two Sheikhs and others. If he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered the Tahiyyat in this state, that indicates that it is greater to him than enjoining good and forbidding evil which are obligatory in principle. This is clear and not hidden, and praise be to Allah. In summary, the Hadith is Mutawatir from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him, extracted by Ahmad from the path of Hammad bin Salamah from Ali bin Zaid from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from him. This is a Hasan chain in witnesses. His saying: (As long as he does not invalidate ablution/Hadath) has been interpreted by the narrator as passing sound or wind, so no attention is paid to disagreement. Al-Hafiz said: (But it is taken from it that avoiding Hadath of the hand and tongue is a fortiori, because the harm from them is more severe. Ibn Battal indicated that). Al-Iraqi prolonged the discussion in explaining the Hadith and mentioning its benefits in (Sharh Al-Taqrib), so whoever wishes let him refer to it. (And his saying: (No Muslim man makes the mosques his home for prayer and remembrance except that Allah becomes joyful with him [from when he exits] just as the family of the absent one becomes joyful with their absent one when he arrives to them). It is from the Hadith of Abu Huraira also.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Extracted by Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from paths from Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Sa'id Al-Maqburi from Sa'id bin Yasar from Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet]. The addition is for Al-Hakim and Ahmad, and Al-Tayalisi has its meaning. Then Al-Hakim said: (Sahih on the condition of the two Sheikhs. Al-Layth bin Sa'd contradicted Ibn Abi Dhi'b, so he narrated it from Al-Maqburi from Abu Ubaidah from Sa'id bin Yasar that he heard Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet] similarly). I say: Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is on their condition from the first path as they said. In the other path: This Abu Ubaidah, I did not know him. Imam Ahmad extracted it from this aspect from paths from Al-Layth. Ibn Khuzaymah narrated it in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib). In (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is Sahih, its men are trustworthy). His saying: (Tabashbasha - becomes joyful): Originates from the joy of a friend at the arrival of a friend, kindness in questioning, and turning towards [someone]. The meaning here: His receiving him with His kindness, drawing him near, and honoring him. In the chapter there are other Hadiths regarding waiting for prayer after prayer and sticking to mosques; in what we mentioned there is sufficiency and adequacy. Whoever desires increase, let him refer to (Al-Targhib). In them, despite their different wordings and meanings, is the encouragement for waiting for prayer...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and settling in mosques for the sake of remembrance and prayer. The least they imply is recommendation (Istihbab). Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, went to this saying: (It is recommended to stick to the mosque for one who is free from earning and dealing). He restricted it with this condition, and we followed him on that, due to what is established in the Sharia of the obligation of striving for sustenance and that a Muslim should not be a burden on people, like His saying, The Exalted: {And when the prayer has been concluded, disperse within the land and seek from the bounty of Allah} [Al-Jumu'ah / 10]. If he is wealthy enough from that, or has reached an old age such that he cannot work, or similar cases, it is reasonable that he makes the House of Allah The Exalted his home and stations himself in it for the remembrance of Allah and prayer. (B) Prohibitions (1 - Exiting the mosque after Adhan before prayer is not lawful, for (A man exited the mosque after Adhan had been called in it [for Asr], so Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, said: As for this one, he has disobeyed Abu Al-Qasim, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira himself, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are two paths from him: First: From Abu Al-Sha'tha', he said... so he mentioned it. Extracted by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad from the path of Ibrahim bin Al-Muhajir, Ash'ath bin Abi Al-Sha'tha', and Al-Muharibi from Abu Al-Sha'tha'. Al-Tirmidhi said - and the context is his -:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). The addition is for him, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad in a narration. Then he and Al-Tayalisi extracted it from the path of Sharik from Ash'ath with it and added: (Then he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, commanded us: If you are in the mosque and prayer is called, let none of you exit until he prays). Al-Mundhiri said: (Narrated by Ahmad and its chain is Sahih). Al-Haythami said: (And its men are men of the Sahih). I say: With this addition, it is not Sahih because Sharik was alone in it, and he is not strong in what he narrates alone as Al-Daraqutni said. In (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful but errs). Furthermore, neither of the (Two Sahihs) used him as proof; rather, Muslim extracted for him as corroboration as Al-Dhahabi stated in (Al-Mizan). So Al-Haythami's absolute statement that its men are men of (Al-Sahih) is not correct because it implies that they are all used as proof in (Al-Sahih), which is not the case. However, the Hadith has come raised [to the Prophet] from another path from Abu Huraira as will come, but I personally did not come across its chain to judge for or against it, although the apparent speech of Al-Mundhiri and Al-Haythami implies that it is strong as you will see.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Second: From Abu Salih from him that he saw a man... The Hadith without the addition. Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Saghir), he said: Muhammad bin Al-Madini - Fustuqah - Al-Baghdadi told us: Surayj bin Yunus told us: Abu Hafs Al-Abbar told us from Muhammad bin Juhadah from him. He said: (No one narrated it from Muhammad bin Juhadah except Abu Hafs Al-Abbar). I say: He is a trustworthy Hafiz, and his name is Umar bin Abdul Rahman. The rest of the men of the chain are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except this Fustuqah, which is his nickname, and his name is Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Fadl Abu Al-Abbas. He is trustworthy, died in the year (289) as in (Tarikh Baghdad). So the chain is Sahih. Al-Shawkani spoke about the Hadith saying: (In its chain is Ibrahim bin Al-Muhajir, and he has been authenticated and weakened). It was hidden from him that Ash'ath bin Abi Al-Sha'tha' followed him [corroborated], and he is trustworthy. Its appearance is Mawquf (stopped), but in meaning it is Marfu' (raised) according to the majority. Al-Mundhiri said in (Mukhtasar Sunan Abi Dawood): (Some mentioned that this is Mawquf, and Abu Umar Al-Namari mentioned that it is Musnad [Marfu'] according to them. He said: They do not differ regarding this and that, that both are Musnad Marfu'. Meaning: This and the saying of Abu Huraira: Whoever does not answer - meaning the invitation - has disobeyed Allah and His Messenger). Al-Hafiz said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Al-Tabarani extracted it in (Al-Awsat) from the path of Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, and he explicitly raised it to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and with specification, and its wording is: (No one hears the call in this mosque of mine then exits from it except for a need, then does not return to it, except a hypocrite). I say: Al-Mundhiri said in (Al-Targhib): (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and its narrators are used as proof in (Al-Sahih)). Al-Haythami said in (Al-Majma') similarly. I say: It has a witness from the Hadith of Uthman bin Affan raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Whoever is overtaken by Adhan in the mosque then exits, not exiting for a need while not intending to return, he is a hypocrite). Ibn Majah extracted it from Abdul Jabbar bin Umar from [Ibn] Abi Farwah from Muhammad bin Yusuf, the freed slave of Uthman bin Affan, from his father from him. In (Al-Zawa'id): (Its chain is weak; it contains Ibn Abi Farwah, his name is Ishaq bin Abdullah: they weakened him, and likewise Abdul Jabbar bin Umar). Another witness is Mursal, extracted by Al-Darimi from the path of Abdul Rahman bin Harmalah, he said: A man came to Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib bidding him farewell for Hajj or Umrah. He said to him: Do not leave until you pray, for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (No one exits from the mosque after the call except a hypocrite, except a man whom a need brought out and he intends to return to the mosque). He said: Indeed my companions are at Al-Harrah. He said: So he went out. He said: Sa'id kept mentioning him until he was informed that he fell from his mount and broke his thigh. This is a Hasan chain; all its men are men of Muslim except that he narrated for Abdul Rahman as corroboration as in (Tahdhib Al-Tahdhib). Al-Hakim claimed in (Al-Mustadrak) that Muslim used him as proof, and stated in another place that he is from the men of Al-Bukhari, and this is among his delusions which Al-Dhahabi agreed with him on. This Hadith was narrated by Abdul Razzaq in his (Musannaf) from this aspect as in (Nasb Al-Rayah). Al-Mundhiri attributed it to Abu Dawood in his (Marasil), and it is in (Al-Mukhtasar). Al-Shawkani said: (The two Hadiths indicate the prohibition of exiting the mosque after hearing the Adhan for other than Wudu, relieving oneself, and what necessity calls for, until he prays that prayer in it, because that mosque has become designated for that prayer. Al-Tirmidhi said after mentioning the Hadith: And upon this is the practice among the people of knowledge from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and those after them: That no one exits the mosque [after Adhan] except for an excuse: that he is without Wudu or an unavoidable matter. It is narrated from Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i that he said: He exits as long as the Mu'adhin has not started the Iqamah. This, to us, is for one who has an excuse to exit from it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: End quote. Ibn Raslan said in (Sharh Al-Sunan): Exiting is disliked according to the generality of the people of knowledge if it is without excuse of purity or similar, otherwise it is permissible without dislike. Al-Qurtubi said: This is carried on being a Hadith raised to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, due to the evidence of its attribution to him, and it is as if he heard what implies the prohibition of exiting the mosque after Adhan, so he applied the term disobedience to it). I say: Therefore, the Hadith is evidence for prohibition as Al-Shawkani said. Ibn Hazm preceded him to that where he said: (Whoever is in the mosque and Adhan is called, it is not lawful for him to exit the mosque unless he is without Wudu or for a necessity). Saying it is only disliked is contrary to the apparent meaning of the Hadith (And this is if it is without excuse, but with it, it is permissible as will come in the Permissibles). (2 - Interlacing fingers as long as he is in it, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (If one of you performs ablution in his house then comes to the mosque, he is in prayer until he returns, so let him not do like this: and he interlaced his fingers). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Darimi and Al-Hakim - and the wording is his - extracted it from the path of Ismail bin Umayyah from Al-Maqburi from him. Al-Hakim said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Sahih on the condition of the two Sheikhs). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Al-Mundhiri did not accept that in (Al-Targhib) where he said: (There is a view regarding what he said). I say: Perhaps its basis is that there is disagreement regarding it from Al-Maqburi as will come, but Ismail bin Umayyah is trustworthy and firm as in (Al-Taqrib). Muhammad bin Ajlan followed him [narrating] from Al-Maqburi from Abu Huraira; Al-Hakim extracted it from Yahya bin Sa'id from Ibn Ajlan. The Hadith was also extracted by Ibn Khuzaymah in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib). The referenced disagreement came in several ways: This is one of them. Second: Sufyan Al-Thawri from Muhammad bin Ajlan from Al-Maqburi from Ka'b bin Ujrah raised [to the Prophet] with it. Al-Darimi extracted it. Abu Bakr bin Ayyash followed him in Ibn Majah, and Qurran bin Tammam Abu Tammam and Sharik bin Abdullah in Ahmad, all from Ibn Ajlan with it. Third: Al-Layth from Ibn Ajlan from Sa'id Al-Maqburi from a man from Banu Ka'b from Ka'b. Al-Tirmidhi extracted it with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Ibn Jurayj followed him except that he said: From some of Banu Ka'b bin Ujrah from Ka'b. Ahmad narrated it. Fourth: Ibn Abi Dhi'b from Sa'id Al-Maqburi from a man from Banu Salim from his father from his grandfather from Ka'b. Al-Tayalisi and Ahmad extracted it. This is a severe disagreement. Therefore, Al-Hafiz said: (Abu Dawood extracted it, and Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban authenticated it. In its chain is a difference due to which some weakened it). I say: Al-Bayhaqi criticized it. I say: Perhaps the first aspect is the correct one due to the agreement of two trustworthy narrators on it: Ismail bin Umayyah and Ibn Ajlan, even though there was disagreement on Ibn Ajlan also as you saw. But we do not know if this confusion is from him or his Sheikh Sa'id? The apparent is the second. And Allah knows best. However, the Hadith has an origin from the narration of Ka'b bin Ujrah from two other paths in which this disagreement does not enter: First: From Dawud bin Qais from Sa'd bin Ishaq bin Fulan bin Ka'b bin Ujrah that Abu Thumamah Al-Khayyat told him that Ka'b bin Ujrah told him, he said... so he mentioned it raised [to the Prophet] similarly.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Abu Dawood and Ahmad extracted it. Al-Mundhiri said: (With a good (Jayyid) chain). The scholar Ahmad Shakir followed him in his (Commentary on Al-Tirmidhi). I have a reservation about it, for this Abu Thumamah, even though (Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat) and extracted this Hadith for him in his (Sahih)) as in (Al-Nayl), his condition is unknown as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Daraqutni said: (Not known, abandoned) as in (Al-Mizan) by Al-Dhahabi, and he said: Not known). Yes, it is possible to say: It is Hasan due to others (Li Ghayrihi) because of what preceded and what follows: Second: Ibn Hibban extracted it in his (Sahih), he said: Abu Arubah told us: Muhammad bin Sa'dan told us: Sulayman bin Abdullah told us from Ubaidullah bin Umar [and] from Zaid bin Abi Anisah from Al-Hakam from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Laila from Ka'b bin Ujrah raised [to the Prophet]. Al-Ayni mentioned it in (Al-Umdah) and remained silent on it. Its men are trustworthy except Muhammad bin Sa'dan; I did not know him. Perhaps he is Muhammad bin Sa'dan Abu Ja'far Al-Bazzar who narrated from Abu Ja'far Al-Nufayli and Fayd bin Wathiq and others. Abu Abdullah Al-Hakimi narrated from him - he has a biography in (Tarikh Baghdad) - and he said: (He died in the year two hundred and seventy-seven) and did not mention any disparagement or modification regarding him. However, the Hadith is interrupted (Munqati'), for Sulayman bin Abdullah, who is Ibn Muhammad bin Sulayman Al-Harrani, died in the year two hundred and sixty-three...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...and Ubaidullah bin Amr - who is Al-Raqqi - died in the year one hundred and eighty (79). So between their deaths is (83) years. Perhaps between them is Muhammad bin Sulayman Al-Harrani, the grandfather of this Sulayman, for he narrates from him. It has a witness from the Hadith of the freed slave of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. Ahmad extracted it: Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr told us, he said: Ubaidullah bin Abdullah bin Mawhab told us, he said: My uncle told me - meaning Ubaidullah bin Abdul Rahman bin Mawhab - from a freed slave of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, he said: While I was with Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when we entered the mosque, behold a man sitting in the middle of the mosque squatting (Muhtabiyan), interlacing his fingers into each other. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, signaled to him, but the man did not notice the signal of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, turned to Abu Sa'id and said: (If one of you is in the mosque, let him not interlace, for interlacing is from Satan. Indeed, one of you remains in prayer as long as he is in the mosque until he exits from it). Then he narrated it from Waki' from Ubaidullah with it. Ibn Abi Shaybah extracted it from him as in (Al-Umdah). Al-Hafiz said: (In its chain is a weak and an unknown person). I say: The first is Ubaidullah, who is Ibn Abdul Rahman bin Abdullah bin Mawhab. He said: In (Al-Taqrib):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (is not strong) and the other is his uncle Ubaidullah bin Abd al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Mawhab, who is acceptable (Maqbul) as in (Al-Taqrib). From this you know that the statement of Al-Mundhiri and then Al-Haythami: (Narrated by Ahmad with a good chain) is not good. Yes, the Hadith is good (Hasan), rather authentic (Sahih) by the sum of these paths. It has been contradicted by the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, led us in one of the two afternoon prayers (Dhuhr or Asr). He prayed two Rak'ahs with us then said Taslim. Then he stood up to a piece of wood placed in the mosque and leaned on it as if he was angry, and he placed his right hand over his left and interlaced his fingers... The Hadith. Al-Bukhari extracted it and titled it (Chapter: Interlacing fingers in the mosque and elsewhere). In it is evidence for the permissibility of interlacing fingers in the mosque. Either it is said: This is specific to him, peace and blessings be upon him, based on what is established in the principles (Usul) that his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, takes precedence over his action in case of contradiction. Or his action clarifies his prohibition, that it is not for prohibition (Tahrim) but for dislike (Karahah). Perhaps this is closer. And Allah knows best. See (Nayl Al-Awtar).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (3 - Approaching it for one who ate garlic and the like of foul-smelling vegetables and plants. This is prohibited as long as the offensive smell remains in him, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, in the Battle of Khaybar: (Whoever eats from this foul-smelling plant [he said on the first day: Garlic, then said: Garlic, onion, and leek] let him not approach our mosque (and in a wording: our mosques. And in a second hadith: let him not approach us nor pray with us. Added in a third: three days [and let him sit in his house]. And in a fourth: until its smell leaves him. And in a fifth: and let him not harm us with the smell of garlic) for the angels are harmed by what humans are harmed by. And in a sixth: He said: If you must eat them, then kill them by cooking, meaning: Onion and garlic). The Hadith came from a group of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, through many paths with different wordings, some adding to others: First: Jabir bin Abdullah, and there are paths from him: 1 - Kathir bin Hisham from Hisham Al-Dastawa'i from Abu Al-Zubair from him - and the context is his. Extracted by Muslim and Ahmad. Al-Tabarani narrated it in (Al-Saghir) via Yahya bin Rashid Al-Bara': Hisham bin Hassan Al-Firdawsi told us from Abu Al-Zubair with it, and added: (Garlic, onion, leek, and radish). He said: (No one narrated it from Hisham Al-Firdawsi except Yahya bin Rashid).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: He is weak as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) and his Sheikh Al-Haythami in (Al-Majmu'). It is an addition established from another path as will come, without saying: (radish), for it was only narrated in this path. Ibn Majah extracted the Hadith via Abd al-Rahman bin Nimran Al-Hajari from Abu Al-Zubair with it: That a group of people came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and he found the smell of leek from them. He said: (Did I not forbid you from eating this plant? Indeed the angels are harmed by what the human is harmed by). Abd al-Rahman bin Nimran is unknown as in (Al-Taqrib). But Hammad bin Salamah followed him: Abu Al-Zubair informed us, more complete than it. Extracted by Ahmad. 2 - Ibn Juraij said: Ata informed me from him. In it is the first addition in Muslim and Al-Nasa'i, and the context and the other wording are his. And Al-Tirmidhi, and he authenticated it via Yahya bin Sa'id from him (1). The wording of Muslim: (Garlic). And he said once: (Onion, garlic, and leek). Al-Hafiz said:
foot_note: 1. (1) And Ahmad narrated it (3/380) from Abd al-Razzaq: Ibn Juraij informed us with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Abu Nu'aym narrated it in (Al-Mustakhraj) via Rawh bin Ubadah from Ibn Juraij similarly, and specified the one who said: (And he said once). Its wording: Ibn Juraij said: And Ata said at another time: (Garlic, onion, and leek). Abu Al-Zubair narrated it from Jabir with the wording: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade eating onion and leek. And he said: There was no garlic in our land at that time. Thus Ibn Khuzaimah extracted it from the narration of Yazid bin Ibrahim and Abd al-Razzaq from Ibn Uyaynah both from Abu Al-Zubair. I say: This does not negate the previous interpretation since it being absent from their land does not imply it was not brought to them. Even if this interpretation were impossible, the narration of the affirmer would take precedence over the narration of the negator). Al-Hafiz means by the interpretation referred to the narration of Al-Bukhari via Abu Asim who said: Juraij informed us with it with the wording: (Whoever eats from this plant - meaning garlic - let him not come near us in our mosque). This is a narration of Muslim from two other paths from Ibn Juraij. Then Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Al-Bayhaqi extracted it via Ibn Wahb: Yunus informed me from Ibn Shihab who said: Ata bin Abi Rabah told me with it. In it is the second addition and its wording: (Whoever eats garlic or onion, let him keep away from us) or (or let him keep away from our mosque and sit in his house). And that he was brought a pot containing vegetables from legumes and found a smell from it, so he asked and was informed of what legumes were in it. He said: (Bring it near) to some of his companions. When he saw it, he disliked eating it. He said: (Eat, for I converse with one whom you do not converse with).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Abd al-Malik bin Marwan followed him in Ahmad, and Al-Layth bin Sa'd in Al-Tabarani without the story of the pot. Al-Tabarani said: (Al-Zuhri did not narrate a hadith from Ata other than this). Second: Anas bin Malik, narrated from him by Abd al-Aziz bin Suhayb who said: Anas was asked about garlic, so he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Whoever eats from this plant, let him not approach us nor pray with us). This is the second Hadith. Third: Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman elevated with the wording: (Whoever spits towards the Qiblah will come on the Day of Resurrection with his spit between his eyes. And whoever eats from this foul vegetable, let him not approach our mosque - three times -). Extracted by Abu Dawood via Zirr bin Hubaish from Hudhayfah, I think from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Its chain is authentic on the condition of the Two Sheikhs. Al-Mundhiri attributed it in (Al-Targhib) to Ibn Khuzaimah only in his (Sahih), which is a shortcoming. He cited it in another place with the first part of it and said: (Narrated by Abu Dawood, Ibn Khuzaimah, and Ibn Hibban in their (Sahihs)). I say: It is the third Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Fourth: Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, and there are four paths from him: 1 - From Abu Nadra from him who said: We had not yet exceeded the conquest of Khaybar when we fell upon that vegetable, garlic, and the people were hungry. So we ate from it heavily, then went to the mosque. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, found the smell and said: (Whoever eats anything from this foul plant, let him not approach us in the mosque). The people said: Prohibited, prohibited. That reached the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so he said: (O people, it is not for me to prohibit what Allah has made lawful for me, but it is a plant whose smell I dislike). 2 - From Ibn Khabbab from him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by an onion plantation, he and his companions. Some people dismounted and ate from it, and others did not eat. We went to him, and he called those who did not eat onion and delayed the others) until its smell went away. Extracted by Muslim, and Al-Bayhaqi extracted it from the first perspective. 3 - From Bakr bin Sawadah that Abu Al-Najib, the freed slave of Abdullah bin Sa'd, told him that Abu Sa'id al-Khudri told him: That garlic and onion were mentioned in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. It was said: O Messenger of Allah, and the strongest of all that is garlic, do you prohibit it? The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Eat it. And whoever among you eats, let him not approach this mosque until its smell leaves him).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Narrated by Abu Dawood. Its chain is good (Hasan) in witnesses; all its narrators are trustworthy men of the (Sahih) except this Abu Al-Najib. Ibn Hibban alone declared him trustworthy, and no narrator from him was mentioned other than this Bakr. In (Al-Taqrib): (He is acceptable). I say: Ibn Khuzaimah narrated it in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib) (1/134). It has a witness which is (the Sixth) and another which is the one after it. 4 - From Bishr bin Harb: I heard Abu Sa'id al-Khudri narrating, he said: We raided Fadak and Khaybar with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. He said: Allah opened Fadak and Khaybar for His Messenger. The people fell upon a vegetable of theirs, this garlic and onion. He said: So they went to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he found its smell and was harmed by it. Then the people returned, and he said: (Beware, do not eat it. Whoever eats anything of it, let him not approach our gathering). The Hadith was extracted by Ahmad. Its chain is good (Hasan), Allah willing. Its narrators are trustworthy men of the Two Sheikhs except this Bishr, who is truthful with some leniency as in (Al-Taqrib). Fifth: Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by Ibn Shihab from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from him with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Whoever eats from this plant, let him not approach our mosque and not harm us with the smell of garlic). Extracted by Muslim - and the wording is his - and Ibn Majah and Ahmad. Al-Mundhiri attributed it to Al-Nasa'i also, but I did not find it there; perhaps it is in his (Sunan Al-Kubra). This is the fifth Hadith, and it is in (Al-Musnad). Sixth: Abdullah bin Umar. Narrated by Ubaidullah bin Umar from Nafi' from him with the wording: (Whoever eats from this plant - meaning garlic - let him not approach our mosque). Extracted by Al-Bukhari and Al-Darimi, and they added: (in the Battle of Khaybar). And Muslim, and he added at its end: (until its smell goes away). And Ibn Majah and Ahmad. And from him Abu Dawood with the wording: (The mosques). In a copy of Muslim: (our mosques), which is what Al-Mundhiri quoted from him, then said: (And in a narration for both of them: (let him not come to the mosques). I say: It is a narration of Muslim, and it contains the addition that is in Al-Bukhari. As for this narration, I did not find it with him. Al-Hafiz attributed it in (Sharh Al-Bukhari) to Muslim alone. If it were with Al-Bukhari himself, he would have attributed it to him. Allah knows best. Seventh: Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah, who said: I ate garlic and came to the prayer place of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, having missed one Rak'ah. When I entered the mosque, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, found the smell of garlic. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, finished his prayer, he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Whoever eats from this plant, let him not approach us until its smell - or his smell - goes away). When I finished the prayer, I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah, give me your hand. He said: So I put his hand inside the sleeve of my shirt to my chest, and behold, my chest was bound (1) (he tied his belly with a band due to hunger). He said: ( indeed you have an excuse). Extracted by Abu Dawood: Shayban bin Farrukh told us: Abu Hilal told us: Humaid bin Hilal told us from Abu Burdah from him. This is a good chain; all its narrators are trustworthy men of Muslim except Abu Hilal, whose name is Muhammad bin Sulaym Al-Rasibi, who is truthful with some leniency as in (Al-Taqrib). Ahmad extracted it from Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi from him briefly. Eighth: Qurrah Abu Mu'awiyah: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade these two plants and said: (Whoever eats them, let him not approach our mosque). And he said: (If you must...) The Hadith, which is the sixth. Extracted by Abu Dawood and Ahmad via Abd al-Malik bin Amr who said: Khalid ibn Maysarah told us: Mu'awiyah bin Qurrah told us from his father.
foot_note: 1. (1) It was their custom that if one of them was hungry, he would tie his belly with a band and perhaps put a stone under it. (Nihayah).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a good chain; its narrators are trustworthy men of the Two Sheikhs except Khalid bin Maysarah, who is truthful as Ibn Adi said. Al-Hafiz said: (He is Salih al-Hadith / good in Hadith). Ninth: Ma'qil bin Yasar who said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, on a journey of his, and we camped in a place with much garlic. Some people among the Muslims partook of it, then came to the prayer place praying with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. He forbade them from it. Then they came after that to the prayer place, and he forbade them from it. Then they came after that to the prayer place, and he forbade them from it. Then they came after that to the prayer place, and he found its smell from them. He said: (Whoever eats from this plant, let him not approach us in our mosque). Extracted by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Saghir) briefly via Al-Hakam bin Tahman Abu Izzah Al-Dabbagh from Abu Al-Rabab the freed slave of Ma'qil bin Yasar from Ma'qil with it. Al-Haythami said after citing it briefly: (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Saghir), and in it is Abu Al-Zayyat who is unknown). I say: Thus it appeared in our copy of it: Al-Zayyat. With Zai then Ya then Ta. What is in (Al-Musnad) in two places and Al-Tabarani is: Al-Rabab with Ra then two Bas (1). In any case, I did not find anyone who wrote his biography.
foot_note: 1. (1) And thus it appeared in (Al-Ta'jil), and he mentioned him among the Sheikhs of Al-Hakam bin Tahman.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Hakam bin Tahman is Ibn Abi Al-Qasim. He said in (Al-Ta'jil): (Abu Zur'ah said: A trustworthy Sheikh, a righteous man. Abu Hatim said: Acceptable [La ba'sa bihi], Salih al-Hadith. Ibn Hibban weakened him in (Al-Dhayl). I say: And Ibn Ma'in also declared him trustworthy). Tenth: Abu Tha'labah Al-Khushani who said: I raided with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, Khaybar, and the people were hungry... The Hadith. He said: And we found in its gardens onions and garlic, and the people were hungry, so they strove [ate] and went, and lo, the mosque smelled of onion and garlic. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Whoever eats from this foul vegetable, let him not approach us...) The Hadith. Extracted by Ahmad via Baqiyyah from Bahir bin Sa'd from Khalid bin Ma'dan from Jubayr bin Nufayr from him. This is a chain whose narrators are trustworthy, except that Baqiyyah is a Mudallis and used 'an'an. Regarding the Hadith, Al-Mundhiri said, followed by Al-Haythami: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) with a good chain). I say: Firstly, the Hadith is in (Al-Musnad), so it should have been attributed to it. Secondly, it contains 'an'an' from a Mudallis, which negates its goodness (Husn). Perhaps Baqiyyah explicitly stated narration in Al-Tabarani's narration. In these Hadiths is an emphasized prohibition forbidding one who ate garlic and the like from entering

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: every mosque. This is the school of all scholars except what was narrated from some that the prohibition is specific to his mosque, peace and blessings be upon him, due to his saying in the first wording: (our mosque). This is not proof because the third Hadith indicated that the mentioned saying was issued by him, peace be upon him, following the Battle of Khaybar and its conquest. So his saying: (our mosque) means the place prepared for prayer during his stay there, or the intent by mosque is the genus and the addition is to the Muslims, i.e., let him not approach the mosque of the Muslims. This is supported by the second wording: our mosques. I say: This is strengthened by the reasoning of harming Muslims and angels, and this is realized in every mosque as is obvious. Then this reasoning necessitates two matters not explicitly stated in the Hadith: First: Appending gathering places of worship to mosques, such as the prayer place of Eid and funerals and the like. This is also supported by the generality of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Let him not approach us nor pray with us). Al-Hafiz said: (Some appended them by analogy, and holding to this generality is better. Its parallel is his saying: (and let him sit in his house)). Second: Appending everything that has a foul smell from foods and others to garlic. Al-Nawawi reported it from scholars and said: (Al-Qadi said: Appended to it is one who ate radish and was burping. He said: And Ibn

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Murabit said: Appended to it is one who has halitosis in his mouth or has a wound with a smell). I say: There is clear questionability in what Ibn Al-Murabit said, because the smell from the mentioned ones is not by their earning nor by their choice, so it is not correct to append them to the first ones, for they are choosers in that, able to avoid it if they wish. Therefore, Ibn Al-Munir said in (Al-Hashiyah): (Some of our companions appended the leper and others to the garlic eater in prevention from entering the mosque). He said: (This is open to question because the garlic eater introduced this impediment upon himself by his choice, while the leper's ailment is heavenly). I say: So he is excused thereby and is not prevented from entering. This is supported by the fact that when Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah found the smell of garlic on him, peace and blessings be upon him, and objected to him, and he showed him his excuse - which is that he only ate it out of hunger - he excused him as preceded in the seventh Hadith. So the leper and the like are excused a fortiori (1). Al-Hafiz said: (Some appended to that one who has halitosis in his mouth or has a wound with a smell. Some added and appended those with professions like the fishmonger, and those with disabilities like the leper, and one who harms people
foot_note: 1. (1) Except that it might be said: It is permissible to prevent the leper not because of the smell, but because his disease is contagious and harms the worshiper, and he is ordered to stay away from him by his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Flee from the leper as you flee from the lion). Since implementing this order necessitates all or some worshipers staying away from the mosque and suspending or reducing congregational prayer, and the violation in that is not hidden, therefore it requires preventing the leper from this aspect, and appending to him everyone with a contagious disease. And Allah knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: with his tongue. Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid indicated that all of this is unsatisfactory expansion). In summary, what is doubtless and almost agreed upon among scholars is: That the reason of harm necessitates preventing everyone who consumes something with a foul smell, whether food, drink, or otherwise, from entering, provided he is choosing that, not compelled like medication or a profession like butchery and the like. I say: It is almost agreed upon because Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, disagreed in it, where he said: (Whoever eats garlic, onion, or leek, it is obligatory on him not to pray in the mosque until the smell goes away, and it is obligatory to remove him from the mosque if he enters before the cessation of the smell. If he prays in the mosque like that, he has no prayer. And no one is prevented from the mosque other than those we mentioned, neither one with halitosis, nor a leper, nor one with a disability). Then he cited the Hadith of Umar coming next and the Hadith of Jabir, then said: (Ali said: He, peace be upon him, did not prevent anyone from attending mosques other than those we mentioned {And he does not speak from [his own] inclination} {And never is your Lord forgetful}). I say: This is rigidity from him on the wording without looking at the meaning, for the reasoning in Jabir's Hadith by 'harm' indicates clearly the prohibition of everything whose smell harms, according to the detail we mentioned just now. Therefore we say decisively: The first of those appended to garlic is: The foul plant known as (tobacco), because the stench

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: of its smell is more harmful to Muslims than garlic and others mentioned in the text of the Hadith, as testified by everyone whom Allah saved from this calamity which hardly anyone escapes except a few. Indeed, the afflicted themselves testify to that, may Allah heal them from it. And Allah will not heal them unless they follow its path: {As for he who gives and fears Allah. And believes in the best [reward]. We will ease him toward ease}. That is the Sunnah of Allah in His servants, and you will not find for the Sunnah of Allah any change. Indeed, it is a severe punishment that these and their likes are prevented from entering mosques where believers gather and close angels attend, thus being deprived of witnessing the abundant good which contains multiplication of prayer by twenty-seven degrees. More severe than that is that they be expelled from them - if they enter - forcibly and by power, as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to do as will come. Indeed in that is a lesson {So take warning, O people of vision} [Al-Hashr / 2]. He said in (Al-Fath): (Benefit): The ruling of the courtyard of the mosque and what is close to it is its ruling. Therefore, if he, peace and blessings be upon him, found its smell in the mosque, he would order the one from whom it was found to be expelled to Al-Baqi' as established in Muslim). I say: Perhaps the expression with his saying: (let him not approach) is to convey this meaning, unlike if he said: let him not enter. So reflect. Then he said: (Note): It occurred in the Hadith of Hudhayfah in Ibn Khuzaimah: (Whoever eats from this foul vegetable, let him not approach our mosque three times). And he titled it: The time of prohibition from coming to

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the congregation for eating garlic. This is questionable due to the possibility that his saying: (three times) relates to the saying, i.e., he said that three times. Rather, this is the apparent meaning because the cause of prevention is the presence of the smell, and it does not last this period). Then the prohibition in the previous Hadiths implies forbiddance (Tahrim). The literalists (Zahiriyyah) went to this, including Ibn Hazm, and the text of his words on that has preceded shortly. It is the truth, Allah willing, for several reasons: First: That the default in prohibition is forbiddance, so it is not permissible to depart from it except for evidence or context, and there is nothing of that here. Second: That it was coupled with the emphasized Nun of confirmation, and that confirms the prohibition and forbiddance. Third: That it forfeits congregational prayer, which is obligatory according to the most correct opinions as will be explained in its place, so leaving it is forbidden. If entering the mosque for those mentioned in the Hadith were not more forbidden, the Wise Lawgiver would not have punished them by preventing them from it and would not have wasted on them the multiplication mentioned just now. And Allah Almighty says: {Indeed, Allah does not do injustice, [even] as much as an atom's weight; while if there is a good deed, He multiplies it and gives from Himself a great reward} [An-Nisa / 40]. He, Glorified and Exalted, knows best. From what we mentioned, you know that arguing with the Hadith that congregation is not an individual obligation is not correct, because the Lawgiver only forbade them from it as a punishment for them for coming to it with what is a greater crime than leaving it without excuse.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Among the evidence that the prohibition is for forbiddance is that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to order the expulsion of whoever had the smell of garlic or onion from the mosque. This is not the status of one who committed a disliked act (Makruh) as is not hidden. Therefore we said: (It is obligatory on the capable to expel them from the mosque due to the Hadith of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: (Indeed you, O people, eat two plants which I do not see as anything but foul: this onion and garlic. I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, if he found their smell from a man in the mosque, he ordered him to be taken out to Al-Baqi'. So whoever eats them, let him kill them by cooking). The Hadith was extracted by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via Qatadah from Salim bin Abi Al-Ja'd Al-Ghatafani from Ma'dan bin Abi Talhah Al-Ya'mari that Umar bin Al-Khattab said... so he mentioned it. Al-Nawawi said: (In it is the expulsion of one from whom the smell of garlic, onion, and the like is found from the mosque, and removing the evil by hand for whoever is able). Al-Sindi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: (Perhaps in the expulsion to Al-Baqi' is an alert that it is not appropriate for him to accompany the living, rather he should accompany the dead who are not harmed by his like, or it is to indicate that he has joined the dead who do not remember Allah and do not pray, since he caused himself to be prevented from mosques. It is possible they were put [in] that direction for discipline). I say: The apparent meaning of the command implies the obligation of expulsion, and Ibn Hazm explicitly stated that as

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: preceded. So it is another proof for the prohibition of entering the mosque for these people, because it corresponds to obligation. (Except for one who ate them for an excuse like hunger or medication, he enters and is not expelled due to the Hadith of Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah who said: (I ate garlic and came to the prayer place of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, having missed one Rak'ah. When I entered the mosque, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, found the smell of garlic. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, finished the prayer, he said: (Whoever eats from this plant, let him not approach us until its smell - or his smell - goes away). When I finished the prayer, I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah, give me your hand. He said: So I put his hand inside the sleeve of my shirt to my chest, and behold, my chest was bound. He said: (Indeed you have an excuse). The Hadith was extracted by Abu Dawood with a good chain as preceded in the extraction of the chapter's Hadiths. Al-Bayhaqi also extracted it in (Al-Sunan Al-Kubra). As for the Hadith which Al-Bukhari cited in a suspended form saying: (And the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: Whoever eats garlic and onion out of hunger or otherwise, let him not approach our mosque), Al-Hafiz said: (I did not see the restriction to hunger and otherwise explicitly, but it is taken from the speech of the Companion in some paths of Jabir's Hadith and others. In Muslim from the narration of Abu Al-Zubair from Jabir, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade eating onion and leek, but need overcame us... The Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He has from the narration of Abu Nadra from Abu Sa'id: We had not yet exceeded the conquest of Khaybar when we fell upon this vegetable, and the people were hungry... The Hadith. Ibn Al-Munir said in (Al-Hashiyah): Some of our companions appended the leper and others to the garlic eater in prevention from the mosque. He said: And this is open to question because the garlic eater introduced this impediment upon himself by his choice, while the leper's ailment is heavenly. He said: But his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: out of hunger or otherwise. Indicates equality between them. End quote. It is as if he saw Al-Bukhari's saying in the heading 'And the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him' to the end, and thought it was the wording of a Hadith. It is not so; rather it is from Al-Bukhari's jurisprudence and his allowance of mentioning Hadith by meaning). So the Hadith does not indicate the meaning Al-Bukhari went to, due to the possibility that he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not know that need and hunger were what drove them to eat. Indeed, this is the apparent meaning because if he, peace and blessings be upon him, knew that, he would have excused them as in this Hadith of Al-Mughirah. Based on this, the Hadith indicates the difference between the needy and others, not the equality between them as Ibn Al-Munir imagined due to Al-Bukhari's narration of the Hadith by meaning. So reflect. (4 - Taking a specific place in it to pray in, not moving to another, due to the Hadith: (He, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade the pecking of the crow, the spreading of the beast of prey, and that a man settles in the place in the mosque (and in a wording: the one place, and in another: the place he prays in) as a camel settles). The Hadith is from the narration of Abd al-Rahman bin Shibl, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: He forbade... The Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi - and the other wording is his - and Ahmad - and the second wording is his - all from Ja'far bin Abdullah ibn Al-Hakam from Tamim bin Muhammad from him. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic chain). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Ibn Khuzaimah and Ibn Hibban also narrated it in their (Sahihs) as in (Al-Targhib). I say: There is doubt regarding the authenticity of its chain in my view. That is because Al-Dhahabi himself listed this Tamim in (Al-Mizan) and said: (Al-Bukhari said: There is some question about him). Al-Uqayli, Al-Dawlabi, and Ibn Al-Jarud mentioned him in (Al-Du'afa). As for Ibn Hibban, he declared him trustworthy as is his habit in declaring trustworthy those not famous for narration, for they mentioned no narrator for him other than the mentioned Ja'far bin Abdullah. As for Al-Dhahabi's statement: (Uthman bin Abd al-Rahman Al-Tara'ifi narrated from him), it is a clear error, for he - meaning Al-Tara'ifi - died in year two or three and two hundred, so how can he narrate from Tamim who is a Tabi'i from the fourth layer according to Ibn Hajar in (Al-Taqrib), and he mentioned in it that he is: (Lenient). I say: However, the Hadith is strengthened by the witness extracted by Ahmad in (Al-Musnad):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Isma'il told us: Uthman Al-Batti informed us from Abd al-Hamid bin Salamah from his father that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade the pecking of the crow, the spreading of the beast of prey, and that a man settles in his place in prayer as a camel settles. Its narrators are trustworthy except this Abd al-Hamid, who is unknown as in (Al-Taqrib). His saying: (and that a man settles in the place in the mosque as a camel settles). Al-Khattabi said in (Al-Ma'alim) followed by Ibn Al-Athir in (Al-Nihayah): (It has two aspects: One: That a man frequents a known place in the mosque not praying except in it, like a camel does not seek shelter from its resting place except a smooth kneeling place it has settled in and taken as a resting place, not kneeling except in it. The other aspect: That he kneels on his knees before his hands when he wants to prostrate, like the kneeling of a camel on the place it settled in. And that he not drop down in his prostration bending his knees until he places them on the ground with stillness and deliberation). I say: Ibn Al-Athir did not mention his saying: (And that he not drop down...) etc. Perhaps the reason for that is it being contradictory to what preceded it where he said: (That he kneels on his knees... like the kneeling of a camel). And in this he says: (bending his knees...) etc. It seems Al-Khattabi, may Allah have mercy on him, sees that the consideration is not placing the knees before the hands, but rather the thud resulting from placing them so on the ground as heard from the camel. So if he places them so with stillness and deliberation without sound, he has exited resemblance to the animal, so the prohibition does not include them on the second view. But this is not possible usually, meaning placing them

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: before the hands without a thud as is witnessed. Therefore the prohibition of it is established from his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, just as it is established that his guidance is contrary to that, which is that the Sunnah in prostration, by word from him, peace and blessings be upon him, and action, is placing the hands before the knees to avoid resemblance to the camel which kneels on its knees which are in its forelegs, contrary to those who claimed otherwise. I have clarified this in (Al-Ta'liqat Al-Jiyad 'ala Zad Al-Ma'ad) and its explanation will also come in the appropriate place in this book, Allah willing. However, this second aspect is very far from the Hadith, especially with the collection of its wordings mentioned above. They determine that the intended meaning is the first aspect. A group of commentators asserted it. Some limited themselves to it and did not address mentioning the second aspect, indicating it is not considered, like Al-Munawi and others. Some explicitly stated the improbability of the mentioned aspect, like Al-Sindi, may Allah have mercy on him, in his (Hashiyah) on Al-Nasa'i and Sheikh Ali Al-Qari in (Al-Mirqat). The text of his words on that is: (The second meaning is not correct here because it cannot be what is likened to. Also, if this meaning were intended, the prohibition would not have been specific to the place in the mosque. Since he mentioned [place], it indicated that the intent is the first. Ibn Hajar said: Its wisdom is that it leads to fame, showing off (Riya'), reputation, and being bound by habits, fortunes, and desires. All these are calamities and calamities, so avoiding what leads to them as much as possible is determined). The apparent meaning of the prohibition implies the forbiddance (Tahrim) of these three mentioned in the Hadith. Regarding the prohibition

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: of the first two are other Hadiths whose mention will come in their places, Allah willing. Ibn Al-Humam said: (In (Al-Nihayah) from Al-Halwani that he mentioned regarding fasting from our companions: It is disliked to take a specific place in the mosque in it because worship becomes a habit for him in it and becomes heavy elsewhere, and worship if it becomes a habit, the way is to leave it. And so perpetual fasting was disliked. End quote. So how about one who took it for another corrupt purpose). Dislike (Karahah) if used absolutely by our scholars means forbiddance (Tahrim). This is the truth in this issue, Allah willing. Sheikh Jamal Al-Din Al-Qasimi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Islah Al-Masajid): (Some regular attendees of congregation love a specific place or corner of the mosque, either behind the Imam, or beside the pulpit, or in front of it, or at the end of its right or left wall, or the raised platform at its back, such that they do not enjoy worship or staying except in it. If he sees someone preceded him to it, he might force him to move away for him because it is monopolized, or he leaves it angry or saying Hawqalah or Istirja'. The one staying in it might surprise by saying it is his place since such and such year. He might seek help from his likes among ignorant ascetics to make him stand from it... to other forms of ignorance with which most mosques are afflicted. It is not hidden that the love of a place in the mosque specifically arises from ignorance or showing off and reputation, and that it be said: He does not pray except in such place, or he is of the people of the first row, which is

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: among what nullifies the deed if noticed and loved, we seek refuge in Allah. Even if this settler did not intend that, at least he loses the pleasure of worship due to excessive familiarity and greed for this place such that nothing calls him to the mosque except his spot. Prohibition of that has been reported). I say: Then he mentioned the Hadith then said: (In (Sharh Al-Iqna'): It is disliked for other than the Imam to persist in a place in it praying only in it). Then he said: (In most large mosques there is a group that adheres to [the area] behind the Imam opposite the Mihrab. They come to the mosque before prayer and take their rows and specific places because each one of them has a specific place in that spot from which he rarely deviates. It may happen that someone comes from the people thinking there is a gap there or hoping space will be made for him. If the comer is of status in knowledge or position, they forgive him. If he is of a class other than them, some of them stick to their place and do not make space, even if the place allows making space. Some of them, if they sense his coming, sit cross-legged to take the amount of expected space and restrict him. If prayer is established and someone enters, if there is ample space in the place after Iqamah, they tolerate his intrusion. If there is not sufficient space but they can make space, then do not ask about their strange behaviors. Some of them leave their place and go to the second row sulking, filled with rage and anger. Some of them signal him to return and say: There is no place there. Some of them make noise, say Uff, say Hawqalah, and dispute in whispers. He might complete his noise after prayer since he would have estimated within himself while in prayer what to reprimand him with and rebuke him for

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: his action. It may happen that a new adherer comes with them and precedes one of them to his place and sits in it. When this old adherer arrives and sees his place taken, sometimes he sulks to the end of the row and looks at his place with a hidden glance, regretful and enraged at this one who usurped his place. Patience might not accommodate him, so you see him speaking openly and saying to him: (O brother, we are not children of yesterday and today in this mosque; we have been praying in this place for forty years, so where is the taste/manners?) So reflect on what these ignorant ones bring and reflect on their worship stuffed with showing off, vanity, and arrogance. Is there a trace of fear [of Allah] in the hearts of such people, or existence of the fruit of prayer in them? No! How much they need an educator and discipliner. And Allah is the One sought for help). I say: I have witnessed one of these - and he is a commoner - who prays only behind the Imam, not deviating right or left by a hair's breadth. Whoever competes with him for that, even if he is a person of knowledge, he looks at him with a look sufficient to turn him back from competing with him. This, along with falling into the mentioned prohibition, has also opposed his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Let those of understanding and intellect among you be near me). Narrated by Muslim and others, and it will come. This is among the evils of opposing him, peace be upon him. Such a man is more deserving of what Ubayy bin Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him, did to Qais bin Abbad who said: While I was in the mosque in Medina in the front row, a man pulled me from behind a pull, moved me aside, and stood in my place. By Allah, I did not comprehend my prayer. When he finished, lo, it was Ubayy bin Ka'b. He said: O young man, may Allah not grieve you. Indeed, this is a covenant from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to us that we be near him... The Hadith

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Nasa'i recorded it, and its chain is Sahih; its men are the men of Al-Bukhari except Muhammad bin Umar bin Ali bin Muqaddam, Al-Nasa'i's Sheikh in it, who he authenticated. Yusuf bin Yaqub in it is Ibn Abi Al-Qasim Al-Duba'i. It has another path in (Al-Musnad) from Qais, and its chain is also Sahih; all its men are trustworthy men of Muslim except Iyas bin Qatada, who was authenticated by Ibn Sa'd and Ibn Hibban. Abu Hamza in it is Abdul Rahman bin Abdullah or Ibn Abi Abdullah Al-Mazini, Shu'ba's neighbor. (5 - Sitting of people in a circle before the Friday prayer, even for knowledge and discussion, due to the hadith: (The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade buying and selling in the mosque, reciting poetry in it, [announcing lost property in it], [and sitting in circles (and in a wording: that people sit in circles) on Friday before the prayer]). The hadith was recorded by Abu Dawood and Al-Nasa'i separately, as well as Ibn Majah, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad - and the context is his. All of them via the path of Muhammad bin Ajlan from Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas. The two additions are with all of them except Al-Nasa'i and Al-Tahawi - they do not have the first one - and likewise...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tirmidhi, except that he indicated it in the chapter title where he said: (Chapter: What came regarding the dislike of buying and selling, announcing lost property, and poetry in the mosque). Ibn Majah and Al-Bayhaqi do not have the other addition. The other wording in it belongs to Al-Tirmidhi. Then he said: (Hasan Hadith). Amr bin Shu'aib is Ibn Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas. Muhammad bin Ismail (meaning Al-Bukhari) said: (I saw Ahmad and Ishaq - and he mentioned others - using the hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib as evidence. Muhammad said: Shu'aib bin Muhammad heard from his grandfather Abdullah bin Amr. Abu Isa said: Those who spoke against the hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib only weakened him because he narrates from his grandfather's scroll; as if they saw that he did not hear these hadiths from his grandfather. Ali bin Abdullah said: It was mentioned from Yahya bin Saeed that he said: The hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib is flimsy with us). The truth is that his hadith (is not from the highest categories of Sahih, rather it is of the Hasan type) as Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan) after recounting the sayings of the Imams about him. The defect raised by those who defected it claiming he did not hear from his grandfather is refuted by narrations established wherein he explicitly stated hearing from him, as clarified by the researcher Ahmad Muhammad Shakir in his commentary on Al-Tirmidhi, so let whoever wishes review it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Furthermore, Muhammad bin Ajlan is spoken of, though he is Hasan in hadith as preceded repeatedly. Usama bin Zaid followed him in Ahmad, limiting it to the first sentence. Al-Hafiz cited the second sentence from him and said: (Recorded by Ibn Khuzaima in his (Sahih) and Al-Tirmidhi who classified it as Hasan. Its chain is Sahih to Amr, so whoever authenticates his copy authenticates it). Perhaps it is in Ibn Khuzaima via a path other than Ibn Ajlan's path which Al-Tirmidhi narrated from, for I do not believe Al-Hafiz would authenticate a chain containing Ibn Ajlan. And Allah knows best. Al-Khattabi said in (Al-Ma'alim): (Al-Hilaq): with a Kasra on the Ha and Fatha on the Lam: plural of Halqah (circle). Some of our Sheikhs used to narrate it as (forbade Al-Halq) with a Sukun on the Lam, and he told me that he remained for forty years not shaving his head before the prayer on Friday. So I said to him: It is only (Al-Hilaq) plural of Halqah. He only disliked gathering before the prayer for knowledge and discussion, and commanded to be occupied with prayer and listening to the sermon and dhikr. When finished, gathering and forming circles is after that. He said: You have relieved me, may He reward me well. He was one of the righteous, may Allah have mercy on him. In (Al-Mirqat): (The reason for the prohibition is that when people form circles, talking and raising voices usually prevail over them, and if they are like that, they do not listen to the sermon while they are commanded to listen to it. Thus said...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...some of them. Al-Nurbashti said: The prohibition bears two meanings: First: That this formation contradicts the gathering of worshipers. Second: That the gathering for Friday prayer is a grave matter; one who attends it cannot concern himself with anything else until he finishes. People forming circles before prayer suggests heedlessness of the command they were called to. In (Sharh Al-Sunnah): The hadith implies the dislike of forming circles on Friday before prayer for discussing knowledge; rather, one should occupy oneself with Dhikr, prayer, and listening to the sermon, and there is no harm after that. In (Al-Ihya'): Sitting in circles before prayer is disliked). In (Nayl Al-Awtar): (The majority interpreted the prohibition as dislike (Karahah), because it might cut the rows, while they are commanded to come early on Friday and align in rows, the first then the first. Al-Tahawi said: Forming circles which is forbidden before prayer is when it covers the mosque and dominates it, then it is disliked; otherwise, there is no harm. The restriction to 'before prayer' indicates its permissibility afterwards for knowledge and Dhikr. The restriction to 'Friday' indicates its permissibility on other days, as in the agreed-upon hadith from Abu Waqid Al-Laithi who said: While the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was in the mosque, three people came. Two approached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and one went away. As for one of them, he saw a gap in the circle and sat in it, and the other sat behind them... The hadith. As for forming circles in the mosque for worldly matters, it is not permissible. In the hadith of Ibn Masud: There will be in the end of times people who sit in mosques in circles, their desires are the world; do not sit with them for Allah has no need in them. Al-Iraqi mentioned it in (Sharh Al-Tirmidhi)...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He said: Its chain is weak; it contains Bazi' Abu Al-Khalil, who is very weak). I say: Al-Haythami cited this hadith of Ibn Masud in (Al-Majma') with this wording and said: (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and it contains Bazi' Abu Al-Khalil, who was accused of fabrication). Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Accused; Ibn Hibban said: He brings fabricated things from trustworthy narrators as if he intends them). Then Al-Dhahabi listed hadiths for him, including this one, then said: (Ibn Adi said: He has denounced narrations like this that are not corroborated). However, Al-Mundhiri cited the hadith in (Al-Targhib) with the wording: (And from Abdullah - meaning: Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him - who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (There will be in the end of times people whose conversation in their mosques... Allah has no need in them). Recorded by Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih). It appears from this that Abu Al-Khalil was not unique in narrating the hadith, for two reasons: First: Ibn Hibban spoke very harshly about him as you heard, so it is very unlikely that he would narrate this hadith for him in his (Sahih). Thus, he must have narrated it from another path. Second: That Al-Mundhiri prefaced it with (wa 'an) [And from], indicating that it is Sahih or...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Hasan or close to them. He does not do that (if the chain contains someone said to be: a liar, fabricator, accused, agreed to be abandoned or weak, or...) as he stated in the book's introduction. For such cases, he prefaces with the word: (Ruwiya) [It was narrated] to indicate its weakness. You have seen that Abu Al-Khalil is accused of fabrication, so it is inconceivable that he would preface what he narrated with the word (An) [From]. This and what preceded indicate that the hadith is in Ibn Hibban from another path. Nevertheless, I personally cannot rely on merely Ibn Hibban's authentication before seeing its chain and narrators, due to what we know of his leniency in that, as we have pointed out repeatedly on various occasions. If we find it and judge it Sahih or at least Hasan, it must be mentioned in the main text of the book. And Allah is the Guardian of success (1). Then Al-Ghazali cited the hadith in (Al-Ihya') with the wording: (There will come in the end of times people from my nation who will come to mosques and sit in them in circles, their mention is the world and love of the world; do not sit with them for Allah has no need in them).
foot_note: 1. (1) Then what I deduced was confirmed, for I found the hadith in (Takhrij Al-Kashshaf) by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar. He said (p. 73, no. 94): (Recorded by Al-Tabarani from the narration of Abu Wa'il from Ibn Masud raised [to the Prophet]: (There will be in the end of times people sitting in mosques in circles, their desire is the world; do not sit with them for Allah has no need in them). In it is Bazi' Abu Al-Khalil, its narrator from Al-A'mash from him, and he is Matruk [abandoned]. Al-Daraqutni said: He was unique in it. This is questionable, for Ibn Hibban recorded it in his (Sahih) via the path of Isa bin Yunus from Al-A'mash with the wording:... I say: So he mentioned it. He said: In the chapter from Anas raised [to the Prophet]. I say: So he cited it via the path of Al-Hakim and remained silent on it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in his Takhrij: (Ibn Hibban narrated it from the hadith of Ibn Masud, and Al-Hakim from the hadith of Anas and said: Sahih Al-Isnad [Correct chain]). I say: This is a third matter supporting what I went to, because if the hadith were in Ibn Hibban via the path of Abu Al-Khalil, Al-Iraqi would not have remained silent on it here, just as he did not remain silent on it in (Sharh Al-Tirmidhi) as previously quoted from Al-Shawkani. However, his silence on Al-Hakim's authentication is not good. Stranger than that is Al-Dhahabi's agreement with him on its authentication. He recorded it in (Al-Mustadrak) via the path of Ahmad bin Bakr Al-Bali: Zaid bin Al-Hubab narrated to us: Sufyan Al-Thawri narrated to us from Awn bin Abi Juhaifah from Al-Hasan bin Abi Al-Hasan from Anas raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (There will come upon people a time when they will form circles in their mosques and their concern is nothing but the world; Allah has no need in them, so do not sit with them). He said: (Sahih Al-Isnad). Al-Dhahabi said the same, overlooking the criticism said about this Ahmad bin Bakr, which he himself mentioned in his (Mizan). Here is the text of his words: (Ahmad bin Bakr Al-Balisi, also called: Ibn Bakrawayh Abu Saeed. Ibn Adi said: He narrated denounced reports [Manakir] from trustworthy narrators. Then he listed three hadiths for him, among them from Hajjaj from Ibn Jurayj from Ata from Abu Saeed raised [to the Prophet]: Whoever hates Umar hates me, and whoever loves him loves me. Umar is with me wherever I reside, and I am with Umar wherever he resides. Muhammad bin...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...Hamdun Al-Naysaburi narrated to us: Ahmad narrated to us. Abu Al-Fath Al-Azdi said: He used to fabricate hadith). Al-Hafiz added to it in (Al-Lisan) what is summarized as: (Al-Daraqutni said: Others are more established than him. He said in Ghara'ib Malik: Weak. Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat) and said: He used to err. I say: He has a fabricated hadith with a Sahih chain narrated from him by Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Al-Mufassir the trustworthy Egyptian - he said: And I have no other from him - from Ibn Jurayj from Ibn Abbas raised [to the Prophet]: Whoever strives for his brother in a need, his past and future sins are forgiven). (Benefit): As for the hadith famous on tongues: (Speech in the mosque consumes good deeds as fire consumes wood), it has no basis. Al-Ghazali cited it in (Al-Ihya') with the wording: (Hadith in the mosque consumes good deeds as animals consume grass). Its extractor Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said: (I did not find a basis for it). Furthermore, regarding the hadith, you have seen the scholars' disagreement on the reason for the prohibition of forming circles in it. It is not possible to be decisive on any of that due to the lack of a text from the Infallible. But its general wording includes every circle, even for knowledge and discussion, which is what is implied by the words of Al-Baghawi in (Sharh Al-Sunnah) and Al-Khattabi in (Al-Ma'alim). And Allah knows best. (6 - Reciting poetry against one another - which is boasting with poetry and doing it excessively until it dominates other things, and until much noise and disturbance is feared from it, contradicting the sanctity of mosques.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: For the previous hadith: (And he (forbade) that poetry be recited in it), and in a wording: (And regarding reciting poetry against one another). The hadith is from the narration of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather. Its referencing has preceded shortly. The other wording belongs to Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Bayhaqi. It has a witness from the hadith of Hakim bin Hizam who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade that retaliation be taken in the mosque, or hudud (punishments) be established in it, or poetry be recited in it. Recorded by Al-Daraqutni. The interpretation of 'Tanashud' (reciting against one another) as mentioned is the best interpretation said about it. I quoted it from the commentary of the scholar Ahmad Muhammad Shakir on Al-Tirmidhi. By it, one reconciles between the hadith and the hadiths indicating the permissibility of reciting poetry in mosques, as will be mentioned in (The Permissibles), number (11). Scholars differed regarding that; some forbade it absolutely and some permitted it absolutely. Al-Qurtubi said in his (Tafsir): (The best view is detailing: One should look at the poetry. If it entails praise of Allah Almighty or the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, or defending them, as Hassan's poetry was, or contains urging to do good, preaching, asceticism in the world and minimizing it, then it is good in mosques and elsewhere). He said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Whatever is not like that is not permissible, because poetry mostly is not free from obscenity, lies, and beautifying falsehood. Even if it is free from that, the least it has is idle talk and nonsense, and mosques are purified from that due to His saying: {In houses which Allah has permitted to be raised} [Al-Nur / 36]. It may be permissible to recite it in the mosque, like the saying of the poet: If rain falls on a people's land we graze it * Even if they are angry. This type, even if it has no praise or commendation, is permissible because it is free from obscenity and lies). (And for the coming hadith: (Mosques were only built for what they were built for). It is from the hadith of Buraydah in Muslim and others as will come. Al-Nawawi said: (Its meaning is for the remembrance of Allah, prayer, knowledge, discussion of good, and the like). So they were not built for reciting poetry in them, so it was forbidden (1). (7 - Announcing lost property, seeking it, and asking about it by raising the voice, for the previous hadith also: (And he (forbade) that lost property be announced in it).
foot_note: 1. (1) (Benefit): As for the hadith recorded by Ibn Al-Sunni in (Amal Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah) (p. 53, no. 150) via the path of Abbad bin Kathir from Yazid bin Khusaifah from Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman bin Thawban from his father from his grandfather Thawban raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Whoever you see reciting poetry in the mosque, say: May Allah break your mouth, three times), it is weak in chain. Abbad bin Kathir is Al-Ramli Al-Filastini (weak) as in (Al-Taqrib). And Abdul Rahman bin Thawban, I did not find anyone who wrote his biography. Others narrated it from Yazid bin Khusaifah differing from Abbad bin Kathir in both text and chain as will come.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith is a sentence from the hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather, and it preceded completely in paragraph (5), and its referencing preceded there. It says in (Al-Nihayah): (It is said: Nashadtu al-dallata fa-ana nashid: if I sought it. And Anshadtuha: if I defined/identified it. It is from Al-Nashid: raising the voice). The hadith contains evidence for the prohibition of asking about a lost animal in the mosque provided it is done by raising the voice. Ibn Hazm and Al-San'ani in (Subul Al-Salam) held this view, and it is the truth, God willing, because it is apparent from the prohibition, and because the Prophet, peace be upon him, ordered that the announcer be told what follows as a punishment for him: (And for the other hadith: (A Bedouin came after the Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed the Fajr prayer, so he stuck his head through the door of the mosque] and said: Who called (meaning: who found and called me) to the red camel? The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: May you not find it [May you not find it, may you not find it]. [These] mosques were only built for what they were built for). It is from the hadith of Buraydah, may Allah be pleased with him. Recorded by Muslim, and the first addition is his; and Ibn Majah, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad, as well as Ibn Al-Sunni and Al-Bayhaqi via paths from Alqamah bin Marthad from Sulaiman bin Buraydah from his father with it. The second and third additions are for Ahmad in a narration, and he has...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: from the first addition: (Fajr prayer), and likewise Al-Tayalisi except for the second addition. Al-Mundhiri attributed the hadith to Al-Nasa'i as well, but I did not find it in it; perhaps it is in (Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah) or in his (Al-Sunan Al-Kubra). The hadith has witnesses: First: From Jabir who said: A man came announcing a lost animal in the mosque, so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (May you not find it). Recorded by Al-Nasa'i via the path of Zaid bin Abi Anisa from Abu Al-Zubayr from him. Its chain is Sahih, all its men are trustworthy, were it not for the 'an'ana of Abu Al-Zubayr. Second: From Anas like the hadith of Jabir. He said in (Al-Majma'): (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) and its men are trustworthy, and Al-Bazzar recorded it with a weak chain).
