He said in another place: (In it is Musa bin Ubaidah Al-Rabadhi and he is weak). Third: From Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas like it. Al-Haythami said: (Recorded by Al-Bazzar and in it is Abu Saeed Al-Aghsham, whom I do not know, and Al-Hajjaj bin Artat who is a Mudallis). Fourth: From Abdullah bin Masud who said: We were ordered, if we saw someone announcing lost property in the mosque, to say to him: May you not find it. Recorded by Al-Bazzar, and its men are men of the Sahih except Muhammad bin Ismail bin Samurah who is...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: trustworthy. Al-Tabarani recorded it in (Al-Kabir) from Ibn Sirin or others who said: Ibn Masud heard a man announcing lost property in the mosque, so he silenced him and scolded him and said: We have been forbidden from this. Al-Mundhiri said, followed by Al-Haythami: (Ibn Sirin did not hear from Ibn Masud). I say: Ibn Al-Sunni recorded it via the path of Al-Sha'bi who said... and mentioned it with the wording: So he angered him, and a man said: O Abu Abdul Rahman, you were not obscene. He said: We were ordered with that. Its men are trustworthy but it is also disconnected, for Al-Sha'bi did not hear from Ibn Masud by agreement. (It is obligatory on whoever hears that to say to the announcer: (May Allah not return it to you, for mosques were not built for this), for he, peace be upon him, commanded that in his saying: (Whoever hears a man announcing lost property in the mosque, let him say... so he mentioned it. And in a wording: (May Allah not restore it to you)). The hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; Abu Abdullah the client of Shaddad bin Al-Had heard it from him. Recorded by Muslim, Ibn Majah, Ibn Al-Sunni, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad. The other wording belongs to the latter two via...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: the path of Haywah bin Shuraih from Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman Abu Al-Aswad from him. In (Al-Targhib), the hadith was attributed to Abu Dawood as well, but I did not find it with him right now. Al-San'ani said: (The hadith is evidence for the prohibition of asking about a lost animal in the mosque. Is asking about other things like luggage appended to it even if it was lost in the mosque? It is said: It is appended due to the reason (Illah) which is his saying: (for mosques were not built for this). Even if one lost luggage in it or elsewhere, sitting at the mosque door asking those exiting and entering [is permissible?]. Also, there is difference of opinion regarding teaching children Quran in the mosque; perhaps the preventer prevents it due to the raising of voices in it which is forbidden in the hadith of Wathila: (Keep your mosques free from your insane, your children, and your raising of voices). Recorded by Abdul Razzaq, Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and Ibn Majah). I say: But the chain of this hadith is weak as explained in the first paragraph of Etiquettes. In (Sahih Al-Bukhari) there is what contradicts it, which is the hadith of Ka'b bin Malik: That he demanded repayment of a debt from Ibn Abi Hadrad in the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in the mosque. Their voices rose until the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, heard them while he was in his house. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came out to them until he lifted the curtain of his room and called out: (O Ka'b bin Malik, O Ka'b). He said: At your service, O Messenger of Allah. He signaled with his hand to deduct half of your debt. Ka'b said: I have done so, O Messenger of Allah. The Messenger of Allah said: (Stand and pay him).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This hadith apparently indicates the permissibility of raising the voice in the mosque for a worldly purpose because he, peace be upon him, did not rebuke the disputants for raising their voices. However, Al-Bukhari narrated before it from Umar what contradicts it: From Al-Saib bin Yazid who said: (I was standing in the mosque when a man threw pebbles at me. I looked and it was Umar bin Al-Khattab. He said: Go and bring me these two. So I brought them to him. He said: Who are you or where are you from? They said: From the people of Taif. He said: If you were from the people of this city, I would have hurt you [beaten you]; you raise your voices in the mosque of the Messenger of Allah?) Al-Bukhari titled it: (Chapter: Raising the voice in mosques). Al-Hafiz said: (He indicated by the title the disagreement regarding that. Malik disliked it absolutely whether in knowledge or otherwise. Others differentiated between what relates to a religious purpose or worldly benefit and what has no benefit. Al-Bukhari cited in the chapter the hadith of Umar indicating prohibition and the hadith of Ka'b indicating its absence, hinting that prohibition is for what has no benefit, and its absence is for what necessity compels to. The discussion on it has preceded in the Chapter of Litigation. Hadiths have been narrated prohibiting raising voices in mosques, but they are weak; Ibn Majah extracted some of them, so it seems the author alluded to them). He said in the chapter he alluded to: (In the hadith is the permissibility of raising the voice in the mosque, and it is so unless it becomes excessive. The author has dedicated a chapter for it coming soon. What is reported from Malik is forbidding it in the mosque...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: absolutely. And from him is the differentiation between raising the voice for knowledge and good and what is necessary, so it is permissible, and between raising it for clamor and the like, so it is not. Al-Muhallab said: If raising the voice in the mosque were not permissible, the Prophet, peace be upon him, would not have left them and would have explained that to them. I say: Those who prohibit can say: Perhaps his prohibition of that preceded, so he sufficed with it and limited himself to achieving the means leading to abandoning that through reconciliation requiring the abandonment of the dispute causing the raising of voice). And Allah knows best. Then Al-San'ani said under his saying, peace be upon him: Let him say: (May Allah not return it to you): (A punishment for him for committing in the mosque what is not permissible. Its apparent meaning is that he says it aloud and that it is obligatory). (Or he says: (May you not find it, three times; these mosques were only built for what they were built for) as in the hadith before this). (8 - Buying and Selling, for the previous hadith (paragraph 5): (The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade buying and selling in the mosque). And it must be said to the seller or buyer: (May Allah not make your trade profitable). He, peace be upon him, commanded that in his saying: (If you see someone selling or buying in the mosque, say: May Allah not make your trade profitable. And if you see someone announcing lost property in it, say: May Allah not return it to you). The first hadith is from the narration of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather, and it is Hasan in...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: chain, and its referencing preceded there. The second hadith is from the hadith of Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet]. Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi via paths from Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad Al-Darawardi: Yazid bin Khusaifah informed us from Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman bin Thawban from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Hadith). Al-Hakim said: (Sahih according to the condition of Muslim), and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Ibn Khuzaima also recorded it as in (Al-Targhib), and likewise Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Shawkani restricted it: In (Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah). Ibn Al-Sunni narrated the first part in (Amal Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah) similarly, and Ibn Hibban narrated it in his (Sahih) and Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla) the second part similarly as well. The first addition belongs to Al-Darimi and likewise Al-Tirmidhi in a copy, and the other belongs to the first of them [Al-Darimi] and likewise Al-Bayhaqi. The hadith has been narrated from Abdul Rahman bin Thawban from his father raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Whoever you see reciting poetry in the mosque, say: May Allah break your mouth three times. And whoever you see announcing it [lost property] in the mosque, say: May you not find it three times. And whoever...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: you see selling and buying in the mosque, say: May Allah not make your trade profitable). Al-Haythami said: (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and I did not find anyone who wrote the biography of Abdul Rahman bin Thawban). I say: Ibn Al-Sunni narrated the first sentence of it via the path of Abbad bin Kathir from Yazid bin Khusaifah from Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman bin Thawban from his father from his grandfather. This Abbad is weak and contradicted Al-Darawardi in both chain and text, as preceded. Regarding the hadith, Al-Tirmidhi said: (The practice is upon this according to some people of knowledge; they disliked buying and selling in the mosque. This is the opinion of Ahmad and Ishaq. Some people of knowledge permitted buying and selling in the mosque). He mentioned similar to this regarding the first hadith. Al-Shawkani said: (The two hadiths indicate the prohibition of buying and selling. The majority went to interpreting the prohibition as dislike (Karahah). Al-Iraqi said: Scholars agreed that a sale contract concluded in the mosque cannot be annulled; thus said Al-Mawardi. You are aware that interpreting prohibition as dislike requires a contextual indication diverting it from the real meaning which is prohibition according to those who hold it, that prohibition is in reality for unlawfulness (Tahrim), and this is the truth. Their consensus on the impermissibility of annulment and the validity of the contract does not contradict prohibition, so it is not valid to make it...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: a contextual indication to interpret prohibition as dislike. Some Shafi'i scholars held that buying and selling in the mosque is not disliked, but the hadiths refute them. The companions of Abu Hanifa differentiated between if it becomes dominant and frequent, then it is disliked, or if it is little, then there is no dislike; a distinction for which there is no evidence). I say: Among those who explicitly stated permissibility is Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla), his text being: (Selling is permissible in the mosque. Allah Almighty said: {And Allah has permitted trade} [Al-Baqarah / 275]. No prohibition came regarding that except via the path of Amr bin Shu'aib from his father from his grandfather, and it is a scroll). I say: The hadith of Amr bin Shu'aib has disagreement, and the most likely view is that he is Hasan in hadith as previously explained. Furthermore, this hadith of Abu Huraira refutes him, and its chain is Sahih according to him, for he narrated the second part of it as preceded and used it as evidence for the prohibition of announcing lost property in the mosque. So his school should have been the prohibition of buying and selling in the mosque, were it not that he did not connect the hadith completely but rather abbreviated it. Al-San'ani said in his (Sharh): (It contains evidence for the prohibition of buying and selling in mosques, and that one who sees that in it must say to each of the seller and buyer: May Allah not make your trade profitable. He says it aloud to rebuke the doer of that. The reason is his saying previously: For mosques were not built for that). Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in (Al-Mirqat): (Our scholars permitted buying for the one in I'tikaf (seclusion) without bringing the merchandise. Among the heinous innovations is selling the Kaaba's coverings behind the Maqam and selling books and others in Al-Masjid Al-Haram. And more heinous...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: than it is placing litters, waterskins, and luggage in it, especially during the Hajj season and times of overcrowding. Allah is the Guardian of the affair of His religion, and there is no power nor strength except by Him). (9 - Carrying out Hudud (Punishments) and Retaliation (Qisas), due to his saying, peace be upon him: (Hudud are not to be established in mosques, nor is retaliation taken in them)). The hadith is from the narration of Hakim bin Hizam, may Allah be pleased with him. Recorded by Al-Daraqutni and Ahmad via the path of Waki': Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Shu'aythi narrated to us from Al-Abbas bin Abdul Rahman Al-Madani (and Al-Daraqutni said: Al-Makki) from Hakim with it. Its men are trustworthy except this Al-Abbas bin Abdul Rahman. Al-Husayni said in (Al-Tadhkirah) as in (Al-Ta'jeel): (Unknown). Then Al-Hafiz followed him saying: (I say: Thus I read in Al-Husayni's handwriting, and it is an ugly mistake. What is in the Musnad of Hakim bin Hizam from (Musnad Ahmad) is: From Waki' from Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Shu'aythi from Al-Qasim bin Abdul Rahman Al-Muzani from Hakim regarding perfume in mosques, raised [to the Prophet]. And from Hajjaj from Al-Shu'aythi from Zufar bin Wathimah from Hakim. This is how it is in the biography of Zufar bin Wathimah from Hakim in (Al-Atraf) by Al-Mizzi. He mentioned the narration of Dawood and said: Waki' narrated it from Al-Shu'aythi but did not raise it. I say: In summary, Al-Abbas bin Abdul Rahman has no entry in the hadith of Hakim...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: in (Musnad Ahmad). And Allah knows best. As for his saying: Al-Madani, it is a distortion; rather it is Al-Muzani with Damma on Mim followed by dotted Zai). Thus Al-Hafiz judged Al-Husayni to be in error and claimed that the biographee is Al-Qasim bin Abdul Rahman Al-Muzani, not Al-Abbas bin Abdul Rahman Al-Madani. It appears that the origin of this difference arose from the difference in copies of (Al-Musnad) regarding the name of the biographee. This is supported by the fact that our printed copy agrees completely with what Al-Husayni mentioned. We do not know the correct version of that because the matter requires scrutiny of many corrected copies of (Al-Musnad), and how can we have that? Perhaps the scholar Professor Ahmad Muhammad Shakir has investigated that in his new edition of (Al-Musnad). However, it seems more likely to me that it is Al-Abbas bin Abdul Rahman because it is so in Al-Daraqutni's narration, even if it differed in his attribution (Nisbah) as indicated earlier; that does not prevent preferring what the two narrations agreed upon. In Al-Hafiz's words, there is another contradiction to what is in our copy of (Al-Musnad), as he said previously: (From Hakim regarding perfume in mosques). Hakim has no hadith with this meaning in (Al-Musnad), although he narrated many hadiths in two places in it. But it is most likely that there is a distortion in our copy of (Al-Ta'jeel) and that the original is: (Regarding Hudud in mosques). And Allah knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In summary, the most likely view is that the biographee is Al-Abbas bin Abdul Rahman contrary to what Al-Hafiz claimed. As for whether he is Madani or Makki, that has not been verified by us. In the men of (Al-Tahdhib): (Abbas bin Abdul Rahman, client of Bani Hashim, from Al-Abbas bin Abdul Muttalib and Abu Huraira, and from him Dawood bin Abi Hind). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Taqrib): (He is Mastur [hidden/unknown condition]). I say: Perhaps he is the biographee, for he is from his generation. And Allah knows best. Furthermore, Al-Shu'aythi has another Sheikh in this hadith. Recorded by Abu Dawood and Al-Daraqutni from Sadaqah bin Khalid, and Al-Hakim from Zuhair bin Hunaid, both from Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Nadri from Zufar bin Wathimah from Hakim bin Hizam that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade that retaliation be taken in the mosque, or hudud be established in it, or poetry be recited in it. Hajjaj contradicted them saying: Al-Shu'aythi narrated to us from Zufar bin Wathimah with it suspended (Mawquf) on Hakim. Recorded by Ahmad, and he said: (He did not raise it), meaning Hajjaj. I say: Sadaqah bin Khalid is trustworthy, used as proof by Al-Bukhari, and he raised it, which is an addition that must be accepted, especially since he was followed by Zuhair bin Hunaid who is acceptable (Maqbul) as in (Al-Taqrib).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Likewise, Waki' followed him from Al-Shu'aythi from the first path raised. It preceded from (Al-Ta'jeel) that Al-Mizzi said: (Waki' narrated it from Al-Shu'aythi but did not raise it, and I did not find this narration now). Al-Hakim remained silent on the hadith, and it was dropped from (Al-Talkhis) by Al-Dhahabi. He said in the biography of Zufar bin Wathimah in (Al-Mizan) after citing this hadith for him: (Abdul Haq weakened it - meaning the hadith - and Ibn Al-Qattan said: Its defect is ignorance of Zufar's condition, Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Shu'aythi was unique in narrating from him. I say: Ibn Ma'in and Duhaym authenticated him). Al-Hafiz's opinion on it varied; he said in (Bulugh Al-Maram): (Its chain is weak). And in (Al-Talkhis): (There is no harm in its chain). In my view, the hadith is Hasan considering the corroboration of Al-Abbas bin Abdul Rahman for Zufar bin Wathimah, for one strengthens the other. In (Al-Mirqat): (It is Hasan as some Hafiz stated). I say: It may ascend to the degree of Sahih li-ghayrihi (Sahih due to others) by its witnesses, among which are: From Ibn Abbas raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (Hudud are not to be established in the mosque, nor is a father killed for [killing] his son). Recorded by Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, and Ibn Majah.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And Al-Daraqutni via the path of Ismail bin Muslim from Amr bin Dinar from Tawus from him. Al-Tirmidhi said: (We do not know it with this chain raised except from the hadith of Ismail bin Muslim, and some people of knowledge spoke against him regarding his memory). I say: But he was not unique in it; rather Qatada followed him. Recorded by Al-Bazzar in his (Musnad) from him from Amr bin Dinar as in (Nasb Al-Rayah). I say: Likewise, Al-Daraqutni narrated it via the path of Abu Al-Mughira: Saeed bin Bashir narrated to us from Qatada with it. Al-Hakim narrated it via Abu Al-Jamahir Muhammad bin Uthman: Saeed bin Bashir narrated to us: Amr bin Dinar narrated to us with it, dropping Qatada from between them. Perhaps Saeed bin Bashir heard it from Qatada first then heard it from Amr directly, for he explicitly stated hearing from him. He - meaning Saeed - is disagreed upon, and in my view he is Hasan in hadith if he does not contradict. As for Al-Hafiz, he weakened him in (Al-Taqrib). Ubaidullah bin Al-Hasan Al-Anbari followed him from Amr bin Dinar with it. Recorded by Al-Daraqutni: And Abdul Baqi bin Qani' narrated to us: Al-Hasan bin Ali Al-Ma'mari narrated to us: Uqba bin Mukram Al-Ammi narrated to us: Tamar Umar bin Amir Abu Hafs Al-Sa'di - and he used to live in Bani Rifa'ah - narrated to us from Ubaidullah bin Al-Hasan Al-Anbari with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is a Sahih chain; all its men are trustworthy among the men of Muslim except Ibn Qani' and Al-Ma'mari, and they are both trustworthy. Al-Suyuti attributed the hadith in (Al-Jami') to Ahmad as well, and I checked the Musnad of Ibn Abbas in it but did not find it. And Allah knows best. Al-Bayhaqi also narrated it in his (Sunan) from the last aspect. Among them is from Ibn Lahi'ah from Muhammad bin Ajlan that he heard Amr bin Shu'aib narrating from his father from his grandfather: That the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade establishing Hudud in mosques. Recorded by Ibn Majah. This is a Hasan chain in witnesses, for Ibn Lahi'ah is trustworthy but is feared for his poor memory. Among them is from Jubayr bin Mut'im with the wording: (Hudud are not to be established in mosques). He said in (Al-Majma'): (Recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and in it is Al-Waqidi, and he is weak). He said in another place: (Recorded by Al-Bazzar and in it is Al-Waqidi, and he is weak due to his Tadlis (obfuscation), but he explicitly stated hearing). In the chapter from Wathila bin Al-Asqa' with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Keep your boys away from your mosques...) The Hadith. In it: (And the execution of your Hudud/punishments). Its chain is weak, and it has preceded in the discussion on the first paragraph of etiquettes. The Hadith indicates the prohibition of executing Hudud in mosques and the prohibition of retaliation (Qisas) in them, because prohibition, as established in the Principles (Usul), is in reality for prohibition (Tahrim), and there is nothing to divert it here from its real meaning. Thus in (Al-Nayl) and similarly in (Subul Al-Salam). So whoever holds that the prohibition is for discouragement (Tanzih), like the Shafi'is, must provide evidence. Al-Munawi said in (Al-Fayd): (So it is disliked as Tanzih. Yes, if one upon whom retaliation is due takes refuge in it, retaliation can be exacted from him in it, even in Al-Masjid Al-Haram; a leather mat is spread and retaliation is exacted in it to hasten the fulfillment of the right according to Al-Shafi'i. And Abu Hanifa said: He is not killed in the Haram; rather he is forced to exit). I say: The apparent view is what Abu Hanifa said because the Hadith was absolute and did not differentiate. And in (Al-Mirqat): (Because in that there is a kind of violation of its sanctity and due to the possibility of contaminating it with a wound or Hadath [impurity]. And the saying of Ibn Abi Laila: 'They are established' is anomalous (Shadh). Thus Ibn Hajar mentioned. Ibn Al-Malik said: Lest the mosque be contaminated. And in (Sharh Al-Sunnah): Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said regarding one upon whom a Hadd became obligatory in the mosque: Take him out. And from Ali similarly). What is known from his guidance, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, is executing Hudud outside the mosque as...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...in the Hadith of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, in the story of Ma'iz. He said, may Allah be pleased with him: A man came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, while he was in the mosque and called out to him saying: O Messenger of Allah, I have committed Zina. So he turned away from him until he repeated it four times. When he testified against himself four times... The Hadith. In it: So the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Take him and stone him). Jabir bin Abdullah said: So we stoned him at the Musalla. End quote abbreviated from Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad. And from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered the stoning of the Jew and the Jewess at the door of the mosque... The Hadith. Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Hakim from the path of Ibn Ishaq: He said: And Muhammad bin Talha bin Yazid bin Rakanah told me from Ismail bin Ibrahim Al-Shaibani from him. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih on the condition of Muslim). He said: (Perhaps an illusionist from other than the people of the craft might imagine that Ismail Al-Shaibani is unknown, but it is not so, for Amr bin Dinar narrated from him). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. I say: Al-Shaibani is not unknown as Al-Hakim said; rather he is known, but he is not from the men of Muslim, so how does he authenticate it on his condition? Indeed, none of the authors of the Six Books narrated from him. He is only from the men of (Al-Ta'jil), and mentioned in his biography: (Abu Zur'ah said: Trustworthy, counted among the Kufis, and Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat)...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Likewise Muhammad bin Talha is not from the men of Muslim, although he is trustworthy. And Ibn Ishaq only narrated for him in conjunction with others. In summary, the chain of the Hadith is Hasan, and Al-Hafiz remained silent on it in (Al-Fath). (10 - Spitting, especially towards the Qibla and the right, and it is forbidden (Haram). For he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saw spit on the Qibla wall, so he scraped it off, then turned to the people [and became angry with them] and said: (If one of you is praying, let him not spit in front of his face, for Allah is in front of his face when he prays). The Hadith is from the narration of Nafi' from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Al-Nasa'i from the path of Malik - and it is in (Al-Muwatta) - and Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from paths from him. Likewise Al-Bayhaqi extracted it. The addition is for Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad. The latter added in a narration: (Nor to his right. Then he called for a stick and scraped it off, then called for perfume (Khaluq) and scented it). This has preceded. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, may Allah be pleased with him:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, loved dried date stalks ('arajin) and they were constantly in his hands. So he entered the mosque and saw sputum in the Qibla of the mosque, so he scraped it off. Then he turned to the people angrily and said: Would any of you be pleased if someone spat in his face? Indeed, when one of you faces the Qibla, he is facing his Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, and the angel is on his right. So let him not spit to his right nor in his Qibla, and let him spit to his left or under his foot. If an urge hastens him, let him say like this - and Ibn Ajlan described that - spitting into his garment then rubbing parts of it against each other. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, and Ahmad from Ibn Ajlan from Iyad bin Abdullah from him. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih on the condition of Muslim). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, but it is not so; rather it is only Hasan, not on the condition of Muslim as explained repeatedly. In (Al-Targhib): (Narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah in his (Sahih). In a narration by him similarly except he said in it: (For Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, is in front of you in your prayers, so do not direct anything of harm in front of you... The Hadith). Ibn Khuzaymah titled it: (Chapter on the prohibition of directing anything to which the name of harm applies towards the Qibla in prayer). I say: The Hadith has another path from Abu Sa'id which will come shortly, if Allah the Exalted wills. It indicates the prohibition of spitting in the mosque towards the Qibla from two aspects: First: His anger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, at them when he saw the spit in the Qibla.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The other: His forbidding them, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, from that, and prohibition in principle implies forbiddenness (Tahrim). Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in (Sharh Al-Taqrib): (Is this prohibition of the worshiper spitting in front of him or to his right for forbiddenness or discouragement? Al-Qurtubi said: His turning to the people angrily indicates the prohibition of spitting on the Qibla wall, and that it is expiated by burying it and scraping it off, as he said regarding the whole mosque: Spitting in the mosque is a sin and its expiation is burying it. I say: What indicates the prohibition of spitting towards the Qibla is what Abu Dawood narrated with a good chain from the Hadith of Al-Sa'ib bin Khallad that a man led a people in prayer and spat towards the Qibla. I say: So he mentioned the Hadith coming after this, and in it: that he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said to him: You have harmed Allah and His Messenger. A group of Shafi'is stated absolutely the dislike of spitting in the mosque, among them Al-Mahamili, Sulaym Al-Razi, Al-Ruyani, Abu Al-Abbas Al-Jurjani, and the author of (Al-Bayan). Al-Nawawi in (Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab) asserted the verification of its prohibition, and it seems he held to his saying in the Sahih Hadith that it is a sin). Al-Hafiz said: (This reasoning (meaning his saying: (For Allah is in front of his face) indicates that spitting towards the Qibla is Haram whether it is in the mosque or not, especially from the worshiper. So the dispute regarding whether the dislike of spitting in the mosque is for discouragement or prohibition does not apply here). Then he cited the Hadith of Al-Sa'ib and the Hadith of Hudhayfah, and it comes also. (And (A man led a people in prayer and spat towards the Qibla while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was looking. So the Messenger of...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said when he finished: (Let him not pray for you). So he wanted to pray for them after that) but they prevented him and informed him of the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. So he mentioned that to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and he said: (Yes). And I think he said: (You have harmed Allah and His Messenger)). The Hadith was narrated by Abu Dawood - and the addition is his - and Ahmad from the path of Abdullah bin Wahb from Amr bin Al-Harith from Bakr bin Sawadah Al-Judhami from Salih bin Khaiwan from Abu Sahlah Al-Sa'ib bin Khallad that a man led a people... The Hadith. Al-Mundhiri remained silent on it in his (Mukhtasar), and likewise Al-Hafiz in (Al-Fath). His Sheikh Al-Iraqi said in (Sharh Al-Taqrib): (Its chain is good). Ibn Hibban also narrated it in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib). The men of the Hadith's chain are trustworthy men of Muslim except Salih bin Khaiwan - with the pointed [Kh] and it is said: with the unpointed [Ha] - whom Al-Ajli and Ibn Hibban declared trustworthy, although no one narrated from him except this Bakr as stated by Al-Dhahabi in (Al-Mizan). Therefore, Abdul Haqq Al-Azdi said: (He is not used as proof). Ibn Al-Qattan criticized him for that and authenticated his Hadith. I say: The scientific principles testify to what Al-Azdi said, except that the Hadith is Hasan or Sahih because it has a witness from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, with its meaning. Al-Mundhiri cited it and said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) with a good chain and its men are trustworthy) as in (Al-Majma'). (And he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Whoever spits towards the Qibla will come on the Day of Resurrection with his spit between his eyes)). The Hadith is from the narration of Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by Abu Dawood and others with a Sahih chain. It has a completion: (And whoever eats from this foul vegetable let him not approach our mosque for three [days]). Discussion on it has passed. It has a witness from the Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (The owner of the sputum in the Qibla will be resurrected on the Day of Resurrection with it in his face). Narrated by Al-Bazzar, Ibn Khuzaymah in his (Sahih) - and this is his wording - and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Targhib). In the path of Al-Bazzar is Asim bin Umar: Al-Bukhari and a group weakened him, and Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Al-Thiqat) as in (Al-Majma'). This Hadith indicates by its apparent meaning the dislike of spitting towards the Qibla inside prayer and outside it due to it not being restricted to the state of prayer. Al-Hafiz said: (Al-Nawawi asserted the prohibition in every state inside prayer and outside it, whether in the mosque or elsewhere. It was reported from Malik that he said: There is no harm in it - meaning outside prayer. What testifies to the prohibition is what Abdul Razzaq and others narrated from Ibn Mas'ud that he disliked [that]...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...one spits to his right while not in prayer. And from Mu'adh bin Jabal, he said: I have not spat to my right since I embraced Islam. And from Umar bin Abdul Aziz that he forbade his son from it absolutely). I say: The report of Ibn Mas'ud was also narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and its men are trustworthy as in (Al-Majma'). As for the Hadith of Amr bin Hazm: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, spit to his right, to his left, and in front of him, it is not authentic; rather it is very weak containing Al-Waqidi. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) also. (If one must spit, let him spit to his left if it is empty of worshipers, otherwise under his left foot provided burying it in it is possible by the ground being sand or pebbles, not tiles or covered with rugs. Otherwise, let him spit in his garment or shoe due to his saying, peace be upon him ([What is the matter with one of you standing facing his Lord then expectorating in front of him? Would one of you like to be faced and then expectorated in his face?] If one of you stands for prayer, let him not spit in front of him, for he is conversing with Allah as long as he is in his prayer place, nor to his right, for on his right is an angel. Let him spit to his left (added in a second Hadith: (if it is empty) or under his [left] foot and bury it). Added in a third Hadith: (If he does not find a place to spit, then in his garment or shoe). The Hadith was reported from a group of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: First: Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are paths from him: 1 - Abdul Razzaq bin Hammam from Ma'mar from Hammam heard Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet] with it, and the context is his. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Ahmad, and Al-Bayhaqi. 2 - Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri from Humaid bin Abdul Rahman that Abu Huraira and Abu Sa'id told him: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saw sputum on the wall of the mosque, so he took a pebble and scraped it off, then said... so he mentioned it similarly. It contains the second addition between parentheses with the wording: (If one of you expectorates, let him not expectorate in front of his face nor to his right, but let him spit to his left or under his left foot). Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Darimi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad. A narration from Abu Huraira and from Abu Sa'id, and from him alone Al-Tayalisi, and likewise Al-Nasa'i, which is a narration of the two Sheikhs. 3 - Ismail bin Ulayyah from Al-Qasim bin Mahran from Abu Rafi' from him with it similarly. It contains the first addition, and at its end similar to what came in the third Hadith with the wording:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (If he does not find [a place], let him say like this. And Al-Qasim described: He spat in his garment then wiped parts of it against each other). Narrated by Muslim, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad. Then Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad also narrated it, as well as Al-Bayhaqi from the path of Shu'bah from Al-Qasim with it similarly. Muslim and Al-Bayhaqi added in the narration of Hushaym from Al-Qasim: Abu Huraira said: (It is as if I am looking at the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, folding parts of his garment over others). (Alert): This Al-Qasim bin Mahran is Al-Qaysi, their freed slave, and he is trustworthy; Ibn Ma'in and others declared him trustworthy. Al-Mundhiri was confused about him with another where he said in (Al-Targhib): (And Ibn Majah narrated from Al-Qasim bin Mahran - and he is unknown - from Abu Rafi' from Abu Huraira). I say: So he cited the Hadith. The unknown Al-Qasim bin Mahran is other than this one who narrated the Hadith from Abu Rafi'. He [the unknown] is earlier than this one, narrated from Imran bin Husayn, and his hearing from him is not established, and from Musa bin Ubaidah. Al-Dhahabi and others differentiated between them. Furthermore, attributing the Hadith to Ibn Majah alone has shortcoming. Glory be to Him upon Whom nothing is hidden. Second: Anas bin Malik, and there are two paths from him:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: 1 - Humaid from him: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saw sputum in the Qibla, and that distressed him until it was seen in his face. So he stood and scraped it with his hand and said: (Indeed, when one of you stands in his prayer, he is conversing with his Lord, or indeed his Lord is between him and the Qibla, so let not one of you spit towards his Qibla, but to his left or under his foot). Then he took the edge of his cloak and spat in it, then folded part of it over the other and said: (Or let him do like this). Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Al-Darimi, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad, and his chain with him is thulathi (has three narrators). Humaid explicitly stated his hearing from Anas in Abdul Razzaq, so his Tadlis (obfuscation) is secure as in (Al-Fath). 2 - Qatadah from him briefly without the cause of the Hadith nor his saying: Then he took... etc. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from paths from him. He explicitly stated his hearing from Anas in Al-Bukhari, which is a narration of Al-Bayhaqi and others. Third: Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, and there are four paths from him: 1 - Al-Zuhri from Humaid bin Abdul Rahman from him. This has preceded in the Hadith of Abu...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Huraira from the second path. 2 - Fulayh from Sa'id bin Al-Harith from Abu Salamah from him, he said: These are dried date stalks in which Allah has placed blessing for us. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to love them and use them as a staff, so we used to prepare them and bring them to him. He saw spit in the Qibla of the mosque while in his hand was a stalk from those stalks, so he scraped it and said... so he mentioned it. This is the third Hadith which contains the addition at its end. Narrated by Ahmad, and its chain is Sahih on the condition of the Six. 3 - Ibn Ajlan from Iyad bin Abdullah from him. Its wording and extraction preceded in the beginning of the discussion on this paragraph. 4 - Hammad from Thabit from Abu Nadrah from him very briefly with the wording: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, spat in his garment then rubbed it. Narrated by Ahmad, and its chain is Sahih on the condition of Muslim. Fourth: Jabir bin Abdullah, and there are two paths from him: 1 - From Ubadah bin Al-Walid bin Ubadah bin Al-Samit from him like the Hadith of Abu...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Salamah from Abu Sa'id, and the Marfu' wording from it is: (Would any of you like Allah to turn away from him?) Then he said: (Indeed when one of you stands to pray, Allah is in front of his face, so let him not spit in front of his face nor to his right, and let him spit to his left under his left foot. If an urge hastens him, let him do with his garment like this) and he placed it on his mouth then rubbed it... The Hadith. Its extraction preceded in the discussion on the first paragraph of etiquettes at the Hadith: (He saw sputum in the Qibla of the mosque). 2 - Abu Al-Zubayr from him briefly without mentioning the cause with the wording: (Or under his left foot). Narrated by Ahmad, and its men are trustworthy men of Muslim, so it is Sahih in chain if Abu Al-Zubayr heard it from him. Fifth: Tariq bin Abdullah raised [to the Prophet] with the wording: (If you pray, do not spit in front of you nor to your right, but spit towards your left if it is empty, otherwise under your feet and rub it). Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Hakim, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad, and the wording...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: is his from paths from Mansur, he said: I heard Rib'i bin Hirash from him with it. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah extracted it without his saying: (if it is empty) and his saying: (and rub it). Al-Tirmidhi said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith, and the practice is upon this according to the people of knowledge). This Hadith is the second Hadith referred to in the original. In these Hadiths is indication of the prohibition of spitting in the mosque towards the Qibla and the right due to his prohibition, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and his sternness against whoever opposed that, such that he removed the Imam who did that from Imamate and said to him: (You have harmed Allah and His Messenger). This is the biggest proof for prohibition. What the Imams said regarding that has preceded shortly. In them is an explicit indication of the permissibility of spitting in it towards the left or under the left foot with its condition, which is burying. In it is a refutation of Al-Nawawi where he said in his (Sharh) on Muslim: (And his saying, peace be upon him: (Let him spit under his foot and to his left) this is outside the mosque. As for the worshiper in the mosque, he does not spit except in his garment). The face of refuting him is that his saying, peace be upon him, was said specifically regarding the mosque when he saw the sputum in its Qibla, so he forbade them from that and from spitting towards...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: the right, and permitted them to spit in it under the foot and to the left, and ordered them to bury it by saying: (Let him bury it). So whoever opposes and does not bury has sinned, otherwise not. As for Al-Nawawi's reasoning for what he went to by saying: (Because of his saying, peace be upon him: (Spitting in the mosque is a sin), so how could he permit it, peace be upon him?). I say: The matter has been decided and he permitted it, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. The problem only came from his understanding of the Hadith he mentioned and the one coming after it contrary to what the scholars understood, as he himself stated, and we will quote his words regarding that, Allah willing, so the truth becomes clear to you. (And he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: (Spitting (Basoq) (and in a wording: Tafl. And in another: Nukha'ah) in the mosque is a sin and its expiation is burying it). The Hadith was narrated by Qatadah from Anas raised [to the Prophet]. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi who authenticated it, Al-Darimi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from paths from him. The second wording is for Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad in a narration of theirs, and the other is for them except Muslim. In Al-Nasa'i's narration (Busaq) with Sad instead of Zai. (Tafl) - with the two dots above -: blowing with slight spittle, and it is more than Nafth.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (And (Nukhamah) which is (Nukha'ah) from the head also and from the chest, and it is said: tanakh-khama and tanakh-kha'a). (And in a narration: (Spitting in the mosque is a bad deed and burying it is a good deed). It is from the Hadith of Abu Umamah, may Allah be pleased with him, raised [to the Prophet]. Ahmad extracted it: Zaid bin Al-Hubab told us: Husayn bin Waqid informed us: Abu Ghalib told us that he heard Abu Umamah. This is a Hasan chain; its men are trustworthy men of Muslim except Abu Ghalib, who is truthful but errs as in (Al-Taqrib). In (Al-Majma'): (Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) except that he said: (A sin and its expiation is burying it), and the men of Ahmad are trustworthy). Al-Mundhiri said: (Its chain is acceptable (La ba'sa bihi)). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (Its chain is Hasan). Abu Dawood narrated, and from him Al-Bayhaqi, saying: Al-Qa'nabi told us: Abu Mawdud told us from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Hadrad Al-Aslami: I heard Abu Huraira raised [to the Prophet]: (Whoever enters this mosque and spits in it or expectorates, let him dig and bury it. If he does not do so, let him spit in his garment then take it out with him). Ahmad extracted it from Zaid bin Al-Hubab and from Waki', both from Abu Mawdud with it similarly. Waki's wording is:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (If one of you spits in my mosque or the mosque, let him dig and deepen, or let him spit in his garment until he takes it out). This is a chain Al-Mundhiri remained silent on in his (Mukhtasar), and it is probable for Hasan. Abu Mawdud's name is Abdul Aziz bin Abi Sulayman, and Abu Dawood declared him trustworthy, and a group of trustworthy narrators narrated from him. Abdul Rahman bin Abi Hadrad Al-Aslami, Al-Daraqutni said: (There is no harm in him). He said in Al-Taqrib: (He is Acceptable). Likewise, he said about Abu Mawdud. And Allah knows best. (And he said: (The deeds of my Ummah were displayed to me, their good and their bad. I found in their good deeds removing harm from the road, and I found in their bad deeds sputum being in the mosque not buried). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by Muslim, Ibn Majah, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad. (And he said: If one of you expectorates in the mosque, let him hide his sputum lest it touches the skin of a believer or his clothing and harms him).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: It is from the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas. Ahmad extracted it: Ibn Abi Adi told us from Ibn Ishaq, and Ya'qub: My father told us from Ibn Ishaq: Abdullah bin Muhammad told me, Ya'qub said: Ibn Abi Atiq, from Amir bin Sa'd, narrated to him from his father Sa'd. This is a Hasan chain; all its men are trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs except Ibn Ishaq, and he is Good (Hasan) in Hadith. In (Al-Majma'): (Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Ya'la and its men are trustworthy). Al-Hafiz said: (Narrated by Ahmad with a Hasan chain). These Hadiths indicate what the previous Hadith of Abu Huraira indicated, which is the permissibility of spitting in the mosque - upon need of course - if he buries it. Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in (Sharh Al-Taqrib): (Abu Al-Walid Al-Baji said: If he spits in the mosque and covers his spit, there is no sin upon him. Al-Qurtubi also narrated from Ibn Makki that it is only a sin for the one who spits in it and does not bury it. Al-Qurtubi said: What indicates the correctness of this is his saying in the Hadith of Abu Dharr: (And I found in their bad deeds sputum being in the mosque not buried). So the ruling of bad deed was not established for it by mere placement in the mosque, but by that and its remaining unburied. I say: His permission for that in the Hadith of the chapter (meaning the previous Hadith of Abu Huraira) by his saying: (Or under his feet and bury it) also indicates it. If we carry the Hadith on intending...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...its being in the mosque as preceded, and it is explicitly stated in the Hadith of Abu Sa'id and Abu Huraira mentioned at the beginning of the chapter). Al-Nawawi disagreed with that and exaggerated, saying in (Sharh Muslim): (Know that spitting in the mosque is a sin absolutely, whether one needs to spit or does not need to, rather he should spit in his garment. If he spits in the mosque, he has committed the sin, and he must expiate this sin by burying the spit. This is the correct view, that spitting is a sin as stated by the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. The scholars and Qadi Iyad said: It contains a false statement, the summary of which is that spitting is not a sin except regarding the one who does not bury it, but as for the one who intends to bury it, it is not a sin. He used false things as evidence for it, so his saying this is a mistake contrary to the text of the Hadith). Al-Hafiz said: (The summary of the dispute is that here are two generalities that conflicted, which are his saying: (Spitting in the mosque is a sin) and his saying: (And let him spit to his left or under his foot). So Al-Nawawi makes the first general and restricts the second to when he is not in the mosque. And Al-Qadi contrarily makes the second general and restricts the first to the one who does not intend to bury it. A group agreed with Al-Qadi, among them Ibn Makki in (Al-Tanqib), Al-Qurtubi in (Al-Mufhim), and others. Witnessing for them). Then he mentioned the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, then the Hadith of Abu Umamah, and said: (It is clearer than it in intent). Then the Hadith of Abu Dharr and Al-Qurtubi's speech on it preceded. Then he said: (Sa'id bin Mansur narrated from Abu Ubaidah bin Al-Jarrah:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: That he expectorated in the mosque one night and forgot to bury it until he returned to his home. So he took a torch of fire then came and sought it until he buried it. Then he said: Praise be to Allah who did not write a sin against me tonight. This indicates that the sin is specific to the one who leaves it, not the one who buries it. The reason for prohibition guides to it, which is the believer being harmed by it. What indicates that its generality is restricted: The permissibility of that in the garment even if he was in the mosque without dispute. In Abu Dawood from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Al-Shikhkhir that he prayed with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and spat under his left foot then rubbed it with his shoe. Its chain is Sahih and its origin is in Muslim. The apparent is that this was in the mosque, so it supports what preceded). I say: Al-Nawawi's restriction of the second Hadith which Al-Hafiz pointed to, to when he is not in the mosque, is false because it was reported regarding the mosque specifically as preceded from Al-Iraqi. So how is it permissible to restrict it to other than what the Hadith was reported for? The truth is that there is no contradiction between the two Hadiths at all: The first Hadith - and what is in its meaning - stated that spitting in the mosque is a sin if he does not bury it. But if he buries it, it is not a sin because it - meaning the burial - is a good deed that wiped out the sin of spitting as in the Hadith of Abu Umamah. The second Hadith - meaning the previous Hadith of Abu Huraira - only permitted spitting with burial as preceded. So if he does not bury it, he has committed the sin inevitably. Thus, the two Hadiths are in agreement. And praise be to Allah.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Then Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said: (In his saying: (let him bury it). What implies that the license for spitting in the mosque is when the mosque's furnishing is pebbles or dust, not when it is marble, tiles, rugs, or mats. The author of (Al-Mufhim) narrated from some of them saying: We heard from some of our Sheikhs that this is only permissible if there is nothing in the mosque but dust or sand as their mosques were in the first era. As for if there are rugs in the mosque and mats of value which spitting spoils and dirties, then it is not permissible out of respect for the angels. I say: Rubbing it with the shoe has been reported instead of burying in what Muslim narrated from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Al-Shikhkhir, who said: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and saw him expectorate and rub it with his shoe. This also bears possibility of being in dust or pebbles, so burying it in dust is achieved by rubbing it. Al-Baji said: He does not have the right to spit on the ground and rub it with his foot because that dirties the place for whoever wants to sit in it. I say: Abu Dawood narrated from the narration of Abu Sa'id (so in the original, and correct: Abu Sa'd), he said: I saw Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' in the mosque of Damascus spitting on the reed mat (Buri) then he wiped it with his foot. It was said to him: Why did you do that? He said: Because I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, doing it. Al-Buri: The mat made of reeds, said by Al-Harawi in (Al-Gharibain). Based on this, it is not spoiled by that. And the Hadith is also not authentic). I say: The defect of this Hadith is this Abu Sa'd, who is Al-Himsi Al-Himyari. Al-Faraj bin Fadalah narrated from him in Abu Dawood. Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (No one narrated from him except Al-Faraj bin Fadalah). I say: So he is unknown, and Al-Hafiz explicitly stated that in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Faraj bin Fadalah is also weak as Al-Mundhiri said in his (Mukhtasar), and the Hadith was faulted by him, and likewise he said in (Al-Taqrib). (11 - Urination and the like, due to his saying, peace be upon him, to the Bedouin who entered the mosque then urinated in it: (Indeed this House was built for the remembrance of Allah and prayer, and it is not to be urinated in). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Ibn Majah, Ahmad, and Ibn Hibban in his (Sahih). It was mentioned in full in the discussion on the purity of the place - Issue Five. It has a witness from the Hadith of Anas with the wording: (Indeed these mosques are not suitable for anything of filth, urine, and defecation). Narrated by Muslim and others, and it preceded there. In the Hadith is evidence for the obligation of keeping mosques free from urine and all impurities. Al-Iraqi said: (This is so if that leads to contaminating them with impurity. If they are not contaminated, like if he urinated in a vessel or was bled (cupped) into a vessel in the mosque, then the more correct view is the prohibition of urination and the dislike of bleeding without its prohibition. Al-Nawawi asserted in (Sharh Muslim) the dislike of bleeding into a vessel and did not...

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: ...narrate a disagreement regarding it. Al-Iraqi said: Likewise, whoever has impurity on his body or garment, if he is secure from contaminating the mosque with it, his entry is permissible, and if he fears that, it is not permissible). Ibn Hazm said in (Al-Muhalla): (Urination in the mosque is not permissible. Whoever urinates in it must pour a bucket of water over his urine. Spitting in it is not permissible. Whoever spits in it must bury his spit. Then he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered the cleaning and perfuming of mosques - as we cited before - which necessitates everything to which the name of cleaning and perfuming applies. Cleaning and perfuming necessitate the removal of every forbidden thing, every filth, and every rubbish. So the substance of urine and others must be removed). (Let it be known that these prohibitions and the commands before them are part of the elevation mentioned in His saying, The Exalted: {In houses which Allah has permitted to be raised and that His Name be mentioned therein} [An-Nur / 36]). Discussion on it preceded in the discussion on the second matter of what should be observed in building mosques, so refer to it. (12 - Taking it as a thoroughfare, due to his saying, peace be upon him: (Do not take mosques as thoroughfares except for remembrance or prayer). The Hadith is from the narration of Abdullah bin Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir), he said: Ahmad bin Abdul Wahhab bin Najdah Al-Hawti told us: Yahya bin Salih Al-Wahazi told us: Ali bin Hawshab told us from Abu Qabil from Salim from his father with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: This is a good (Jayyid) chain; all its men are trustworthy. This Al-Hawti - with Fatha on the unpointed [Ha] and Sukun on Waw and after it an unpointed [Ta] - is among the Sheikhs of Al-Nasa'i whom Al-Tabarani shared in narrating from, and he is truthful as in (Al-Taqrib). Ali bin Hawshab is acceptable (La ba'sa bihi) as Duhaym said, and Al-Hafiz relied on it in (Al-Taqrib). Abu Qabil - with Fatha on Qaf - his name is Huyayy bin Hani, Ibn Ma'in and others declared him trustworthy. The rest of his men are men of Al-Bukhari. Therefore, Al-Mundhiri said in (Al-Targhib): (And its chain is acceptable). Al-Haythami said: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and (Al-Awsat) and its men are trustworthy). The Hadith has another path from Ibn Umar without his saying: (Except for remembrance or prayer). Ibn Majah extracted it with a weak chain, from the path of Zaid bin Jubairah Al-Ansari from Dawud bin Al-Husayn from Nafi' from him with the wording: (Traits not fitting in the mosque: It is not taken as a thoroughfare, no weapon is drawn in it, no bow is gripped in it, no arrows are scattered in it, no raw meat is passed through it, no Hadd punishment is struck in it, no retaliation is taken in it from anyone, and it is not taken as a market). Zaid bin Jubairah is weak as in (Al-Umdah), and in (Al-Taqrib) he is: (Abandoned). Ibn Kathir said in Tafsir: (In its chain is weakness).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Then Al-Ayni said after mentioning the Hadith from the path of Ibn Majah: (I do not see it as authentic). (And with him also from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas: (Keep mosques clean and do not take them as thoroughfares, no menstruating woman should pass in it, no Junub should sit in it except wayfarers, no arrows should be scattered in it, no sword should be drawn in it, no Hadd should be struck in it, and no poetry should be recited in it. If recited, it is said: May Allah break your mouth). I say: I did not find this with Ibn Majah, nor did Al-Nabulsi cite it in (Al-Dhakhai'r), nor did I find it in any of the books of Sunnah I have. I do not see it as authentic. And Allah knows best. (He, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, indicated this meaning when he said: (Close for me every wicket in this mosque except the wicket of Abu Bakr). The Hadith is from the narration of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, came out during his illness in which he died, his head bound with a rag, and sat on the pulpit. He praised Allah and extolled Him, then said: Indeed, there is no one among people more generous to me with his life and wealth than Abu Bakr Ibn Abi Quhafah. If I were to take a close friend from the people, I would have taken Abu Bakr as a close friend, but the friendship of Islam is better. Close... etc. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Ahmad as preceded in the seventh matter of the matters that should be observed in building mosques. Al-Qurtubi said in his (Tafsir): (So he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered the closing of doors because it led to taking the mosque as a thoroughfare and crossing through it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He excepted the wicket gate of Abu Bakr to honor him and as a special privilege because they were rarely separated). And in (Tafsir Ibn Kathir): (Some scholars disliked passing through it except for a need if an alternative is found). I say: Evidence has come indicating the permissibility of passing through the mosque as will come in Permissible Acts, paragraph (1). So it should be interpreted as being for a need and rarely, such that it does not lead to using it as a thoroughfare. This is what appeared to me in reconciliation, and I have not seen anyone address that. And Allah knows best. c - Permissible Acts: (1 - Passing through it occasionally for a need due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Whoever passes through any of our mosques or markets (and in a wording: If one of you passes through our mosque or our market. And in a wording: through a market or gathering or mosque) carrying arrows, let him hold their heads [sharp points]. Or he said: (let him grasp their heads - three times -) lest he hit any of the Muslims [with anything]. (And in a wording: lest he wound anyone with them) The Hadith was extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad via Burayd (with Ba, diminutive of Burd, he is Ibn Abdullah bin Abi Burdah) from Abu Burdah from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari elevated with the second wording. The first wording is Al-Bukhari's alone in a narration. The last wording is Al-Tahawi's, and Al-Bukhari has its meaning. The last addition is for the Two Sheikhs and Ibn Majah.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Thabit followed him from Abu Burdah with it similarly. Extracted by Muslim and Ahmad via Hammad bin Salamah from him. It contains the first addition and the third wording, but it does not have in Muslim: (or mosque). Laith - who is Ibn Abi Sulaim - also followed him in Ahmad similarly. Then the last wording is also in Ahmad via Abu Ahmad: Burayd bin Abdullah told us with it from Abu Musa who said: (If one of you passes...) The Hadith. Thus it occurred in (Al-Musnad) as stopped [Mawquf] at him. It is in Al-Tahawi from this perspective via two paths from Abu Ahmad elevated. I do not know if the narration occurred like this in (Al-Musnad) or if its elevation to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was dropped from it? The Hadith is evidence for the permissibility of passing through the mosque even if carrying weapons. Al-Bukhari titled it with what we mentioned, saying: (Chapter: Passing through the mosque). Al-Hafiz said: (Meaning: its permissibility, which is deduced from the Hadith of the chapter by way of priority [a fortiori]). I say: But it should be interpreted as for need and rarity such that it does not lead to using the mosque as a thoroughfare, which is forbidden as preceded. And Allah knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 2 - Women coming to it under two conditions: First: That they go out not perfumed nor displaying adornment, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (If one of you [women] attends the mosque (and in a wording: (Isha [prayer]) let her not touch perfume) The Hadith is from the narration of Zainab Al-Thaqafiyyah, wife of Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him. Extracted by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Abu Awanah, and Ahmad, and the second wording is his via Muhammad bin Ajlan: Bukair bin Abdullah ibn Al-Ashajj told me from Busr bin Sa'id from her. This is a good [Hasan] chain. Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Hisham followed him from Bakr with it with the second wording. Extracted by Ahmad and Al-Tayalisi, as well as Al-Nasa'i. Al-Layth bin Sa'd followed him in Al-Nasa'i with the first wording. Muslim extracted it via Makhramah from his father from Busr bin Sa'id with it. In the chapter from Abu Hurairah and others as will come: (And the second: That they ask permission from their husbands, and permission is obligatory upon them [husbands] due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Do not prevent your women from the mosques [at night] if they ask your permission to them [but let them go out Tafilat (unperfumed)] [and their houses are better for them]))

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Hadith is from the narration of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him and them, and there are paths from him: 1 - Al-Zuhri from Salim bin Abdullah from him. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad via paths from him. The wording is Muslim's and Ahmad's. The first addition is Al-Bukhari's. Muslim added: So Bilal bin Abdullah said: By Allah, we will surely prevent them. He said: So Abdullah turned to him and cursed him with a bad curse the like of which I never heard him curse, and said: I inform you from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and you say: By Allah, we will surely prevent them? It is in Ahmad also without his saying: (cursed him...). (1) 2 - Mujahid from him similarly, containing the first addition. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi,
foot_note: 1. (1) He added in a narration: He said: The wife of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, used to pray in the mosque. He said to her: You know that I love... She said: By Allah, I will not stop until you forbid me. He said: So Umar stabbed while she was in the mosque. And he extracted it in Musnad Umar (1/40) via Yahya bin Abi Ishaq from Salim bin Abdullah who said: Umar was a jealous man. When he went out to prayer, Atikah bint Zaid followed him. He used to dislike her going out and dislike preventing her. He used to narrate that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: So he mentioned the Hadith. Its narrators are trustworthy narrators of the Six, except that it is disconnected as in (Al-Fath) (2/306), for Salim did not hear from Umar as his Sheikh said in (Al-Majmu') (2/33).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via paths from him. They all added except Al-Bukhari: (So a son of Abdullah bin Umar said: We will not let them go out so they take it as a means of corruption. He said: So Ibn Umar rebuked him and said: I say: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said, and you say: We will not let them?) In a narration of Muslim and Ahmad: (So he struck his chest). Ahmad added in another narration: (So Abdullah did not speak to him until he died). Its chain is authentic. He has in a fourth narration the second addition via Laith bin Abi Sulaim from Mujahid. Laith is weak, but this addition is authentic due to its occurrence in other Hadiths as will come. 3 - Nafi' from him with the wording: (Do not prevent the female servants of Allah from the mosques of Allah). Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad via paths from him. Al-Bukhari added at its beginning: (A wife of Umar used to attend Morning and Isha prayers in congregation in the mosque.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It was said to her: Why do you go out when you know that Umar dislikes that and is jealous? She said: What prevents him from forbidding me? He said: The saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prevents him... so he mentioned it. 4 - Abdullah bin Yazid Al-Muqri: Sa'id bin Abi Ayyub told us: Ka'b bin Alqamah told us from Bilal bin Abdullah bin Umar from his father elevated with the wording: (Do not prevent women from their shares of the mosques if they ask your permission). So Bilal said: By Allah, we will surely prevent them. Abdullah said to him: I say the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said, and you say: We will surely prevent them? 5 - Habib bin Abi Thabit from him containing the last addition with the wording: (Do not prevent your women from the mosques, and their houses are better for them). Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Hakim, and Ahmad via Yazid bin Harun: Al-Awwam bin Hawshab informed us: Habib informed me with it. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on their condition). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him. Ibn Khuzaimah also authenticated it as in (Al-Fath). Al-Nawawi authenticated it in (Al-Majmu') and Al-Iraqi in (Al-Taqrib). 6 - Amr bin Dinar from him: (Do not prevent women from coming to the mosques. His son said: By Allah, we will surely prevent them. Ibn Umar said: I tell you from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and you say this?) Extracted by Al-Tayalisi: Hisham Al-Dastawa'i told us from Amr

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: This is an authentic chain on the condition of the Six. The Hadith has witnesses: Among them from Abu Hurairah elevated: (Do not prevent the female servants of Allah from the mosques of Allah, but let them go out while they are Tafilat [unperfumed]). Extracted by Abu Dawood, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad via Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah from him. This is a good chain; Al-Mundhiri remained silent on it in his (Mukhtasar). Ibn Khuzaimah also narrated it as in (Al-Fath). Al-Iraqi attributed it in (Al-Taqrib) to Muslim, which is an error. Among them from Yazid bin Khalid Al-Juhani elevated similarly. Extracted by Ahmad from Abd al-Rahman bin Ishaq from Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Hisham from Busr bin Sa'id from him. In (Al-Majmu'): (Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Bazzar, and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and its chain is good). Thus he said. Ahmad's men are Muslim's men except Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Hisham. He said in (Al-Khulasah): (He narrated from Bukair bin Al-Ashajj, and from him Ibrahim bin Sa'd. Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy). In (Al-Taqrib): (He is acceptable).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Hadith was also narrated by Ibn Hibban as in (Al-Fath). Among them from Aisha similarly. Extracted by Ahmad: Al-Hakam told us: Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Al-Rijal told us, my father said mentioning from his mother from her with it. Aisha said: (If he saw their state today, he would have prevented them). This is an authentic chain; all its narrators are trustworthy narrators of Muslim except Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Al-Rijal, who is truthful but may err as in (Al-Taqrib). Umm Abi Al-Rijal's name is Amrah bint Abd al-Rahman. Yahya bin Sa'id narrated it from her limiting to Aisha's saying with the wording: (If the Messenger of Allah had realized what women have introduced, he would have prevented them from the mosques as the women of the Children of Israel were prevented). Extracted by Malik, and from his path Al-Bukhari, as well as Abu Dawood. Muslim and Ahmad narrated it via paths from Yahya with it. Abu Hurairah has another Hadith in the chapter with the wording: (Any woman who touches incense should not witness the last Isha with us). Extracted by Muslim and Abu Dawood (1) via Busr bin Sa'id from him.
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Nasa'i also narrated it (2/283) and Ahmad (2/304).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then he and Ibn Majah narrated it via Asim bin Ubaidullah from Ubaid Mawla Abi Rahm from Abu Hurairah who said: A woman met him from whom the smell of perfume was found, and her hem was creating dust [hurricane]. He said: O female servant of the Compeller, did you come from the mosque? She said: Yes. He said: And you perfumed yourself? She said: Yes. He said: I heard my beloved Abu Al-Qasim, peace and blessings be upon him, say: (No prayer is accepted from a woman who perfumes herself for this mosque until she goes back and bathes her washing from Janabah [major impurity]). This is a weak chain. Asim bin Ubaidullah is weak. His Sheikh Ubaid Mawla Abi Rahm - who is Ibn Abi Ubaid - is acceptable as in (Al-Taqrib). From this perspective Al-Tayalisi and Ahmad extracted it. Then he extracted it via Za'idah from Laith from Abd al-Karim from Mawla Abi Rahm with it similarly. Laith is Ibn Abi Sulaim, who is weak. His Sheikh Abd al-Karim is unknown as in (Al-Ta'jil). It came from another path better than this briefly: (If a woman goes out to the mosque, let her wash from perfume as she washes from Janabah).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Extracted by Al-Nasa'i via Ibrahim bin Sa'd who said: I heard Safwan bin Sulaim - and I did not hear other than it from Safwan - narrating from a trustworthy man from Abu Hurairah elevated with it. Al-Nasa'i said after it: (Brief). Its narrators are all trustworthy except the man who was not named, for he is unknown to us. Perhaps he is Ubaid Mawla Abi Rahm named in the first path. In the Hadith is evidence for the permissibility of women attending mosques for prayer with the mentioned conditions. Despite that, their prayer in their houses is better for them as he, peace and blessings be upon him, said in the last addition. In its meaning are other Hadiths; perhaps they will come, Allah willing, in (Congregational Prayer). In (Al-Fath): (Ibn Daqiq Al-Eid said: This Hadith is general regarding women, but the jurists restricted it with conditions: Among them is that she does not perfume herself, which is in some narrations: (And let them go out Tafilat). I say: It is with Fatha on Ta and Kasra on Fa, meaning: unperfumed. It is said: A woman is Tafila if her smell is changed. He said: Appended to perfume is what is in its meaning because the reason for prevention from it is what it contains of stirring the motive of desire, like beautiful clothing, visible jewelry, and luxurious adornment. Likewise mixing with men. Many jurists of the Malikis and others differentiated between the young woman and others. This is open to question because if she is free from what was mentioned and is covered, safety is obtained

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: for her, especially if that is at night. It was reported in some paths of the Hadith and others what indicates that a woman's prayer in her house is better than her prayer in the mosque). I say: So he mentioned the last addition and what is in its meaning which we referred to. Then he said: (The reason her prayer in concealment is better is the realization of safety in it from Fitnah. This is confirmed after the existence of what women introduced of Tabarruj [display] and adornment. Hence Aisha said what she said. Some held onto Aisha's saying for the absolute prevention of women. This is open to question since the change of ruling does not result from that because she suspended it on a condition that did not exist based on a conjecture she thought, saying: If he saw, he would have prevented. It is said in reply: He did not see and did not prevent. So the ruling continued. Even Aisha did not explicitly state prevention, although her speech implies she saw prevention. Also, Allah Glory be to Him knew what they would introduce, yet He did not reveal to His Prophet to prevent them. If what they introduced necessitated preventing them from mosques, preventing them from other places like markets would be more appropriate. Also, the introduction [of Tabarruj] only occurred from some women, not all of them. If prevention is determined, let it be for those who introduced it. It is better to look at what corruption is feared from, so it is avoided due to his indication, peace and blessings be upon him, to that by preventing perfuming and adornment, as well as the restriction to night as preceded). I say: This restriction indicates that permission is only commanded for husbands if their request to go out to the mosque is at night. But if it is during the day, they are not commanded to [permit]; if they wish they permit, and if they wish they prevent. Al-Hafiz said in (Sharh Al-Taqrib): (Ibn Battal said: In this narration is evidence that the day is contrary to that due to his specification

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: of the night. He said: This Hadith judges the absolute one. Do you not see Aisha's saying: No one recognizes them due to the darkness (Ghalas)?) (A third condition: That they leave to their houses immediately upon their Salam with the Imam who stays in his place, and those behind him of men, until they leave it. For (Women in the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, when they said Salam from the obligatory prayer, stood up. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and those who prayed of men remained for whatever Allah willed. [And they used to think that was so women would leave before men [caught up with them]] [So they enter their houses before the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, leaves]. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood, the men stood) The Hadith is from the narration of Umm Salamah. Extracted by Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via paths from Ibn Shihab: Hind bint Al-Harith Al-Firasiyyah informed me that Umm Salamah informed her with it. The context is Al-Bukhari's, Al-Nasa'i's, and Ahmad's. The first addition is Abu Dawood's, Al-Bayhaqi's, and Ahmad's. Al-Bukhari has similar, containing the addition: (that he catches them). The last addition is his also. Al-Hafiz said: (In the Hadith is the Imam's consideration of the followers' conditions and precaution in avoiding what

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: might lead to the forbidden. In it is avoiding places of suspicion and dislike of mixing men with women in the streets, let alone houses. The implication of the mentioned reasoning is that if the followers were men only, this staying is not recommended. Based on this Ibn Qudamah interpreted the Hadith of Aisha that he, peace and blessings be upon him, when he said Salam, did not sit except the amount to say: O Allah You are Peace and from You is Peace, Blessed are You O Owner of Majesty and Honor. Extracted by Muslim. In it is that women used to attend the congregation in the mosque) (3 - Entry of the menstruating woman, especially for a need, due to the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: The Messenger of Allah said to me: (Hand me the Khumrah (small mat) from the mosque). I said: I am menstruating. He said: (Indeed your menses is not in your hand). [So I handed it to him]) The Hadith was extracted by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi who authenticated it, Al-Darimi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via Al-A'mash from Thabit bin Ubaid from Al-Qasim bin Muhammad from her. The addition is Al-Tayalisi's, and he does not have: (from the mosque). Abd al-Malik bin Humaid bin Abi Ghunyah followed him from Thabit bin Ubaid with it. Extracted by Ahmad. This is a strong follow-up; this Abd al-Malik is trustworthy, used as proof by the Six. Muslim extracted it from him and from Hajjaj together from Thabit.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It has another path: Extracted by Ibn Majah from Abu Al-Ahwas and Al-Tayalisi from Sallam, both from Abu Ishaq from Abdullah Al-Bahi from her with it. This is an authentic chain. Isra'il differed with them, saying: From Abu Ishaq from Al-Bahi from Abdullah bin Umar from her. Extracted by Ahmad. Sharik also narrated it from Abu Ishaq, extracted by Ahmad also. Zuhair differed with all of them, saying: From Abu Ishaq from Al-Bahi from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Aisha... The Hadith. Extracted by Ahmad, making it from the Musnad of Ibn Umar, not from his narration from Aisha. Most likely, this difference is from Abu Ishaq himself, not from those narrating from him, for he had become confused in his old age. It is preferable to me that the correct narration is that of those who said from him from Al-Bahi from her. Isma'il Al-Suddi followed him.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Extracted by Al-Darimi and Ahmad, and Al-Abbas bin Dharih in Ahmad, both from Al-Bahi from her with it. In Al-Suddi's narration: That he, peace and blessings be upon him, was in the mosque when he said that. But this Al-Suddi - who is the Elder Isma'il bin Abd al-Rahman - although trustworthy, there is talk about him. In (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, has illusions).
