If someone like him is alone in an addition without all narrators, the soul is not reassured of its establishment. I say this even though this addition has been authenticated from another Companion, Abu Hurairah, as will come. However, it is possible that this is another story; indeed, this is closer to the apparent narration. Its wording is from Abu Hurairah who said: While the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was in the mosque, he said: (O Aisha, hand me the garment). She said: I am menstruating. He said: (Indeed your menses is not in your hand). So she handed it to him. Extracted by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad via Yahya bin Sa'id from Yazid ibn Kaisan from Abu Hazim from him. What indicates that the incident is multiple is that the requested item in this one is: (the garment) and in that one: (the Khumrah) - which is a mat or woven palm leaves and similar plants as preceded. And the statement

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: that it is a single incident requires much affectation, as Al-Sindi clarified in his footnote on Muslim: First, that the request was originally the Khumrah and the garment together, but some narrators limited it to mentioning one of them or forgot. This involves accusing the narrator of illusion and attributing deficiency to him without any proof, and the implication is not hidden. Second: That his saying: (from the mosque) is not from the core of the Hadith nor from his speech, peace and blessings be upon him, but rather from Aisha's speech, attached to her saying: He said. Al-Nawawi stated in (Sharh Muslim) quoting Al-Qadi. So the origin of the Hadith according to them is like this: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to me from the mosque: (Hand me the Khumrah). This is contrary to the apparent meaning of the Hadith. It is very unlikely that the origin of the Hadith is what they mentioned, then all narrators agree on narrating it in a form that does not come to mind except that his saying: (from the mosque) is from his speech, peace and blessings be upon him, and that it is attached to (Hand me). Supporting what we mentioned is that the authors of the four Sunan except Al-Nasa'i titled the Hadith with what its apparent meaning indicates, saying: (Chapter: The menstruating woman handing something from the mosque). Al-Tirmidhi said: (Aisha's Hadith is Hasan Sahih. It is the saying of the generality of the people of knowledge; we know of no difference among them in that: That there is no harm in a menstruating woman handling something from the mosque). Al-Khattab said in (Al-Ma'alim): (In the Hadith is jurisprudence that a menstruating woman may hand something with her hand from the mosque,

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: and that one who swore not to enter a house or mosque does not break his oath by inserting his hand or part of his body into it as long as he does not enter it with his whole body). His speech here indicates that he understood from the Hadith that Aisha only inserted her hand into the mosque, therefore he deduced from it what he mentioned regarding the oath. This is a subtle understanding and restricting the Hadith with what is not in it indicating it. Perhaps Al-Khattabi is among those who see that a menstruating woman has no right to enter the mosque due to evidence he established, so he restricted the Hadith with it. This would be acceptable if the evidence were authentic, but it is not authentic as will come. So the Hadith should be left on its generality. What supports the generality and absolute nature has come. The Imam said: Sufyan told us from Manbudh from his mother who said: I was with Maimunah, and Ibn Abbas came to her. She said: O my son, why is your head disheveled? He said: Umm Ammar who combs me is menstruating. She said: O my son, and where is the menses from the hand? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to enter upon one of us while she was menstruating, place his head in her lap, and recite the Quran while she was menstruating. Then one of us would take her Khumrah and place it in the mosque. O my son, and where is the menses from the hand? Al-Nasa'i extracted it via Muhammad bin Mansur from Sufyan with it briefly with the wording: (So she spreads it while she is menstruating). Al-Shawkani said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Muhammad bin Mansur is trustworthy, and Manbudh was declared trustworthy by Ibn Ma'in. Abd al-Razzaq, Ibn Abi Shaybah, and Al-Diya in (Al-Mukhtara) extracted it with similar wording from her. The Hadith has witnesses. I say: But Umm Manbudh, he said in (Al-Taqrib): (Acceptable). He also said about her son that he is: (Acceptable). So the chain is Hasan in witnesses. Then Al-Shawkani said: (So it is proof for those who say it is permissible for a menstruating woman to enter the mosque for a need, and supports attaching the prepositional phrase in the first Hadith to his saying: (Hand me), because her entering the mosque to place the Khumrah in it is no different from her entering to take it out). Among the witnesses of the Hadith which Al-Shawkani referred to previously: From Ibn Umar: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Aisha: (Hand me the Khumrah from the mosque). She said: She is menstruating. He said: (It is not in your hand).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Extracted by Ahmad via Ibn Abi Layla from Nafi' from him. Its narrators are narrators of the Two Sheikhs except Ibn Abi Layla, who has poor memory. Ubaidullah bin Umar differed with him, narrating it stopped [Mawquf] at Ibn Umar (That he used to order his maid to hand him the Khumrah from the mosque, and she would say: I am menstruating. He would say: Your menses is not in your hand. So she would hand it to him). Thus Al-Darimi extracted it: Muhammad bin Uyaynah informed us from Ali bin Mushir from him. This is an authentic chain; its narrators are trustworthy narrators of the Two Sheikhs except Muhammad bin Uyaynah, and Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy, and a group of trustworthy narrators narrated from him. However, the Hadith, even if stopped, is elevated in meaning because it only applies to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. And Allah knows best. Among them from Abu Bakrah: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his servant: (Hand me the Khumrah from the mosque). She said: I am menstruating. He said: (Hand it to me). He said in (Al-Majmu'): (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir) and its narrators are authenticated). Among them from Umm Ayman who said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Hand me the Khumrah from the mosque). I said: I am menstruating. He said: (Your menses is not in your hand). Al-Haythami said: (Narrated by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir). In it is Abu Nu'aym from Salih bin Rustam. If he is Abu Nu'aym Al-Fadl bin Dukain, his narrators are all trustworthy. If he is Dirar bin Surad, he is weak). As for the Hadith extracted by Abu Dawood via Al-Aflt bin Khalifah who said: Jasrah bint Dajajah told me, saying: I heard Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, say: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came while the doors of his companions' houses were facing into the mosque. He said: (Turn these houses away from the mosque). Then the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, entered, and the people did nothing hoping a concession would be revealed for them. He came out to them later and said: (Turn these houses away from the mosque, for I do not make the mosque lawful for a menstruating woman or a Junub) (1), it is a disputed Hadith and is not authentic due to its disturbance (Idtirab) and Jasrah bint Dajajah being alone in narrating it, and she is not famous. Aflt narrated it from her like this. Mahduj Al-Dhuhli narrated it from her saying: Umm Salamah informed me with it briefly with the wording:
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Bayhaqi also extracted it (2/442-443) and added: Except for Muhammad and the family of Muhammad. And he indicated the weakness of the Hadith.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered the courtyard of this mosque and called out at the top of his voice: (The mosque is not lawful for a Junub or a menstruating woman). Extracted by Ibn Majah and Ibn Abi Hatim in (Al-Ilal), both via Abu Nu'aym: Ibn Abi Ghunyah told us from Abu Al-Khattab Al-Hajari from Mahduj with it. He added in (Al-Ilal): (Except for the Prophet, his wives, Ali, and Fatimah bint Muhammad). He said in (Al-Zawa'id): (Weak chain: Mahduj was not declared trustworthy, and Abu Al-Khattab is unknown). Ibn Hazm said likewise regarding Abu Al-Khattab and said regarding (Mahduj) that he is: (Fallen, narrating conundrums from Jasrah). Then Ibn Abi Hatim said: (Abu Zur'ah said: They say: From Jasrah from Umm Salamah. The correct is from Aisha). In it is an indication that Mahduj was not alone in it, which is the case. Ibn Hazm said: (We narrated it via Abd al-Wahhab from Ata Al-Khaffaf from Ibn Abi Ghunyah from Isma'il from Jasrah bint Dajajah from Umm Salamah with it, and it contains the addition). Then Ibn Hazm rejected it saying: (Ata Al-Khaffaf is Ata bin Muslim: Munkar al-Hadith, and Isma'il is unknown). I say: Thus in (Al-Muhalla): (Abd al-Wahhab from Ata Al-Khaffaf). And in its margin: (In the Yemeni copy: Abd al-Wahhab bin Ata Al-Khaffaf, which is an error).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: I say: What is in the Yemeni copy agrees with what Ibn al-Qayyim quoted in (Tahdhib Al-Sunan) from Ibn Hazm and critiqued him on, where he said: (Then he [meaning Ibn Hazm] narrated it via Abd al-Wahhab bin Ata Al-Khaffaf... Ibn Hazm said: Abd al-Wahhab bin Ata is Munkar al-Hadith and Isma'il is unknown. The matter is not as Abu Muhammad [meaning Ibn Hazm] said, for Ibn Ma'in said: He is trustworthy... Salih bin Muhammad said: They denounced a Hadith from Al-Khaffaf which he narrated for Thawr bin Yazid from Makhul from Kuraib from Ibn Abbas regarding the virtue of Al-Abbas, and they did not denounce other than it... As for Isma'il, if he is Isma'il bin Raja' bin Rushd Al-Zubaidi, he mentioned in the biography of Ibn Abi Utbah (thus, perhaps the original: Ghunyah as in (Al-Muhalla), although Utbah also occurred in Ibn al-Qayyim's quotation from him here, Allah knows best) that he narrated from this Isma'il, and did not mention any Isma'il other than him among his Sheikhs, so he is trustworthy, Muslim narrated for him in (Al-Sahih). After all, this exception (meaning the preceding addition) is false, fabricated, an addition by some extremist Shi'as, and Ibn Majah did not extract it in the Hadith). In summary, Ibn Hazm only softened his speech regarding (Ata bin Muslim Al-Khaffaf) as his statement mentioned just now is explicit. Ibn al-Qayyim thought he meant his son Abd al-Wahhab bin Ata, so he began refuting Ibn Hazm and citing the statements of Imams praising him. He is undoubtedly in better condition than his father Ata, as becomes clear by reviewing the statements of Imams regarding them both. In (Al-Taqrib):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Abd al-Wahhab bin Ata Al-Khaffaf: Truthful, may err). And he said in the biography of his father Ata: (Truthful, errs often). However, it is not clear to me whether the narrator of the Hadith from Ibn Abi Ghunyah is the father or the son, due to the difference in copies as preceded, although the commentator on (Al-Muhalla), Judge Ahmad Muhammad Shakir, asserted the first and deemed the opposing copy erroneous. Perhaps his proof for that is Ibn Hazm's discussion on Ata rather than Abd al-Wahhab. Against this arises this question: Who is this Abd al-Wahhab? If it is said: He is the son of the mentioned Ata, we say we did not find anyone mentioning him among the narrators from his father. If it is someone else, I did not know him. And Allah knows best. In any case, the pivot of this Hadith is Jasrah, as in the ones before it. She is not famous for trustworthiness and integrity such that the soul is reassured in using her report as independent proof. None of the early scholars whose authentication is proof authenticated her; rather Al-Bukhari criticized her as will come. Therefore, a group of Hadith scholars weakened her Hadith, pointed out by Al-Khattabi in (Al-Ma'alim). Abu Muhammad Abd al-Haqq said: (It is not established due to its chain). Ibn al-Qattan critiqued him with what is insufficient and unsatisfactory, saying, as in (Nasb al-Rayah): (Jasrah bint Dajajah is a Tabi'iyah. Al-Bukhari's saying in (Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (She has marvels) is not sufficient to drop what she narrated. Aflt and Qudamah bin Abd bin Abdah Al-Amiri narrated from her). I say: So what? This Qudamah is also not famous. In (Al-Taqrib): (It is said he is Fulayh Al-Amiri, acceptable). He mentioned in (Al-Tahdhib) among the narrators from her: Mahduj, who is unknown as preceded, and Umar bin Umair bin Mahduj, and I did not find a biography for him. In summary, everyone who narrated from Jasrah is not known for integrity - except Aflt - so how can his narration from her be an authentication for her? Yes, Al-Ijli and Ibn Hibban explicitly authenticated her, as he mentioned her in (Al-Thiqat). His leniency in authentication, as well as Al-Ijli's, is known to those who follow their speech on differed-upon narrators. Therefore you see Al-Hafiz did not rely on their authentication despite quoting it from them in (Al-Tahdhib). He said in (Al-Taqrib): (She is acceptable). Meaning her Hadith is weak if she is alone, as he mentioned in the introduction, which is his saying: (The Sixth: Who has no Hadith except a little, and nothing is established regarding him for which his Hadith should be abandoned. This is indicated by the term: (Acceptable) where followed up, otherwise soft in Hadith). From what preceded explanation, you know that Al-Shawkani's statement that the Hadith is authentic following Ibn Khuzaimah is incorrect. And his saying:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (Ibn Sayyid al-Nas said: By my life, declaring it Hasan is the least of its ranks due to the trustworthiness of its narrators and the existence of external witnesses for it) is also open to question, because these witnesses are like no witnesses since they revolve around Jasrah as preceded. The Hadith was not reported from other than her path via an acceptable way, otherwise we would have adopted it. Yes, Ibn Hazm narrated it via Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Zabalah from Sufyan bin Hamzah from Kathir bin Zaid from Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah: That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not permit anyone to sit in the mosque or pass through it while Junub except Ali bin Abi Talib. Then he said: (Muhammad bin Al-Hasan is mentioned with lying, and Kathir bin Zaid likewise). Thus he said. Kathir bin Zaid is Al-Aslami Al-Sahmi, and he did not sink to this level nor was he accused of lying; rather he is differed upon, some authenticated him and others weakened him. In (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful, makes mistakes). He said regarding Ibn Zabalah: (They called him a liar). So he is the defect of the Hadith. Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah is Al-Makhzumi, and he practices much Tadlis and Irsal as Al-Hafiz said. So the Hadith is Mursal also.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It was also recorded by Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Bazzar as well, as in (Takhrij Al-Kashshaf), via the path of Salim bin Abi Hafsa from Atiyya from Abu Saeed, raised [to the Prophet]: (O Ali, it is not lawful for anyone to be in this mosque while Junub [ritually impure] except me and you). He said: (A Hasan Gharib hadith; we do not know it except from this aspect, and Muhammad bin Ismail heard this hadith from me and considered it strange). I say: This is a weak chain because Atiyya is Al-Awfi, who is weak, and Salim bin Abi Hafsa is truthful (Saduq) in hadith but is an extreme Shiite, as in (Al-Taqrib). Al-Bazzar said: (He was a Shiite but was not abandoned, and he was not corroborated on this) (1). Then Al-Bazzar narrated it from the narration of Al-Hasan bin Ziyad from Kharijah bin Sa'd from his father Sa'd, exactly the same. He said: (We do not know it from Sa'd except with this chain). I say: Al-Hasan bin Ziyad is Al-Lu'lu'i, the student of Abu Hanifa, and a group of Imams like Ibn Ma'in and others called him a liar. Thus, it becomes clear from the foregoing that no hadith is established regarding the prohibition of the menstruating woman or...
foot_note: 1. (1) Then I saw Ibn Kathir said in (Al-Tafsir) (1/501): (It is a weak hadith that is not established; this Salim is Matruk [abandoned] and his Sheikh Atiyya is weak).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...the Junub entering the mosque. The default rule is permissibility, so one does not depart from it except with a valid transmitted proof that establishes the argument, especially since there is authentic evidence supporting this principle, which is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned in the original source: (Hand me the Khumrah [small mat] from the mosque) and other evidences that will follow. Ibn Hazm said: (It is permissible for menstruating women and women with postpartum bleeding to marry and to enter the mosque, and likewise for the Junub, because no prohibition has come regarding any of that. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: (The believer does not become impure). The People of the Suffah used to sleep in the mosque in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and they were a large group, and there is no doubt that among them were those who had wet dreams, yet they were never forbidden from that. A group said: The Junub and the menstruating woman may not enter the mosque except passing through. This is the view of Al-Shafi'i. They mentioned the saying of Allah Almighty: {O you who have believed, do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated until you know what you are saying or in a state of janabah, except those passing through [a place of prayer], until you have washed [your whole body]} [An-Nisa / 43]. They claimed that Zaid bin Aslam or others said: Its meaning is: Do not approach the places of prayer. Ibn Hazm said: There is no proof in the statement of Zaid, and even if it were true that he said it, it would be an error on his part, because it is not permissible to think that Allah Almighty wanted to say: 'Do not approach the places of prayer,' and then obscured His statement to us by saying: {Do not approach prayer}. It has been narrated that the verse is regarding the prayer itself from Ali bin Abi Talib, Ibn Abbas, and a group. Malik said: He may not pass through it at all...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...and Abu Hanifa and Sufyan said: They [Junub/Menstruating] may not pass through it; if they are compelled to do so, they must perform Tayammum then pass through it. Those who prohibited it argued with the hadith...). I say: He then cited the hadith of Aisha, Umm Salama, and Al-Muttalib bin Abdullah mentioned previously, and said: (And all of this is false). Then he explained their defects similar to what preceded. Then [he cited] what is narrated via the path of Al-Bukhari with his chain from Aisha, the Mother of the Believers: That a black bondswoman belonged to an Arab tribe and they freed her, so she came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and embraced Islam. She had a tent or a small hut in the mosque. Ibn Hazm said: (This is a woman residing in the mosque of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and it is known that women menstruate, yet he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not prevent her from that nor forbid it. And everything that he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not forbid is permissible). He said: (If entering the mosque were not permissible for a menstruating woman, he, peace and blessings be upon him, would have informed Aisha of that when she menstruated, but he only forbade her from Tawaf around the House. It is certain falsehood that entering the mosque would be unlawful for her and yet he, peace and blessings be upon him, would not forbid her from it and restrict himself to forbidding her from Tawaf. This is the view of Al-Muzani, Dawood, and others). In (Tafsir Al-Qurtubi): (A group granted concession for the Junub to enter the mosque, and some of them argued with the saying of the Prophet...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...peace be upon him: (The believer is not impure). Ibn Al-Mundhir said: And we say this). I say: Some took a middle path and said entry is permissible if he performs Wudu. In the (Tafsir of Al-Imad Ibn Kathir): (Imam Ahmad held the view that if the Junub performs Wudu, it is permissible for him to stay in the mosque, based on what he and Saeed bin Mansour in his (Sunan) narrated with a Sahih chain: That the Companions used to do that. Saeed bin Mansour said: Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad - who is Al-Darawardi - narrated to us from Hisham bin Sa'd from Zaid bin Aslam from Ata bin Yasar who said: I saw men from the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sitting in the mosque while they were Junub if they had performed the Wudu of prayer. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of Muslim. And Allah knows best). I say: Al-Darimi narrated it from the hadith of Jabir with the wording: (We used to walk in the mosque while we were Junub and we saw no harm in that). He extracted it via the path of Ibn Abi Layla from Abu Al-Zubayr from him, and its men are trustworthy. However, Ibn Abi Layla has poor memory and Abu Al-Zubayr is a Mudallis and used 'an'ana [saying 'from' without stating he heard it]. Hushaym also narrated it from him similarly; Al-Bayhaqi extracted it. Perhaps Wudu is recommended (Mustahabb) due to the practice of the Companions. And Allah knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: In summary, there is no evidence for the prohibition of the menstruating woman or the Junub entering the mosque, and the default is permissibility, and it is accompanied by what supports it as preceded. And Allah Almighty is the Guardian of success. (4 - Entering with unsheathed weapons, for: (He, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered a man who was distributing arrows in the mosque not to pass through unless he held them by their arrowheads [so as not to scratch a Muslim])). The hadith is from the narration of Jabir bin Abdullah Al-Ansari, and there are two paths from him: 1 - Al-Layth bin Sa'd from Abu Al-Zubayr from him, and the context is his. Recorded by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad via paths from him. 2 - Sufyan bin Uyaynah from Amr bin Dinar from him, abbreviated similarly without mentioning the distributing. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim also, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad as well, and its chain is tripartite. Hammad bin Zaid followed him from Amr and it contains the addition. The two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim] recorded it, but Al-Bukhari does not have: (So as not to [Kay]).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith has a Sahih witness from the narration of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, which preceded in the first paragraph of this chapter. It has another witness recorded by Al-Tabarani in (Al-Awsat) from Muhammad bin Ubaidullah who said: We were with Abu Saeed Al-Khudri in the mosque when a man turned over some arrows. Abu Saeed said: Did this man not know that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade turning over weapons in the mosque? Al-Haythami said: (It contains Abu Al-Bilad, whom Abu Hatim weakened). Al-Hafiz said: (In the hadith is an indication of honoring blood, whether little or much, emphasizing the sanctity of the Muslim, and the permissibility of bringing weapons into the mosque). Similar to this is in (Al-Umdah). (5 - Bringing children in, and there are hadiths regarding it: (a) Abu Qatada Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, said: While we were sitting in the mosque [suddenly] the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came out to us carrying Umamah bint Abi Al-Aas bin Al-Rabee - her mother was Zainab, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him - and she was a little girl whom he carried [on his shoulder]. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed while she was on his shoulder; he would put her down when he bowed and return her [to his shoulder] when he stood up. [So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed while she was on his shoulder] until he finished his prayer doing that with her). This has passed briefly in (Purity of Clothes), Issue Four.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith was recorded by Abu Dawood and Al-Nasa'i - and the first addition is his - and Ahmad, via Al-Layth bin Sa'd from Saeed bin Abi Saeed from Amr bin Sulaim Al-Zuraqi from him. This is a Sahih chain according to the condition of the two Sheikhs. They [Bukhari and Muslim] and others recorded it via paths from Amr with it briefly, and its takhrij (verification) has preceded in the place indicated in the original. The second addition belongs to Abu Dawood and Ahmad, and the third and fourth belong to him [Ahmad] alone. Al-Nasa'i titled the hadith with what we titled it, saying: (Bringing children into mosques). Al-Hafiz indicated this in (Al-Fath) saying: (It was used as evidence for the permissibility of bringing children into mosques). Badr al-Din al-Ayni said in (Al-Umdah): (Among the benefits of this hadith is the permissibility of bringing small children into mosques). (b): Abu Bakrah Al-Thaqafi said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to pray [leading the people], and when he prostrated, Al-Hasan would jump onto his back and onto his neck. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, would lift him gently so that he would not fall. He did that more than once. When he finished his prayer, [he hugged him and kissed him, so] they said: O Messenger of Allah, we saw you do with Al-Hasan something we have not seen you do [with anyone]? He said: (He is my sweet basil (Rayhanah) of this world, and this son of mine is a master (Sayyid), and perhaps Allah, Blessed and Exalted, will...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...reconcile through him between two [great] groups of Muslims). The hadith was recorded by Ahmad: Affan narrated to us: Mubarak bin Fadalah narrated to us from Al-Hasan: Abu Bakrah informed me: That the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to... etc. Then he recorded it in another place: Hashim narrated to us: Al-Mubarak narrated to us: Al-Hasan narrated to us: Abu Bakrah narrated to us with it similarly. It contains the first and third additions. Al-Tayalisi recorded it: Ibn Fadalah narrated to us with it similarly, containing the second addition. This is a good (Jayyid) chain connected by hearing. Al-Bayhaqi recorded it from this path in (Al-Dala'il), containing the last addition as in (Al-Fath). The hadith has been narrated from other paths briefly from Al-Hasan Al-Basri: 1 - Isra'il Abu Musa said: I heard Al-Hasan say: I heard Abu Bakrah say: I saw the Messenger of Allah on the pulpit with Al-Hasan bin Ali at his side. He would face the people once and face him another time and say: (This son of mine is a master, and perhaps Allah...). The hadith. Recorded by Al-Bukhari and Al-Nasa'i - and they have the last addition - and Ahmad.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: 2 - Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Ansari: Al-Ash'ath bin Abdul Malik narrated to us from Al-Hasan from Abu Bakrah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ascended the pulpit and said... The hadith. And it contains the addition indicated previously. Recorded by Abu Dawood and Al-Tirmidhi who said: (Hasan Sahih Hadith). 3 - Hammad bin Zaid from Ali bin Zaid from Al-Hasan from Abu Bakrah who said: While the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was preaching, Al-Hasan bin Ali came and climbed up the pulpit to him. The Prophet, peace be upon him, hugged him and wiped his head and said:... The hadith. And it contains the addition. Recorded by Abu Dawood and Ahmad. Ali bin Zaid is Ibn Jud'an and there is weakness in him. Al-Hakim recorded it in (Al-Mustadrak) from the last two aspects and remained silent about them, and the chain of the first of them is Sahih. Regarding Al-Hasan, may Allah be pleased with him, there are two other stories. One of them is about him riding on his back, peace be upon him, while he was prostrating, and his prolonging the prostration for his sake, and his saying when asked about that: (My son rode me and I hated to hasten him until he satisfied his need). Perhaps it will come in (Prostration), God willing.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The other is about him, peace and blessings be upon him, descending from the pulpit when he saw Al-Hasan and his brother Al-Hussein tripping in their shirts. Perhaps it will come in the Friday Sermon. (c) Anas said: (The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to hear the crying of a child with his mother while he was in prayer, so he would recite a light Surah or a short Surah). Recorded by Muslim, Al-Daraqutni, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via the path of Ja'far bin Sulaiman from Thabit Al-Bunani from him. He, peace and blessings be upon him, confirmed that by his saying: (d): He, peace be upon him, said: (I enter prayer intending to prolong it, then I hear the crying of a child, so I shorten it due to the intensity of his mother's distress over him). This is from the hadith of Anas as well. Recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim as well, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi as well, and Ahmad via paths from Saeed bin Abi Aruba who said: Qatada narrated to us from him with it. It has a witness from the hadith of Abu Qatada in Al-Bukhari and others, and perhaps it will come. Al-Hafiz said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (This hadith (meaning: the hadith of Abu Qatada) was used as evidence for the permissibility of bringing children into mosques, but it is open to discussion due to the possibility that the child was left in a house near the mosque such that his crying could be heard). I say: This possibility is far-fetched, especially with the first hadith of Anas: (He hears the crying of the child with his mother), for its apparent meaning - rather it is a text stating - that the child was with his mother in the mosque. So the mentioned possibility is invalid. In these hadiths is the permissibility of bringing children into mosques, even if they are small and stumble in their walk, even if crying is possible, because the Prophet, peace be upon him, approved that and did not deny it. Rather, he prescribed for Imams to shorten the recitation due to a child's crying, fearing hardship on his family. Perhaps the wisdom in that is accustoming them to obedience and attending the congregation from a young age. For those scenes they see in the mosques and what they hear - of Dhikr, Quran recitation, Takbir, Tahmid, and Tasbih - have a strong effect on their souls - without them realizing - which does not disappear, or is difficult to disappear, when they reach maturity and enter the battlefield of life and its adornments. Similar to this is the Adhan in the ear of the newborn. The researcher Ibn al-Qayyim said in (Tuhfat al-Mawlud): (The secret of the Adhan - and Allah knows best - is that the first thing to strike the human hearing are words organizing the grandeur and majesty of the Lord, and the Testification (Shahada) by which one first enters Islam...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...so that serves as indoctrination for him regarding the rituals of Islam upon entering the world, just as he is indoctrinated with the word of Tawhid upon leaving it. It is not impossible that the effect of the Adhan reaches his heart and affects him even if he does not perceive it... etc.). Perhaps modern psychology supports the influence on a small child, even in the cradle, by what he hears and sees. I imagine I read a useful research on this subject by some writer, but I do not recall now who it is or in which book it is. As for older children, their being influenced by that is clear and accepted. However, if there are any among them who play in the mosques and run, their fathers and guardians must discipline and educate them, or the custodian and servant must expel them. On this basis is the action mentioned by Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir: (Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, if he saw children playing in the mosque, would hit them with the light whip (Durrah), and he used to inspect the mosque after Isha and leave no one in it). As for the hadith: (Keep your mosques free of your children), it is weak according to Ibn Hajar, Ibn Kathir, and others, so it does not stand against the preceding hadiths. Its verification has preceded in the discussion on it under the first paragraph of (Etiquettes of Mosques). (6 - Bringing in the deceased to pray over him, because the Prophet, peace be upon him ([did not] pray over Suhail bin Bayda (and in a wording: the two sons of Bayda: Suhail and his brother) [except] in the [middle of the] mosque)).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The hadith is from the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, and it has two paths: 1 - Abbad bin Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr from her. Recorded by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Tahawi, and Ahmad via paths from him. The first and second additions are with all of them except Al-Tirmidhi. Muslim and Ahmad have an addition explaining the reason for Aisha's narration of the hadith, which is: (That Aisha ordered that the funeral procession of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas pass through the mosque so she could pray over him. People denied that of her, so she said: How fast people forget! He did not pray... etc.). Al-Tahawi recorded it likewise. Ahmad added in it: (So he passed by her) and in a wording: (So he was carried through the mosque and she prayed for him). In a narration of his, and likewise Muslim - and the context is his - from Aisha: That when Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas died, the wives of the Prophet, peace be upon him, sent word that they pass his funeral procession...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...into the mosque so they could pray over him. They did so, and stopped with him near their chambers so they could pray over him - he was taken out from the door of funerals which was towards the sitting places (Maqa'id). News reached them that people criticized that and said: Funerals were not brought into the mosque. That reached Aisha, so she said: How fast people are to criticize what they have no knowledge of? They criticized us for passing a funeral through the mosque, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not pray [except in the mosque]. Both extracted it via the path of Musa bin Uqba from Abdul Wahid bin Hamza from Abbad. In it, according to Muslim, is the last addition, which is also with Al-Nasa'i from this path. 2 - Al-Dahhak bin Uthman from Abu Al-Nadr from Abu Salamah bin Abdul Rahman from her with it using the second wording. Recorded by Muslim and Abu Dawood. Its wording with the first [Muslim] is: (When Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas died, she said: Bring him into the mosque so I can pray over him. That was denied of her, so she said: By Allah, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed... etc.). It is with Al-Tahawi completely, except that the raised part (Marfu') with him is with the first wording. Malik also recorded it in (Al-Muwatta) from Abu Al-Nadr from Aisha, dropping Abu Salamah from the chain. Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: (Thus it is in (Al-Muwatta) according to the majority and narrators as disconnected (Munqati'). Hammad bin Khalid Al-Khayyat narrated it from Malik from Abu Al-Nadr from Abu Salamah from Aisha, so he was unique in that from Malik).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Then Malik narrated from Nafi from Abdullah bin Umar that he said: The funeral prayer was performed for Umar bin Al-Khattab in the mosque. I say: Its chain is as sound as the sun. And from Urwa who said: The funeral prayer was performed for Abu Bakr in the mosque. Recorded by Saeed bin Mansour, along with the one before it, as in (Al-Muntaqa). Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Talkhis): (It is established that Umar prayed over Abu Bakr in the mosque, and Suhayb prayed over Umar in the mosque; it is in (Al-Muwatta) and others). I say: There is nothing in (Al-Muwatta) except the prayer over Umar. Al-Shawkani cited it in (Al-Nayl) with the wording of (Al-Talkhis) and said: (Recorded by Ibn Abi Shaybah). Then Al-Shawkani said: (The hadith indicates the permissibility of bringing the deceased into the mosque and praying over him in it. This is the view of Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, Ishaq, and the majority. Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: The Medinans narrated it in a narration from Malik, and Ibn Habib Al-Maliki held it. Ibn Abi Dhi'b, Abu Hanifa, Malik in his famous view, the Hadawis, and everyone who held the impurity of the dead disliked it. They answered the hadith of the chapter by saying it is interpreted that the prayer over the sons of Bayda [took place while] they were...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...outside the mosque and the worshipers were inside, and that is allowed by agreement. This is refuted by the fact that Aisha used it as evidence when they denied her order to bring the funeral into the mosque. They also answered that the matter settled on abandoning that because those who denied Aisha were from the Companions. This is refuted by the fact that when Aisha denied that denial, they submitted to her, which indicates she preserved what they forgot, and that the matter settled on permissibility. Indicating this is the prayer over Abu Bakr and Umar in the mosque as preceded. Also, the reason for which they disliked praying over the dead in the mosque is their claim that he is impure, which is false because of what preceded that the believer does not become impure, alive or dead. The strongest evidence they used for dislike is what Abu Dawood recorded from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (Whoever prays over a funeral in the mosque, there is nothing for him). Ibn Majah recorded it with the wording: (...he has nothing). Its chain contains Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah, and more than one of the Imams spoke against him. Al-Nawawi said: They - meaning the majority - answered it with several answers: First: That it is weak and not valid to use as proof. Ahmad said: This is a weak hadith; Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah was unique in it, and he is weak. Second: That what is in the famous verified heard copies of (Sunan Abu Dawood) is: (Whoever prays over a funeral in the mosque, there is nothing against him), so they have no argument then. Third: That if the hadith were established and it was established as: (nothing for him), it would be obligatory to interpret (for him/lahu) as meaning: against him (alayhi) to reconcile the two narrations. He said: It has come meaning 'against' like His saying: {If you do evil, then it is against it (laha)} [Al-Isra / 7].

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Fourth: That it is interpreted as a decrease in reward for the one who prayed in the mosque and returned without accompanying it to the graveyard, because he missed accompanying it to the graveyard and attending its burial. End). I say: The most likely view regarding the hadith of Abu Huraira in terms of transmission is the narration of those who said: (he has nothing) or (there is nothing for him), because it is so with all who recorded the hadith whom we came across, except Abu Dawood. He recorded it via the path of Yahya bin Saeed from Ibn Abi Dhi'b: Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah narrated to me from him with the wording: (there is nothing against him). Waki' contradicted him in Ibn Majah and Ahmad, and Hajjaj and Yazid bin Harun in Ahmad, and Asad and Ma'n bin Isa in Al-Tahawi; all of them from Ibn Abi Dhi'b with the wording: (there is nothing for him). Except the first of them said: (he has nothing), and the meaning is one. My heart is not reassured by any of the answers Al-Nawawi mentioned except the first answer, which is that the hadith is weak so there is no proof in it. However, what Al-Nawawi recounted of its weakening is not sufficient to convince. Al-Nawawi himself said in (Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab): (It is weak by agreement of the Hafizs. Among those who explicitly stated its weakness are Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal, Abu Bakr bin Al-Mundhir, Al-Bayhaqi, and others. Ahmad said: This hadith is among what was uniquely narrated...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...by Salih Mawla Al-Taw'amah. There is disagreement regarding his integrity, but most of what they faulted him for is confusion (Ikhtilat). They said: And the hearing of Ibn Abi Dhi'b and his likes from him was before the confusion, and this hadith is from the narration of Ibn Abi Dhi'b from him). I say: In (Al-Taqrib): (Truthful (Saduq), he became confused at the end of his life. Ibn Adi said: There is no harm in the narration of the early ones from him like Ibn Abi Dhi'b and Ibn Jurayj). I say: If Ibn Abi Dhi'b narrated from him before the confusion, and this hadith is from his narration from him, then how is his hadith weak? Therefore, Ibn Al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Al-Zad) after quoting the sayings of the Imams about him which revolve around what Ibn Adi stated: (This hadith is Hasan because it is from the narration of Ibn Abi Dhi'b from him, and his hearing from him is old, before his confusion, so his confusion is not a cause to reject what he narrated before confusion). I say: This is the truth if Ibn Abi Dhi'b had not heard from him after that, but that is not the case. (Al-Tirmidhi said from Al-Bukhari from Ahmad bin Hanbal who said: Ibn Abi Dhi'b heard from Salih lately and narrated rejected reports (Munkar) from him). Ibn Al-Qattan quoted it from Al-Tirmidhi like this. I say: In this is the explanation for the reason of Ahmad's weakening of the hadith, which is that Ibn Abi Dhi'b narrated from him after the confusion as well. Perhaps it is the basis for Ibn Hibban's saying in (Kitab Al-Du'afa):

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: (He became confused at the end of his life, and his recent hadith could not be distinguished from his old, so he deserved abandonment). Then he mentioned this hadith for him and said: (It is false; how could the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say it when he prayed over Suhail bin Bayda in the mosque). Thus the defect of the hadith becomes clear, and that it is weak and does not stand against the authentic hadith of Aisha. The truth is that bringing the funeral into the mosque and praying in it is permissible without dislike, but that was not his custom, peace and blessings be upon him; rather, the majority of his practice was praying over it outside the mosque, so it is better, as will be explained God willing in (Funerals). (7 - Bringing in a Polytheist (Mushrik) for a need, and there are hadiths regarding it: (a) Abu Huraira said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent cavalry towards Najd, and they brought a man from Bani Hanifa called Thumamah bin Uthal [the master of the people of Yamama]. They tied him to one of the pillars of the mosque. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came out to him and said [to him]: (What do you have, O Thumamah?) He said: I have good, O Muhammad: If you kill, you kill one with blood [to be avenged]; if you show favor, you show favor to a grateful one; and if you want wealth, ask [and you will be given] whatever you wish of it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, left him until the next day, then said: (What do you have, O Thumamah?) He said: What I told you: If you show favor, you show favor to a grateful one; if you kill, you kill one with blood [to be avenged]; and if you want wealth, ask [and you will be given] whatever you wish of it. [The Messenger of Allah] left him until the day after (and in a wording: after)...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...tomorrow, then said: (What do you have, O Thumamah?) He said: I have what I told you [If you show favor, you show favor to a grateful one; if you kill, you kill one with blood; and if you want wealth, ask and you will be given whatever you wish of it]. So [the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him] said: (Release Thumamah). He went to a palm grove near the mosque and washed himself, then entered the mosque and said: I testify that there is no god but Allah and I testify that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger (and in a wording: O Messenger of Allah) O Muhammad, by Allah, there was no face on earth more hateful to me than your face, but now your face has become the most beloved of [all] faces to me. By Allah, there was no religion more hateful to me than your religion, but now your religion has become the most beloved of [all] religion to me. By Allah, there was no land more hateful to me than your land, but now your land has become the most beloved of [all] lands to me. Your cavalry took me while I was intending Umrah, so what do you see? The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, gave him glad tidings and ordered him to perform Umrah. When he arrived in Mecca, someone said to him: Have you turned Sabian [apostate]? He said: No, but I have submitted (became Muslim) with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. No, by Allah, not a grain of wheat will come to you from Yamama until the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, permits it. The Hadith was recorded by Al-Bukhari, Muslim - and the context is his - Abu Dawood, and Al-Bayhaqi, but they did not quote it completely, and Ahmad via Al-Layth bin Sa'd who said: Saeed narrated to me that he heard Abu Huraira with it. All additions are from Muslim and Ahmad except the second one, which is for Ahmad alone. The second and third wordings are his and Al-Bukhari's as well. Abdul Hamid bin Ja'far followed him in Muslim: Saeed bin Abi Saeed narrated to me with it similarly.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Ibn Ajlan followed him from Saeed with it similarly, and added at the end: (Umar said: By Allah, he was smaller in my eyes than a pig, and [now] he is greater in my eyes than a mountain. He was let go, so he came to Yamama and withheld from them [supplies], so they cried out and complained, and wrote: Order the connection [of supplies]. He said: So he wrote to him). Thus Ahmad recorded it, and its chain is good (Hasan). Then he recorded it briefly via the path of Abdullah bin Umar from Saeed Al-Maqburi with it: That Thumamah bin Uthal Al-Hanafi became Muslim, so the Prophet, peace be upon him, ordered that he go to the garden of Abu Talha and wash. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: (The Islam of your companion has become good). This is a weak chain because this Abdullah bin Umar - who is Al-Umari Al-Mukabbir - has poor memory and has brought something unique excluding trustworthy narrators in this hadith. (b) Jubayr bin Mut'im said: I came to Medina regarding the ransom of Badr (and in a narration: ransom of the Polytheists). He said: And he was a polytheist on that day. He said: So I entered the mosque while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was praying the Maghrib prayer, and he recited {At-Tur} in it. [When he reached this verse: {Or were they created by nothing, or were they the creators [of themselves]? Or did they create the heavens and the earth? Rather, they are not certain. Or have they the depositories of...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...your Lord, or are they the controllers? [Or have they a stairway [into the heaven] upon which they listen? Then let their listener produce a clear authority]} [At-Tur / 38]] my heart almost flew]. (And in the first narration: It was as if my heart cracked due to the recitation of the Quran). The hadith was recorded by Al-Tayalisi, and from him Al-Bayhaqi - and the context is his - and Ahmad - and the second narration is his - via the path of Shu'bah from Sa'd bin Ibrahim who said: Some of my brothers narrated to me from Abu Jubayr bin Mut'im with it. Al-Tahawi also recorded it from Wahb bin Jarir, and Al-Khatib in his (Tarikh) from Yaqub bin Ishaq Al-Hadrami, both from Shu'bah with it. Al-Hadrami said: From Sa'd bin Ibrahim from his brother. They do not have the mention of the mosque. Then Al-Khatib said: (Ghundar and others followed him from Shu'bah. Abu Umar Al-Hawdi narrated it from Shu'bah from Sa'd bin Ibrahim from some of his brothers from Jubayr bin Mut'im. Abu Al-Walid Al-Tayalisi contradicted him, narrating it from Shu'bah from Sa'd bin Ibrahim from Jubayr bin Mut'im. The hadith of Yaqub Al-Hadrami and those who followed him is the correct one). I say: This is a Sahih chain, God willing. Its men are all trustworthy men of the Six Books. The brother of Sa'd bin Ibrahim is Yaqub bin Ibrahim, for he is the one known for his brother Sa'd narrating from him. Al-Bukhari recorded it via the path of Sufyan bin Uyaynah who said: They narrated to me...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...from Al-Zuhri from Muhammad bin Jubayr with it similarly with some abbreviation, and it contains the first addition. Ibn Majah recorded it from Muhammad bin Al-Sabah: Sufyan informed us from Al-Zuhri with it, containing the other addition. Thus Ibn Al-Sabah narrated it from Sufyan from Al-Zuhri without an intermediary. Perhaps the first narration is the correct one, but Al-Hafiz did not mention nor name those who narrated it to Ibn Uyaynah, as if he did not come across that. Al-Bukhari also recorded it in (Af'al Al-Ibad) via the path of Muhammad bin Ishaq from Al-Zuhri with it using the wording: I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, regarding the ransom of captives, so I slept in a mosque after Asr while I was in my polytheism. By Allah, nothing woke me except the recitation of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in Maghrib with {At-Tur. And a Book inscribed}. Its men are trustworthy, all men of Muslim, except Muhammad bin Ishaq who is trustworthy but a Mudallis and used 'an'ana. It is in the (Two Sahihs), (Al-Muwatta), (Sunan) of Abu Dawood and Al-Nasa'i, and the (Two Musnads) as well via paths from Al-Zuhri briefly with the wording: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, recite {At-Tur} in Maghrib. I found a third path for the hadith recorded by Al-Tabarani in his (Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir). He said: Ahmad bin Zuhair Al-Tustari and Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Shu'aib Al-Rajafi narrated to us...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...they said: Muhammad bin Umar Al-Bahrani narrated to us: Abu Amir Al-Aqadi informed us: Abu Amr Al-Sadusi informed us from Abdullah bin Abi Bakr bin Muhammad bin Amr bin Hazm: Uthman bin Abi Sulaiman informed me from Nafi bin Jubayr from Jubayr bin Mut'im who said: I came to Medina when I came to it, and I was not a Muslim that day, and severe drowsiness had befallen me. I arrived at the mosque until I was startled by the recitation of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for Maghrib, reciting in {At-Tur. And a Book inscribed}. I pronounced 'Inna lillah' (Istirja') until I exited the mosque, and that was the first time Islam entered my heart. This is a Sahih chain; its men are all trustworthy men of Muslim except the two Sheikhs of Al-Tabarani, whom I did not find biographies for. Abu Amr Al-Sadusi is Saeed bin Salamah bin Abi Al-Husam Al-Adawi. In the chapter from Abu Huraira who said: The Jews came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, while he was sitting in the mosque among his companions, and said: O Abu Al-Qasim, regarding a man and a woman from them who committed adultery. Recorded by Abu Dawood, and via his path Al-Bayhaqi from Ma'mar from Al-Zuhri: A man from Muzaynah narrated to us while we were with Saeed bin Al-Musayyib from him. Al-Mundhiri said: (A man from Muzaynah is unknown). I say: Then Abu Dawood recorded it via the path of Muhammad bin Ishaq...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...and Yunus from Al-Zuhri: I heard a man from Muzaynah who follows knowledge and retains it. With it more complete than it. And from Uthman bin Abi Al-Aas Al-Thaqafi: That the delegation of Thaqif came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, so he lodged them in the mosque so it would be softer for their hearts. They stipulated to the Prophet, peace be upon him, that they not be gathered (for war/labor), nor pay tithes, nor bow in prayer, and that no one other than them be appointed over them. He said: (You will not be gathered, nor pay tithes, nor bow, and no one other than you will be appointed over you. And there is no good in a religion that has no bowing). Recorded by Al-Tayalisi, and via his path Abu Dawood, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad from the hadith of Hammad bin Salamah from Humaid from Al-Hasan from him. This is a chain whose men are all trustworthy men of Muslim, so it is Sahih if Al-Hasan heard it from Uthman. Then Al-Bayhaqi said: (Ash'ath narrated it from Al-Hasan as Mursal with some of its meaning, adding: It was said: O Messenger of Allah, you lodged them in the mosque while they are polytheists? He said: (The earth does not become impure; only the son of Adam becomes impure). The hadith was recorded by Ibn Abi Shaybah and Al-Tabarani also from the narration of Al-Hasan from Uthman as in (Takhrij Al-Kashshaf). As for this Mursal addition, some have narrated it as connected (Mawsul). Abu Bakr Al-Jassas said in (Ahkam Al-Quran):

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (Hammad bin Salamah narrated from Humaid from Al-Hasan from Uthman bin Abi Al-Aas: That when the delegation of Thaqif came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he pitched a tent for them in the mosque. They said: O Messenger of Allah, [we are] an unclean people. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (There is nothing of the uncleanness of people upon the earth; rather, the uncleanness of people is upon themselves). Yunus narrated from Al-Zuhri bin Al-Musayyib: That Abu Sufyan used to enter the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was a disbeliever, except that this is not lawful in the Sacred Mosque due to the statement of Allah: {so let them not approach the Sacred Mosque} [At-Tawbah / 28]. Abu Bakr said: As for the delegation of Thaqif, they came after the conquest of Mecca to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the verse was revealed in the year in which Abu Bakr performed Hajj, which is the ninth year. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, lodged them in the mosque and informed that their being unclean does not prevent their entry into the mosque. In that, there is evidence that the impurity of disbelief does not prevent the disbeliever from entering the mosque. As for Abu Sufyan, he came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to renew the truce, and that was before the Conquest, and Abu Sufyan was a polytheist at that time. Even if the verse's revelation was after that, it only implied the prohibition of approaching the Sacred Mosque and did not imply prohibiting disbelievers from entering other mosques). In summary, there is a view regarding the validity of this addition in the Hadith because it is Mursal according to Al-Bayhaqi, and we have not found it connected except in what Abu Bakr Al-Jassas cited in a suspended manner. I say this, even if Siddiq Hasan Khan used it as evidence in (Ar-Rawdah An-Nadiyyah)

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: and we do not know his chain of transmission for that. This is with the knowledge that the origin of the Hadith, regarding its validity, is subject to scrutiny due to what preceded regarding its defect. And Allah knows best. (And all mosques are equal in that regard except the Sacred Mosque, for it is not permissible to enable them to approach it due to the saying of the Exalted: {O you who have believed, indeed the polytheists are unclean, so let them not approach the Sacred Mosque after this, their [final] year} [At-Tawbah / 28]). The verse is evidence for the prohibition of the entry of disbelievers and polytheists into the Sacred Mosque. This wording indicates the entire Haram (Sanctuary), which is the school of Ata bin Abi Rabah, who said: (The entire Haram is a Qiblah and a Mosque, so they should be prevented from entering the Haram due to the saying of the Exalted: {Glory be to Him who took His Servant by night from the Sacred Mosque} while he was only taken up from the house of Umm Hani). Al-Qurtubi mentioned it and then said: (Therefore, it is forbidden to enable a polytheist to enter the Haram entirely. If a messenger comes from them, the Imam goes out to the Hill (non-sanctuary area) to hear what he says). I say: Specifying the Sacred Mosque by mention in the noble verse indicates that other mosques do not share its ruling, so the entry of polytheists into them is permissible. This is supported by the preceding Hadiths. Ibn Hazm went to this view in (Al-Muhalla), saying: (And the entry of polytheists into all mosques is permissible except the Haram of Mecca entirely, the Mosque and other than it; it is not lawful at all for a disbeliever to enter it. This is the saying of Al-Shafi'i and Abu Sulayman. Abu Hanifa said: There is no harm if a Jew or a Christian enters it, but other religions are prevented from it

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: and Malik disliked the entry of anyone from the disbelievers into any of the mosques. Allah the Exalted said: {Indeed the polytheists are unclean...} the verse. Ibn Hazm said: So Allah specified the Sacred Mosque; thus, it is not permissible to extend it to others without a text). I say: The followers of Malik argued for his school using the reasoning mentioned in the verse, so they applied it to all mosques. Al-Qurtubi said: (Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The verse is general regarding all polytheists but specific to the Sacred Mosque, and they are not prevented from entering others; so he permitted the entry of Jews and Christians into other mosques). Ibn Al-Arabi said: (This is rigidity from him upon the apparent meaning because the saying of the Mighty and Majestic: {Indeed the polytheists are unclean} [At-Tawbah / 28] is an alert to the cause being polytheism and impurity). Siddiq Khan said in (Nayl Al-Maram): (This is answered by the fact that this analogy is rejected by his, peace and blessings be upon him, tying of Thumamah bin Uthal in his mosque and lodging the delegation of Thaqif in it). I say: As for tying Thumamah, Ibn Al-Arabi himself answered it by saying it was before the revelation of the verse. Ibn Al-Arabi himself answered similarly regarding Abu Sufyan entering the mosque as preceded. As for the lodging of the delegation of Thaqif in it, if its chain were authentic, it would be a proof against them with no answer for it, because it was after the revelation of the verse as previously mentioned from Abu Bakr Al-Jassas. I say: The transmission from Abu Hanifa regarding this issue has differed; for Ibn Hazm narrated

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: from him - as preceded - the permissibility of the entry of the Jew and the Christian only into the Sacred Mosque and other mosques. This agrees with what Al-Jassas recounted in (Al-Ahkam) and Al-Ayni in (Al-Umdah) from Abu Hanifa. Al-Ayni said: (And he argued with what Ahmad narrated in his (Musnad) with a good chain from Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (No polytheist shall enter this mosque of ours after this year of ours, except for the people of the covenant and their servants).) Others besides these attributed to Abu Hanifa the opinion of the permissibility of the polytheist entering as well. In (Fath Al-Bari): (Regarding the entry of the polytheist into the mosque, there are schools of thought. From the Hanafis is permissibility absolutely. From the Malikis and Al-Muzani is prohibition absolutely. From the Shafi'is is the detailing between the Sacred Mosque and others due to the verse. And it is said: Permission is given to the Scriptuary (Kitabi) specifically. The Hadith of the chapter refutes this, for Thumamah was not from the People of the Book). This transmission is supported by what is in (Fayd Al-Bari): (As for the Hanafis, they said: The polytheist is not physically impure, and he may enter the Sacred Mosque and others, as in (Al-Jami' As-Saghir), so the verse was problematic for them. I say: In (As-Siyar Al-Kabir), it states that he does not enter the Sacred Mosque according to us as well, as is the apparent meaning of the text. It was chosen in (Ad-Durr Al-Mukhtar) because it is the last of the writings of Muhammad, may Allah be pleased with him. Then Sheikh Al-Kashmiri, the author of (Al-Fayd), explicitly stated his choice of it and reasoned for that by his saying in what preceded of the book:

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (For it is more consistent with the Qur'an and closer to the Imams). I say: As for the Hadith of Jabir which Abu Hanifa used as proof, it is not authentic because it is from the narration of Sharik from Ash'ath bin Sawar from Al-Hasan from him, and it is in (Al-Musnad) from two paths from Sharik. It has two defects: First: The 'an'an (using the word "from") of Al-Hasan Al-Basri, and he is a Mudallis (obfuscator in narration) as in (At-Taqrib) and others. The other: The weakness of Sharik - who is the Judge - regarding his memory. It has come with a strong chain halted (Mauquf) at Jabir, which is the correct view. Abu Bakr Al-Jassas said after mentioning it from this mode in a suspended manner: (Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ishaq Al-Marwazi told us, he said: Al-Hasan bin Abi Ar-Rabi' Al-Jurjani told us, he said: Abdur-Razzaq informed us: Ibn Jurayj informed us: Abu Az-Zubayr informed me that he heard Jabir bin Abdullah say regarding the saying of the Exalted: {Indeed the polytheists are unclean, so let them not approach the Sacred Mosque}: Except if he is a slave or one of the people of the Dhimma). I say: This is an authentic chain. Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ishaq is Abu Al-Qasim, known as Hamid Ra'sihi; Al-Khatib wrote his biography in his (Tarikh) and said: (Al-Barqani said: I asked Al-Abhari about him, and he said: Trustworthy, died in the year three hundred and twenty-nine). His Sheikh, Al-Hasan bin Abi Ar-Rabi' Al-Jurjani, is one of the Sheikhs of Ibn Majah, and he is Al-Hasan bin Yahya bin Al-Ja'd bin Nashit; Al-Khatib also wrote his biography and said:

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (Ibn Abi Hatim Ar-Razi said: I heard from him with my father, and he is truthful). Likewise, Al-Hafiz said in (At-Taqrib) that he is: (Truthful). The rest of the men of the chain are trustworthy according to the criteria of Muslim. From this, you know that the statement of Ibn Al-Arabi: (It is a weak chain) is incorrect. Then Abu Bakr Al-Jassas said: (Abu Az-Zubayr halted it at Jabir (meaning Al-Hasan raised it to the Prophet), and it is possible that both are correct, so Jabir might have raised it at times and gave a fatwa with it at other times). I say: This reconciliation is good, but it is only resorted to if the one who raised it is an authority in his narration and memory, and you have known that there are two defects in the raised (Marfu') narration, unlike this halted (Mauquf) one, so it was the preferred one. (Anecdote): Ibn Al-Arabi said: (I used to see a wonder in Damascus: Its grand mosque had two gates: an eastern gate, which is the Gate of Jayrun, and a western gate. People used to make it a path they walked upon all day for their needs. The Dhimmi (non-Muslim subject), if he wanted to pass, would stand at the gate until a Muslim passed by him

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: crossing, so the Dhimmi would say to him: O Muslim, do you permit me to pass with you? He would say: Yes. So he would enter with him, wearing the Ghiyar - the badge of the people of the Dhimma. If the custodian saw him, he would shout at him: Go back, go back. The Muslim would say to him: I gave him permission. So the custodian would leave him). This, and Ibn Hazm has a valuable research in this station in verifying that the word (Mushrikin) [polytheists] in the previous verse includes Jews and Christians, contrary to Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him. It must be quoted due to the benefits within it and the refutation of some doubts regarding certain verses, which might not be found in another book. He, may Allah have mercy on him, said: (As for the statement of Abu Hanifa, he said: Allah the Exalted has differentiated between the polytheists and the rest of the disbelievers, saying the Exalted: {Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from their disbelief]} [Al-Bayyinah / 1]. And the Exalted said: {Indeed, those who have believed and those who were Jews and the Sabeans and the Christians and the Magians and those who associated others with Allah - indeed, Allah will judge between them} [Al-Hajj / 17]. He said: The Mushrik (polytheist) is the one who sets up a partner for Allah, not the one who does not set up a partner for Him. Ibn Hazm said: He has no argument other than what we mentioned. As for his attachment to the two verses, there is no argument for him in them because Allah the Exalted said: {In both of them are fruit and date palms and pomegranates} [Ar-Rahman / 68], and the pomegranate is a fruit. And the Exalted said: {Whoever is an enemy to Allah and His angels and His messengers and Gabriel and Michael} [Al-Baqarah / 98], and they are among the angels. And the Exalted said: {And [mention, O Muhammad], when We took from the prophets their covenant and from you and from Noah and Abraham and Moses and Jesus} [Al-Ahzab / 7], and these are among the prophets

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: Except that what Abu Hanifa used as an argument would be an argument if a proof did not come that Jews, Christians, Magians, and Sabeans are polytheists, because nothing conjoined to another thing is interpreted as being other than it until a proof comes that it is it or part of it. So we say, and with Allah is success: The first contradictor of the text of the two verses is Abu Hanifa, because the Magians are polytheists according to him, yet Allah the Exalted differentiated in mention between the Magians and the polytheists, so his attachment to Allah's conjoining of one group to the other is invalidated. Then we found that Allah the Exalted has said: {Indeed, Allah does not forgive that you associate partners with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills} [An-Nisa / 48]. If there were a disbelief here that is not polytheism (Shirk), it would be forgiven for whom Allah the Exalted wills, contrary to Shirk, and no Muslim says this. Then Ibn Hazm narrated via the path of Muslim with his chain to Ibn Mas'ud who said: A man said: O Messenger of Allah, which sin is greatest with Allah? He said: That you call upon a rival for Allah while He created you. He said: Then which? He said: That you kill your child for fear that he eats with you. And from his path also with his chain from Abu Bakrah who said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, so he said: (Shall I not inform you of the greatest of major sins? Three times. Associating partners with Allah, disobedience to parents, and false testimony or false speech). And from him also from Abu Hurairah in a raised report: (Avoid the seven destructors). It was said: O Messenger of Allah, and what are they? He said:

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (Associating partners with Allah, magic, killing the soul which Allah has forbidden except by right, consuming the orphan's wealth, consuming usury, fleeing on the day of the march [battle], and slandering chaste, unaware, believing women). Ali bin Hazm said: If there were a disbelief here that is not polytheism, that disbelief would be outside of the major sins, and disobedience to parents and false testimony would be greater than it; and no Muslim says this. So it is correct that every disbelief is polytheism and every polytheism is disbelief, and they are two Sharia names which Allah the Exalted applied to one meaning. As for his argument that the polytheist is only the one who sets up a partner for Allah, it is demolished against him from two aspects: One of them: The Christians set up a partner for Allah who creates like His creation, yet he says: They are not polytheists. This is a clear contradiction. The second: The Brahmins and those who say the world is eternal and that it has one eternal Creator, and those who say regarding the prophethood of Ali bin Abi Talib and Al-Mughirah and Bazigh—all of them do not set up a partner for Allah the Exalted, yet they are polytheists according to Abu Hanifa. This is a clear contradiction. And a third aspect: Which is that if the polytheist were not such unless the name of 'association' (Tashrik) in the language applied to him—which is whoever sets up a partner for Allah the Exalted only—it would be obligatory that disbelief not be such unless from one who disbelieved in Allah the Exalted and denied Him entirely, not from one who acknowledged Him and did not deny Him. This would entail that there are no disbelievers except the Dahriyyah (materialists/atheists) only, and that the Jews, Christians, Magians, and Brahmins are not disbelievers because they are all acknowledgers of Allah the Exalted; and neither he nor any Muslim says this

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: on the face of the earth. Or it would be obligatory that everyone who covered something be a Kafir (disbeliever), for Kufr in the language is: covering. Since all of this is false, it is correct that they are two names which Allah the Exalted transferred from their subject in the language to apply to everyone who denies anything from the religion of Islam, being in his denial obstinate towards the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, after the warning reached him. And with Allah the Exalted is success). I say: The obligation mentioned in the third aspect did not appear correct to me, because he who says that Shirk is other than Kufr makes it more specific than it, and it is known that the specific enters into the general, like the entry of Christians and Jews among the polytheists according to Ibn Hazm in the previous verse, and according to others from the predecessors among the Companions and the Successors in the saying of the Exalted: {And do not marry polytheistic women until they believe, and a believing slave woman is better than a polytheist woman, even though she might please you. And do not marry polytheistic men [to your women] until they believe} [Al-Baqarah / 221] the verse. So everyone who commits Shirk has committed Kufr by agreement, so the obligation is not valid. However, Ibn Hazm says the reverse as well, which is that everyone who disbelieves by any of the nullifiers has committed Shirk, and the evidences he cited support that. I do not know what contradicts that from the Book and the Sunnah. Rather, the apparent meaning of the saying of the Exalted in Surah Al-Kahf: {And present to them an example of two men: We granted to one of them two gardens of grapevines, and We bordered them with palm trees, and We placed between them crops} [Al-Kahf / 32] to the saying of the Exalted: {And he said to his companion while he conversed with him, "I am greater than you in wealth and mightier in numbers." And he entered his garden while he was unjust to himself. He said, "I do not think that this will perish ever. And I do not think the Hour will occur. And even if I should be brought back to my Lord, I will surely find better than this as a return." His companion said to him while he conversed with him, "Have you disbelieved in He who created you from dust and then from a sperm-drop and then proportioned you [as] a man? But as for me, He is Allah, my Lord

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: and I do not associate with my Lord anyone} the verses [Al-Kahf / 34-38] to the saying of the Exalted: {And his fruits were encompassed, so he began to turn his hands over what he had spent on it, while it was fallen upon its trellises and said, "Oh, I wish I had not associated with my Lord anyone"} [Al-Kahf / 42]. So He, Glory be to Him, applied to this man who denied the Resurrection and the Gathering that he associated partners with Him, the Exalted. This is apparent from the context of the verses, for the Exalted did not recount about him any disbelief other than what was mentioned, then He recounted his regret when he saw what befell his fruits and his two gardens by his saying: {Oh, I wish I had not associated with my Lord anyone}. So He applied Shirk to the mentioned disbelief. Perhaps the reason is that his denial of the Resurrection is a resort to the idea that Allah the Exalted is not capable of it, which is incapacitating the Lord, Glory be to Him and Exalted, and whoever incapacitates Him, Glory be to Him and Exalted, has likened Him to His creation; so it is polytheism). Al-Qurtubi mentioned it similarly. And Allah knows best. (8 - Bringing a Riding Animal in for a Need: Because he, upon him be peace and blessings, entered the Sacred Mosque circling on his she-camel, as Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: (The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, circled in the Farewell Pilgrimage on his mount at the House and between As-Safa and Al-Marwah so that the people could see him and so he could look over [them] and they could ask him, [for] the people crowded him) the Hadith. Muslim, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ahmad extracted it from the path of Ibn Jurayj: Abu Az-Zubayr informed me that he heard Jabir bin Abdullah. The context is Ahmad's, the addition is Muslim's and Abu Dawood's, and a narration belongs to Ahmad. It has a witness from the Hadith of Aisha in Muslim and An-Nasa'i with the wording:

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, circled in the Farewell Pilgrimage around the Kaaba on a camel, touching the Corner with his hooked staff. Muslim added: Disliking that the people push him away. And another from the Hadith of Abu At-Tufayl. In the chapter is a report from Umm Salamah regarding her circling while riding, and they will come in (The Hajj) if Allah the Exalted wills. Al-Bukhari titled the Hadith of Umm Salamah in (The Book of Prayer) as: (Chapter: Bringing the Camel into the Mosque for a Cause), meaning: A need. Ibn Battal said: (In this Hadith is the permissibility of the entry of animals whose meat is eaten into the mosque if that is needed, because their urine does not make it impure, unlike other animals. This was critiqued [by saying] that there is no indication in the Hadith of impermissibility when there is a need; rather, that revolves around pollution and the lack thereof, so where pollution is feared, entry is prevented). Al-Ayni objected to him in his (Sharh) saying: (There is a consideration in it, because his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (Circle while you are riding (meaning Umm Salamah) does not indicate that permissibility and the lack thereof revolve around pollution; rather, its apparent meaning indicates permissibility absolutely in case of necessity. And it was said: His she-camel was trained and taught, so what is feared of pollution is secured from her while she is moving. I say: We grant this regarding the she-camel of the Prophet, upon him be peace and blessings

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: but what is said regarding the she-camel that Umm Salamah was upon while she was circling? If it is said: It was the she-camel of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. It is said to him: That needs to be clarified with evidence). (9 - Ablution: For (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, performed ablution in the mosque) the Hadith. Ahmad extracted it: Waki' told us from Abu Khalid from Abu Al-Aliyah from a man from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: I memorized for you that... etc. This is a good chain as Al-Haythami said. I say: Its men are trustworthy, the men of the two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim], except Abu Khalid, who is Muhajir bin Makhlad Abu Makhlad, and it is said: Abu Khalid, the client of the Bakrat. He narrated from Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Bakrah and Abu Al-Aliyah Ar-Rayahi. And from him narrated Awf Al-A'rabi, Wuhayb, Khalid Al-Hadhdha, Hammad bin Zayd, his brother Sa'id bin Zayd, and Abdul-Wahhab Ath-Thaqafi. Wuhayb used to criticize him and say: (He does not memorize). Ibn Ma'in said: (Salih [acceptable]). Abu Hatim said: (Lenient in Hadith, not all that, and not precise; his Hadith is written). Ibn Hibban mentioned him in (Ath-Thiqat). As-Saji said: (He is truthful, well-known; whoever says about him: 'unknown' is nothing [wrong]). I say: So he is Good (Hasan) in Hadith if Allah the Exalted wills, provided he does not contradict

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: And it is authentic that Abu Huraira performed ablution on the roof of the mosque. Ahmad and Muslim extracted it. In the Hadith is the permissibility of ablution in the mosque. An-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (Ibn Al-Mundhir reported the consensus of the scholars on its permissibility as long as he does not harm anyone with it). I say: Al-Iraqi said in (Sharh At-Taqrib): (Ibn Battal narrated its permissibility from most of the people of knowledge, and he narrated from Malik and Sahnun its dislike as a purification for the mosque). I say: The Hadith is a proof against them. Yes, it must not be accompanied by what violates [decorum] legally, as is the reality today in most mosques which piped water (Fayjah) has been drawn to, due to what is heard of the loud sound from the rush of water from the (faucets) and its collision with the tiles, which causes noise and disturbance to those praying in it. Therefore, we see that it is necessary to place the ablution facility in a confined place beside the mosques, not inside them, as is the matter in the Mosque of (Isa Pasha) facing Souq Al-Hamidiyah and others.
