(10 - Gathering and Sitting in Circles to Study the Qur'an and Knowledge: Due to the Hadith: While he was sitting in the mosque and the people were with him, three people approached. Two approached the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and one went away. [When they stood over the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, they greeted him]. As for one of them, he saw a gap in the circle so he sat in it. As for the other, he sat

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: behind them. As for the third, he turned back going away. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, finished, he said: (Shall I not inform you about the three people?) [They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah. He said:] (As for one of them, he sought shelter with Allah, so Allah sheltered him. As for the other, he was shy, so Allah was shy of him. As for the other, he turned away, so Allah turned away from him) the Hadith. From the narration of Abu Waqid Al-Laithi, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Bukhari extracted it - and the context is his in a narration - and Muslim and At-Tirmidhi, all three of them from Malik from Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talha: That Abu Murrah, the client of Aqil bin Abi Talib, informed him from him. Al-Hafiz attributed it to An-Nasa'i as well and said: (It is in (Al-Muwatta). I say: I did not find it now with them. The first addition belongs to At-Tirmidhi, and it is at An-Nasa'i's as well and most narrators of Al-Muwatta as in (Al-Fath). Ahmad extracted it from the path of Yahya bin Abi Kathir: Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talha told me the same. And in it is the other addition.
foot_note: 1. (1) Then I found it in (Al-Muwatta) (3/ 132-133) containing the first addition. I found a witness for the Hadith from the narration of Anas similar to it. Al-Hakim extracted it (4/ 255) and authenticated it, and Adh-Dhahabi agreed with him. It has a good chain of transmission.

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: Muslim also extracted it from this mode, but he did not cite its wording; rather, he referred to what was before it by his saying: (With its like in meaning). An-Nawawi said in the explanation of the Hadith: (In it is the desirability of the scholar sitting for his companions and others in a prominent place visible to the people - and the mosque is best - so he reminds them of knowledge and goodness. In it is the permissibility of circles of knowledge and remembrance in the mosque, the desirability of entering them and sitting with their people, and the dislike of turning away from them without an excuse... etc.). Al-Hafiz said: (As for what Muslim narrated from the Hadith of Jabir bin Samura who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered the mosque while they were in circles, so he said: (What is the matter with me that I see you as 'Izin [separate groups]). There is no contradiction between it and this, because he only disliked their circling over what has no benefit or utility, contrary to their circling around him, for that was to hear knowledge and learn from him). I say: This Hadith does not contain his denial, upon him be peace and blessings, of their circling absolutely; rather, he only denied their separating into circles and circles. This is the meaning of his saying: ('Izin). An-Nawawi said: (Meaning: Separate, group by group. It is with the lightening of the Zay, the singular is 'Izah. Its meaning is the prohibition of separation and the command of gathering). I say: This is supported by the fact that Abu Dawood extracted the Hadith from the path of Al-A'mash, then narrated following that from him that he said:

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (It is as if he loves the group/congregation). So the Hadith, therefore, has no relation to forming circles, neither negatively nor positively. (And (He came out to a circle of his companions and said: (What made you sit?) They said: We sat remembering Allah and praising Him for guiding us to Islam and bestowing it (and in a wording: (you) upon us. He said: (By Allah, nothing made you sit except that?) They said: By Allah, nothing made us sit except that. He said: (Behold, indeed I did not ask you to swear out of suspicion of you, but Gabriel came to me and informed me: That Allah boasts of you to the angels) the Hadith. From the narration of Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan. Muslim extracted it - and the context is his - and An-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad from the path of Marhum bin Abdul-Aziz from Abu Na'amah As-Sa'di from Abu Uthman from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri from him. The other wording belongs to An-Nasa'i and Ahmad. (And he, upon him be peace and blessings, said: (No people gathered (and in a wording: (There are no people who gather) in a house of the houses of Allah the Exalted reciting [and learning] the Book of Allah and studying it amongst themselves except that tranquility descended upon them, mercy covered them, the angels surrounded them, and Allah mentioned them among those who are with Him) the Hadith. From the narration of Abu Huraira. Muslim, Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad extracted it

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: from Al-A'mash from Abu Salih from him. The other wording and the addition belong to Ahmad. Then it is a fragment of a Hadith in Muslim and Ibn Majah. Al-Mundhiri attributed it in its entirety to Abu Dawood, At-Tirmidhi, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah in his (Sahih), and Al-Hakim, and said: (Authentic on their condition). An-Nawawi said in (Sharh Muslim): (It was said the intended meaning of Sakina (tranquility) here is mercy, which is what Qadi Iyad chose, but it is weak due to the conjunction of mercy upon it. It was said: Reassurance and dignity, which is better. In this is evidence for the merit of gathering to recite the Qur'an in the mosque, which is our school and the school of the majority. Malik said: It is disliked. And some of his companions interpreted it). I say: Perhaps the interpretation referred to is that what Malik disliked of the gathering was what contradicted his guidance, upon him be peace and blessings, therein, like gathering for recitation with one voice (unison), for it is an innovation that was not transmitted from him, upon him be peace and blessings, nor from any of the Companions. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to sometimes command whoever recited the Qur'an so he could hear his recitation, just as Ibn Mas'ud recited to him, and he said: (I love to hear it from other than myself). Umar used to command whoever recited to him and his companions while they listened; so sometimes he commanded Abu Musa and sometimes he commanded Uqbah bin Amir. Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab narrated it in (Jami' Al-Ulum wal-Hikam) then said: (Harb mentioned that he saw the people of Damascus, the people of Homs, the people of Mecca, and the people of Basra gathering for the Qur'an after the Dawn Prayer. However, the people of the Sham (Levant) recite the Qur'an all of them

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: entirely from one Surah with loud voices, while the people of Mecca and the people of Basra gather, so one of them recites ten verses and the people listen, then another recites ten verses until they finish. Harb said: And all of that is good and beautiful. Malik denied that upon the people of Sham). I say: This which Malik denied is the truth, if Allah the Exalted wills, due to its contradiction of the Sunnah as preceded. (Except that this is not permissible before the Friday prayer specifically, as preceded in (The Prohibitions) paragraph (5). (11 - Reciting Good Poetry Occasionally, Especially if it is in Defense of Islam: For then it is from Jihad. (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to place a pulpit for Hassan in the mosque which he would stand upon boasting on behalf of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him (and in a wording: (defending him with poetry) and in another: mocking those who spoke against the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would say: (Indeed Allah supports Hassan with the Holy Spirit as long as he defends or boasts on behalf of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him) the Hadith. From the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. Abu Dawood - and the third wording is his - and At-Tirmidhi and Al-Hakim - and the context is his - and Ahmad - and the second wording as well as the addition are his - extracted it from paths from Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Az-Zanad from his father from Urwah and Hisham bin Urwah from Urwah from her

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: This is a good chain. At-Tirmidhi said: (Good Authentic [Hasan Sahih]). Al-Hakim said: (Authentic in chain). And Adh-Dhahabi agreed with him. It is in (Sahih Muslim) from another path from her, but it does not contain the placing of the pulpit in the mosque. In it is: And he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: (Hassan mocked them, so he healed and was healed). Hassan said: I mocked Muhammad so I answered on his behalf - And with Allah, in that, is the reward. The verses in their entirety. (And (Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, passed by Hassan while he was reciting [poetry] in the mosque [so he glanced at him] [and said: Hush]. He said: [- in a circle in which was Abu Huraira -]: I used to recite while in it was one who is better than you. [Then he turned to Abu Huraira and said: Did you hear the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: (Answer for me, O Allah aid him with the Holy Spirit)? He said: Yes] [So Umar left while knowing that he intended the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him]) the Hadith. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ahmad extracted it - and the context is his - all of them from Sufyan bin Uyainah from Az-Zuhri from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib who said... so he mentioned it. The first addition belongs to Muslim, the second to all except Al-Bukhari, and the sixth to them except Abu Dawood

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: Ma'mar narrated it from Az-Zuhri in a similar manner, abbreviated without mentioning the mosque and Umar's denial upon Hassan. In it is the fifth addition. Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad extracted it. Ibrahim bin Sa'd narrated it from him without the raised (Marfu') part of it. In it are the third and last additions. Ahmad extracted it, then he extracted it from the path of Muhammad bin Amr from Yahya bin Abdur-Rahman who said: Umar passed... the Hadith, similar to the narration of Ibrahim. In it is the fourth addition. Then it became clear to me that this chain is interrupted, for Yahya bin Abdur-Rahman is the son of Hatib bin Abi Balta'ah, and they did not mention a narration for him from the Companions. His death was in the year (104) and Umar's death was in the year (23), so it is unlikely that he witnessed the story. Therefore, it was obligatory to strike out this addition, and we have done so. Then the Hadith was extracted by Al-Bukhari and Muslim from paths from Az-Zuhri also, who said: Abu Salamah bin Abdur-Rahman bin Auf informed me: That he heard Hassan bin Thabit Al-Ansari call Abu Huraira to witness: I ask you by Allah, did you hear the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, say: (O Hassan, answer on behalf of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. O Allah, aid him with the Holy Spirit)? Abu Huraira said: Yes. (And he, upon him be peace and blessings, said: (Indeed the believer strives with his sword and his tongue

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: and by the One in Whose Hand is my soul, it is as if what you shoot them with is the spraying of arrows). It is from the Hadith of Ka'b bin Malik: That he said to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: Indeed Allah, Mighty and Majestic, has revealed regarding poetry what He revealed. So he said... so he mentioned it. Ahmad extracted it: Abdur-Razzaq told us: Ma'mar informed us from Az-Zuhri from Abdur-Rahman bin Ka'b bin Malik from his father with it. This is an authentic chain on the condition of the two Sheikhs. It has a witness from the Hadith of Anas who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, entered Mecca in the Umrah of the Making Up (Qada), and Ibn Rawaha was before him saying: "Clear the way for the sons of the disbelievers today / Today we strike you regarding its interpretation / A strike that removes heads from their resting place / And distracts the intimate friend from his friend." Umar said: O Ibn Rawaha, in the Haram of Allah and before the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, you say this poetry? The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Let him be, for by the One in Whose Hand is my soul, his speech is harder on them than the falling of arrows). An-Nasa'i and At-Tirmidhi extracted it from the path of Abdur-Razzaq who said: Ja'far bin Sulayman told us from Thabit from him. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: In the Hadith of Hassan: The permissibility of good poetry in the mosque. An-Nasa'i titled it by his saying: (The License for Reciting Good Poetry in the Mosque). The majority of scholars went to this. As for the mutual exchange of poetry (Tanashud), it is forbidden as preceded in (The Prohibitions) paragraph (6). Al-Bayhaqi said: (We do not see any harm in reciting the likes of what Hassan used to say in defense of Islam and its people in the mosque or elsewhere. The first Hadith was reported regarding the mutual exchange of poems of the Jahiliyyah and others which do not befit the mosque. And with Allah is success). (13 - Setting up a Tent for the Sick and Others for a Need: Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: (Sa'd [Ibn Mu'adh] was injured on the Day of the Trench [a man from Quraish called Hibban bin Al-Ariqah shot him] in the medial arm vein, so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, pitched a tent for him in the mosque [so] he could visit him from near. [They were not alarmed - while in the mosque [with him] was a tent belonging to Banu Ghifar - except by the blood flowing towards them. They said: O people of the tent, what is this coming to us from your direction? And behold, it was Sa'd's wound feeding blood; he died from it]). The Hadith. Al-Bukhari extracted it - and the context is his - and Muslim, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Ahmad from the path of Hisham from his father from her. The second addition belongs to Ahmad and likewise

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: Al-Bukhari and Muslim in a narration of theirs, the third to Muslim alone, the fourth to all except him, and the last to the two Sheikhs, and the addition in it belongs to Muslim. He has another path which Ahmad extracted from Muhammad bin Amr from his father from his grandfather Alqamah bin Waqqas from her with its like, more complete than it. In it is the first addition. This is a good chain as Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath). Al-Bukhari titled the Hadith with: (Chapter: The Tent in the Mosque for the Sick and Others). Al-Hafiz said: (Meaning: The permissibility of that). In (Al-Umdah): (Ibn Battal said: In it is the permissibility of inhabiting the mosque for an excuse, and the chapter is titled with it). In (Sharh Muslim): (In it is the permissibility of sleeping in the mosque and the permissibility of the sick person staying in it, even if he is wounded). In (Nayl Al-Awtar): (The Hadith indicates the permissibility of leaving the sick person in the mosque, even if there is in that a possibility of something exiting him which would soil the mosque). (And (He, upon him be peace, used to practice I'tikaf (seclusion) in the last ten of Ramadan. (Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: So I used to pitch a tent (Khiba') for him, and he would pray Morning Prayer then enter it. [And he intended once to practice I'tikaf in the last ten of Ramadan, so he ordered its construction and it was pitched]. [Then Aisha asked his permission to practice I'tikaf, and he gave her permission, so she pitched a dome (Qubbah) in it]. [And Hafsa asked

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: Aisha to ask permission for her [from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him] so she did]. [So she ordered her structure and it was pitched]. When Zaynab bint Jahsh saw it, she pitched another tent. [And she was a woman of jealous nature]. When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, arose (and in a wording: (When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, turned away in the morning) [towards the place in which he intended to practice I'tikaf]) he saw the tents and said: (What is this)? [They said: The structure of Aisha, Hafsa, and Zaynab]. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Is it righteousness you think of them? (And in a narration: (Is it righteousness they intended by this? I am not practicing I'tikaf). And in another: What carried them to this? Is it righteousness? Remove them, for I do not [want to] see them. So they were removed. And in a wording: (So he ordered his structure and it was dismantled, and he ordered his wives regarding their structures and they were dismantled). So he abandoned I'tikaf in that month, then practiced I'tikaf for ten [days] of Shawwal) the Hadith. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad extracted it from paths from Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Ansari: Amrah bint Abdur-Rahman told me from Aisha with it. The context belongs to Al-Bukhari. The second addition is his, as are the third and fourth, and for Ahmad. He has the addition which is in it and likewise the one after it. The first addition belongs to Abu Dawood, and Muslim has its like. The sixth addition belongs to Abu Awanah as in (Al-Fath). The seventh addition belongs to Al-Bukhari, as do the eighth and ninth. This last one belongs to Ahmad as well. The second wording, and the second and third narrations belong to Al-Bukhari. The third wording belongs to Abu Dawood. An-Nasa'i titled the Hadith as he titled the first Hadith by his saying:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (Pitching a tent in the mosques). Al-Hafiz said: (And from it is the permissibility of pitching tents in the mosque). In the chapter, on the authority of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) performed I'tikaf in the mosque, and he heard them reciting aloud (sic) while he was in a dome of his, so he lifted the curtains and said: (Verily, each of you is conversing with his Lord, so let not some of you harm others, and let not some of you raise [your voices] over others in recitation) or he said: (in prayer). Ahmed extracted it: Abd al-Razzaq told us: Ma'mar told us on the authority of Ismail ibn Umayyah on the authority of Abu Salamah ibn Abd al-Rahman on his authority, and this is a Sahih chain of narration according to the condition of the Six. Abu Dawood extracted it from them via this mode. (14 - Playing with spears and the like from the instruments of war because of what it contains of training for fighting and strengthening for Jihad, for (Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, entered while the Abyssinians were playing [in the mosque], so Umar rebuked them (and in a narration: so he reached for the pebbles to throw at them), so the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (Leave them, O Umar, [for they are Banu Arfidah]). The hadith is from the narrations of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him; Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad extracted it by way of Al-Zuhri on the authority of Saeed ibn al-Musayyib on his authority. The context belongs to Al-Nasa'i, and the other narration is a narration for the two Sheikhs and a narration for Ahmad, and the first addition

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: is for all except Muslim, and the other is for Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad, and it is also with Abu Awanah in his (Sahih) as in (Al-Fath) (2/ 356), and he said: (It is as if he means that this is their custom and their way, and it is of the permissible matters, so there is no disapproval upon them). The hadith has a witnessing report from the narration of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with him [sic], which is: (Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: (So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) called me [while the Abyssinians were playing with their spears in the mosque] [on the day of Eid] [and said to me: O Humayra, would you like to look at them? I said: Yes] [So he stood me behind him] [and lowered his shoulders for me so that I could look at them] so I placed my chin on his shoulder and rested my face against his cheek] so I looked from above his shoulders (and in a narration: (from between his ear and his shoulder) [while he was saying: Carry on, O Banu Arfidah] [She said: And among their sayings that day was: Abba Al-Qasim is good] until I was satisfied) (and in a narration: (until when I became bored, he said: Is that enough? I said: Yes. He said: Then go) and in another: I said: Do not rush, so he stood for me, then said: Is that enough? I said: Do not rush. She said: And I had no love for looking at them, but I loved that the women would know his standing for me and my place with him [and I was a girl] [so estimate the estimate of a girl [Arab], of young age, eager for amusement]). First: Urwah on her authority, extracted by Al-Bukhari and Muslim

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: and Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from paths on his authority, some of them adding to others. The context belongs to Ahmad, and the first addition is for all except that Al-Nasa'i and Al-Tayalisi do not have: (with their spears), and the second addition is for Al-Nasa'i and Ahmad, and the two Sheikhs have its meaning, and the fourth is for the two Sheikhs, and the fifth is for Ahmad alone and its chain is Sahih according to the condition of the Six, and the seventh is for the two Sheikhs, and the ninth is for Muslim, and the tenth is for them all except Al-Tayalisi, and the addition that is within it is for Muslim alone. Ahmad added in a narration: She said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said that day: (Let the Jews know that there is room [flexibility] in our religion; verily I was sent with a tolerant Hanifiyyah). He extracted it by way of Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi al-Zinad on the authority of his father who said: Urwah said to me that Aisha said: And this Abd al-Rahman is sound in hadith [Hasan al-Hadith] but there is weakness in his memory, and for that reason Ibn Adi said: (Some of what he narrates is not followed), and for that reason I avoided his addition here as he was solitary in it excluding everyone who narrated the hadith from Urwah. Al-Hafiz attributed it to Al-Sarraj by way of Abu al-Zinad with it. And he remained silent about it, so if it was from the path of his son on his authority, then you have known what is in it, and if it was from the path of other than him, then it is necessary to look into it. And Allah knows best.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And the second narration is for Ahmad alone. Its chain is Sahih according to the condition of the Six as well, and it is in the second path as well. Second: Ubayd ibn Umayr on her authority, similar to it, and in it is the second narration; Muslim and Ahmad extracted it. Third: Yahya ibn Abd al-Rahman on her authority, abridged, and in it is the meaning of the fifth addition; Ahmad extracted it: Khalaf ibn al-Walid told us, he said: Abbad ibn Abbad told us on the authority of Muhammad ibn Amr on his authority, and this is a chain whose men are trustworthy, except that it is interrupted between Yahya and Aisha as has preceded. Fourth: Abu Salamah on her authority. And in it are the third, sixth, and eighth additions and the third narration. Al-Hafiz said after attributing it to Al-Nasa'i, and perhaps he means (his Sunan Al-Kubra): (Its chain is Sahih, and I did not see in a Sahih hadith the mention of Al-Humayra except in this). Likewise, Al-Iraqi said in (Takhrij Al-Ihya) that its chain is Sahih. Al-Nasa'i titled the hadith with his saying: (Playing in the mosque on the day of Eid and the looking of women at that). And Al-Hafiz said in the explanation of his saying: (And the Abyssinians were playing in the mosque):

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: in it is the permissibility of that in the mosque. Ibn al-Tin narrated from Abu al-Hasan al-Lakhmi: That playing with spears in the mosque is abrogated by the Qur'an and the Sunnah: As for the Qur'an, it is His saying, Exalted is He: {In houses which Allah has permitted to be raised} [An-Nur / 36]. As for the Sunnah, it is the hadith: (Keep your mosques free of your children and your insane ones). It was critiqued that the hadith is weak, and there is not in it nor in the Verse a declaration of what he claimed, nor is the date known so that abrogation is established. Some Malikis narrated from Malik that their playing was outside the mosque and Aisha was in the mosque. This is not proven from Malik, for it contradicts what is explicitly stated in the paths of this hadith, and in some of them is that Umar disapproved of their playing in the mosque, so the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: (Leave them). Playing with spears is not mere play; rather, it contains training of the brave for the positions of wars and preparation for the enemy. Al-Muhallab said: The mosque is established for the command of the community of Muslims, so whatever actions combine the benefit of the religion and its people are permissible in it). This contains a restriction of the play permissible in the mosque to what contains a public interest. This is the truth, if Allah the Exalted wills. Al-San'ani critiqued that in (Subul al-Salam) with the wording that preceded: (Let the Jews know that in our religion is room...) etc., saying: (And this refutes the statement of Al-Tabari that the Abyssinians are forgiven what is not forgiven for others, so it is affirmed where it was reported, and it refutes the statement of those who said: That playing with spears is not mere play, but contains training for the brave for the positions of wars and preparation for the enemy, for in that is the interest that gathers the general Muslims and is needed in establishing the religion, so its performance in the mosque was permitted).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: I say: And you have known from what preceded that this wording is not Sahih, rather it is weak, so it is not permissible to rely upon it in this research, especially since it contradicts the absolute nature mentioned in the previous Verse. And Allah knows best. (15 - Tying the prisoner to the pillar, due to the hadith preceding in paragraph (7): (The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent horsemen towards Najd, and they brought a man from Banu Hanifa called: Thumamah ibn Uthal - the master of the people of Yamama - so they tied him to a pillar of the pillars of the mosque) The hadith) and it is a Sahih hadith, agreed upon, and its takhrij has preceded there with its mention in full. Al-Bukhari and Al-Nasa'i titled it with what we mentioned, and Al-Bukhari said: (And Shuraih used to order the debtor to be detained by a pillar of the mosque). Al-Hafiz said: (Ma'mar connected it on the authority of Ayyub on the authority of Ibn Sirin who said: Shuraih, if he judged against a man regarding a right, would order his detention in the mosque until he fulfilled what was upon him; if he gave the right [he was released], otherwise he ordered him to prison) (And his saying, upon him be blessings and peace: (Verily, an Ifrit from the Jinn began to dart at me last night to interrupt my prayer, but Allah enabled me over him, so I choked him (and in a narration: so I strangled him) and I intended to tie him to the side of a pillar of the pillars of the mosque until you would wake up and look at him, all of you or every one of you, then I remembered the saying of my brother Sulaiman: {My Lord, forgive me and grant me a kingdom such as will not belong to anyone after me} [Sad / 35] so Allah returned him banished).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The hadith is from the narration of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, and there are two paths for it from him: First: From Shu'bah on the authority of Muhammad ibn Ziyad, he said: I heard Abu Hurairah say... so he mentioned it. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Al-Daraqutni extracted it. Second: From Muhammad ibn Amr on the authority of Abu Salamah on his authority with it, similar to it, abridged with the second narration. Al-Bayhaqi extracted it, and this is a Hasan chain. This story has come from a group of the Companions other than Abu Hurairah: Among them is Abu Darda with Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Al-Bayhaqi. And among them is Jabir ibn Samurah with Al-Daraqutni, Ahmad, and Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and its chain is Sahih according to the condition of Muslim. And among them is Abu Sa'id al-Khudri

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: with Ahmad with a Hasan chain, and perhaps it will come in (The Sutrah). Al-Haythami said: (And its men are trustworthy). Al-Bukhari titled the hadith with several titles, among them: (Chapter: The Prisoner or the Debtor is Tied in the Mosque). His commentator Al-Ayni said: (In it is evidence for the permissibility of tying the prisoner in the mosque, and upon this Al-Bukhari titled the Chapter, and from this Al-Muhallab said: That in the hadith is the permissibility of tying the one whose escape is feared due to a right against him or a debt, and securing him in the mosque or elsewhere). (16 - Judiciary and Li'an [Mutual Cursing] due to the hadith of Sahl ibn Sa'd, may Allah be pleased with him: (That a man from the Ansar came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: O Messenger of Allah, do you see [what to do if] a man finds a man with his wife, should he kill him, or how should he act? So Allah revealed regarding his affair what is mentioned in the Qur'an regarding the command of those who mutually curse. So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: Allah has judged regarding you and your wife. He said: So they mutually cursed in the mosque while I was a witness.... The Hadith) Al-Bukhari extracted it - and the context belongs to him - and Muslim from the path of Ibn Jurayj who said: Ibn Shihab informed me about the woman who mutually curses and about the Sunnah regarding her from the hadith of Sahl ibn Sa'd, the brother of Banu Sa'idah, that a man... etc. Al-Bukhari titled it with: (Chapter: Mutual Cursing in the Mosque).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: And he extracted it abridged in two other places from this mode and titled it in them with: (Chapter: Judiciary and Li'an in the Mosque). The hadith was narrated by Malik on the authority of Ibn Shihab with it, similar to it. And from the path of Malik, Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad extracted it, all of them on the authority of Malik with it. Al-Bukhari mentioned in a suspended [mu'allaq] manner: (And Umar engaged in mutual cursing at the pulpit of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and Shuraih, Al-Sha'bi, and Yahya ibn Ya'mar judged in the mosque, and Marwan judged against Zaid ibn Thabit with the oath at the pulpit, and Al-Hasan and Zurarah ibn Abi Awfa used to judge in the courtyard outside of the mosque). Al-Hafiz mentioned in (his explanation) those who connected these reports, so refer back to it, for we will not prolong by mentioning that. Then Al-Hafiz said: (Ibn Battal said: A group recommended judging in the mosque. And Malik said: It is the ancient command because the woman and the weak can reach the judge in it, whereas if he was in his home, the people would not reach him due to the possibility of screening [seclusion]. He said: And Ahmad and Ishaq said this. A group disliked that, and Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz wrote to Al-Qasim ibn Abd al-Rahman: Do not judge in the mosque, for the menstruating woman and the polytheist come to you. Al-Shafi'i said: It is more beloved to me that he judges in other than the mosque for that reason. Al-Karabisi said: Some of them disliked ruling in

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: the mosque because the judgment might be between a Muslim and a polytheist, so the polytheist would enter the mosque. He said: And the entry of the polytheist into the mosque is disliked. But ruling between them has not ceased to be from the practice of the Predecessors [Salaf] in the mosque of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and others. Then he cited regarding that many reports. Ibn Battal said: And the hadith of Sahl ibn Sa'd is a proof for permissibility, even if preserving the mosque is better. Malik said: Those who passed used to sit in the courtyards of the mosque, either in the place of funerals or in the courtyard of the house of Marwan. He said: And I indeed recommend that in the cities so that the Jew, the Christian, the menstruating woman, and the weak can reach him, and it is closer to humility). I say: And the statement of Al-Karabisi: (And the entry of the polytheist into the mosque is disliked) is something for which there is no evidence for its absolute application; rather, the Sunnah indicates the permissibility of bringing them into the mosques except the Sacred Mosque, as previously explained in paragraph seven. This is supported by the reports with which he himself corrected this saying, so take note. And in (Al-Umdah) is a summary: (Al-Bukhari only mentioned this hadith abridged to establish the permissibility of judging in the mosque, which is held by the general scholars. It is reported from Al-Shafi'i that it is disliked in the mosque if he prepares it for that, excluding if a judgment happens to come to him in it. Our companions all said: It is recommended that he sits in the assembly of judgment in the congregational mosque. If there is a mosque next to his house, he may do that. If he judges in his house, it is permissible. The congregational mosque is the most convenient place for the people and the most worthy so that there is hidden from no one

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: his sitting nor the day of his judgment. Al-Sha'bi used to judge in the congregational mosque, and Shuraih used to judge in the mosque and dye [his beard] with black. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) judged in his mosque between the Ansar regarding inheritances that were old). I say: I have not found this hadith right now, so it should be reviewed. The saying of Al-Shafi'i is closer to reasoning because it does not reject what we mentioned from the Sunnah, just as no caution is necessitated by it in the mosque, contrary to if it was prepared for judgment, for then it is difficult to keep it free from the rabble and noise. And Allah knows best. (17 - Lying on the back, due to the hadith of Abdullah ibn Zaid al-Mazini: That he saw the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) lying on his back in the mosque, placing one of his feet over the other) Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Malik extracted it, and from him Abu Dawood, and likewise Al-Nasa'i, Muhammad in his (Muwatta), Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from paths on the authority of Al-Zuhri, he said: Abbad ibn Tamim informed me on the authority of his uncle with it. Al-Tirmidhi said: (A Hasan Sahih hadith). The hadith has a witness from the hadith of Abu Hurairah which Ibn Hibban authenticated as in (Al-Fath).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: The hadith is evidence for what we mentioned regarding the permissibility of lying on the back in the mosque. Al-Bukhari and Al-Nasa'i titled it with that, and the commentary of the (Two Sahihs) and others proceeded upon that. Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath): (And it is apparent that his action, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was to clarify permissibility, and that was at a time of rest, not when people were gathered, due to what is known of his custom of sitting among them with complete dignity, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. Al-Khattabi said: In it is the permissibility of leaning in the mosque and lying down, and types of resting. Al-Dawudi said: In it is that the reward narrated for the one staying in the mosque is not specific to the sitter, but is obtained for the one lying on his back as well). Know that it has been proven in (Sahih Muslim) and others from the hadith of Jabir: That the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade that a man lift one of his legs over the other while he is lying on his back. It is clear that this does not contradict what we mentioned of absolute lying on the back; rather, in its apparent meaning, it contradicts lying on the back in the form mentioned in the two hadiths. Scholars have reconciled them by interpreting this prohibition as applying when it is feared that the private part [awrah] will be exposed, and permissibility when that is secured. And Allah knows best. As for the hadith which Al-Tabarani extracted from the hadith of Qatadah ibn al-Nu'man: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: (When Allah finished His creation, He lay on His back and placed His leg over the other and said: It is not befitting for anyone of My creation to do this),

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: then there is speculation regarding its establishment. Al-Haythami said in (Al-Majma'): (Al-Tabarani narrated it via three sheikhs: Ja'far ibn Sulaiman al-Nawfali, Ahmad ibn Rushdin al-Masri, and Ahmad ibn Dawud al-Makki. As for Ahmad ibn Rushdin, he is weak, and the two [others] I did not know, and the rest of its men are the men of the Sahih). I consider the authenticity of this hadith very unlikely because it suggests the meaning which the Jews, those who earned [Allah's] anger, said: (Allah created the heavens and the earth in six days then rested on the seventh day), which is Saturday, and they call it the day of rest. Allah the Exalted refuted them in more than one Verse, saying, Exalted is He: {And We did certainly create the heavens and earth and what is between them in six days, and there touched Us no weariness} [Qaf / 38]. It is most likely that the origin of the hadith is from the Israeliyat [stories of the Children of Israel] that leaked to the Muslims from some of the People of the Book, then some narrators imagined in it, so they raised it to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as appeared in (Musnad Ahmad), and it is an error as Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir explained in (The Tafsir) and others. (18 - Sleeping and Napping for the needy among men, even if not a stranger, provided it is not taken as a regular sleeping place and a place for napping. Regarding that are hadiths: (a) From Abdullah ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with him: That he used to sleep while he was a young bachelor with no family in the mosque of the Prophet, may Allah

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Exalted be He, upon him and grant him peace. And in a wording from him, he said: (We used to, in the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), sleep in the mosque [and] nap in it while we were young men). The hadith is Sahih, agreed upon, and there are two paths for it from him: First: From Ubayd Allah ibn Umar, he said: Nafi' told me, he said: Abdullah informed me with it. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad extracted it from paths on his authority. The second wording is the wording of Ahmad, and likewise Ibn Majah, except that he does not have: (and nap...). And Ubayd Allah ibn Umar - who is the younger [Al-Musaghar] - Al-Umari followed him, and he is Abdullah ibn Umar the Elder [Al-Mukabbar], and he is his brother; Ahmad extracted it. Second: From Abd al-Razzaq: Ma'mar informed us on the authority of Al-Zuhri on the authority of Salim on the authority of Ibn Umar with it, similar to it. Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad extracted it. The wording of Al-Tirmidhi is like the second wording except that he did not say: (and nap in it). And he said: (A Hasan Sahih hadith).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Salih ibn Abi al-Akhdar followed him on the authority of Al-Zuhri; Ahmad extracted it. (b) From Sahl ibn Sa'd, he said: The Messenger of Allah came to the house of Fatimah but did not find Ali in the house, so he said: (Where is your cousin?) She said: There was something between me and him, so he got angry with me and went out and did not nap at my place. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to a person: (Look where he is?) He came and said: O Messenger of Allah, he [is there] in the mosque sleeping [in the shade of the wall]. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came while he was lying down, his cloak having fallen from his side (and in a wording: from his back, and the dust reached his back). So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) began wiping it from him and saying: (Get up, Abu Turab; get up, Abu Turab). Al-Bukhari and Muslim extracted it from the path of Abu Hazim on his authority. The first addition belongs to Al-Bukhari in (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad) and a narration in (his Sahih), and the second belongs to Al-Tabarani as in (Al-Fath), and it is with Al-Bukhari as well, but he did not mention the word: (shade/fay'). The other wording is his as well in a narration. Al-Bayhaqi also extracted the hadith. In the chapter are other hadiths, and some of them will come. In the two hadiths and what is in their meaning is the permissibility of sleeping and napping in the mosque based on

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: the detail which we mentioned. Al-Bukhari titled them with something like that, saying: (Chapter: Sleeping of Men in the Mosque). Al-Hafiz said: (Meaning the permissibility of that, and it is the saying of the majority. It was narrated from Ibn Abbas that it is disliked except for one who intends to pray, and from Ibn Masud absolutely, and from Malik the differentiation between one who has a dwelling, so it is disliked, and one who has no dwelling, so it is permitted). Then Al-Hafiz said in the explanation of hadith (b): (In it is the intent of the Title, because the hadith of Ibn Umar indicates its permissibility for the one who has no dwelling, and likewise the rest of the hadith of the chapter, except for the story of Ali, for it implies generalization. But it is possible to differentiate between sleeping at night and the nap of the day). In Al-Tirmidhi: (A group of the people of knowledge permitted sleeping in the mosque. Ibn Abbas said: Do not take it as a regular sleeping place or napping place. A group of the people of knowledge went to the saying of Ibn Abbas). Al-Bayhaqi said: (We narrated from Saeed ibn al-Musayyib that he was asked about sleeping in the mosque? He said: Then where were the People of the Suffah? Meaning: They were sleeping in it. And we narrated from Ibn Masud and Ibn Abbas, then from Mujahid and Saeed ibn Jubayr what indicates their dislike of sleeping in the mosque, so it is as if they recommended for one who finds a dwelling not to intend the mosque for sleeping in it). As for our saying: (provided it is not taken as a regular sleeping place and a place for napping), that is because the mosques were not built for this, so increasing that in them, especially without need, is inconsistent with the purpose of their construction. For that reason

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said in a fatwa of his in this regard: (It is necessary to differentiate between the slight matter and those with needs, and that which becomes a habit and increases, and what is for those without needs. For this reason, Ibn Abbas said: Do not take the mosque as a regular sleeping place or napping place). (19 - Dwelling in a corner of it for the one who has no shelter among men or women. Regarding it are hadiths: (a) From Talha ibn Amr al-Basri, he said: [I came to Medina as an emigrant and] a man [of us], if he came to Medina, if he had an acquaintance [Arif], he would stay with him, and if he had no acquaintance, he would stay at the Suffah. So I came to it [while I had no acquaintance in it], so I stayed at the Suffah... The Hadith). Al-Hakim and Al-Bayhaqi extracted it in full - and the context belongs to him - from paths on the authority of Dawud ibn Abi Hind on the authority of Abu Harb ibn Abi al-Aswad on his authority. The additions are for Al-Bayhaqi except the second of them, for it belongs to his sheikh Al-Hakim, and he said: (Sahih of chain). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as he said. Its men up to Talha are trustworthy, men of Muslim. Ahmad also extracted it from this mode with some abbreviation. Ibn Hibban also extracted it in (his Sahih) as in (Ta'jil al-Manfa'ah), and Al-Tabarani as in (Al-Isabah).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (b) From Abu Hurairah, he said: (The People of the Suffah were guests of [the people of] Islam; they did not take shelter with family nor property) it is a piece of a long hadith of his which Al-Bukhari, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Hakim extracted - the context belongs to the two of them and the addition to the first of them - and he [Al-Hakim] authenticated it, and Al-Bayhaqi and Ahmad from paths on the authority of Umar ibn Dharr: Mujahid told us on his authority with it. Al-Hafiz said: (And in the Mursal of Yazid ibn Abdullah ibn Qusait with Ibn Sa'd: The People of the Suffah were poor people who had no homes, so they used to sleep in the mosque; they had no shelter other than it. And he has from the path of Nu'aym ibn al-Mujmir on the authority of Abu Hurairah: I was of the People of the Suffah, and when we reached the evening, we attended the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so he would order each man so he would leave with a man or more, so there would remain of those who remained ten or less or more, so the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would come with his dinner, so we would dine with him. When we finished, he said: Sleep in the mosque). I say: The first narration in (Tabaqat Ibn Sa'd) is from the Chapter of mentioning the People of the Suffah. As for the other narration with the mentioned wording, I did not find it in this place referred to from (Al-Tabaqat), and I reviewed the biography of Abu Hurairah in it but did not find it either, so Allah knows best regarding the location of this narration in (Al-Tabaqat). Al-Bayhaqi narrated on the authority of Uthman ibn al-Yaman in a Mu'dal manner, he said:

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: When the Emigrants to Medina increased and they had no house or shelter, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) lodged them in the mosque and named them the Companions of the Suffah, so he used to sit with them and be familiar with them (And the Suffah: a shaded place in the Prophetic Mosque) as in (Al-Fath). (c) From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: That a black slave girl belonged to a tribe of the Arabs, so they freed her, but she remained with them. She said: A young girl of theirs came out having on her a red scarf of leather strips. She said: She put it down or it fell from her, and a kite passed by it while it was lying, so it thought it was meat and snatched it. She said: So they searched for it but did not find it. She said: So they accused me of it. She said: So they began searching. She said: Until they searched in her private part. She said: By Allah, I was standing with them when the kite passed and dropped it. She said: So it fell among them. She said: So I said: This is what you accused me of, you claimed, while I am innocent of it, and here it is. She said: So she came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and accepted Islam. Aisha said: She had a tent in the mosque or a small hut. She said: She used to come to me and talk at my place. She said: She would not sit a sitting at my place except that she said: And the day of the scarf is from the wonders of our Lord * Verily He saved me from the town of disbelief. Aisha said: So I said to her: What is the matter with you that you do not sit a sitting with me except that you say this? She said: So she told me this hadith). Al-Bukhari extracted it from the path of Abu Usamah on the authority of Hisham on the authority of his father on her authority with it.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Then he extracted it on the authority of Ali ibn Mushir on the authority of Hisham with it, similar to it. The hadith was narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah also as in (Al-Fath). Ibn Battal said: (In it is that whoever has no dwelling and no place to sleep, it is permitted for him to sleep in the mosque, whether he is a man or a woman, when there is security from temptation [Fitnah]. And in it is the setting up of the tent and the like for the poor person, whether man or woman). It was quoted in (Al-Umdah). I say: The first two hadiths indicate that as well regarding men specifically. As for settling in the entire mosque for necessity - as occurred in these days when about seventy thousand Palestinians emigrated to Syria fleeing from the atrocities of the Jews, so the state lodged some of them in many of the mosques - I believe in the permissibility of that on the condition that it does not lead to the suspension of the congregational prayer, such that the congregational mosques and mosques are many, so the emigrants lodge in some of them, of those whose closure in the faces of the worshipers does not lead to the indicated suspension. And Allah the Exalted knows best. (30 - Division of Wealth, due to the hadith: Wealth was brought to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from Bahrain (and in a narration: That Al-Ala' ibn al-Hadrami sent eighty thousand to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from Bahrain) so he said: (Pour it into the mosque) - and it was the most wealth brought to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) (and in the other narration: So he ordered it, and it was spread on a mat, and the call for prayer was made). So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out to the prayer and did not turn to it. When he finished the prayer, he came and sat by it [and the people came when they saw the wealth, and there was no counting or weighing that day, it was only by grasping, so he did not see anyone except that he gave him. Then Al-Abbas came to him and said: O Messenger of Allah, give me, for I ransomed myself and I ransomed Aqil [on the day of Badr and Aqil had no wealth]. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: (Take). So he scooped into his garment

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (and in the other narration: in a Khamisah [garment] that was upon him) then he went to lift it but could not [so he raised his head to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)] and said: O Messenger of Allah, order one of them to lift it for me. He said: (No). He said: Then you lift it for me [so the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) smiled until his premolars or canine teeth showed] and said: (No) [But return a portion to the wealth and carry what you can bear]. So he poured some of it out, then went to lift it [but did not lift it], so he said: O Messenger of Allah, order one of them to lift it for me. He said: (No). He said: Then you lift it. He said: (No). So he poured some of it out, then carried it and threw it on his shoulder, then departed [saying: As for one of the two things Allah promised us, He has fulfilled it, and I do not know what He will do regarding the other, meaning His saying: {Say to those in your hands of the captives: If Allah knows any good in your hearts, He will give you something better than what was taken from you, and He will forgive you} [Al-Anfal / 70]. So this is better than what was taken from me, and I do not know what He will do regarding forgiveness] - so the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) continued following him with his gaze until he was hidden from us, in wonder at his greed. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not stand while a dirham remained of it) The Hadith. Al-Bukhari extracted it like this, prolonged and abridged, and it is suspended [Mu'allaq] where he said: And Ibrahim ibn Tahman said on the authority of Abd al-Aziz ibn Suhayb on the authority of Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, he said... so he mentioned it. Al-Hafiz said: (Abu Nu'aym connected it in his (Mustakhraj) and Al-Hakim in his (Mustadrak) from the path of Ahmad ibn Hafs ibn Abdullah al-Naysaburi on the authority of his father on the authority of Ibrahim ibn Tahman. And

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: Al-Bukhari extracted several hadiths with this chain to Ibrahim ibn Tahman). I say: I sought the hadith in its likely places in (Al-Mustadrak) but did not find it, so Allah knows best regarding its place in it. I only found in it the other narration, and it is in the biography of Al-Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, from the path of Hashim ibn al-Qasim: Sulaiman ibn al-Mughirah told us on the authority of Humayd ibn Hilal on the authority of Abu Burdah on the authority of Abu Musa al-Ash'ari: That Al-Ala' ibn al-Hadrami... with it, similar to it. And in it are all the additions except the sixth addition, for it is in a narration of Al-Bukhari. Ibn Sa'd extracted it in (Al-Tabaqat) from his sheikh Hashim ibn al-Qasim with it, and the context belongs to him. Then Al-Hakim said: (A Sahih hadith according to the condition of Muslim). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Then, Al-Bukhari titled the hadith with: (Chapter: Division and Hanging the Cluster of Dates in the Mosque). Al-Hafiz said: (In it is the permissibility of placing what the Muslims share of charity and the like in the mosque. Its place is when it does not prevent what the mosque was established for, such as prayer and other things for which the mosque was built. Like placing this wealth is the placing of the wealth of Zakat al-Fitr. And it is benefited from it the placing of what is of general benefit in the mosque, such as water for the drinking of whoever is thirsty. It is possible to differentiate between what is placed for distribution and what is placed for storage, so the second is prevented excluding the first. And success is with Allah the Exalted). I say: Al-Bukhari did not mention in this chapter a hadith regarding hanging the cluster of dates, even though

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: he titled for it, so it is as if he indicated by that some of the hadiths narrated regarding that as will come, but he did not mention them, even if they were Sahih, because they are not according to his condition. (31 - Hanging the fruit stalk or the cluster for the poor, for (he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered from every garden a cluster for the mosque) The Hadith. Al-Hakim extracted it from the path of Saeed ibn Abi Maryam: Abd al-Aziz ibn Muhammad told us on the authority of Ubayd Allah ibn Umar on the authority of Nafi' on the authority of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered... etc. And he said: (Sahih according to the condition of Muslim). And it is as he said, and Al-Dhahabi affirmed it. Al-Tabarani also narrated it in (Al-Awsat). Al-Haythami said: (And its men are the men of the Sahih). In (Al-Fath): (Thabit extracted it (in Al-Dala'il) with the wording: It is hung in the mosque - meaning for the poor - and in a narration of his: And Mu'adh ibn Jabal was over it, meaning: over its guarding or over its division). Al-Hakim mentioned a witness for it from the path of Muhammad ibn Ishaq on the authority of Muhammad ibn Yahya ibn Habban on the authority of his uncle Wasi' on the authority of Habban on the authority of Jabir ibn Abdullah: That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) granted concession regarding the Araya [donated palm trees], a Wasq, two Wasqs, three, and four, and said: (In the cutting of every ten Wasqs is a cluster to be placed for the poor in the mosque). He said: (It is Sahih according to the condition of Muslim).

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: But it is not so, even if Al-Dhahabi affirmed it, because Ibn Ishaq is a Mudallis [concealer of defects in chain] and he used the 'an'ana [saying 'from'], and furthermore, Muslim did not use him as proof; he only narrated from him in conjunction with others or as a follow-up. (For that reason (The Ansar used to bring out - when it was the harvest of palm trees - from their gardens clusters of unripe dates and hang them on a rope between two pillars in the mosque of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so the poor Emigrants would eat from it... The Hadith) And its completion is: (So one of them would intend to insert a cluster containing bad dates [Hashaf], thinking that it is permissible within the abundance of clusters being placed. So there was revealed regarding whoever did that: {And do not aim at the defective of it to spend [from that]} [Al-Baqarah / 267]. He says: Do not intend the bad dates of it to spend {while you would not take it except with closed eyes} [Al-Baqarah / 267]. He says: If it was gifted to you, you would not have accepted it except out of shyness from its owner, out of anger that he sent to you what you had no need for. {And know that Allah is Free of need} of your charities {Praiseworthy} extracted by Ibn Majah and Al-Hakim from the path of Asbat ibn Nasr on the authority of Al-Suddi on the authority of Adi ibn Thabit on the authority of Al-Bara' ibn Azib regarding His saying, Glory be to Him: {And from what We have produced for you from the earth. And do not aim at the defective of it to spend} [Al-Baqarah / 267] he said.... so he mentioned it. Al-Hakim said: (Sahih according to the condition of Muslim). Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, and it is as they said. Ibn Jarir also narrated it, and Ibn Mardawayh as in Ibn Kathir.

book_title: Al-Thamar al-Mustatab fi Fiqh al-Sunnah wa al-Kitab
text: (And Auf ibn Malik al-Ashja'i said: (The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came out to us having a stick, and in the mosque were hanging clusters, among which was a cluster containing bad dates. So he poked the cluster with the stick that was in his hand and said: (If the Lord of this charity had willed, he would have given charity with better than this. Verily, the Lord of this charity will indeed eat bad dates on the Day of Resurrection) The Hadith. Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad extracted it - and the context belongs to him - on the authority of Abd al-Hamid ibn Ja'far on the authority of Salih ibn Abi Arayb on the authority of Kathir ibn Murrah al-Hadrami on his authority. This is a Hasan chain; its men are trustworthy, men of Muslim, except Salih ibn Abi Arayb. Al-Dhahabi said in (Al-Mizan): (Ibn al-Qattan said: His condition is not known, and it is not known who narrated from him other than Abd al-Hamid ibn Ja'far. I [Dhahabi] say: Rather, Haywah ibn Shurayh, Al-Layth, Ibn Lahi'ah, and others narrated from him. He has hadiths. Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy). I say: And he extracted this hadith of his in (his Sahih), and likewise Ibn Khuzaymah as in (Al-Targhib). I say: Al-Hakim authenticated a hadith for him, and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him in (his Talkhis). For that reason, Al-Hafiz said in (Explanation of Al-Bukhari) after he cited this hadith from the path of Al-Nasa'i: (And it is not according to his condition - meaning Al-Bukhari - even if its chain is strong).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Mundhiri remained silent on it in his (Mukhtasar), then I found it in (Al-Mustadrak) and he [Al-Hakim] authenticated it, as did Al-Dhahabi. In these two hadiths, there is evidence for the permissibility of hanging the 'Qinu' — with a Kasrah on the Qaf and a Sukun on the Nun — which is the 'Adhq' (cluster) and the 'Arjun' (date bunch) containing dates. Similar to it in ruling is the grape cluster and the like. The speech of Al-Hafiz regarding this has preceded in the past chapter. And in (Al-Umdah): (Ibn Al-Qasim said: Malik was asked about hanging fruit clusters in the mosque and what resembles that, and he said: There is no harm in it. He was asked about the water that is provided for drinking in the mosque, 'Do you see it permissible to drink from it?' He said: 'Yes, it was only placed for thirst, and it was not intended only for the destitute, so I do not see that one should refrain from drinking it, and this has ceased to be the practice of the people.') (32 - Asking by the needy and giving charity to him, due to the hadith: 'Is there anyone among you who fed a poor person today?' Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'I entered the mosque and there was a beggar asking, and I found a piece of bread with Abdul Rahman, so I took it [from him] and gave it to him'). The Hadith was narrated by Abu Dawood — and the addition is his — and Al-Hakim via Mubarak bin Fadalah from Thabit Al-Bunani from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Layla from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Bakr in a Marfu' form. Al-Hakim said: 'Sahih according to the condition of Muslim.' Al-Dhahabi agreed with him, but they were mistaken, for this Mubarak is not one of Muslim's narrators at all, and he is truthful (Saduq) but he is...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...a Mudallis (one who conceals defects in the chain) and has used 'an'an (said 'from'). Despite that, Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu'): 'Its chain is good (Jayyid).' Al-Mundhiri said in his (Mukhtasar): 'Abu Bakr Al-Bazzar said: We do not know of this Hadith being narrated from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Bakr except with this chain, and he mentioned that it was narrated as Mursal.' I say: This Mursal report strengthens this connected (Mawsul) one. Then he said: 'Muslim narrated it in his (Sahih) and Al-Nasa'i in his (Sunan) from the hadith of Abu Hazim Salman Al-Ashja'i from Abu Hurayrah with a similar meaning, but more complete.' I say: The hadith is in (Sahih Muslim) as Al-Mundhiri mentioned, but it does not mention that the charity was in the mosque; rather, it is general. As for Al-Nasa'i, I did not find it in his (Sunan Al-Sughra), nor did Al-Nabulusi attribute it to him in (Al-Dhakha'ir), so it appears it is in his (Sunan Al-Kubra). Al-Suyuti said in the treatise (Badhl Al-Asjad li Su'al Al-Masjid) from his (Al-Hawi), after quoting Al-Mundhiri's words: 'I say: It was narrated: And Al-Bukhari narrated it in (Ahkam Al-Masajid) by Al-Zarkashi.' This is how it is in the original, and there is clear confusion in the phrasing. In any case, the hadith is not in Al-Bukhari. And Allah knows best. In the chapter, from Ibn Abbas, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, went out to the mosque while the people were praying, between bowing, prostrating, standing, and sitting. Suddenly there was a poor man asking, so the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, entered and said: 'Did anyone give you anything?'

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Who?' He said: 'That standing man.' He said: 'In what state did he give it to you?' He said: 'While he was bowing.' He said: 'That is Ali bin Abi Talib.' Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said 'Allahu Akbar' at that, while saying: ({And whoever is an ally of Allah and His Messenger and those who have believed - indeed, the party of Allah - they will be the predominant.} [Al-Ma'idah / 56]). In some books, it states that he recited the verse preceding this one, which is: ({Your ally is none but Allah and [therefore] His Messenger and those who have believed, those who establish prayer and give zakah, and they bow [in worship]}). However, it is a weak hadith. Ibn Mardawayh narrated it with this wording in his (Tafsir) via Muhammad bin Al-Sa'ib Al-Kalbi from Abu Salih from him. Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said: 'This chain is not to be rejoiced over; Al-Kalbi is abandoned (Matruk). Then Ibn Mardawayh narrated it from the hadith of Ali bin Abi Talib himself, Ammar bin Yasir, and Abu Rafi', and none of it is authentic at all due to the weakness of their chains and the anonymity of their narrators.' As for Al-Suyuti, he said in the aforementioned treatise: 'These are paths for the revelation of this noble verse regarding giving charity to a beggar in the mosque, confirming one another.' I do not think this is correct, because the fact that multiple paths strengthen a hadith is not absolute as mentioned in the books of Terminology (Mustalah); rather, that is restricted to when there is...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...in the paths some narrators who have weakness in their memory but are trustworthy in themselves and not abandoned. I do not believe these paths have this description found in them. I say this even though I have not stood upon their narrators except for the first path, which contains Al-Kalbi, who is abandoned, so his hadith is discarded and cannot be used for support. And Allah knows best. Furthermore, if it were correct to say about these paths what Al-Suyuti went for, Ibn Kathir himself would have mentioned it, especially since he is more knowledgeable about Hadith and its defects than Al-Suyuti, as is not hidden. In summary, the reliance in this chapter is on the hadith of Abdul Rahman bin Abi Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him. It contains evidence for what we mentioned regarding the permissibility of asking and giving charity in the mosque. Abu Dawood titled a chapter for it with some of that, saying: (Chapter: Asking in the Mosques). Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, was asked about this issue, and he answered, may Allah have mercy on him, with the text: 'The principle of begging is forbidden inside the mosque and outside the mosque except for necessity. If there is a necessity and he asks in the mosque without harming anyone by stepping over people's necks, nor by anything other than stepping over, and he does not lie in what he narrates and mentions of his condition, and he does not raise his voice loudly to harm people—such as asking the Khatib while the Khatib is delivering the sermon, or while they are listening to knowledge that he distracts them from, and similar to that—then it is permissible, and Allah knows best.' (Fatawa) by him. Al-Suyuti said in the previously mentioned treatise, summarized:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ('Asking in the mosque is Makruh (disliked) as a discouragement (Tanzeeh), and giving to the beggar in it is an act of worship for which one is rewarded, and it is not Makruh, let alone Haram. This is what is transmitted and what the hadiths indicated.') Then he quoted Al-Nawawi as saying: 'There is no harm in giving to the beggar in the mosque due to this hadith.' Al-Suyuti said: 'The hadith he cited contains evidence for both matters together: that charity to him is not Makruh, and that asking in the mosque is not prohibited, because he, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, became aware of that through the information from Al-Siddiq and did not deny it. If it were Haram, he would not have affirmed it, but would have prevented the beggar from returning to ask in the mosque. By this, it is known that the prohibition of asking in the mosque—if proven—is interpreted as dislike and discouragement, and this diverts it from prohibition.' He said: 'As for what occurred in (Al-Madkhil) by Ibn Al-Hajj from the hadith: (Whoever asks in the mosques, deprive him), it has no basis. We only said it is Makruh based on the hadith forbidding announcing lost property in the mosque and his saying: (Indeed, the mosques were not built for this).' Also indicating the permissibility of giving charity in the mosque is the upcoming hadith, which Al-Suyuti missed and did not cite in his treatise, nor did he even allude to it, which is: 'A man entered the mosque [in a shabby condition], so the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, ordered that they throw clothes for him. So they threw, and he ordered that two garments be given to him from them. Then he urged charity, so the man came and threw one of the two garments, so he shouted at him (and in a wording: he scolded him) and said: (Take your garment).'

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. Abu Dawood narrated it — and the context is his — as did Al-Nasa'i (and the other wording is his), Al-Tahawi, Al-Hakim, and Ahmad via Ibn Ajlan: 'Iyad narrated to us from him.' This is a Hasan chain. Al-Hakim said: 'Sahih according to the condition of Muslim.' Al-Dhahabi agreed, but it is not so, as previously warned about repeatedly. The addition is from Ahmad and likewise Al-Nasa'i, and in their versions, it is more complete, containing the command for the prayer of greeting the mosque while the Imam is delivering the sermon on Friday. This portion of it was narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, and its wording preceded in the Seventh Etiquette, Hadith number (4), so let whoever wishes refer to it. In the chapter, from Jarir bin Abdullah, he said: We were in the early part of the day with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, when some people came, naked, wearing striped woollen garments (mujitabi al-nimar), with swords slung over their shoulders... The face of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, changed when he saw the poverty they were in. He entered and exited, then ordered Bilal, so he called the Adhan and established the prayer. He prayed and then addressed the people saying: {O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul...} to the end of the verse: {Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer} [Al-Nisa / 1], and the verse in Al-Hashr: {Fear Allah and let every soul look to what it has put forth for tomorrow} [Al-Hashr / 19]: 'Let a man give charity from his dinar...' The Hadith. In it, a man from the Ansar initiated the charity, then people followed in succession after him. And in it, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said:

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ('Whoever establishes a good sunnah in Islam...') The Hadith was narrated by Muslim and others. Refer to our comment on (Al-Targhib). (23 - Permissible speech occasionally, provided that one does not make that a habit, due to the saying of Jabir bin Samura, may Allah be pleased with him: I witnessed the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, more than a hundred times [in the mosque] while his companions were reciting poetry and mentioning things from the matter of the Jahiliyyah, and he might smile with them). The Hadith was narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad via Sharik from Simak from him. The context with the addition is Ahmad's. Al-Tayalisi paired Qays bin Al-Rabi' with Sharik, so the chain is Hasan, nay Sahih, for Al-Tirmidhi said: 'This is a Hasan Sahih hadith, and Zuhayr also narrated it from Simak.' I say: This narration of Zuhayr is with Muslim and Ahmad with its meaning, and Abu Khaythamah followed it up in Muslim, and his wording is: He would not stand from his prayer place in which he prays the Morning Prayer and the Fajr until the sun rose. When the sun rose, he would stand, and they would talk and take up matters of the Jahiliyyah, and they would laugh and he would smile.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: And in (Al-Fatawa) by Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, the text is: (Question regarding sleeping in the mosque, talking, and walking with sandals in the places of prayer, is that permissible or not? The Answer: As for sleeping occasionally for the needy, such as the stranger and the poor person who has no dwelling, it is permissible. As for taking it as a regular place for sleeping and napping, they are forbidden from that. As for speech that Allah and His Messenger love in the mosque, it is good. As for what is forbidden, it is more strictly forbidden in the mosque. Likewise the Makruh. And excess of permissible speech is disliked in it. As for walking with sandals, it is permissible as the Companions used to walk with their sandals in the mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. However, a man should, when he comes to the mosque, do what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, commanded him, so he should look at his sandals; if there is filth on them, he should rub them with dust, for dust is a purifier for them. And Allah knows best). I say: As for the hadith famous on the tongues of people and hung on the walls of many mosques: (Speech in the mosque eats up good deeds just as fire eats up wood or just as animals eat up grass), Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in (Takhrij Al-Ihya): 'I did not find a source for it.' Al-Saghani said in his (Mawdu'at - Fabrications): 'And among the fabricated hadiths is their saying: (Whoever speaks with worldly speech in the mosques or in the mosque, Allah invalidates his deeds of forty years).' And among them are the fabricated hadiths regarding the virtue of lamps, lanterns, and mats in the mosque; nothing of that is proven. Rather, the Companions used to speak at certain times in the mosque and sleep in it as well, but...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: ...with complete manners, modesty, and respect, and likewise in the graveyards and behind the funeral procession). (34 - Eating and drinking occasionally, due to the hadith of Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Jaz' Al-Zubaydi, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: We were one day with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in the Suffah, so food was placed for us and we ate. Then the prayer was established, so we prayed and did not perform ablution. And in a narration from him, he said: We used to eat bread and meat during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in the mosque). The Hadith was narrated by Ahmad, as well as his son Abdullah, who said: My father narrated to me: Harun narrated to us — Abu Abdul Rahman said: And I heard from Harun — he said: Abdullah bin Wahb narrated to us saying: Haywah bin Shurayh informed me saying: Uqbah bin Muslim informed me from him with the first narration. This is a Sahih chain, its men are trustworthy men of Muslim except Uqbah, who is Thiqah (trustworthy). As for the other narration, Ibn Majah narrated it saying: Yaqub bin Humayd bin Kasib and Harmalah bin Yahya narrated to us, they said: Abdullah bin Wahb narrated to us: Amr bin Al-Harith informed me: Sulayman bin Ziyad Al-Hadrami narrated to me: That he heard Abdullah bin Al-Harith with it. It says in (Al-Zawa'id): 'Its chain is Hasan, its men are trustworthy, and Yaqub is disputed.' I say: He was only criticized regarding his memory, and this narration of his is supported by Harmalah bin Yahya, who is Thiqah. So the hadith is authentic from Ibn Wahb, and the rest of the men...

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: above him are all trustworthy (1). So the hadith has a Sahih chain, and limiting it to merely Hasan is a shortcoming. Ibn Lahi'ah followed him in narrating from Sulayman bin Ziyad, and said once: from Khalid bin Abi Imran and Sulayman bin Ziyad Al-Hadrami with it similarly. Ahmad narrated it. Ibn Lahi'ah has poor memory, but if he preserved it, then the hadith has three paths from Abdullah bin Al-Harith. In the chapter from Ibn Umar: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was brought some Fadikh (a date drink) in the Mosque of Al-Fadikh, so he drank it, and for that reason, it was named so. Narrated by Ahmad: Waki' narrated to us, Abdullah bin Nafi' narrated to me from his father from him. Its men are trustworthy men of the Six Books except Abdullah bin Nafi', who is weak as in (Al-Taqrib). And via his path Abu Ya'la narrated it with the wording: That the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was brought a jar of Fadikh of unripe dates while he was in the Mosque of Al-Fadikh, so he drank it, and for that reason, it was named the Mosque of Al-Fadikh. Mentioned in (Al-Majma').
foot_note: 1. (1) And Al-Shawkani's saying in (Al-Nayl) (2/137): 'And these are all from the men of the Sahih except Yaqub bin Humayd, and Harmalah bin Yahya has narrated it with him' is not correct. Rather, he should have excepted Sulayman bin Ziyad Al-Hadrami along with Yaqub, for he is not from the men of the Sahih either.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: Al-Shawkani said, summarized: (The hadith indicates the desired point from it, which is the permissibility of eating in the mosque. There are many hadiths regarding this: among them is the residence of the People of the Suffah, for the fact that they had no dwelling other than it necessitates their eating food in it. And among them is the tying of the prisoner to a pillar of the mosque's pillars, and in some of its paths that he remained tied for three days. And among them is pitching tents in the mosque for Sa'd bin Mu'adh as preceded, and for the black woman who used to sweep the mosque. And among them is the delegation of Thaqif lodging in the mosque and others. The hadiths indicating the permissibility of eating food in the mosque are abundant). I say: All these hadiths referenced have been mentioned previously in their appropriate places in this chapter, so let them be reviewed. 10 - Facing the Kaaba (1 - It is obligatory for the person praying to direct his face and body towards the Kaaba. This is established by the Book and the Sunnah: (a) As for the Book, it is the saying of the Exalted: {We have certainly seen the turning of your face in the heaven, and We will surely turn you to a Qiblah with which you will be pleased.
