So turn your face toward Al-Masjid Al-Haram. And wherever you [believers] are, turn your faces toward it [in prayer].} [Al-Baqarah / 114]) (And (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to pray while in Makkah towards Bayt Al-Maqdis [Jerusalem] while the Kaaba was in front of him. And after he migrated to Madinah for sixteen months, then he was turned towards the Kaaba).

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: The Hadith is from the narration of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both. Imam Ahmad narrated it: Yahya bin Hammad narrated to us: Abu Awanah narrated to us from Al-A'mash from Mujahid from Ibn Abbas with it. This is a Sahih chain; its men are all trustworthy men of the two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim]. Al-Hafiz remained silent on it in (Al-Fath). Al-Haythami said in (Al-Majma'): 'Ahmad, Al-Tabarani in (Al-Kabir), and Al-Bazzar narrated it, and its men are men of (Al-Sahih). Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from this perspective. In it is a refutation of Abu Umar bin Abdul Barr where he chose that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, did not face Bayt Al-Maqdis while he was in Makkah, but rather faced it when he migrated to Madinah. He used as evidence the hadith of Al-Bara' coming after this, but there is no proof in it, because even if he did not explicitly deny facing it before that—even if he did explicitly deny it—it would not be a proof. Rather, it would be obligatory to take the hadith of Ibn Abbas because of the addition and knowledge it contains. The addition of a trustworthy narrator is accepted, and one who knows is a proof over one who does not know, and the affirmer takes precedence over the negator. All these are agreed-upon rules and have been stated in many branches of knowledge as is not hidden to the researcher. (And in another hadith: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to love to be directed towards the Kaaba, so Allah revealed: {We have certainly seen the turning of your face in the heaven}, so he turned towards the Kaaba. And the foolish among the people - who were the Jews - said: {What has turned them away from their Qiblah which they used to face? Say, "To Allah belongs the east and the west. He guides whom He wills to a straight path."} [Al-Baqarah / 142])

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab fi Fiqh Al-Sunnah wal-Kitab
text: It is from the hadith of Al-Bara' bin Azib, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, prayed towards Bayt Al-Maqdis for sixteen or seventeen months, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to love... etc. Al-Bukhari narrated it with this context (1). It is also with Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi (who authenticated it), Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Al-Tayalisi, and Ahmad from him with a similar meaning, without his saying: 'And the foolish said... etc.' Al-Hafiz said in (Al-Fath) under his saying: (And he used to love to be directed towards the Kaaba), the text is: 'The clarification of that came in what Al-Tabari and others narrated via the path of Ali bin Abi Talhah from Ibn Abbas who said: When the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, migrated to Madinah, and the Jews—who were the majority of its people—faced Bayt Al-Maqdis, Allah commanded him to face Bayt Al-Maqdis. So the Jews rejoiced. He faced it for seventeen months. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to love to face the Qiblah of Ibrahim, so he used to supplicate and look to the sky, so it was revealed. And via the path of Mujahid, he said: He only loved to turn to the Kaaba because the Jews said: Muhammad opposes us but follows our Qiblah. So it was revealed.' I say: Al-Hafiz remained silent regarding this hadith of Ibn Abbas, and perhaps that is due to the clarity of its defect, for this Ali bin Abi Talhah is truthful (Saduq) but he makes mistakes, and he narrated from Ibn Abbas in a Mursal form and did not see him, as Al-Hafiz himself said in (Al-Taqrib). So the hadith with this context is weak due to its interruption.

book_title: Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab in the Fiqh of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (The wisdom behind this change [of the Qiblah] is that it was a trial and test from Allah, as He clarified in His saying: {And We did not make the Qiblah which you used to face except that We might know who follows the Messenger from who turns back on his heels. And indeed, it was difficult except for those whom Allah guided. And Allah would not let your faith be lost. Indeed, Allah is Ever Gracious and Merciful to the people} [Al-Baqarah: 143]. (B) As for the Sunnah: it is the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to the man who performed his prayer incorrectly: (When you stand for prayer, perform your ablution thoroughly, then face the Qiblah and say the Takbir… the hadith). This is a portion of the well-known hadith of ‘The One Who Prayed Incorrectly’, and this narration is from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, that a man entered the mosque and prayed while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was sitting in a corner of the mosque. The man came and greeted him, so the Prophet said to him (in one narration he added: ‘And peace be upon you’): (Go back and pray, for you have not prayed). So the man returned and prayed, then came back and greeted him. The Prophet said: (And peace [be upon you]. Go back and pray, for you have not prayed). On the third time the man said: Teach me. The Prophet said: (When you stand for prayer, perform your ablution thoroughly, then face the Qiblah and say the Takbir. Then recite whatever is easy for you from the Qur’an. Then bow until you are at ease in your bowing. Then rise until you stand upright. Then prostrate until you are at ease in your prostration. Then rise until you sit straight and are at ease. Then prostrate until you are at ease in your prostration. Then rise until you stand straight. Do this throughout your entire prayer).

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Ibn Majah, and Al-Bayhaqi extracted it via the path of Abdullah bin Numayr and Abu Usamah Hammad bin Abi Usamah, both from Ubaidullah bin Umar from Sa'id bin Abi Sa'id from him. Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan narrated it: Ubaidullah bin Umar told us: Sa'id bin Abi Sa'id informed me from his father from Abu Hurairah with it. It does not mention facing [the Qiblah], and he added in the chain: (from his father). Al-Bukhari also extracted it, as did Muslim, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi, Ahmad, and Al-Bayhaqi. At-Tirmidhi said: (It is more authentic than the narration of Ibn Numayr). Al-Hafiz inclined towards the correctness of both narrations, and that is the correct view, if Allah the Exalted wills. The Hadith has an authentic witness from the narration of Rifa'ah bin Rafi' Al-Badri similar to it, with the wording: (When you stand intending to pray, perform ablution and perfect your ablution, then face the Qiblah and say Takbir...) The Hadith. Al-Hakim extracted it, as did Al-Bukhari in (Juz' Al-Qira'ah) via the path of Dawood bin Qays, An-Nasa'i, Al-Bukhari, Al-Shafi'i in (Al-Umm), Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: from Muhammad bin Ajlan, and Abu Dawood from Muhammad bin Ajlan; the three of them from Ali bin Yahya bin Khallad bin Rafi' bin Malik Al-Ansari, who said: My father told me from a paternal uncle of his who was a Badri (veteran of Badr) - and Muhammad bin Amr said: from Rifa'ah bin Rafi' - with this story. This is an authentic chain on the condition of Al-Bukhari. It is in (Al-Musnad) via the path of Muhammad bin Amr from Ali bin Yahya from Rifa'ah, dropping Yahya bin Khallad from the chain. It is a narration of Al-Bayhaqi. Sharik bin Abi Namir followed him up in this way from Ali bin Yahya from his uncle Rifa'ah; At-Tahawi extracted it in (Sharh Al-Ma'ani). Al-Bayhaqi said: (The correct version is the narration of Dawood bin Qays and those who agreed with him). I say: Among those who agreed with him, other than those we mentioned, are: Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Abi Talha in Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and Al-Bukhari in his (Juz'), Ad-Darimi, Al-Hakim, and via his path Al-Bayhaqi and Ibn Hazm in (Al-Muhalla). Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs). I say: Muslim did not extract anything for Ali bin Yahya and his father, so it is on the condition of Al-Bukhari alone. Among them is Yahya bin Ali bin Khallad in Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and At-Tirmidhi

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: and he classified it as Hasan, as did At-Tahawi, Al-Hakim, and At-Tayalisi. And Muhammad bin Ishaq in Abu Dawood, and from him Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Hakim. All of these narrated it from Ali bin Yahya from his father from his uncle Rifa'ah. However, these last three do not have the mention of facing the Qiblah. It is hidden that this is not harmful after it has been established from the paths of the first group. In the Hadith of Abu Hurairah as well, and this Hadith of Rifa'ah, the narrators differed greatly regarding additions and omissions; so it is obligatory to track that and take the addition from the established path. We will point out the additions reported in it on every occasion and opportunity that presents itself to us, and perhaps we will gather all of that in one place and then refer to it when the matter requires. And Allah is the Granter of success. ([He said at its end: If you do this, your prayer is complete, and whatever you decrease from this, you have only decreased from your prayer]). This addition was narrated uniquely by Abu Dawood in a narration of his from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah, and its chain is authentic on the condition of Al-Bukhari. It is established in the Hadith of Rifa'ah bin Rafi'. This Hadith - like the verse - indicates the obligation of facing the Qiblah in prayer. Ash-Shawkani and others have reported the consensus of Muslims on that except in two cases which will be mentioned. Ash-Shawkani said: (The Hadawiyyah said: Facing the Qiblah is among the conditions for the validity of prayer. We have informed you previously that commands alone are not suitable for inferring conditionality

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: except on the view that the command for a thing is a prohibition of its opposite. However, here there is something that prevents conditionality, which is the report of the expedition that At-Tirmidhi, Ahmad, and At-Tabarani extracted from the Hadith of Amir bin Rabi'ah with the wording: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, on a dark night, and we did not know where the Qiblah was. So every man among us prayed in his own direction. When we reached morning, we mentioned that to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so it was revealed: {So wherever you turn, there is the Face of Allah} [Al-Baqarah / 115]. If facing [the Qiblah] were a condition, repetition would have been obligatory within the time and after it, because the absence of a condition effects non-existence [of the act's validity], even though the Hadawiyyah agree with us on the lack of obligation to repeat after the time has passed, which contradicts his saying: that facing is a condition. This Hadith, even if there is some criticism regarding it among the Hadith scholars, has witnesses that strengthen it). I say: Then he mentioned them, and they will come. Then he said: (In the Hadith of Mu'adh, there is an explicit statement that this was after finishing the prayer before the time had elapsed, which is more explicit in indicating conditionality. In it also is a refutation of the school of those who differentiated in the obligation of repetition between the remaining of time and its absence) (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) I say: More than one scholar has reported the consensus on the invalidity of the prayer of one who intentionally abandons facing the Kaaba, among them Ibn Hazm and Ibn Abd al-Barr Abu Umar, as the text of their words regarding that will come in the explanation of the following Hadith. If this consensus is correct, it is obligatory to resort to it, and it would not be contrary to the Hadith which Ash-Shawkani used as proof for the lack of conditionality. That is because it was reported in a context other than the point of dispute - I mean: regarding the unintentional [omission] - so it indicates the validity of his prayer. The mentioned consensus indicates its invalidity for the intentional one, so there is no disagreement and no contradiction. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, stated decisively in his (Ikhtiyarat) (pp. 27-28) in more than one issue regarding the invalidity of the prayer of one who does not face the Kaaba, and he inevitably means by it the intentional one; as for other than him, it is a place of consideration =

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (3 - And it is obligatory upon one who is viewing the Kaaba or has the status of a viewer to face its eye (essence), because (When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, entered the House, he supplicated in all its corners... when he came out, he prayed two Rak'ahs facing the front of the House (and in a narration: facing the face of the Kaaba) (and in another: at the door of the House) and said: This is the Qiblah [This is the Qiblah]). The Hadith is from the narration of Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with them both. We have abbreviated from it the sentence: (And he did not pray inside it), because it is established via the path of others from the Companions that he, upon him be peace, prayed inside it as previously explained just before (Rules of the Mosques). This Hadith was extracted by Al-Bukhari, Muslim - and the context is his - An-Nasa'i, and Ahmad from the path of Ibn Jurayj who said: I said to Ata: Did you hear Ibn Abbas say: You were only commanded to circumambulate and were not commanded to enter it? He said: He did not forbid entering it, but I heard him say: Usama informed me of it. The second narration with the addition is from the Hadith of Abdul-Malik bin Abi Sulayman who said: Ata told us with it similarly. An-Nasa'i and Ahmad extracted it
foot_note: 1. = Although I can hardly imagine a Muslim who knows the obligation of facing [the Qiblah] then abandons it intentionally, because one who intentionally abandons something usually abandons it due to the struggle and fighting the desires of the self involved, and there is nothing of that here. For the person praying has no escape from facing something, so what would push him and carry him to abandon facing the Kaaba while it is before him and he sees it? This is a matter I almost decisively claim is impossible to occur from a Muslim who knows the ruling. And Allah knows best.

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: and its chain is authentic on the condition of Muslim. As for the third narration, it is from the Hadith of Ibn Abbas as well: That Al-Fadl bin Abbas informed him that he entered the House with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not pray inside the House when he entered it, but when he came out and descended, he prayed two Rak'ahs at the door of the House. Ahmad extracted it: Abdur-Razzaq told us: Ibn Jurayj told us: Amr bin Dinar informed me that Ibn Abbas used to inform him with it. This is an authentic chain on the condition of the Six. In the chapter, there is a report from Ibn Umar also in Al-Bukhari and others via the path of Mujahid from him. Its wording has preceded in the place referred to previously. An-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in (Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab): (And his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (This is the Qiblah). Al-Khattabi said: Its meaning is: The matter of the Qiblah has settled on this House, so it will not be abrogated after today; so pray towards it forever, for it is your Qiblah. He said: It is possible that he taught them the Sunnah of the Imam's position, and that he stands facing its face, not its corners, even if prayer towards all its directions is valid. This is Al-Khattabi's speech. A third meaning is possible, which is: This Kaaba is the Sacred Mosque which you were commanded to face, not the whole Haram, nor Mecca, nor the Mosque which is around the Kaaba; rather it is the Kaaba itself only). Al-Hafiz said in (At-Talkhis) after mentioning this probability from An-Nawawi:

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (And it is a good, marvelous probability). As for the probability mentioned from Al-Khattabi, Sheikh Ali Al-Qari quoted it in (Al-Mirqah) from the statement of At-Tibi, and perhaps he took it from Al-Khattabi, then Al-Qari critiqued it by saying: (I say: This would only be complete in general if he had prayed an obligatory congregational prayer). It is a strong critique as you see. So nothing remains except the first meaning and the probability stated by An-Nawawi, which is what is apparent to us from the Hadith. And Allah knows best. More than one scholar has reported the agreement on the obligation of facing the eye (exact spot) of the Kaaba for the viewer. In (Tafsir Al-Qurtubi): (There is no disagreement among the scholars that the Kaaba is a Qiblah in every horizon, and they agreed that whoever witnesses it and sees it, facing it is obligatory upon him; and that if he abandons facing it while viewing it and knowing its direction, he has no prayer, and he must repeat everything he prayed. Abu Umar mentioned it). Ibn Hazm said: (There is no disagreement among anyone of the Ummah that if a person were in Mecca such that he is able to face the Kaaba in his prayer, but he turns his face intentionally away from it to parts of the Sacred Mosque from its outside or inside, then his prayer is invalid (1), and if he deems that lawful, he is a disbeliever. He said: As for the sick, the ignorant, the fearful, and the coerced, Allah the Exalted says: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity} [Al-Baqarah / 286]. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (If I command you with a command, perform of it what you are able))

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: The word of Ibn Hazm and Abu Umar bin Abd al-Barr agreed on reporting the consensus on the invalidity of the prayer of one who abandons facing the Kaaba intentionally. Discussion on that has preceded just before this Hadith which we were in the midst of discussing. (As for one who is not viewing it and does not know its location, it suffices him to face the direction in which it is, due to the saying of the Exalted: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity} and his saying, upon him be peace and blessings: (What is between the East and the West is a Qiblah). The Hadith is from the narration of Abu Hurairah and Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with them both. As for the first, At-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah extracted it from the path of Abu Ma'shar Najih from Muhammad bin Amr from Abu Salamah from him in a raised (Marfu') report. Abu Ma'shar is weak. At-Tirmidhi said: (Some people of knowledge have spoken about Abu Ma'shar regarding his memory). I say: But it is strengthened by the follow-up of others for him with another chain. At-Tirmidhi said: Al-Hasan bin Abi Bakr Al-Marwazi told us: Al-Mu'alla bin Al-Mansur told us: Abdullah bin Ja'far Al-Makhrami told us from Uthman bin Muhammad Al-Akhnas from Sa'id Al-Maqburi from Abu Hurairah in a raised report with it. He said: (A Good Authentic Hadith [Hasan Sahih]). Al-Bukhari said: (It is stronger than the Hadith of Abu Ma'shar and more authentic). I say: Its men are trustworthy except At-Tirmidhi's Sheikh: Al-Hasan bin Abi Bakr. It is like this in

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (As-Sunan), even in the copy corrected by Judge Ahmad Shakir, and it is a mistake. The correct [name] is: Al-Hasan bin Bakr, deleting the word (Abi). Likewise, it is in the books of narrators like (At-Tahdhib), (At-Taqrib), and (Al-Khulasah). He is Al-Hasan bin Bakr bin Abdur-Rahman Al-Marwazi Abu Ali, a resident of Mecca. Maslamah said: (Unknown), as in (At-Taqrib). He mentioned a group of trustworthy narrators who narrated from him, and perhaps due to that he said in (At-Taqrib): (He is truthful). And Allah knows best. In summary, the Hadith via these two paths is Hasan (Good), and it is Sahih (Authentic) due to its witness, which is the Hadith of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both. It also has two paths: First: From Yazid bin Harun: Muhammad bin Abdur-Rahman bin Al-Mujabbir informed us from Nafi' from him in a raised report with it. Ad-Daraqutni and Al-Hakim extracted it, and from him Al-Bayhaqi. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic, and Ibn Mujabbir is trustworthy). Adh-Dhahabi agreed with him, which is strange from him, for he listed this Ibn Mujabbir in (Al-Mizan) and quoted the statements of the Imams regarding his weakening, and he did not recount even a single statement regarding his authentication. Al-Hafiz affirmed him in

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (Al-Lisan). That indicates that he is weak by agreement, and that Al-Hakim's authentication of him is of no account. However, Ubaidullah bin Umar followed him up from Nafi' with it. Ad-Daraqutni extracted it, and from him Ad-Diya Al-Maqdisi in (Al-Mukhtarah), and Al-Hakim, and from him Al-Bayhaqi from the path of Abu Yusuf Ya'qub bin Yusuf Al-Wasiti: Shu'aib bin Ayyub told us: Abdullah bin Numayr told us from Ubaidullah bin Umar with it. Al-Hakim said: (Authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs, for Shu'aib bin Ayyub is trustworthy and he has connected it). Adh-Dhahabi agreed with him as well. I say: But neither of the two Sheikhs extracted anything for Shu'aib; rather, he is from the men of Abu Dawood only, and he is truthful but obfuscates (Mudallis), as in (At-Taqrib). He has explicitly stated narration [using 'Haddathana'] as you see, so the chain is authentic if the narrator from him, Ya'qub bin Yusuf Al-Wasiti, is trustworthy, for I did not find a mention for him in the books of narrators I have. Al-Bayhaqi said after citing it from the two paths: (Ibn Mujabbir was unique in the first, and Ya'qub bin Yusuf Al-Khallal was unique in the second. The famous version is the narration of the group: Hammad bin Salamah, Za'idah bin Qudamah, Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan and others from Ubaidullah from Nafi' from Ibn Umar from Umar as his statement. He said: And it was narrated from Abu Hurairah in a raised report. Yahya bin Abi Kathir narrated from Abu Qilabah from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. I say: So this is another Mursal witness

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: Then Al-Bayhaqi said: (The intended meaning - and Allah knows best - is the people of Medina and those whose Qiblah is on an azimuth of the people of Medina between the East and the West. That applies to those in the North and the South. As for those in the East and the West, their Qiblah is between the North and the South). As-San'ani said in (Subul As-Salam): (The Hadith is evidence that the obligation is facing the direction, not the eye (exact spot), regarding the one for whom the eye is impossible [to see]. A group of scholars went to this due to this Hadith). I say: And upon this are our scholars, the Hanafis. It says in (Al-Majmu'): (At-Tirmidhi recounted it from Umar bin Al-Khattab, Ali bin Abi Talib, Ibn Abbas, Ibn Umar, and Ibn Al-Mubarak). Al-Qurtubi reported in his (Tafsir) the consensus of the scholars on that, but there is a consideration in that, for An-Nawawi mentioned that the correct view according to the Shafi'is is that hitting the eye of the Kaaba is obligatory. He said: (And some Malikis said it, as well as a narration from Ahmad). I say: This contradicts what is reported from the Companions and this Hadith. Then As-San'ani said:
foot_note: 1. (1) Abu At-Tayyib and others also reported it as in (Al-Majmu') (3/ 207). From such reporting, you learn the leniency of some scholars in claiming consensus in issues where there is disagreement, like this issue.

book_title: The Good Fruit in the Jurisprudence of the Sunnah and the Book
text: (And the mode of using it as evidence for that is that the meaning is that between the two directions is a Qiblah for the non-viewer and those in his status, because for the viewer, his Qiblah is not confined between the two directions of East and West; rather, it is in all directions in his regard, equally, whenever he faces the eye or part of it). The erudite scholar Abu At-Tayyib Siddiq Hasan said in (Ar-Rawdah An-Nadiyyah) the text of which is: (I say: Facing the Qiblah is among the necessities of religion. So whoever can face the Qiblah with verification, that is what is obligatory upon him, like the resident around it who views it without traversing a distance or enduring hardship. Whoever is not like that, his obligation is facing the direction. The intended meaning of that direction is not the Kaaba specifically; rather, the intended meaning is what he, peace and blessings be upon him, guided to regarding being between the East and the West is a Qiblah. So whoever is in the directions of Yemen and knows the direction of the East and the direction of the West turns between the two directions, for that direction is the Qiblah. Likewise, whoever is in the direction of Sham (Levant) turns between the two directions without exhausting the self in estimating the directions, for that... This is the last of what the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, wrote of the book (Ath-Thamar Al-Mustatab)] And praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds
